27934886.pub_title: Gene is essential for development and functional integrity of the subthalamic nucleus.
27934886.pub_abstract: Inactivation of transcription factor Gene in Species results in neonatal mortality of unknown cause. Here, we report that ablation of Gene causes impaired development and loss of the subthalamic nucleus (STN). Functional deficits in the STN have been implicated in the etiology of Disease and Disease. We show that neuronal ablation by Gene-Cre-mediated Gene deletion is sufficient to induce Disease in Species. Transcriptome profiling of STN neurons in conditional Gene knockout Species revealed changes in gene expression reminiscent of those in Disease. We identified Gene, a transcriptional co-activator that is implicated in Disease, as a Gene target. These findings were substantiated by the observation of Gene-dependent demise of STN neurons in conditional models of Gene mutant Species. Finally, we show that the spontaneous firing activity of Gene-deficient STN neurons is profoundly impaired. Our data reveal so far elusive roles of Gene in the development and maintenance of STN function.

23595900.pub_title: Effects of Gene on DNA methylation dynamics during primordial germ cell development in Species.
23595900.pub_abstract: DNA methylation is a central epigenetic event that regulates cellular differentiation, reprogramming, and pathogenesis. Genomewide DNA demethylation occurs in preimplantation embryos and in embryonic germ cell precursors called primordial germ cells (PGCs). We previously showed that Gene, also known as Gene and Gene, protects the maternal genome from Gene (Gene)-mediated conversion of Chemical (5mC) to Chemical (Chemical) in zygotes. Here, we demonstrated that retrotransposon genes, such as long interspersed nuclear element-1 (Line-1) and intracisternal A particle (Gene), showed higher 5mC levels in Gene-null PGCs. In contrast, oxidative Chemical sequence analysis revealed that the amounts of Chemical in Line-1 and Gene were slightly reduced in the Gene-deficient PGCs. From our findings, we propose that Gene is involved in the Tet-mediated active demethylation process during reprogramming of PGCs.

24269712.pub_title: Redundancy in regulation of chondrogenesis in Gene/Gene-deficient Species.
24269712.pub_abstract: Recent in vitro analysis of Gene/Gene-deficient (Gene(-/-)) mesenchymal stem cells revealed altered chondrogenic differentiation, characterised by enhanced proliferation and delayed differentiation. However, adult Gene(-/-) Species develop normally and show only ultrastructural defects of the cartilage but no major abnormalities. We therefore focused, in this study, on chondrogenesis in vivo in Gene(-/-) Species embryos to reveal potential molecular changes during embryogenesis and possible redundant mechanisms, which explain the almost normal phenotype despite Gene/Gene loss. In situ hybridisation analysis revealed larger expression areas of Gene and Gene positive, proliferating chondrocytes at day 15.5 and 16.5 of embryogenesis in Gene(-/-) Species. The initially diminished zone of Gene-expressing Disease chondrocytes at day 15.5 was compensated at day 16.5 in Gene(-/-) embryos. Supported by in vitro studies using mesenchymal stem cells, we discovered that chondrogenesis in Gene(-/-) Species is modified by enhanced Gene, Gene and Gene expression. Finally, we identified reduced Gene and CRE activity, analysed by reporter gene- and electrophoretic mobility shift assays, important for redundancy mechanism which rescued delayed Disease differentiation and allows normal development of Gene(-/-) Species. In summary, as observed in other knockout models of molecules important for cartilage development and differentiation, viability and functional integrity is reached by remarkable molecular redundancy in Gene/Gene knockout Species.

24361185.pub_title: Gene is regulated by Gene and restricted to the myogenic lineage.
24361185.pub_abstract: BTB-BACK-Kelch (BBK) proteins play broad roles in cellular and molecular regulation. The role of BBK proteins in the skeletal muscle lineage and myogenesis remains an active area of research. Herein, we report a novel BBK gene, Gene, which we discovered and found to be restricted to the myogenic lineage. We observed that Gene was absent in proliferating myoblasts and upregulated upon myogenic differentiation. In situ hybridization analysis revealed that Gene was restricted to the skeletal muscle lineage during embryogenesis. We identified a conserved 1.2kb upstream region, which directs reporter expression to the developing skeletal muscle lineage. Transcriptional and mutagenesis assays demonstrated that the E-box motifs contribute to the Gene promoter activity. We have also demonstrated the in vivo and in vitro binding between MRFs and the E-box motif in the 1.2kb promoter of the Gene gene. Our studies have revealed that the Gene family can transactivate the 1.2kb-luc reporter through the E-box motifs. In addition, we have shown that Gene can recruit the Gene complex in vivo. Using shRNA knockdown, our study has revealed that Gene plays an important role in the myogenic differentiation. In summary, we have demonstrated that Gene is the direct downstream target gene of the Gene family and regulates myogenic differentiation. Our results further support the notion that Gene may serve as an adapter of Cul3 during myogenic differentiation.

25668066.pub_title: Combined loss of the Gene and Gene transcription factors in male Species disrupts testicular development and confers adrenal-like function in the testes.
25668066.pub_abstract: The roles of the Gene and Gene transcription factors in testis development were examined by simultaneously ablating Gene and Gene with Sf1Cre (Nr5a1Cre). The deletion of both genes resulted in a striking testicular phenotype. Embryonic Sf1Cre; Gene(flox/flox) Gene(flox/flox) (conditional double mutant) testes were smaller than control organs and contained irregular testis cords and fewer gonocytes. Gene expression analysis revealed significant down-regulation of Gene and Gene. Surprisingly, Gene expression was strongly up-regulated and remained high beyond postnatal day 7, when it is normally extinguished. Neither Gene nor Gene was detected in the Sertoli cells of the mutant postnatal testes. Furthermore, the expression of the steroidogenic genes Star, Gene, Gene, and Gene was low throughout embryogenesis. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a prominent reduction in cytochrome P450 side-chain cleavage enzyme (Gene)- and Chemical dehydrogenase-positive (3betaHSD) cells, with few 17alpha-hydroxylase/17,20 lyase-positive (Gene) cells present. In contrast, in postnatal Sf1Cre; Gene(flox/flox) Gene(flox/flox) testes, the expression of the steroidogenic markers Star, Gene, and Gene was increased, but a dramatic down-regulation of Gene, which is required for Chemical synthesis, was observed. The genes encoding adrenal enzymes Gene, Gene, Gene, and Mcr2 were strongly up-regulated, and clusters containing numerous CYP21A2-positive cells were localized in the interstitium. These data suggest a lack of testis functionality, with a loss of normal steroidogenic testis function, concomitant with an expansion of the adrenal-like cell population in postnatal conditional double mutant testes. Sf1Cre; Gene(flox/flox) Gene(flox/flox) animals of both sexes lack adrenal glands; however, despite this deficiency, males are viable in contrast to the females of the same genotype, which die shortly after birth.

26755743.pub_title: Gene is essential for endothelial cell glycosylation and vascular development.
26755743.pub_abstract: Gene is a transmembrane protein identified as a Gene-interacting protein and recently has been shown to be a subunit required for Gene (Gene) activity. To investigate the integrated role of Gene in vascular development, we have characterized endothelial-specific Gene knockout embryos. Here, we show that endothelial-specific Gene knockout results in Disease due to vascular development defects in yolk sac and embryo proper. Loss of Gene in endothelial cells reduces proliferation and promotes apoptosis of the cells largely through defects in the glycosylation of key endothelial proteins including Gene, Gene, and Gene, and Disease can be rescued by treatment with the end product of Gene activity, Chemical. Moreover, Gene functions in endothelial cells during embryogenesis are Gene independent. These data uniquely show the importance of Gene and protein glycosylation during vascular development.

26110920.pub_title: Chemical Accumulators Gene and Gene in Species Chemical Neurons: Implications for Gene Mediated Excitation.
26110920.pub_abstract: A developmental "switch" in Chemical transporters occurs in most neurons resulting in Gene mediated hyperpolarization in the adult. However, several neuronal cell subtypes maintain primarily depolarizing responses to Gene receptor activation. Among this group are Gene (Chemical) neurons, which control puberty and reproduction. Gene is the primary Chemical accumulator in neurons, expressed at high levels early in development and contributes to depolarization after Gene receptor activation. In contrast, Gene is the primary Chemical extruder in neurons, expressed at high levels in the adult and contributes to hyperpolarization after Gene receptor activation. Anion exchangers (AEs) are also potential modulators of responses to Gene activation since they accumulate Chemical and extrude Chemical. To evaluate the mechanism(s) underlying Gene mediated depolarization, Chemical neurons were analyzed for 1) expression of Chemical transporters and AEs in embryonic, pre-pubertal, and adult Species 2) responses to Gene receptor activation in Gene-/- Species and 3) function of AEs in these responses. At all ages, Chemical neurons were immunopositive for Gene and Gene but not Gene or Gene. Using explants, Chemical imaging and gramicidin perforated patch clamp techniques we found that Chemical neurons from Gene-/- Species retained relatively normal responses to the Gene agonist Chemical. However, acute pharmacological inhibition of Gene with bumetanide eliminated the depolarization/Chemical response to Chemical in 40% of Chemical neurons from WT Species. In the remaining Chemical neurons, Chemical- mediated mechanisms accounted for the remaining Chemical responses to Chemical. Collectively these data reveal mechanisms responsible for maintaining depolarizing Gene mediated transmission in Chemical neurons.

22886731.pub_title: Expression of nuclear factor one A and -B in the olfactory bulb.
22886731.pub_abstract: The nuclear factor one (Gene) family of transcription factors consists of four members in vertebrates, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene, which share a highly conserved Chemical-terminal DNA-binding domain. Gene genes are widely expressed in the developing Species brain, and Species mutants lacking Gene, Gene, or Gene exhibit Disease in several areas, including the cortex, hippocampus, pons, and cerebellum. Here we analyzed the expression of Gene and Gene in the developing and adult olfactory bulb (Disease), rostral migratory stream (RMS), and subventricular zone (SVZ). We found that Gene and Gene are expressed within these regions during Disease and postnatal development and in the adult. Immunohistochemical analysis using cell-type-specific markers revealed that migrating neuroblasts in the adult brain express Gene transcription factors, as do astrocytes within the RMS and progenitor cells within the SVZ. Moreover, astrocytes within the Disease express Gene, whereas mitral cells within the Disease express Gene. Taken together these data show that Gene and Gene are expressed in both the developing and the adult Disease and in the RMS and SVZ, indicative of a regulatory role for these transcription factors in the development of this facet of the olfactory system.

22434869.pub_title: Dermal Gene activity in response to epidermal Wnt ligands is required for fibroblast proliferation and hair follicle initiation.
22434869.pub_abstract: Dermal fibroblasts are required for structural integrity of the skin and for hair follicle development. Uniform Wnt signaling activity is present in dermal fibroblast precursors preceding hair follicle initiation, but the functional requirement of dermal Wnt signaling at early stages of skin differentiation and patterning remains largely uncharacterized. We show in Species that epidermal Wnt ligands are required for uniform dermal Wnt signaling/Gene activity and regulate fibroblast cell proliferation and initiation of hair follicle placodes. In the absence of dermal Wnt signaling/Gene activity, patterned upregulation of epidermal Gene activity and Gene expression are absent. Conversely, forced activation of Gene signaling leads to the formation of thickened dermis, enlarged epidermal placodes and dermal condensates that result in prematurely differentiated enlarged hair follicles. These data reveal functional roles for dermal Wnt signaling/Gene in fibroblast proliferation and in the epidermal hair follicle initiation program.

26822476.pub_title: Common arterial trunk and ventricular non-compaction in Gene knockout Species indicate a crucial role of Gene in cardiac development.
26822476.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is important for development of the Disease and brain in both Species and Species. Although a role in cardiovascular development can be expected, the hearts ofLrp2knockout (KO) Species have not yet been investigated. We studied the cardiovascular development ofLrp2KO Species between embryonic day 10.5 (E10.5) and E15.5, applying morphometry and immunohistochemistry, using antibodies against Gene (neural crest cells), Gene (second heart field), Gene (epicardium derived cells), Chemical (myocardium) and Gene. TheLrp2KO Species display a range of severe Disease, including Disease, common arterial trunk (persistent truncus arteriosus) with Disease, Disease, overriding of the tricuspid valve and marked thinning of the Disease. Both the neural crest cells and second heart field, which are essential for the lengthening and growth of the right ventricular outflow tract, are abnormally positioned in theLrp2KO. This explains the absence of the aorto-pulmonary septum, which leads to common arterial trunk and Disease. Severe blebbing of the epicardial cells covering the ventricles is seen. Epithelial-mesenchymal transition does occur; however, there are fewer Gene-positive epicardium-derived cells in the ventricular wall as compared to normal, coinciding with the myocardial thinning and deep intertrabecular spaces. Gene plays a crucial role in cardiovascular development in Species. This corroborates findings of Disease in Species withLRP2mutations. Future studies should reveal the underlying signaling mechanisms in which Gene is involved during cardiogenesis.

22972987.pub_title: Gene kinase signaling regulates embryonic angiogenesis by modulating endothelial cell survival and migration.
22972987.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a mediator of various cytokine signaling pathways. Germline deficiency of Gene causes Disease, including dilated blood vessels at midgestation. However, the mechanisms by which Gene regulates vessel formation have not been elucidated. Gene binding proteins 1 and 2 (TAB1 and TAB2) are activators of Gene, but their roles in embryonic Gene signaling have not been determined. In the present study, we characterized Species embryos harboring endothelial-specific deletions of Gene, Tab1, or Tab2 and found that endothelial Gene and TAB2, but not TAB1, were critically involved in vascular formation. Gene deficiency in endothelial cells caused increased cell death and vessel regression at embryonic day 10.5 (E10.5). Deletion of Gene signaling largely rescued endothelial cell death in Gene-deficient embryos at E10.5. However, Disease in both Gene and Gene signaling still exhibited dilated capillary networks at E12.5. TAB2 deficiency caused reduced Gene activity, resulting in abnormal capillary blood vessels, similar to the compound deficiency of Gene and Gene signaling. Ablation of either Gene or TAB2 impaired cell migration and tube formation. Our results show that endothelial Gene signaling is important for 2 biologic processes in angiogenesis: inhibiting Gene-dependent endothelial cell death and promoting Gene-independent angiogenic cell migration.

23041177.pub_title: Roles of Gene during formation and patterning of the Species inner ear.
23041177.pub_abstract: Fgf and Gene signalling have been shown to be required for formation of the otic placode in vertebrates. Whereas several Fgfs including Gene, Gene and Gene have been shown to participate during early placode induction, Gene signalling is required for specification and maintenance of the otic placode, and dorsal patterning of the otic vesicle. However, the requirement for specific members of the Gene gene family for otic placode and vesicle formation and their potential interaction with Fgf signalling has been poorly defined. Due to its spatiotemporal expression during placode formation in the hindbrain Gene has been postulated as a potential candidate for its specification. Here we have examined the role of Gene during formation of the otic placode and vesicle in Species embryos. Gene expression depends on the presence of Gene indicating a serial regulation between Fgf and Gene signalling during otic placode induction and specification. Gene by itself however is neither essential for placode specification nor redundantly required together with Fgfs for otic placode and vesicle formation. Interestingly however, Gene and Gene are redundantly required for expression of Gene in the hindbrain indicating additional reciprocal interactions between Fgf and Gene signalling. Further reduction of Gene signalling by the inactivation of Gene in a Gene mutant background revealed a redundant requirement for both genes during morphogenesis of the dorsal portion of the otic vesicle.

25800779.pub_title: The long noncoding RNA Pnky regulates neuronal differentiation of embryonic and postnatal neural stem cells.
25800779.pub_abstract: While thousands of long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) have been identified, few lncRNAs that control neural stem cell (NSC) behavior are known. Here, we identify Pinky (Pnky) as a neural-specific lncRNA that regulates neurogenesis from NSCs in the embryonic and postnatal brain. In postnatal NSCs, Pnky knockdown potentiates neuronal lineage commitment and expands the transit-amplifying cell population, increasing neuron production several-fold. Pnky is evolutionarily conserved and expressed in NSCs of the developing Species brain. In the embryonic Species cortex, Pnky knockdown increases neuronal differentiation and depletes the NSC population. Pnky interacts with the splicing regulator Gene, and Gene knockdown also enhances neurogenesis. In NSCs, Pnky and Gene regulate the expression and alternative splicing of a core set of transcripts that relates to the cellular phenotype. These data thus unveil Pnky as a conserved lncRNA that interacts with a key RNA processing factor and regulates neurogenesis from embryonic and postnatal NSC populations.

26076477.pub_title: Podocyte-Specific Deletion of Species Gene Does Not Impair Podocyte Development, Function or Stress Response.
26076477.pub_abstract: The Gene (Gene) is a member of the immunoglobulin protein superfamily, present in various epithelial cells including glomerular epithelial cells. Beside its known function as a virus receptor, it also constitutes an integral part of cell-junctions. Previous studies in the Species pronephros postulated a potential role of Gene for the terminal differentiation of glomerular podocytes and correct patterning of the elaborated foot process architecture. However, due to early Disease of constitutive Gene knockout Species, Species data on kidney epithelial cells have been lacking. Interestingly, Gene is robustly expressed during podocyte development and in adulthood in response to Disease. We therefore used a conditional transgenic approach to elucidate the function of Gene for podocyte development and stress response. Surprisingly, we could not discern a developmental phenotype in podocyte specific Gene knock-out Species. In addition, despite a significant up regulation of Gene during toxic, genetic and immunologic podocyte injury, we could not detect any impact of Gene on these injury models. Thus these data indicate that in contrast to lower vertebrate models, Species podocytes have acquired molecular programs to compensate for the loss of Gene.

25922525.pub_title: Gene promotes the proliferative capacity of neural progenitor cells in brain development.
25922525.pub_abstract: Neural progenitor cells (NPCs) have distinct proliferation capacities at different stages of brain development. Gene is an RNA-binding protein with two homologs in Species: Gene and Gene. Here we show that Gene/b are enriched in early NPCs and their expression declines during neural differentiation. Gene single-knockout Species show reduced NPC proliferation, enhanced cell cycle exit and a smaller brain, whereas Species lacking both Gene alleles and one Gene allele display similar but more severe phenotypes. Ectopic expression of Gene in Species results in increased NPC proliferation, NPC numbers and brain size. Mechanistically, Gene physically and functionally interacts with Gene (Gene) and regulates Gene-Gene signaling. The function of Gene/b in NPCs could be attributed, at least in part, to the regulation of their mRNA targets that encode Gene and Gene. Thus, Gene and Gene have overlapping functions in temporally regulating NPC proliferation during early brain development.

25219497.pub_title: A global regulatory mechanism for activating an exon network required for neurogenesis.
25219497.pub_abstract: The vertebrate and neural-specific Chemical/Chemical (SR)-related protein Gene/Gene regulates an extensive program of alternative splicing with critical roles in nervous system development. However, the mechanism by which Gene controls its target exons is poorly understood. We demonstrate that Gene-dependent neural exons are associated with a unique configuration of intronic cis-elements that promote rapid switch-like regulation during neurogenesis. A key feature of this configuration is the insertion of specialized intronic enhancers between Chemical tracts and acceptor sites that bind Gene to potently activate exon inclusion in neural cells while weakening 3' splice site recognition and contributing to exon skipping in nonneural cells. Gene further operates by forming multiple interactions with early spliceosome components bound proximal to 3' splice sites. These multifaceted interactions achieve dominance over neural exon silencing mediated by the splicing regulator Gene. The results thus illuminate a widespread mechanism by which a critical neural exon network is activated during neurogenesis.

24012369.pub_title: Architectural niche organization by Gene is linked to hair follicle stem cell function.
24012369.pub_abstract: In adult skin, self-renewing, undifferentiated hair follicle stem cells (HF-SCs) reside within a specialized niche, where they spend prolonged times as a single layer of polarized, quiescent epithelial cells. When sufficient activating signals accumulate, HF-SCs become mobilized to fuel tissue regeneration and hair growth. Here, we show that architectural organization of the HF-SC niche by transcription factor Gene plays a critical role in HF-SC behavior. Using genome-wide chromatin and transcriptional profiling of HF-SCs in vivo, we show that Gene directly transactivates genes that orchestrate cytoskeletal dynamics and adhesion. Conditional ablation of Gene results in gross cellular disorganization and HF-SC polarization within the niche. Gene loss leads to a failure to maintain HF-SC quiescence and hair anchoring, as well as progressive transformation of the niche into a sebaceous gland. These findings suggest that niche organization underlies the requirement for Gene in hair follicle structure and function.

22056786.pub_title: ETS-dependent regulation of a distal Gene cardiac enhancer.
22056786.pub_abstract: The developing heart contains an inner tube of specialized endothelium known as endocardium, which performs multiple essential functions. In spite of the essential role of the endocardium in heart development and function, the transcriptional pathways that regulate its development remain largely undefined. Gene is a zinc finger transcription factor that is expressed in multiple cardiovascular lineages and is required for endocardial cushion development and Disease, but the transcriptional pathways upstream of Gene in the endocardium and its derivatives in the endocardial cushions are unknown. Here, we describe a distal enhancer from the Species Gene gene that is briefly active in multiple cardiac lineages early in cardiac development but restricts to the endocardium where it remains active through cardiogenesis. The activity of this Gene cardiac enhancer in transgenic embryos and in cultured aortic endothelial cells is dependent on four ETS sites. To identify which ETS transcription factors might be involved in Gene regulation via the ETS sites in the enhancer, we determined the expression profile of 24 distinct ETS factors in embryonic Species hearts. Among multiple ETS transcripts present, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene were the most abundant in the early Disease. We found that Gene, Gene, and Gene were strongly expressed in the heart at embryonic day 8.5 and that Gene and Gene bound to the endogenous Gene enhancer in cultured endothelial cells. Thus, these studies define the ETS expression profile in the early Disease and identify an ETS-dependent enhancer from the Gene locus.

23553930.pub_title: Essential role of Gene for the establishment and maintenance of the germ cell line.
23553930.pub_abstract: Gene is a pluripotency-conferring gene expressed in primordial germ cells (PGCs) and postnatal oocytes, but the role it plays during germ cell development and early embryogenesis is unknown. Since Gene ablation causes early Disease shortly after blastocyst implantation, we generated Species bearing Gene-conditional deletion in germ cells at different stages of their development through the Cre/loxP recombination system. Embryos lacking Gene in PGCs show a dramatic decrease of germ cell numbers at the time of their specification. At later stages, we found that Gene is strictly required for Gene proliferation. On the contrary, Gene deletion in meiotic oocytes does not impair postnatal oogenesis and early embryogenesis, indicating that it is not essential for oocyte maturation or for zygotic development. We also show that Gene regulates Kit expression in PGCs and binds to discrete transcriptional regulatory sequences of this gene, which is known to be important for PGCs survival and proliferation. Gene also stimulates the expression of Gene, which is required for normal development of fetal germ cells, and Gene, a potential regulator of Gene pluripotency.

25681586.pub_title: Cardiac endothelial cells express Disease-1: Gene expression in the developing, adult and Disease.
25681586.pub_abstract: Disease is the leading cause of Disease worldwide. Due to their limited regenerative capacity lost cardiomyocytes are replaced by a non-contractile fibrotic scar tissue. The epicardial layer of the heart provides cardiac progenitor cells during development. Because this layer regains embryonic characteristics in the adult heart after Disease, it could serve as a promising source for resident cardiac progenitor cells. Disease (Gene) is associated with the activation and reactivation of the epicardium and therefore potentially important for the differentiation and regenerative capacity of the epicardium. To gain more insight into the regulation of Gene we examined the spatiotemporal expression pattern of Gene during Species development and after Disease. Interestingly, we found that Gene is expressed in the majority of the cardiac endothelial cells within the myocardial ventricular layer of the developing heart from E12.5 onwards. In the adult heart only a subset of coronary endothelial cells remains positive for Gene. After Disease Gene is temporally upregulated in the endothelial cells of the Disease area and the border zone of the heart. In vitro experiments show that endothelial Gene expression can be induced by Disease. We show that Gene is associated with endothelial cell proliferation: Gene expression is higher in proliferating endothelial cells, Gene knockdown inhibits the proliferation of endothelial cells, and Gene regulates Gene expression. Finally, endothelial cells lacking Gene are not capable to establish a proper vascular network in vitro. Together, these results suggest a possible role for Gene in cardiac vessel formation in development and disease.

24338367.pub_title: The extracellular matrix glycoprotein Gene regulates neurogenesis during development and in the adult dentate gyrus of Species.
24338367.pub_abstract: Abnormal generation of inhibitory neurons that synthesize Chemical (GABAergic) is characteristic of Disease. We provide evidence that the extracellular matrix molecule Gene (Gene) - which is predominantly expressed by a subpopulation of interneurons - plays a role in the generation of GABAergic and granule neurons in the Species dentate gyrus by regulating fate determination of neural stem or progenitor cells (NSCs). During development, absence of Gene in constitutively Gene-deficient (Gene(-/-)) Species results in increased numbers of dentate gyrus GABAergic neurons, decreased expression of its receptor beta1 integrin, increased activation of Gene and increased expression of the GABAergic specification gene Gene. Postnatally, increased GABAergic input to adult hippocampal NSCs in Gene(-/-) Species is associated not only with increased numbers of GABAergic and, particularly, Gene-immunoreactive neurons, as seen during development, but also with increased numbers of granule neurons, thus contributing to the increased differentiation of NSCs into granule cells. These findings indicate the importance of Gene in the regulation of hippocampal neurogenesis and suggest that Gene acts through distinct direct and indirect mechanisms during development and in the adult.

26964679.pub_title: Expression and localization of Inter-alpha Inhibitors in rodent brain.
26964679.pub_abstract: Inter-alpha Inhibitor Proteins (IAIPs) are a family of related Chemical protease inhibitors. IAIPs are important components of the systemic innate immune system. We have identified endogenous IAIPs in the central nervous system (CNS) of Species during development and shown that treatment with IAIPs reduces neuronal cell death and improves behavioral outcomes in neonatal Species after Disease. The presence of IAIPs in CNS along with their exogenous neuroprotective properties suggests that endogenous IAIPs could be part of the innate immune system in CNS. The purpose of this study was to characterize expression and localization of IAIPs in CNS. We examined cellular expressions of IAIPs in vitro in cultured cortical Species neurons, in cultured Species neurons, microglia, and astrocytes, and in vivo on brain sections by immunohistochemistry from embryonic (E) day 18 Species and postnatal (P) day 10 Species. Cultured cortical Species neurons expressed the light chain gene Gene and heavy chain genes Gene mRNA transcripts and IAIP proteins. IAIP proteins were detected by immunohistochemistry in cultured cells as well as brain sections from E18 Species and P10 Species. Immunoreactivity was found in neurons, microglia, astrocytes and Disease in multiple brain regions including cortex and hippocampus, as well as within both the Disease and choroid plexus. Our findings suggest that IAIPs are endogenous proteins expressed in a wide variety of cell types and regions both in vitro and in vivo in rodent CNS. We speculate that endogenous IAIPs may represent endogenous neuroprotective immunomodulatory proteins within the CNS.

23175628.pub_title: Rho signalling restriction by the Gene Gene integrates growth and morphogenesis in the pancreas.
23175628.pub_abstract: The development of functional organ architecture relies on coordinated morphogenesis and growth. In the developing pancreas, the branching epithelium is organised in discrete domains, delineating one specific domain of progenitor cells at the tip of the branches. The molecular mechanisms underlying the coordinated action of branching and proliferation in organ formation are largely unknown. Here, we identify the Gene protein Gene as an essential regulator of pancreas tissue architecture in the Species embryo. Conditional ablation of Gene expression in the pancreas disrupts epithelial morphogenesis and tip-domain organisation, resulting in hampered proliferation of tip progenitors and subsequent Disease. Gene acts by regulating Rho signalling spatially and temporally during pancreas development. Our findings provide new insights into the mechanisms that shape pancreatic epithelium to create a mature organ and establish a functional link between Rho-mediated control of epithelial remodelling and organ size determination, involving reciprocal interaction of actin-MAL/Gene and MAPK signalling pathways.

26062937.pub_title: The intracellular domains of Gene and Gene are functionally equivalent during development and Disease.
26062937.pub_abstract: Although Gene and Gene are closely related paralogs and function through the same canonical signaling pathway, they contribute to different outcomes in some cell and disease contexts. To understand the basis for these differences, we examined in detail Species in which the Notch intracellular domains (N1ICD and N2ICD) were swapped. Our data indicate that strength (defined here as the ultimate number of intracellular domain molecules reaching the nucleus, integrating ligand-mediated release and nuclear translocation) and duration (half-life of NICD-RBPjk-MAML-DNA complexes, integrating cooperativity and stability dependent on shared sequence elements) are the factors that underlie many of the differences between Gene and Gene in all the contexts we examined, including T-cell development, skin differentiation and Disease, the inner ear, the lung and the retina. We were able to show that phenotypes in the heart, endothelium, and marginal zone B cells are attributed to Disease but not to intracellular domain composition. Tissue-specific differences in NICD stability were most likely caused by alternative scissile bond choices by tissue-specific gamma-secretase complexes following the intracellular domain swap. Reinterpretation of clinical findings based on our analyses suggests that differences in outcome segregating with Gene or Gene are likely to reflect outcomes dependent on the overall strength of Gene signals.

24576537.pub_title: Gene promotes male germ cell differentiation by suppressing Gene-dependent meiotic and Gene-independent mitotic pathways.
24576537.pub_abstract: Germ cell sex is defined by factors derived from somatic cells. Gene is known to be a male sex-promoting factor that inactivates Chemical (RA) in somatic cells. In Gene-null XY gonads, germ cells are exposed to a higher level of RA than in normal XY gonads and this activates Gene to induce meiosis while male-specific gene expression is suppressed. However, it is unknown whether meiotic entry by an elevated level of RA is responsible for the suppression of male-type gene expression. To address this question, we have generated Gene/Gene double knockout (dKO) embryos. We successfully suppressed the induction of meiosis in Gene-null XY germ cells by removing the Gene gene. Concomitantly, we found that the male genetic program represented by the expression of Gene and Gene was totally rescued in about half of dKO germ cells, indicating that meiotic entry causes the suppression of male differentiation. However, half of the germ cells still failed to enter the appropriate male pathway in the dKO condition. Using microarray analyses together with immunohistochemistry, we found that Gene expression was accompanied by mitotic activation, but was canceled by inhibition of the RA signaling pathway. Taken together, we conclude that inhibition of RA is one of the essential factors to promote male germ cell differentiation, and that Gene suppresses two distinct genetic programs induced by RA: a Gene-dependent meiotic pathway, and a Gene-independent mitotic pathway.

24220334.pub_title: Dynamic expression pattern of Gene and its relationship with CpG methylation in the promoter during Species embryo development.
24220334.pub_abstract: Species Gene is located on chromosome 13 and serves many functions in important physiological processes involving Chemical. In this study, imprinting analysis indicated that Gene exhibits a dynamic and specific allelic expression pattern during embryo development. This showed paternal-origin sex bias in embryonic day 9.5 (E9.5) whole embryos and placenta, and biallelic expression in the major embryonic organs and placenta at E15.5. In situ hybridization determined the spatiotemporal expression pattern of Gene in Species embryos from the mid- to late-embryonic stages. This demonstrated that Gene was widely expressed in the neural tissues, including the forebrain, midbrain, hindbrain, and neural tube, at the mid-embryonic stage. By the late-embryonic stage, Gene was extensively detected throughout the developing organism, including in the liver, brain, lung, kidney, and tongue. In addition, methylation analyses indicated that tissue-specific CpG methylation of the Gene promoter was correlated with Gene mRNA expression in major E15.5 tissues. Furthermore, stage-specific CpG methylation of the Gene promoter was associated with gene expression in the liver at three developmental stages. Our results suggest that Gene might serve specific biological functions in regulating the development process of the Species embryo, and that CpG methylation of the Gene promoter may play an important role in regulating Gene at a transcriptional level.

27802172.pub_title: Interplay between Gene and Gene regulates hemogenic endothelial fate in the yolk sac.
27802172.pub_abstract: Endothelial to hematopoietic transition (Chemical) is a dynamic process involving the shutting down of endothelial gene expression and switching on of hematopoietic gene transcription. Although the factors regulating Chemical in hemogenic endothelium (HE) of the dorsal aorta have been relatively well studied, the molecular regulation of yolk sac HE remains poorly understood. Here, we show that Gene inhibits the expression of Gene target genes in HE, while having no effect on Gene expression itself. We establish that Gene directly interacts with Gene and inhibits its transcriptional activity. Through this interaction we demonstrate that Gene hinders Gene DNA binding as well as the interaction between Gene and its co-factor Gene. Finally, we show by single-cell expression profiling and immunofluorescence that Gene is broadly expressed across the Gene+ yolk sac HE population compared with Gene. Collectively, these data demonstrate for the first time how direct protein-protein interactions between endothelial and hematopoietic transcription factors regulate contrasting transcriptional programs during HE differentiation and Chemical.

22589746.pub_title: Gene regulates collagen gene transcription by association with RNA polymerase II in developing bone.
22589746.pub_abstract: PRDM family members are transcriptional regulators involved in tissue specific differentiation. Gene has been reported to predominantly repress transcription, but a characterization of its molecular functions in a relevant biological context is lacking. We demonstrate here that Gene is highly expressed in developing bones; and, by genome-wide mapping of Gene occupancy in pre-osteoblastic cells, we uncover a novel and unique role for Gene in targeting all Species collagen genes as well as several SLRP proteoglycan genes. In particular, we show that Gene controls both Collagen I transcription and fibrillogenesis by binding inside the Gene gene body and maintaining RNA polymerase II occupancy. In vivo, Gene loss results in delayed ossification involving a pronounced impairment in the assembly of fibrillar collagens. Collectively, our results define a novel role for Gene in sustaining the transcriptional program necessary to the proper assembly of osteoblastic extracellular matrix.

21998026.pub_title: The Gene is required for proper anterior-posterior somite patterning in Species.
21998026.pub_abstract: The Gene (Gene) is a component of a negative feedback system that attenuates Notch pathway-mediated signaling. In vertebrates, the timing and spacing of formation of the mesodermal somites are controlled by a molecular oscillator termed the segmentation clock. Somites are also patterned along the rostral-caudal axis of the embryo. Here, we demonstrate that Disease and Species exhibit genetic background-dependent defects of the axial skeleton. While progression of the segmentation clock occurred in Disease, they exhibited altered rostrocaudal patterning of the somites. In Gene mutant embryos, the posterior somite compartment was expanded. These studies confirm an anticipated, but previously undocumented role for the Gene gene in vertebrate somite patterning and provide an example of the strong influence that genetic background plays on the phenotypes exhibited by mutant Species.

27317810.pub_title: LGN plays distinct roles in oral epithelial stratification, filiform papilla morphogenesis and hair follicle development.
27317810.pub_abstract: Oral epithelia protect against constant challenges by bacteria, viruses, toxins and Disease while also contributing to the formation of ectodermal appendages such as teeth, salivary glands and lingual papillae. Despite increasing evidence that differentiation pathway genes are frequently mutated in Disease, comparatively little is known about the mechanisms that regulate normal oral epithelial development. Here, we characterize oral epithelial stratification and describe multiple distinct functions for the mitotic spindle orientation gene LGN (Gene) in promoting differentiation and tissue patterning in the Species oral cavity. Similar to its function in epidermis, apically localized LGN directs perpendicular divisions that promote stratification of the palatal, buccogingival and ventral Disease. Surprisingly, however, in dorsal tongue LGN is predominantly localized basally, circumferentially or bilaterally and promotes planar divisions. Loss of LGN disrupts the organization and morphogenesis of filiform papillae but appears to be dispensable for embryonic hair follicle development. Thus, LGN has crucial tissue-specific functions in patterning surface ectoderm and its appendages by controlling division orientation.

22872862.pub_title: Gene knockout Species is a model of distal Disease with Disease, with additional extrarenal phenotype.
22872862.pub_abstract: Disease (dRTA) is a severe disorder of acid-base homeostasis, often accompanied by Disease. We and others have previously shown that mutations in the tissue-restricted a4 and B1 subunits of the H(+)-ATPase underlie this syndrome. Here, we describe an Gene knockout Species, which lacks the a4 subunit. Using beta-galactosidase as a reporter for the null gene, developmental a4 expression was detected in developing bone, nose, eye, and skin, in addition to that expected in kidney and inner ear. By the time of weaning, Gene(-/-) Species demonstrated severe Disease, Disease, and early Disease. Null Species were hypocitraturic, but Disease was absent. They were severely hearing-impaired, as shown by elevated auditory brainstem response thresholds and absent endocochlear potential. They died rapidly unless alkalinized. If they survived weaning with alkali supplementation, treatment could later be withdrawn, but -/- animals remained acidotic with alkaline urine. They also had an impaired sense of smell. Heterozygous animals were biochemically normal until acid-challenged, when they became more acidotic than +/+ animals. This Species model recapitulates the loss of H(+)-ATPase function seen in Species disease and can provide additional insights into dRTA and the physiology of the a4 subunit.

25274628.pub_title: An atypical canonical Gene (Gene) signaling pathway regulates Gene (Gene) expression during odontogenesis.
25274628.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) signaling plays an essential role in early tooth development, evidenced by disruption of Gene signaling leading to an early arrested tooth development. Despite being a central mediator of Gene canonical signaling pathway, inactivation of Gene in dental mesenchyme does not result in early Disease. In the current study, we investigated the mechanism of receptor-activated Smads (R-Smads) and Gene in the regulation of the odontogenic gene Gene expression in the dental mesenchyme. We showed that the canonical Gene signaling is not operating in the early developing tooth, as assessed by failed activation of the BRE-Gal transgenic allele and the absence of Chemical-(p)Gene/8-Gene complexes. The absence of pSmad1/5/8-Gene complex appeared to be the consequence of saturation of Gene by pSmad2/3 in the dental mesenchyme as knockdown of Gene or overexpression of Gene led to the formation of pSmad1/5/8-Gene complexes and activation of canonical Gene signaling in dental mesenchymal cells. We showed that Gene but not Gene are required for Gene-induced expression of Gene in dental mesenchymal cells. We further presented evidence that in the absence of Gene, BMPs are still able to induce pSmad1/5/8 nuclear translocation and their binding to the Gene promoter directly in dental mesenchymal cells. Our results demonstrate the functional operation of an atypical canonical Gene signaling (Gene-independent and Gene/8-dependent) pathway in the dental mesenchyme during early odontogenesis, which may have general implication in the development of other organs.

23515312.pub_title: An allelic series at the Gene (Gene) locus reveals the functional specificity of Pax genes.
23515312.pub_abstract: The advent of the ocular and nervous system in metazoan evolution coincides with the diversification of a single ancestral paired box (Pax) gene into Gene, Gene(5a), and Gene. To investigate the role of these Pax genes in neural development, we have generated an allelic series of knock-in models at the Gene locus. We showed that although Gene(5a) and Gene could not replace Gene for its autoregulation in lens induction or for neural differentiation in retina, Gene(5a) was sufficient for Disease. In brain development, cell proliferation in the cerebral cortex and dorsoventral patterning of the Disease and neural tube were partially rescued in either knock-in mutant. Contrary to the previous belief, our genetic studies showed that the Gene isoform Gene(5a) could potentially play a role in neuronal differentiation in brain development. Importantly, Gene showed greater rescue efficiency than Gene(5a) in the Disease even though the latter was identical to Gene outside the paired domain. In studying Gene, a Gene direct target gene in Disease, we showed that the level of Gene expression correlated with the in vitro binding of Gene, Gene, and Gene(5a) paired domain on its enhancer. Our results show that Gene is uniquely required for eye development, but in brain development, Gene can be functionally substituted by related Pax family genes that share a similar paired domain binding specificity.

23172916.pub_title: Regulation of retinal interneuron subtype identity by the Iroquois homeobox gene Gene.
23172916.pub_abstract: Interneuronal subtype diversity lies at the heart of the distinct molecular properties and synaptic connections that shape the formation of the neuronal circuits that are necessary for the complex spatial and temporal processing of sensory information. Here, we investigate the role of Gene, a member of the Iroquois homeodomain transcription factor family, in regulating the development of Disease. Using a knock-in reporter approach, we show that, in the Species retina, Gene is expressed in type 2 and 3a OFF bipolar interneurons and is required for the expression of cell type-specific markers in these cells, likely through direct transcriptional regulation. In Gene mutant Species, presumptive type 3a bipolar cells exhibit an expansion of their axonal projection domain to the entire OFF region of the inner plexiform layer, and adopt molecular features of both type 2 and 3a bipolar cells, highlighted by the ectopic upregulation of Gene (Gene) and Gene. These findings reveal Gene as a key regulator of type 3a bipolar cell identity that prevents these cells from adopting characteristic features of type 2 bipolar cells. Analysis of the Gene;Gene double null retina suggests that the terminal differentiation of type 2 bipolar cells is dependent on the combined expression of the transcription factors Gene and Gene, but also points to the existence of Gene;Gene-independent mechanisms in regulating OFF bipolar subtype-specific gene expression. This work provides insight into the generation of neuronal subtypes by revealing a mechanism in which opposing, yet interdependent, transcription factors regulate subtype identity.

26138477.pub_title: A trans-homologue interaction between reciprocally imprinted Gene and Gene regulates placenta development.
26138477.pub_abstract: The paternally expressed imprinted Gene (Gene) is a retrotransposon-derived gene that has evolved a function in eutherian placentation. Seven miRNAs, including Gene, are processed from a maternally expressed antisense Gene transcript (Rtl1as) and regulate Gene levels through RNAi-mediated post-transcriptional degradation. To determine the relative functional role of Geneas miRNAs in Gene dosage, we generated a Species specifically deleted for Gene. The Gene knockout Species exhibit placentomegaly with specific defects within the Chemical zone involved in maternal-fetal nutrient transfer. Although fetal weight is unaltered, specific Gene transcripts and protein levels are increased in both the fetus and placenta. Phenotypic analysis of single (DeltamiR-127/Gene or Gene/DeltaRtl1) and double (DeltamiR-127/DeltaRtl1) heterozygous Gene- and Gene-deficient Species indicate that Gene is the main target gene of Gene in placental development. Our results demonstrate that Gene is an essential regulator of Gene, mediated by a trans-homologue interaction between reciprocally imprinted genes on the maternally and paternally inherited chromosomes.

23922682.pub_title: Loss of Gene expression is associated with defective bony patterning in the Species vertebral axis.
23922682.pub_abstract: Gene encoded by Gene is a member of the BTB/POZ family of proteins and participates in several pathobiological processes. However, its function during tissue development has not been elucidated. In this study, we compared homozygous null mutant Gene(-/-) and wild type Gene(+/+) Species to determine the consequences of diminished Gene expression. The most remarkable change in Gene(-/-) Species was a vertebral patterning defect in which most knockout animals exhibited a morphological transformation of the sixth lumbar vertebra (L6) into a sacral identity; thus, the total number of pre-sacral vertebrae was decreased by one (to 25) in Gene(-/-) Species. Heterozygous Gene(+/-) Species had an increased tendency to adopt an intermediate phenotype in which L6 underwent partial sacralization. Gene(-/-) Species also exhibited non-closure of the dorsal aspects of thoracic vertebrae T10-T12. Chondrocytes from Gene(+/+) Species expressed abundant Gene while Gene(-/-) chondrocytes had undetectable levels. Loss of Gene in Gene(-/-) Species was associated with significantly reduced chondrocyte migratory potential as well as decreased expression of Gene and Gene, two cartilage-associated extracellular matrix proteins with roles in the development and homeostasis of cartilage and bone. These data suggest that Gene participates in the motility and differentiation of developing chondrocytes and cartilaginous tissues, and its expression is necessary to maintain normal axial patterning of Species skeleton.

23696569.pub_title: Changes in thyroid status during perinatal development of Disease male Species.
23696569.pub_abstract: Species with the Gene (Gene) Disease present with a severe Disease and abnormal serum thyroid hormone (TH) levels, consisting of high T(3) and Disease(4) and rT(3). Species deficient in Gene replicate the thyroid phenotype of Species with the Gene gene mutations. We analyzed the serum TH levels and action in the cerebral cortex and in the liver during the perinatal period of Species deficient in Gene to assess how the Disease develop and to study the thyroidal status of specific tissues. During perinatal life, the thyroid phenotype of Gene-deficient Species is different from that of adult Species. They manifest Disease at embryonic day 18 and postnatal day 0. This perinatal Disease is accompanied by manifestations of TH excess as evidenced by a relative increase in the expression of genes positively regulated by T3 in both the cerebral cortex and liver. An increased tissue accumulation of T(4) and T(3) and the expression of TH alternative transporters, including Gene, Gene, Oatp1c1, and Oatp3a1 in the cortex and Gene and Gene in the liver, suggested that Gene deficiency either directly interferes with tissue efflux of TH or indirectly activates other transporters to increase TH uptake. This report is the first to identify that the ontogenesis of Disease in Gene-deficient Species manifests with TH excess in the perinatal period.

25219788.pub_title: The novel helicase Gene (Gene) is expressed during gastrulation in Species and has a structure similar to a Species DExH box helicase.
25219788.pub_abstract: The gene trap method for embryonic stem cells is an efficient method for identifying new genes that are involved in development. Using this method, we identified a novel gene called helicase family gene related to gastrulation (Gene). Helicase family proteins regulate many systems in the body that are related to cell survival. Gene encodes a protein of 137 kDa, which contains a DExH helicase motif that is now named Gene. Gene is strongly expressed in neural cells (ie, in the headfold, neural plate, neural tube, and brain) and somites during embryogenesis. Growing homozygous mutant embryos have neither differentiated somites nor brains. In these mutants, development was retarded by embryonic day 7.5 (E7.5), and the mutants died at E9.5. After the purification of Gene, an untwisting experiment was performed to confirm the helicase activity of Gene for DNA in vitro. We report for the first time that a helicase family gene is required for differentiation during embryogenesis; this gene might interact with polynucleotides to regulate some genes that are important for early development and has a structure similar to that of a Species DExH box helicase.

24351932.pub_title: Dual role for Gene in promoting striatonigral and repressing striatopallidal genetic programs to specify striatonigral cell identity.
24351932.pub_abstract: Striatal projection neurons comprise two populations of striatonigral and striatopallidal neurons. These two neuronal populations play distinct roles in controlling movement-related functions in the basal ganglia circuits. An important issue is how striatal progenitors are developmentally specified into these two distinct neuronal populations. In the present study, we characterized the function of Gene (Gene), a LIM-homeodomain transcription factor, in striatal development. Genetic fate mapping showed that Gene(+) progeny specifically developed into a subpopulation of striatonigral neurons that transiently expressed Gene. In Nestin-Gene(f/f) KO Species brain, differentiation of striatonigral neurons was defective, as evidenced by decreased expression of striatonigral-enriched genes, including Gene, Gene, Gene (Gene), and Gene. Striatonigral axonal projections were also impaired, and abnormal apoptosis was observed in Gene KO striatum. It was of particular interest that striatopallidal-enriched genes, including Gene (Gene), Chemical, Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene), were concomitantly up-regulated in Gene mutant striatum, suggesting derepression of striatopallidal genes in striatonigral neurons in the absence of Gene. The suppression of striatopallidal genes by Gene was further examined by overexpression of Gene in the striatum of Gene-EGFP Species using in utero electroporation. Ectopic Gene expression was sufficient to repress Gene-EGFP signals in striatopallidal neurons. Taken together, our study suggests that Gene specifies the cell fate of striatonigral neurons not only by orchestrating survival, differentiation, and axonal projections of striatonigral neurons but also by suppressing striatopallidal-enriched genes. The dual action of developmental control by Gene in promoting appropriate striatonigral but repressing inappropriate striatopallidal genetic profiles may ensure sharpening of the striatonigral identity during development.

26256211.pub_title: An Integrated Transcriptome Atlas of Disease Follicle Progenitors, Their Niche, and the Developing Skin.
26256211.pub_abstract: Defining the unique molecular features of progenitors and their niche requires a genome-wide, whole-tissue approach with cellular resolution. Here, we co-isolate embryonic hair follicle (HF) placode and dermal condensate cells, precursors of adult HF stem cells and the Disease/sheath niche, along with lineage-related keratinocytes and fibroblasts, Schwann cells, melanocytes, and a population inclusive of all remaining skin cells. With next-generation RNA sequencing, we define gene expression patterns in the context of the entire Disease, and through transcriptome cross-comparisons, we uncover hundreds of enriched genes in cell-type-specific signatures. Axon guidance signaling and many other pathway genes are enriched in multiple signatures, implicating these factors in driving the large-scale cellular rearrangements necessary for HF formation. Finally, we share all data in an interactive, searchable companion website. Our study provides an overarching view of signaling within the entire Disease and captures a molecular snapshot of HF progenitors and their niche.

27012200.pub_title: Gene facilitates differentiation of proliferating chondrocytes into Disease chondrocytes by enhancing Wnt/Gene signaling in endochondral ossification.
27012200.pub_abstract: Endochondral ossification is a crucial process for longitudinal growth of bones. Differentiating chondrocytes in growth cartilage form four sequential zones of proliferation, alignment into column, Disease, and substitution of chondrocytes with osteoblasts. Wnt/Gene signaling is essential for differentiation of proliferating chondrocytes into Disease chondrocytes in growth cartilage. Gene (Gene), a member of R-spondin family, is an agonist for Wnt signaling, but its role in chondrocyte differentiation remains unknown. Here we report that growth cartilage of Gene-knockout Species shows a decreased amount of Gene and increased amounts collagen type II (CII) and Gene in the abnormally extended proliferating zone. In contrast, expression of collagen type X (CX) in the Disease zone remains unchanged. Differentiating chondrogenic ATDC5 cells, mimicking proliferating chondrocytes, upregulate Gene and its putative receptor, Gene, in parallel. Addition of recombinant Species Gene to differentiating ATDC5 cells decreases expressions of Gene, Gene, and Gene, as well as production of proteoglycans. In contrast, lentivirus-mediated knockdown of Gene has the opposite effect. The effect of Gene on chondrogenic differentiation is mediated by Wnt/Gene signaling, and not by Wnt/PCP or Wnt/Chemical signaling. We propose that Gene activates Wnt/Gene signaling to reduce Gene and Gene and to facilitate differentiation of proliferating chondrocytes into Disease chondrocytes in growth cartilage.

23382688.pub_title: Mutation of the Chemical Disease gene Gene in Species results in morphological and neuroanatomical phenotypes.
23382688.pub_abstract: The ribosome is an evolutionarily conserved organelle essential for cellular function. Ribosome construction requires assembly of approximately 80 different ribosomal proteins (RPs) and four different species of rRNA. As RPs co-assemble into one multi-subunit complex, mutation of the genes that encode RPs might be expected to give rise to phenocopies, in which the same phenotype is associated with loss-of-function of each individual gene. However, a more complex picture is emerging in which, in addition to a group of shared phenotypes, diverse RP gene-specific phenotypes are observed. Here we report the first two Species mutations (Gene(Mtu) and Gene(Zma)) of Gene (Gene), a gene that has been implicated in Diamond-Blackfan Disease. Gene disruption results in decreased body size, abnormal skeletal morphology, mid-ventral white spotting, and Disease. These phenotypes are reported in other Species RP mutants and, as demonstrated for some other RP mutations, are ameliorated by Gene deficiency. Interestingly, Gene mutants have additional overt malformations of the developing central nervous system and Disease, phenotypes that are not reported in Species or Species RP gene mutants. Conversely, Gene Species mutants show no Disease or Disease, phenotypes associated with mutation of Species Gene and other Species RPs, respectively. We provide two novel RP Species models and expand the repertoire of potential phenotypes that should be examined in RP mutants to further explore the concept of RP gene-specific phenotypes.

25715398.pub_title: Muscle composition is regulated by a Gene-Gene feedback loop.
25715398.pub_abstract: Muscle is an integrated tissue composed of distinct cell types and extracellular matrix. While much emphasis has been placed on the factors required for the specification of the cells that comprise muscle, little is known about the crosstalk between them that enables the development of a patterned and functional tissue. We find in Species that deletion of Gene (Gene), an extracellular enzyme regulating collagen maturation and organization, uncouples the balance between the amount of myofibers and that of muscle connective tissue (MCT). We show that Gene secreted from the myofibers attenuates Gene signaling, an inhibitor of myofiber differentiation and promoter of MCT development. We further demonstrate that a Gene-Gene feedback loop between the MCT and myofibers maintains the dynamic developmental homeostasis between muscle components while also regulating MCT organization. Our results allow a better understanding of diseases such as Disease, in which Gene and Gene signaling have been implicated and the balance between muscle constituents is disturbed.

27881777.pub_title: Temporal Profiling of Astrocyte Precursors Reveals Parallel Roles for Gene during Development and after Injury.
27881777.pub_abstract: Lineage development is a stepwise process, governed by stage-specific regulatory factors and associated markers. Astrocytes are one of the principle cell types in the CNS and the stages associated with their development remain very poorly defined. To identify these stages, we performed gene-expression profiling on astrocyte precursor populations in the spinal cord, identifying distinct patterns of gene induction during their development that are strongly correlated with Species astrocytes. Validation studies identified a new cohort of astrocyte-associated genes during development and demonstrated their expression in reactive astrocytes in Species Disease (WMI). Functional studies on one of these genes revealed that Species lacking Gene exhibited impaired astrocyte differentiation during development and repair after WMI, coupled with compromised blood-brain barrier integrity in the adult CNS. These studies have identified distinct stages of astrocyte lineage development associated with Species WMI and, together with our functional analysis of Gene, highlight the parallels between astrocyte development and their reactive counterparts associated with Disease. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: Astrocytes play a central role in CNS function and associated diseases. Yet the mechanisms that control their development remain poorly defined. Using the developing Species spinal cord as a model system, we identify molecular changes that occur in developing astrocytes. These molecular signatures are strongly correlated with Species astrocyte expression profiles and validation in Species spinal cord identifies a host of new genes associated with the astrocyte lineage. These genes are present in reactive astrocytes in Species Disease, and functional studies reveal that one of these genes, Gene, contributes to reactive astrocyte responses after Disease. These studies identify distinct stages of astrocyte lineage development and highlight the parallels between astrocyte development and their reactive counterparts associated with Disease.

25758223.pub_title: A Gene-dependent gene network controls trophoblast branching morphogenesis.
25758223.pub_abstract: Healthy placental development is essential for reproductive success; failure of the feto-maternal interface results in pre-eclampsia and Disease. We found that Gene (Gene), a CP2-type transcription factor, is highly expressed in chorionic trophoblast cells, including basal chorionic trophoblast (BCT) cells located at the chorioallantoic interface in Species placentas. Placentas from Gene-deficient Species embryos displayed defects in BCT cell polarity and basement membrane integrity at the chorioallantoic interface, as well as a severe disruption of labyrinth branching morphogenesis. Selective Gene inactivation only in epiblast-derived cells rescued all placental defects but phenocopied intraembryonic defects observed in global Gene deficiency, implying the importance of Gene activity in trophectoderm-derived cells. ChIP-seq identified 5282 Gene binding sites in placental tissue. By integrating these data with placental gene expression profiles, we identified direct and indirect Gene targets and found a marked enrichment of Gene binding adjacent to genes downregulated in Gene(-/-) placentas, which encoded known regulators of placental development and epithelial morphogenesis. These genes included that encoding the Gene (Gene), which regulates BCT cell integrity and labyrinth formation. In Species placenta, we found that Species orthologs of Species Gene and its targets displayed co-regulation and were expressed in trophoblast cells in a similar domain as in Species placenta. Our data indicate that a conserved Gene-coordinated gene network controls trophoblast branching morphogenesis, thereby facilitating development of the site of feto-maternal exchange. This might have implications for syndromes related to Disease.

25409156.pub_title: RNA regulons in Hox 5' UTRs confer ribosome specificity to gene regulation.
25409156.pub_abstract: Emerging evidence suggests that the ribosome has a regulatory function in directing how the genome is translated in time and space. However, how this regulation is encoded in the messenger RNA sequence remains largely unknown. Here we uncover unique RNA regulons embedded in homeobox (Hox) 5' untranslated regions (UTRs) that confer ribosome-mediated control of gene expression. These structured RNA elements, resembling viral internal ribosome entry sites (IRESs), are found in subsets of Hox mRNAs. They facilitate ribosome recruitment and require the ribosomal protein Gene for their activity. Despite numerous layers of Hox gene regulation, these IRES elements are essential for converting Hox transcripts into proteins to pattern the Species body plan. This specialized mode of IRES-dependent translation is enabled by an additional regulatory element that we term the translation inhibitory element (TIE), which blocks cap-dependent translation of transcripts. Together, these data uncover a new paradigm for ribosome-mediated control of gene expression and organismal development.

27131881.pub_title: Gene Activation in the Dermal Papilla Is Important for Hair Follicle Growth Phase Induction.
27131881.pub_abstract: Hair follicles are skin appendages that undergo periods of growth (anagen), regression (catagen), and rest (telogen) regulated by their mesenchymal component, the dermal papilla (DP). On the basis of the reports of its specific expression in the DP, we investigated signal transducer and activator of transcription (Gene) activation during hair development and cycling. Gene activation in the DP began in late catagen, reaching a peak in early anagen before disappearing for the rest of the cycle. This was confirmed by the expression profile of Gene, a Gene target in the DP. This pattern of expression starts after the first postnatal hair cycle. Quantification of hair cycling using the Flash canonical Wnt signaling in vivo bioluminescence reporter found that conditional knockout of Gene in the DP targeted through Cre-recombinase under the control of the Gene promoter resulted in delayed anagen entry compared with control. Microarray analysis of Gene deletion versus control revealed key changes in Gene, Wnt, and fibroblast growth factor ligands, known for their role in inducing anagen entry. We conclude that Gene activation acts as a mesenchymal switch to trigger natural anagen entry in postdevelopmental hair follicle cycling.

24155945.pub_title: Gene: a lineage tracer for cortical interneurons originating in the lateral/caudal ganglionic eminence and preoptic area.
24155945.pub_abstract: The homeobox-encoding gene Gene and its Disease homologue prospero are key regulators of cell fate-specification. In the developing rodent cortex a sparse population of cells thought to correspond to late-generated cortical pyramidal neuron precursors expresses Gene. Using a series of Species that mark cell lineages in the Disease and, more specifically, different populations of cortical interneurons, we demonstrate that neurons expressing Gene do not represent pyramidal neurons or their precursors but are instead subsets of cortical interneurons. These correspond to interneurons originating in the lateral/caudal ganglionic eminence (LGE/CGE) and a small number of preoptic area (POA)-derived neurons. Expression within the cortex can be detected from late embryonic stages onwards when cortical interneurons are still migrating. There is persistent expression in postmitotic cells in the mature brain mainly in the outer cortical layers. Gene(+ve) interneurons express neurochemical markers such as Chemical, Gene, reelin and vasoactive intestinal peptide, all of which are enriched in LGE/CGE- and some POA-derived cells. Unlike in the cortex, in the striatum Gene marks nearly all interneurons regardless of their origin. Weak expression of Gene can also be detected in oligodendrocyte lineage cells throughout the forebrain. Our data show that Gene can be used as a genetic lineage tracer of nearly all LGE/CGE- and subsets POA-derived cortical interneurons at all developmental and postnatal stages in vivo.

24335282.pub_title: Analysis of the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex during early heart development and Gene repression cardiac gene transcription during P19 cell differentiation.
24335282.pub_abstract: The regulatory networks of differentiation programs and the molecular mechanisms of lineage-specific gene regulation in Species embryos remain only partially defined. We document differential expression and temporal switching of Gene (Gene) subunits, core pluripotency factors and cardiac-specific genes during post-implantation development and subsequent early organogenesis. Using affinity purification of Gene ATPase coupled to mass spectrometry, we characterized the cardiac-enriched remodeling complexes present in E8.5 Species embryos. The relative abundance and combinatorial assembly of the Gene subunits provides functional specificity to Switch/Chemical NonFermentable (SWI/SNF) complexes resulting in a unique gene expression profile in the developing heart. Remarkably, the specific depletion of the Gene subunit demonstrated differential effects on cardiac-specific gene expression and resulted in Disease in vitro. Indeed, the Gene physically interacts and functionally cooperates with Nucleosome Remodeling and Histone Deacetylase (NURD) complex subunits to repressively regulate chromatin structure of the cardiac genes by switching open and poised chromatin marks associated with active and repressed gene expression. Finally, Gene expression modulates Gene occupancy at the loci of cardiac genes regulatory regions in P19 cell differentiation. These findings reveal specialized and novel cardiac-enriched SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complexes, which are required for heart formation and critical for cardiac gene expression regulation at the early stages of heart development.

25139854.pub_title: Gene is required for progression of Gene+ embryonic precursors into HSCs but not prior to this.
25139854.pub_abstract: Haematopoiesis in adult animals is maintained by haematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), which self-renew and can give rise to all blood cell lineages. The AGM region is an important intra-embryonic site of HSC development and a wealth of evidence indicates that HSCs emerge from the endothelium of the embryonic dorsal aorta and extra-embryonic large arteries. This, however, is a stepwise process that occurs through sequential upregulation of Gene and Gene followed by emergence of fully functional definitive HSCs. Although largely dispensable at later stages, the Gene transcription factor is crucially important during developmental maturation of HSCs; however, exact points of crucial involvement of Gene in this multi-step developmental maturation process remain unclear. Here, we have investigated requirements for Gene using a conditional reversible knockout strategy. We report that Gene deficiency does not preclude formation of VE-cad+Gene-Gene+ cells, which are phenotypically equivalent to precursors of definitive HSCs (pre-HSC Type I) but blocks transition to the subsequent Gene+ stage (pre-HSC Type II). These data emphasise that developmental progression of HSCs during a very short period of time is regulated by precise stage-specific molecular mechanisms.

22740348.pub_title: Gene mediates the acute response to decreased cell volume in Species preimplantation embryos by activating Gene.
22740348.pub_abstract: Preimplantation Species embryos are particularly sensitive to increased osmolarity within their normal physiological range. The detrimental effects can be alleviated by organic osmolytes such as Chemical transported into early embryos, an effect thought to be due to the organic osmolyte replacing a portion of intracellular inorganic ions accumulated during acute cell volume regulation. However, no mechanism of cell volume regulation dependent on inorganic ions has been identified in preimplantation embryos. We found that decreased cell volume rapidly activated Na(+)/H(+) exchange in preimplantation Species embryos. This activity was likely mediated by the Gene (Gene) isoform, since it was blocked by the highly selective Gene inhibitor, Chemical, which also inhibited the ability of the 1-cell embryo to maintain cell volume. How Gene is activated by decreased cell volume is not generally well understood. Full activation of Gene by decreased cell volume in 2-cell Species embryos required the activity of the Chemical kinase Gene (Gene), since Gene activation was inhibited by the general Chemical kinase inhibitor Chemical, several selective inhibitors of Gene, and dominant negative Gene expressed in 2-cell embryos. Decreased cell volume furthermore resulted in increased Chemical phosphorylation of proteins in 2-cell embryos detected both by anti-Chemical antibody and an antibody directed against active phospho-Gene. Thus, Gene apparently serves as a cell volume sensor in embryos. Evidence from pharmacological inhibitors further indicated that Gene activation by decreased cell volume was dependent on calmodulin activity, likely downstream of Gene, and required active phospholipase C.

25363691.pub_title: Neuropilins define distinct populations of neural crest cells.
25363691.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Neural crest cells (NCCs) are a transient embryonic cell type that give rise to a wide spectrum of derivatives, including neurons and glia of the sensory and autonomic nervous system, melanocytes and connective tissues in the head. Lineage-tracing and functional studies have shown that trunk NCCs migrate along two distinct paths that correlate with different developmental fates. Thus, NCCs migrating ventrally through the anterior somite form sympathetic and sensory ganglia, whereas NCCs migrating dorsolaterally form melanocytes. Although the mechanisms promoting migration along the dorsolateral path are well defined, the molecules providing positional identity to sympathetic and sensory-fated NCCs that migrate along the same ventral path are ill defined. Neuropilins (Gene and Gene) are transmembrane glycoproteins that are essential for NCC migration. Gene and Gene knockout Species have disparate phenotypes, suggesting that these receptors may play a role in sorting NCCs biased towards sensory and sympathetic fates to appropriate locations. RESULTS: Here we have combined in situ hybridisation, immunohistochemistry and lineage-tracing analyses to demonstrate that neuropilins are expressed in a non-overlapping pattern within NCCs. Whereas Gene is expressed in NCCs emigrating from hindbrain rhombomere 4 (r4) and within trunk NCCs giving rise to sympathetic and sensory ganglia, Gene is preferentially expressed in NCCs emigrating from r2 and in trunk NCCs giving rise to sensory ganglia. By generating a Chemical-inducible lineage-tracing system, we further demonstrate that Gene-expressing NCCs specifically populate sensory ganglia including the trigeminal ganglia (V) in the head and the dorsal root ganglia in the trunk. CONCLUSIONS: Taken together, our results demonstrate that Gene and Gene are expressed in different populations of NCCs, and that Gene-expressing NCCs are strongly biased towards a sensory fate. In the trunk, Gene-expressing NCCs specifically give rise to sensory ganglia, whereas Gene-expressing NCCs likely give rise to both sensory and sympathetic ganglia. Our findings therefore suggest that neuropilins play an essential role in coordinating NCC migration with fate specification.

22564414.pub_title: miR-34s inhibit osteoblast proliferation and differentiation in the Species by targeting Gene.
22564414.pub_abstract: A screen of microRNAs preferentially expressed in osteoblasts identified members of the miR-34 family as regulators of osteoblast proliferation and/or differentiation. Osteoblast-specific gain- and loss-of-function experiments performed in vivo revealed that Gene and -c affected skeletogenesis during embryonic development, as well as bone mass accrual after birth, through two complementary cellular and molecular mechanisms. First, they inhibited osteoblast proliferation by suppressing Gene, Gene, and Gene accumulation.
