The Disease of the bone collar in the mutant Species was markedly delayed and the periosteum was thin, possibly because of the downregulation of Indian hedgehog expression. We conclude that Gene signaling in Disease chondrocytes positively regulates terminal chondrocyte differentiation, angiogenesis in calcified cartilage, and Disease in the bone collar, at least partly through Indian hedgehog signaling in vivo.

24151332.pub_title: Transcript processing and export kinetics are rate-limiting steps in expressing vertebrate segmentation clock genes.
24151332.pub_abstract: Sequential production of body segments in vertebrate embryos is regulated by a molecular oscillator (the segmentation clock) that drives cyclic transcription of genes involved in positioning intersegmental boundaries. Mathematical modeling indicates that the period of the clock depends on the total delay kinetics of a negative feedback circuit, including those associated with the synthesis of transcripts encoding clock components [Lewis J (2003) Curr Chemical]. Here, we measure expression delays for three transcripts [Lunatic fringe, Gene/Gene, and Notch-regulated-ankyrin-repeat-protein (Nrarp)], that cycle during segmentation in the Species, Species, and Species, and provide in vivo measurements of endogenous splicing and export kinetics. We show that mRNA splicing and export are much slower than transcript elongation, with the longest delay (about 16 min in the Species) being due to mRNA export. We conclude that the kinetics of mRNA and protein production and destruction can account for much of the clock period, and provide strong support for delayed autorepression as the underlying mechanism of the segmentation clock.

24760755.pub_title: Gene interact at the blood-brain barrier and also within the brain to maintain an essential Chemical pool that protects against Disease.
24760755.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) and its receptor, Gene (Gene), account for brain retaining Chemical better than other tissues. The primary sources of Gene in plasma and brain are hepatocytes and astrocytes, respectively. Gene is expressed in varying amounts by tissues; within the brain it is expressed primarily by neurons. Knockout of Gene or Gene lowers brain Chemical from ~120 to ~50 ng/g and leads to severe Disease and Disease in mild Disease. Interactions of Gene and Gene that protect against this injury have not been characterized. We studied Gene, Gene, and brain Chemical in knockout Species. Immunocytochemistry showed that Gene mediates Gene uptake at the blood-brain barrier. When Gene(-/-) or Gene(-/-) Species developed severe Disease caused by mild Disease, brain Chemical was ~35 ng/g. In extreme Disease, however, brain Chemical of ~12 ng/g was tolerated when both Gene and Gene were intact in the brain. These findings indicate that tandem Gene-Gene interactions supply Chemical for maintenance of brain neurons. One interaction is at the blood-brain barrier, and the other is within the brain. We postulate that Gene inside the blood-brain barrier is taken up by neurons via Gene, concentrating brain Chemical in them.

22182519.pub_title: Dual function of suppressor of fused in Hh pathway activation and Species spinal cord patterning.
22182519.pub_abstract: The morphogen Sonic hedgehog, one of the Hedgehog (Hh) family of secreted proteins, plays a key role in patterning the Species spinal cord along its dorsoventral (D/V) axis through the activation of Gene (Gene) family of transcription factors. Suppressor of Fused (Gene), a Gene-interacting protein, modulates the D/V patterning of the spinal cord by antagonizing Hh signaling. The molecular mechanisms underlying the function of Gene in Hh pathway activation and spinal cord D/V patterning remain controversial, particularly in light of recent findings that Gene protects Gene and Gene proteins from proteasomal degradation. In the current study, we show that Hh pathway activation and dorsal expansion of ventral spinal cord cell types in the absence of Gene depend on the activator activities of all three Gene family proteins. We also show that Gene plays a positive role in the maximal activation of Hh signaling that defines the ventral-most cell fate in the Species spinal cord, likely through protecting Gene and Gene proteins from degradation. Finally, by altering the level of Gene repressor on a background of reduced Gene activator activities, we reveal an important contribution of Gene repressor activity to the Hh pathway activation and the D/V patterning of the spinal cord.

23429478.pub_title: Gastrointestinal defects of the Gene mutant involve dysregulated Hedgehog and Gene signaling.
23429478.pub_abstract: The gastrointestinal (GI) tract defines the digestive system and is composed of the stomach, intestine and colon. Among the major cell types lining radially along the GI tract are the epithelium, mucosa, smooth muscles and enteric neurons. The Hedgehog (Hh) pathway has been implicated in directing various aspects of the developing GI tract, notably the mucosa and smooth muscle growth, and enteric neuron patterning, while the Gene signaling pathway is selectively required for enteric neuron migration, proliferation, and differentiation. The Gene (Gene) encodes a GPI-anchored membrane protein known to bind to Gene (Gene), Indian Hh (Ihh), and Gene. However, its role in the GI tract has not been examined. Here we show that the Gene mutant GI tract, compared to the control, is shorter, has thinner smooth muscles, and contains more enteric progenitors that are abnormally distributed. These phenotypes are similar to those of the Gene mutant, supporting that Gene mediates most of the Gene activity in the GI tract. Because Gene has been shown to inhibit Gene signaling elicited by Gene (Gene), we explored whether Gene mutant enteric neurons displayed any alteration of Gene signaling levels. Indeed, isolated mutant enteric progenitors not only showed increased levels of Chemical-Gene and its downstream effectors, Chemical-Gene and Chemical-Erk, but also displayed altered responses to Gene and Gene. We therefore conclude that phenotypes observed in the Gene mutant are due to a combination of reduced Hh signaling and increased Gene signaling.

26651292.pub_title: A Dynamic Unfolded Protein Response Contributes to the Control of Cortical Neurogenesis.
26651292.pub_abstract: The cerebral cortex contains layers of neurons sequentially generated by distinct lineage-related progenitors. At the onset of corticogenesis, the first-born progenitors are apical progenitors (APs), whose asymmetric division gives birth directly to neurons. Later, they switch to indirect neurogenesis by generating intermediate progenitors (IPs), which give rise to projection neurons of all cortical layers. While a direct lineage relationship between APs and IPs has been established, the molecular mechanism that controls their transition remains elusive. Here we show that interfering with codon translation speed triggers ER stress and the unfolded protein response (UPR), further impairing the generation of IPs and leading to microcephaly. Moreover, we demonstrate that a progressive downregulation of UPR in cortical progenitors acts as a physiological signal to amplify IPs and promotes indirect neurogenesis. Thus, our findings reveal a contribution of UPR to cell fate acquisition during Species brain development.

26369386.pub_title: Differential genomic imprinting regulates paracrine and autocrine roles of Gene in Species adult neurogenesis.
26369386.pub_abstract: Genomic imprinting is implicated in the control of gene dosage in neurogenic niches. Here we address the importance of Gene imprinting for Species adult neurogenesis in the subventricular zone (SVZ) and in the subgranular zone (SGZ) of the hippocampus in vivo. In the SVZ, paracrine Gene is a cerebrospinal fluid and Gene neurogenic factor requiring biallelic expression, with mutants having reduced activation of the stem cell pool and Disease. In contrast, Gene is imprinted in the hippocampus acting as an autocrine factor expressed in neural stem cells (NSCs) solely from the paternal allele. Conditional mutagenesis of Gene in blood vessels confirms that Gene Gene contributes to NSC maintenance in SVZ but not in the SGZ, and that this is regulated by the biallelic expression of Gene in the vascular compartment. Our findings indicate that a regulatory decision to imprint or not is a functionally important mechanism of transcriptional dosage control in adult neurogenesis.

23166506.pub_title: Disruption of Species Gene, a regulator of centriole biogenesis, Disease.
23166506.pub_abstract: Disruption of the centromere protein J gene, Gene (Gene, MCPH6, SCKL4), which is a highly conserved and ubiquitiously expressed centrosomal protein, has been associated with primary Disease and the Disease. The mechanism by which disruption of Gene causes the proportionate, Disease that is characteristic of Disease is unknown. By generating a hypomorphic allele of Gene, we have developed a Species (Gene(tm/tm)) that recapitulates many of the clinical features of Disease, including intrauterine dwarfism, Disease with Disease, Disease, and Disease, thus providing clear confirmation that specific mutations of Gene can cause Disease. Immunohistochemistry revealed increased levels of DNA damage and apoptosis throughout Gene(tm/tm) embryos and adult Species showed an elevated frequency of micronucleus induction, suggesting that Gene-deficiency results in genomic instability. Notably, however, genomic instability was not the result of defective ATR-dependent DNA damage signaling, as is the case for the majority of genes associated with Disease. Instead, Gene(tm/tm) Disease fibroblasts exhibited irregular centriole and centrosome numbers and mono- and multipolar spindles, and many were near-tetraploid with numerical and structural Disease when compared to passage-matched wild-type cells. Increased cell death due to Disease during Disease development is likely to contribute to the proportionate dwarfism that is associated with Disease.

26138486.pub_title: Identification of in vivo DNA-binding mechanisms of Gene and reconstruction of Gene-dependent gene regulatory networks during forebrain and lens development.
26138486.pub_abstract: The transcription factor Gene is comprised of the paired domain (PD) and homeodomain (Disease). In the developing forebrain, Gene is expressed in ventricular zone precursor cells and in specific subpopulations of neurons; absence of Gene results in disrupted cell proliferation and cell fate specification. Gene also regulates the entire lens developmental program. To reconstruct Gene-dependent gene regulatory networks (GRNs), ChIP-seq studies were performed using forebrain and lens chromatin from Species. A total of 3514 (forebrain) and 3723 (lens) Gene-containing peaks were identified, with ~70% of them found in both tissues and thereafter called 'common' peaks. Analysis of Gene-bound peaks identified motifs that closely resemble Gene-PD, Gene-PD/Disease and Gene-Disease established binding sequences. Mapping of Chemical, H3K27ac, H3K27me3 and RNA polymerase II revealed distinct types of tissue-specific enhancers bound by Gene. Gene directly regulates cortical neurogenesis through activation (e.g. Gene and Gene) and repression (e.g. Gene, Gene, and Gene) of transcription factors. In lens, Gene directly regulates cell cycle exit via components of Gene (Gene, Gene and Gene) and Gene (Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene) signaling pathways. Collectively, these studies provide genome-wide analysis of Gene-dependent GRNs in lens and forebrain and establish novel roles of Gene in organogenesis.

25100604.pub_title: Gene/Gene and Gene form the critical gateway to axotomy-induced motoneuron death in neonates.
25100604.pub_abstract: Disease after transection of the axons (axotomy) in neonates is believed to share the same mechanistic bases as naturally occurring programmed cell death during development. The c-Jun Chemical-terminal kinase pathway is activated in both forms of motoneuron death, but it remains unknown to what extent these two forms of motoneuron death depend on this pathway and which upstream kinases are involved. We found that numbers of facial motoneurons are doubled in neonatal Species deficient in either Gene/Gene (zipper protein kinase, also known as dual leucine zipper kinase), a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, or in Gene/Gene, a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase directly downstream of Gene/Gene, and that the facial motoneurons in those mutant Species are completely resistant to axotomy-induced death. Conditional deletion of Gene/Gene in neurons further suggested that Gene/Gene and Gene/Gene-dependent mechanisms underlying axotomy-induced death are motoneuron autonomous. Nevertheless, quantitative analysis of facial motoneurons during embryogenesis revealed that both Gene/Gene and Gene/Gene-dependent and -independent mechanisms contribute to developmental elimination of excess motoneurons. In contrast to Gene/Gene, Species lacking Gene/Gene, another mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase directly downstream of Gene/Gene, conditionally in neurons did not have excess facial motoneurons. However, some Gene/Gene-deficient facial motoneurons were resistant to axotomy-induced death, indicating a synergistic effect of Gene/Gene on axotomy-induced death of these facial motoneurons. Together, our study provides compelling evidence for the pivotal roles of the Gene/Gene and Gene/Gene-dependent mechanism in axotomy-induced motoneuron death in neonates and also demonstrates that axotomy-induced motoneuron death is not identical to Disease with respect to the involvement of Gene/Gene, Gene/Gene and Gene/Gene.

25228773.pub_title: Gene and Gene redundantly regulate early retinal cell fates during development.
25228773.pub_abstract: Previously, we have shown that Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene) are expressed in retinal progenitor cells, developing retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), and horizontal cells (HCs). However, in Gene-null Species, we only observed an 80% reduction in HCs, but no defects in other cell types. We postulated that the lack of defects in other cell types in Gene-null retinas was a result of redundancy with Gene. To test this theory, we have generated Gene-null Species and now show that their retinas also only have defects in HCs, with a 50% reduction in their numbers. However, when both Gene and Gene are knocked out, the retinas exhibit more profound defects in the development of all early retinal cell types, including completely failed genesis of HCs, compromised generation of cones, reduced production (by 30%) of RGCs, and absence of starburst amacrine cells. Cone subtype diversification and RGC subtype composition also were affected in the double-null retina. Using RNA-Seq expression profiling, we have identified downstream genes of Gene and Gene, which not only confirms the redundancy between the two factors and renders a molecular explanation for the defects in the double-null retinas, but also shows that the onecut factors suppress the production of the late cell type, rods, indicating that the two factors contribute to the competence of retinal progenitor cells for the early retinal cell fates. Our results provide insight into how onecut factors regulate the creation of cellular diversity in the retina and, by extension, in the central nervous system in general.

24404170.pub_title: Targeting of GFP-Cre to the Species Gene locus both drives cre recombinase expression in steroidogenic cells and permits generation of Gene knock out Species.
24404170.pub_abstract: To permit conditional gene targeting of floxed alleles in steroidogenic cell-types we have generated a transgenic Species line that expresses Cre Recombinase under the regulation of the endogenous Cytochrome P450 side chain cleavage enzyme (Gene) promoter. Species Carrying the Gene-GC (GFP-Cre) allele express Cre Recombinase in fetal adrenal and testis, and adrenal cortex, testicular Leydig cells (and a small proportion of Sertoli cells), theca cells of the ovary, and the hindbrain in postnatal life. Circulating Chemical concentration is unchanged in Cyp11(+/GC) males, suggesting steroidogenesis is unaffected by loss of one allele of Gene, Species are grossly normal, and Cre Recombinase functions to recombine floxed alleles of both a YFP reporter gene and the Gene (Gene) in steroidogenic cells of the testis, ovary, adrenal and hindbrain. Additionally, when bred to homozygosity (Gene(GC/GC) ), knock-in of GFP-Cre to the endogenous Gene locus results in a novel Species model lacking endogenous Gene (Gene) function. This unique dual-purpose model has utility both for those wishing to conditionally target genes within steroidogenic cell types and for studies requiring Species lacking endogenous Chemical hormone production.

22869523.pub_title: Gene integrin NPXY motifs regulate kidney collecting-duct development and maintenance by induced-fit interactions with cytosolic proteins.
22869523.pub_abstract: Loss of Gene integrin expression inhibits renal collecting-system development. Two highly conserved NPXY motifs in the distal Gene tail regulate integrin function by associating with Chemical binding (PTB) proteins, such as talin and kindlin. Here, we define the roles of these two Chemical in collecting-system development and delineate the structural determinants of the distal Gene tail using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). Species carrying Chemical mutations have moderate renal collecting-system Disease relative to Gene-null Species. Chemical mutations did not affect renal collecting-system development but increased susceptibility to Disease. NMR spectra in bicelles showed the distal Gene tail is disordered and does not interact with the model membrane surface. Chemical or Chemical mutations did not alter Gene structure or interactions between alpha and Gene subunit transmembrane/cytoplasmic domains; however, they did decrease talin and kindlin binding. Thus, these studies highlight the fact that the functional roles of the NPXY motifs are organ dependent. Moreover, the Gene cytoplasmic tail, in the context of the adjacent transmembrane domain in bicelles, is significantly different from the more ordered, membrane-associated beta3 integrin tail. Finally, Chemical mutations of Gene NPXY motifs induce phenotypes by disrupting their interactions with critical integrin binding proteins like talins and kindlins.

23449535.pub_title: Gene determines urothelial cell fate during ureter development.
23449535.pub_abstract: Developing and adult ureters express the epigenetic regulator Gene, but the role of Gene in ureter development is not well understood. We conditionally ablated Gene in the developing ureter using Gene-Cre and found that Gene expression is upstream of Gene, Gene, and Gene (Gene) expression in the ureteral epithelium. In addition, epithelial stratification in the basal cells required Gene-dependent Gene expression, whereas terminal differentiation of the umbrella cells required Gene-dependent Gene expression. Furthermore, the loss of ureteric Gene resulted in failure of Gene expression, which correlated with reduced smooth muscle cell development and hydroureter. Taken together, we conclude that Gene expression unifies three aspects of ureter development: maintenance of the basal cell population, guidance for terminal differentiation of urothelial cells, and proper investment of ureteral smooth muscle cells.

26965371.pub_title: Gene controls maturation of the mother centriole during cilia biogenesis.
26965371.pub_abstract: Defects in cilia centrosomal genes cause pleiotropic clinical phenotypes, collectively called ciliopathies. Cilia biogenesis is initiated by the interaction of positive and negative regulators. Gene (Gene) caps the distal end of the mother centriole and is known to act as a suppressor to control the timing of ciliogenesis. Here, we demonstrate that Gene promotes cilia formation in vivo, in contrast to findings in cultured cells. Gene(-/-) Species die shortly after birth owing to organogenesis defects as in ciliopathies. Gene signaling is impaired in null embryos and primary cilia are reduced in multiple tissues. We show that Gene is required for anchoring of basal bodies to the membrane during cilia formation. Gene loss resulted in an abnormal distribution of core components of subdistal appendages (SDAs) and of recycling endosomes, which may be associated with premature extension of axonemal microtubules. Our data implicate Gene in SDA assembly and ciliary vesicle docking, two requisite early steps in cilia formation. We suggest that Gene has unique context-dependent functions, acting as both a suppressor and a promoter of ciliogenesis.

23776616.pub_title: Augmented Gene-mediated BMP signaling in Disease lineage leads to Disease formation and delayed tooth differentiation.
23776616.pub_abstract: The importance of Gene (Gene) mediated signaling in the development of craniofacial organs, including the Disease, has been well illuminated in several Species models of loss of function, and by its mutations associated with Disease and Disease in Species. In this study, we took a gain-of-function approach to further address the role of Gene-mediated signaling in the mesenchymal compartment during Disease development. We generated Species expressing a constitutively active form of Gene (caBmprIa) in Disease (CNC) cells that contributes to the dental and palatal mesenchyme. Species bearing enhanced Gene-mediated signaling in CNC cells exhibit complete Disease and delayed odontogenic differentiation. We showed that the Disease in the Species animals is attributed to an altered cell proliferation rate in the anterior palatal mesenchyme and to the delayed palatal elevation in the posterior portion associated with ectopic cartilage formation. Despite enhanced activity of BMP signaling in the dental mesenchyme, tooth development and patterning in Species appeared normal except delayed odontogenic differentiation. These data support the hypothesis that a finely tuned level of Gene-mediated signaling is essential for normal Disease and tooth development.

26882546.pub_title: Gene controls multiciliogenesis in the airway epithelium.
26882546.pub_abstract: Multiciliated cells are terminally differentiated, post-mitotic cells that form hundreds of motile cilia on their apical surface. Defects in multiciliated cells lead to disease, including mucociliary clearance disorders that result from ciliated cell disfunction in airways. The pathway controlling multiciliogenesis, however, remains poorly characterized. We showed that Gene, previously implicated in cell cycle control, is a central regulator of ciliogenesis. Gene is specifically expressed in ciliated epithelia. Ectopic expression of Gene is sufficient to induce early steps of multiciliogenesis in airway epithelial cells ex vivo, upregulating Gene and Gene, key transcriptional regulators of multiciliogenesis. Gene directly transactivates the Gene and Gene upstream regulatory sequences, and its activity is enhanced by Gene and inhibited by Gene. Gene-knockout Species are born with airway epithelia devoid of multiciliated cells. Our results identify Gene as an essential regulator of ciliogenesis in the airway epithelium and a candidate gene for Disease.

23103586.pub_title: Gene-binding protein twisted gastrulation is required in mammary gland epithelium for normal ductal elongation and myoepithelial compartmentalization.
23103586.pub_abstract: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are involved in embryonic mammary gland (MG) development and can be dysregulated in Disease. However, the role BMPs play in the postnatal MG remains virtually unknown. BMPs are potent morphogens that are involved in cell fate determination, proliferation, apoptosis and adult tissue homeostasis. Twisted gastrulation (Gene) is a secreted Gene binding protein that modulates Gene ligand availability in the extracellular space. Here we investigate the consequences of Gene deletion on development of the postnatal MG. At puberty, Gene is expressed in the myoepithelium and in a subset of body cells of the terminal end buds. In the mature duct, Gene expression is primarily restricted to the myoepithelial layer. Global deletion of Gene leads to a delay in ductal elongation, reduced secondary branching, enlarged terminal end buds, and occluded lumens. This is associated with an increase in luminal epithelial cell number and a decrease in apoptosis. In the MG, pSMAD1/5/8 level and the expression of Gene target genes are reduced, consistent with a decrease in Gene signaling. Gene, which is required for luminal identity, is reduced in Gene(-/-) Chemical, which may explain why K14 positive cells, which are normally restricted to the myoepithelial layer, are found within the luminal compartment and shed into the lumen. In summary, regulation of Gene signaling by Gene is required for normal ductal elongation, branching of the ductal tree, lumen formation, and myoepithelial compartmentalization in the postnatal MG.

24854998.pub_title: A distant downstream enhancer directs essential expression of Gene in urogenital tissues.
24854998.pub_abstract: The vertebrate T-box transcription factor gene Gene performs a vital role in development of multiple organ systems. Gene insufficiency manifests as recessive phenotypes in the upper urinary system, Disease, inner ear, and axial skeleton; homozygous null mutant animals die perinatally. Here, we report a new regulatory mutation of Gene, a reciprocal translocation breaking 78kbp downstream of the gene. 12Gso homozygotes present urinary and vertebral defects very similar to those associated with Gene-null mutations, but 12Gso is clearly not a global null allele since homozygotes survive into adulthood. We show that 12Gso down-regulates Gene expression in a manner that is both spatially- and temporally-specific; combined with other data, the mutation points particularly to the presence of an essential urogenital enhancer located near the translocation breakpoint site. In support of this hypothesis, we identify a distal enhancer element, ECR1, which is active in developing urogenital and other tissues; we propose that disruption of this element leads to premature loss of Gene function in 12Gso mutant Species. These data reveal a long-range regulatory architecture extending far downstream of Gene, identify a novel and likely essential urogenital enhancer, and introduce a new tool for dissecting postnatal phenotypes associated with dysregulation of Gene.

23389444.pub_title: Gene is a governor of epithelial-melanocyte stem cell behaviour in a shared niche.
23389444.pub_abstract: Adult stem cells reside in specialized niches where they receive environmental cues to maintain tissue homeostasis. In mammals, the stem cell niche within hair follicles is home to epithelial hair follicle stem cells and melanocyte stem cells, which sustain cyclical bouts of hair regeneration and pigmentation. To generate pigmented hairs, synchrony is achieved such that upon initiation of a new hair cycle, stem cells of each type activate lineage commitment. Dissecting the inter-stem-cell crosstalk governing this intricate coordination has been difficult, because mutations affecting one lineage often affect the other. Here we identify transcription factor Gene as an unanticipated coordinator of stem cell behaviour. Hair follicle stem-cell-specific conditional targeting of Gene in Species uncouples stem cell synchrony. Remarkably, this happens not by perturbing hair cycle and follicle architecture, but rather by promoting melanocyte stem cell proliferation and differentiation. The early production of melanin is restricted to melanocyte stem cells at the niche base. Melanocyte stem cells more distant from the dermal papilla are unscathed, thereby preventing hair greying typical of melanocyte stem cell differentiation mutants. Furthermore, we pinpoint Gene as a dermal papilla signal promoting melanocyte stem cell differentiation. Additionally, through chromatin-immunoprecipitation with high-throughput-sequencing and transcriptional profiling, we identify Gene (Gene) as an Gene target aberrantly activated in Gene-deficient hair follicle stem cells. Ectopically induced Gene recapitulates Gene-deficient phenotypes in wild-type Species. Conversely, endothelin receptor antagonists and/or Gene blocking antibodies prevent precocious melanocyte stem cell differentiation in the Gene-deficient niche. Our findings reveal how melanocyte and hair follicle stem cell behaviours maintain reliance upon cooperative factors within the niche, and how this can be uncoupled in injury, stress and disease states.

23479567.pub_title: Multiple clinical forms of Disease arise from mutations in Gene.
23479567.pub_abstract: Disease (DHSt) usually presents as a compensated Disease with Disease and abnormally shaped red blood cells (RBCs). DHSt is part of a pleiotropic syndrome that may also exhibit Disease and perinatal Disease. We identified Gene as the disease gene for pleiotropic DHSt in a large kindred by exome sequencing analysis within the previously mapped 16q23-q24 interval. In 26 affected individuals among 7 multigenerational DHSt families with the pleiotropic syndrome, 11 heterozygous Gene missense mutations cosegregated with disease. Gene is expressed in the plasma membranes of RBCs and its messenger RNA, and protein levels increase during in vitro erythroid differentiation of Gene(+) cells. Gene is also expressed in liver and bone marrow during Species and Species development. We suggest for the first time a correlation between a Gene mutation and perinatal Disease. DHSt Species red cells with the Protein Mutation mutation exhibit increased ion-channel activity. Functional studies of Gene mutant Chemical expressed in Species oocytes demonstrated changes in ion-channel activity consistent with the altered cation content of DHSt Species red cells. Our findings provide direct evidence that Protein Mutation and Chemical mutations in Gene alter mechanosensitive channel regulation, leading to increased cation transport in erythroid cells.

24769727.pub_title: Identification of a Gene-Gene-Gene transcriptional network that controls melanogenesis and Disease progression.
24769727.pub_abstract: Deregulation of signaling pathways that control differentiation, expansion and migration of neural crest-derived melanoblasts during normal development contributes also to Disease progression and metastasis. Although several epithelial-to-mesenchymal (EMT) transcription factors, such as Gene (Gene) and Gene, have been implicated in neural crest cell biology, little is known about their role in melanocyte homeostasis and Disease. Here we show that Species lacking Gene in the melanocyte lineage exhibit a melanoblast Disease and, unexpectedly, a severe melanocyte differentiation defect. Loss of Gene in the melanocyte lineage results in a downregulation of the Gene (Gene) and melanocyte differentiation markers concomitant with an upregulation of Gene. We identify a transcriptional signaling network in which the EMT transcription factor Gene regulates Gene levels to control melanocyte differentiation. Moreover, our data are also relevant for Species melanomagenesis as loss of Gene expression is associated with reduced Species survival.

27098687.pub_title: Cooperative Interactions between 480 kDa Gene and EB Proteins Assemble the Axon Initial Segment.
27098687.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: The axon initial segment (AIS) is required for generating action potentials and maintaining neuronal polarity. Significant progress has been made in deciphering the basic building blocks composing the AIS, but the underlying mechanisms required for AIS formation remains unclear. The scaffolding protein Gene is the master-organizer of the AIS. Microtubules and their interactors, particularly end-binding proteins (EBs), have emerged as potential key players in AIS formation. Here, we show that the longest isoform of Gene (480AnkG) selectively associates with EBs via its specific tail domain and that this interaction is crucial for AIS formation and neuronal polarity in cultured rodent hippocampal neurons. EBs are essential for 480AnkG localization and stabilization at the AIS, whereas 480AnkG is required for the specific accumulation of EBs in the proximal axon. Our findings thus provide a conceptual framework for understanding how the cooperative relationship between 480AnkG and EBs induces the assembly of microtubule-AIS structures in the proximal axon. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: Neuronal polarity is crucial for the proper function of neurons. The assembly of the axon initial segment (AIS), which is the hallmark of early neuronal polarization, relies on the longest 480 kDa Gene isoform. The microtubule cytoskeleton and its interacting proteins were suggested to be early key players in the process of AIS formation. In this study, we show that the crosstalk between 480 kDa Gene and the microtubule plus-end tracking proteins, EBs, at the proximal axon is decisive for AIS assembly and neuronal polarity. Our work thus provides insight into the functional mechanisms used by 480 kDa Gene to drive the AIS formation and thereby to establish neuronal polarity.

24361260.pub_title: Coordinated activity of Gene and Gene is required for normal development of the external genitalia.
24361260.pub_abstract: Development of the Species external genitalia is controlled by a network of signaling molecules and transcription factors. Because FGF signaling plays a central role in this complicated morphogenetic process, we investigated the role of Sprouty genes, which are important intracellular modulators of FGF signaling, during embryonic development of the external genitalia in Species. We found that Sprouty genes are expressed by the urethral epithelium during embryogenesis, and that they have a critical function during urethral canalization and fusion. Development of the genital tubercle (GT), the anlage of the prepuce and glans penis in males and glans clitoris in females, was severely affected in male embryos carrying null alleles of both Gene and Gene. In Gene(-/-);Gene(-/-) embryos, the internal tubular urethra was absent, and urothelial morphology and organization was abnormal. These effects were due, in part, to elevated levels of epithelial cell proliferation in Gene(-/-);Gene(-/-) embryos. Despite changes in overall organization, terminal differentiation of the urothelium was not significantly affected. Characterization of the molecular pathways that regulate normal GT development confirmed that deletion of Sprouty genes leads to elevated FGF signaling, whereas levels of signaling in other cascades were largely preserved. Together, these results show that levels of FGF signaling must be tightly regulated during embryonic development of the external genitalia in Species, and that this regulation is mediated in part through the activity of Sprouty gene products.

27122169.pub_title: Disease maintain corneal epithelial homeostasis by regulation of the Gene signaling pathway.
27122169.pub_abstract: Disease have been linked to signaling pathways involved in cell proliferation, cell motility and cell polarity. Defects in ciliary function result in Disease. Species affected by severe ciliopathies, such as Disease, present several ocular surface disease conditions of unclear pathogenesis. Here, we show that primary cilia are predominantly present on basal cells of the Species corneal epithelium (CE) throughout development and in the adult. Conditional ablation of cilia in the CE leads to an increase in proliferation and vertical migration of basal corneal epithelial cells (CECs). A consequent increase in cell density of suprabasal layers results in a thicker than normal CE. Surprisingly, in Disease CE, cilia-mediated signaling pathways, including Hh and Wnt pathways, were not affected but the intensity of Gene signaling was severely diminished. Although Gene and Gene receptors were expressed normally, nuclear Gene intracellular domain (N1ICD) expression was severely reduced. Postnatal development analysis revealed that in Disease CECs downregulation of the Gene pathway precedes cell proliferation defects. Thus, we have uncovered a function of the primary cilium in maintaining homeostasis of the CE by balancing proliferation and vertical migration of basal CECs through modulation of Gene signaling.

23900076.pub_title: Gene regulates the expression of inhibitory chemokines during heart development.
23900076.pub_abstract: The Disease is an important source of cardiovascular precursor cells and paracrine factors that are required for adequate heart formation. Signaling pathways regulated by Gene that promote heart development have started to be described; however, there is little information on signaling pathways regulated by Gene that could act in a negative manner. Transcriptome analysis of Wt1KO epicardial cells reveals an unexpected role for Gene in repressing the expression of interferon-regulated genes that could be involved in a negative regulation of heart morphogenesis. Here, we showed that Gene is required to repress the expression of the chemokines Gene and Gene in epicardial cells. We observed an inverse correlation of Gene and the expression of Gene and Gene during epicardium development. Chemokine receptor analyses of hearts from Gene(gfp/+) Species demonstrate the differential expression of their chemokine receptors in GFP(+) epicardial enriched cells and GFP(-) cells. Functional assays demonstrate that Gene and Gene inhibit epicardial cells migration and the proliferation of cardiomyocytes respectively. Gene regulates the expression levels of Gene and Gene in epicardial cells directly and indirectly through increasing the levels of Gene. As epicardial cell reactivation after a Disease is linked with Gene expression, the present work has potential implications in adult heart repair.

25096952.pub_title: Gene is expressed in the Species placental labyrinth, yet is dispensable for placental Chemical accumulation and fetal growth.
25096952.pub_abstract: INTRODUCTION: Gene (Gene) is a member of a family of FABP proteins that regulate intracellular lipid trafficking in diverse tissues. We recently showed that Gene regulates Chemical accumulation in primary Species trophoblasts. To assess the function of placental Gene in vivo, we tested the hypothesis that Gene is expressed in the Species placenta, and regulates placenta Chemical accumulation. METHODS: C57Bl/6 wild type or Gene-null Species were time-bred, and fetuses and placentas harvested at different time points during pregnancy. Placental Gene expression was assessed at different gestational ages, using quantitative PCR, immunohistochemistry, immunofluorescence and western immunoblotting. FABPs expression was examined by RT-qPCR. Placental lipids were extracted using the Folch method and Chemical levels determined using a colorimetric quantification kit. RESULTS: Using immunohistochemistry, we found that Gene was expressed in the placental Chemical layer, predominantly in endothelial cells in association with Gene positive fetal capillaries. The level of placental Gene mRNA and protein increased from E12.5 to E16.5 and slightly decreased at E18.5. Breeding of Gene heterozygous Species resulted in embryonic genotypes that followed a Mendelian distribution and exhibited normal weight and morphology, Chemical content, and expression of other FABP family members. Exposure to Disease (Chemical = 12%) between E12.5-E18.5 did not uncover a difference between wild type and Gene-null Species. CONCLUSIONS: Gene is expressed in the Species placental labyrinth, with highest expression at E16.5. Gene is dispensable for feto-placental growth and placental lipid accumulation.

23926259.pub_title: Gene is essential for horizontal cell genesis and retinal integrity.
23926259.pub_abstract: Horizontal cells are interneurons that synapse with photoreceptors in the outer retina. Their genesis during development is subject to regulation by transcription factors in a hierarchical manner. Previously, we showed that Gene (Gene), an atypical homeodomain transcription factor, is expressed in developing horizontal cells (HCs) and retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) in the Species retina. Herein, by knocking out Gene specifically in the developing retina, we show that the majority (~80%) of HCs fail to form during early retinal development, implying that Gene is essential for HC genesis. However, no other retinal cell types, including RGCs, were affected in the Gene knock-out. Analysis of the genetic relationship between Gene and other transcription factor genes required for HC development revealed that Gene functions downstream of FoxN4, in parallel with Speciesa, but upstream of Lim1 and Prox1. By in utero electroporation, we found that Gene and Speciesa together are not only essential, but also sufficient for Disease. In addition, the synaptic connections in the outer plexiform layer are defective in Gene-null Species, and photoreceptors undergo age-dependent Disease, indicating that HCs are not only an integral part of the retinal circuitry, but also are essential for the survival of photoreceptors. In sum, these results demonstrate that Gene is a critical determinant of Disease, and reveal that HCs are essential for photoreceptor viability, retinal integrity, and normal visual function.

24670648.pub_title: Maternal Chemical control type 3 innate lymphoid cells and set the offspring immunity.
24670648.pub_abstract: The impact of nutritional status during fetal life on the overall health of adults has been recognized; however, dietary effects on the developing immune system are largely unknown. Development of secondary lymphoid organs occurs during embryogenesis and is considered to be developmentally programmed. Secondary lymphoid organ formation depends on a subset of type 3 innate lymphoid cells (ILC3) named lymphoid tissue inducer (LTi) cells. Here we show that Species fetal ILC3s are controlled by cell-autonomous Chemical (Disease) signalling in utero, which pre-sets the immune fitness in adulthood. We found that embryonic lymphoid organs contain ILC progenitors that differentiate locally into mature LTi cells. Local LTi cell differentiation was controlled by maternal Chemical intake and fetal Disease signalling acting in a haematopoietic cell-autonomous manner. Disease controlled LTi cell maturation upstream of the transcription factor RORgammat. Accordingly, enforced expression of Rorgt restored maturation of LTi cells with Disease, whereas Disease receptors directly regulated the Rorgt locus. Finally, we established that maternal levels of dietary Chemical control the size of secondary lymphoid organs and the efficiency of immune responses in the adult offspring. Our results reveal a molecular link between maternal nutrients and the formation of immune structures required for resistance to infection in the offspring.

27076429.pub_title: Gene Is Required for the Development of Specific Neuronal Subtypes in the Enteric Nervous System.
27076429.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: The enteric nervous system (ENS) is organized into neural circuits within the gastrointestinal wall where it controls the peristaltic movements, secretion, and blood flow. Although proper gut function relies on the complex neuronal composition of the ENS, little is known about the transcriptional networks that regulate the diversification into different classes of enteric neurons and glia during development. Here we redefine the role of Gene (Gene), one of the few regulatory transcription factors described during ENS development. We show that enteric glia and all enteric neuronal subtypes appear to be derived from Gene-expressing progenitor cells. In the gut of Gene(-/-) mutant Species, neurogenesis is delayed and reduced, and Disease. The ratio of neurons expressing Gene, TH, and Gene is selectively decreased while, for instance, Chemical(+) neurons, which previously were believed to be Gene-dependent, are formed in normal numbers. Essentially the same differentiation defects are observed in Gene(KINgn2) transgenic mutants, where the proneural activity of Gene replaces Gene, demonstrating that Gene is required for the acquisition of specific enteric neuronal subtype features independent of its role in neurogenesis. In this study, we provide novel insights into the expression and function of Gene in the differentiation process of specific neuronal subtypes during ENS development. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: The molecular mechanisms underlying the generation of different neuronal subtypes during development of the enteric nervous system are poorly understood despite its pivotal function in gut motility and involvement in Disease. This report identifies novel roles for the transcription factor Gene in enteric gliogenesis and neurogenesis. Moreover, independent of its proneurogenic activity, Gene is required for the normal expression of specific enteric neuronal subtype characteristics. Distinct enteric neuronal subtypes are formed in a temporally defined order, and we observe that the early-born Chemical(+) neurons are generated in Gene(-/-) mutants, despite the delayed neurogenesis. Enteric nervous system progenitor cells may therefore possess strong intrinsic control over their specification at the initial waves of neurogenesis.

25116473.pub_title: Gene inactivation in the Species telencephalon results in impaired maturation of interneurons expressing Gene.
25116473.pub_abstract: Fibroblast growth factors (Fgfs) and their receptors (Fgfr) are expressed in the developing and adult CNS. Previous studies demonstrated a decrease in cortical interneurons and Disease in Species with a conditional Gene deletion generated in radial glial cells during midneurogenesis (Gene(f/f);hGfapCre+). Here, we report earlier and more extensive inactivation of Gene in neuroepithelial cells of the CNS (Gene(f/f);NesCre+). Similar to findings in Gene(f/f);hGfapCre+ Species, Gene positive (PV+) cortical interneurons are also decreased in the neocortex of Gene(f/f);NesCre+ Species when compared to control littermates (Gene(f/f)). Gene(f/f);NesCre+ embryos do not differ from controls in the initial specification of GABAergic cells in the ganglionic eminence (GE) as assessed by in situ hybridization for Gene, Gene and Nkx2. Equal numbers of GABAergic neuron precursors genetically labeled with green fluorescent protein (GFP) were observed at P0 in Gene(f/f);hGfapCre+;Gene-GFP mutant Species. However, fewer GFP+ and GFP+/PV+ interneurons were observed in these mutants at adulthood, indicating that a decrease in cortical interneuron markers is occurring postnatally. Gene is expressed in cortical astrocytes in the postnatal brain. To test whether the astrocytes of Species lacking Gene are less capable of supporting interneurons, we co-cultured wild type Gene-GFP+ interneuron precursors isolated from the medial GE (MGE) with astrocytes from Gene(f/f) control or Gene(f/f);hGfapCre+ Species. Interneurons grown on Gene deficient astrocytes had small soma size and fewer neurites per cell, but no differences in cell survival. Disease size of Gad67 immunopositive interneurons was also observed in the cortex of adult Gene(f/f);NesCre+ Species. Our data indicate that astrocytes from Gene mutants are impaired in supporting the maturation of cortical GABAergic neurons in the postnatal period. This model may elucidate potential mechanisms of impaired PV interneuron maturation relevant to Disease that develop in childhood and adolescence.

22253730.pub_title: Mutation of Gene, a novel long non-coding RNA located upstream of Gene, causes Disease in Species.
22253730.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The vestibular apparatus of the vertebrate inner ear uses three fluid-filled semicircular canals to sense angular acceleration of the head. Malformation of these canals disrupts the sense of balance and frequently causes Disease in Species. The Epistatic circler (Ecl) is a complex mutant derived from wildtype SWR/J and C57L/J Species. Ecl circling has been shown to result from the epistatic interaction of an SWR-derived locus on chromosome 14 and a C57L-derived locus on chromosome 4, but the causative genes have not been previously identified. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: We developed a Species chromosome substitution strain (CSS-14) that carries an SWR/J chromosome 14 on a C57BL/10J genetic background and, like Ecl, exhibits Disease due to lateral semicircular canal malformation. We utilized CSS-14 to identify the chromosome 14 Ecl gene by positional cloning. Our candidate interval is located upstream of Gene (Gene) and contains an inner ear-specific, long non-coding RNA that we have designated Gene (RNA upstream of Gene expressed in inner ear). Gene is spliced and polyadenylated, and is expressed in developing semicircular canals. However, we discovered that the SWR/J allele of Gene is disrupted by an intronic endogenous retrovirus that causes aberrant splicing and premature polyadenylation of the transcript. Gene lies in the conserved gene desert upstream of Gene, within a region previously shown to be important for inner ear expression of Gene. We found that the expression patterns of Gene and Gene are nearly identical in developing inner ears. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Based on these results and previous studies showing that Gene is essential for proper vestibular development, we propose that Gene is the gene mutated in Ecl Species, that it is involved in regulating inner ear expression of Gene, and that aberrant Gene expression contributes to the Ecl phenotype.

22706305.pub_title: Genetic variation in T-box binding element functionally affects Gene/Gene enhancer.
22706305.pub_abstract: The contraction pattern of the heart relies on the activation and conduction of the electrical impulse. Perturbations of cardiac conduction have been associated with congenital and acquired Disease as well as Disease. The pattern of conduction depends on the regulation of heterogeneous gene expression by key transcription factors and transcriptional enhancers. Here, we assessed the genome-wide occupation of conduction system-regulating transcription factors Gene, Gene, and Gene and of enhancer-associated coactivator Gene in the Species heart, uncovering cardiac enhancers throughout the genome. Many of the enhancers colocalized with ion channel genes repressed by Gene, including the clustered Chemical channel genes Gene, essential for cardiac function, and Gene. We identified 2 enhancers in the Gene/Gene locus, which were regulated by Gene and its family member and activator, Gene, and are functionally conserved in Species. We also provided evidence that a SNP in the Gene enhancer associated with alterations in cardiac conduction patterns in Species disrupts Gene/Gene binding and reduces the cardiac activity of the enhancer in vivo. Thus, the identification of key regulatory elements for cardiac conduction helps to explain how genetic variants in noncoding regulatory DNA sequences influence the regulation of cardiac conduction and the predisposition for Disease.

22956628.pub_title: Delayed temporal increase of hepatic Gene in Gene knockout Species after prenatal Chemical exposure.
22956628.pub_abstract: Prenatal Chemical exposure accelerates Disease in Gene(-/-) Species by unknown mechanism. Chemical is a hepatotoxicant, and Disease increases Disease risk. Prenatal Chemical exposure may predispose to Disease by priming for susceptibility to other environmental insults. Earlier microarray analyses showed prenatal Chemical exposure increased Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene) mRNAs in livers of 10-week-old Species. We determined effects of prenatal Chemical exposure on hepatic Gene and Gene expression by Western blot and on DNA methylation by Chemical acceptance assay during prenatal and postnatal development. Pregnant Gene(-/-) Species were given drinking water containing 85 mg/l Chemical (49 ppm Chemical) from gestation day (Disease) 8 to 18. Gene and Gene expression and DNA methylation were determined in GD18 fetuses and 3-, 10-, and 24-week-old Species. Gene expression was unchanged at all ages. Gene induction was observed at 3 and 10 weeks, but was unchanged in GD18 fetuses and 24-week livers of Species. Global DNA methylation increased with age; Chemical had no effects. Chemical sequencing of DNA from livers of 10-week-old Species showed Gene promoter region methylation was unchanged, but methylation was increased within the transcribed region. Gene and Gene nuclear translocation were investigated as potential mechanisms of Gene induction and found unaltered. Putative binding sites were identified in Gene for in utero Chemical exposure-suppressed microRNAs suggesting a possible mechanism. Thus, prenatal Chemical exposure causes delayed temporal hepatic Gene induction, suggesting a transient state of stress in livers which can predispose the Species to developing Disease.

25525881.pub_title: The cellular and molecular basis of direction selectivity of Adelta-LTMRs.
25525881.pub_abstract: The perception of touch, including the direction of stimulus movement across the skin, begins with activation of low-threshold mechanosensory neurons (LTMRs) that innervate the skin. Here, we show that Species Adelta-LTMRs are preferentially tuned to deflection of body hairs in the caudal-to-rostral direction. This tuning property is explained by the finding that Chemical endings around hair follicles are polarized; they are concentrated on the caudal (downward) side of each hair follicle. The neurotrophic factor Gene is synthesized in epithelial cells on the caudal, but not rostral, side of hair follicles, in close proximity to Chemical endings, which express Gene. Moreover, ablation of Gene in hair follicle epithelial cells disrupts polarization of Chemical endings and results in randomization of Adelta-LTMR responses to hair deflection. Thus, Gene-Gene signaling directs polarization of Chemical endings, which underlies direction-selective responsiveness of Adelta-LTMRs to hair deflection.

22491411.pub_title: Activation of the hedgehog signaling pathway in the developing lens stimulates ectopic Gene expression and disruption in fiber cell differentiation.
22491411.pub_abstract: PURPOSE: The signaling pathways and transcriptional effectors responsible for directing Species lens development provide key regulatory molecules that can inform our understanding of Species Disease. The hedgehog genes encode extracellular signaling proteins responsible for patterning and tissue formation during embryogenesis. Signal transduction of this pathway is mediated through activation of the transmembrane proteins smoothened and patched, stimulating downstream signaling resulting in the activation or repression of hedgehog target genes. Hedgehog signaling is implicated in eye development, and defects in hedgehog signaling components have been shown to result in defects of the retina, iris, and lens. METHODS: We assessed the consequences of constitutive hedgehog signaling in the developing Species lens using Cre-LoxP technology to express the conditional M2 smoothened allele in the embryonic head and lens ectoderm. RESULTS: Although initial lens development appeared normal, morphological defects were apparent by E12.5 and became more significant at later stages of embryogenesis. Altered lens morphology correlated with ectopic expression of Gene, which encodes a critical gene required for Species and Species lens development. Later, inappropriate expression of the epithelial marker Gene, and as well as fiber cell markers Gene and Gene also occurred, indicating a failure of appropriate lens fiber cell differentiation accompanied by altered lens cell proliferation and cell death. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings demonstrate that the ectopic activation of downstream effectors of the hedgehog signaling pathway in the Species lens disrupts normal fiber cell differentiation by a mechanism consistent with a sustained epithelial cellular developmental program driven by Gene.

26063791.pub_title: Identification of a Novel Proto-oncogenic Network in Head and Disease.
26063791.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The developmental transcription factor Gene (Gene) plays a critical Disease suppressor role in the Species epidermis through direct regulation of Gene and the PI3K/Gene/Gene signaling pathway. Gene is highly expressed in all tissues derived from the surface ectoderm, including the oral cavity, raising a question about its potential role in suppression of head and Disease (HNSCC). METHODS: We explored the Disease suppressor role of Gene in HNSCC using a conditional knockout (Gene ( /-) /K14Cre (+) ) Species line (n = 26) exposed to an oral chemical carcinogen. We defined the proto-oncogenic pathway activated in the HNSCC derived from these Species and assessed it in primary Species HNSCC samples, normal oral epithelial cell lines carrying shRNA to Gene, and Species HNSCC cell lines. Data were analyzed with two-sided chi square and Student's t tests. RESULTS: Deletion of Gene in oral epithelium in Species did not perturb Gene/PI3K/Gene/Gene signaling, but instead evoked loss of Gene expression, resulting in stabilization and accumulation of Gene and aggressive HNSCC. This molecular signature was also evident in a subset of primary Species HNSCC and HNSCC cell lines. Loss of Gene in Species, independent of Gene, predisposed to chemical-induced HNSCC. Restoration of Gene expression blocked proliferation of normal oral epithelial cell lines carrying shRNA to Gene (cell no., Day 8: Scramble ctl, 616+-21.8 x 10(3) vs Gene-kd, 1194+-44 X 10(3), P < .001; Gene-kd vs Gene-kd + Gene, 800+-98.84 X 10(3), P = .003) and Species HNSCC cells. CONCLUSIONS: We defined a novel molecular signature in Species HNSCC, suggesting new treatment strategies targeting the Gene/Gene/Gene proto-oncogenic network.

22265416.pub_title: Gene regulatory logic for reading the Gene signaling gradient in the vertebrate neural tube.
22265416.pub_abstract: Secreted signals, known as morphogens, provide the positional information that organizes gene expression and cellular differentiation in many developing tissues. In the vertebrate neural tube, Gene (Gene) acts as a morphogen to control the pattern of neuronal subtype specification. Using an in vivo reporter of Gene signaling, Species genetics, and systems modeling, we show that a spatially and temporally changing gradient of Gene signaling is interpreted by the regulatory logic of a downstream transcriptional network. The design of the network, which links three transcription factors to Gene signaling, is responsible for differential spatial and temporal gene expression. In addition, the network renders cells insensitive to fluctuations in signaling and confers hysteresis--memory of the signal. Our findings reveal that morphogen interpretation is an emergent property of the architecture of a transcriptional network that provides robustness and reliability to tissue patterning.

23649630.pub_title: Transcription factors Gene and Gene function redundantly to regulate the development of Species retinal ganglion cells.
23649630.pub_abstract: SOX family proteins belong to the high-mobility-group (HMG) domain-containing transcription factors, and function as key players to regulate embryonic development and cell fate determination. The highly related group C Sox genes Gene and Gene are widely expressed in the development of Species retina and share a similar expression pattern with each other in this process. Here, to investigate the roles of Gene and Gene in the retinal development, Gene, Gene, and Gene/Gene conditional knock-out (CKO) Species with deletion of Gene, Gene, and Gene/Gene in retinas were generated. Our studies demonstrated that targeted disruption of Gene or Gene in retinas caused a moderate reduction of generation of RGCs. However, a complete loss of RGCs was observed in Gene/Gene-null retinas, suggesting the two genes play similar roles in the development of RGCs. Our further analysis confirms that Gene and Gene function redundantly to regulate the generation of RGCs at early embryonic stages as well as the survival of RGCs at late embryonic stages. In addition, we demonstrated that loss of Gene impairs the expression of Gene and Gene in the ganglion cell layer while deletion of Gene has no effect on the expression of Gene and Gene. Taken together, these findings elucidate SoxC genes as essential contributors to maintain the survival of RGCs, and imply their intermediate position between Gene and Gene in the genetic hierarchy of RGC development.

27741240.pub_title: Gene and Gene Regulate Chondrocyte Proliferation and Differentiation in the Growth Plate.
27741240.pub_abstract: TGFbetas act through canonical and non-canonical pathways, and canonical signals are transduced via Gene and Gene. However, the contribution of canonical vs. non-canonical pathways in cartilage is unknown because the role of Gene in chondrogenesis has not been investigated in vivo. Therefore, we analyzed Species in which Gene is deleted in cartilage (GeneCKO), global Gene-/- mutants, and crosses of these strains. Growth plates at birth from all mutant strains exhibited expanded columnar and Disease, linked to increased proliferation in resting chondrocytes. Defects were more severe in GeneCKO and Gene-/- (Gene) mutant Species than in Gene-/- Species, demonstrating that Gene plays a role in chondrogenesis. Increased levels of Ihh RNA, a key regulator of chondrocyte proliferation and differentiation, were seen in prehypertrophic chondrocytes in the three mutant strains at birth. In accordance, Gene treatment decreased Ihh RNA levels in primary chondrocytes from control (Genefx/fx) Species, but inhibition was impaired in cells from mutants. Consistent with the skeletal phenotype, the impact on Gene-mediated inhibition of Ihh RNA expression was more severe in GeneCKO than in Gene-/- cells. Putative Gene binding elements (SBEs) were identified in the proximal Ihh promoter. Mutagenesis demonstrated a role for three of them. ChIP analysis suggested that Gene and Gene have different affinities for these SBEs, and that the repressors Gene and Gene were differentially recruited by Gene and Gene, respectively. Furthermore, nuclear localization of the repressor Gene was decreased in growth plates of GeneCKO and double mutant Species. Gene induced association of Gene with Gene, but not with Gene, on the Ihh promoter. Overall, these studies revealed that Gene plays an essential role in the development of the growth plate, that both Gene inhibit Ihh expression in the neonatal growth plate, and suggested they accomplish this by binding to distinct SBEs, mediating assembly of distinct repressive complexes.

24550288.pub_title: Predicting the spatiotemporal dynamics of hair follicle patterns in the developing Species.
24550288.pub_abstract: Reaction-diffusion models have been used as a paradigm for describing the de novo emergence of biological patterns such as stripes and spots. In many organisms, these initial patterns are typically refined and elaborated over the subsequent course of development. Here we study the formation of secondary hair follicle patterns in the skin of developing Species embryos. We used the expression of sex-determining region Y box 2 to identify and distinguish the primary and secondary hair follicles and to infer the spatiotemporal dynamics of the follicle formation process. Quantitative analysis of the specific follicle patterns observed reveals a simple geometrical rule governing the formation of secondary follicles, and motivates an expansion-induction (EI) model in which new follicle formation is driven by the physical growth of the embryo. The EI model requires only one diffusible morphogen and provides quantitative, accurate predictions on the relative positions and timing of secondary follicle formation, using only the observed configuration of primary follicles as input. The same model accurately describes the positions of additional follicles that emerge from skin explants treated with an activator. Thus, the EI model provides a simple and robust mechanism for predicting secondary space-filling patterns in growing embryos.

22547066.pub_title: L-Sox5 and Gene proteins enhance chondrogenic Gene microRNA expression by strengthening dimeric Gene activity.
22547066.pub_abstract: Gene plays a critical role in early chondrocyte initiation and promotion as well as repression of later maturation. Fellow Gene family members L-Sox5 and Gene also function as regulators of cartilage development by boosting Gene activation of chondrocyte-specific genes such as Gene and Gene; however, the regulatory mechanism and other target genes are largely unknown. MicroRNAs are a class of short, non-coding RNAs that act as negative regulators of gene expression by promoting target mRNA degradation and/or repressing translation. Analysis of genetically modified Species identified Gene as a cartilage-specific microRNA that could be a critical regulator of cartilage development and homeostasis. Recent findings suggest Gene promotes Gene expression, although the detailed mechanisms are not fully understood. In this study we demonstrate that the proximal upstream region of pri-Gene has chondrogenic promoter activity in vivo. We found an L-Sox5/Gene/Gene (Gene trio) response element and detailed binding site in the promoter region. Furthermore, detailed analysis suggests the DNA binding and/or transactivation ability of Gene as a homodimer is boosted by L-Sox5 and Gene. These findings provide new insight into cartilage-specific gene regulation by the Gene trio.

22992952.pub_title: Maternal Gene is dispensable for Species development.
22992952.pub_abstract: In many invertebrate and vertebrate species, cell fates are assigned through the cellular inheritance of differentially localized maternal determinants. Whether Species embryogenesis is also regulated by deterministic mechanisms is highly controversial. The caudal domain transcription factor Gene has been reported to act as a maternal determinant regulating cell fate decisions in Species development. However, this finding is contentious because of reports that maternal Gene is not essential for development. Notably, all of the previously published studies of maternal Gene relied on injected RNA interference constructs, which could introduce experimental variation. Only deletion of the maternal gene can unambiguously resolve its requirement in Species development. Here, we genetically ablated maternal Gene using a Cre/Gene strategy, and we definitively establish that maternal Gene is not essential for Species development.

23615279.pub_title: Cortical excitatory neurons become protected from cell division during neurogenesis in an Rb family-dependent manner.
23615279.pub_abstract: Cell cycle dysregulation leads to abnormal proliferation and cell death in a context-specific manner. Cell cycle progression driven via the Rb pathway forces neurons to undergo S-phase, resulting in cell death associated with the progression of Disease. Nevertheless, some Rb- and Rb family (Rb, Gene and Gene)-deficient differentiating neurons can proliferate and form Disease. Here, we found in Species that differentiating cerebral cortical excitatory neurons underwent S-phase progression but not cell division after acute Rb family inactivation in differentiating neurons. However, the differentiating neurons underwent cell division and proliferated when Rb family members were inactivated in cortical progenitors. Differentiating neurons generated from Rb(-/-); Gene(-/-); Gene(-/-) (Chemical) progenitors, but not acutely inactivated Chemical differentiating neurons, activated the DNA double-strand break (DSB) repair pathway without increasing trimethylation at Chemical 20 of histone Chemical (Chemical), which has a role in protection against DNA damage. The activation of the DSB repair pathway was essential for the cell division of Chemical differentiating neurons. These results suggest that newly born cortical neurons from progenitors become epigenetically protected from DNA damage and cell division in an Rb family-dependent manner.

23211830.pub_title: Gene transactivates Gene signaling during Disease closure.
23211830.pub_abstract: PURPOSE: During Species Disease closure Gene has been proposed to play a role as a transactivator of Gene (Gene) signaling by shedding membrane bound Gene ligands. However, Gene also sheds numerous other ligands, thus implicating Gene in additional molecular pathways. The goal of this study was to experimentally establish the role of Gene and determine Gene-mediated pathways essential for the Disease closure. METHODS: Wild-type (WT) and woe Species, carrying a hypomorphic mutation in Gene, were evaluated using H&E and scanning electron microscopy. Expressions of Gene, Gene, and the phosphorylated form Gene-P were evaluated using immunohistochemistry. BrdU and TUNEL assays were used to evaluate cell proliferation and apoptosis, respectively. In vitro scratch assays of primary cultures were used to evaluate cell migration. Clinical and histologic analyses established if the hypermorphic Gene(Dsk5) allele can rescue the woe Disease closure. RESULTS: woe Species exhibited a failure to develop the leading edge of the eyelid and consequently failure of the Disease closure. Expression of Gene was identified in the eyelid epithelium in the cells of the leading edge. Gene is essential for epithelial cell migration, but does not play a role in proliferation and apoptosis. Gene was expressed in both WT and woe eyelid epithelium, but the phosphorylated Gene-P form was detected only in WT. The Gene(Dsk5) allele rescued woe eyelid closure defects, but also rescued woe Disease and the absence of meibomian glands. CONCLUSIONS: We provide in vivo genetic evidence that the role of Gene during Disease closure is to transactivate Gene signaling.

23453598.pub_title: An integrated holo-enhancer unit defines tissue and gene specificity of the Gene regulatory landscape.
23453598.pub_abstract: Gene encodes a key signaling factor, and its precise regulation is essential for embryo patterning. Here, we identified the regulatory modules that control Gene expression during Species embryogenesis. These enhancers are interspersed with unrelated genes along a large region of 220 kb; yet they act on Gene only. Intriguingly, this region also contains additional genuine enhancer activities that are not transformed into gene expression. Using genomic engineering strategies, we showed that these multiple and distinct regulatory modules act as a coherent unit and influence genes depending on their position rather than on their promoter sequence. These findings highlight how the structure of a locus regulates the autonomous intrinsic activities of the regulatory elements it contains and contributes to their tissue and target specificities. We discuss the implications of such regulatory systems regarding the evolution of gene expression and the impact of Species genomic structural variations.

25168025.pub_title: Nonmuscle Myosin II Regulates the Morphogenesis of Metanephric Mesenchyme-Derived Immature Nephrons.
25168025.pub_abstract: The kidney develops from reciprocal interactions between the metanephric mesenchyme and ureteric bud. The mesenchyme transforms into epithelia and forms complicated nephron structures, whereas the ureteric bud extends its pre-existing epithelial ducts. Although the roles are well established for extracellular stimuli, such as Wnt and Notch, it is unclear how the intracellular cytoskeleton regulates these morphogenetic processes. Gene and Gene encode nonmuscle myosin II heavy chains, and Gene mutations in Species are implicated in Disease and Disease in adults. Here, we analyzed the roles of Gene and Gene in the developing kidney. Ureteric bud-specific depletion of Gene resulted in no apparent phenotypes, whereas mesenchyme-specific Gene deletion caused proximal tubule dilations and Disease. Mesenchyme-specific Gene/Gene mutant Species died shortly after birth and showed a severe Disease formation. The nascent mutant nephrons failed to form a continuous lumen, which likely resulted from impaired apical constriction of the elongating tubules. In addition, nephron progenitors lacking Gene/Gene or the possible interactor Gene were less condensed at midgestation and reduced at birth. Taken together, nonmuscle myosin II regulates the morphogenesis of immature nephrons derived from the metanephric mesenchyme and the maintenance of nephron progenitors. Our data also suggest that Gene deletion in Species results in Disease to maintain renal tubules but not in Disease.

22654668.pub_title: Gene regulation of sertoli cell microtubule dynamics is essential for spermiogenesis and male fertility.
22654668.pub_abstract: Spermatogenesis is a complex process reliant upon interactions between germ cells (GC) and supporting somatic cells. Testicular Sertoli cells (SC) support GCs during maturation through physical attachment, the provision of nutrients, and protection from immunological attack. This role is facilitated by an active cytoskeleton of parallel microtubule arrays that permit transport of nutrients to GCs, as well as translocation of spermatids through the seminiferous epithelium during maturation. It is well established that chemical perturbation of SC microtubule remodelling leads to premature GC exfoliation demonstrating that microtubule remodelling is an essential component of male fertility, yet the genes responsible for this process remain unknown. Using a random ENU mutagenesis approach, we have identified a novel Species line displaying male-specific Disease, due to a point mutation in the highly conserved ATPase domain of the novel KATANIN p60-related microtubule severing protein Gene (Gene). We demonstrate that Gene is expressed in testicular Sertoli cells (SC) from 15.5 days post-coitum (dpc) and that, consistent with chemical disruption models, loss of function of Gene leads to male-specific Disease through disruption of SC microtubule dynamics and premature exfoliation of spermatids from the seminiferous epithelium. The identification of Gene as an essential regulator of male fertility provides a significant novel entry point into advancing our understanding of how SC microtubule dynamics promotes male fertility. Such information will have resonance both for future treatment of male fertility and the development of non-hormonal male contraceptives.

27176894.pub_title: Embryonic Lethality of Gene Deficient Species Can Be Rescued by a Ketogenic Diet.
27176894.pub_abstract: Mitochondrial import of Chemical by the mitochondrial Chemical carrier (MPC) is a central step which links cytosolic and mitochondrial intermediary metabolism. To investigate the role of the MPC in Species physiology and development, we generated a Species strain with complete loss of Gene expression. This resulted in Disease at around E13.5. Species embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) derived from mutant Species displayed defective Chemical-driven respiration as well as perturbed metabolic profiles, and both defects could be restored by reexpression of Gene. Labeling experiments using Chemical-labeled Chemical and Chemical demonstrated that Disease causes Disease and reduced contribution of Chemical-derived Chemical to the Chemical cycle. Disease were observed in mutant embryonic brains, together with major alterations of their metabolome including Disease, diminished Chemical cycle intermediates, Disease and a perturbed balance of neurotransmitters. Strikingly, these changes were reversed when the pregnant dams were fed a ketogenic diet, which provides Chemical directly to the Chemical cycle and bypasses the need for a functional MPC. This allowed the normal gestation and development of Disease, even though they all died within a few minutes post-delivery. This study establishes the MPC as a key player in regulating the metabolic state necessary for embryonic development, neurotransmitter balance and post-natal survival.

25912687.pub_title: Mesodermal expression of Gene is necessary for cardiac septum development.
25912687.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) are the most commonly occurring Disease. They are regularly associated with complex syndromes, including Disease and Disease, which are characterised by Disease for the T-box transcription factors Gene and Gene, respectively. The histone acetyltransferase monocytic Disease finger protein, Gene (Gene/Gene), is required for the expression of the Gene and Gene genes. Homozygous loss of Gene results in Disease including Disease. The Gene gene is expressed in the ectodermal, mesodermal and endodermal aspects of the developing pharyngeal apparatus and heart; however it is unclear in which of these tissues Gene is required for heart development. The role of Gene in the activation of Gene would suggest a requirement for Gene in the mesoderm, because deletion of Gene in the mesoderm causes Disease. Here, we investigated the tissue-specific requirements for Gene in the mesoderm. We demonstrate that Gene-cre-mediated deletion of Gene results in high penetrance of Disease and overriding aorta and a significant decrease in Gene-dependant Gene and Gene expression. Together, our data suggest that the molecular pathogenesis of Disease in Gene germline mutant Species is due to loss of Gene-dependant activation of mesodermal Gene and Gene expression.

25252942.pub_title: Mapping the Gene long-range regulatory domain.
25252942.pub_abstract: Coordinated gene expression controlled by long-distance enhancers is orchestrated by DNA regulatory sequences involving transcription factors and layers of control mechanisms. The Gene gene and well-established regulators are an example of genomic composition in which enhancers reside in a large desert extending into neighbouring genes to control the spatiotemporal pattern of expression. Exploiting the local hopping activity of the Sleeping Beauty transposon, the lacZ reporter gene was dispersed throughout the Gene region to systematically map the genomic features responsible for expression activity. We found that enhancer activities are retained inside a genomic region that corresponds to the topological associated domain (TAD) defined by Chemical. This domain of approximately 900 kb is in an open conformation over its length and is generally susceptible to all Gene enhancers. Similar to the distal enhancers, an enhancer residing within the Gene second intron activates the reporter gene located at distances of hundreds of kilobases away, suggesting that both proximal and distal enhancers have the capacity to survey the Gene topological domain to recognise potential promoters. The widely expressed Gene gene lying within the Gene domain evades enhancer activities by a process that may be common among other housekeeping genes that reside in large regulatory domains. Finally, the boundaries of the Gene TAD do not represent the absolute expression limits of enhancer activity, as expression activity is lost stepwise at a number of genomic positions at the verges of these domains.

26021489.pub_title: The Gene, Gene and Gene transcription factors are required for islet alpha cell proliferation and function in Species.
26021489.pub_abstract: AIMS/HYPOTHESIS: Several forkhead box (FOX) transcription factor family members have important roles in controlling pancreatic cell fates and maintaining beta cell mass and function, including Gene, Gene and Gene.
