In this study we have examined the importance of Gene, Gene and Gene of the FOXP subfamily in islet cell development and function. METHODS: Species harbouring floxed alleles for Gene, Gene and Gene were crossed with pan-endocrine Gene-Cre Species to generate single and compound Foxp mutant Species. Species were monitored for changes in Chemical tolerance by IPGTT, serum insulin and glucagon levels by radioimmunoassay, and endocrine cell development and proliferation by immunohistochemistry. Gene expression and Chemical-stimulated hormone secretion experiments were performed with isolated islets. RESULTS: Only the triple-compound Gene/4 conditional knockout (cKO) mutant had an overt islet phenotype, manifested physiologically by Disease. This resulted from the reduction in glucagon-secreting alpha cell mass and function. The proliferation of alpha cells was profoundly reduced in Gene/2/4 cKO islets through the effects on mediators of replication (i.e. decreased Gene, Gene and Gene activators, and increased Gene inhibitor). Adult islet Gene/2/4 cKO beta cells secrete insulin normally while the remaining alpha cells have impaired glucagon secretion. CONCLUSIONS/INTERPRETATION: Collectively, these findings reveal an important role for the Gene, 2, and 4 proteins in governing postnatal alpha cell expansion and function.

26034287.pub_title: Evolutionary comparison reveals that diverging Gene sites are signatures of ancestral topological associating domains borders.
26034287.pub_abstract: Increasing evidence in the last years indicates that the vast amount of regulatory information contained in Species genomes is organized in precise 3D chromatin structures. However, the impact of this spatial chromatin organization on gene expression and its degree of evolutionary conservation is still poorly understood. The Six homeobox genes are essential developmental regulators organized in gene clusters conserved during evolution. Here, we reveal that the Six clusters share a deeply evolutionarily conserved 3D chromatin organization that predates the Cambrian explosion. This chromatin architecture generates two largely independent regulatory landscapes (RLs) contained in two adjacent topological associating domains (TADs). By disrupting the conserved TAD border in one of the Species Six clusters, we demonstrate that this border is critical for preventing competition between promoters and enhancers located in separated RLs, thereby generating different expression patterns in genes located in close genomic proximity. Moreover, evolutionary comparison of Six-associated Disease reveals the presence of CCCTC-binding factor (Gene) sites with diverging orientations in all studied Species. Genome-wide examination of Species Gene data reveals that this conserved Gene configuration is a general signature of Disease, underscoring that common organizational principles underlie TAD compartmentalization in deuterostome evolution.

25174608.pub_title: Generation of a Cre knock-in into the Gene locus to mark early cardiac and smooth muscle cell lineages.
25174608.pub_abstract: The molecular events that control cell fate determination in cardiac and smooth muscle lineages remain elusive. Gene is an important transcription cofactor that regulates cell proliferation, differentiation, and development of the cardiovascular system. Here, we describe the construction and analysis of a dual Cre and enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP) knock-in Species line in the Gene locus (Myocd(KI)). We report that the Myocd(KI) allele expresses the Cre enzyme and the EGFP in a manner that recapitulates endogenous Gene expression patterns. We show that Gene expression marks the earliest cardiac and smooth muscle lineages. Furthermore, this genetic model allows for the identification of a cardiac cell population, which maintains both Gene and Gene expression, in E7.75-E8.0 embryos, highlighting the contribution and merging of the first and second heart fields during cardiogenesis. Therefore, the Myocd(KI) allele is a unique tool for studying cardiovascular development and lineage-specific gene manipulation.

27107132.pub_title: Endothelial Gene Is Required for Proper Development of the Semilunar Valves and Cardiac Outflow Tract.
27107132.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Disease is the most common type of Disease, affecting  2% of the population. Malformations involving the cardiac outflow tract and semilunar valves account for >50% of these cases predominantly because of a Disease, which has an estimated prevalence of 1% in the population. We previously reported that mutations in Gene were a cause of Disease in nonsyndromic autosomal-dominant Species pedigrees. Subsequently, we described a highly penetrant Species model of Disease, consisting of a Disease with thickened cusps and associated Disease and regurgitation, in Gene-Disease adult Species backcrossed into a Gene-null background. METHODS AND RESULTS: Here, we described the Disease in Gene(+/-);Gene(-/-) embryos that led to  65% lethality by postnatal day 10. Although expected Mendelian ratios of Gene(+/-);Gene(-/-) embryos were found at embryonic day 18.5, histological examination revealed thickened, malformed semilunar valve leaflets accompanied by additional anomalies of the cardiac outflow tract including Disease and overriding aorta. The aortic valve leaflets of Gene(+/-);Gene(-/-) embryos at embryonic day 15.5 were significantly thicker than controls, consistent with a defect in remodeling of the semilunar valve cushions. In addition, we generated Species Disease for Gene specifically in endothelial and endothelial-derived cells in a Gene-null background and found that Gene(fl/+);Tie2-Cre(+/-);Gene(-/-) Species recapitulate the Disease phenotype of Gene(+/-);Gene(-/-) embryos. CONCLUSIONS: Our data demonstrate the role of endothelial Gene in the proper development of the semilunar valves and cardiac outflow tract.

23996638.pub_title: Gene interacts with Gene genetically to regulate inner ear sensory cell orientation and the normal development of the female reproductive tract in Species.
23996638.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Planar cell polarity (Chemical) signaling regulates the coordinated polarization of cells and is required for the normal development and function of many tissues. Previous studies have identified conserved Chemical genes, such as Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene), in the regulation of coordinated orientation of inner ear hair cells and female reproductive tract development. Gene shares a PET-LIM homology with Gene. It is not clear whether Gene acts in Chemical processes in mammals. RESULTS: We identified Gene as a Gene-interacting protein through a 2-hybrid screen with a cochlea cDNA library. Gene is enriched to cell-cell boundaries in the presence of Gene in cultured cells. Genetic inactivation of Gene leads to abnormal hair cell orientation in the vestibule and cellular patterning defects in the cochlea. In addition, Gene genetically interacts with Gene to regulate hair cell orientation in the cochlea and the opening of the vaginal tract. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings suggested Gene as a gene involved in coordinated hair cell orientation in the inner ear and in female reproductive tract development. Furthermore, its genetic interaction with Gene implicated it as a potential molecular link, responsible for mediating the role of Gene-containing membranous Chemical complexes in directing morphologic polarization.

26243870.pub_title: Gene and Gene are required for Gene-dependent urinary tract morphogenesis.
26243870.pub_abstract: Despite the high occurrence of Disease of the lower urinary tract in Species, the molecular, cellular and morphological aspects of their development are still poorly understood. Here, we use a conditional knockout approach to inactivate within the nephric duct (ND) lineage the two effectors of the Hippo pathway, Gene and Gene. Deletion of Gene leads to Disease with blind-ending megaureters at birth. In Gene mutants, the ND successfully migrates towards, and contacts, the cloaca. However, close analysis reveals that the tip of the Gene(-/-) ND forms an aberrant connection with the cloaca and does not properly insert into the cloaca, leading to later detachment of the ND from the cloaca. Gene deletion from the ND does not cause any defect, but analysis of Gene(-/-);Gene(-/-) NDs indicates that both genes play partially redundant roles in ureterovesical junction formation. Aspects of the Gene(-/-) phenotype resemble Disease to Gene signaling, including excess budding of the ND, increased phospho-ERK and increased expression of Gene, Sprouty1, Gene and Gene. Importantly, the Gene(ND) (-/-) ND phenotype can be largely rescued by reducing Gene gene dosage. Taken together, these results suggest that disrupting Gene/Gene activities enhances Gene pathway activity and contributes to pathogenesis of lower urinary tract defects in Species Species.

22851319.pub_title: The transition from meiotic to mitotic spindle assembly is gradual during early Species development.
22851319.pub_abstract: The transition from meiosis to mitosis, classically defined by fertilization, is a fundamental process in development. However, its mechanism remains largely unexplored. In this paper, we report a surprising gradual transition from meiosis to mitosis over the first eight divisions of the Species embryo. The first cleavages still largely share the mechanism of spindle formation with meiosis, during which the spindle is self-assembled from randomly distributed microtubule-organizing centers (MTOCs) without centrioles, because of the concerted activity of dynein and kinesin-5. During preimplantation development, the number of cellular MTOCs progressively decreased, the spindle pole gradually became more focused, and spindle length progressively scaled down with cell size. The typical mitotic spindle with centrin-, Gene-, kinesin-12-, and CP110-positive centrosomes was established only in the blastocyst. Overall, the transition from meiosis to mitosis progresses gradually throughout the preimplantation stage in the Species embryo, thus providing a unique system to study the mechanism of centrosome biogenesis in vivo.

23897762.pub_title: Generation and characterization of a Chemical-inducible Eomes(CreER) Species line.
23897762.pub_abstract: Transgenic Species lines expressing inducible forms of Cre-recombinase in a tissue-specific manner are powerful genetic tools for studying aspects of development and various processes in the adult. The T-box transcription factor eomesodermin (Eomes) plays critical roles for maintenance and differentiation of different pools of stem and progenitor cells from early Disease stages to adulthood. These include trophoblast stem cells, epiblast cells during the generation of the primary germ layers, neurogenic intermediate progenitor cells in Disease and adult cortical neurogenesis, and maturing natural killer and T cells. Here, we report on the generation and analysis of an Eomes(CreER) -targeted allele by placing the Chemical-activatable Cre-recombinase (CreER) under the control of the Eomes genomic locus. We demonstrate that CreER expression recapitulates endogenous Eomes transcription within different progenitor cell populations. Chemical administration specifically labels Eomes-expressing cells and their progeny as demonstrated by crossing Eomes(CreER) animals to different Cre-inducible reporter strains. In summary, this novel Eomes(CreER) allele can be used as elegant genetic tool that allows to follow the fate of Eomes-positive cells and to genetically manipulate them in a temporal specific manner.

25677622.pub_title: Chemical inhibits histone methyltransferase Gene during palatogenesis.
25677622.pub_abstract: Disease with or without palate (Disease/P) is a common Disease in Species and is thought to be caused by genetic and environmental factors. However, the epigenetic mechanisms underlying orofacial clefts are not fully understood. Here, we investigate how the Disease of Chemical (RA), which can induce Disease in Species and Species, regulates histone methyltransferase, Gene (Gene) during palatal development in Species. We treated Species embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) with 1 muM all-trans RA and discovered that the global level of H3K36me3 was downregulated and that expression of the H3K36 methyltransferase gene, Gene, was reduced. The expression level of Gene in Disease shelves was reduced during palatogenesis, following maternal administration of 100 mg/kg body weight of RA by gastric intubation. Furthermore, the expression of Gene in palatal shelves was observed in epithelial and mesenchymal cells at all stages, suggesting an important role for palatal development. Our results suggest that the pathogenesis of Disease observed after excessive RA exposure is likely to be associated with a reduction in the histone methyltransferase, Gene.

22623674.pub_title: Integration of H-2Z1, a somatosensory cortex-expressed transgene, interferes with the expression of the Gene and Gene flanking genes and affects the differentiation of a subset of cortical interneurons.
22623674.pub_abstract: H-2Z1 is an enhancer trap transgenic Species line in which the lacZ reporter delineates the somatosensory area of the cerebral cortex where it is expressed in a subset of layer IV neurons. In the search of somatosensory specific genes or regulatory sequences, we mapped the H-2Z1 transgene insertion site to chromosome 17, 100 and 460 kb away from Gene and Gene flanking genes. We show here that insertion of the H-2Z1 transgene results in three distinct outcomes. First, a genetic background-sensitive expression of lacZ in several brain and body structures. While four genes in a 1 Mb region around the insertion are expressed in the barrel cortex, H-2Z1 expression resembles more that of its two direct neighbors. Moreover, H-2Z1 closely reports most of the body and brain expression sites of the Gene chromatin remodeling gene including tooth buds, thymic epithelium, pontine nuclei, fastigial cerebellar nuclei, and cerebral cortex. Second, the H-2Z1 transgene causes insertional mutagenesis of Gene and Gene, leading to a strong decrease in their expressions. Finally, insertion of H-2Z1 affects the differentiation of a subset of cortical GABAergic interneurons, a possible consequence of downregulation of Gene expression. Thus, the H-2Z1 "somatosensory" transgene is inserted in the regulatory landscape of two genes highly expressed in the developing somatosensory cortex and reports for a subdomain of their expression profiles. Together, our data suggest that regulation of H-2Z1 expression results from local and remote genetic interactions.

24064341.pub_title: Defective prolactin signaling Disease beta-cell development during the perinatal period.
24064341.pub_abstract: Prolactin (PRL) and placental lactogens stimulate beta-cell replication and insulin production in Disease and Disease cells through binding to the Gene (Gene). However, the contribution of Gene signaling to beta-cell ontogeny and function in perinatal life and the effects of the lactogens on adaptive islet growth are poorly understood. We provide evidence that expansion of beta-cell mass during both embryogenesis and the postnatal period is impaired in the Gene(-/-) Species model. Gene(-/-) newborns display a 30% reduction of beta-cell mass, consistent with reduced proliferation index at E18.5. PRL stimulates Chemical incorporation and Gene phosphorylation in INS-1 cells, supporting a role for beta-cell Gene signaling in PRL action. Interestingly, a defect in the development of acini is also observed in absence of Gene signaling, with a sharp decline in cellular size in both endocrine and exocrine compartments. Of note, a decrease in levels of Gene, a PRL target, in the Goto-Kakizaki (GK) Species, a spontaneous model of type 2 Disease, is associated with a lack of PRL-mediated beta-cell proliferation in Disease buds. Reduced pancreatic Gene expression in both Species and Species models suggests that this factor may constitute a molecular link between PRL signaling and cell ontogenesis. Together, these results provide evidence that PRL signaling is essential for pancreas ontogenesis during the critical perinatal window responsible for establishing functional beta-cell reserve.

23319608.pub_title: Gene governs distinct pathways to direct multiple aspects of Species neural crest cell development.
23319608.pub_abstract: Development of the cerebral vessels, pharyngeal arch arteries (PAAs). and cardiac outflow tract (OFT) requires multipotent neural crest cells (NCCs) that migrate from the neural tube to target tissue destinations. Little is known about how Species NCC development is orchestrated by gene programming at the chromatin level, however. Here we show that Gene (Gene), an ATPase subunit of the Gene (Gene) chromatin-remodeling complex, is required in NCCs to direct cardiovascular development. Species embryos lacking Gene in NCCs display immature cerebral vessels, aberrant Chemical patterning, and shortened OFT. Gene suppresses an apoptosis factor, Gene (Gene), and a cell cycle inhibitor, Gene(Gene), to inhibit apoptosis and promote proliferation of NCCs, thereby maintaining a multipotent cell reservoir at the neural crest. Gene also supports Gene (Gene) expression to allow NCCs to develop into mature vascular smooth muscle cells of cerebral vessels. Within NCCs, Gene partners with chromatin remodeler Gene (Gene) on the Gene promoter to activate Gene, which encodes a receptor for semaphorin to guide NCCs into the OFT. Our findings reveal an important role for Gene and its downstream pathways in the survival, differentiation, and migration of the multipotent NCCs critical for Species cardiovascular development.

24218595.pub_title: Hox5 interacts with Gene to restrict Gene expression in the developing forelimb.
24218595.pub_abstract: To date, only the five most posterior groups of Hox genes, Hox9-Gene, have demonstrated loss-of-function roles in limb patterning. Individual paralog groups control proximodistal patterning of the limb skeletal elements. Hox9 genes also initiate the onset of Gene expression in the posterior forelimb compartment, and collectively, the posterior Gene/D genes maintain posterior Gene (Gene) expression. Here we show that an anterior Hox paralog group, Hox5, is required for forelimb anterior patterning. Deletion of all three Hox5 genes (Gene, Gene, and Gene) leads to anterior forelimb defects resulting from derepression of Gene expression. The phenotype requires the loss of all three Hox5 genes, demonstrating the high level of redundancy in this Hox paralogous group. Further analyses reveal that Hox5 interacts with Disease zinc finger biochemically and genetically to restrict Gene expression. These findings, along with previous reports showing that point mutations in the Gene limb enhancer lead to similar Disease, highlight the importance of Gene repression for proper patterning of the vertebrate limb.

22903063.pub_title: Positional differences of axon growth rates between sensory neurons encoded by Gene.
22903063.pub_abstract: The formation of functional connectivity in the nervous system is governed by axon guidance that instructs nerve growth and branching during development, implying a similarity between neuronal subtypes in terms of nerve extension. We demonstrate the molecular mechanism of another layer of complexity in vertebrates by defining a transcriptional program underlying growth differences between positionally different neurons. The rate of axon extension of the early subset of Disease neurons is encoded in neurons at different axial levels. This code is determined by a segmental pattern of axial levels of Runx family transcription factor Gene. Gene in turn determines transcription levels of genes encoding cytoskeletal proteins involved in axon extension, including Gene and Gene which have ongoing activities determining axon growth in early sensory neurons and blocking Rock activity reverses axon extension deficits of Gene(-/-) neurons. Thus, Gene acts to regulate positional differences in axon extension properties apparently without affecting nerve guidance and branching, a principle that could be relevant to other parts of the nervous system.

23720746.pub_title: Species lacking Gene are viable but display Gene Disease and dentate gyrus distortion.
23720746.pub_abstract: Gene acetylation at Chemical-40, located on the luminal side of microtubules, has been widely studied and used as a marker for stable microtubules in the cilia and other subcellular structures, but the functional consequences remain perplexing. Recent studies have shown that Gene and its paralog are responsible for Gene acetylation in Species. There is one such protein known as Gene (Gene) per higher organism. Species Gene appears to govern embryo development, raising the intriguing possibility that Gene is also critical for development in mammals. In addition to Gene, three other Species acetyltransferases, Gene-Gene, Gene, and Gene, have been shown to acetylate Gene in vitro, so an important question is how these four enzymes contribute to the acetylation in vivo. We demonstrate here that Gene is a major Gene acetyltransferase in Species. It is widely expressed in Species embryos and tissues. Although Gene-null animals display no overt phenotypes, Gene acetylation is lost in sperm flagella and the dentate gyrus is slightly deformed. Furthermore, Species Gene colocalizes on bundled microtubules with doublecortin. These results thus suggest that Species Gene may regulate advanced functions such as learning and memory, thereby shedding novel light on the physiological roles of Gene acetylation in mammals.

22232429.pub_title: RNA profiling and chromatin immunoprecipitation-sequencing reveal that Speciesa stabilizes pancreas progenitor identity via the control of MNX1/HLXB9 and a network of other transcription factors.
22232429.pub_abstract: Pancreas development is initiated by the specification and expansion of a small group of endodermal cells. Several transcription factors are crucial for progenitor maintenance and expansion, but their interactions and the downstream targets mediating their activity are poorly understood. Among those factors, Speciesa, a basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factor which controls pancreas exocrine cell differentiation, maintenance, and functionality, is also needed for the early specification of pancreas progenitors. We used RNA profiling and chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) sequencing to identify a set of targets in pancreas progenitors. We demonstrate that Mnx1, a gene that is absolutely required in pancreas progenitors, is a major direct target of Speciesa and is regulated by a distant enhancer element. Pdx1, Nkx6.1, and Onecut1 are also direct Speciesa targets whose expression is promoted by Speciesa. These proteins, most of which were previously shown to be necessary for pancreas bud maintenance or formation, form a transcription factor network that allows the maintenance of pancreas progenitors. In addition, we identify Bmp7, Nr5a2, RhoV, and P2rx1 as new targets of Speciesa in pancreas progenitors.

24278332.pub_title: Peritruncal coronary endothelial cells contribute to proximal coronary artery stems and their aortic orifices in the Species heart.
24278332.pub_abstract: Avian embryo experiments proved an ingrowth model for the coronary artery connections with the aorta. However, whether a similar mechanism applies to the Species heart still remains unclear. Here we analyzed how the main coronary arteries and their orifices form during Species heart development. Gene (Gene) is expressed in coronary vascular endothelial cells including peritruncal endothelial cells. By immunostaining, however, we did not find Gene expression in endothelial cells of the aorta during the period of coronary vessel development (E10.5 to E15.5). As a result of this unique expression difference, Gene(CreERT2/+) genetically labels nascent coronary vessels forming on the heart, but not the aorta endothelium when pulse activated by Chemical injection at E10.5. This allowed us to define the temporal contribution of these distinct endothelial cell populations to formation of the Species coronary artery orifice. We found that the peritruncal endothelial cells were recruited to form the coronary artery orifices. These cells penetrate the wall of aorta and take up residence in the aortic sinus of valsalva. In conclusion, main coronary arteries and their orifices form through the recruitment and vascular remodeling of peritruncal endothelial cells in Species heart.

23754951.pub_title: Histone acetyl transferase 1 is essential for Species development, genome stability, and the processing of newly synthesized histones H3 and H4.
23754951.pub_abstract: Gene is an evolutionarily conserved type B histone acetyltransferase that is thought to be responsible for the diacetylation of newly synthesized histone H4 on Chemical 5 and 12 during chromatin assembly. To understand the function of this enzyme in a complex organism, we have constructed a conditional Species knockout model of Gene. Species Gene is essential for viability, as homozygous deletion of Gene results in neonatal lethality. The lungs of embryos and Disease in Gene were much less mature upon histological evaluation. The neonatal lethality is due to severe Disease development that result in less aeration and Disease. Many of the Gene(-/-) neonates also display significant Disease in the bones of the skull and jaw. Gene(-/-) Species embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) are defective in cell proliferation and are sensitive to DNA damaging agents. In addition, the Gene(-/-) MEFs display a marked increase in genome instability. Analysis of histone dynamics at sites of replication-coupled chromatin assembly demonstrates that Gene is not only responsible for the acetylation of newly synthesized histone H4 but is also required to maintain the acetylation of histone H3 on Chemical 9, 18, and 27 during replication-coupled chromatin assembly.

27034231.pub_title: FGFR2c-mediated Gene-MAPK activity regulates coronal suture development.
27034231.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) signaling is critical for proper craniofacial development. A gain-of-function mutation in the 2c splice variant of the receptor's gene is associated with Disease, which is characterized by Disease, the premature fusion of one or more of the cranial vault sutures, leading to craniofacial maldevelopment. Insight into the molecular mechanism of Disease has identified the Gene-MAPK signaling cascade as a critical regulator of suture patency. The aim of this study is to investigate the role of FGFR2c-induced Gene-MAPK activation in the regulation of coronal suture development. Loss-of-function and gain-of-function Fgfr2c mutant Species have overlapping phenotypes, including Disease and Disease. In vivo analysis of coronal sutures in loss-of-function and gain-of-function models demonstrated fundamentally different pathogenesis underlying Disease. Calvarial osteoblasts from gain-of-function Species demonstrated enhanced Disease and maturation with concomitant increase in Gene-MAPK activation. In vitro inhibition with the Gene protein inhibitor U0126 mitigated Gene protein activation levels with a concomitant reduction in alkaline phosphatase activity. This study identifies Genec-mediated Gene-MAPK signaling as a key mediator of craniofacial growth and coronal suture development. Furthermore, our results solve the apparent paradox between loss-of-function and gain-of-function Genec mutants with respect to Disease.

26453549.pub_title: Intrinsic factors and the embryonic environment influence the formation of extragonadal Disease during gestation.
26453549.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Pluripotent cells are present in early embryos until the levels of the pluripotency regulator Gene drop at the beginning of somitogenesis. Elevating Gene levels in explanted post-pluripotent cells in vitro restores their pluripotency. Cultured pluripotent cells can participate in normal development when introduced into host embryos up to the end of gastrulation. In contrast, pluripotent cells efficiently seed Disease in adult animals. In Species, extragonadal Disease and Disease are most frequently found in the sacrococcygeal region of neonates, suggesting that these Disease originate from cells in the posterior of the embryo that either reactivate or fail to switch off their pluripotent status. However, experimental models for the persistence or reactivation of pluripotency during embryonic development are lacking. METHODS: We manually injected embryonic stem cells into conceptuses at E9.5 to test whether the presence of pluripotent cells at this stage correlates with Disease formation. We then examined the effects of reactivating embryonic Gene expression ubiquitously or in combination with Gene within the primitive streak (PS)/tail bud (TB) using a transgenic Species line and embryo chimeras carrying a PS/TB-specific heterologous gene expression cassette respectively. RESULTS: Here, we show that pluripotent cells seed Disease in post-gastrulation embryos. However, at these stages, induced ubiquitous expression of Gene does not lead to restoration of pluripotency (indicated by Gene expression) and Disease formation in utero, but instead causes a severe phenotype in the extending anteroposterior axis. Use of a more restricted T(Bra) promoter transgenic system enabling inducible ectopic expression of Gene and Gene specifically in the posteriorly-located primitive streak (PS) and tail bud (TB) led to similar axial Disease to those induced by Gene alone. These cells underwent induction of pluripotency marker expression in Epiblast Stem Cell (EpiSC) explants derived from somitogenesis-stage embryos, but no Disease formation was observed in vivo. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings show that although pluripotent cells with teratocarcinogenic potential can be produced in vitro by the overexpression of pluripotency regulators in explanted somitogenesis-stage somatic cells, the in vivo induction of these genes does not yield Disease. This suggests a restrictive regulatory role of the embryonic microenvironment in the induction of pluripotency.

26644518.pub_title: Gene promotes and maintains slow muscle fiber identity during postnatal development and reinnervation.
26644518.pub_abstract: Each adult Species skeletal muscle has a unique complement of fast and slow myofibers, reflecting patterns established during development and reinforced via their innervation by fast and slow motor neurons. Existing data support a model of postnatal "matching" whereby predetermined myofiber type identity promotes pruning of inappropriate motor axons, but no molecular mechanism has yet been identified. We present evidence that fiber type-specific repulsive interactions inhibit innervation of slow myofibers by fast motor axons during both postnatal maturation of the neuromuscular junction and myofiber reinnervation after injury. The repulsive guidance ligand Gene is expressed only on slow myofibers, whereas its candidate receptor, Gene, localizes exclusively to fast motor endplates. Adult Species lacking Gene have dramatically fewer slow myofibers in fast and mixed muscles, and misexpression of Gene on fast myofibers followed by denervation/reinnervation promotes their respecification to a slow phenotype. We therefore conclude that Gene/ephrin interactions guide the fiber type specificity of neuromuscular interactions during development and adult life.

23975681.pub_title: A model for the molecular underpinnings of Disease in Disease.
23975681.pub_abstract: Species with Disease (Gene) present various Disease, including Disease, and Disease. Gene is genetically associated with mutations in the Gene gene, which encodes one of the earliest transcription factors to initiate tooth development. Thus, Gene has long been considered as an upstream regulator of the transcriptional hierarchy in early tooth development. However, because Gene is also a major regulator of later stages of tooth development, especially during amelogenesis, it is unclear how mutant forms cause Disease. In this report, we outline the transcriptional mechanism that is defective in Gene. We demonstrate that during normal tooth development Gene activates Amelogenin (Gene) expression, whose product is required for enamel formation, and that this regulation is perturbed by missense Gene mutations found in Gene Species. We further show that Gene-mediated Gene activation is controlled by chromatin-associated factor Gene, and that Gene prevents Gene from efficiently binding to and activating the Gene promoter. Consistent with a physiological significance to this interaction, we show that Gene-Gene Species display a severe loss of Gene expression on the labial side of the lower incisors, as well as Disease-consistent with the Species Gene phenotype. Collectively, these findings define transcriptional mechanisms involved in normal tooth development and shed light on the molecular underpinnings of the enamel defect observed in Gene Species who carry Gene mutations. Moreover, our findings validate the etiology of the enamel defect in a novel Species model of Gene.

24848070.pub_title: Recessive mutations in Gene cause a new type of early-onset Disease.
24848070.pub_abstract: Mutations in several genes cause Disease, but numerous Species still have unclear Disease, hampering our understanding of the development of the disease and preventing pathogenesis-oriented treatment. We used whole-genome sequencing with linkage analysis to study a consanguineous family with early-onset antibody-negative Disease and identified a novel deletion in Gene (Gene/dimerization cofactor of hepatocyte nuclear factor 1 alpha), a gene that was recently proposed as a likely cause of Disease. A subsequent reevaluation of Species with mild Disease due to mutations in Gene from the BIODEF database identified three additional Species who had developed Gene-like Disease in Disease, indicating early beta-cell failure. We found that Gene is expressed in the developing pancreas of both Species and Species embryos from early specification onward showing colocalization with Gene. Importantly, a morpholino-mediated knockdown in Species revealed that Gene activity is required for the proper establishment of early Disease fate within the endoderm. We provide the first genetic evidence that Gene mutations can cause early-onset Disease with features similar to dominantly inherited Disease. This condition responds to and can be treated with oral drugs instead of Gene, which is important clinical information for these Species. Finally, Species at risk can be detected through a newborn screening for Disease.

25834056.pub_title: Incoherent feed-forward regulatory loops control segregation of C-mechanoreceptors, nociceptors, and pruriceptors.
25834056.pub_abstract: Species skin is innervated by diverse, unmyelinated C fibers that are associated with senses of Disease, itch, temperature, or touch. A key developmental question is how this neuronal cell diversity is generated during development. We reported previously that the runt domain transcription factor Gene is required to coordinate the development of these unmyelinated cutaneous sensory neurons, including Gene(+) low-threshold c-mechanoreceptors (CLTMs), MrgprD(+) polymodal nociceptors, MrgprA3(+) pruriceptors, MrgprB4(+) c-mechanoreceptors, and others. However, how these Gene-dependent cutaneous sensory neurons are further segregated is poorly illustrated. Here, we find that the Gene-dependent transcription factor gene Zfp521 is expressed in, and required for establishing molecular features that define, Gene(+) CLTMs. Furthermore, Gene and Zfp521 form a classic incoherent feedforward loop (I-FFL) in controlling molecular identities that normally belong to MrgprD(+) neurons, with Gene and Zfp51 playing activator and repressor roles, respectively (in genetic terms). A knock-out of Zfp521 allows prospective Gene lineage neurons to acquire MrgprD(+) neuron identities. Furthermore, Gene might form other I-FFLs to regulate the expression of MrgprA3 and MrgprB4, a mechanism preventing these genes from being expressed in Gene-persistent Gene(+) and MrgprD(+) neurons. The evolvement of these I-FFLs provides an explanation for how modality-selective sensory subtypes are formed during development and may also have intriguing implications for sensory neuron evolution and sensory coding.

27523608.pub_title: The Deubiquitinase Gene Is an Essential Negative Regulator of Inflammation and Autoimmunity.
27523608.pub_abstract: Chemical-1 (M1)-linked ubiquitin chains regulate the activity of Gene, immune homeostasis, and responses to Disease. The importance of negative regulators of M1-linked chains in vivo remains poorly understood. Here, we show that the M1-specific deubiquitinase Gene is essential for preventing Gene-associated systemic Disease in Species and Species. A homozygous hypomorphic mutation in Species Gene causes a potentially fatal autoinflammatory condition termed Gene-related Disease (ORAS). Four independent Gene Species models reveal that Disease in immune cells results in cell-type-specific effects, ranging from over-production of inflammatory cytokines and Disease due to accumulation of Disease and spontaneous Gene activation in myeloid cells to downregulation of M1-polyubiquitin signaling by degradation of LUBAC in B and T cells. Remarkably, treatment with anti-Gene neutralizing antibodies ameliorates Disease in ORAS Species and rescues Species phenotypes. Hence, Gene is critical for restraining life-threatening spontaneous Disease and maintaining immune homeostasis.

22573622.pub_title: The bHLH transcription factor Gene is required for lineage-specific EMT of cardiac fibroblast progenitors.
22573622.pub_abstract: The basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) family of transcription factors orchestrates cell-fate specification, commitment and differentiation in multiple cell lineages during development. Here, we describe the role of a bHLH transcription factor, Gene (Gene/Pod1/Gene), in specification of the cardiac fibroblast lineage. In the developing heart, the epicardium constitutes the primary source of progenitor cells that form two cell lineages: coronary vascular smooth muscle cells (cVSMCs) and cardiac fibroblasts. Currently, there is a debate regarding whether the specification of these lineages occurs early in the formation of the epicardium or later after the cells have entered the myocardium. Lineage tracing using a Chemical-inducible Cre expressed from the Gene locus demonstrated that the majority of Gene-expressing epicardial cells are committed to the cardiac fibroblast lineage prior to initiation of epicardial epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). Furthermore, Gene null hearts fail to form cardiac fibroblasts, and lineage tracing of the null cells showed their inability to undergo EMT. This is the first report of a transcription factor essential for the development of cardiac fibroblasts. We demonstrate a unique role for Gene in multipotent epicardial progenitors, prior to the process of EMT that is essential for cardiac fibroblast development.

23933587.pub_title: Endothelin regulates neural crest deployment and fate to form great vessels through Gene/Gene-independent mechanisms.
23933587.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene), originally identified as a vasoconstrictor peptide, is involved in the development of cranial/cardiac neural crest-derived tissues and organs. In craniofacial development, Gene binds to Endothelin type-A receptor (Gene) to induce homeobox genes Gene/Gene and determines the mandibular identity in the first pharyngeal arch. However, it remains unsolved whether this pathway is also critical for pharyngeal arch artery development to form thoracic arteries. Here, we show that the Gene/Gene signaling is involved in pharyngeal artery development by controlling the fate of neural crest cells through a Gene/Gene-independent mechanism. Gene and Gene knock-out Species demonstrate abnormalities in pharyngeal arch artery patterning, which include persistent first and second pharyngeal arteries, resulting in additional branches from common carotid arteries. Neural crest cell labeling with Gene-Cre transgene and immunostaining for smooth muscle cell markers revealed that neural crest cells abnormally differentiate into smooth muscle cells at the first and second pharyngeal arteries of Gene knock-out embryos. By contrast, Gene/Gene knockout little affect the development of pharyngeal arch arteries and coronary arteries, the latter of which is also contributed by neural crest cells through an Edn-dependent mechanism. These findings indicate that the Gene/Gene signaling regulates neural crest differentiation to ensure the proper patterning of pharyngeal arch arteries, which is independent of the regional identification of the pharyngeal arches along the dorsoventral axis mediated by Gene/Gene.

23999326.pub_title: Gene regulates dendritic morphogenesis in Species cerebral cortex.
23999326.pub_abstract: Disease (HSPs) are Species genetic disorders characterized by lower extremity Disease and Disease. Mutations in Gene (Gene) have been identified in Species with HSP Gene. However, the function of Gene in the Species brain remains unclear. Here, we found that expression of Gene mRNA was restricted in the deep layer of Species cerebral cortex during the early development. We examined Gene functions by delivering its plasmids to the upper layer cortical neurons using in utero electroporation. The effects of ectopic expression in the pyramidal neurons were determined both in culture and in situ at postnatal stages of neocortical development. In cultured cortical neurons, overexpressing Gene increased dendrite growth and arborization, whereas HSP-associated mutant Protein Mutation, which is devoid of GTPase activity, had no such effects. Consistent with this, in vivo expression of wild type Gene, but not of the mutant Protein Mutation, increased dendritic growth of the cortical neurons. This suggests that the role of Gene on dendritic morphogenesis depends on its GTPase activity. The expression of Gene and Protein Mutation did not affect the migration of cortical neurons. These results indicate that Gene regulates dendritic morphogenesis, which may provide new insights into the neuropathogenic mechanism of Disease Gene.

22464328.pub_title: Synergistic, context-dependent, and hierarchical functions of epithelial components in thymic microenvironments.
22464328.pub_abstract: Specialized niche environments specify and maintain stem and progenitor cells, but little is known about the identities and functional interactions of niche components in vivo. Here, we describe a modular system for the generation of artificial thymopoietic environments in the Species embryo. Thymic epithelium that lacks hematopoietic function but is physiologically accessible for hematopoietic progenitor cells is functionalized by individual and combinatorial expression of four factors, the chemokines Gene and Gene, the cytokine Gene, and the Notch ligand Gene. The distinct phenotypes and variable numbers of hematopoietic cells in the resulting epithelial environments reveal synergistic, context-dependent, and hierarchical interactions among effector molecules. The surprisingly simple rules determining hematopoietic properties enable the in vivo engineering of artificial environments conducive to the presence of distinct Disease or B lymphoid lineage precursors; moreover, synthetic environments facilitate the procurement of physiological progenitor cell types for analytical purposes and future therapeutic applications.

22415368.pub_title: A unique role of cohesin-Gene in gene regulation and development.
22415368.pub_abstract: Vertebrates have two cohesin complexes that consist of Gene, Gene, Gene/Gene and either Gene or Gene, but their functional specificity is unclear. Species embryos lacking Gene show developmental delay and die before birth. Comparison of the genome-wide distribution of cohesin in wild-type and Gene-null cells reveals that Gene is largely responsible for cohesin accumulation at promoters and at sites bound by the insulator protein Gene. As a consequence, ablation of Gene alters transcription of genes involved in biological processes related to Disease (Disease), a Disease linked to dysfunction of cohesin. We show that the presence of cohesin-Gene at the promoter of myc and of protocadherin genes positively regulates their expression, a task that cannot be assumed by cohesin-Gene. Lack of Gene also alters cohesin-binding pattern along some gene clusters and leads to dysregulation of genes within. We hypothesize that impaired cohesin-Gene function in gene expression underlies the molecular aetiology of Disease.

23063798.pub_title: Myocardial Gene is essential for Species ventricular wall morphogenesis.
23063798.pub_abstract: Gene is a highly conserved transcription factor with multifaceted roles in development and disease. Mutations in Gene are associated with Disease, a Disease characterized in part by Disease. Species models have helped elucidate Gene functions; however its cardiac-specific roles during development remain unclear. We employed a Cre/loxp strategy to uncover the specific activities of Gene in the developing Species myocardium. Myocardial deletion of Gene resulted in a thin-myocardial wall defect with dramatically reduced trabeculation. The mutant heart defects strongly resemble the phenotype caused by disruption of Gene and Gene (Gene) signaling pathways, two central mediators of myocardial wall development. Our further examination showed that expression of Gene is regulated by both BMP and Gene signaling. The thin-wall defect in mutant hearts is caused by a reduction in both cell proliferation and cell size. Gene promotes cardiomyocyte proliferation through regulating expression of cell cycle regulators (including Gene, Gene, and Gene) and promotes cardiomyocyte growth through regulating expression of Gene. In addition, expression of multiple sarcomere proteins is altered in Gene myocardial-inactivation embryos, indicating its essential role for proper cardiomyocyte differentiation. In summary, Gene acts downstream of BMP and Gene cardiogenic signaling pathways to promote normal myocardial wall morphogenesis.

25802403.pub_title: Induction of hematopoietic and endothelial cell program orchestrated by ETS transcription factor ER71/Gene.
25802403.pub_abstract: The ETS factor Gene (aka ER71) is essential for the generation of the blood and vascular system, as Gene deficiency leads to a Disease in blood and endothelial cell formation and Disease in the Species. However, the Gene-mediated gene regulatory network and signaling governing hematopoietic and endothelial cell development are poorly understood. Here, we map Gene global binding sites and carry out in vitro differentiation of embryonic stem cells, and germ line and conditional knockout Species studies to uncover mechanisms involved in the hemangiogenic fate commitment from mesoderm. We show that Gene binds to enhancers that specify hematopoietic and endothelial cell lineages. We find that the hemangiogenic progenitor population in the developing embryo can be identified as Gene(high)PDGFRalpha(-). Notably, these hemangiogenic progenitors are exclusively sensitive to Gene-dependent Gene signaling. Importantly, Gene turns on other Ets genes, thereby establishing an ETS hierarchy. Consequently, the hematopoietic and endothelial cell program initiated by Gene is maintained partly by other ETS factors through an ETS switching mechanism. These findings highlight the critical role that transient Gene expression plays in the regulation of hematopoietic and endothelial cell lineage specification and stability.

25098329.pub_title: Generation of Pet1210-Cre transgenic Species line reveals non-serotonergic expression domains of Gene both in CNS and periphery.
25098329.pub_abstract: Neurons producing Chemical (Chemical, Chemical) constitute one of the most widely distributed neuronal networks in the Species central nervous system (CNS) and exhibit a profuse innervation throughout the CNS already at early stages of development. Serotonergic neuron specification is controlled by a combination of secreted molecules and transcription factors such as Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene. In the Species, Gene mRNA expression appears between 10 and 11 days post coitum (dpc) in serotonergic post-mitotic precursors and persists in serotonergic neurons up to adulthood, where it promotes the expression of genes defining the mature serotonergic phenotype such as Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene). Hence, the generation of genetic tools based on Gene specific expression represents a valuable approach to study the development and function of the serotonergic system. Here, we report the generation of a Gene(210)-Cre transgenic Species line in which the Cre recombinase is expressed under the control of a 210 kb fragment from the Gene genetic locus to ensure a reliable and faithful control of somatic recombination in Gene cell lineage. Besides Cre-mediated recombination accurately occurred in the serotonergic system as expected and according to previous studies, Gene(210)-Cre transgenic Species line allowed us to identify novel, so far uncharacterized, Gene expression domains. Indeed, we showed that in the raphe Gene is expressed also in a non-serotonergic neuronal population intermingled with Gene-expressing cells and mostly localized in the B8 and B9 nuclei. Moreover, we detected Cre-mediated recombination also in the developing pancreas and in the ureteric bud derivatives of the kidney, where it reflected a specific Gene expression. Thus, Gene(210)-Cre transgenic Species line faithfully drives Cre-mediated recombination in all Gene expression domains representing a valuable tool to genetically manipulate serotonergic and non-serotonergic Gene cell lineages.

24553289.pub_title: The Disease/C activator Gene is essential for meiotic prophase I in Species.
24553289.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is an activator of the Anaphase promoting complex/cyclosome (Disease/C) and an important regulator of the mitotic cell division cycle. Using a germ-cell-specific conditional knockout model we examined its role in entry into meiosis and early meiotic events in both sexes. Loss of Disease/C(Gene) activity in the male germline led to both a mitotic and a Disease resulting in Disease due to the absence of mature spermatozoa. Spermatogonia in the prepubertal testes of such Species had abnormal proliferation and delayed entry into meiosis. Although early recombination events were initiated, male germ cells failed to progress beyond zygotene and underwent apoptosis. Loss of Disease/C(Gene) activity was associated with raised Gene levels, suggesting that Gene may trigger apoptosis. By contrast, female FZR1Delta Species were subfertile, with Disease by 5 months of age. Germ cell loss occurred embryonically in the ovary, around the time of the zygotene-pachytene transition, similar to that observed in males. In addition, the transition of primordial follicles into the growing follicle pool in the neonatal ovary was abnormal, such that the primordial follicles were prematurely depleted. We conclude that Disease/C(Gene) is an essential regulator of spermatogonial proliferation and early meiotic prophase I in both male and female germ cells and is therefore important in establishing the reproductive health of adult male and female mammals.

22859373.pub_title: Dual reporter approaches for identification of Cre efficacy and astrocyte heterogeneity.
22859373.pub_abstract: Gene inactivation reporters are powerful tools to circumvent limitations of the widely used Cre/loxP system of conditional mutagenesis. With new conditional transgenic Species lines expressing the enhanced cyan fluorescent protein (ECFP) instead of Gene (Gene) after Cre-mediated recombination, we demonstrate dual reporter approaches to simultaneously examine astrocyte subpopulations expressing different connexins, identify compensatory up-regulation within gene families, and quantify Cre-mediated deletion at the allelic level. Analysis of a newly generated Gene knock-in ECFP Species revealed an unexpected heterogeneity of Gene-expressing astrocytes across brain areas.

26637977.pub_title: Mutations Preventing Regulated Exon Skipping in MET Cause Disease.
26637977.pub_abstract: The periosteum contributes to bone repair and maintenance of cortical bone mass. In contrast to the understanding of bone development within the epiphyseal growth plate, factors that regulate periosteal osteogenesis have not been studied as intensively. Disease (OFD) is a Disease and is typically sporadic and characterized by radiolucent lesions affecting the cortical bone immediately under the periosteum of the tibia and fibula. We identified germline mutations in MET, encoding a receptor Chemical kinase, that segregate with an autosomal-dominant form of OFD in three families and a mutation in a fourth affected subject from a simplex family and with Disease. Mutations identified in all families with dominant inheritance and in the one simplex subject with Disease abolished the splice inclusion of exon 14 in MET transcripts, which resulted in a MET receptor (MET(D N A Mutation)) lacking a cytoplasmic juxtamembrane domain. Splice exclusion of this domain occurs during normal embryonic development, and forced induction of this exon-exclusion event Disease differentiation in vitro and inhibited bone-matrix mineralization. In an additional subject with unilateral OFD, we identified a somatic MET mutation, also affecting exon 14, that substituted a Chemical residue critical for MET receptor turnover and, as in the case of the MET(D N A Mutation) mutations, had a stabilizing effect on the mature protein. Taken together, these data show that aberrant MET regulation via the juxtamembrane domain subverts core MET receptor functions that regulate osteogenesis within cortical diaphyseal bone.

26950855.pub_title: Lack of Gene signaling causes maldevelopment of the intestinal microvasculature and facilitates Disease in neonatal Species.
26950855.pub_abstract: The pathogenesis of Disease (NEC), a common Disease affecting premature Species, remains poorly understood. We previously found that intestinal Gene expression is decreased in Species NEC samples and in a neonatal Species NEC model prior to detectable histological Disease. Therefore, we hypothesized that lack of Gene (Gene) signaling facilitates neonatal Disease by impairing intestinal microvasculature development. Here, we found that intestinal Gene and its receptor, Gene, were highly expressed at the end of fetal life and significantly decreased after birth in Species. Furthermore, selective inhibition of Gene kinase activity and exposure to a neonatal NEC protocol significantly decreased the density of the intestinal microvascular network, which was further reduced when both interventions were provided together. Furthermore, Gene inhibition resulted in greater mortality and incidence of severe Disease in pups submitted to the NEC model. The percentage of lamina propria endothelial cells was decreased during NEC induction, and further decreased when Gene signaling was inhibited. This was associated with decreased endothelial cell proliferation rather than apoptosis. In conclusion, we found that Gene and Gene proteins are highly expressed in the intestine before birth, and are significantly downregulated in the immediate neonatal period. Furthermore, Gene signaling is necessary to maintain the integrity of the intestinal mucosal microvasculature during the postnatal period and lack of Gene signaling predisposes to NEC in neonatal Species.

23709645.pub_title: The guidance molecule Gene is differentially involved in the arealization of the Species and primate neocortex.
23709645.pub_abstract: The visual cortex is organized into discrete domains characterized by their specific function, connectivity, chemoarchitecture, and cytoarchitecture. Gradients of transcription factors across the anteroposterior and mediolateral axes of the neocortex have previously been demonstrated to specify the main sensory regions. However, they do not account for the establishment of multiple areas in the primate visual cortex, which occupies approximately 50% of the neocortical surface. We demonstrate that the guidance molecule Gene (Gene) is initially secreted in the cortical plate of the embryonic Species monkey and acts as an intrinsic cue to control the migration of subpopulations of neuronal progenitors and projection neurons expressing the receptor Gene (Gene). During the first 2 postnatal weeks, Gene expression becomes primarily associated with ventral visual cortical areas, leading to the specific migration of Gene+ neurons in the late maturing visual areas. In the Species, Gene distribution is not arealized, but Gene expression becomes restricted to the posterior neocortex at embryonic day 16.5. The selective reduction in the striate cortex we observe in Gene-/- animals potentially results from the differential distribution of Gene+ cells. Therefore, the Gene/Gene pathway participates to the parcellation of the visual neocortex in both the Species and the Species, however, through different regulatory processes.

22357600.pub_title: The splicing regulator Gene is required for both cerebellar development and mature motor function.
22357600.pub_abstract: The Rbfox proteins (Gene, Gene, and Gene) regulate the alternative splicing of many important neuronal transcripts and have been implicated in a variety of Disease. However, their roles in brain development and function are not well understood, in part due to redundancy in their activities. Here we show that, unlike Gene deletion, the CNS-specific deletion of Gene disrupts cerebellar development. Genome-wide analysis of Gene(-/-) brain RNA identifies numerous splicing changes altering proteins important both for brain development and mature neuronal function. To separate developmental defects from alterations in the physiology of mature cells, Gene and Gene were deleted from mature Purkinje cells, resulting in highly irregular firing. Notably, the Gene mRNA encoding the Gene Chemical channel, a key mediator of Purkinje cell pacemaking, is improperly spliced in Gene and Gene mutant brains, leading to highly reduced protein expression. Thus, Gene protein controls a post-transcriptional program required for proper brain development. Gene is subsequently required with Gene to maintain mature neuronal physiology, specifically Purkinje cell pacemaking, through their shared control of Chemical channel transcript splicing.

23980576.pub_title: Respiratory distress and early neonatal lethality in Gene/Gene double-mutant Species.
23980576.pub_abstract: Heat shock proteins Gene and Gene are closely related members of the HSP110 family and act as cochaperones. We generated Gene(-/-)Gene(-/-) Species to investigate a functional complementarity between Gene and Gene during embryonic development. Gene(-/-)Gene(-/-) embryos exhibited marked Disease and Disease. Compared with lungs of wild-type, Gene(-/-), and Gene(-/-) embryos, Gene(-/-)Gene(-/-) lungs were characterized by diminished saccular spaces and increased mesenchymal septa. Mesenchymal hypercellularity was determined to be due to an increased cell proliferation index and decreased cell death. A significant increase in expression levels of prosurvival protein Gene may be the cause for inhibition of apoptotic process in lungs of Gene(-/-)Gene(-/-) embryos. Accumulation of glycogen and diminished expression of surfactant protein B, prosurfactant protein C, and aquaporin 5 in saccular epithelium suggested impaired maturation of type II and type I pneumocytes in the Gene(-/-)Gene(-/-) lungs. Further experiments showed a significant accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins in the lungs of Gene(-/-)Gene(-/-) embryos, indicating an impaired chaperone activity. Our study demonstrates that Gene and Gene collaborate in Disease, which is necessary for adaptation to air breathing at birth.

27693698.pub_title: Identification of a new sweat gland progenitor population in Species and the role of their niche in tissue development.
27693698.pub_abstract: Sweat gland cells are responsible for the regulation of body temperature and are critical for wound repair. Furthermore, they have the regenerative potential in response to injury, and show a substantial turnover during both wound healing and homeostasis. However, as a usual research model of sweat gland, Species have not too much glandular cells for experiments. In this study, we identify previously unreported sweat gland progenitor population in Species and characterize them. The progenitor characteristics of sweat gland were confirmed using cellular immunofluorescence assay and quantitative real-time PCR assay. K8 and Gene expression was barely detected in the early stage of skin development (Embryo 17.5d) and increased to a high level at P5d (postnatal 5d), then showed reduction at adult stage (P28d). Further investigation of K8 and Gene positive cells using tissue immunofluorescence revealed the presence of sweat gland progenitors in Disease of Species at early stage of sweat gland development and continuous reduction during the developmental process. In vivo transplantation assay with animal models elucidated that sweat gland specific niche in paw pads was critical for the development of sweat gland cells. Although the relationship between new sweat gland progenitors and their niche still needs to be further investigated, the presence of these cells implicates that there is more source ascribed to sweat glands in addition to serving as progenitors in Species.

23103168.pub_title: The H3K27 demethylase Gene is required for maintenance of the Disease, neonatal breathing, and survival.
23103168.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) antagonizes Polycomb silencing by demethylating Chemical 27 on histone H3. The interplay of methyltransferases and demethylases at this residue is thought to underlie critical cell fate transitions, and the dynamics of H3K27me3 during neurogenesis posited for Gene a critical role in the acquisition of neural fate. Despite evidence of its involvement in early neural commitment, however, its role in the emergence and maturation of the Species CNS remains unknown. Here, we inactivated Gene in the Species and found that its loss causes perinatal lethality with the complete and selective disruption of the pre-Botzinger complex (PBC), the pacemaker of the respiratory rhythm generator. Through genetic and electrophysiological approaches, we show that the enzymatic activity of Gene is selectively required for the maintenance of the PBC and controls critical regulators of PBC activity, uncovering an unanticipated role of this enzyme in the late structuring and function of neuronal networks.

22223437.pub_title: Targeting Gene expression in Disease during early skeletal development.
22223437.pub_abstract: Gene is a known master transcription factor for osteoblast differentiation, as well as an essential regulator for chondrocyte maturation. Recently, more and more data has shown that Gene regulates Disease chondrocyte-specific type X collagen gene (Gene) expression in different species. However, how Gene regulation of Gene expression impacts chondrocyte maturation, an essential step of endochondral bone formation, remains unknown. We have recently generated Species in which Flag-tagged Gene was driven by a cell-specific Gene control element. Significantly increased level of Gene and Gene mRNA transcripts were detected in Species Species limbs at both E17.5 (embryonic day 17.5) and P1 (post-natal day1) stages, suggesting an in vivo correlation of Gene and Gene expression. Surprisingly, skeletal staining suggested delayed ossification in both the axial and the appendicular skeleton of Species from E14.5 until P6. Histological analysis showed elongated Disease in Species, with less von Kossa and TUNEL staining in long bone sections at both E17.5 and P1 stages, suggesting defective mineralization due to delayed chondrocyte maturation or apoptosis. Indeed, we detected increased level of anti-apoptotic genes Gene, Gene, and Gene in Species by real-time RT-PCR. Moreover, immunohistochemistry and Western blotting analysis also suggested increased Gene expression in Disease chondrocytes of Species. Together, our data suggest that targeting Gene in Disease chondrocytes upregulates expression of Gene and other marker genes (such as Gene). This will change the local matrix environment, delay chondrocyte maturation, reduce apoptosis and matrix mineralization, and eventually, lead to Disease.

24766809.pub_title: Species Gene mutations alter tRNA biogenesis, affecting both peripheral and central nervous system function.
24766809.pub_abstract: Gene is a RNA kinase involved in tRNA splicing. Recently, Gene kinase-dead Species were shown to display a Disease with loss of motor neurons and Disease. Species genome analyses now identified a Gene homozygous missense mutation (Protein Mutation) in five unrelated families, leading to a loss of Gene interaction with the tRNA splicing endonuclease (TSEN) complex, largely reduced pre-tRNA cleavage activity, and accumulation of linear tRNA introns. The affected individuals develop severe motor-sensory defects, Disease, and Disease. Species carrying kinase-dead Gene also displayed Disease and reduced cortical brain volume due to the enhanced cell death of neuronal progenitors that is associated with reduced numbers of cortical neurons. Our data elucidate a Disease defined by Gene mutations that impair tRNA splicing. Reduction of a founder mutation to homozygosity illustrates the importance of rare variations in disease and supports the clan genomics hypothesis.

23172912.pub_title: Importance of the pluripotency factor Gene in the Species nucleolus during early embryonic development.
23172912.pub_abstract: The maternal nucleolus is required for proper activation of the embryonic genome (EGA) and early embryonic development. Nucleologenesis is characterized by the transformation of a nucleolar precursor body (Gene) to a mature nucleolus during preimplantation development. However, the function of NPBs and the involved molecular factors are unknown. We uncover a novel role for the pluripotency factor Gene, the biological significance of which was previously demonstrated in the reprogramming of Species somatic cells to induced pluripotent stem (Disease) cells. Here, we show that Gene accumulates at the Gene and the mature nucleolus in Species preimplantation embryos and embryonic stem cells (ESCs), where it colocalizes with the nucleolar marker B23 (Gene). Gene has nucleolar localization in non-Species primate (NHP) preimplantation embryos, but is cytoplasmic in NHP ESCs. Gene transcripts show a striking decline before Species EGA, whereas Gene protein localizes to NPBs at the time of EGA. Following knockdown with a Gene morpholino, the majority of embryos arrest between the 2- and 4-cell stages and never develop to morula or blastocyst. Gene morpholino-injected embryos arrested at the 2-cell stage were not enriched with Gene at presumptive Gene sites, indicating that functional NPBs were not assembled. Based on these results, we propose that Gene is an essential factor of nucleologenesis during early embryonic development.

26923596.pub_title: Gene Regulates Multiple Steps of Chondrocyte Differentiation during Skeletal Development and Bone Repair.
26923596.pub_abstract: Hippo signaling controls organ size and tissue regeneration in many organs, but its roles in chondrocyte differentiation and bone repair remain elusive. Here, we demonstrate that Gene, an effector of Hippo pathway inhibits skeletal development, postnatal growth, and bone repair. We show that Gene regulates chondrocyte differentiation at multiple steps in which it promotes early chondrocyte proliferation but inhibits subsequent chondrocyte maturation both in vitro and in vivo. Mechanistically, we find that Gene requires Teads binding for direct regulation of Gene expression to promote chondrocyte proliferation. In contrast, Gene inhibits chondrocyte maturation by suppression of Gene expression through interaction with Gene. In addition, Gene also governs the Disease repair by inhibition of cartilaginous callus tissue formation. Taken together, our work provides insights into the mechanism by which Gene regulates endochondral ossification, which may help the development of therapeutic treatment for bone regeneration.

22120711.pub_title: Reexpression of oncoprotein Gene in proliferative beta-cells and Gene Disease in Species.
22120711.pub_abstract: Gene, a member of the large Maf transcription factor family, is essential for the embryonic and terminal differentiation of pancreatic alpha- and beta-cells. However, the role of Gene in the control of adult islet-cell proliferation remains unknown. Considering its oncogenic potential in several other tissues, we investigated the possible alteration of its expression in adult Species beta-cells under different conditions of proliferation. We found that Gene, in general silenced in these cells, was reexpressed in ~30% of adaptive beta-cells both in gestational female Species and in Species fed with a high-fat diet. Importantly, reactivated Gene expression was also observed in the early beta-cell lesions and Disease that developed in beta-cell specific Gene mutant Species, appearing in >80% of beta-cells in hyperplasic or Disease islets from the mutant Species >4 months of age. Moreover, Gene expression could be induced by Chemical stimulation in INS-1 Species Disease cells. The induction was further reinforced following Gene knockdown by siRNA. Furthermore, Gene overexpression in cultured betaTC3 cells enhanced cell foci formation both in culture medium and on soft agar, accompanied with the increased expression of Gene and D2. Conversely, Gene downregulation by siRNA transfection reduced BrdU incorporation in INS-1E cells. Taken together, our data reveal that Gene inactivation leads to Gene reexpression in Species beta-cells in vivo, and provides evidence that deregulated ectopic Gene expression may have a hitherto unknown role in adult beta-cell proliferation and Gene-related tumorigenesis.

23658181.pub_title: Thalamic control of neocortical area formation in Species.
23658181.pub_abstract: The Species neocortex undergoes dramatic transformation during development, from a seemingly homogenous sheet of neuroepithelial cells into a complex structure that is tangentially divided into discrete areas. This process is thought to be controlled by a combination of intrinsic patterning mechanisms within the cortex and afferent axonal projections from the thalamus. However, roles of thalamic afferents in the formation of areas are still poorly understood. In this study, we show that genetically increasing or decreasing the size of the lateral geniculate nucleus of the Species thalamus resulted in a corresponding change in the size of the primary visual area. Furthermore, elimination of most thalamocortical projections from the outset of their development resulted in altered areal gene expression patterns, particularly in the primary visual and somatosensory areas, where they lost sharp boundaries with adjacent areas. Together, these results demonstrate the critical roles of thalamic afferents in the establishment of neocortical areas.

25249462.pub_title: Gene controls the number and distribution of astrocytes and oligodendrocytes in the gray matter and white matter of the spinal cord.
25249462.pub_abstract: Glia constitute the majority of cells in the Species central nervous system and are crucial for neurological function. However, there is an incomplete understanding of the molecular control of glial cell development. We find that the transcription factor Gene (Gene), which is best known for its role in neurogenesis, also functions in both astrocyte and oligodendrocyte lineages arising in the Species spinal cord at late embryonic stages. Clonal fate mapping in vivo reveals heterogeneity in Gene-expressing glial progenitors and shows that Gene defines cells that are restricted to either gray matter (GM) or white matter (WM) as astrocytes or oligodendrocytes. Conditional deletion of Gene post-neurogenesis shows that Gene is required during oligodendrogenesis for generating the correct numbers of WM but not GM oligodendrocyte precursor cells, whereas during astrocytogenesis Gene functions in balancing the number of dorsal GM protoplasmic astrocytes with dorsal WM fibrous astrocytes. Thus, in addition to its function in neurogenesis, Gene marks glial progenitors and controls the number and distribution of astrocytes and oligodendrocytes in the GM and WM of the spinal cord.

23660517.pub_title: Progressive impairment of muscle regeneration in Gene 3 isoform knockout Species.
23660517.pub_abstract: The Gene (Gene) genes encode alternative splicing factors that are essential for the postnatal development of multiple tissues, and the inhibition of Gene activity by toxic C(C)UG repeat RNAs is a major pathogenic feature of the neuromuscular disease Disease. While Gene controls fetal-to-adult splicing transitions in muscle and Gene serves a similar role in the brain, the function of Gene in vivo is unknown. Here, we report that Species Gene, which encodes protein isoforms that differ in the number of tandem zinc-finger RNA-binding motifs and subcellular localization, is expressed primarily during embryonic development but also transiently during injury-induced adult skeletal muscle regeneration. Gene expression is required for normal C2C12 myogenic differentiation and high-throughput sequencing combined with cross-linking/immunoprecipitation analysis indicates that Gene binds preferentially to the 3' untranslated regions of genes implicated in cell growth and proliferation. In addition, Mbnl3DeltaE2 isoform knockout Species, which fail to express the major Gene nuclear isoform, show age-dependent delays in injury-induced muscle regeneration and Disease. These results suggest that Gene inhibition by toxic RNA expression may be a contributing factor to the progressive skeletal Disease and wasting characteristic of Disease.

23638043.pub_title: Gene inhibitor Chemical delays disease progression but does not extend survival in the Gene Species model of Disease.
23638043.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) is a fatal Disease that causes progressive Disease due to motor neuron death. Several lines of published evidence suggested that inhibition of Gene (Gene) signaling might protect neurons from degeneration. To test this hypothesis in vivo, we treated the Gene transgenic Species model of Disease with Chemical, an Gene inhibitor clinically approved for oncology indications. Although Chemical failed to extend Disease Species survival it did provide a modest but significant delay in the onset of multiple behavioral measures of disease progression. However, given the lack of protection of motor neuron synapses and the lack of survival extension, the small benefits observed after Chemical treatment appear purely symptomatic, with no modification of disease course.

24771490.pub_title: A novel cell migratory zone in the developing hippocampal formation.
24771490.pub_abstract: The hippocampal formation (HF) is a unique structure in the Species brain and is subdivided into the dentate gyrus, Ammon's horn, and subiculum by their functions and connectivity in the neuronal circuit. Because behaviors of the neural stem cells, neuronal progenitors, and the differentiating neurons are complex during hippocampal morphogenesis, the differentiation of these subdivisions has not been well understood. In this study, we investigated embryonic and postnatal expression of the proteins Gene, Gene, and Gene, which clearly indicate principal cells of the dentate gyrus (Gene positive) and Ammon's horn (Gene and Gene positive). Expression patterns of Gene and Gene were consistent with previously suggested localization of migratory pathways of the dentate granule cells and hippocampal pyramidal cells. Interestingly, we found intermingling of Gene-expressing cells and Gene-expressing cells in a cell migratory stream, suggesting previously unknown behaviors of differentiating cells of the HF.

26324926.pub_title: Mutual regulation between Gene and Gene promotes subcerebral projection neuron identity in the developing cerebral cortex.
26324926.pub_abstract: Generation of distinct cortical projection neuron subtypes during development relies in part on repression of alternative neuron identities. It was reported that the Gene (Gene) is required for proper development of callosal neuron identity and represses expression of genes that are essential for subcerebral axon development. Surprisingly, Gene has recently been shown to be necessary for subcerebral axon development. Here, we unravel a previously unidentified mechanism underlying this paradox. We show that Gene directly activates transcription of Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene), genes essential for subcerebral neuron development. We find that the mutual regulation between Gene and Gene enables Gene to promote subcerebral neuron identity in layer 5 neurons, and to repress subcerebral characters in callosal neurons. Thus, Gene promotes the development of callosal and subcerebral neurons in a cell context-dependent manner.

25144937.pub_title: Gene is a physiological regulator of Gene that suppresses genomic instability and tumorigenesis.
25144937.pub_abstract: Cell-based studies showed that several Gene-binding ribosomal proteins, upon overexpression, stabilize and activate Gene. In contrast, here we show in a Species knockout study that Gene-binding Gene (Gene), upon disruption, activates Gene. Germline inactivation of Gene triggers ribosomal stress to stabilize Gene, which degrades Gene to reduce Gene-Gene E3 ligase towards Gene, leading to Gene-dependent apoptotic depletion of hematopoietic stem cells and postnatal Disease, which is rescued by Gene deletion. Paradoxically, while increased Gene is expected to inhibit tumorigenesis, Gene-/-;Gene+/- Species develop Disease at higher incidence with Gene loss-of-heterozygosity and severe genome Disease, suggesting that Gene disruption impose a selection pressure against Gene. Thus, Gene has dual functions in Gene regulation: under Gene+/+ background, Genel disruption triggers ribosomal stress to induce Gene and apoptosis, whereas under Gene+/- background, Genel disruption triggers genomic instability and Gene deletion to promote tumorigenesis. Our study provides a new paradigm of Gene regulation.

26265072.pub_title: Deletion of the tyrosine phosphatase Gene in Sertoli cells causes Disease in Species.
26265072.pub_abstract: The male's ability to reproduce is completely dependent on Sertoli cells. However, the mechanisms governing the functional integrity of Sertoli cells have remained largely unexplored. Here, we demonstrate that deletion of Gene in Sertoli cells results in Disease in Species. In Gene knockout Species (SCSKO), a normal population of Sertoli cells was observed, but the blood-testis barrier (Chemical) was not formed. Gene ablation initiated the untimely and excessive differentiation of spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs) by disturbing the expression of paracrine factors.
