As a consequence, the process of spermatogenesis was disrupted, and the germ cells were depleted. Furthermore, Gene deletion impaired the cell junctions of the primary Sertoli cells and failed to support the clonal formation of SSCs co-cultured with SCSKO Sertoli cells. As expected, Gene restoration largely restores the cell junctions of the primary Sertoli cells and the clonal formation of SSCs. To identify the underlying mechanism, we further demonstrated that the absence of Gene suppressed Gene phosphorylation, and thus, the expression of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)- and Chemical-induced target genes. These results collectively suggest that Gene is a critical signaling protein that is required to maintain Sertoli cell function and could serve as a novel target for Disease therapies.

22182523.pub_title: Redundant functions of Rac GTPases in inner ear morphogenesis.
22182523.pub_abstract: Development of the Species inner ear requires coordination of cell proliferation, cell fate determination and morphogenetic movements. While significant progress has been made in identifying developmental signals required for inner ear formation, less is known about how distinct signals are coordinated by their downstream mediators. Members of the Gene family of small GTPases are known regulators of cytoskeletal remodeling and numerous other cellular processes. However, the function of Rac GTPases in otic development is largely unexplored. Here, we show that Gene and Gene redundantly regulate many aspects of inner ear morphogenesis. While no morphological defects were observed in Gene(-/-) Species, Gene(CKO); Gene(-/-) double mutants displayed enhanced vestibular and cochlear Disease compared to Gene(CKO) single mutants. Moreover, in Gene(CKO); Gene(-/-) mutants, we observed compromised Gene-mediated cell adhesion, reduced cell proliferation and increased cell death in the early developing otocyst, leading to a decreased size and malformation of the membranous labyrinth. Finally, cochlear extension was severely disrupted in Gene(CKO); Gene(-/-) mutants, accompanied by a loss of epithelial cohesion and formation of ectopic sensory patches underneath the cochlear duct. The compartmentalized expression of otic patterning genes within the Gene(CKO); Gene(-/-) mutant otocyst was largely normal, however, indicating that Gene proteins regulate inner ear morphogenesis without affecting cell fate specification. Taken together, our results reveal an essential role for Rac GTPases in coordinating cell adhesion, cell proliferation, cell death and cell movements during otic development.

23321669.pub_title: Gene promotes Disease via Polycomb-dependent and -independent transcriptional programs.
23321669.pub_abstract: Epigenetic mechanisms mediate heritable control of cell identity in normal cells and Disease. We sought to identify epigenetic regulators driving the pathogenesis of Disease (PDAC), one of the most lethal Species Disease. We found that Gene (also known as Ndy1, Gene, and Gene), an H3K36 histone demethylase implicated in bypass of cellular senescence and somatic cell reprogramming, is markedly overexpressed in Species PDAC, with levels increasing with disease grade and stage, and highest expression in metastases. Gene silencing abrogated tumorigenicity of PDAC cell lines exhibiting loss of epithelial differentiation, whereas Gene overexpression cooperated with KrasG12D to promote PDAC formation in Species models. Gain- and loss-of-function experiments coupled to genome-wide gene expression and ChIP studies revealed that Gene drives tumorigenicity through 2 different transcriptional mechanisms. Gene repressed developmental genes through cobinding with Polycomb group (PcG) proteins at transcriptional start sites, whereas it activated a module of metabolic genes, including mediators of protein synthesis and mitochondrial function, cobound by the Gene oncogene and the histone demethylase Gene. These results defined epigenetic programs through which Gene subverts cellular differentiation and drives the pathogenesis of an aggressive subset of PDAC.

27390088.pub_title: Gene is required for cardiomyocyte proliferation in Species neonatal hearts.
27390088.pub_abstract: It has been long recognized that the Species heart loses its proliferative capacity soon after birth, yet, the molecular basis of this loss of cardiac proliferation postnatally is largely unknown. In this study, we found that cardiac Gene, a member of the epidermal growth factor receptor family, exhibits a rapid and dramatic decline in expression at the neonatal stage. We further demonstrate that conditional ablation of Gene in the ventricular myocardium results in upregulation of negative cell cycle regulators and a significant reduction in cardiomyocyte proliferation during the narrow neonatal proliferative time window. Together, our data reveal a positive correlation between the expression levels of Gene with Disease and suggest that reduction in cardiac Gene expression may contribute to the loss of postnatal cardiomyocyte proliferative capacity.

23761906.pub_title: Conditional deletion of Gene reveals distinct critical periods for survival and function of hair cells in the organ of Corti.
23761906.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) encodes a basic helix-loop-helix protein that is the first transcription factor to be expressed in differentiating hair cells. Previous work suggests that expression of Gene in prosensory precursors is necessary for the differentiation and survival of hair cells, but it is not clear whether Gene is required exclusively for these processes, or whether it regulates other functions later during hair cell maturation. We used EGFP-tagged Gene knock-in Species to demonstrate for the first time that Gene protein is expressed in hair cell precursors several days before the appearance of differentiated markers, but not in the broad pattern expected of a proneural gene. We conditionally deleted Gene at different points in hair cell development and observe a rapid onset of Disease, suggesting that the Gene protein is unstable in differentiating hair cells and is necessary through an extended phase of their differentiation. Conditional deletion of Gene reveals multiple functions in hair cell survival, maturation of stereociliary bundles, and auditory function. We show the presence of distinct critical periods for Gene in each of these functions, suggesting that Gene may be directly regulating many aspects of hair cell function. Finally, we show that the supporting cell death that accompanies loss of Gene in hair cells is likely caused by the abortive trans-differentiation of supporting cells into hair cells. Together our data suggest that Gene regulates multiple aspects of hair cell development and function.

22351047.pub_title: Characterization of G protein-coupled receptor 56 protein expression in the Species developing neocortex.
22351047.pub_abstract: Gene, one of the adhesion G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), plays an important role in the development of the cerebral cortex. Mutations in Gene cause a severe Species cortical malformation called bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria (Chemical), characterized by a global malformation of the cerebral cortex that most severely affects the frontal and parietal regions. To characterize the expression pattern of Gene in the developing cerebral cortex, we developed a Species monoclonal antibody against Species Gene. We revealed that Gene is expressed in multiple cell types in the preplate, marginal zone, subventricular zone (SVZ), and ventricular zone (VZ). Most interestingly, the expression of Gene in preplate neurons showed an anterior-to-posterior gradient at embryonic day (E) 10.5-11.5. In contrast, the expression pattern of the Gene ligand, collagen III, revealed no visible gradient pattern. With the widespread expression of Gene in the developing cortex, it is difficult to draw a specific conclusion as to which of the Gene-expressing cells are critical for Species brain development. However, the correlation between Gene expression in neurons at E10.5-E11.5 and the anatomic distribution of the cortical malformation in both Species and Species suggests that its function in preplate neurons is indispensible.

25232016.pub_title: Establishment of paternal genomic imprinting in Species prospermatogonia analyzed by nuclear transfer.
25232016.pub_abstract: In Species, the establishment of paternal genomic imprinting in male germ cells starts at midgestation, as suggested by DNA methylation analyses of differentially methylated regions (DMRs). However, this information is based on averages from mixed populations of germ cells, and the DNA methylation pattern might not always provide a full representation of imprinting status. To obtain more detailed information on the establishment of paternal imprinting, single prospermatogonia at Embryonic Days 15.5 (E15.5), E16.5, and E17.5 and at Day 0.5 after birth were cloned using nuclear transfer; previous reports suggested that cloned embryos reflected the Species's genomic imprinting status. Then, the resultant fetuses (E9.5) were analyzed for the DNA methylation pattern of three paternal DMRs (IG-Gene, H19 Gene, and Gene Gene) and the expression pattern of imprinted genes therein. The overall data indicated that establishment of genomic imprinting in all paternally imprinted regions was completed by E17.5, following a short intermediate period at E16.5. Furthermore, comparison between the methylation status of DMRs and the expression profiles of imprinted genes suggested that methylation of the IG-Gene, but not the H19 Gene, solely governed the control of its imprinted gene cluster. The Gene Gene seemed to be imprinted later than the other two genes. We also found that the methylation status of the Gene Gene, the secondary Gene that acquires DNA methylation after fertilization, was likely to follow the methylation status of the upstream IG-Gene. Thus, the systematic analyses of Chemical-derived embryos provided additional important information on the establishment of paternal imprinting.

24335253.pub_title: Gene cell-autonomously determines dorsal Disease fate independently of isthmic organizing activity.
24335253.pub_abstract: During embryonic development, the rostral neuroectoderm is regionalized into broad areas that are subsequently subdivided into progenitor compartments with specialized identity and fate. These events are controlled by signals emitted by organizing centers and interpreted by target progenitors, which activate superimposing waves of intrinsic factors restricting their identity and fate. The transcription factor Gene plays a crucial role in Disease development by positioning the midbrain-hindbrain boundary (MHB) and its organizing activity. Here, we investigated whether Gene is cell-autonomously required to control identity and fate of dorsal Disease progenitors. With this aim, we have inactivated Gene in the Gene(+) dorsal Disease domain, previously named m1, without affecting MHB integrity. We found that the Gene(+) m1 domain can be further subdivided into a dorsal Gene(+) m1a and a ventral Gene(-) m1b sub-domain. Loss of Gene in the m1a (Gene(+) Gene(+)) sub-domain impairs the identity and fate of progenitors, which undergo a full switch into a coordinated cerebellum differentiation program. By contrast, in the m1b sub-domain (Gene(+) Gene) Gene is prevalently required for post-mitotic transition of Disease GABAergic precursors. Moreover, genetic cell fate, BrdU cell labeling and Gene conditional inactivation experiments indicate that in Gene mutants all ectopic cerebellar cell types, including external granule cell layer (EGL) precursors, originate from the m1a progenitor sub-domain and that reprogramming of Disease precursors into EGL or cerebellar GABAergic progenitors depends on temporal sensitivity to Gene ablation. Together, these findings indicate that Gene intrinsically controls different aspects of dorsal Disease. In this context, Gene is cell-autonomously required in the m1a sub-domain to suppress cerebellar fate and promote Disease differentiation independently of the MHB organizing activity.

27629416.pub_title: Gene Contributes to Neurogenesis via Stabilizing the Mucin-type O-Glycoprotein Podoplanin.
27629416.pub_abstract: Mucin-type O-glycosylation is initiated by an evolutionarily conserved family of polypeptide Chemical-acetylgalactosaminyltransferases (ppGalNAc-Ts). Previously, it was reported that Gene is restrictively expressed at a high level in the brain. Here we provide evidence for the critical role of Gene in neural differentiation. In detail, we show that the expression of Gene was dramatically up-regulated during early neurogenesis in Species embryonic brains. Similar changes were also observed in cell models of neuronal differentiation by using either primary Species cortical neural precursor cells or Species Disease P19 cells. Knockout of Gene in P19 cells suppressed not only neural induction but also neuronal differentiation. These effects are at least partly mediated by the mucin-type O-glycoprotein Chemical (Gene), as knockdown of Gene led to a similar inhibition of neuronal differentiation and Gene was significantly reduced at the posttranscriptional level after Gene knockout. Further data demonstrate that Gene acts as a substrate of Gene and that the Gene-mediated O-glycosylation on Gene is important for its stability. Taken together, this study suggests that Gene contributes to neuronal differentiation through glycosylating and stabilizing Gene, which provides insights into the regulatory roles of O-glycosylation in Species neural development.

26045045.pub_title: Gene-mediated Gene degradation is required for nuclear degradation and normal epidermal terminal differentiation.
26045045.pub_abstract: Nuclear degradation is a key stage in keratinocyte terminal differentiation and the formation of the cornified envelope that comprises the majority of epidermal barrier function. Disease, the retention of nuclear material in the cornified layer of the epidermis, is a common histological observation in many Disease, notably in Disease and Disease. Keratinocyte nuclear degradation is not well characterised, and it is unclear whether the retained nuclei contribute to the altered epidermal differentiation seen in Disease and Disease. Loss of Gene function strongly correlated with Disease both in Disease samples and in organotypic culture models. Although levels of DNAses, including Gene, were unchanged, proteomic analysis revealed an increase in Gene. Gene phosphorylates Gene, targeting it for degradation. Consistent with this, Gene degradation was inhibited and Gene was observed in the cornified layer of Gene knockdown organotypic cultures, surrounding retained nuclear material. Using Gene-phosphorylation-dead Lamin A constructs we show that the retention of nuclear material is sufficient to cause profound changes in epidermal terminal differentiation, specifically a reduction in Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene expression. We show that preventing nuclear degradation upregulates Gene expression and Gene signalling. Consistent with these data, we observe both Disease and evidence of increased Gene signalling in Disease. We therefore present a model that, in the absence of Gene-mediated Gene degradation, DNA degradation processes, such as those mediated by Gene, are prevented, leading to Disease and changes in epidermal differentiation.

24039599.pub_title: Stochastic loss of silencing of the imprinted Gene/Gene allele, in a Species model and Species with Disease, has functional consequences.
24039599.pub_abstract: Genomic imprinting is a process that causes genes to be expressed from one allele only according to parental origin, the other allele being silent. Diseases can arise when the normally active alleles are not expressed. In this context, low level of expression of the normally silent alleles has been considered as genetic noise although such expression has never been further studied. Disease (Disease) is a Disease involving imprinted genes, including Gene, which are only expressed from the paternally inherited allele, with the maternally inherited allele silent. We present the first in-depth study of the low expression of a normally silent imprinted allele, in pathological context. Using a variety of qualitative and quantitative approaches and comparing wild-type, heterozygous and homozygous Species deleted for Gene, we show that, in absence of the paternal Gene allele, the maternal Gene allele is expressed at an extremely low level with a high degree of non-genetic heterogeneity. The level of this expression is sex-dependent and shows transgenerational epigenetic inheritance. In about 50% of mutant Species, this expression reduces birth lethality and severity of the Disease, correlated with a reduction in the loss of serotonergic neurons. In wild-type brains, the maternal Gene allele is never expressed. However, using several Species models, we reveal a competition between non-imprinted Gene promoters which results in monoallelic (paternal or maternal) Gene expression, suggesting that Gene allelic exclusion occurs in the absence of imprinting regulation. Importantly, specific expression of the maternal Gene allele is also detected in post-mortem brain samples of Disease individuals. Our data reveal an unexpected epigenetic flexibility of Disease imprinted genes that could be exploited to reactivate the functional but dormant maternal alleles in Disease. Overall our results reveal high non-genetic heterogeneity between genetically identical individuals that might underlie the variability of the phenotype.

25246615.pub_title: Gene is required for timely activation of Disease/C in meiosis I and Gene reactivation in meiosis II.
25246615.pub_abstract: In mitosis, the Greatwall kinase (called Gene [Gene] in mammals) is essential for prometaphase entry or progression by suppressing protein Gene (Gene) activity. Gene suppression in turn leads to high levels of Gene substrate phosphorylation. We have used a Species model with an oocyte-specific deletion of Gene to show that Gene-null oocytes resume meiosis I and reach metaphase I normally but that the onset and completion of anaphase I are delayed. Moreover, after the completion of meiosis I, Gene-null oocytes failed to enter meiosis II (MII) because they reassembled a nuclear structure containing decondensed chromatin. Our results show that Gene is required for the timely activation of anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome to allow meiosis I exit and for the rapid rise of Gene activity that is needed for the entry into MII in Species oocytes.

27562601.pub_title: Gene and Gene regulate spindle orientation by affecting the dynamics of astral microtubules.
27562601.pub_abstract: Correct orientation of cell division is considered an important factor for the achievement of normal brain size, as mutations in genes that affect this process are among the leading causes of Disease. Abnormal spindle orientation is associated with reduction of the neuronal progenitor symmetric divisions, premature cell cycle exit, and reduced neurogenesis. This mechanism has been involved in Disease resulting from mutation of Gene, the most frequently affected gene in autosomal recessive Species primary Disease (MCPH), but it is presently unknown how Gene regulates spindle orientation. In this report, we show that Gene may control spindle positioning by interacting with Species kinase (Gene), a protein whose loss is also responsible for severe Disease in mammals. We show that the absence of Gene leads to abnormal spindle orientation in mammals and insects. In Species cortical development, this phenotype correlates with increased production of basal progenitors. Gene is required to recruit Gene at the spindle, and Gene overexpression rescues Gene phenotype. Gene and Gene affect the organization of astral microtubules (MT), and low doses of MT-stabilizing drug revert the spindle orientation phenotype produced by their knockdown. Finally, Gene regulates both astral-MT nucleation and stability. Our results provide a functional link between two established Disease proteins.

22753148.pub_title: Distinct roles of microRNAs in epithelium and mesenchyme during tooth development.
22753148.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Tooth development is known to be mediated by the cross-talk between signaling pathways, including Gene, Fgf, Bmp, and Wnt. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are 19- to 25-nt noncoding small single-stranded RNAs that negatively regulate gene expression by binding target mRNAs, which is believed to be important for the fine-tuning signaling pathways in development. To investigate the role of miRNAs in tooth development, we examined Species with either mesenchymal (Wnt1Cre/Dicer(fl/fl)) or epithelial (ShhCre/Dicer(fl/fl)) conditional deletion of Dicer, which is essential for miRNA processing. RESULTS: By using a Gene genetic background for Wnt1Cre/Dicer(fl/fl), we were able to examine tooth development, because the mutants retained mandible and Disease. Wnt1Cre/Dicer(fl/fl) Species showed an Disease or absence of teeth development, which varied in frequency between incisors and molars. Extra incisor tooth formation was found in ShhCre/Dicer(fl/fl) Species, whereas molars showed no significant anomalies. Microarray and in situ hybridization analysis identified several miRNAs that showed differential expression between incisors and molars. CONCLUSION: In tooth development, miRNAs thus play different roles in epithelium and mesenchyme, and in incisors and molars.

24428937.pub_title: Gene/Gene is required for the generation of Gene-expressing microvillous cells in the Species main olfactory epithelium.
24428937.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The main olfactory epithelium (MOE) in mammals is a specialized organ to detect odorous molecules in the external environment. The MOE consists of four types of cells: olfactory sensory neurons, supporting cells, basal cells, and microvillous cells. Among these, development and function of microvillous cells remain largely unknown. Recent studies have shown that a population of microvillous cells expresses the monovalent cation channel Gene (Gene). To examine functional differentiation of Gene-expressing microvillous cells in the MOE, we investigated the expression and function of Gene, a POU (Pit-Oct-Unc) transcription factor required for functional differentiation of Gene-expressing sweet, umami, and bitter taste bud cells in oropharyngeal epithelium and solitary chemosensory cells in nasal respiratory epithelium. RESULTS: Gene is expressed in a subset of basal cells and apical non-neuronal cells in the MOE of Disease and adult Species. Two-color in situ hybridization revealed that a small population of Gene-expressing cells was co-labeled with Gene/Gene and that most Gene-expressing cells coexpress Gene. To investigate whether Gene has an irreplaceable role in the MOE, we analyzed Gene-deficient Species. In the absence of Gene, olfactory sensory neurons differentiate normally except for a limited defect in terminal differentiation in ectoturbinate 2 of some of MOEs examined. In contrast, the impact of Disease on Gene-expressing microvillous cells is much more striking: Gene, villin, and Gene, cell markers previously shown to identify Gene-expressing microvillous cells, were no longer detectable in Gene-deficient Species. In addition, quantitative analysis demonstrated that the density of superficial microvillous cells was significantly decreased in Gene-deficient Species. CONCLUSION: Gene is expressed in a minority of Gene-positive olfactory progenitor cells and a majority of Gene-expressing microvillous cells in the main olfactory epithelium. Loss-of-function mutation of Gene resulted in complete loss of Gene-expressing microvillous cells, whereas most of olfactory sensory neurons differentiated normally. Thus, Gene is a critical regulator for the generation of Gene-expressing microvillous cells in the main olfactory epithelium in Species.

21954064.pub_title: Deletion of a single allele of the Gene gene is sufficient to cause oxidative stress, delayed differentiation and Disease in Species brain.
21954064.pub_abstract: Impaired neuronal migration and cell death are commonly observed in Species with Disease (Chemical), and in Species models of this diseases. In Gene-deficient Species, we observed that the deletion of a single allele of the Gene gene (Gene(+/-) heterozygous Species) caused cell death in primary neuronal cultures prepared from the neocortex and cerebellum, although to a lesser extent as compared with the homozygous-null animals (Gene(-/-) Species). In corresponding brain sections, cell death was rare, but differences between the genotypes were similar to those found in vitro. Because Gene has been implicated in peroxisomal proliferation, we searched for alterations in peroxisomal abundance in the brain of heterozygous and homozygous Gene-null Species compared with wild-type animals. Deletion of one allele of the Gene gene slightly increased the abundance of peroxisomes, whereas the deletion of both alleles caused a 30% reduction in peroxisome number. The size of the peroxisomal compartment did not correlate with Disease. Similar to cell death, neuronal development was delayed in Gene(+/-) Species, and to a further extent in Gene(-/-) Species, as measured by a reduced mRNA and protein level of Gene and a reduced protein level of the mature isoform of Gene. Moreover, a gradual increase in oxidative stress was found in brain sections and primary neuronal cultures from wild-type to heterozygous to homozygous Gene-deficient Species. Gene was upregulated in neurons from Gene(+/-) Species, but not from Gene(-/-) animals, whereas the level of Gene remained unchanged in neurons from Gene(+/-) Species and was reduced in those from Gene(-/-) Species, suggesting a partial compensation of oxidative stress in the heterozygotes, but a failure thereof in the homozygous Gene(-/-) brain. In conclusion, we report the alterations in the brain caused by the deletion of a single allele of the Gene gene. Our data might lead to the reconsideration of the clinical treatment of Chemical and the common way of using knockout Species models for studying Disease.

23312518.pub_title: Gene-dependent expression of Gene (Gene, Gene) regulates the fate switch between cortical and striatal interneurons.
23312518.pub_abstract: Species pallial (cortical and hippocampal) and striatal interneurons are both generated in the embryonic subpallium, including the medial ganglionic eminence (MGE). Herein we demonstrate that the Gene (Gene, Gene) zinc finger homeobox gene is required in the MGE, directly downstream of Gene, to generate cortical interneurons that express Gene, Gene, and Gene. In its absence, Gene expression is not repressed, and cells that ordinarily would become cortical interneurons appear to transform toward a subtype of GABAergic striatal interneurons. These results show that Gene is required to generate cortical interneurons, and suggest a mechanism for the Disease observed in Species with Gene mutations (Mowat-Disease).

23319657.pub_title: Gene signaling in chondrocytes modulates endochondral ossification and Disease development.
23319657.pub_abstract: Here we examined the involvement of Gene signaling in the endochondral ossification process, which is crucial for Disease (OA) development. Intracellular domains of Gene were translocated into the nucleus of chondrocytes with their differentiation in Species limb cartilage and in Species and Species Disease. A tissue-specific inactivation of the Gene transcriptional effector recombination signal binding protein for Ig kappa J (RBPjkappa) in chondroprogenitor cells of Gene (Gene)-Cre;Gene(fl/fl) Species embryos caused an impaired terminal stage of endochondral ossification in the limb cartilage. The RBPjkappa inactivation in adult articular cartilage after normal skeletal growth using type II collagen (Gene)-Cre(Gene);Gene(fl/fl) Species by Chemical injection caused resistance to OA development in the knee joint. Notch intracellular domain with the effector RBPjkappa stimulated endochondral ossification through induction of the target gene Gene in chondrocytes. Among the Gene ligands, Gene was strongly induced during OA development. Finally, intraarticular injection of Chemical (DAPT), a small compound Gene inhibitor, to the Species knee joint prevented OA development. The RBPjkappa-dependent Gene signaling in chondrocytes modulates the terminal stage of endochondral ossification and OA development, representing an extracellular therapeutic target of OA.

23150495.pub_title: Ablation of Gene-positive cells in male Species anterior pituitary leads to atypical Disease.
23150495.pub_abstract: In this study, we have investigated the expression and function of the transcription factor Gene (Gene)/Gene in the developing anterior pituitary. Gene is initially expressed in all differentiating hormonal cells types, but its expression is mostly restricted to the somatotroph lineage after birth. Gene knockout results in Disease. However, the analysis of a conditional mutant demonstrates that this phenotype does not originate from a lack of Gene expression in the pituitary. Using an Gene allele driving a Cre-activable toxin gene, we performed a genetic ablation of Gene-positive cells in the pituitary. During the postnatal period, this ablation leads to specific and progressive depletion of the somatotroph population, creating a novel model of early-onset Disease (Disease). Mutant animals were subjected to a complete metabolic analysis, revealing atypical and expected features. Consistent with an adult-onset isolated Disease model, mutant animals are Disease and display increased insulin sensitivity and Chemical clearance. This latter phenotype is in contrast to the Chemical intolerance observed in another early-onset Disease model. Surprisingly, increased insulin sensitivity is not accompanied by a modified balance between fat and lean tissues, but by reduced metabolic adaptability between Chemical and lipid oxidation conditions. This suggests that the relationship between these metabolic features and insulin sensitivity should be reconsidered. In conclusion, our mutant may be a valuable genetic model with which to study the effects of long-term Disease, in conditions of normal pancreatic function and unaffected balance between fat and Disease.

24927569.pub_title: Notch regulation of myogenic versus endothelial fates of cells that migrate from the somite to the limb.
24927569.pub_abstract: Multipotent Gene-positive (Gene(+)) cells in the somites give rise to skeletal muscle and to cells of the vasculature. We had previously proposed that this cell-fate choice depends on the equilibrium between Gene and Gene expression. In this study, we report that the Notch pathway promotes vascular versus skeletal muscle cell fates. Overactivating the Notch pathway specifically in Gene(+) progenitors, via a conditional Gene(NICD) allele, results in an increase of the number of smooth muscle and endothelial cells contributing to the aorta. At limb level, Gene(+) cells in the somite give rise to skeletal muscles and to a subpopulation of endothelial cells in blood vessels of the limb. We now demonstrate that in addition to the inhibitory role of Notch signaling on skeletal muscle cell differentiation, the Notch pathway affects the Gene:Gene balance and promotes the endothelial versus myogenic cell fate, before migration to the limb, in multipotent Gene(+) cells in the somite of the Species embryo.

25092332.pub_title: Disease chondrocytes can become osteoblasts and osteocytes in endochondral bone formation.
25092332.pub_abstract: According to current dogma, chondrocytes and osteoblasts are considered independent lineages derived from a common osteochondroprogenitor. In endochondral bone formation, chondrocytes undergo a series of differentiation steps to form the growth plate, and it generally is accepted that death is the ultimate fate of terminally differentiated Disease chondrocytes (HCs). Osteoblasts, accompanying vascular invasion, lay down endochondral bone to replace cartilage. However, whether an HC can become an osteoblast and contribute to the full osteogenic lineage has been the subject of a century-long debate. Here we use a cell-specific Chemical-inducible genetic recombination approach to track the fate of Species HCs and show that they can survive the cartilage-to-bone transition and become osteogenic cells in fetal and postnatal endochondral bones and persist into adulthood. This discovery of a chondrocyte-to-osteoblast lineage continuum revises concepts of the ontogeny of osteoblasts, with implications for the control of bone homeostasis and the interpretation of the underlying pathological bases of Disease.

26631740.pub_title: Lack of Gene Downregulation Disrupts the Expansion and Maturation of Postnatal Species beta-Cells.
26631740.pub_abstract: Transcription factor expression fluctuates during beta-cell ontogeny, and disruptions in this pattern can affect the development or function of those cells. Here we uncovered that Species endocrine pancreatic progenitors express high levels of the homeodomain transcription factor Gene, whereas both immature and mature beta-cells scarcely express this protein. We also investigated if sustained Gene expression is incompatible with beta-cell development or maintenance using transgenic Species approaches. We discovered that Gene upregulation in mature beta-cells has no functional consequences; in contrast, Gene overexpression in immature beta-cells promotes acute fasting Disease. Using a combination of immunostaining and quantitative and comparative gene expression analyses, we determined that Gene upregulation reduces proliferation, impairs maturation, and enables apoptosis in postnatal beta-cells. Also, we uncovered substantial deficiency in beta-cells that overexpress Gene of the key regulator of beta-cell maturation Gene, several Gene downstream targets required for Chemical-stimulated insulin secretion, and genes encoding important components of FGF signaling. Moreover, knocking down Gene in Species EndoC-betaH1 beta-cells caused increased expression of many of these same gene products. These and other results in our study indicate that reducing the expression of Gene is beneficial for the expansion and maturation of postnatal beta-cells.

23676498.pub_title: Gene is required for postimplantation uterine function and pregnancy maintenance.
23676498.pub_abstract: Abnormalities in cell-cell communication and growth factor signaling pathways can lead to defects in maternal-fetal interactions during pregnancy, including immunologic rejection of the fetal/placental unit. In this study, we discovered that Gene (Gene) is essential for postimplantation physiology and fertility. Despite normal implantation and early placental/fetal development, deletion of Gene in the uterine deciduae of Species triggered Disease in decidualization that resulted in abnormal vascular development, Disease, and a deficiency of uterine natural killer cells. Absence of Gene signaling in the uterine decidua consequently suppressed Gene, Gene, angiopoietin, and Gene signaling. Disruption of these pathways collectively lead to placental Disease, fetal demise, and female sterility, thereby placing Gene at a central point in the regulation of several physiologic signaling pathways and events at the maternal-fetal interface. Since trophoblast invasion and uterine vascular modification are implicated in normal placentation and fetal growth in Species, our findings suggest that abnormalities in uterine Gene-mediated signaling pathways can have catastrophic consequences in Species for the maintenance of pregnancy.

22157817.pub_abstract: In the Species embryo, few mechanical signals have been identified to influence organ development and function. Here, we report that an increase in the volume of interstitial or extracellular fluid mechanically induces growth of an organ system, that is, the lymphatic vasculature. We first demonstrate that lymph vessel expansion in the developing Species embryo correlates with a peak in interstitial fluid pressure and lymphatic endothelial cell (LEC) elongation. In 'loss-of-fluid' experiments, we then show that aspiration of interstitial fluid reduces the length of LECs, decreases Chemical phosphorylation of Gene (Gene), and inhibits LEC proliferation. Conversely, in 'gain-of-fluid' experiments, increasing the amount of interstitial fluid elongates the LECs, and increases both Gene phosphorylation and LEC proliferation. Finally, we provide genetic evidence that Gene integrins are required for the proliferative response of LECs to both fluid accumulation and cell stretching and, therefore, are necessary for lymphatic vessel expansion and fluid drainage. Thus, we propose a new and physiologically relevant mode of Gene activation, which is based on mechanotransduction and is essential for normal development and fluid homeostasis in a Species embryo.

26742650.pub_title: Notch signal reception is required in vascular smooth muscle cells for ductus arteriosus closure.
26742650.pub_abstract: The ductus arteriosus is an arterial vessel that shunts blood flow away from the lungs during fetal life, but normally occludes after birth to establish the adult circulation pattern. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close after birth is termed patent ductus arteriosus, and is one of the most common Disease. Our previous work demonstrated that vascular smooth muscle cell expression of the Gene gene, which encodes a ligand for Notch family receptors, is essential for postnatal closure of the ductus arteriosus in Species. However, it was not known what cell population was responsible for receiving the Gene-mediated signal. Here we show, using smooth muscle cell-specific deletion of the Gene gene, which encodes a transcription factor that mediates all canonical Notch signaling, that Notch signal reception in the vascular smooth muscle cell compartment is required for ductus arteriosus closure. These data indicate that homotypic vascular smooth muscle cell interactions are required for proper contractile smooth muscle cell differentiation and postnatal closure of the ductus arteriosus in Species.

23475960.pub_title: Gene is required for the specification of joint cell fates.
23475960.pub_abstract: Joints form within the developing skeleton through the segmentation and cavitation of initially continuous cartilage condensations. However, the molecular pathways controlling joint formation largely remain to be clarified. In particular, while several critical secreted signals have been identified, no transcription factors have yet been described as acting in the early stages of joint formation. Working upstream of the early joint marker Gene, we found that the transcription factor Gene plays a pivotal role in specifying joint cell fates. We first identified an enhancer upstream of the Gene gene driving joint-specific expression in transgenic reporter Species. A comprehensive in silico screen suggested Gene as a candidate transcription factor activating this Gene enhancer element. Gene is specifically expressed in joints during embryonic joint development, and its conditional deletion from early limb bud mesenchyme in Species severely affects both initiation and subsequent differentiation of all Disease. Gene directly regulates Gene as well as Gene during early stages of joint development, causing a decrease of canonical Gene activity in the joint interzone. Postnatally, Gene-deficient Species show a range of Disease, including Disease between juxtaposed skeletal elements, irregular articular surfaces, and Disease of ligaments.

25605943.pub_title: Clonal analysis reveals a common origin between nonsomite-derived neck muscles and Disease.
25605943.pub_abstract: Neck muscles constitute a transition zone between somite-derived skeletal muscles of the trunk and limbs, and muscles of the head, which derive from cranial mesoderm. The trapezius and Disease are formed from progenitor cells that have expressed markers of cranial pharyngeal mesoderm, whereas other muscles in the neck arise from Gene-expressing cells in the somites. Mef2c-AHF-Cre genetic tracing experiments and Gene mutant analysis show that nonsomitic neck muscles share a gene regulatory network with cardiac progenitor cells in pharyngeal mesoderm of the second heart field (SHF) and branchial arch-derived head muscles. Retrospective clonal analysis shows that this group of neck muscles includes laryngeal muscles and a component of the splenius muscle, of mixed somitic and nonsomitic origin. We demonstrate that the trapezius muscle group is clonally related to myocardium at the venous pole of the heart, which derives from the posterior SHF. The left clonal sublineage includes myocardium of the pulmonary trunk at the arterial pole of the heart. Although muscles derived from the first and second Disease also share a clonal relationship with different SHF-derived parts of the heart, neck muscles are clonally distinct from these muscles and define a third clonal population of common skeletal and cardiac muscle progenitor cells within cardiopharyngeal mesoderm. By linking neck muscle and heart development, our findings highlight the importance of cardiopharyngeal mesoderm in the evolution of the vertebrate heart and neck and in the pathophysiology of Species Disease.

23022071.pub_title: The Gene related genes, Gene, Gene, and Mut, are broadly expressed in placental and embryonic tissues during Species organogenesis.
23022071.pub_abstract: Organ-specific Disease are seen in Species with some Disease of Chemical metabolism. To determine whether three Species genes, whose Species counterparts are associated with isolated Gene (Gene, Gene and Mut), show tissue-specific expression during organogenesis, we used in situ hybridization to characterize their pattern of expression in wild type embryos and placentas at embryonic days (E) E10.5, E11.5 and E12.5. These three genes are ubiquitously expressed in the placenta and in embryos at E10.5. At E11.5, we observed tissue specific expression patterns for these three genes in lung, head and Rathke's pouch. At E12.5, although Mut expression was ubiquitous, we found cell-type specific expression patterns for Gene and Gene in the developing craniofacial region, the lung, the liver, and the gut. These results suggest that during organogenesis the proteins encoded by these three genes may interact in only a subset of cells.

22790009.pub_title: Gene and Gene cooperate to regulate gangliogenesis, axon guidance and target innervation in the sympathetic nervous system.
22790009.pub_abstract: The sympathetic nervous system (SNS) arises from neural crest (NC) cells during embryonic development and innervates the internal organs of vertebrates to modulate their stress response. Gene and Gene are receptors for guidance cues of the class 3 Gene (Gene) family and are expressed in partially overlapping patterns in sympathetic NC cells and their progeny. By comparing the phenotypes of Species lacking Gene or its ligand Gene with Species lacking Gene in the sympathetic versus vascular endothelial cell lineages, we demonstrate that Gene signalling through Gene has multiple cell-autonomous roles in SNS development. These roles include neuronal cell body positioning, Disease and axon guidance, first during sympathetic chain assembly and then to regulate the innervation of the heart and aorta. Loss of Gene or its ligand Gene impaired sympathetic gangliogenesis more mildly than loss of Gene/Gene signalling, but caused ectopic neurite extension along the embryonic aorta. The analysis of compound mutants lacking Gene and Gene or Gene and Gene in the SNS demonstrated that both signalling pathways cooperate to organise the SNS. We further show that abnormal sympathetic development in Species lacking Gene in the sympathetic lineage has functional consequences, as it causes sinus Disease, similar to Species lacking Gene.

22615490.pub_title: Phosphorylation of distinct sites in Gene modifies cofactor associations and the dynamics of transcriptional regulation.
22615490.pub_abstract: Mutations in the gene encoding methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (Gene) lead to disrupted neuronal function and can cause the Disease. Gene is a transcriptional regulator that binds to methylated DNA and is most abundant in neuronal nuclei. The mechanisms by which Gene regulates gene expression remain ambiguous, as it has been reported to function as a transcriptional silencer or activator and to execute these activities through both gene-specific and genome-wide mechanisms. We hypothesized that posttranslational modifications of Gene may be important for reconciling these apparently contradictory functions. Our results demonstrate that Gene contains multiple posttranslational modifications, including phosphorylation, acetylation, and ubiquitylation. Phosphorylation of Gene at S229 or Chemical influenced selective in vivo interactions with the chromatin factors Gene and Gene and the cofactors Gene and Gene. pS229 Gene was specifically enriched at the Gene promoter, and phosphorylation of Gene was necessary for differentiation-induced activation and repression of the Gene target genes Gene and Gene. These results demonstrate that phosphorylation is one of several factors that are important for interpreting the complexities of Gene transcriptional modulation.

26005867.pub_title: Transcriptional regulator Gene is essential for Species Disease perception.
26005867.pub_abstract: Disease perception has evolved as a warning mechanism to alert organisms to tissue damage and dangerous environments. In Species, however, undesirable, excessive or Disease is a common and major societal burden for which available medical treatments are currently suboptimal. New therapeutic options have recently been derived from studies of individuals with Disease (Disease). Here we identified 10 different homozygous mutations in Gene (encoding Gene and RIZ homology domain-containing protein 12) in subjects with Disease from 11 families. Prdm proteins are a family of epigenetic regulators that control neural specification and neurogenesis. We determined that Gene is expressed in nociceptors and their progenitors and participates in the development of sensory neurons in Species embryos. Moreover, Disease-associated mutants abrogate the histone-modifying potential associated with wild-type Gene. Gene emerges as a key factor in the orchestration of sensory neurogenesis and may hold promise as a target for new Disease therapeutics.

24733397.pub_title: The Chemical reductase activity of Gene is reciprocally activated by Gene to control retinoid homeostasis.
24733397.pub_abstract: The Chemical-inducible Gene (Gene) is thought to function as a Chemical reductase that controls the levels of all-Chemical, the immediate precursor for bioactive Chemical. However, the weak catalytic activity of Gene and the lack of changes in Chemical conversion to Chemical and Chemical in the cells overexpressing Gene undermine its role as a physiologically important all-Chemical reductase. This study demonstrates that Gene requires the presence of Gene (Gene) to display its full catalytic activity. The Gene-activated Gene acts as a robust high affinity all-Chemical-specific reductase that effectively converts Disease to Chemical, decreasing the rate of Chemical biosynthesis. In turn, the Gene activity of Gene is reciprocally activated by Gene. At E13.5, Gene-null embryos have ~4-fold lower levels of Chemical and Chemical, but only slightly elevated levels of Chemical. The membrane-associated Chemical reductase and Gene activities are decreased by ~4- and ~2-fold, respectively, in Gene(-/-) embryos, and Gene(-/-) Species embryonic fibroblasts exhibit reduced metabolism of both Chemical and Chemical. Neither Gene nor Gene has to be itself catalytically active to activate each other. The transcripts encoding Gene and Gene are co-localized at least in some tissues during development. The mutually activating interaction between the two related proteins may represent a highly sensitive and conserved mechanism for precise control over the rate of Chemical biosynthesis.

24498290.pub_title: Expression of signaling components in Disease.
24498290.pub_abstract: Closure of an epithelium opening is a critical morphogenetic event for development. An excellent example for this process is the transient closure of Disease. Eyelid closure requires shape change and migration of epithelial cells at the tip of the developing eyelids, and is dictated by numerous signaling pathways. Here we evaluated gene expression in epithelial cells isolated from the tip (leading edge, LE) and inner surface epithelium (IE) of the eyelid from E15.5 Species fetuses by laser capture microdissection (LCM). We showed that the LE and IE cells are different at E15.5, such that IE had higher expression of muscle specific genes, while LE acquired epithelium identities. Despite their distinct destinies, these cells were overall similar in expression of signaling components for the "eyelid closure pathways". However, while the LE cells had more abundant expression of Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene, and Gene and Gene, the IE cells had more abundant expression of Gene and Gene. In addition, the LE cells had more abundant expression of Gene (Gene), but the IE cells had high expression of Gene. Our results suggest that the functionally distinct LE and IE cells have also differential expression of signaling molecules that may contribute to the cell-specific responses to morphogenetic signals. The expression pattern suggests that the Gene, Gene and NOTCH pathways are preferentially active in LE cells, the BMP pathways are effective in IE cells, and the Wnt pathway may be repressed in LE and IE cells via different mechanisms.

22215812.pub_title: Gene regulates directional migration of enteric neural crest through Gene, integrin signaling, and Gene activity.
22215812.pub_abstract: Disease (HSCR) is caused by a reduction of enteric neural crest cells (ENCCs) in the gut and Disease blockage. Knowledge of the genetics underlying HSCR is incomplete, particularly genes that control cellular behaviors of ENCC migration. Here we report a novel regulator of ENCC migration in Species. Disruption of the Gene gene causes an Disease due to Disease, which resembles Species HSCR. Time-lapse imaging of ENCCs within the embryonic gut demonstrates a collective cell migration defect. Mutant ENCCs show undirected cellular protrusions and disrupted directional and chain migration. Gene acts cell-autonomously in ENCCs and colocalizes with integrin and Gene at cell protrusions. Mechanistically, we show that Gene negatively regulates integrin signaling through the RHO/ROCK pathway and coordinates Gene (Gene) with Gene activity to regulate cytoskeletal dynamics. Strikingly, lamellipodia formation and in vivo ENCC chain migration defects are rescued by inhibition of ROCK or integrin function. Our results demonstrate a previously unknown pathway in ENCC collective migration in vivo and provide new candidate genes for Species genetic studies of HSCR.

23288605.pub_title: Expression of Gene in Species embryonic stem cells directs the differentiation of neuronal precursors and identifies unique patterns of down-stream gene expression.
23288605.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Delineating the cascades of growth and transcription factor expression that shape the developing nervous system will improve our understanding of its molecular histogenesis and suggest strategies for cell replacement therapies. In the current investigation, we examined the ability of the proneural gene, Gene (Gene; also Gene, Gene), to drive differentiation of pluripotent embryonic stem cells (ESC). RESULTS: Transient expression of Gene in ESC was sufficient to initiate neuronal differentiation, and produced neuronal subtypes reflecting its expression pattern in vivo. To begin to address the molecular mechanisms involved, we used microarray analysis to identify potential down-stream targets of Gene expressed at sequential stages of neuronal differentiation. CONCLUSIONS: ESC expressing Gene begin to withdraw from cycle and form precursors that differentiate exclusively into neurons. This work identifies unique patterns of gene expression following expression of Gene, including genes and signaling pathways involved in process outgrowth and cell migration, regional differentiation of the nervous system, and cell cycle.

23798389.pub_title: Gene deletion reveals an essential mechanism that maintains the genomic stability of stem and progenitor cells.
23798389.pub_abstract: Stem and progenitor cells maintain a robust DNA replication program during the tissue expansion phase of embryogenesis. The unique mechanism that protects them from the increased risk of replication-induced DNA damage, and hence permits self-renewal, remains unclear. To determine whether the genome integrity of stem/progenitor cells is safeguarded by mechanisms involving molecules beyond the core DNA repair machinery, we created a Gene (a stem and Disease cell-enriched protein) conditional-null allele and showed that neural-specific knockout of Gene predisposes embryos to spontaneous DNA damage that leads to severe Disease in vivo. In cultured neural stem cells, depletion of Gene triggers replication-dependent DNA damage and perturbs self-renewal, whereas overexpression of Gene shows a protective effect against Chemical-induced DNA damage. Mechanistic studies performed in Species embryonic fibroblast cells showed that loss of Gene triggers DNA damage and growth arrest independently of the Gene status or rRNA synthesis. Instead, Gene is directly recruited to DNA damage sites and regulates the recruitment of the core repair protein, Gene, to Chemical-induced foci. This work establishes the primary function of Gene in maintaining the genomic stability of actively dividing stem/progenitor cells by promoting the recruitment of Gene to stalled replication-induced DNA damage foci.

21492869.pub_title: Gene is down-regulated during duodenal Disease formation in Fgfr2IIIb-/- Species.
21492869.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Homozygous null mutation of Gene (Fgfr2IIIb) or its ligand Gene (Gene) results in Disease in Species. Mutations of either of these genes in Species cause Disease and associated Disease. Recently, mutations in the Chemical-binding protein receptor gene Gene were reported to be implicated in this syndrome as well. This suggests that the Chemical (RA) signaling pathway interacts with the Gene-Fgfr2IIIb signaling pathway during duodenal development. Accordingly, we hypothesized that Fgfr2IIIb-/- Species embryos would exhibit disruptions in expression of Gene, the gene for the enzyme that regulates the final step in the conversion of Chemical to the active form RA, during Disease formation. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Fgfr2III -/- Species were generated from heterozygous breedings. Embryos were harvested between embryonic day (E) 11.0 to E 13.5 and genotyped by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Duodenums were dissected out, fixed and photographed. Whole mount and section in situs were performed for Gene. RESULTS: Fgfr2IIIb-/- embryos demonstrate subtle changes in the duodenal morphology by E11.5 with complete involution of the atretic precursor by E 13.5. Gene appears to be down-regulated as early as E 11.5 in the atretic precursor a full 2 days before this segment disappears. CONCLUSIONS: In Fgfr2IIIb-/- Species embryos, a reduction of Gene expression is observed within the region that is forming the Disease. This is the first demonstration of such an event in this model. As in Species, these results implicate disruptions between Fgfr2IIIb receptor function and RA signaling in the formation of this defect and indicate that Fgfr2IIIb-/- Species embryos are a valid model for the study of the atretic spectrum of defects in Species duodenal development.

27864382.pub_title: Molecular dynamics of Gene modulates Wnt action and regulates meibomian gland development.
27864382.pub_abstract: Secreted Dickkopf (Dkk) proteins are major Wnt pathway modulators during organ development. Gene has been widely studied and acts as a general Wnt inhibitor. However, the molecular function of other Dkks remains largely unknown. Here, we show that Gene selectively inhibits a subset of Wnts, but is further inactivated by proteolytic cleavage. Meibomian gland (MG) formation is employed as a model where Gene and its Wnt targets are expressed. Skin-specific expression of Gene arrests MG growth at early germ phase, which is similar to that observed in Gene-ablated Tabby Species. Consistent with transient Gene action, intact Gene inhibits MG extension but the cleaved form progressively increases during MG development with a concomitant upswing in Wnt activity. Furthermore, both Gene and its receptor (and Wnt co-receptor) Gene are direct Gene targets during MG induction. In cell and organotypic cultures, Gene inhibition is eliminated by elevation of Gene. Also, Gene upregulation restores MG formation in Tabby Species. Thus, the dynamic state of Gene itself and its interaction with Gene modulates Wnt function during MG development, with a novel limitation of Gene action by proteolytic cleavage.

24063807.pub_title: Gene is a limiting factor controlling the proportions of primitive endoderm and epiblast in the ICM of the Species blastocyst.
24063807.pub_abstract: The primitive endoderm (PE) and epiblast (EPI) are two lineages derived from the inner cell mass (ICM) of the E3.5 blastocyst. Although it has been shown that FGF signaling is necessary and sufficient for PE specification in the ICM, it is unknown what mechanisms control the PE/EPI proportion in the embryo. Because modulation of FGF signaling alone is sufficient to convert all ICM cells to either PE or EPI, a model has been proposed in which the amount of FGF in the embryo controls the PE/EPI proportion. To test this model, we reduced the amount of Gene, the major FGF in the preimplantation embryo, using various genotypes of Gene mutants. We observed a maternal contribution of Gene in PE specification, but it was dispensable for development. In addition, upon treatment of Gene mutant embryos with exogenous Gene, we observed a progressive increase of PE proportions in an Gene dose dependent manner, regardless of embryo genotype. We conclude that the amount of Gene is limited and regulates PE/EPI proportions in the Species embryo.

22949407.pub_title: Mitochondrial Chemical production negatively regulates neural progenitor proliferation and cerebral cortical development.
22949407.pub_abstract: Although high amounts of reactive Chemical species (ROS) can damage cells, ROS can also play roles as second messengers, regulating diverse cellular processes. Here, we report that embryonic Species cerebral cortical neural progenitor cells (NPCs) exhibit intermittent spontaneous bursts of mitochondrial Chemical (SO) generation (mitochondrial SO flashes) that require transient opening of membrane permeability transition pores (mPTP). This quantal SO production negatively regulates NPC self-renewal. Mitochondrial SO scavengers and mPTP inhibitors reduce SO flash frequency and enhance Disease, whereas prolonged mPTP opening and SO generation increase SO flash incidence and decrease Disease. The inhibition of Disease by mitochondrial SO involves suppression of extracellular signal-regulated kinases. Moreover, Species lacking Gene (Gene-/- Species) exhibit significantly fewer proliferative NPCs and differentiated neurons in the embryonic cerebral cortex at midgestation compared with wild-type littermates. Cultured Gene-/- NPCs exhibit a significant increase in SO flash frequency and reduced Disease. Taken together, our findings suggest that mitochondrial SO flashes negatively regulate NPC self-renewal in the developing cerebral cortex.

23019366.pub_title: Hedgehog-responsive mesenchymal clusters direct patterning and emergence of intestinal villi.
23019366.pub_abstract: In the adult intestine, an organized array of finger-like projections, called villi, provide an enormous epithelial surface area for absorptive function. Villi first emerge at embryonic day (E) 14.5 from a previously flat luminal surface. Here, we analyze the cell biology of villus formation and examine the role of paracrine epithelial Hedgehog (Hh) signals in this process. We find that, before villus emergence, tight clusters of Hh-responsive mesenchymal cells form just beneath the epithelium. Cluster formation is dynamic; clusters first form dorsally and anteriorly and spread circumferentially and posteriorly. Statistical analysis of cluster distribution reveals a patterned array; with time, new clusters form in spaces between existing clusters, promoting approximately four rounds of villus emergence by E18.5. Cells within mesenchymal clusters express Gene and Gene, as well as Gene, a receptor previously shown to participate in villus development. BrdU-labeling experiments show that clusters form by migration and aggregation of Hh-responsive cells. Inhibition of Hh signaling prevents cluster formation and villus development, but does not prevent emergence of villi in areas where clusters have already formed. Conversely, increasing Hh signaling increases the size of villus clusters and results in exceptionally wide villi. We conclude that Hh signals dictate the initial aspects of the formation of each villus by controlling Disease and regulating cluster size.

24198279.pub_title: Cell delamination in the Disease fold and its implication for the origin of ectomesenchyme.
24198279.pub_abstract: The neural crest is a transient structure unique to vertebrate embryos that gives rise to multiple lineages along the rostrocaudal axis. In cranial regions, neural crest cells are thought to differentiate into chondrocytes, osteocytes, pericytes and stromal cells, which are collectively termed ectomesenchyme derivatives, as well as pigment and neuronal derivatives. There is still no consensus as to whether the neural crest can be classified as a homogenous multipotent population of cells. This unresolved controversy has important implications for the formation of ectomesenchyme and for confirmation of whether the neural fold is compartmentalized into distinct domains, each with a different repertoire of derivatives. Here we report in Species and Species that cells in the neural fold delaminate over an extended period from different regions of the cranial neural fold to give rise to cells with distinct fates. Importantly, cells that give rise to ectomesenchyme undergo epithelial-mesenchymal transition from a lateral neural fold domain that does not express definitive neural markers, such as Gene and Gene. Additionally, the inference that cells originating from the cranial neural ectoderm have a common origin and cell fate with trunk neural crest cells prompted us to revisit the issue of what defines the neural crest and the origin of the ectomesenchyme.

26608785.pub_title: Histone Modifier Genes Alter Conotruncal Heart Phenotypes in 22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome.
26608785.pub_abstract: We performed whole exome sequence (WES) to identify genetic modifiers on 184 individuals with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (22q11DS), of whom 89 case subjects had severe Disease (Disease) and 95 control subjects had normal hearts. Three genes including Gene (Gene), Gene (Gene), and Gene (Gene) had rare (Gene < 0.001) predicted deleterious single-nucleotide variations (Disease) in seven case subjects and no control subjects (p = 0.005; Fisher exact and permutation tests). Because Gene and Gene are involved in chromatin modification, we investigated other histone modification genes. Eighteen case subjects (20%) had Disease in four genes (Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene) all involved in demethylation of histones (H3K9, H3K27). Overall, Disease were enriched in histone modifier genes that activate transcription (Fisher exact p = 0.0004, permutations, p = 0.0003, OR = 5.16); however, Disease in control subjects were not enriched. This implicates histone modification genes as influencing risk for Disease in presence of the deletion.

23087612.pub_title: Constitutively expressed Protocadherin-alpha regulates the coalescence and elimination of homotypic olfactory axons through its cytoplasmic region.
23087612.pub_abstract: Olfactory sensory neuron (OSN) axons coalesce into specific glomeruli in the olfactory bulb (Disease) according to their odorant receptor (OR) expression. Several guidance molecules enhance the coalescence of homotypic OSN projections, in an OR-specific- and neural-activity-dependent manner. However, the mechanism by which homotypic OSN axons are organized into glomeruli is unsolved. We previously reported that the clustered protocadherin-alpha (Gene) family of diverse cadherin-related molecules plays roles in the coalescence and elimination of homotypic OSN axons throughout development. Here we showed that the elimination of small ectopic homotypic glomeruli required the constitutive expression of a Gene isoform and Gene's cytoplasmic region, but not OR specificity or neural activity. These results suggest that Gene proteins provide a cytoplasmic signal to regulate repulsive activity for homotypic OSN axons independently of OR expression and neural activity. The counterbalancing effect of Gene proteins for the axonal coalescence mechanisms mediated by other olfactory guidance molecules indicate a possible mechanism for the organization of homotypic OSN axons into glomeruli during development.

23085236.pub_title: Gene function in the epiblast is required for the maintenance but not the Disease in Species.
23085236.pub_abstract: The formation of the anteroposterior axis in Species requires a Gene-dependent symmetry-breaking event that leads to the formation of the primitive streak and gastrulation. Gene is expressed sequentially in two distinct areas of the Species embryo before the appearance of the primitive streak; first in the posterior visceral endoderm and soon after in the adjacent posterior epiblast. Hence, although an axial requirement for Gene is well established, its temporal and tissue specific requirements remain an open question. Here, we report the conditional inactivation of Gene in the epiblast of developing Species embryos. Contrary to previous studies, our data shows that embryos lacking Gene specifically in the epiblast are able to initiate gastrulation and advance to late primitive streak stages but fail to thrive and are resorbed by E9.5. At the molecular level, we provide evidence that Gene regulates its own expression and that of other primitive streak markers via activation of the canonical Gene signaling pathway.

25595964.pub_title: Spatial distributions of Gene and Gene in Disease and postnatal Species lens development.
25595964.pub_abstract: The expression of the water channel protein aquaporin (AQP)-5 in adult rodent and Species lenses was recently reported using immunohistochemistry, molecular biology, and mass spectrometry techniques, confirming a second transmembrane water channel that is present in lens fibre cells in addition to the abundant Gene protein. Interestingly, the sub-cellular distribution and level of post-translational modification of both proteins changes with fibre cell differentiation and location in the adult rodent lens. This study compares the sub-cellular distribution of Gene and Gene during Disease and postnatal fibre cell development in the Species lens to understand how the immunolabelling patterns for both AQPs observed in adult lens are first established. Immunohistochemistry was used to map the cellular and sub-cellular distribution of Gene and Gene throughout the lens in cryosections from adult (6 weeks-8 months) and postnatal (0-2 weeks) Species lenses and in sections from paraffin embedded Species embryos (E10-E19). All sections were imaged by fluorescence confocal microscopy. Using antibodies directed against the Chemical-terminus of each AQP, Gene was abundantly expressed early in development, being found in the cytoplasm of cells of the lens vesicle and surrounding tissues (E10), while Gene was detected later (E11), and only in the membranes of elongating primary fibre cells. During the course of subsequent Disease and postnatal development the pattern of cytoplasmic Gene and membranous Gene labelling was maintained until postnatal day 6 (P6). From P6 Gene labelling became progressively more membranous initially in the lens nucleus and then later in all regions of the lens, while Gene labelling was abruptly lost in the lens nucleus due to Chemical-terminal truncation. Our results show that the spatial distribution patterns of Gene and Gene observed in the adult lens are established during a narrow window of postnatal development (P6-P15) that precedes eye opening and coincides with regression of the hyaloid vascular system. Our results support the hypothesis that, in the older fibre cells, insertion of Gene into the fibre cell membrane may compensate for any change in the functionality of Gene induced by truncation of its Chemical-terminal tail.

23449628.pub_title: Disease of Gene causes limb and Disease in the Species Disease partial trisomy distal 4q.
23449628.pub_abstract: Partial trisomy distal 4q (denoted 4q+) is a Species Disease caused by duplication of the distal end of the long arm of chromosome 4 (Chr4). This disorder manifests typical phenotypes, including Disease, renal, heart and Disease. Although these clinical features are likely caused by a dosage imbalance in the gene network involving the trisomic region, the causative gene or genes and the molecular bases are largely unknown. Here, we report Species Gene (Gene) as a model animal of 4q+. The Gene genome contains an insertion of a 6.5 Mb fragment from Species chromosome 8 into chromosome 6. This insertion fragment contains 17 genes, including Gene, that encode the basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor and is syntenic to the distal end of Species Chr4, 4q32.3 to 4q34.1, which is responsible for 4q+. A comparison of phenotypes between Species with Gene and 4q+ revealed that Gene shows direct parallels with many phenotypes of 4q+ such as Disease, heart, Disease. Rebalancing the gene dosage by a genetic cross with Gene knockout Species ameliorated symptoms of the heart and Disease of Gene. Conversely, an increase in copy number of Gene in wild-type Species recaptures the heart and Disease of Gene. Our results collectively demonstrate that overdosage of Gene is a major cause for at least the limb and heart phenotypes of 4q+ and that Species Gene provides a unique animal model for understanding the molecular bases underlying the complex phenotypes of 4q+.

22589736.pub_title: Histone h1 depletion impairs embryonic stem cell differentiation.
22589736.pub_abstract: Pluripotent embryonic stem cells (ESCs) are known to possess a relatively open chromatin structure; yet, despite efforts to characterize the chromatin signatures of ESCs, the role of chromatin compaction in stem cell fate and function remains elusive. Linker histone H1 is important for higher-order chromatin folding and is essential for Species embryogenesis. To investigate the role of H1 and chromatin compaction in stem cell pluripotency and differentiation, we examine the differentiation of embryonic stem cells that are depleted of multiple H1 subtypes. H1c/H1d/H1e triple null ESCs are more resistant to spontaneous differentiation in adherent monolayer culture upon removal of Gene. Similarly, the majority of the triple-H1 null embryoid bodies (EBs) lack morphological structures representing the three germ layers and retain gene expression signatures characteristic of undifferentiated ESCs. Furthermore, upon neural differentiation of EBs, triple-H1 null cell cultures are deficient in neurite outgrowth and lack efficient activation of neural markers. Finally, we discover that triple-H1 null embryos and EBs fail to fully repress the expression of the pluripotency genes in comparison with wild-type controls and that H1 depletion impairs DNA methylation and changes of histone marks at promoter regions necessary for efficiently silencing pluripotency gene Gene during stem cell differentiation and embryogenesis. In summary, we demonstrate that H1 plays a critical role in pluripotent stem cell differentiation, and our results suggest that H1 and chromatin compaction may mediate pluripotent stem cell differentiation through epigenetic repression of the pluripotency genes.

22275534.pub_title: Effects of reduced Gene expression on trophoblast morphology, fetoplacental vascularity, and pregnancy outcomes in Species.
22275534.pub_abstract: Preeclampsia is a life-threatening disorder characterized by maternal gestational Disease and Disease that results from placental dysfunction. Placental abnormalities include Disease and a 50% reduction in placental expression of the transcription factor Gene. In Species, homozygous deletion of Gene prevents syncytiotrophoblast differentiation and is embryonic lethal. We used heterozygous Gene mutants (Gene(+/-)) to test the hypothesis that hypomorphic expression of placental Gene causes defective syncytiotrophoblast differentiation and maternal and placental phenotypes that resemble preeclampsia. We mated wild-type female Species with Gene(+/-) fathers to obtain wild-type mothers carrying  50% Gene(+/-) conceptuses. Gene(+/-) placentas had Disease including reduced gene expression of Gene-regulated Gene, elevated expression of Gene, a thickened interhemal membrane separating maternal and fetal circulations, and electron microscopic evidence in Disease and impaired maternal-fetal transfer. Fetoplacental vascularity was quantified by histomorphometry and microcomputed tomography imaging. In Gene(+/-), it was  30% greater than wild-type littermates, whereas placental Gene (Gene) expression and fetal and placental weights did not differ. Wild-type mothers carrying Gene(+/-) conceptuses developed late gestational Disease (118+-2 versus 109.6+-0.7 mm Hg in controls; P<0.05). We next correlated fetoplacental vascularity with placental Gene expression in Species control and pathological pregnancies and found that, as in Species, fetoplacental vascularity increased when Gene protein expression decreased (R(2)=-0.45; P<0.05). These results support a role for reduced placental Gene expression as a causative factor in defective syncytiotrophoblast differentiation and maternal and placental phenotypes in preeclampsia in Species.

26248544.pub_title: Prospective separation and transcriptome analyses of cortical projection neurons and interneurons based on lineage tracing by Gene (Gene)-GFP/Gene-mRFP reporters.
26248544.pub_abstract: In the cerebral cortex, projection neurons and interneurons work coordinately to establish neural networks for normal cortical functions. While the specific mechanisms that control productions of projection neurons and interneurons are beginning to be revealed, a global characterization of the molecular differences between these two neuron types is crucial for a more comprehensive understanding of their developmental specifications and functions. In this study, using lineage tracing power of combining Gene and Gene-mRFP reporter Species, we prospectively separated intermediate progenitor cell (IPC)-derived neurons (IPNs) from non-IPC-derived neurons (non-IPNs) of the Disease. Molecular characterizations revealed that IPNs and non-IPNs were enriched with projection neurons and interneurons, respectively. Expression profiling documented cell-specific genes including differentially expressed transcriptional regulators that might be involved in cellular specifications, for instance, our data found that Gene and Gene, which were known for important functions in neural stem/progenitor cells, continued to be expressed by interneurons but not by projection neurons. Transcriptome analyses of cortical neurons isolated at different stages of neurogenesis revealed distinct temporal patterns of expression of genes involved in early-born or late-born neuron specification. These data present a resource useful for further investigation of the molecular regulations and functions of projection neurons and interneurons.

23795570.pub_title: Role of Gene-positive cells in the remodeling morphogenesis during vascular development.
23795570.pub_abstract: Gene is a critical determinant for the commitment of endothelial (EC) and hematopoietic (HPC) cells from mesoderm. Gene is assumed to be transiently required for EC commitment but dispensable after most ECs differentiate around E9.5. To confirm the time window of Gene requirement, Gene was ablated at different time points using ROSA26CreER Species. Unexpectedly, Gene ablation at E9.5 caused vascular remodeling defects in cranial and yolk sac vasculature. Immunostaining showed that Gene (Gene)- cells were present around forming vasculature, mostly co-expressing Gene with a small number of Gene+/Gene+ cells, indicating that Gene+/Gene+/Gene- cells are the major Gene+ population promoting vascular remodeling around E9.5. Gene expression analysis showed up-regulation of Fgf proteins, Gene, Gene and matrix metalloproteases in Gene+/VEDAC- cells over Gene-/Gene+ mature ECs. Blockade of those factors caused reduced EC sprouting in ex vivo explant culture from E9.5 embryos, suggesting the functional significance of environmental factors derived from Gene+ cells. Altogether, we propose that Gene+/VEDAC- cells around E9.5-E10.5 provide extracellular factors to complete vascular morphogenesis in addition to becoming differentiated ECs incorporated into vessels. This insight for the new role of Ets protein in perivascular Gene+/Gene-/(Gene+) cells to induce expression of angiogenic factors may provide another strategy to control angiogenesis.

23996959.pub_title: Gene:Cre knock-in Species line: a novel tool for pancreas- and CNS-specific gene deletion.
23996959.pub_abstract: Gene is a homeodomain-containing transcriptional regulator necessary for the appropriate differentiation of ventral neuronal populations in the spinal cord and hindbrain, and endocrine cell populations in the pancreas and intestine. In each tissue, Gene inactivation leads to reciprocal cell fate alterations. To confirm the cell fate changes are due to respecification of Gene-expressing progenitors and to provide a novel tool for lineage tracing in the pancreas and CNS, we generated an Gene:Cre Species line by knocking in a Cre-EGFP cassette into the Gene genomic locus and inactivating endogenous Gene. The Protein Mutation-CAG-LSL-tdTomato reporter was used to monitor the specificity and efficiency of Gene:Cre activity; the Species reporter faithfully recapitulated endogenous Gene expression and could be detected as early as embryonic day (e) 9.25 in the developing CNS and was initiated shortly thereafter at e9.5 in the pancreas. Lineage analyses in the CNS confirmed the cell populations thought to be derived from Gene-expressing progenitor domains. Furthermore, lineage studies verified Gene expression in the earliest pancreatic progenitors that give rise to all cell types of the pancreas; however they also revealed more robust Cre activity in the dorsal versus ventral pancreas. Thus, the Gene:Cre line provides a novel tool for gene manipulations in the CNS and pancreas.

23023706.pub_title: Mesodermal Gene inactivation leads to Disease- like phenotype.
