Just prior to the developmental stage of palatal shelf elevation in wild-type littermates, Gene mutant embryos exhibit increased cell density, reduced hyaluronan accumulation and Disease in the palatal mesenchyme. Together, these results demonstrate that, although it is a ubiquitously expressed Gene, Gene has specific functions in protein glycosylation and tissue morphogenesis.

23908115.pub_title: Osteoclast-secreted Gene in the coupling of bone resorption to formation.
23908115.pub_abstract: Bone remodeling is characterized by the sequential, local tethering of Disease and is key to the maintenance of bone integrity. While bone matrix-mobilized growth factors, such as TGF-beta, are proposed to regulate remodeling, no in vivo evidence exists that an osteoclast-produced molecule serves as a coupling factor for bone resorption to formation. We found that Gene, a protein secreted by mature bone-resorbing osteoclasts, targets stromal cells to stimulate Disease. Gene expression was robustly induced when mature osteoclasts were placed on dentin or Chemical, and also by increasing extracellular Chemical. Gene expression in bone increased in a high-turnover state (such as that induced by Gene injections in vivo), but decreased in conditions associated with suppressed Disease (such as with aging and after Chemical treatment). Targeted deletion of Gene in Species eliminated Gene expression in bone, whereas its deficiency in osteoblasts did not exert any significant effect. Osteoclast-specific deletion of Gene resulted in Disease due to reduced bone formation and impaired the coupling process after resorption induced by Gene injections, impairing bone mass recovery. These data demonstrate that Gene is an osteoclast-secreted coupling factor that regulates bone remodeling.

23754801.pub_title: Adult pituitary cell maintenance: lineage-specific contribution of self-duplication.
23754801.pub_abstract: The identification of a stable pool of progenitor/stem cells in the adult pituitary has renewed the interest of identifying mechanisms for maintenance of pituitary cells throughout life. Whereas developmental studies have shown that progenitor expansion is the major source of new differentiated cells during pituitary organogenesis, the contribution of these progenitors for maintenance of the adult tissue is not clear although progenitors were clearly involved in cell expansion following end-organ ablation, notably after adrenalectomy and/or gonadectomy. We have used a genetic trick that eliminates dividing cells by apoptosis in order to assess the contribution of differentiated corticotropes and melanotropes for maintenance of their population in the adult pituitary. The system relies on chromosome instability created by the action of the Cre recombinase on inverted loxP sites. Expression of Cre recombinase in corticotropes and melanotropes led to progressive loss of corticotropes whereas melanotropes were unaffected. Because the Cre transgene is not expressed in progenitors, the data indicate that maintenance of the adult corticotrope pool is primarily due to self-duplication of differentiated cells. In contrast, melanotropes do not divide. Maintenance of corticotropes by self-duplication contrasts with the reported proliferative response of undifferentiated cells observed after adrenalectomy. If corticotrope reentry into cell cycle constitutes a normal mechanism to maintain the adult corticotrope pool, this same mechanism may also be perturbed during corticotrope Disease development in Disease.

24444792.pub_title: Selective regulation of axonal growth from developing hippocampal neurons by Disease factor superfamily member Gene.
24444792.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene, Gene) is a member of the Disease Disease factor superfamily that regulates lymphocyte survival and activation and has been implicated in tumorigenesis and Disease. Here we report the expression and first known activity of Gene in the nervous system. Gene and one of its receptors, Gene (Gene, Gene), are expressed by hippocampal pyramidal cells of fetal and postnatal Species. In culture, these neurons secreted Gene, and function-blocking antibodies to either Gene or Gene reduced axonal elongation. Recombinant Gene enhanced axonal elongation, but did not influence dendrite elongation. The effect of Gene on axon elongation was inhibited by anti-Gene and the expression of a signaling-defective Gene mutant in these neurons, suggesting that the axon growth-promoting effect of Gene is mediated by Gene. Gene promoted phosphorylation and activation of Gene, Gene and Gene and Chemical phosphorylation and inactivation of Gene in cultured hippocampal pyramidal cells. Inhibition of Gene/Gene (activators of Gene/Gene), PI3-kinase (activator of Gene) or Gene inhibited the axon growth-promoting action of Gene, as did pharmacological activation of Gene and the expression of a constitutively active form of Gene. These findings suggest that Gene promotes axon elongation by a mechanism that depends both on Gene signaling and PI3-kinase/Gene/Gene signaling.

26371318.pub_title: Gene regulates the timing of Gene-dependent cortical neurogenesis.
26371318.pub_abstract: The timing of cortical neurogenesis has a major effect on the size and organization of the mature cortex. The deletion of the LIM-homeodomain transcription factor Gene in cortical progenitors by Nestin-cre leads to a dramatically smaller cortex. Here we report that Gene regulates the cortex size by maintaining the cortical progenitor proliferation and delaying the initiation of neurogenesis. The loss of Gene in cortical progenitors results in precocious Disease differentiation and a temporal shift of cortical neurogenesis. We further investigated the underlying mechanisms at play and demonstrated that in the absence of Gene, the Wnt/Gene pathway failed to maintain progenitor proliferation. We developed and applied a mathematical model that reveals how precocious neurogenesis affected cortical surface and thickness. Thus, we concluded that Gene is required for Gene function in maintaining cortical progenitor proliferation and controls the timing of cortical neurogenesis.

25834070.pub_title: Disease and variable Disease, a new mutation affecting the Gene gene in the Species, causes variable defects in kidney development and Disease.
25834070.pub_abstract: Many genes, including Gene (Gene), are involved in regulation of Species kidney development. We describe here a new recessive mutation (Disease and variable Disease, kavh) in the Species that leads to downregulation of Gene transcript, causing several Disease: agenesis, Disease, and Disease with variable age of onset. The mutation is closely associated with a reciprocal translocation, Gene, whose Chromosome 12 breakpoint is upstream from Gene. The kavh/kavh mutant provides a model to study kidney development and test therapies for Disease.

23894536.pub_title: A tudor domain protein Gene interacts with the mRNA-binding protein Gene and is involved in Species oocyte meiotic resumption.
23894536.pub_abstract: Species oocytes are arrested at prophase I of meiosis, and resume meiosis prior to ovulation. Coordination of Disease and resumption is partly dependent on the post-transcriptional regulation of maternal transcripts. Here, we report that, Gene (Gene), a maternal protein containing Tudor-like domains, interacts with a known mRNA-binding protein Gene, and is involved in regulating maternal transcripts to control meiotic resumption. Species oocytes deficient for Gene undergo normal folliculogenesis, but are defective in resuming meiosis. Gene, via its Tudor-like domain, forms a ribonucleoprotein complex with Gene, and regulating mRNA stability and/or translation. The mRNA for the Chemical-degrading enzyme, Gene, is reduced in Gene mutant oocytes, possibly contributing to Disease. Our study demonstrates that Gene regulates maternal transcripts post-transcriptionally and is involved in meiotic resumption.

23343763.pub_title: Deficiency in spliceosome-associated factor Gene does not affect ongoing cell cycling but delays exit from quiescence and results in Disease in Species.
23343763.pub_abstract: Gene is an armadillo-repeat protein that associates with the Gene/Gene complex of the spliceosome. Unlike the majority of spliceosomal proteins (and despite having no obvious homologs), Gene is inessential for cell viability as revealed by studies in both vertebrate B cell lines and in Species. Here, however, we show that ablation of Gene in the Species germline results in mid-gestation Disease but that lineage-specific Gene ablation in early B cell precursors does not affect the production and abundance of mature B lymphocytes. However, Gene-deficient resting B lymphocytes show sluggish exit from quiescence on cell activation, although once entry into cycle has initiated, proliferation and differentiation in response to mitogenic stimuli continue largely unaffected. A similar sluggish exit from quiescence is also observed on reprovision of nutrients to Chemical-starved Gene-deficient Species. The results indicate that, whereas other RNA splicing-associated factors have been connected to cell cycle progression, Gene plays no essential role in cycling cells but does fulfill an evolutionarily conserved function in helping cells to undergo efficient exit from quiescence following activation.

27088858.pub_title: The Gene/5-Gene/Gene module controls liver zonation and size.
27088858.pub_abstract: Gene/5 receptors and their cognate RSPO ligands potentiate Wnt/Gene signalling and promote proliferation and tissue homeostasis in epithelial stem cell compartments. In the liver, metabolic zonation requires a Wnt/Gene signalling gradient, but the instructive mechanism controlling its spatiotemporal regulation is not known. We have now identified the Gene/5-Gene/Gene module as a master regulator of Wnt/Gene-mediated metabolic liver zonation. Liver-specific Gene/5 loss of function (LOF) or RSPO blockade disrupted hepatic Wnt/Gene signalling and zonation. Conversely, pathway activation in Gene/Gene LOF Species or with recombinant Gene protein expanded the hepatic Wnt/Gene signalling gradient in a reversible and Gene/5-dependent manner. Recombinant Gene protein increased liver size and improved liver regeneration, whereas Gene/5 LOF caused the opposite effects, resulting in hypoplastic livers. Furthermore, we show that Gene(+) hepatocytes throughout the lobule contribute to liver homeostasis without zonal dominance. Taken together, our results indicate that the Gene/5-Gene/Gene module controls metabolic liver zonation and is a hepatic growth/size rheostat during development, homeostasis and regeneration.

26577899.pub_title: Pharyngeal Disease and lethal Disease and its branches in Species deficient for the Gene/Gene transcription factor.
26577899.pub_abstract: The aortic arch and major branch arteries are formed from the three pairs of pharyngeal arch arteries (PAAs) during embryonic development. Their morphological defects are clinically observed as isolated diseases, as a part of complicated Disease or as a manifestation of multi-organ syndromes such as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. Although numerous genes have been implicated in Chemical formation and remodeling, detailed mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here we report that the Species null for Gene/Gene, a gene encoding a downstream transcription factor of Notch and Gene signaling pathways, show perinatal lethality on the C57BL/6N, C57BL/6N x C57BL/6J or C57BL/6N x 129X1/SvJ background. Gene/Gene null embryos display abnormal development of the fourth Chemical (PAA4), which results in Disease including right-sided aortic arch, interruption of the aortic arch and aberrant origin of the right subclavian artery. Impaired vessel formation occurs randomly in Chemical4 of Gene/Gene null embryos, which likely causes the variability of Disease. Endothelial cells in Chemical4 of null embryos differentiate normally but are structurally disorganized at embryonic day 10.5 and 11.5. Vascular smooth muscle cells are nearly absent in the structurally-defective PAA4, despite the appropriate migration of cardiac neural crest cells into the fourth pharyngeal arches. Endothelial expression of Gene is down-regulated in the structurally-defective Chemical4 of null embryos, which may be one of the mechanisms underlying the suppression of vascular smooth muscle cell differentiation. While the direct downstream phenomena of the Gene/Gene deficiency remain to be clarified, we suggest that Gene/Gene-dependent transcriptional regulation has an important role in Chemical formation during embryonic development.

23661704.pub_title: Transcriptional regulation by the Disease protein, Gene, suggests a role of the metalloproteinase Gene in Species genitourinary development.
23661704.pub_abstract: Gene (a disintegrin and metalloproteinase with thrombospondin motifs) is a secreted Species metalloproteinase with unknown function. We report here that Species Gene is co-expressed with the Disease protein, Gene, in the developing glomeruli of Disease. Gene mRNA levels were significantly reduced upon transfection of embryonic Species kidney explants with Gene antisense vivo-morpholinos. Antisense knockdown of Gene inhibited branching morphogenesis in kidney organ cultures. Gene was detected by in situ mRNA hybridization and/or immunohistochemistry also in embryonic gonads and in spermatids and granulosa cells of adult testes and Disease, respectively. Silencing of Gene by transfection with antisense vivo-morpholinos significantly increased Gene mRNA in cultured embryonic XY gonads (11.5 and 12.5 days postconception), and reduced Gene transcripts in XX gonads (12.5 and 13.5 days postconception). Three predicted Gene consensus motifs could be identified in the promoter and the 5'-untranslated region of the Species Gene gene. Binding of Gene protein to these elements was verified by EMSA and ChIP. A firefly luciferase reporter gene under control of the Gene promoter was activated ~8-fold by transient co-transfection of Species granulosa cells with a Gene expression construct. Gradual shortening of the 5'-flanking sequence successively reduced and eventually abrogated Gene promoter activation by Gene. These findings demonstrate that Gene differentially regulates the Gene gene in XX and XY embryonic gonads. It is suggested that Gene acts immediately downstream of Gene during Species urogenital development. We propose that Gene is involved in branching morphogenesis of the kidneys in Species.

22304922.pub_title: Gene is a multifunctional coreceptor that integrates diffusible- and contact-axon guidance signals.
22304922.pub_abstract: Growing axons encounter multiple guidance cues, but it is unclear how separate signals are resolved and integrated into coherent instructions for growth cone navigation. We report that Chemical (GPI)-anchored ephrin-As function as "reverse" signaling receptors for motor axons when contacted by transmembrane EphAs present in the dorsal limb. Ephrin-A receptors are thought to depend on transmembrane coreceptors for transmitting signals intracellularly. We show that the receptor Chemical kinase Gene is required for motor axon attraction mediated by ephrin-A reverse signaling. Gene also mediates GPI-anchored Gene signaling in response to Gene, a diffusible chemoattractant in the limb, indicating that Gene is a multifunctional coreceptor for guidance molecules. Axons respond synergistically to coactivation by Gene and EphA ligands, and these cooperative interactions are gated by Gene levels. Our studies uncover a hierarchical GPI-receptor signaling network that is constructed from combinatorial components and integrated through Gene using ligand coincidence detection.

27662828.pub_title: Generation and characterization of a novel transgenic Species harboring conditional nuclear factor-kappa B/Gene knockout alleles.
27662828.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Nuclear Factor-Kappa B (NF-kB) is a family of transcription factors that are important in embryonic development, Disease, epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and Disease. The 65 kDa Gene subunit is the major transcriptional activator of the NF-kB pathways. Whole-body deficiency of Gene leads to massive apoptosis of liver hepatocytes and Disease in utero. To study the role of Gene in physiology and in disease states in a manner that circumvents this embryonic lethal phenotype, we have generated a Species with Gene conditional knockout (CKO) alleles containing loxP sites that are deleted by activated Cre recombinase. RESULTS: We demonstrate that RelACKO/CKO Species are fertile, do not display any Disease and can be crossed with Cre-expressing Species to delete Gene in a temporal, tissue-specific manner. Our mating of RelACKO/CKO Species with Gene-Cre transgenic led to Disease. In contrast, mating of RelACKO/CKO Species with Col1alpha2-CreER Species allowed for the generation of double transgenics which could be stimulated with Chemical to induce fibroblast-specific Gene deletion in adulthood. CONCLUSIONS: Based on our collective data, we conclude that this novel RelACKO/CKO Species allows for efficient deletion of Gene in a tissue-specific manner. This RelACKO/CKO Species will be an invaluable tool for deciphering the mechanistic roles of Gene in various cells and tissues during development and in disease.

23499552.pub_title: Progressive reactive lymphoid connective tissue disease and development of autoantibodies in Gene-deficient Species.
23499552.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a member of the class A scavenger receptors, with most similarity to Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene), which are primarily expressed by macrophages and dendritic cells, in which they participate in clearance of various polyanionic macromolecules, pollution particles, and pathogens. The biological role of Gene has been unknown. Herein, we show that Gene is an endocytotic receptor whose ligand repertoire includes the typical scavenger receptor ligands, whole bacteria, and purified Gram-negative bacterial lipopolysaccharide. In contrast to expression of Gene and Gene in immune cells, Gene is found in a subset of fibroblast-like cells in the interstitial stroma of most organs, with additional expression in the epithelial cells of testis and choroid plexus. Gene-null Species develop with age lymphoid cell accumulation in many organs, in particular the lungs, and show decreased endocytotic function in fibroblasts. Furthermore, about one-third of the Species develop antinuclear antibodies. These disturbances are reminiscent of those found in many Species autoimmune connective tissue disorders, which suggests that defects in fibroblast Gene can underlie some forms of Disease.

26952936.pub_title: Epigenetic response to environmental stress: Assembly of Gene-Gene/GLP-DNMT3 repressive chromatin complex on Gene promoter in pathologically stressed hearts.
26952936.pub_abstract: Chromatin structure is determined by nucleosome positioning, histone modifications, and DNA methylation. How chromatin modifications are coordinately altered under pathological conditions remains elusive. Here we describe a stress-activated mechanism of concerted chromatin modification in the heart. In Species, pathological stress activates cardiomyocytes to express Gene (nucleosome-remodeling factor), Gene/Glp (histone methyltransferase), and Dnmt3 (DNA methyltransferase). Once activated, Gene recruits Gene and then Dnmt3 to sequentially assemble repressive chromatin-marked by Chemical and CpG methylation-on a key molecular motor gene (Gene), thereby silencing Gene and impairing cardiac contraction. Disruption of Gene, Gene or Dnmt3 erases repressive chromatin marks and de-represses Gene, reducing stress-induced Disease. In Species Disease hearts, Gene-Gene/GLP-DNMT3 complex is also activated; its level correlates with Chemical/CpG methylation, Gene repression, and Disease. Our studies demonstrate a new mechanism of chromatin assembly in stressed hearts and novel therapeutic targets for restoring Gene and ventricular function. The stress-induced Gene-Gene-Dnmt3 interactions and sequence of repressive chromatin assembly on Gene illustrates a molecular mechanism by which the heart epigenetically responds to environmental signals. This article is part of a Special Issue entitled: Cardiomyocyte Biology: Integration of Developmental and Environmental Cues in the Heart edited by Marcus Schaub and Hughes Abriel.

23206892.pub_title: The combinatorial guidance activities of Gene and Gene are essential for forebrain commissure formation.
23206892.pub_abstract: We have shown that Gene is a repulsive axon guidance molecule for a variety of neuron classes and that genetic deletion of Gene in Species results in the absence of all forebrain commissures. Moreover, we also identified a secreted molecule, Gene (Gene), that belongs to the small Chemical-rich proteoglycan family (SLRP) and inhibits signaling molecules, such as BMP and Wnt. Gene knockout Species show malformation of the corpus callosum (CC) and agenesis of the anterior commissure (AC), suggesting the importance of Gene function in forebrain commissure formation. There is a possibility that the combined function of these two proteins is essential for the formation of these commissures. In this study, we investigate this possibility by generating Gene/Gene doubly heterozygous Species and comparing their forebrain commissure phenotypes with those of singly heterozygous Species. We found that, although Gene and Gene did not interact directly, their genetic interaction was evident from the significantly higher prevalence of CC malformation and agenesis of the AC in the Gene/Gene doubly heterozygous Species. Importantly, in this study, we demonstrated a new function of Gene in guiding anterior olfactory neuronal (AON) and cortical axons. Gene bound to and provided growth inhibitory signals dose-dependently to AON and cortical axons in outgrowth assay. Gene also induced growth cone collapse when applied acutely to these cultured neurons. Furthermore, Gene and Gene had additive effects in inhibiting cortical and Disease. Thus, based on a combination of genetic analyses and in vitro experiments, we propose that the combined guidance activities of Gene and Gene regulate forebrain commissure formation.

25708312.pub_title: Gene (Gene) directly regulates Gene receptor alpha2, Gene, and theta subunits in the hippocampus.
25708312.pub_abstract: The homeostatic regulation of neuronal activity in glutamatergic and GABAergic synapses is critical for neural circuit development and synaptic plasticity. The induced expression of the transcription factor Gene (Gene) in neurons is tightly associated with many forms of neuronal activity, but the underlying target genes in the brain remained to be elucidated. This study uses a quantitative real-time PCR approach, in combination with in vivo chromatin immunoprecipitation, and reveals that Gene receptor subunit, Gene (alpha2), Gene (Gene), and Gene (theta) genes, are transcriptional targets of Gene. Transfection of a construct that over-expresses Gene in Disease (Neuro2A) cells up-regulates the alpha2, Gene, and theta subunits. Given that Gene knockout Species display less Gene, Gene, and GRBRQ mRNA in the hippocampus, and that Gene directly binds to their promoters and induces mRNA expression, the present findings support a role for Gene as a major regulator for altered Gene receptor composition in homeostatic plasticity, in a glutamatergic activity-dependent manner. The Gene (Gene) is an inducible transcription factor to mediate rapid gene expression by neuronal activity. However, its underlying molecular target genes and mechanisms are not fully understood. We suggest that Gene receptor subunits, Gene (alpha2), Gene (Gene), and Gene (theta) genes are transcriptional targets of Gene. Neuronal activity-dependent up-regulation of Gene might lead to altered subtypes of Gene receptors for the maintenance of homeostatic excitatory and inhibitory balance for the regulation of synaptic strength.

22431517.pub_title: Cardiac expression of ms1/STARS, a novel gene involved in cardiac development and disease, is regulated by GATA4.
22431517.pub_abstract: Ms1/STARS is a novel muscle-specific actin-binding protein that specifically modulates the myocardin-related transcription factor (MRTF)-serum response factor (SRF) regulatory axis within striated muscle. This ms1/STARS-dependent regulatory axis is of central importance within the cardiac gene regulatory network and has been implicated in cardiac development and postnatal cardiac function/homeostasis. The dysregulation of ms1/STARS is associated with and causative of pathological cardiac phenotypes, including Disease and Disease. In order to gain an understanding of the mechanisms governing ms1/STARS expression in the heart, we have coupled a comparative genomic in silico analysis with reporter, gain-of-function, and loss-of-function approaches. Through this integrated analysis, we have identified three evolutionarily conserved regions (ECRs), alpha, Species, and DINA, that act as cis-regulatory modules and confer differential cardiac cell-specific activity. Two of these ECRs, alpha and DINA, displayed distinct regulatory sensitivity to the core cardiac transcription factor GATA4. Overall, our results demonstrate that within embryonic, neonatal, and adult hearts, GATA4 represses ms1/STARS expression with the pathologically associated depletion of GATA4 (type 1/type 2 Disease models), resulting in ms1/STARS upregulation. This GATA4-dependent repression of ms1/STARS expression has major implications for MRTF-SRF signaling in the context of cardiac development and disease.

27396339.pub_title: Gene-Gene Confers Enhanced Self-Renewal and Lymphoid Potential during a Restricted Window in Development.
27396339.pub_abstract: Gene-Gene+ Species B cell acute Disease is characterized by an early onset and dismal survival. It initiates before birth, and very little is known about the early stages of the disease's development. Using a conditional Gene-Gene-expressing Species model in which fusion expression is targeted to the earliest definitive hematopoietic cells generated in the Species embryo, we demonstrate that Gene-Gene imparts enhanced B lymphoid potential and increases repopulation and self-renewal capacity during a putative pre-leukemic state. This occurs between embryonic days 12 and 14 and manifests itself most strongly in the lymphoid-primed multipotent progenitor population, thus pointing to a window of opportunity and a potential cell of origin. However, this state alone is insufficient to generate disease, with the Species succumbing to Disease only after a long latency. Future analysis of the molecular details of this pre-leukemic state will shed light on additional events required for progression to acute Disease.

26641717.pub_title: Persistent cell migration and adhesion rely on retrograde transport of beta(1) integrin.
26641717.pub_abstract: Integrins have key functions in cell adhesion and migration. How integrins are dynamically relocalized to the leading edge in highly polarized migratory cells has remained unexplored. Here, we demonstrate that beta1 integrin (known as Gene in Species), but not beta3, is transported from the plasma membrane to the trans-Golgi network, to be resecreted in a polarized manner. This retrograde trafficking is restricted to the non-ligand-bound conformation of beta1 integrin. Retrograde trafficking inhibition abrogates several beta1-integrin-specific functions such as cell adhesion in early embryonic development of Species, and persistent cell migration in the developing posterior gonad arm of Species. Our results establish a paradigm according to which retrograde trafficking, and not endosomal recycling, is the key driver for beta1 integrin function in highly polarized cells. These data more generally suggest that the retrograde route is used to relocalize plasma membrane machinery from previous sites of function to the leading edge of migratory cells.

25778822.pub_title: Expression of the Olig gene family in the developing Species inner ear.
25778822.pub_abstract: Transcription factors are believed to play key roles in determining cell fate in inner ear development. Olig genes, which are basic helix-loop-helix transcription factors, have been reported to play important roles in the development of the central nervous system. However, members of this family have not previously been implicated in inner ear development, despite the similarity between otocyst and neural tube development. Gene begins to be expressed at the ventral domain of the otocyst at embryonic day (E) 9.5, and Gene expression in the epithelium of the developing inner ear persists to E15.5. Gene expression is localized to the cochleovestibular ganglia from E12.5 through E14.5. Gene has a diffuse expression pattern in the developing inner ear from E12.5 through the postnatal stage. Furthermore, at early stages of inner ear development, the Gene expression domain overlaps a region that is positive for Gene and Gene. This observation indicates that Gene may play an important role in the specification of the prosensory domain in the developing inner ear. As Olig genes are expressed in the Species developing inner ear in a temporospatially distinct fashion, they may play substantial roles in the regulation of Species inner ear development.

26697723.pub_title: Isolation and Characterization of Fetal Leydig Progenitor Cells of Male Species.
26697723.pub_abstract: Fetal and adult Leydig cells develop in Species prenatal and postnatal testes, respectively. In Species, fetal Leydig cells (FLCs) emerge in the interstitial space of the testis at embryonic day 12.5 and thereafter increase in number, possibly through differentiation from progenitor cells. However, the progenitor cells have not yet been identified. Previously, we established Species in which FLCs are labeled strongly with enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP). Interestingly, fluorescence-activated cell sorting provided us with weakly EGFP-labeled cells as well as strongly EGFP-labeled FLCs. In vitro reconstruction of fetal testes demonstrated that weakly EGFP-labeled cells contain FLC progenitors. Transcriptome from the 2 cell populations revealed, as expected, marked differences in the expression of genes required for growth factor/receptor signaling and steroidogenesis. In addition, genes for energy metabolisms such as glycolytic pathways and the Chemical cycle were activated in strongly EGFP-labeled cells, suggesting that metabolism is activated during FLC differentiation.

24401371.pub_title: Gene plays an integral role in dorsoventral patterning of the spinal cord by segregating floor plate/p3 fates via Gene suppression and Gene maintenance.
24401371.pub_abstract: During embryogenesis, the dorsal roof plate and the ventral floor plate (FP) act as organizing centers to pattern the developing neural tube. Organizer-secreted morphogens provide signals that are interpreted via the graded expression of transcription factors. These factors establish a combinatorial code, which subsequently determines the fate of neuronal progenitors along the dorsoventral axis. To further separate the fates and promote distinct identities of the neural progenitors, mutual repression takes place among transcription factors expressed in progenitors situated along the dorsoventral axis. The molecular mechanisms acting in the developing spinal cord and underlying the segregation of the progenitor pool containing cells with a mixed FP/p3 fate into separate FP cells and V3 neurons are not fully understood. Using in vivo ectopic expression in Species, we found that Gene induces ectopic Gene-positive cells and indirectly downregulates Gene expression. To examine the role of Gene in the FP, Gene-Gene signaling was blocked in Gene null Species and to a greater extent in Gene null/Gene heterozygous bigenic mutants. Complementary to the findings obtained by gain of function in Species, the loss of function in Species indicated that the segregation of the FP/p3 population into its derivatives was interrupted. Together, the data suggest that Gene is a novel determinant factor regulating the segregation of the FP and p3 identities, which is an essential step for establishing a definitive FP fate in the embryonic spinal cord.

25451153.pub_title: Multiple requirements of the focal Disease gene Chemical during ocular morphogenesis.
25451153.pub_abstract: Wnt glycoproteins control key processes during development and disease by activating various downstream pathways. Wnt secretion requires post-translational modification mediated by the O-acyltransferase encoded by the Disease Chemical homolog gene (Gene). In Species, Gene mutations cause Disease (Disease, or Disease), an Disease that is frequently accompanied by Disease such as Disease, Disease, or even Disease. Although genetic ablation of Gene in Species has provided insight into the etiology of defects caused by ectomesodermal Disease in Disease, the requirement for Gene and the actual Wnt ligands during eye development have been unknown. In this study, Gene hemizygosity occasionally caused Disease reminiscent of Disease. Conditional inactivation of Gene in periocular mesenchyme led to defects in mid- and hindbrain and in craniofacial development, but was insufficient to cause Disease. However, a combination of conditional Gene depletion in Disease, lens, and neural crest-derived periocular mesenchyme induced severe Disease with high penetrance. In particular, we observed Disease, transdifferentiation of the dorsal and ventral retinal pigment epithelium, defective optic cup periphery, and closure defects of the eyelid, as well as defective corneal morphogenesis. Thus, Gene is required in both extraocular and neuroectodermal tissues to regulate distinct Wnt-dependent processes during morphogenesis of the posterior and anterior segments of the eye.

23195472.pub_title: Gene expression and IG-DMR hypomethylation of Gene in developing corticospinal neurons.
23195472.pub_abstract: The Species cerebral cortex plays a central role in higher cognitive functions and in the complex task of motor control. Gene (Gene) appears to play a role in cortical development and Disease, but the expression and regulation of Gene in the cortex is not clear. In this study, we examined the expression of transcript variants of Gene in the developing Species cerebral cortex. By in situ hybridization, we found that a novel transcript variant of Gene with 8 small exons was expressed in the developing cortex, whereas the long isoforms of Gene (~11 kb) were enriched in corticospinal neurons (CSNs) in layer V of the cortex. No transcript variants of Gene were found in the neural progenitors at E12.5, when the intergenic differential methylation region (IG-DMR) near Gene was highly methylated. IG-DMR became demethylated at E15.5 and remained hypomethylated in early CSNs isolated from Gene-EGFP Species. The expression of Gene transcript variant 1 was inversely correlated with the IG-DMR methylation level during development. Moreover, expression of paternally expressed gene Gene was limited to the upper layers, consistent with the idea that the maternally expressed gene may be preferentially transcribed in the lower layers of the cortex. The spatiotemporal expression pattern of Gene suggests that it may participate in the early development of CSNs and contribute to cortical malfunctions related to aberrant imprinting in Gene.

25468546.pub_title: Gene mutant placentas show normal structure and function in the Species.
25468546.pub_abstract: INTRODUCTION: Kisspeptins, encoded by the Gene gene, are a set of related neuropeptides that are required for activation of the Species reproductive axis at puberty and to maintain fertility. In addition, Gene signaling via the G-protein coupled receptor Gene (Gene) has been suggested to regulate Species placental formation and correlations have been found between altered Gene levels in the maternal blood and the development of pre-eclampsia. METHODS: We have used Gene and Gene mutant Species to investigate the role of Gene signaling in the structure and function of the Species placenta. RESULTS: Expression of Gene and Gene was confirmed in the Species placenta but no differences in birth weight were found in Species that had been supported by a mutant placenta during fetal development. Stereological measurements found no differences between Gene mutant and wild-type placentas. Measurement of amino-acid and Chemical transport across the Gene mutant placentas at E15.5 days did not reveal any functional defects. DISCUSSION: These data indicate that Species placentas can develop a normal structure and function without Gene signaling and can support normal fetal development and growth.

25084151.pub_title: Redundant role of Gene and epsilon during Species embryonic development.
25084151.pub_abstract: Gene and epsilon are mediators of important cellular events, such as cell proliferation, migration or apoptosis. The formation of blood vessels, i.e., vasculo- and angiogenesis, is a process where these isoforms have also been shown to participate. However, Species deficient in either Gene or epsilon are viable and therefore their individual contribution to the formation of the vasculature appeared so far dispensable. In this study, we show that double null mutation of Gene and epsilon causes Disease at approximately E9.5. At this stage, whole mount staining of the endothelial marker Gene in double null embryos revealed defective blood vessel formation. Moreover, culture of double deficient Species allantois showed impaired endothelial cell organization, and analyses of double deficient embryo sections showed dilated vessels, decreased endothelial-specific adherent junctions, and decreased contact of endothelial cells with mural cells. Gene and epsilon also appeared essential for vascular smooth muscle cell differentiation, since alpha-smooth muscle actin, a classical marker for vascular smooth muscle cells, was almost undetectable in Disease at E9.5. Subsequent qPCR analyses showed decreased Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene, among other angiogenesis related transcripts in double deficient embryos. Taken together, these data suggest for the first time an in vivo redundant role between members of the novel Protein Kinase C subfamily that allows for mutual compensation during Species embryonic development, with vasculogenesis/angiogenesis as an obvious common function of these two Protein Kinase Cs. Gene and epsilon might therefore be useful targets for inhibiting vasculo- and/or angiogenesis.

25446537.pub_title: Aggrecan is required for growth plate cytoarchitecture and differentiation.
25446537.pub_abstract: The proteoglycan aggrecan is a prominent component of the extracellular matrix in growth plate cartilage. A naturally occurring, recessive, perinatally lethal mutation in the aggrecan core protein gene, cmd(bc) (Gene(cmd-Bc)), that deletes the entire protein-coding sequence provided a model in which to characterize the phenotypic and morphologic effects of aggrecan deletion on skeletal development. We also generated a novel transgenic Species, Tg(Gene-Gene), that has the Species Gene coding sequence driven by the Species Gene promoter to enable the production of cmd(bc)/cmd(bc); Tg(Gene-Gene) rescue embryos. These were used to assess the impact of aggrecan on growth plate organization, chondrocyte survival and proliferation, and the expression of mRNAs encoding chondrocyte differentiation markers and growth factors. Homozygous mutant (cmd(bc)/cmd(bc)) embryos exhibited severe defects in all skeletal elements with deformed and shortened (50%) limb elements. Expression of aggrecan in rescue embryos reversed the skeletal defects to varying degrees with a 20% increase in limb element length and near-full reversal (80%) of size and diameter of the ribcage and vertebrae. Aggrecan-null growth plates were devoid of matrix and lacked chondrocyte organization and differentiation, while those of the rescue embryos exhibited matrix production concomitant with partial zonation of chondrocytes having proliferative and Disease. Deformation of the trachea, likely the cause of the mutation's lethality, was reduced in the rescue embryos. Aggrecan-null embryos also had abnormal patterns of Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene mRNA expression in the growth plate. Expression of Species aggrecan in the rescue embryos notably increased COLX expression, accompanied by the reappearance of a Disease and Gene expression. Significantly, in transgenic rescue embryos, the cell death and decreased proliferation phenotypes exhibited by the mutants were reversed; both were restored to wild-type levels. These findings suggest that aggrecan has a major role in regulating the expression of key growth factors and signaling molecules during development of cartilaginous tissue and is essential for proper chondrocyte organization, morphology, and survival during embryonic limb development.

24416220.pub_title: Gene is a modulator of craniofacial development.
24416220.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The Gene gene is responsible for Coffin-Lowry syndrome, an Disease causing Disease, skeletal growth delays, with Disease typically associated with this syndrome. Craniofacial and Disease encountered in this rare disease have been poorly characterized. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: We examined, using X-Ray microtomographic analysis, the variable Disease and Disease present in Gene knockout Species, a model of Coffin-Lowry syndrome, as well as in triple Gene,2,3 knockout mutants. We report Gene mutation produces surpernumerary teeth midline/mesial to the first molar. This highly penetrant phenotype recapitulates more ancestral tooth structures lost with evolution. Most likely this leads to a Disease. Abnormalities of molar shape were generally restricted to the mesial part of both upper and lower first molars (M1). Expression analysis of the four Gene genes (Gene) was performed at various stages of odontogenesis in wild-type (WT) Species. Gene is expressed in the mesenchymal, neural crest-derived compartment, correlating with proliferative areas of the developing teeth. This is consistent with Gene functioning in cell cycle control and growth regulation, functions potentially responsible for severe dental phenotypes. To uncover molecular pathways involved in the etiology of these defects, we performed a comparative transcriptomic (DNA microarray) analysis of mandibular wild-type versus Gene-/Y molars. We further demonstrated a misregulation of several critical genes, using a Gene shRNA knock-down strategy in molar tooth germs cultured in vitro. CONCLUSIONS: This study reveals Gene regulates craniofacial development including tooth development and patterning via novel transcriptional targets.

23817199.pub_title: Gene and Gene cooperatively regulate vascular smooth muscle differentiation from neural crest cells.
23817199.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: Vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) differentiation from neural crest cells (NCCs) is critical for cardiovascular development, but the mechanisms remain largely unknown. OBJECTIVE: Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) function in VSMC differentiation from NCCs is controversial. Therefore, we determined the role and mechanism of a TGF-beta downstream signaling intermediate Gene in NCC differentiation to VSMCs. METHODS AND RESULTS: By using Cre/loxP system, we generated a NCC tissue-specific Gene knockout Species model and found that Gene deletion resulted in defective NCC differentiation to VSMCs in aortic arch arteries during embryonic development and caused vessel wall abnormality in adult carotid arteries where the VSMCs are derived from NCCs. The abnormalities included 1 layer of VSMCs missing in the media of the arteries with distorted and thinner elastic lamina, leading to a thinner vessel wall compared with wild-type vessel. Mechanistically, Gene interacted with Gene (Gene) to regulate VSMC marker gene expression. Gene was required for TGF-beta-induced Gene nuclear translocation, whereas Gene enhanced Gene binding to VSMC marker promoter. Furthermore, we found that Gene, but not Gene, was a progenitor-specific transcription factor mediating TGF-beta-induced VSMC differentiation from NCCs. Gene also seemed to be involved in determining the physiological differences between NCC-derived and mesoderm-derived VSMCs. CONCLUSIONS: Gene is an important factor in regulating progenitor-specific VSMC development and physiological differences between NCC-derived and mesoderm-derived VSMCs.

24859004.pub_title: The ability of inner-cell-mass cells to self-renew as embryonic stem cells is acquired following epiblast specification.
24859004.pub_abstract: The precise relationship of embryonic stem cells (ESCs) to cells in the Species embryo remains controversial. We present transcriptional and functional data to identify the embryonic counterpart of ESCs. Marker profiling shows that ESCs are distinct from early inner cell mass (ICM) and closely resemble pre-implantation epiblast. A characteristic feature of Species ESCs is propagation without Gene signalling. Single-cell culture reveals that cell-autonomous capacity to thrive when the Gene pathway is inhibited arises late during blastocyst development and is lost after implantation. The frequency of deriving clonal ESC lines suggests that all E4.5 epiblast cells can become ESCs. We further show that ICM cells from early blastocysts can progress to Gene independence if provided with a specific laminin substrate. These findings suggest that formation of the epiblast coincides with competence for Gene-independent self-renewal in vitro and consequent propagation as ESC lines.

22322304.pub_title: The Gene Protein Mutation Species as a model for Species Disease.
22322304.pub_abstract: Pathological Disease has been implicated in certain Disease, including minimal Disease, Disease, and Disease. We studied our previously established Species model carrying a homozygous mutation in the key enzyme of Chemical biosynthesis, Chemical 2-epimerase/Chemical kinase. Mutant Species died before postnatal day 3 (P3) from severe Disease with podocyte effacement and segmental glomerular basement membrane splitting due to Disease. Administration of the Chemical precursor Chemical (Chemical) led to improved sialylation and survival of mutant pups beyond P3. We determined the onset of the Disease in the embryonic stage. A lectin panel, distinguishing normally sialylated from hyposialylated glycans, used WGA, SNA, PNA, Jacalin, Disease, and VVA, indicating Disease of predominantly O-linked glycoproteins in mutant Species. The glomerular glycoproteins Gene and Gene were hyposialylated in this unique Species model. Chemical treatment appeared to ameliorate the Disease status of mutant Species, indicated by a lectin histochemistry pattern similar to that of wild-type Species, with improved sialylation of both Gene and Gene, as well as reduced Disease compared with untreated mutant Species. These findings suggest application of our lectin panel for categorizing Species kidney specimens based on glomerular sialylation status. Moreover, the partial restoration of glomerular architecture in Chemical-treated Species highlights Chemical as a potential treatment for Species affected with Disease.

24855103.pub_title: Preimplantation Species embryo is a target for opioid ligand-receptor signaling.
24855103.pub_abstract: Synchronization of preimplantation embryo development to Disease is one of the prerequisites for normal embryo implantation. While previous studies have ascribed an adverse effect to aberrant opioid signaling on embryo and fetal development, it has remained unclear whether the opioid system is operative in early pregnancy events. In the present study, employing multiple pharmacological and genetic approaches, we demonstrated that preimplantation embryos spanning the zygote to blastocyst express the opioid receptor subtypes and the oviduct expresses endogenous opioid precursors dynamically, which suggest that opioid signaling is functionally operative during preimplantation embryo development. Subsequent analysis further revealed that an aberrantly activated opioid signaling by Chemical can remarkably derail normal preimplantation embryo development via inhibiting intracellular Chemical mobilization, while a cotreatment of Chemical with Chemical can remarkably reverse the adverse effects of Chemical on preimplantation embryo development. Besides shedding light on the pathophysiological significance of the opioid system during early embryo development in Species, our findings have potential clinical relevance because an abused use of illicit opiate drugs is frequently associated with retarded fetal development and pregnancy failure in Species.

24107967.pub_title: Gene signaling levels control migration and neuronal differentiation of enteric ganglion precursors.
24107967.pub_abstract: Pleiotropic growth factors play a number of critical roles in continuous processes of embryonic development; however, the mechanisms by which a single regulatory factor is able to orchestrate diverse developmental events remain imperfectly understood. In the development of the enteric nervous system (ENS), myenteric ganglia (Chemical) form initially, after which the submucosal ganglia (SMGs) develop by radial inward migration of immature ENS precursors from the myenteric layer. Here, we demonstrate that Gene (Gene) is essential for the formation not only of the Chemical, but the SMGs as well, establishing Gene as a long-term acting neurotrophic factor for ENS development in a Species model. Gene promotes radial migration of SMG precursors. Interestingly, premigratory SMG precursors in the myenteric layer were distinguished from the surrounding neuronally differentiating cells by their lower activation of the Gene-mediated MAPK pathway, suggesting that low activation of Gene downstream pathways is required for the maintenance of the immature state. ENS precursors devoid of Gene signaling during midgestation halt their migration, survive, and remain in an undifferentiated state over the long-term in vivo. Reactivation of Gene signaling in these dormant precursors restores their migration and neuronal differentiation in gut organ culture. These findings suggest that pleiotropic function of Gene is at least in part governed by modulating levels of intracellular activation of Gene downstream pathways; high activation triggers neuronal differentiation, whereas low activation is crucial for the maintenance of progenitor state.

25875176.pub_title: Functional synergy between Gene receptors Gene and Gene in Species brain development.
25875176.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene), a peptide hormone and one of the most abundant neuropeptides in vertebrate brain, mediates its actions via two G-protein coupled receptors, Gene and Gene, respectively active in peripheral organs and the central nervous system. Here, we demonstrate that the Gene receptors have a dynamic and largely reciprocal expression in embryonic and postnatal brain. Using compound homozygous mutant Species lacking the activity of both Gene receptors, we uncover their additive, functionally synergistic effects in brain development and demonstrate that Gene receptor loss leads to abnormalities of cortical development, including defects in the formation of the midline and corpus callosum, and cortical interneuron migration. Using comparative transcriptome analysis of embryonic neocortex, we define the molecular mechanisms underlying these defects. Thus we demonstrate a developmental, hitherto unappreciated, role of the two Gene receptors in Species neocortical development.

22278926.pub_title: Bimodal control of Gene gene transcription in the spinal cord defines two regulatory subclusters.
22278926.pub_abstract: The importance of Hox genes in the specification of neuronal fates in the spinal cord has long been recognized. However, the transcriptional controls underlying their collinear expression domains remain largely unknown. Here we show in Species that the correspondence between the physical order of Gene genes and their rostral expression boundaries, although respecting spatial collinearity, does not display a fully progressive distribution. Instead, two major anteroposterior boundaries are detected, coinciding with the functional subdivision of the spinal cord. Tiling array analyses reveal two distinct blocks of transcription, regulated independently from one another, that define the observed expression boundaries. Targeted deletions in vivo that remove the genomic fragments separating the two blocks induce ectopic expression of posterior genes. We further evaluate the independent regulatory potential and transcription profile of each gene locus by a tiling array approach using a contiguous series of transgenes combined with locus-specific deletions. Our work uncovers a bimodal type of Gene spatial collinearity in the developing spinal cord that relies on two separate 'enhancer mini-hubs' to ensure correct Gene gene expression levels while maintaining their appropriate anteroposterior boundaries.

22495305.pub_title: An RNA interference screen uncovers a new molecule in stem cell self-renewal and long-term regeneration.
22495305.pub_abstract: Adult stem cells sustain tissue maintenance and regeneration throughout the lifetime of an animal. These cells often reside in specific signalling niches that orchestrate the stem cell's balancing act between quiescence and cell-cycle re-entry based on the demand for tissue regeneration. How stem cells maintain their capacity to replenish themselves after tissue regeneration is poorly understood. Here we use RNA-interference-based loss-of-function screening as a powerful approach to uncover transcriptional regulators that govern the self-renewal capacity and regenerative potential of stem cells. Hair follicle stem cells provide an ideal model. These cells have been purified and characterized from their native niche in vivo and, in contrast to their rapidly dividing progeny, they can be maintained and passaged long-term in vitro. Focusing on the nuclear proteins and/or transcription factors that are enriched in stem cells compared with their progeny, we screened ~2,000 short hairpin RNAs for their effect on long-term, but not short-term, stem cell self-renewal in vitro. To address the physiological relevance of our findings, we selected one candidate that was uncovered in the screen: TBX1. This transcription factor is expressed in many tissues but has not been studied in the context of stem cell biology. By conditionally ablating Tbx1 in vivo, we showed that during homeostasis, tissue regeneration occurs normally but is markedly delayed. We then devised an in vivo assay for stem cell replenishment and found that when challenged with repetitive rounds of regeneration, the Tbx1-deficient stem cell niche becomes progressively depleted. Addressing the mechanism of TBX1 action, we discovered that TBX1 acts as an intrinsic rheostat of BMP signalling: it is a Species that governs the transition between stem cell quiescence and proliferation in hair follicles. Our results validate the RNA interference screen and underscore its power in unearthing new molecules that govern stem cell self-renewal and tissue-regenerative potential.

24148772.pub_title: Differential expression of the metastasis suppressor Gene in decidual cells and trophoblast giant cells at the feto-maternal interface.
24148772.pub_abstract: Invasion of trophoblasts into maternal uterine tissue is essential for establishing mature feto-maternal circulation. The trophoblast invasion associated with placentation is similar to Disease invasion. In this study, we investigated the role of Gene, an antimetastasis factor, at the maternal-fetal interface during placentation. Species embryos were obtained from gestational days 5.5 (E5.5) to E13.5. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that Gene was expressed on decidual cells around the track made when a fertilized ovum invaded the endometrium, at days E5.5 and E7.5, and on trophoblast giant cells, along the central maternal artery of the placenta at E9.5. Gene in trophoblast giant cells was increased at E11.5, and then decreased at E13.5. Furthermore, Gene was upregulated during the Chemical-mediated trophoblastic differentiation of BeWo cells. Collectively, these results indicate that Gene is differentially expressed in decidual cells and trophoblasts at the maternal-fetal interface, suggesting that Gene prevents trophoblast invasion during placentation.

25212783.pub_title: A novel Amh-Treck transgenic Species line allows toxin-dependent loss of supporting cells in gonads.
25212783.pub_abstract: Cell ablation technology is useful for studying specific cell lineages in a developing organ in vivo. Herein, we established a novel anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)-toxin receptor-mediated cell knockout (Treck) Species line, in which the Gene was specifically activated in Sertoli and granulosa cells in postnatal testes and Disease respectively. In the postnatal testes of Amh-Treck transgenic (Tg) male Species, DT injection induced a specific loss of the Sertoli cells in a dose-dependent manner, as well as the specific degeneration of granulosa cells in the primary and secondary follicles caused by DT injection in Tg females. In the testes with depletion of Sertoli cell, germ cells appeared to survive for only several days after DT treatment and rapidly underwent cell degeneration, which led to the accumulation of a large amount of cell debris within the seminiferous tubules by day 10 after DT treatment. Transplantation of exogenous healthy Sertoli cells following DT treatment rescued the germ cell loss in the transplantation sites of the seminiferous epithelia, leading to a partial recovery of the spermatogenesis. These results provide not only in vivo evidence of the crucial role of Sertoli cells in the maintenance of germ cells, but also show that the Amh-Treck Tg line is a useful in vivo model of the function of the supporting cell lineage in developing Species gonads.

23169458.pub_title: Gene expression is upregulated in adult spinal cord after Disease in both oligodendrocyte lineage and ependymal cells.
23169458.pub_abstract: The upregulation of genes normally associated with development may occur in the adult after Disease (SCI). To test this, we performed real-time RT-PCR array analysis of Species spinal cord mRNAs comparing embryonic day (E)14.5 spinal cord with intact adult and adult cord 1 week after a clinically relevant standardized contusion SCI. We found significantly increased expression of a large number of neural development- and stem cell-associated genes after SCI. These included Gene (Gene), a transcription factor that regulates self-renewal and potency of embryonic neural stem cells and is one of only a few key factors needed to induce pluripotency. In adult spinal cord of Gene-EGFP Species, Gene-EGFP was found mainly in the ependymal cells of the central canal. After SCI, both mRNA and protein levels of Gene were significantly increased at and near the injury site. By 1 day, Gene was upregulated in NG2(+) oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OPC) in the spared white matter. By 3 days, Gene-EGFP ependymal cells had increased proliferation and begun to form multiple layers and clusters of cells in the central lesion zone of the cord. Expression of Gene by NG2(+) cells had declined by 1 week, but increased numbers of other Gene-expressing cells persisted for at least 4 weeks after SCI in both Species and Species models. Thus, SCI upregulates many genes associated with development and neural stem cells, including the key transcription factor Gene, which is expressed in a pool of cells that persists for weeks after SCI.

27929058.pub_title: Tectal-derived interneurons contribute to phasic and tonic inhibition in the visual thalamus.
27929058.pub_abstract: The release of Chemical from local interneurons in the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN-INs) provides inhibitory control during visual processing within the thalamus. It is commonly assumed that this important class of interneurons originates from within the thalamic complex, but we now show that during early postnatal development Gene/Gene-expressing precursor cells migrate from the dorsal midbrain to generate dLGN-INs. The unexpected extra-diencephalic origin of dLGN-INs sets them apart from GABAergic neurons of the reticular thalamic nucleus. Using optogenetics we show that at increased firing rates tectal-derived dLGN-INs generate a powerful form of tonic inhibition that regulates the gain of thalamic relay neurons through recruitment of extrasynaptic high-affinity GABAA receptors. Therefore, by revising the conventional view of thalamic interneuron ontogeny we demonstrate how a previously unappreciated Disease population controls thalamic relay neuron excitability.

26883496.pub_title: MiRNA-128 regulates the proliferation and neurogenesis of neural precursors by targeting Gene in the developing cortex.
26883496.pub_abstract: During the development, tight regulation of the expansion of neural progenitor cells (NPCs) and their differentiation into neurons is crucial for normal cortical formation and function. In this study, we demonstrate that microRNA (miR)-128 regulates the proliferation and differentiation of NPCs by repressing Gene). Specifically, overexpression of miR-128 reduced NPC proliferation but promoted NPC differentiation into neurons both in vivo and in vitro. In contrast, the reduction of endogenous miR-128 elicited the opposite effects. Overexpression of miR-128 suppressed the translation of Gene, and knockdown of endogenous Gene phenocopied the observed effects of miR-128 overexpression. Furthermore, concomitant overexpression of Gene and miR-128 in NPCs rescued the phenotype associated with miR-128 overexpression, enhancing neurogenesis but inhibiting proliferation, both in vitro and in utero. Taken together, these results demonstrate a novel mechanism by which miR-128 regulates the proliferation and differentiation of NPCs in the developing neocortex.

24803591.pub_title: The tissue-specific transcriptomic landscape of the mid-gestational Species embryo.
24803591.pub_abstract: Differential gene expression is a prerequisite for the formation of multiple cell types from the fertilized egg during embryogenesis. Understanding the gene regulatory networks controlling cellular differentiation requires the identification of crucial differentially expressed control genes and, ideally, the determination of the complete transcriptomes of each individual cell type. Here, we have analyzed the transcriptomes of six major tissues dissected from mid-gestational (TS12) Species embryos. Approximately one billion reads derived by RNA-seq analysis provided extended transcript lengths, novel first exons and alternative transcripts of known genes. We have identified 1375 genes showing tissue-specific expression, providing gene signatures for each of the six tissues. In addition, we have identified 1403 novel putative long noncoding RNA gene loci, 439 of which show differential expression. Our analysis provides the first complete transcriptome data for the Species embryo. It offers a rich data source for the analysis of individual genes and gene regulatory networks controlling mid-gestational development.

23942202.pub_title: Genetic analysis of the role of Gene in the coordination of lower body and external genitalia formation.
23942202.pub_abstract: Although several syndromes include abnormalities of both the ventral body wall and external genitalia, the developmental bases of this correlation are largely unknown. Naturally occurring mutations in Gene (Gene, Strong's luxoid: Alx4Lst) have ventral body wall and Disease. We sought to determine whether the development of the genital tubercle (GT) and its derivatives, the external genitalia, is affected by this mutation. We thus performed genetic and tissue labeling analyses in mutant Species. GeneLst/Gene mutants displayed Disease of the dorsal GT and reduced expression of Gene. We analyzed cell migration during GT formation by tissue labeling experiments and discovered that the cells located in the proximal segment of the umbilical cord (infra-umbilical mesenchyme) migrate toward the dorsal part of the GT. The GeneLst/Gene mutants also displayed augmented expression of Hh signal-related genes. Hence, we analyzed a series of combinatorial mutants for Gene, Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene). These phenotype-genotype analyses suggested a genetic interaction between Gene and Hh signaling during GT formation. Moreover, Hh gain-of-function mutants phenocopied some of these phenotypes. These observations reveal novel information regarding the pathogenic mechanisms of Disease, which are largely unknown.

23902858.pub_title: Gene regulates the guidance of post-crossing spinal commissural axons in a subtype-specific manner.
23902858.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Spinal commissural axons represent a model system for deciphering the molecular logic that regulates the guidance of midline-crossing axons in the developing central nervous system (CNS). Whether the same or specific sets of guidance signals control the navigation of molecularly distinct subtypes of these axons remains an open and largely unexplored question. Although it is well established that post-crossing commissural axons alter their responsiveness to midline-associated guidance cues, our understanding of the repulsive mechanisms that drive the post-crossing segments of these axons away from the midline and whether the underlying guidance systems operate in a commissural axon subtype-specific manner, remains fragmentary at best. RESULTS: Here, we utilize axonally targeted transgenic reporter Species to visualize genetically distinct dorsal interneuron (dI)1 and Gene commissural axons and show that the repulsive class 3 semaphorin (Sema3) guidance receptor Gene (Gene), is selectively expressed on the Gene population and is required for the guidance of post-crossing Gene, but not Gene, axons. Consistent with these observations, the midline-associated Gene ligands, Gene and Gene, promote the collapse of Gene, but not Gene, axon-associated growth cones in vitro. We also identify, for the first time, a discrete GABAergic population of ventral commissural neurons/axons in the embryonic Species spinal cord that expresses Gene, and show that Gene is required for the proper guidance of their post-crossing axons. CONCLUSIONS: Together, our findings indicate that Gene is selectively expressed in distinct populations of commissural neurons in both the dorsal and ventral spinal cord, and suggest that Sema3-Gene signaling regulates the guidance of post-crossing commissural axons in a population-specific manner.

25263125.pub_title: Induction of the nuclear receptor Gene by the cytokine Gene is critical for the differentiation of fetal monocytes into alveolar macrophages.
25263125.pub_abstract: Tissue-resident macrophages constitute heterogeneous populations with unique functions and distinct gene-expression signatures. While it has been established that they originate mostly from embryonic progenitor cells, the signals that induce a characteristic tissue-specific differentiation program remain unknown. We found that the nuclear receptor Gene determined the perinatal differentiation and identity of alveolar macrophages (AMs). In contrast, Gene was dispensable for the development of macrophages located in the peritoneum, liver, brain, heart, kidneys, intestine and fat. Transcriptome analysis of the precursors of AMs from newborn Species showed that Gene conferred a unique signature, including several transcription factors and genes associated with the differentiation and function of AMs. Expression of Gene in fetal lung monocytes was dependent on the cytokine Gene. Therefore, Gene has a lung-specific role in the perinatal development of AMs through the induction of Gene in fetal monocytes.

22632726.pub_title: Optic chiasm presentation of Gene in the context of Gene and Gene promotes retinal axon midline crossing.
22632726.pub_abstract: At the optic chiasm, retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) project ipsi- or contralaterally to establish the circuitry for binocular vision. Ipsilateral guidance programs have been characterized, but contralateral guidance programs are not well understood. Here, we identify a Chemical molecular system for contralateral RGC projections: Gene (Gene) and Gene are expressed on Disease and Gene on chiasm neurons, and Gene and Gene are also expressed on contralateral RGCs. Gene is repulsive to contralateral RGCs, but Gene in combination with Gene and Gene converts repulsion to growth promotion. Gene functions as a receptor for Gene. Gene, Gene, and Gene are all required for efficient RGC decussation at the optic chiasm. These findings suggest a mechanism by which a complex of Gene, Gene, and Gene at the chiasm midline alters the sign of Gene and signals Gene/Gene receptors on RGCs to implement the contralateral RGC projection.

27430022.pub_title: A flexible, multilayered protein scaffold maintains the slit in between glomerular podocytes.
27430022.pub_abstract: Vertebrate life critically depends on renal filtration and excretion of low molecular weight waste products. This process is controlled by a specialized cell-cell contact between podocyte foot processes: the slit diaphragm (SD). Using a comprehensive set of targeted KO Species of key SD molecules, we provided genetic, functional, and high-resolution ultrastructural data highlighting a concept of a flexible, dynamic, and multilayered architecture of the SD. Our data indicate that the Species SD is composed of Gene and Gene molecules, while Gene and Gene do not participate in podocyte intercellular junction formation. Unexpectedly, homo- and heteromeric Gene/Gene complexes are rarely observed. Instead, single Gene molecules appear to form the lower part of the junction close to the glomerular basement membrane with a width of 23 nm, while single Gene molecules form an adjacent junction more apically with a width of 45 nm. In both cases, the molecules are quasiperiodically spaced 7 nm apart. These structural findings, in combination with the flexibility inherent to the repetitive Ig folds of Gene and Gene, indicate that the SD likely represents a highly dynamic cell-cell contact that forms an adjustable, nonclogging barrier within the renal filtration apparatus.

27590203.pub_title: FGF and Gene pathways control initiation and branching of distinct subsets of developing nasal glands.
27590203.pub_abstract: Disease, Disease and altered mucus secretion from the respiratory submucosal glands (SMG) are characteristics of airway diseases such as Disease, Disease and chronic Disease. More commonly, hyper-secretion of the nasal SMGs contributes to Disease and Disease. Considering the role of these glands in disease states, there is a significant dearth in understanding the molecular signals that regulate SMG development and patterning. Due to the imperative role of FGF signalling during the development of other branched structures, we investigated the role of Gene during initiation and branching morphogenesis of Species nasal SMGs. Gene is expressed in the mesenchyme around developing SMGs while expression of its receptor Gene is seen within glandular epithelial cells. In the Gene null embryo, Steno's gland and the maxillary sinus gland were completely absent while other neighbouring nasal glands showed normal duct elongation but defective branching. Interestingly, the medial nasal glands were present in Gene homozygotes but missing in Fgfr2b mutants, with expression of Gene specifically expressed around these developing glands, indicating that Gene might compensate for loss of Gene in this group of glands. Intriguingly the lateral nasal glands were only mildly affected by loss of FGF signalling, while these glands were missing in Gene mutant Species, where the Steno's and maxillary sinus gland developed as normal. This analysis reveals that regulation of nasal gland development is complex with different subsets of glands being regulated by different signalling pathways. This analysis helps shed light on the nasal gland defects observed in Species with Disease (Disease) (defect Gene pathway) and Disease (defect Geneb pathway).

25926459.pub_title: Dentate Gyrus Development Requires Gene Activity to Maintain Progenitor Population and Gene Pathway Feedback Regulation.
25926459.pub_abstract: The Gene/Gene pathway is an important developmental signaling pathway. Mutations in upstream elements of this pathway result in Disease (NCFC) syndromes, which are typified by Disease that are reliant upon hippocampal function. The role of Gene signaling during hippocampal development has not been examined and may provide critical insight into the cause of Disease in NCFC syndromes. In this study, we have generated Gene and conditional Gene compound knock-out Species to determine the role of Gene signaling during development of the hippocampal dentate gyrus. We found that loss of both Gene and Gene resulted in 60% fewer granule cells and near complete absence of neural progenitor pools in the postnatal dentate gyrus. Loss of Gene impaired maintenance of neural progenitors as they migrate from the dentate ventricular zone to the dentate gyrus proper, resulting in premature depletion of neural progenitor cells beginning at E16.5, which prevented generation of granule cells later in development. Finally, loss of Gene alone does not impair development of the dentate gyrus as animals expressing only Gene developed a normal hippocampus. These findings establish that Gene signaling regulates maintenance of progenitor cells required for development of the dentate gyrus.

23220102.pub_title: Gene directly regulates early inner ear expression of Gene.
23220102.pub_abstract: The analysis of Gene Species mutants has demonstrated a critical role for this ligand in neurosensory development of the vertebrate inner ear, and we have been looking to define the direct upstream regulators of Gene in this sensory organ, as part of constructing the programme of early inner ear development. Through the analysis of reporter constructs in transgenic Species embryos and neonatal Species, in this report we define a minimal 1400 bp enhancer from the 5' flanking region of Gene. This enhancer drives reporter transgene expression in a manner that recapitulates endogenous expression of Gene, from its initial onset in the invaginating otic placode and onwards throughout gestation, controlling Gene expression in all developing sensory patches and in the developing VIIIth ganglion. This regulatory region includes three putative Gene binding sites that we demonstrate directly interacts with Gene protein through the DNA binding domain with differing affinities. Site directed mutagenesis of all three sites and functional testing in transgenic embryos using reporter transgenes reveals an absolute requirement for Gene in controlling Gene expression. Transgenic analysis of individual Gene binding site mutations illustrates that only one of these binding sites is necessary for reporter expression. Together these data demonstrate that Gene directly activates Gene in the early inner ear, and does so through a single binding site.

22156770.pub_title: ES cell differentiation system recapitulates the establishment of imprinted gene expression in a cell-type-specific manner.
22156770.pub_abstract: Genomic imprinting is a phenomenon whereby monoallelic gene expression occurs in a parent-of-origin-specific manner. A subset of imprinted genes acquires a tissue-specific imprinted status during the course of tissue development, and this process can be analyzed by means of an in vitro differentiation system utilizing embryonic stem (ES) cells. In neurons, the gene Gene is expressed from the maternal allele only, and a paternally expressed non-coding, antisense RNA has been implicated in the imprinting process in Species and Species. Here, to study the genomic imprinting mechanism, we established F1 hybrid ES cells derived from two sub-species of Species and established an in vitro neuronal differentiation system in which neuron-specific imprinting of Gene was recapitulated. With this system, we revealed that the switch from biallelic expression to maternal, monoallelic expression of Gene occurs late in neuronal development, during the neurite outgrowth period, and that the expression of endogenous antisense transcript from the Gene locus is up-regulated several hundred-fold during the same period. Our results suggest that evaluation of the quality of ES cells by studying their differentiation in vitro should include evaluation of epigenetic aspects, such as a comparison with the genomic imprinting status found in tissues in vivo, in addition to the evaluation of differentiation gene markers and morphology. Our F1 hybrid ES cells and in vitro differentiation system will allow researchers to investigate complex end-points such as neuron-specific genomic imprinting, and our F1 hybrid ES cells are a useful resource for other tissue-specific genomic imprinting and epigenetic analyses.

23147502.pub_title: Gene on Disease end feet is required for pial basement membrane integrity and columnar organization of the developing cerebral cortex.
23147502.pub_abstract: Interactions between the embryonic pial basement membrane (PBM) and Disease (RG) are essential for morphogenesis of the cerebral cortex because disrupted interactions cause Disease. To elucidate the role of Gene (Gene) in PBM-RG interactions, we studied the expression of Gene protein and Gene mRNA (which encodes Gene protein) in developing cerebral cortex and analyzed cortical phenotypes in Gene CNS conditional mutant Species. In normal embryonic cortex, Gene mRNA was expressed in the ventricular zone, which contains RG nuclei, whereas Gene protein was expressed at the cortical surface on RG end feet. Breaches of PBM continuity appeared during early neurogenesis in Gene mutants. Diverse cellular elements streamed through the breaches to form Disease that were confluent with the underlying residual cortical plate and contained variably truncated RG fibers, many types of cortical neurons, and radial and intermediate progenitor cells. Nevertheless, layer-specific molecular expression seemed normal in heterotopic neurons, and axons projected to appropriate targets. Dendrites, however, were excessively tortuous and lacked radial orientation. These findings indicate that Gene is required on RG end feet to maintain PBM integrity and suggest that Disease involve disturbances of RG structure, progenitor distribution, and dendrite orientation, in addition to neuronal "overmigration."

24125951.pub_title: Sexual differences of imprinted genes' expression levels.
24125951.pub_abstract: In mammals, genomic imprinting has evolved as a dosage-controlling mechanism for a subset of genes that play critical roles in their unusual reproduction scheme involving viviparity and placentation. As such, many imprinted genes are highly expressed in sex-specific reproductive organs. In the current study, we sought to test whether imprinted genes are differentially expressed between the two sexes. According to the results, the expression levels of the following genes differ between the two sexes of Species: Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene.
