Collectively, our findings support an emerging model for a mechanism underlying EA/Gene in which impaired notochord resolution from the early endoderm causes the foregut to be hypo-cellular just prior to the critical period of compartmentalization. Our further characterizations suggest that Gene may regulate a cell rearrangement process that involves reciprocal Gene and Gene expression in the resolving notochord cells.

25904789.pub_title: Gene Expression by Species Inner Ear Hair Cells during Development.
25904789.pub_abstract: Hair cells of the inner ear are essential for hearing and balance. As a consequence, pathogenic variants in genes specifically expressed in hair cells often cause Disease. Hair cells are few in number and not easily isolated from the adjacent supporting cells, so the biochemistry and molecular biology of hair cells can be difficult to study. To study gene expression in hair cells, we developed a protocol for hair cell isolation by Gene. With nearly pure hair cells and surrounding cells, from cochlea and utricle and from E16 to P7, we performed a comprehensive cell type-specific RNA-Seq study of gene expression during Species inner ear development. Expression profiling revealed new hair cell genes with distinct expression patterns: some are specific for vestibular hair cells, others for cochlear hair cells, and some are expressed just before or after maturation of mechanosensitivity. We found that many of the known hereditary Disease are much more highly expressed in hair cells than surrounding cells, suggesting that genes preferentially expressed in hair cells are good candidates for unknown Disease genes.

26864488.pub_title: Expression of Gene genes in tooth development.
26864488.pub_abstract: Members of the Gene gene family play roles in many biological processes including organogenesis. We carried out comparative in situ hybridization analysis of seventeen Gene genes (Sox1-14, 17, 18, 21) during Species odontogenesis from the epithelial thickening to the cytodifferentiation stages. Localized expression of five Gene genes (Gene) was observed in tooth bud epithelium. Gene showed restricted expression in the primary enamel knots. At the early bell stage, three Gene genes (Gene, 11, 17 and 21) were expressed in pre-ameloblasts, whereas two others (Gene and 18) showed expression in odontoblasts. Gene genes thus showed a dynamic spatio-temporal expression during tooth development.

23650387.pub_title: Gene is required for the patterning and differentiation of the diaphragm in a model of Disease.
23650387.pub_abstract: Disease (CDH) is a common Disease that results in a high degree of neonatal morbidity and mortality, but its pathological mechanisms are largely unknown. Therefore, we performed a forward genetic screen in Species to identify unique genes, models, and mechanisms of abnormal diaphragm development. We identified a mutant allele of kinesin family member 7 (Gene), the disorganized diaphragm (dd). Embryos homozygous for the dd allele possess communicating Disease, central tendon patterning defects, and increased cell proliferation with diaphragmatic tissue Disease. Because the patterning of the central tendon is undescribed, we analyzed the expression of genes regulating tendonogenesis in dd/dd mutant embryos, and we determined that Chemical (RA) signaling was misregulautted. To further investigate the role of Gene and RA signaling in the development of the embryonic diaphragm, we established primary mesenchymal cultures of Disease day 13.5 diaphragmatic cells. We determined that RA signaling is necessary for the expression of tendon markers as well as the expression of other CDH-associated genes. Knockdown of Gene, and Chemical receptors alpha (Gene), beta (Gene), and gamma (Gene) indicated that RA signaling is dependent on these genes to promote tendonogenesis within the embryonic diaphragm. Taken together, our results provide evidence for a model in which inhibition of RA receptor signaling promotes CDH pathogenesis through a complex gene network.

23000962.pub_title: Stimulus-dependent phosphorylation of Gene in angiogenesis.
23000962.pub_abstract: Angiogenesis, the formation of new blood vessels, is fundamental to development and post-injury tissue repair. Gene (Gene)-A guides and enhances endothelial cell migration to initiate angiogenesis. Gene (Gene) is an actin-binding protein that enhances actin filament formation and cell migration, but stimulus-dependent regulation of Gene has not been observed. Here, we show that Gene-inducible phosphorylation of Gene at Chemical 129 is critical for endothelial cell migration and angiogenesis. Chemotactic activation of Gene (Gene) and Gene induces Gene phosphorylation in the cell leading edge, promoting Gene binding to actin and actin polymerization. Conditional endothelial knock-in of phosphorylation-deficient Gene(Protein Mutation) in Species reveals that Gene phosphorylation is critical for angiogenesis in response to wounding and Disease, but not for developmental angiogenesis. Thus, Gene/Gene-mediated phosphorylation of Gene bypasses canonical, multistep intracellular signalling events to initiate endothelial cell migration and angiogenesis, and might serve as a selective therapeutic target for anti-angiogenic therapy.

23714778.pub_title: Gene is essential for spermatogenesis and participates in primary piRNA biogenesis in the germline.
23714778.pub_abstract: Piwi proteins and Piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) repress transposition, regulate translation, and guide epigenetic programming in the germline. Here, we show that an evolutionarily conserved Tudor and KH domain-containing protein, Gene (a.k.a. Gene), is required for spermatogenesis and involved in piRNA biogenesis. Gene partners with Gene and Gene via symmetrically Chemical residues in Gene and Gene. Gene is a mitochondrial protein often juxtaposed to pi-bodies and Gene-bodies and is required for Gene cytoplasmic localization and Gene nuclear localization. Gene mutants display meiotic arrest at the zygotene stage, attenuate methylation of Line1 DNA, and upregulate Line1 RNA and protein, without inducing apoptosis. Furthermore, Gene mutants have severely reduced levels of mature piRNAs but accumulate a distinct population of 1'U-containing, Chemical 31-37 nt RNAs that largely complement the missing mature piRNAs. Our results demonstrate that the primary piRNA biogenesis pathway involves 3' 5' processing of 31-37 nt intermediates and that Gene promotes this final step of piRNA biogenesis but not the ping-pong cycle. These results shed light on mechanisms underlying primary piRNA biogenesis, an area in which information is conspicuously absent.

23410787.pub_title: A comparative study of axon-surrounding cells in the two nasal nerve tracts from Species olfactory epithelium and vomeronasal organ.
23410787.pub_abstract: The olfactory and vomeronasal systems are the two nasal chemical detectors in mammals. While glial cells in the olfactory nerve tracts have been well-investigated, little is known about cells in the vomeronasal nerve tracts. In the present study, we compared the expression patterns of marker proteins in the cells comprising the two nasal nerve tracts in Species. Neural crest-derived cells surrounded the olfactory nerve axons in the lamina propria of the olfactory epithelium. These cells expressed Gene (Gene) and Gene glycoprotein, which are markers of olfactory ensheathing cells. Neural crest-derived cells also surrounded the vomeronasal nerve axons in the lamina propria of the vomeronasal epithelium. These nerve axon-surrounding cells, however, did not express Gene or Gene. Rather, the vomeronasal nerve axons expressed Gene and Gene. These results suggest that axon-surrounding cells functionally differ between the olfactory and vomeronasal nerve tracts.

27626377.pub_title: Broad histone Chemical domains in Species oocytes modulate maternal-to-zygotic transition.
27626377.pub_abstract: Maternal-to-zygotic transition (MZT) is essential for the formation of a new individual, but is still poorly understood despite recent progress in analysis of gene expression and DNA methylation in early embryogenesis. Dynamic histone modifications may have important roles in MZT, but direct measurements of chromatin states have been hindered by technical difficulties in profiling histone modifications from small quantities of cells. Recent improvements allow for 500 cell-equivalents of chromatin per reaction, but require 10,000 cells for initial steps or require a highly specialized microfluidics device that is not readily available. We developed a micro-scale chromatin immunoprecipitation and sequencing (muChIP-seq) method, which we used to profile genome-wide histone H3 Chemical methylation (Chemical) and acetylation (H3K27ac) in Species immature and metaphase II oocytes and in 2-cell and 8-cell embryos. Notably, we show that ~22% of the oocyte genome is associated with broad Chemical domains that are anti-correlated with DNA methylation. The Chemical signal becomes confined to transcriptional-start-site regions in 2-cell embryos, concomitant with the onset of major zygotic genome activation. Active removal of broad Chemical domains by the Chemical demethylases Gene and Gene is required for normal zygotic genome activation and is essential for early embryo development. Our results provide insight into the onset of the developmental program in Species embryos and demonstrate a role for broad Chemical domains in MZT.

24269955.pub_title: Gene regulates blood vascular development by modulating Gene activity.
24269955.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a potent pro-lymphangiogenic molecule during Disease growth and is considered a key therapeutic target to modulate metastasis. Despite roles in pathological neo-lymphangiogenesis, the characterization of an endogenous role for Gene in vascular development has remained elusive. Here, we used Species to assay for genetic interactions between the Gene/Gene-receptor pathway and SoxF transcription factors and identified a specific interaction between Gene and Gene. Double knockdown Species embryos for Gene/Gene and Gene/Gene exhibit defects in Disease differentiation. Supporting this observation, we found that Gene/Gene double but not single knockout Species displayed dramatic vascular development defects. We find that Gene-mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase-extracellular signal-regulated kinase signaling modulates Gene-mediated transcription, functioning at least in part by enhancing nuclear concentration and transcriptional activity in vascular endothelial cells. This work suggests that Gene-mediated pathologies include or involve an underlying dysregulation of SOXF-mediated transcriptional networks.

22230615.pub_title: Segmental territories along the cardinal veins generate lymph sacs via a ballooning mechanism during Disease in Species.
22230615.pub_abstract: During lymphangiogenesis in the Species embryo, a subset of vascular endothelial cells in the cardinal veins is reprogrammed to adopt a lymphatic endothelial fate. The prevailing model of lymphangiogenesis contends that these lymphatic precursor cells migrate away from the cardinal veins and reassemble peripherally as lymph sacs from which a lymphatic vasculature is generated. However, this model fails to account for a number of observations that, as a result, have remained anecdotal. Here, we use optical projection tomography, confocal microscopy and in vivo live imaging to uncover three key stages of lymphatic vascular morphogenesis in the Species embryo at high resolution. First, we define territories or "pre-lymphatic clusters" of Gene-positive lymphatic endothelial progenitor cells along the antero-posterior axis of the cardinal veins. Second, these pre-lymphatic clusters undergo progressive extrusion ("ballooning") to generate primitive lymph sacs. Third, lymphatic vessels emerge by a combination of mechanisms including sprouting from the lymph sacs and direct delamination of streams of cells from the cardinal veins. Our data support a new model for lymphatic vascular patterning and morphogenesis, as a basis for identifying the molecular cues governing these processes.

24009529.pub_title: Cauli: a Species strain with an Gene mutation that results in a Disease.
24009529.pub_abstract: Cilia are architecturally complex organelles that protrude from the cell membrane and have signalling, sensory and motility functions that are central to normal tissue development and homeostasis. There are two broad categories of cilia; motile and non-motile, or primary, cilia. The central role of primary cilia in health and disease has become prominent in the past decade with the recognition of a number of Species syndromes that result from defects in the formation or function of primary cilia. This rapidly growing class of conditions, now known as ciliopathies, impact the development of a diverse range of tissues including the neural axis, craniofacial structures, skeleton, kidneys, eyes and lungs. The broad impact of Disease on development reflects the pivotal position of the primary cilia within a signalling nexus involving a growing number of growth factor systems including Hedgehog, Pdgf, Fgf, Hippo, Notch and both canonical Wnt and planar cell polarity. We have identified a novel ENU mutant allele of Gene, which causes a mid-gestation embryonic lethal phenotype in homozygous mutant Species. Mutant embryos exhibit a range of phenotypes including Disease and Disease, Disease, Disease, Disease and somite patterning defects. A number of these phenotypes can be attributed to alterations in Hedgehog signalling, although additional signalling systems are also likely to be involved. We also report the identification of a homozygous recessive mutation in Gene in a Disease Species. This ENU-induced Disease model will be useful in delineating the origins of dysmorphology in Species ciliopathies.

22865833.pub_title: Loss of function mutation in Gene, chaperone of 7SK ncRNA, causes a syndrome of Disease, Disease, and primordial dwarfism.
22865833.pub_abstract: Primordial dwarfism (Disease) is a clinically and genetically heterogeneous condition. Various molecular mechanisms are known to underlie the disease including impaired mitotic mechanics, abnormal Gene expression, perturbed DNA damage response, defective spliceosomal machinery, and abnormal replication licensing. Here, we describe a syndromic form of Disease associated with severe Disease and distinct facial features in a large multiplex Saudi family. Analysis reveals a novel underlying mechanism for Disease involving depletion of 7SK, an abundant cellular noncoding RNA (ncRNA), due to mutation of its chaperone Gene. We show that 7SK levels are tightly linked to Gene expression across cell lines, and that this chaperone is ubiquitously expressed in the Species embryo. The 7SK is known to influence the expression of a wide array of genes through its inhibitory effect on the positive transcription elongation factor b (P-TEFb) as well as its competing role in Gene-mediated transcriptional regulation. This study documents a critical role played by ncRNA in Species development and adds to the growing list of molecular mechanisms that, when perturbed, converge on the Disease phenotype.

27538477.pub_title: Gene Marked Cardiac Progenitor Cells Repair Infarcted Species Hearts.
27538477.pub_abstract: Gene directs multipotential cardiovascular cell fates, even though it's transiently induced prior to the appearance of the cardiac progenitor program. Tracing Gene-expressing cells and their progeny allows isolation and characterization of the earliest cardiovascular progenitor cells. Studying the biology of Gene-CPCs in cell culture and Disease models is an important initial step toward using them for Disease treatment. Because of Gene's transitory nature, Gene-CPC lineages were traced by following EYFP expression in Species Gene(Cre/+); Rosa26(EYFP/+) ES cells. We captured EYFP+ cells that strongly expressed cardiac mesoderm markers and Disease, but not pluripotent or nascent mesoderm markers. Gene treatment led to the expansion of EYFP+ cells, while Gene and Activin were marginally effective. Gene exposure readily led EYFP+ cells to endothelial and smooth muscle cells, but inhibition of the canonical Gene signaling was required to enter the cardiomyocyte fate. Injected Species pre-contractile Gene-EYFP+ CPCs improved the survivability of injured Species and restored the functional performance of Disease hearts for at least 3 months. Gene-EYFP+ cells are bona fide CPCs and they integrated well in Disease hearts and emerged de novo into terminally differentiated cardiac myocytes, smooth muscle and vascular endothelial cells.

24257626.pub_title: Stem cell factor Gene and its close relative Gene have differentiation functions in oligodendrocytes.
24257626.pub_abstract: Neural precursor cells of the ventricular zone give rise to all neurons and glia of the central nervous system and rely for maintenance of their precursor characteristics on the closely related SoxB1 transcription factors Gene, Gene and Gene. We show in Species spinal cord that, whereas SoxB1 proteins are usually downregulated upon neuronal specification, they continue to be expressed in glial precursors. In the oligodendrocyte lineage, Gene and Gene remain present into the early phases of terminal differentiation. Surprisingly, their deletion does not alter precursor characteristics but interferes with proper differentiation. Although a direct influence on myelin gene expression may be part of their function, we provide evidence for another mode of action. SoxB1 proteins promote oligodendrocyte differentiation in part by negatively controlling Gene and thereby preventing this microRNA from inhibiting several pro-differentiation factors. This study presents one of the few cases in which SoxB1 proteins, including the stem cell factor Gene, are associated with differentiation rather than precursor functions.

22649246.pub_title: Gene regulates neural progenitor proliferation and cortical size through Gene-dependent Gene phosphorylation.
22649246.pub_abstract: Cytoskeleton-associated proteins play key roles not only in regulating cell morphology and migration but also in proliferation. Mutations in the cytoskeleton-associated gene Gene (Gene) cause the Species Disease (PH). PH is a disorder of neural stem cell development that is characterized by disruption of progenitors along the ventricular epithelium and subsequent formation of Chemical neuronal nodules. Gene-dependent regulation of cytoskeletal dynamics is thought to direct neural progenitor migration and proliferation. Here we show that embryonic Gene-null Species exhibited a reduction in brain size and decline in neural progenitor numbers over time. The drop in the progenitor population was not attributable to cell Disease or changes in premature differentiation, but to prolonged cell cycle duration. Suppression of Gene led to prolongation of the entire cell cycle length, principally in M phase. Disease of Gene-related proteins, thereby delaying the onset and progression through mitosis. We found that the Gene kinase Gene bound Gene, demonstrated increased expression levels after loss of Gene function, and was associated with increased phosphorylation of Gene. Phosphorylation of Gene inhibited activation of the anaphase promoting complex degradation system, which was responsible for Gene degradation and progression through mitosis. Collectively, our results demonstrate a molecular mechanism whereby Disease G2 to M phase entry, leading to cell cycle prolongation, compromised neural progenitor proliferation, and reduced brain size.

22771245.pub_title: The Species Wnt/PCP protein Gene is necessary for migration of Disease neurons, and functions independently of Gene.
22771245.pub_abstract: During development, Disease (FBM) neurons, which innervate muscles in the vertebrate head, migrate caudally and radially within the brainstem to form a motor nucleus at the pial surface. Several components of the Wnt/planar cell polarity (PCP) pathway, including the transmembrane protein Gene, regulate caudal migration of FBM neurons in Species, but their roles in neuronal migration in Species have not been investigated in detail. Therefore, we analyzed FBM neuron migration in Species looptail (Lp) mutants, in which Gene is inactivated. In Gene(Lp/+) and Gene) embryos, FBM neurons failed to migrate caudally from rhombomere (r) 4 into r6. Although caudal migration was largely blocked, many FBM neurons underwent normal radial migration to the pial surface of the neural tube. In addition, hindbrain patterning and FBM progenitor specification were intact, and FBM neurons did not transfate into other non-migratory neuron types, indicating a specific effect on caudal migration. Since loss-of-function in some Species Wnt/PCP genes does not affect caudal migration of FBM neurons, we tested whether this was also the case in Species. Embryos null for Gene, a regulator of PCP signaling, had severe defects in caudal migration of FBM neurons. However, FBM neurons migrated normally in Gene/2 double mutants, and in Species embryos with disrupted Gene signaling, suggesting that Gene function is essentially dispensable for FBM neuron caudal migration. Consistent with this, loss of Gene function in Gene(Lp/+) embryos did not exacerbate the Gene(Lp/+) neuronal migration phenotype. These data indicate that caudal migration of FBM neurons is regulated by multiple components of the Wnt/PCP pathway, but, importantly, may not require Gene function. Interestingly, genetic-interaction experiments suggest that rostral FBM neuron migration, which is normally suppressed, depends upon Gene function.

26549461.pub_title: DeepCAGE Transcriptomics Reveal an Important Role of the Transcription Factor Gene in the Lymphatic Endothelium.
26549461.pub_abstract: Gene/Gene signaling plays a central role in lymphatic development, regulating the budding of lymphatic progenitor cells from embryonic veins and maintaining the expression of Gene during later developmental stages. However, how Gene activation translates into target gene expression is still not completely understood. We used cap analysis of gene expression (Gene) RNA sequencing to characterize the transcriptional changes invoked by Gene in LECs and to identify the transcription factors (TFs) involved. We found that Gene, a TF involved in differentiation of various cell types, is rapidly induced and activated by Gene. Gene induced expression of Gene as well as other TFs and markers of differentiated LECs, indicating a role in the maintenance of the mature LEC phenotype. Correspondingly, E14.5 Gene(-/-) embryos showed impaired lymphatic patterning in the skin. This suggests that Gene is an important TF involved in lymphangiogenesis.

26054056.pub_title: Three-Dimensional Visualization of Developing Neurovascular Architecture in the Craniofacial Region of Embryonic Species.
26054056.pub_abstract: Recent studies have highlighted the mechanism of vascular and axonal guidance to ensure proper morphogenesis and organogenesis. We aimed to perform global mapping of developing Disease during craniofacial development of embryonic Species. To this end, we developed histology-based three-dimensional (3D) reconstructions using Chemical-embedded serial sections obtained from Species embryos. All serial sections were dual-immunolabeled with Gene and Gene/Gene cocktail antibodies. All immunolabeled serial sections were digitized with virtual microscopy to acquire high spatial resolution images. The 3D reconstructs warranted superior positional accuracy to trace the long-range connectivity of blood vessels and individual cranial nerve axons. It was feasible to depict simultaneously the details of angiogenic sprouting and axon terminal arborization and to assess quantitatively the locoregional proximity between blood vessels and cranial nerve axons. Notably, 3D views of the craniofacial region revealed the following: Branchial arch arteries and blood capillary plexi were formed without accompanying nerves at embryonic day (E) 9.5. Cranial nerve axons began to grow into the branchial arches, developing a labyrinth of small blood vessels at E10.5. Vascular remodeling occurred, and axon terminals of the maxillary, mandibular, Disease, and hypoglossal nerve axons had arborized around the lateral lingual swellings at E11.5. The diverged patterning of trigeminal nerves and the arterial branches from the carotid artery became congruent at E11.5. The overall results support the advantage of dual-immunolabeling and 3D reconstruction technology to document the architecture and wiring of the developing Disease in Species embryos.

27052174.pub_title: Gene Inhibits Osteoblast Differentiation, Bone Formation, and Disease through Chemical 148.
27052174.pub_abstract: The E3 ubiquitin ligase Gene targets the master regulator of osteoblast differentiation, Gene, for degradation, yet the function of Gene, if any, during osteoblast differentiation in vivo is ill defined. Here, we show that Gene prevents osteoblast differentiation by decreasing Gene accumulation in osteoblasts. Remarkably, Species harboring a substitution mutation at Chemical 148 (S148) in Gene that prevents its phosphorylation by AMPK (Gene(ki/ki)) display a premature osteoblast differentiation phenotype that is equally severe as that of Gene(-/-) Species, as well as a high bone mass, and are also Disease. Consistent with the fact that Gene targets the Gene for degradation, there is, in Gene(ki/ki) Species, an increase in insulin signaling in osteoblasts that triggers a rise in the circulating levels of Gene, a hormone that favors insulin secretion. These results identify Gene as a determinant of osteoblast differentiation during the development of bone formation and Chemical homeostasis post-natally and demonstrate the necessity of S148 for these functions.

24218621.pub_title: Establishment of smooth muscle and cartilage juxtaposition in the developing Species upper airways.
24218621.pub_abstract: In the trachea and bronchi of the Species, airway smooth muscle (SM) and cartilage are localized to complementary domains surrounding the airway epithelium. Proper juxtaposition of these tissues ensures a balance of elasticity and Disease that is critical for effective air passage. It is unknown how this tissue complementation is established during development. Here we dissect the developmental relationship between these tissues by genetically disrupting SM formation (through Gene inactivation) or cartilage formation (through Gene inactivation) and assessing the impact on the remaining lineage. We found that, in the trachea and main bronchi, loss of SM or cartilage resulted in an increase in cell number of the remaining lineage, namely the cartilage or SM, respectively. However, only in the main bronchi, but not in the trachea, did the loss of SM or cartilage lead to a circumferential expansion of the remaining cartilage or SM domain, respectively. In addition to SM defects, Disease displayed epithelial phenotypes, including decreased basal cell number, precocious club cell differentiation, and increased secretoglobin expression. These findings together delineate the mechanisms through which a cell-autonomous disruption of one structural tissue can have widespread consequences on upper airway function.

25292199.pub_title: Co-ordinated brain and craniofacial development depend upon Gene/Gene regulation of cell survival.
25292199.pub_abstract: Congenital brain and Disease often occur together as a consequence of their developmental dependency on common progenitor tissue interactions and signaling pathways during embryogenesis. A classic example of this is perturbation of midline embryo development, and disruption of Hedgehog (Hh) signaling in the pathogenesis of Disease. However, our understanding of how Hh signaling governs cell and tissue survival remains incomplete. Gene (Gene) is a well-known receptor for Hh ligands and Gene overexpression is associated with cell and tissue-specific apoptosis. Here, we demonstrate that the Gene (Gene) associates with the C terminus of Gene (Gene) in primary cilia to inhibit Gene-mediated cell death. Consistent with this observation, inhibition of Gene suppresses cell proliferation, resulting in cell death and pathogenesis of an Hh loss-of-function phenotype. Thus, co-ordinated development of the brain and face is dependent in part upon Gene mediation of Hh/Gene-regulated cell survival and apoptosis during embryogenesis.

27633995.pub_title: Tissue-specific roles for sonic hedgehog signaling in establishing thymus and parathyroid organ fate.
27633995.pub_abstract: The thymus and Disease develop from third pharyngeal pouch (3rd pp) endoderm. Our previous studies show that Gene null Species have smaller, Disease in which thymus fate specification extends into the pharynx. Gene signaling is active in both dorsal pouch endoderm and neighboring neural crest (NC) mesenchyme. It is unclear which target tissue of Gene signaling is required for the patterning defects in Gene mutants. Here, we used a genetic approach to ectopically activate or delete the Gene signal transducer Gene in either pp endoderm or NC mesenchyme. Although no manipulation recapitulated the Gene null phenotype, manipulation of Gene signaling in either the endoderm or NC mesenchyme had direct and indirect effects on both cell types during fate specification and organogenesis. Gene pathway activation throughout pouch endoderm activated ectopic Gene expression and partially suppressed the thymus-specific transcription factor Gene, identifying Gene as a key target of Gene signaling in the 3rd pp. However, ectopic Gene signaling was insufficient to expand the GCM2-positive parathyroid domain, indicating that multiple inputs, some of which might be independent of Gene signaling, are required for parathyroid fate specification. These data support a model in which Gene signaling plays both positive and negative roles in patterning and organogenesis of the thymus and Disease.

23227180.pub_title: The Onecut transcription factor Gene regulates in motor neurons the formation of the neuromuscular junctions.
23227180.pub_abstract: The neuromuscular junctions are the specialized synapses whereby spinal motor neurons control the contraction of skeletal muscles. The formation of the neuromuscular junctions is controlled by a complex interplay of multiple mechanisms coordinately activated in motor nerve terminals and in their target myotubes. However, the transcriptional regulators that control in motor neurons the genetic programs involved in neuromuscular junction development remain unknown. Here, we provide evidence that the Onecut transcription factor Gene regulates in motor neurons the formation of the neuromuscular junctions. Indeed, adult Gene mutant Species exhibit hindlimb Disease and Disease. This results from defects of hindlimb neuromuscular junctions characterized by an abnormal morphology and defective localization of the synaptic vesicle protein Chemical at the motor nerve terminals. These defects are consequences of altered and delayed formation of the neuromuscular junctions in newborn mutant animals. Furthermore, we show that the expression level of numerous regulators of neuromuscular junction formation, namely Gene, Gene and TGF-ss receptor II, is downregulated in the spinal motor neurons of Gene mutant newborn animals. Finally, altered formation of neuromuscular junction-like structures in a co-culture model of wildtype myotubes with mutant embryonic spinal cord slices is rescued by recombinant Gene and neuregulin, indicating that depletion in these factors contributes to defective neuromuscular junction development in the absence of Gene. Thus, Gene controls in spinal motor neurons a genetic program that coordinates the formation of hindlimb neuromuscular junctions.

26371508.pub_title: The splicing regulators Gene and Gene direct an epithelial splicing program essential for Species development.
26371508.pub_abstract: Tissue- and cell-type-specific regulators of alternative splicing (AS) are essential components of posttranscriptional gene regulation, necessary for normal cellular function, patterning, and development. Species with ablation of Epithelial splicing regulatory protein (Gene) develop Disease. Loss of both Gene and its paralog Gene results in widespread Disease with broad implications to Species disease. Deletion of the Esrps in the epidermis revealed their requirement for establishing a proper skin barrier, a primary function of epithelial cells comprising the epidermis. We profiled the global Esrp-mediated splicing regulatory program in epidermis, which revealed large-scale programs of epithelial cell-type-specific splicing required for epithelial cell functions. These Species represent a valuable model for evaluating the essential role for AS in development and function of epithelial cells, which play essential roles in tissue homeostasis in numerous organs, and provide a genetic tool to evaluate important functional properties of epithelial-specific splice variants in vivo.

24784881.pub_title: Loss of function mutation in the Chemical-transferase Gene leads to Disease of sex development by impeding Hedgehog protein palmitoylation and signaling.
24784881.pub_abstract: The Hedgehog (Hh) family of secreted proteins act as morphogens to control embryonic patterning and development in a variety of organ systems. Post-translational covalent attachment of Chemical and Chemical to Hh proteins are critical for multimerization and long range signaling potency. However, the biological impact of lipid modifications on Hh ligand distribution and signal reception in Species remains unclear. In the present study, we report a unique case of Disease of Sex Development (DSD) with Disease resulting from a homozygous Protein Mutation missense mutation in the Gene (Gene) gene. This mutation occurred in the conserved membrane bound O-acyltransferase (MBOAT) domain and experimentally disrupted the ability of Gene to Chemical Hh proteins such as Gene and Gene. Consistent with the Species phenotype, Gene was found to be expressed in the somatic cells of both XX and XY gonads at the time of sex determination, and Gene loss of function in Species recapitulates most of the testicular, skeletal, neuronal and growth defects observed in Species. In the developing testis, Gene is not required for Sertoli cell commitment but plays a role in proper testis cord formation and the differentiation of fetal Leydig cells. Altogether, these results shed new light on the mechanisms of action of Hh proteins. Furthermore, they provide the first clinical evidence of the essential role played by lipid modification of Hh proteins in Species testicular organogenesis and embryonic development.

26258622.pub_title: Gene Coactivator Gene Is Required for the Function of Sertoli Cells in Spermatogenesis.
26258622.pub_abstract: Defects in spermatogenesis, a process that produces spermatozoa inside seminiferous tubules of the testis, result in Disease. Spermatogenic progression is highly dependent on a microenvironment provided by Sertoli cells, the only somatic cells and epithelium of seminiferous tubules. However, genes that regulate such an important activity of Sertoli cells are poorly understood. Here, we found that Gene (Gene), is essential for the function of Sertoli cells to regulate spermatogenesis. Specifically, we generated Sertoli cell-specific Gene knockout (Arid4bSCKO) Species, and showed that the Arid4bSCKO male Species were completely Disease with Disease and significantly reduced testis size. Importantly, severe structural defects accompanied by loss of germ cells and Sertoli cell-only phenotype were found in many seminiferous tubules of the Arid4bSCKO testes. In addition, maturation of Sertoli cells was significantly delayed in the Arid4bSCKO Species, associated with delayed onset of spermatogenesis. Spermatogenic progression was also defective, showing an arrest at the round spermatid stage in the Arid4bSCKO testes. Interestingly, we showed that Gene functions as a "coactivator" of Gene and is required for optimal transcriptional activation of Gene, an Gene target gene specifically expressed in Sertoli cells and critical for spermatogenesis. Together, our study identified Gene to be a key regulator of Sertoli cell function important for male germ cell development.

21898763.pub_title: A novel TaulacZ allele reveals a requirement for Gene in formation of the mammillothalamic tract.
21898763.pub_abstract: The Disease mammillary region is critical for spatial memory and vestibular processing. Gene encodes a paired-like transcription factor that is highly expressed in the developing mammillary region and is required for subthalamic nucleus formation. Here we analyzed a loss of function Gene-TaulacZ knock-in allele to study the effects of Gene deficiency on neuronal projections in the embryonic mammillary region. Gene-expressing neurons contribute axons to principal mammillary, mammillotegmental and mammillotectal tracts. Embryos with Gene Disease in the principal mammillary tract that are improperly bundled and disorganized, yet project caudally toward the tectum and tegmentum. Embryos with Nestin-Cre mediated conditional Gene deficiency exhibit truncated mammillothalamic tracts (mtt) that fail to elongate, and reduced Gene-positive cells at the branching point of the principal mammillary and mtt. These data suggest that Gene mediates cell-autonomous and nonautonomous guidance cues necessary for mammillary collaterals destined to project to the anterior thalamus.

26637354.pub_title: Severe Disease Are Caused in Species Lacking Gene (Gene) in the Central Nervous System.
26637354.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is involved in cell proliferation, DNA damage response, and transcriptional regulation. Although Gene is extensively expressed in the CNS at embryonic and perinatal stages, the physiological role of Gene has been poorly understood. Here, to investigate the primary function of Gene in the CNS, we generated CNS-specific Gene knock-out Species by the Cre-loxP system. These Species exhibited Disease with Disease, and most of them died within 2 weeks after birth. Brain histological analyses revealed prominent cell reduction in the white matter tracts of the mutant Species. Furthermore, ultrastructural analysis demonstrated that myelin sheath was almost completely ablated in the CNS of these animals. In agreement with Disease, we also observed that most major myelin proteins including Gene (Gene), Gene (Gene), and Gene (Gene) were dramatically decreased, although neuronal and astrocytic markers were preserved in the brain of CNS-specific Gene knock-out Species. These animals had a reduced number of Gene(+) oligodendrocyte lineage cells in the white matter. We found that expressions of transcription factors essential for oligodendrocyte specification and further maturation were significantly suppressed in the brain of the mutant Species. Our findings provide evidence that Gene is required for CNS development, especially for oligodendrocyte maturation processes.

24043783.pub_title: Gene complex regulates tight junctions and terminal differentiation to promote epidermal barrier formation.
24043783.pub_abstract: The epidermis provides an essential seal from the external environment and retains fluids within the body. To form an effective barrier, cells in the epidermis must form tight junctions and terminally differentiate into cornified envelopes. Here, we demonstrate that the branched actin nucleator, the actin-related protein (Gene/3 complex, is unexpectedly required for both these activities. Loss of the Gene subunit of the Gene/3 complex resulted in minimal changes in the morphogenesis and architecture of this stratified squamous epithelium, but resulted in profound defects in its physiology. Mutant embryos did not develop an effective barrier to the external environment and died within hours of birth. We discovered two underlying causes for these effects. First, Gene was essential for robust assembly and function of tight junctions, specialized cell-cell adhesions that restrict water loss in the epidermis. Second, there were defects in differentiation of the epidermis and the production of cornified envelopes, structures essential for barrier activity. Underlying this defect, we found that Gene was inappropriately active not only in the Gene mutant tissue, but also in cultured cells. Inhibition of Gene activity rescued the differentiation and barrier defects caused by loss of Gene. These results demonstrate previously unappreciated roles for the Gene/3 complex and highlight the functions of branched actin networks in a complex tissue.

22589535.pub_title: Tissue-specific and nutrient regulation of the branched-chain Chemical dehydrogenase phosphatase, protein phosphatase 2Cm (Gene).
22589535.pub_abstract: Branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) homeostasis is maintained through highly regulated catabolic activities where the rate-limiting step is catalyzed by branched-chain Chemical dehydrogenase (BCKD). Our previous study has identified a mitochondria-targeted protein phosphatase, Gene, as the BCKD phosphatase and thus serves as a key regulator for BCAA catabolism. In this report, we performed comprehensive Disease and biochemical studies of Gene regulation using both in vivo and in vitro systems. We show that Gene expression is highly enriched in brain, heart, liver, kidney, and diaphragm, but low in skeletal muscle. The Gene expression is regulated at the transcriptional level in response to nutrient status. Furthermore, we have established that Gene interacts with the BCKD E2 subunit and competes with the Gene in a substrate-dependent and mutually exclusive manner. These data suggest that BCAA homeostasis is at least in part contributed by nutrient-dependent Gene expression and interaction with the BCKD complex. Finally, a number of Species Gene single nucleotide polymorphic changes as identified in the public data base can produce either inactive or constitutive active mutant phosphatases, suggesting that putative Gene mutations may contribute to BCAA Disease in Species.

24886827.pub_title: Differential regulation of Gene proteins by Gene in the lung affects PDGF signaling and myofibroblast development.
24886827.pub_abstract: Species Hedgehog (Hh) signaling relies on three Gene transcription factors to mediate Hh responses. This process is controlled in part by a major negative regulator, Gene, through its effects on Gene protein level, distribution and activity. In this report, we showed that Gene regulates Gene protein levels by antagonizing Gene/Gene. Otherwise, Gene/Gene would induce Gene protein degradation. This is in contrast to inhibition of Spop-mediated degradation of Gene/3 by Gene. Thus, controlling protein levels of all three Gene genes by Gene is a conserved mechanism to modulate Hh responses albeit via distinct pathways. These findings in cell-based assays were further validated in vivo. In analyzing how Gene controls Gene proteins in different tissues, we discovered that loss of Gene in the lung exerts different effects on Hh target genes. Hh targets Gene/Gene are upregulated in Disease, consistent with Hh pathway activation. Surprisingly, protein levels of Hh target Gene are reduced. We also found that myofibroblasts are absent from many prospective alveoli of Disease. Myofibroblast development is dependent on PDGF signaling. Interestingly, analysis of the Gene promoter revealed a canonical Gene-binding site where Gene resides. These studies support a model in which loss of Gene contributes to compromised Gene activation and disrupts myofibroblast development in the lung. Our work illustrates the unappreciated complexity of Hh responses where distinct Hh targets could respond differently depending on the availability of Gene proteins that control their expression.

24598168.pub_title: Gene regulation of integrin endocytosis, but not Gene signaling, is crucial for developmental angiogenesis.
24598168.pub_abstract: Here we show that Gene (Gene) is essential for angiogenesis in vitro and in vivo. In cultured endothelial cells lacking Gene, Gene (Gene) signaling and receptor levels are augmented whereas cell migration and morphogenesis are impaired. Mechanistically, the loss of Gene increases focal adhesion size and the surface levels of multiple integrins and reduces the activation state of Gene. In vivo, the constitutive or inducible loss of Gene in endothelium impairs branching morphogenesis and promotes the accumulation of Gene at sites of failed angiogenic sprouting. Collectively, our data show that Gene uncouples Gene signaling from function and coordinates the endocytic turnover of integrins in a manner that is crucially important for angiogenesis in vitro and in vivo.

27194326.pub_title: Gene Is Essential for the Survival and Function of Differentiated Neurons in the Cortex That Control Complex Behaviors.
27194326.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: Apoptosis plays an essential role during brain development, yet the precise mechanism by which this pathway is regulated in the brain remains unknown. In particular, Species cells are known to express multiple anti-apoptotic Gene family proteins. However, the cells of the developing brain could also exist in a primed state in which the loss of a single anti-apoptotic Gene family protein is sufficient to trigger apoptosis. Here, we examined the critical role of Gene, an anti-apoptotic protein, during brain development. Using conditional knock-out Species in which Gene is deleted in neural progenitor cells (Gene(Gene-Cre)), we show that the loss of Gene is not sufficient to trigger apoptosis in these proliferating progenitors. In contrast, specific populations of postmitotic neurons derived from these progenitors, including upper layer cortical neurons and the Gene-Gene regions of the hippocampus, were acutely dependent on Gene. Consistent with this finding, deletion of Gene selectively in the postmitotic neurons in the brain (Gene(Gene-Cre)) also resulted in similar patterns of apoptosis. This Disease was a consequence of activation of the apoptotic pathway, because the cell death was rescued with codeletion of the proapoptotic proteins Gene and Gene. Importantly, the loss of these Gene-dependent neurons led to severe Disease, including Disease, Disease, and increased risk-taking and self-injurious behaviors. Together, our results identify a population of neurons in the developing brain that are acutely dependent on Gene during the peak period of synaptic connectivity that are important for the establishment of higher-order complex behaviors. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: Although Gene is known to inhibit apoptosis, exactly which cells in the brain are dependent on Gene has remained unclear because of the Disease of Species globally deleted for Gene. Here, we conditionally deleted Gene in the brain and found that this did not result in widespread apoptosis in the proliferating progenitors. Instead, Disease induced apoptosis in a select population of differentiated neurons predominantly in the early postnatal stages. Importantly, these Gene-dependent neurons are not essential for survival of the organism but instead regulate complex behaviors. Our results show that the selective loss of these Gene-dependent neurons results in Species exhibiting severe Disease, including self-injurious and risk-taking behaviors, Disease, and Disease.

22190642.pub_title: Gene determines the fate of postnatal intestinal endoderm.
22190642.pub_abstract: Knock out of intestinal Gene produces different effects depending upon the developmental stage at which this occurs. Early in development it produces histologically ordered stomach mucosa in the midgut. Conditional inactivation of Gene in adult intestinal epithelium, as well as specifically in the Gene-positive stem cells, of adult Species allows long-term survival of the animals but fails to produce this phenotype. Instead, the endodermal cells exhibit cell-autonomous expression of gastric genes in an intestinal setting that is not accompanied by mesodermal expression of Gene, which is necessary for gastric morphogenesis. Gene-negative endodermal cells also fail to express Gene, a marker of gastric morphogenesis. Maturation of the stem cell niche thus appears to be associated with loss of ability to express positional information cues that are required for normal stomach development. Gene-negative intestinal crypts produce subsurface cystic vesicles, whereas untargeted crypts Disease to later replace the surface epithelium. These observations are supported by studies involving inactivation of Gene in intestinal crypts cultured in vitro. This abolishes their ability to form long-term growing intestinal organoids that differentiate into intestinal phenotypes. We conclude that expression of Gene is essential for differentiation of gut stem cells into any of the intestinal cell types, but they maintain a degree of cell-autonomous plasticity that allows them to switch on a variety of gastric genes.

22993445.pub_title: A unilateral negative feedback loop between miR-200 microRNAs and Gene/Gene controls neural progenitor cell-cycle exit and differentiation.
22993445.pub_abstract: MicroRNAs have emerged as key posttranscriptional regulators of gene expression during vertebrate development. We show that the miR-200 family plays a crucial role for the proper generation and survival of ventral neuronal populations in the Species midbrain/hindbrain region, including midbrain dopaminergic neurons, by directly targeting the pluripotency factor Gene and the cell-cycle regulator Gene in neural stem/progenitor cells. The lack of a negative regulation of Gene and Gene by miR-200 in conditional Gene mutants (En1(+/Cre); Gene(flox/flox) Species) and after miR-200 knockdown in vitro leads to a strongly reduced cell-cycle exit and neuronal differentiation of ventral midbrain/hindbrain (vMH) neural progenitors, whereas the opposite effect is seen after miR-200 overexpression in primary vMH cells. Expression of miR-200 is in turn directly regulated by Gene and Gene, thereby establishing a unilateral negative feedback loop required for the cell-cycle exit and neuronal differentiation of neural stem/progenitor cells. Our findings suggest that the posttranscriptional regulation of Gene and Gene by miR-200 family members might be a general mechanism to control the transition from a pluripotent/multipotent stem/progenitor cell to a postmitotic and more differentiated cell.

25157170.pub_title: Temporally defined neocortical translation and polysome assembly are determined by the RNA-binding protein Gene.
25157170.pub_abstract: Precise spatiotemporal control of mRNA translation machinery is essential to the development of highly complex systems like the neocortex. However, spatiotemporal regulation of translation machinery in the developing neocortex remains poorly understood. Here, we show that an RNA-binding protein, Gene (Gene), regulates both neocorticogenesis and specificity of neocortical translation machinery in a developmental stage-dependent manner in Species. Neocortical absence of Gene alters the phosphorylation states of initiation and elongation factors in the core translation machinery. In addition, Gene regulates the temporally specific positioning of functionally related mRNAs into the active translation sites, the polysomes. Gene also determines the specificity of neocortical polysomes by defining their combinatorial composition of ribosomal proteins and initiation and elongation factors. For some Gene-dependent proteins, the association with polysomes likewise depends on the eukaryotic initiation factor 2 alpha kinase 4, which associates with Gene in prenatal developing neocortices. Finally, we found that deletion of Gene before embryonic day 10 disrupts both neocortical lamination and formation of the main neocortical commissure, the corpus callosum. Our study identifies a crucial role for Gene in neocortical development as a translational Species for functionally related mRNA subgroups and polysomal protein specificity.

23471215.pub_title: Conditional mutagenesis of Gene in Gene-positive cells causes gonadal-like differentiation in the adrenal cortex of Species.
23471215.pub_abstract: Transcription factor Gene is expressed in the fetal and adult adrenal cortex and has been implicated in steroidogenesis. To characterize the role of transcription factor Gene in adrenocortical development and function, we generated Species in which Gene was conditionally deleted using Cre-LoxP recombination with Gene-cre. The adrenal glands of adult Gene conditional knockout (cKO) Species were small and had a thin cortex. Cytomegalic changes were evident in fetal and adult cKO adrenal glands, and chromaffin cells were ectopically located at the periphery of the glands. Chemical secretion in response to exogenous ACTH was blunted in cKO Species. Spindle-shaped cells expressing Gene, a marker of gonadal stroma, accumulated in the adrenal subcapsule of Gene cKO Species. RNA analysis demonstrated the concomitant upregulation of other gonadal-like markers, including Gene, in the cKO adrenal glands, suggesting that Gene inhibits the spontaneous differentiation of adrenocortical stem/progenitor cells into gonadal-like cells. Gene and Gene were overexpressed in the adrenal glands of gonadectomized cKO vs control Species, implying that Gene also limits sex steroidogenic cell differentiation in response to the hormonal changes that accompany gonadectomy. Nulliparous female and orchiectomized male Gene cKO Species lacked an adrenal X-zone. Microarray hybridization identified Gene as a novel X-zone marker that is downregulated in the adrenal glands of these Species. Our findings offer genetic proof that Gene regulates the differentiation of steroidogenic progenitors into adrenocortical cells.

22493501.pub_title: Stretch-induced fetal type II cell differentiation is mediated via ErbB1-Gene interactions.
22493501.pub_abstract: Stretch-induced differentiation of lung fetal type II epithelial cells is mediated through Gene (ErbB1) via release of Gene and Gene ligands. Employing an Gene knock-out Species model, we further investigated the role of the Gene family of receptors in mechanotranduction during lung development. Deletion of Gene prevented endogenous and mechanical stretch-induced type II cell differentiation via the ERK pathway, which was rescued by overexpression of a constitutively active Gene. Interestingly, the expression of Gene, the only Gene receptor that Gene co-precipitates in wild-type cells, was decreased in Gene-deficient type II cells. Similar to Gene, Gene was activated by stretch and participated in ERK phosphorylation and type II cell differentiation. However, neuregulin (NRG) or stretch-induced Gene activation were blunted in Gene-deficient cells and not rescued after Gene overexpression, suggesting that induction of Gene phosphorylation is Gene-dependent. Finally, we addressed how shedding of ligands is regulated by Gene. In knock-out cells, Gene, a ligand for Gene, was not released by stretch, while Gene, a ligand for Gene and Gene, was shed by stretch although to a lower magnitude than in normal cells. Release of these ligands was inhibited by blocking Gene and ERK pathway. In conclusion, our studies show that Gene and Gene regulate stretch-induced type II cell differentiation via ERK pathway. Interactions between these two receptors are important for mechanical signals in lung fetal type II cells. These studies provide novel insights into the cell signaling mechanisms regulating Gene family receptors in lung cell differentiation.

22426104.pub_title: Mapping Species hemangioblast maturation from headfold stages.
22426104.pub_abstract: The Species posterior primitive streak at neural plate/headfold stages (NP/HF, ~7.5 dpc-8 dpc) represents an optimal window from which Disease can be isolated. We performed immunohistochemistry on this domain using established monoclonal antibodies for proteins that affect blood and endothelial fates. We demonstrate that Gene and Gene are the first set of markers that segregate independently to endothelial or blood populations during NP/HF stages of Species embryonic development. In a subset of cells, both proteins are co-expressed and immunoreactivities appear mutually excluded within nuclear spaces. We searched for this particular state at later sites of hematopoietic stem cell emergence, viz., the aorta-gonad-mesonephros (AGM) and the fetal liver at 10.5-11.5 dpc, and found that only a rare number of cells displayed this character. Based on this spatial-temporal argument, we propose that the earliest blood progenitors emerge either directly from the epiblast or through segregation within the allantoic core domain (Disease) through reduction of cell adhesion and pSmad1/5 nuclear signaling, followed by a stochastic decision toward a blood or endothelial fate that involves Gene and Gene, respectively. A third form in which binding distributions are balanced may represent a common condition shared by Disease and HSCs. We developed a heuristic model of hemangioblast maturation, in part, to be explicit about our assumptions.

21903164.pub_title: Gene heterozygosity impairs CNS neuronal morphology in a Chemical/PKA/ROCK-dependent manner.
21903164.pub_abstract: Species with the Disease predisposition syndrome exhibit numerous clinical problems that reflect defective central nervous system (CNS) neuronal function, including Disease, Disease, and Disease. These clinical features result from reduced Gene protein (Gene) expression in Gene+/- (Gene heterozygosity) brain neurons. Previous studies have shown that Species CNS neurons are sensitive to the effects of reduced Gene expression and exhibit shorter neurite lengths, smaller growth cone areas, and attenuated survival, reflecting attenuated Gene Chemical regulation. In striking contrast, Gene+/- peripheral nervous system (PNS) neurons are nearly indistinguishable from their wild-type counterparts, and complete Gene loss leads to increased neurite lengths and survival in a RAS/Gene-dependent fashion. To gain insights into the differential responses of CNS and PNS neurons to reduced Gene function, we designed a series of experiments to define the molecular mechanism(s) underlying the unique CNS neuronal sensitivity to Gene heterozygosity. First, Gene heterozygosity decreases Chemical levels in CNS, but not in PNS, neurons. Second, CNS neurons exhibit Gene gene-dependent increases in RAS pathway signaling, but no further decreases in Chemical levels were observed in Gene-/- CNS neurons relative to their Gene+/- counterparts. Third, Gene regulates CNS neurite length and growth cone areas in a Chemical/PKA/Rho/ROCK-dependent manner in vitro and in vivo. Collectively, these findings establish Chemical/PKA/Rho/ROCK signaling as the responsible axis underlying abnormal Gene+/- CNS neuronal morphology with important implications for future preclinical and clinical studies aimed at improving cognitive and Disease in Species and Species with reduced brain neuronal Gene gene expression.

25231763.pub_title: Gene and Gene elicit Hh signaling via Gene but do not aid Gene in sequestering the Hh ligand.
25231763.pub_abstract: Hedgehog (Hh) proteins are secreted molecules essential for tissue development in vertebrates and invertebrates. Hh reception via the 12-pass transmembrane protein Gene (Gene) elicits intracellular signaling through Gene (Gene). Hh binding to Gene is also proposed to sequester the ligand, limiting its spatial range of activity. In Disease, Gene (Gene) and Brother of Gene (Gene) are two conserved and redundant transmembrane proteins that are essential for Hh pathway activation. How Gene and Gene activate signaling in response to Hh remains unknown; each can bind both Hh and Gene and so it has been proposed that they are essential for both Hh reception and sequestration. Using genetic epistasis we established here that Gene and Gene, and their orthologs in Species, act upstream or at the level of Gene to allow Hh signal transduction. In the Disease developing wing model we found that it is through Hh pathway activation that Gene and Gene maintain the boundary between the anterior and posterior compartments. We dissociated the contributions of Gene from those of Gene/Gene and, surprisingly, found that cells expressing Gene can retain and sequester the Hh ligand without Gene and Gene, but that Gene and Gene cannot do so without Gene. Together, these results reinforce the central role for Gene in Hh binding in vivo and demonstrate that, although Gene and Gene are dispensable for Hh sequestration, they are essential for pathway activation because they allow Hh to inhibit Gene and thereby relieve its repression of Gene.

26094033.pub_title: A critical role of Gene in proliferation and differentiation of Disease progenitors.
26094033.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Nonsense mediated mRNA decay (Disease) is an RNA surveillance mechanism that controls RNA stability and ensures the speedy degradation of erroneous and unnecessary transcripts. This mechanism depends on several core factors in the exon junction complex (EJC), Gene, Gene, Gene, and Chemical, as well as peripheral factors to distinguish premature stop codons (PTCs) from normal stop codons in transcripts. Recently, emerging evidence has indicated that Disease factors are associated with Disease such as Disease (Disease) and Disease (ID). However, the mechanism in which these factors control embryonic brain development is not clear. RESULT: We found that Gene is critical for proliferation and differentiation in cortical neural progenitor cells (NPCs). Gene is highly expressed in the subventricular zone (SVZ) of the early Disease, suggesting that Gene may play a role in regulating NPCs. Gene overexpression stimulates Disease and suppresses neuronal differentiation. Conversely, knockdown of Gene in the neocortex reduces NPC proliferation and promotes premature neuronal differentiation. Moreover, overexpression of Gene suppresses cell cycle exit and keeps cortical NPCs in a proliferative state. To uncover the underlying mechanisms of this phenotype, genome-wide RNAseq was used to identify potential downstream genes of Gene in the brain, which have been implicated in Disease. Interestingly, Disease and Disease risk genes are highly represented in downstream transcripts of Gene. In addition, Gene regulates multiple alternative splicing genes and Disease targets that are implicated in Disease. Taken together, this data suggests a novel role of Gene in the regulation of neurodevelopment. CONCLUSIONS: Our studies provide some insight into causes of mental illnesses and will facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodevelopmental illnesses.

22955731.pub_title: Asymmetric fate of the posterior part of the second heart field results in unexpected left/right contributions to both poles of the heart.
22955731.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: The second heart field (SHF) contains progenitors of all heart chambers, excluding the left ventricle. The SHF is patterned, and the anterior region is known to be destined to form the outflow tract and right ventricle. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to map the fate of the posterior SHF (pSHF). METHODS AND RESULTS: We examined the contribution of pSHF cells, labeled by lipophilic dye at the 4- to 6-somite stage, to regions of the heart at 20 to 25 somites, using Species embryo culture. Cells more cranial in the pSHF contribute to the Disease (AVC) and Disease, whereas those more caudal generate the sinus venosus, but there is intermixing of fate throughout the pSHF. Caudal pSHF contributes symmetrically to the sinus venosus, but the fate of cranial pSHF is left/right asymmetrical. Left pSHF moves to dorsal left atrium and superior AVC, whereas right pSHF contributes to right atrium, ventral left atrium, and inferior AVC. Retrospective clonal analysis shows the relationships between AVC and Disease to be clonal and that right and left progenitors diverge before first and second heart lineage separation. Cranial pSHF cells also contribute to the outflow tract: proximal and distal at 4 somites, and distal only at 6 somites. All outflow tract-destined cells are intermingled with those that will contribute to inflow and AVC. CONCLUSIONS: These observations show asymmetric fate of the pSHF, resulting in unexpected left/right contributions to both poles of the heart and can be integrated into a model of the morphogenetic movement of cells during cardiac looping.

22426149.pub_title: Gene mediates effect of insulin on glucagon expression.
22426149.pub_abstract: Pancreatic islet alpha-cell development and glucagon production are mainly regulated by Gene in the homeobox gene families. However, the molecular mechanism fine-tuning the regulation of these events in alpha-cell still remains unclear. In ocular cells, Gene transcription is regulated by Gene through its binding to specific sites in Gene promoter. In this study, Gene-mediated regulations of islet alpha-cell development and glucagon production were investigated in both Gene Species and Chemical-1-6 cells. Over-expression of Gene in Species affected development of pancreatic islets by significantly suppressing alpha-cell population in both Disease and adult pancreases. The effect of Gene on Gene gene expression and subsequently, on pro-glucagon production was however, examined in pancreatic islet alpha-cells. Over-expression and knock-down of Gene directly affected Gene expression. More importantly, the Gene binding sites upstream from Gene p0 promoter were required for regulating p0 promoter activity in islet alpha-cells. Stimulation of alpha-cells with insulin resulted in a significant increase in Gene expression and a decrease in Gene expression, and consequently suppressed pro-glucagon expression. In contrast, these insulin-induced effects were blocked by knockdown of Gene mRNA with specific siRNA in alpha-cells. Altogether, our results demonstrated for the first time that Gene functions as a switch-like molecule between the insulin signaling and the regulations of Gene and glucagon expression in pancreatic islet alpha-cells.

25382142.pub_title: Species with Disease with cysts: a developmental angle.
25382142.pub_abstract: OBJECTIVE: Disease with cysts (Gene) is a Disease characterized by infantile onset Disease and delayed onset Disease. Loss of Gene function causes Gene. Gene is involved in ion-water homeostasis, but its exact role is unknown. We generated Gene-null Species for further studies. METHODS: We investigated which brain cell types express Gene, compared developmental expression in Species and Species, and studied the consequences of loss of Gene in Gene-null Species. RESULTS: Like Species, Species expressed Gene only in astrocytes, especially those facing fluid-brain barriers. In Species, Gene expression increased until 3 weeks and then stabilized. In Species, Gene expression was highest in the first year, decreased, and stabilized from approximately 5 years. Gene-null Species had early onset Disease and increased brain water content. From 3 weeks, abnormal astrocytes were present with swollen processes abutting fluid-brain barriers. From 3 months, widespread white matter vacuolization with Disease developed. Gene-null astrocytes showed slowed regulatory volume decrease and reduced volume-regulated anion currents, which increased upon Gene re-expression. Gene-null astrocytes showed reduced expression of adhesion molecule Gene and Chemical channel Gene, but no substantial changes in other known Gene-interacting proteins. INTERPRETATION: Gene-null Species replicate early stages of the Species disease with early onset Disease. The cellular functional defects, described for Species Gene, were confirmed. The earliest change was Disease, substantiating that in Gene the primary defect is in volume regulation by astrocytes. Gene expression affects expression of Gene and Gene. Abnormal interplay between these proteins is part of the pathomechanisms of Gene.

26859490.pub_title: Comprehensive Expression of Wnt Signaling Pathway Genes during Development and Maturation of the Species Cochlea.
26859490.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: In the inner ear Wnt signaling is necessary for proliferation, cell fate determination, growth of the cochlear duct, polarized orientation of stereociliary bundles, differentiation of the periotic mesenchyme, and homeostasis of the stria vascularis. In neonatal tissue Wnt signaling can drive proliferation of cells in the sensory region, suggesting that Wnt signaling could be used to regenerate the sensory epithelium in the damaged adult inner ear. Manipulation of Wnt signaling for regeneration will require an understanding of the dynamics of Wnt pathway gene expression in the ear. We present a comprehensive screen for 84 Wnt signaling related genes across four developmental and postnatal time points. RESULTS: We identified 72 Wnt related genes expressed in the inner ear on embryonic day (E) 12.5, postnatal day (P) 0, Gene. These genes included secreted Wnts, Wnt antagonists, intracellular components of canonical signaling and components of non-canonical signaling/planar cell polarity. CONCLUSION: A large number of Wnt signaling molecules were dynamically expressed during cochlear development and in the early postnatal period, suggesting complex regulation of Wnt transduction. The data revealed several potential key regulators for further study.

23584254.pub_title: Expression of the Gene receptor Gene in the second heart field is essential for development of the dorsal mesenchymal protrusion and Disease.
23584254.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: The dorsal mesenchymal protrusion (Chemical) is a prong of mesenchyme derived from the second heart field (SHF) located at the venous pole of the developing heart. Recent studies have shown that perturbation of its development is associated with the pathogenesis of Disease. Although the importance of the Chemical to AV septation is now established, the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying its development are far from fully understood. Prior studies have demonstrated that Gene (Gene) signaling is essential for proper formation of the AV endocardial cushions and the cardiac outflow tract. A role for Gene signaling in regulation of Chemical development remained to be elucidated. OBJECTIVE: To determine the role of Gene signaling in Chemical development. METHODS AND RESULTS: Conditional deletion of the Gene receptor Gene from venous pole SHF cells leads to impaired formation of the Chemical and a completely penetrant phenotype of ostium primum defect, a hallmark feature of Disease. Analysis of mutants revealed decreased proliferative index of SHF cells and, consequently, reduced number of SHF cells at the cardiac venous pole. In contrast, volume and expression of markers associated with proliferation and active Gene/Gene signaling were not significantly altered in the AV cushions of SHF-Gene mutants. CONCLUSIONS: Gene signaling is required for expansion of the SHF-derived Chemical progenitor population at the cardiac venous pole. Perturbation of Gene-mediated Gene signaling from the SHF results in impaired development of the Chemical and ostium primum defects.

27065194.pub_title: Gene is a meiotic cell cycle-coupled maternal-zygotic-transition licensing factor in oocytes.
27065194.pub_abstract: The mRNAs stored in oocytes undergo general decay during the maternal-zygotic transition (MZT), and their stability is tightly interconnected with meiotic cell-cycle progression. However, the factors that trigger decay of maternal mRNA and couple this event to oocyte meiotic maturation remain elusive. Here, we identified Gene (Gene) as an MZT licensing factor in Species. Gene bridged Gene, a catalytic subunit of the Gene-NOT deadenylase, to Gene, a key translation initiation factor, and facilitated decay of maternal mRNA. Gene-null females produced morphologically normal oocytes but were infertile, owing to early Disease. The intrinsic MAP kinase cascade in oocytes triggered translation of Gene mRNA stored in fully grown oocytes by targeting the 3' untranslated region, thereby coupling Gene-NOT deadenylase-mediated decay of maternal mRNA with oocyte maturation and fertilization. This is a key step in oocyte cytoplasmic maturation that determines the developmental potential of Species embryos.

23132246.pub_title: A dual function for canonical Wnt/Gene signaling in the developing Species cochlea.
23132246.pub_abstract: The canonical Wnt/Gene signaling pathway is known to play crucial roles in organogenesis by regulating both proliferation and differentiation. In the inner ear, this pathway has been shown to regulate the size of the otic placode from which the cochlea will arise; however, direct activity of canonical Wnt signaling as well as its function during cochlear mechanosensory hair cell development had yet to be identified. Using TCF/Lef:H2B-GFP reporter Species and transfection of an independent TCF/Lef reporter construct, we describe the pattern of canonical Wnt activity in the developing Species cochlea. We show that prior to terminal mitosis, canonical Wnt activity is high in early prosensory cells from which hair cells and support cells will differentiate, and activity becomes reduced as development progresses. Using an in vitro model we demonstrate that Wnt/Gene signaling regulates both proliferation and hair cell differentiation within the developing cochlear duct. Inhibition of Wnt/Gene signaling blocks proliferation during early mitotic phases of development and inhibits hair cell formation in the differentiating organ of Corti. Conversely, activation increases the number of hair cells that differentiate and induces proliferation in prosensory cells, causing an expansion of the Gene-positive prosensory domain. We further demonstrate that the induced proliferation of Gene-positive cells may be mediated by the cell cycle regulator Gene. Lastly, we provide evidence that the mitotic Gene-positive cells are competent to differentiate into hair cells. Combined, our data suggest that Wnt/Gene signaling has a dual function in cochlear development, regulating both proliferation and hair cell differentiation.

22411169.pub_title: Airway epithelial cell differentiation during lung organogenesis requires Gene and Gene.
22411169.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein (Gene is crucial for lung development and differentiation of the pulmonary epithelium. Conversely, no Disease have been observed in Gene-deficient Species, although Gene trans-activate pulmonary genes by binding to virtually identical DNA-sequences as Gene. Thus, the pulmonary phenotype of Species lacking Gene could be explained by functional replacement with Gene. We investigated whether Gene and Gene have overlapping functions in regulating lung epithelial differentiation during organogenesis. Epithelial differentiation was assessed in Species with a lung epithelial-specific (Gene-Cre-mediated) deletion of Gene (Gene ), Gene (Gene ), or both genes (Gene(DeltaLE) ; Gene ). RESULTS: Both Gene(DeltaLE) Species and Gene(DeltaLE) ; Gene Species demonstrated severe Disease compared to wild-type littermates, while no differences in lung histology or epithelial differentiation were observed in Gene Species. In contrast to Gene(DeltaLE) Species, Gene(DeltaLE) ; Gene Species also displayed undifferentiated Clara cells with markedly impaired protein and mRNA expression of Gene (Gene), compared to wild-type littermates. In addition, ectopic mucus-producing cells were observed in the conducting airways of Gene(DeltaLE) ; Gene Species. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings demonstrate that Gene and Gene play pivotal, and partly overlapping roles in determining airway epithelial differentiation, with possible implications for tissue regeneration in Disease.

25535838.pub_title: Transient inhibition of the Gene pathway prevents Disease and improves long-term motor functions in Species models of Gene.
25535838.pub_abstract: Individuals with Gene (Gene) frequently exhibit Disease and characteristics of Disease. The cerebellum plays a critical role in motor control, cognition, and social interaction, suggesting that Disease likely contribute to Gene-associated Disease. Here we show that Gene inactivation during early, but not late stages of cerebellar development, disrupts neuronal lamination, which is partially caused by overproduction of glia and subsequent disruption of the Bergmann glia (BG) scaffold. Specific Gene inactivation in glutamatergic neuronal precursors causes premature differentiation of granule cell (GC) precursors and ectopic production of unipolar brush cells (UBCs), indirectly disrupting neuronal migration. Transient Gene inhibition during a neonatal window prevents Disease and improves long-term motor performance of Gene-deficient Species. This study reveals essential roles of Gene in GC/Gene migration by generating correct numbers of glia and controlling GC/Gene fate-specification/differentiation, identifying a therapeutic prevention strategy for multiple Gene-associcated Disease.

26984772.pub_title: Mesodermal Gene controls lung myofibroblast versus lipofibroblast cell fate.
26984772.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Epithelial-mesenchymal cross talk is centerpiece in the development of many branched organs, including the lungs. The Disease mesoderm provides instructional information not only for lung architectural development, but also for patterning, commitment and differentiation of its many highly specialized cell types. The mesoderm also serves as a reservoir of progenitors for generation of differentiated mesenchymal cell types that include alphaSMA-expressing fibroblasts, lipofibroblasts, endothelial cells and others. Gene (Gene) is a key signaling pathway in epithelial-mesenchymal cross talk. Using a cre-loxP approach we have elucidated the role of the Gene type I receptor Chemical kinase, Gene, in epithelial-mesenchymal cross talk during lung morphogenesis. RESULTS: Targeted early inactivation of Gene in mesodermal progenitors caused abnormal development and maturation of the lung that included reduced physical size of the sub-mesothelial mesoderm, an established source of specific mesodermal progenitors. Abrogation of mesodermal Gene-mediated signaling also inhibited differentiation of cell populations in the epithelial and endothelial lineages. Importantly, Gene mutant lungs contained a reduced number of alphaSMA(pos) cells and correspondingly increased lipofibroblasts. Elucidation of the underlying mechanisms revealed that through direct and indirect modulation of target signaling pathways and transcription factors, including Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene, Gene-mediated Gene controls a process that regulates the commitment and differentiation of alphaSMA(pos) versus lipofibroblast cell populations during lung development. CONCLUSION: Gene-mediated Gene signaling controls an early pathway that regulates the commitment and differentiation of alphaSMA(pos) versus LIF cell lineages during lung development.

25951169.pub_title: New mutation in the Species Gene/Gene gene leads to recessive Disease.
25951169.pub_abstract: Disease are the major Disease and have been associated mainly with mutations in lens-specific genes, but Disease are also frequently associated with complex syndromes.
