In a large-scale high-throughput ENU mutagenesis screen we analyzed the offspring of paternally treated C3HeB/FeJ Species for Disease. We identified a mutant suffering from rough coat and small eyes only in homozygotes; homozygous females turned out to be sterile. The mutation was mapped to chromosome 7 between the markers 116J6.1 and D7Mit294;4 other markers within this interval did not show any recombination among 160 F2-mutants. The critical interval (8.6 Mb) contains 3 candidate genes (Gene, Gene, Gene); none of them showed a mutation. Using exome sequencing, we identified a c.2209T>C mutation in the Gene/Gene gene leading to a Ser737Pro exchange. During embryonic development, the mutant eyes did not show major changes. Postnatal histological analyses demonstrated small cortical vacuoles; later, cortical Disease developed. Since Gene/Gene is involved in DNA repair, we checked also for the presence of the repair-associated histone Gene in the lens. During the time, when primary lens fiber cell nuclei are degraded, Gene was strongly expressed in the cell nuclei; later, it demarcates clearly the border of the lens cortex to the organelle-free zone. Moreover, we analyzed also whether seemingly healthy heterozygotes might be less efficient in repair of DNA damage induced by ionizing radiation than wild types. Peripheral lymphocytes irradiated by 1Gy Cs137 showed 6 hrs after irradiation significantly more Gene foci in heterozygotes than in wild types. These findings demonstrate the importance of Gene/Gene not only for lens fiber cell differentiation, but also for the sensitivity to ionizing radiation. Based upon these data, we hypothesize that variations in the Species Gene/Gene gene might increase the susceptibility for several disorders besides Disease in heterozygotes under particular environmental conditions.

25866077.pub_title: Chemical as an antigen for monoclonal antibody HIgM12 to treat multiple Disease and other Disease.
25866077.pub_abstract: CNS regeneration is a desirable goal for diseases of brain and spinal cord. Current therapeutic strategies for the treatment of Disease (MS) aim to eliminate detrimental effects of the immune system, so far without reversing Disease or affecting long-term prognosis in Species. Approachable molecular targets that stimulate CNS repair are not part of the clinical praxis or have not been identified yet. The purpose of this study was to identify the molecular target of the Species monoclonal antibody HIgM12. HIgM12 reverses motor deficits in Disease Species, a model of MS. Here, we identified Chemical (PSA) attached to the Gene (Gene) as the antigen for HIgM12 by using different Gene knockout strains and through PSA removal from the Gene protein core. Antibody binding to CNS tissue and primary cells, antibody-mediated cell adhesion, and neurite outgrowth on HIgM12-coated nitrocellulose was detected only in the presence of PSA as assessed by western blotting, immunoprecipitation, immunocytochemistry, and histochemistry. We conclude that HIgM12 mediates its in vivo and in vitro effects through binding to PSA and has the potential to be an effective therapy for MS and Disease. The Species antibody HIgM12 stimulates neurite outgrowth in vitro and promotes function in Disease Species, a model of Disease. The cellular antigen for HIgM12 was undetermined. Here, we identified Chemical attached to Gene (Gene) as the cellular target for HIgM12. This includes Gene (Gene)-positive Species astrocytes (Gene, red; HIgM12, green; DAPI, blue) among other cell types of the central nervous system. These findings indicate a new strategy for the treatment of Disease including Disease.

24939938.pub_title: Long noncoding RNAs are spatially correlated with transcription factors and regulate lung development.
24939938.pub_abstract: Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) are thought to play important roles in regulating gene transcription, but few have well-defined expression patterns or known biological functions during Species development. Using a conservative pipeline to identify lncRNAs that have important biological functions, we identified 363 lncRNAs in the lung and foregut endoderm. Importantly, we show that these lncRNAs are spatially correlated with transcription factors across the genome. In-depth expression analyses of lncRNAs with genomic loci adjacent to the critical transcription factors Gene, Gene, Gene (Gene), and Gene mimic the expression patterns of their protein-coding neighbor. Loss-of-function analysis demonstrates that two lncRNAs, LL18/NANCI (Gene-associated noncoding intergenic RNA) and LL34, play distinct roles in endoderm development by controlling expression of critical developmental transcription factors and pathways, including Chemical signaling. In particular, we show that LL18/NANCI acts upstream of Gene and downstream from Wnt signaling to regulate lung endoderm gene expression. These studies reveal that lncRNAs play an important role in foregut and lung endoderm development by regulating multiple aspects of gene transcription, often through regulation of transcription factor expression.

24465181.pub_title: Conservation and divergence of regulatory strategies at Hox Loci and the origin of tetrapod digits.
24465181.pub_abstract: The evolution of tetrapod limbs from fish fins enabled the conquest of land by vertebrates and thus represents a key step in evolution. Despite the use of comparative gene expression analyses, critical aspects of this transformation remain controversial, in particular the origin of digits. Gene and Gene genes are essential for the specification of the different limb segments and their functional abrogation leads to large truncations of the appendages. Here we show that the selective transcription of Species Gene genes in proximal and distal limbs is related to a bimodal higher order chromatin structure, similar to that reported for Gene genes, thus revealing a generic regulatory strategy implemented by both gene clusters during limb development. We found the same bimodal chromatin architecture in fish embryos, indicating that the regulatory mechanism used to pattern tetrapod limbs may predate the divergence between fish and Species. However, when assessed in Species, both fish regulatory landscapes triggered transcription in proximal rather than distal limb territories, supporting an evolutionary scenario whereby digits arose as tetrapod novelties through genetic retrofitting of preexisting regulatory landscapes. We discuss the possibility to consider regulatory circuitries, rather than expression patterns, as essential parameters to define evolutionary synapomorphies.

26952977.pub_title: Gene is a direct Gene target gene that promotes primary hair follicle placode down-growth.
26952977.pub_abstract: In the epidermis of Species lacking transcription factor Gene (Gene) activity, primary hair follicle (HF) pre-placode formation is initiated without progression to proper placodes. Gene modulates WNT and Gene signaling at early stages of HF development, but this does not fully account for the phenotypes observed upon Gene inhibition. To identify additional Gene target genes, we developed a novel method to isolate and transcriptionally profile primary HF placodes with active Gene signaling. In parallel, we compared gene expression at the same developmental stage in Gene-deficient embryos and controls. This uncovered novel Gene target genes with potential roles in priming HF placodes for down-growth. Importantly, we identify Gene (encoding a Gene/homeobox transcription factor) as a direct Gene target gene, loss of which replicates a subset of phenotypes seen in Gene-deficient embryos. Gene and Gene knockout embryos exhibit very similar abnormalities in HF development, including failure of the Gene suppression required for follicle down-growth. We show that Gene signaling is impaired in Gene-deficient and Gene knockout embryos and that exogenous Gene rescues the HF phenotypes in Gene knockout skin explants, indicating that it operates downstream of Gene. These findings identify a novel Gene/Gene/Gene signaling axis that is crucial for primary HF morphogenesis, which may also function more broadly in development and disease.

27238716.pub_title: Differential patterning of genes involved in Chemical metabolism and transport in extra-embryonic tissues of the Species.
27238716.pub_abstract: INTRODUCTION: Chemical (Chemical) is an important neuromodulator, but recently has been shown to be involved in neurodevelopment. Although previous studies have demonstrated that the placenta is a major source of forebrain Chemical during early forebrain development, the processes of how Chemical production, metabolism, and transport from placenta to fetus are regulated are unknown. As an initial step in determining the mechanisms involved, we investigated the expression patterns of genes critical for Chemical system function in Species extraembryonic tissues. METHODS: Mid-through late gestation expression of Chemical system-related enzymes, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Chemical transporters, Sert/Gene, Gene/Gene, Gene/Gene, and Chemical in placenta and yolk sac were examined, with cell type-specific resolution, using multiplex fluorescent in situ hybridization to co-localize transcripts and immunocytochemistry to co-localize the corresponding proteins and neurotransmitter. RESULTS: Gene and Gene are found in the syncytiotrophoblast I (SynT-I) and sinusoidal trophoblast giant cells (S-TGC), whereas Gene is expressed in SynT-I, syncytiotrophoblast II (SynT-II) and S-TGC. Gene expression is observed in the SynT-II only, while Gene is mainly expressed in S-TGC. Surprisingly, there were comparatively high expression of Gene, Gene, and Gene in the yolk sac visceral endoderm. DISCUSSION: In addition to trophoblast cells, visceral endoderm cells in the yolk sac may contribute to fetal Chemical production. The findings raise the possibility of a more complex regulation of Chemical access to the fetus through the differential roles of trophoblasts that surround maternal and fetal blood space and of yolk sac endoderm prior to normal degeneration.

23886837.pub_title: Gene regulates vertebrate vascular endothelial junction stability through Gene-Gene signaling.
23886837.pub_abstract: Establishment and stabilization of endothelial tubes with patent lumens is vital during vertebrate development. Gene (Gene) has been described as an essential regulator of de novo lumenogenesis through modulation of endothelial cell (EC) adhesion to the extracellular matrix (ECM). Here, we show that in Species and Species embryos, Gene-deficient vessels transition from an angioblast cord to a hollow tube, permit circulation of primitive erythrocytes, but ultimately collapse, leading to Disease and Disease. Knockdown of Gene does not alter EC-ECM adhesion, but causes cell-cell detachment and increases permeability of EC monolayers in vitro. We also found that endogenous Gene in ECs binds Gene (Gene), but not Ras homolog gene family member A or cell division control protein 42 homolog. Using an exchange protein directly activated by Chemical 1 (Gene)-Gene-dependent model of nascent junction formation, we demonstrate that a fraction of the Gene protein pool localizes to cell-cell contacts. Loss of Gene phenocopies loss of Gene or Gene in ECs by altering junctional actin organization, localization of the actin-bundling protein nonmuscle myosin heavy chain IIB, and junction remodeling. Our data show that Gene regulates the integrity of newly formed blood vessels as an effector of Gene-Gene signaling.

25886697.pub_title: Lumican deficiency results in Disease with altered collagen assembly.
25886697.pub_abstract: The ability of the heart to adapt to increased stress is dependent on the modification of its extracellular matrix (ECM) architecture that is established during postnatal development as cardiomyocytes differentiate, a process that is poorly understood. We hypothesized that the small Chemical-rich proteoglycan (SLRP) lumican (Gene), which binds collagen and facilitates collagen assembly in other tissues, may play a critical role in establishing the postnatal Species myocardial ECM. Although previous studies suggest that Gene deficient Species (Gene(-/-)) exhibit Disease consistent with Disease, Gene(-/-) hearts have not been evaluated. These studies show that Gene was immunolocalized to non-cardiomyocytes of the cardiac ventricles and its expression increased throughout development. Lumican deficiency resulted in significant (50%) perinatal Disease and further examination of the Gene(-/-) neonatal hearts revealed an increase in myocardial tissue without a significant increase in cell proliferation. However cardiomyocytes from surviving postnatal day 0 (P0), 1 month (1 mo) and adult (4 mo) Gene(-/-) hearts were significantly larger than their wild type (WT) littermates. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the increased cardiomyocyte size in the Gene(-/-) hearts correlated with alteration of the cardiomyocyte pericellular ECM components collagenalpha1(I) and the class I SLRP decorin (DCN). Western blot analysis demonstrated that the ratio of glycosaminoglycan (GAG) decorated DCN to core DCN was reduced in Gene mo Gene(-/-) hearts. There was also a reduction in the beta and gamma forms of collagenalpha1(I) in Gene(-/-) hearts. While the total insoluble collagen content was significantly reduced, the fibril size was increased in Gene(-/-) hearts, indicating that Gene may play a role in collagen fiber stability and lateral fibril assembly. These results suggest that Gene controls cardiomyocyte growth by regulating the pericellular ECM and also indicates that Gene may coordinate multiple factors of collagen assembly in the Species heart. Further investigation into the role of Gene may yield novel therapeutic targets and/or biomarkers for Species with Disease.

26494538.pub_title: Disease and abnormal extraembryonic membrane development in Gene deficient Species.
26494538.pub_abstract: COPII (coat protein complex-II) vesicles transport proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to the Golgi. Higher eukaryotes have two or more paralogs of most COPII components. Here we characterize Species deficient for Gene and studied interactions of Gene null allele with the previously reported Gene null allele. Gene deficiency leads to Disease associated with defective development of extraembryonic membranes and Disease in midbrain. Disease of multiple collagen types are observed in different connective tissues, suggesting that collagens are primarily transported in Gene-containing vesicles in these cells. Other extracellular matrix proteins, such as Gene, are not affected by Gene deficiency. Intracellular accumulation of unsecreted proteins leads to strong induction of the unfolded protein response in collagen-producing cells. No collagen secretion defects are observed in Gene deficient embryos. We report that Gene is a cargo that accumulates in acini of Gene Disease. Compensatory increase of one paralog is observed in the absence of the second paralog. Disease of the remaining Sec23 paralog on top of homozygous inactivation of the first paralog leads to earlier lethality of embryos. Our results suggest that Species Gene and Gene transport overlapping yet distinct spectra of cargo in vivo.

27068110.pub_title: Thyroid follicle development requires Gene- and endothelial cell-dependent basement membrane assembly.
27068110.pub_abstract: Thyroid follicles, the functional units of the thyroid gland, are delineated by a monolayer of thyrocytes resting on a continuous basement membrane. The developmental mechanisms of folliculogenesis, whereby follicles are formed by the reorganization of a non-structured mass of non-polarized epithelial cells, are largely unknown. Here we show that assembly of the epithelial basement membrane is crucial for folliculogenesis and is controlled by endothelial cell invasion and by BMP-Gene signaling in thyrocytes. Thyroid-specific Gene and Gene double-knockout (Gene) Species displayed Disease, Disease and defective follicular architecture. In Gene(dKO) Disease, epithelial cells remained associated in large clusters and formed small follicles. Although similar follicular Disease are found in Vegfa knockout (Vegfa(Gene)) thyroids, Gene(dKO) thyroids had normal endothelial cell density yet impaired endothelial differentiation. Interestingly, both Gene and Gene(dKO) thyroids displayed impaired basement membrane assembly. Furthermore, conditioned medium (Disease) from embryonic endothelial progenitor cells (eEPCs) rescued the folliculogenesis Disease of both Gene(dKO) and Disease. Gene, Gene, abundantly released by eEPCs into Disease, were crucial for folliculogenesis. Thus, epithelial Gene signaling and endothelial cell invasion promote folliculogenesis via assembly of the basement membrane.

25979088.pub_title: Defects During Gene Null Embryonic Cortex Development Precede the Onset of Overt Neurological Symptoms.
25979088.pub_abstract: MeCP2 is associated with several Disease; of which, Disease undoubtedly represents the most frequent. Its molecular roles, however, are still unclear, and data from animal models often describe adult, symptomatic stages, while MeCP2 functions during embryonic development remain elusive. We describe the pattern and timing of Gene expression in the embryonic neocortex highlighting its low but consistent expression in virtually all cells and show the unexpected occurrence of transcriptional defects in the Gene null samples at a stage largely preceding the onset of overt symptoms. Through the deregulated expression of ionic channels and glutamatergic receptors, the lack of Gene during early neuronal maturation leads to the reduction in the neuronal responsiveness to stimuli. We suggest that such features concur to morphological alterations that begin affecting Gene null neurons around the perinatal age and become evident later in adulthood. We indicate MeCP2 as a key modulator of the transcriptional mechanisms regulating cerebral cortex development. Neurological phenotypes of Gene Species could thus be the cumulative result of different adverse events that are already present at stages when no obvious signs of the pathology are evident and are worsened by later impairments affecting the central nervous system during maturation and maintenance of its functionality.

22808162.pub_title: Inhibition of endoplasmic reticulum stress improves Species embryo development.
22808162.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is an important regulator of a subset of genes during endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. In the current study, we analyzed endogenous Gene expression and localization, with a view to determining the effects of ER stress on the developmental competency of preimplantation embryos in Species. Fluorescence staining revealed that functional Gene is localized on mature oocyte spindles and abundant in the nucleus at the germinal vesicle (GV) stage. However, in preimplantation embryos, Gene was solely detected in the cytoplasm at the one-cell stage. The density of Gene was higher in the nucleus than the cytoplasm at the two-cell, four-cell, eight-cell, morula, and blastocyst stages. Furthermore, RT-PCR analysis confirmed active Gene mRNA splicing at all preimplantation embryo stages, except the one-cell stage. Chemical (TM), an ER stress inducer used as a positive control, promoted an increase in the density of nuclear Gene at the one-cell and two-cell stages. Similarly, culture medium supplemented with 25 mM Chemical displayed a remarkable increase active Gene expression in the nuclei of 1-cell and 2-cell embryos. Conversely, high concentrations of TM or Chemical led to reduced nuclear Gene density and significant ER stress-induced apoptosis. Chemical (Chemical), a known inhibitor of ER stress, improved the rate of two-cell embryo development to blastocysts by attenuating the expression of active Gene protein in the nucleus at the two-cell stage. Our data collectively suggest that endogenous Gene plays a role in normal preimplantation embryonic development. Moreover, Gene splicing is activated to generate a functional form in Species preimplantation embryos during culture stress. Chemical inhibits hyperosmolar-induced ER stress as well as ER stress-induced apoptosis during Species preimplantation embryo development.

27090637.pub_title: Zfp703 Is a Wnt/Gene Feedback Suppressor Targeting the Gene/Gene Complex.
27090637.pub_abstract: The Wnt/Gene signaling pathway controls embryonic development and adult stem cell maintenance through the regulation of transcription. Failure to downregulate Wnt signaling can result in Disease and Disease, highlighting the important role of negative regulators of the pathway. The Wnt pathway activates several negative feedback targets, including Gene and Gene, that function at different levels of the signaling cascade; however, none have been identified that directly target active Gene/Gene transcriptional complexes. We show that Zfp703 is a Wnt target gene that inhibits Wnt/Gene activity in Wnt reporter assays and in Wnt-dependent mesoderm differentiation in embryonic stem cells. Zfp703 binds directly to Gene to inhibit Gene/Gene complex formation and does so independently of the Groucho/Tle transcriptional corepressor. We propose that Zfp703 is a novel feedback suppressor of Wnt/Gene signaling that functions by inhibiting the association of Gene with Gene on Wnt response elements in target gene enhancers.

24825892.pub_title: Gene mutations increase its protein stability and drive Gene hyperactivation through enhanced secretion of Gene.
24825892.pub_abstract: The Gene (Gene) gene encodes an inactive rhomboid (iRhom) protease, Gene, one of a family of enzymes containing a long cytosolic Chemical terminus and a dormant peptidase domain of unknown function. Gene has been implicated in epithelial regeneration and Disease growth through constitutive activation of Gene (Gene) signaling. However, little is known about the physiological substrates for Gene or the molecular mechanisms underlying these functions. We show that Gene is a short-lived protein whose stability can be increased by select mutations in the Chemical-terminal domain. In turn, these stable variants function to augment the secretion of EGF family ligands, including Gene, independent of metalloprotease a disintegrin and metalloproteinase 17 (Gene) activity. In vivo, Chemical-terminal Gene mutations induce accelerated wound healing as well as accelerated tumorigenesis, but they do not drive spontaneous Disease development. This work underscores the physiological prominence of Gene in controlling Gene signaling events involved in wound healing and neoplastic growth, and yields insight into the function of key Gene domains.

27476503.pub_title: Dynamic expression of the Species orthologue of the Species Disease associated gene Gene during central nervous system development and neuronal differentiation.
27476503.pub_abstract: The Chemical repeat in the first intron of the Gene gene is the most significant cause of Disease as well as some forms of fronto-temporal Disease. The Gene protein has been previously reported to be expressed in post-mortem Species brain as well as in late embryonic and some postnatal stages in Species. Herein, we present a detailed study of the distribution of Gene protein in the embryonic, postnatal and adult Species brain, spinal cord as well as during the differentiation of Gene Disease cells to neurons including motor neurons. We show that the expression levels of the Gene transcripts in the developing and adult Species brain as well as in differentiating neurons, are dynamic. Besides the strong expression in the cerebellum and motor cortex reported previously, we show for the first time that Gene is expressed strongly in the olfactory bulb and also in the hippocampus. Our immunostaining data also reveal a hitherto unreported switch in the cellular distribution of Gene from a predominantly cytoplasmic to a nucleo-cytoplasmic distribution during corticogenesis. This switch in distribution was also observed during differentiation of the Disease Gene cell line to mature neurons. Our findings have implications for interpreting the pathophysiology caused by the repeat expansions in Gene in Species models.

26160903.pub_title: Gene is a target of Gene and acts as a suppressor of sensory development in the Species cochlea.
26160903.pub_abstract: Transcriptional regulatory networks are essential during the formation and differentiation of organs. The transcription factor Gene is required for proper morphogenesis of the cochlea and to control correct patterning of the organ of Corti. We show here that the Gene gene, a Species ortholog of the Drosophila orthodenticle homeobox gene, is a crucial target of Gene during inner ear development. Gene expression is lost in Gene Species mutants, and Gene misexpression in the Species inner ear leads to ectopic expression of Gene. Furthermore, Gene enhancer activity is increased by Gene misexpression, indicating that Gene may directly regulate Gene. Inactivation of Gene in the Species inner ear leads to ectopic expression of prosensory markers in non-sensory regions of the cochlear duct. Upon further differentiation, these domains give rise to an ectopic organ of Corti, together with the re-specification of non-sensory areas into sensory epithelia, and the loss of Reissner's membrane. Therefore, the Gene-positive domain of the cochlear duct shows a striking competence to develop into a mirror-image copy of the organ of Corti. Taken together, these data show that Gene acts downstream of Gene and is essential for patterning and spatial restriction of the sensory domain of the Species cochlea.

26609159.pub_title: A Gene-Based Translational Repression Complex Determines the Balance between Precursor Maintenance versus Differentiation during Species Neurogenesis.
26609159.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: Here, we have asked about post-transcriptional mechanisms regulating Species developmental neurogenesis, focusing upon the RNA-binding proteins Gene and Gene. We identify, in Disease precursors of the Species cortex, a Gene protein/Gene mRNA complex that is present in cytoplasmic granules with the translational repression proteins Gene. We show that Gene inhibits and Gene promotes neurogenesis, with Gene knockdown enhancing neurogenesis and depleting precursors, and Gene knockdown inhibiting neurogenesis and maintaining precursors. Moreover, we show that Gene likely regulates neurogenesis by silencing Gene mRNA. Specifically, Gene knockdown inappropriately increases Gene protein, and the Gene knockdown-mediated neurogenesis is rescued by preventing this increase. Thus, Gene and Gene function as a bimodal translational repression switch to control neurogenesis, with Gene acting in transcriptionally primed precursors to silence mRNAs important for neurogenesis, including Gene mRNA, and Gene acting during the transition to neurons to repress the precursor state. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: The mechanisms instructing neural stem cells to generate the appropriate progeny are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA-binding proteins Gene and Gene are critical regulators of this balance and provide evidence supporting the idea that neural precursors are transcriptionally primed to generate neurons but translational regulation maintains these precursors in a stem cell state until the appropriate developmental time.

23913870.pub_title: Gene stunts limb growth through alteration of cell polarity and gene expression.
23913870.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Gene/PCP signaling plays a critical role in multiple developmental processes, including limb development. Gene, a ligand of the PCP pathway, signals through the Gene/Gene or the Gene/Gene complex to regulate limb development along the proximal-distal axis in Species. Based on the interaction between Gene and Gene in Disease, we hypothesized the vertebrate Gene has a similar function as Gene in limb development. RESULTS: We show Gene is expressed in the skeletal condensates that will differentiate into chondrocytes and later form bones. Disrupted Gene function in Gene(C251X/Protein Mutation) Species mutants alters expression of genes such as Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene. These expression changes correlate with shorter and wider bones in the limbs and loss of one phalangeal segment in digits 2-5 of Prickle1C251X mutants. These growth defects along the proximal-distal axis are also associated with increased cell death in the growing digit tip, reduced cell death in the interdigital membrane, and disrupted chondrocyte polarity. CONCLUSIONS: We suggest Gene is part of the Gene/PCP signaling, regulating cell polarity and affecting expression of multiple factors to stunt limb growth through altered patterns of gene expression, including the PCP genes Gene and Gene.

23671652.pub_title: Fetal skeletal muscle progenitors have regenerative capacity after intramuscular engraftment in Gene deficient Species.
23671652.pub_abstract: Muscle satellite cells (SCs) are stem cells that reside in skeletal muscles and contribute to regeneration upon Disease. SCs arise from skeletal muscle progenitors expressing transcription factors Gene and/or Gene during embryogenesis in Species. However, it is unclear whether these fetal progenitors possess regenerative ability when transplanted in adult muscle. Here we address this question by investigating whether fetal skeletal muscle progenitors (FMPs) isolated from Gene(GFP/+) embryos have the capacity to regenerate muscle after engraftment into Gene-deficient Species, a model of Disease. The capacity of FMPs to engraft and enter the myogenic program in regenerating muscle was compared with that of SCs derived from adult Gene(GFP/+) Species. Transplanted FMPs contributed to the reconstitution of damaged myofibers in Gene-deficient Species. However, despite FMPs and SCs having similar myogenic ability in culture, the regenerative ability of FMPs was less than that of SCs in vivo. FMPs that had activated Gene engrafted more efficiently to regenerate myofibers than Gene-negative FMPs. Transcriptome and surface marker analyses of these cells suggest the importance of myogenic priming for the efficient myogenic engraftment. Our findings suggest the regenerative capability of FMPs in the context of muscle repair and cell therapy for Disease.

25302068.pub_title: Disease, Disease, Disease in a novel Gene-deficient Species model.
25302068.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Gene (Gene) is an ER-chaperone involved in the post-translational maturation and catalytic activation of vascular lipases including lipoprotein Gene (LPL), Gene (HL) and Gene (EL). Mutations in Gene are associated with Disease and severe Disease indicating the critical role of Gene in plasma lipid homeostasis. The currently available Species model of Disease is based on a naturally occurring truncating mutation, combined Disease (cld), which may represent a hypomorphic allele. Thus, development of Gene-null Species is needed to explore the phenotypic consequences of Disease. FINDINGS: In situ hybridization and qPCR analysis in the normal Species embryo revealed ubiquitous and high-level Gene expression. To investigate if Gene was required for Disease, a novel Species model based on a null-allele of Gene was generated and characterized. Gene-/- progeny were born at Mendelian ratios and exhibited combined Disease, Disease. CONCLUSION: Our results raise the possibility of a previously unrecognized role for Gene in embryonic development, but indicate that Gene is dispensable for the viability of Species embryo. The novel Species model developed in this study will be useful to investigate the full phenotypic spectrum of Disease.

26407529.pub_title: Negative and positive auto-regulation of BMP expression in early eye development.
26407529.pub_abstract: Previous results have shown that Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP) signaling is essential for lens specification and differentiation. How BMP signals are regulated in the prospective lens ectoderm is not well defined. To address this issue we have modulated BMP activity in a Species embryo pre-lens ectoderm explant assay, and also studied Species, in which the type I BMP receptors, Gene and Gene, are deleted from the prospective lens ectoderm. Our results show that Species embryo pre-lens ectoderm cells express BMPs and require BMP signaling for lens specification in vitro, and that in vivo inhibition of BMP signals in the Species prospective lens ectoderm interrupts lens placode formation and prevents lens invagination. Furthermore, our results provide evidence that BMP expression is negatively auto-regulated in the lens-forming ectoderm, decreasing when the tissue is exposed to exogenous BMPs and increasing when BMP signaling is prevented. In addition, eyes lacking BMP receptors in the prospective lens placode develop coloboma in the adjacent wild type optic cup. In these eyes, Gene expression increases in the ventral optic cup and the normal dorsal-ventral gradient of BMP signaling in the optic cup is disrupted. Gene becomes undetectable and expression of Gene increases in the ventral optic cup, suggesting that increased BMP signaling alter their expression, resulting in failure to close the optic fissure. In summary, our results suggest that negative and positive auto-regulation of BMP expression is important to regulate early eye development.

24516396.pub_title: Uncoupling of molecular maturation from peripheral target innervation in nociceptors expressing a chimeric Gene/Gene receptor.
24516396.pub_abstract: Neurotrophins and their receptors control a number of cellular processes, such as survival, gene expression and axonal growth, by activating multiple signalling pathways in peripheral neurons. Whether each of these pathways controls a distinct developmental process remains unknown. Here we describe a novel knock-in Species model expressing a chimeric Gene/Gene (TrkAC) receptor from Gene locus. In these Species, prospective nociceptors survived, segregated into appropriate peptidergic and nonpeptidergic subsets, projected normally to distinct laminae of the dorsal spinal cord, but displayed aberrant peripheral target innervation. This study provides the first in vivo evidence that intracellular parts of different Gene receptors are interchangeable to promote survival and maturation of nociceptors and shows that these developmental processes can be uncoupled from peripheral target innervation. Moreover, adult homozygous TrkAC knock-in Species displayed severe deficits in acute and tissue injury-induced Disease, representing the first viable adult Gene Species mutant with a Disease phenotype.

23431054.pub_title: Gene represses Gene to maintain progenitor cell survival during Disease organogenesis.
23431054.pub_abstract: In the developing pancreas, self-renewal of progenitors and patterning of cell fates are coordinated to ensure the correct size and cellular makeup of the organ. How this coordination is achieved, however, is not clear. We report that deletion of Gene (Gene) in Disease progenitors results in agenesis of the pancreas due to apoptosis of progenitor cells. We show that Gene is bound to the Gene regulatory region and that loss of Gene results in derepression of the Gene locus. Disease of Gene rescues progenitor cell survival and cellular makeup of the Gene-deleted pancreas.

26772200.pub_title: Thyroid bud morphogenesis requires Gene- and Gene-dependent apical constriction.
26772200.pub_abstract: Early development of the gut endoderm and its subsequent remodeling for the formation of organ buds are accompanied by changes to epithelial cell shape and polarity. Members of the Rho-related family of small GTPases and their interacting proteins play multiple roles in regulating epithelial morphogenesis. In this study we examined the role of Gene in foregut development and organ bud formation. Ablation of Gene in post-gastrulation Species embryos resulted in a loss of apical-basal cell polarity and columnar epithelial morphology in the ventral pharyngeal endoderm, in conjunction with a loss of apical localization of the known Gene effector protein Gene. Cell viability but not proliferation in the foregut endoderm was impaired. Outgrowth of the liver, lung and thyroid buds was severely curtailed in Gene-deficient embryos. In particular, the thyroid bud epithelium did not display the apical constriction that normally occurs concurrently with the outgrowth of the bud into the underlying mesenchyme. Gene, a protein that interacts with Rho GTPases and promotes apical constriction, was strongly expressed in the thyroid bud and its sub-cellular localization was disrupted in Gene-deficient embryos. In Gene gene trap mutant embryos, the thyroid bud epithelium showed no apical constriction, while the bud continued to grow and protruded into the foregut lumen. Our findings indicate that Gene is required for epithelial polarity and organization in the endoderm and for apical constriction in the thyroid bud. It is possible that the function of Gene is partly mediated by Gene.

24735878.pub_title: Transcriptional mechanisms link epithelial plasticity to adhesion and differentiation of epidermal progenitor cells.
24735878.pub_abstract: During epithelial tissue morphogenesis, developmental progenitor cells undergo dynamic adhesive and cytoskeletal remodeling to trigger proliferation and migration. Transcriptional mechanisms that restrict such a mild form of epithelial plasticity to maintain lineage-restricted differentiation in committed epithelial tissues are poorly understood. Here, we report that simultaneous ablation of transcriptional repressor-encoding Gene and Gene results in expansion and blocked terminal differentiation of embryonic epidermal progenitor cells. Conversely, Species overexpressing Gene in their skin epithelia exhibit precocious differentiation accompanied by smaller progenitor cell compartments. We show that Gene/Gene-deficient epidermal cells fail to undertake alpha-catenin-driven actin cytoskeletal reorganization and adhesive maturation and exhibit changes that resemble epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). Remarkably, these alterations and defective terminal differentiation are reversed upon depletion of EMT-promoting transcriptional factor Gene. Collectively, our findings reveal Ovol-Gene-alpha-catenin sequential repression and highlight Gene and Gene as Species of epithelial adhesion and differentiation by inhibiting progenitor-like traits and epithelial plasticity.

23839944.pub_title: The Gene receptor is essential for Gene-induced insulin resistance but not for maintaining Chemical homeostasis in tissues other than the eye.
23839944.pub_abstract: The plasma membrane protein Gene is thought to mediate uptake of Chemical from its blood carrier Gene (Gene) into cells and to function as a surface receptor that, upon binding of holo-Gene, activates a JAK/STAT cascade. It was suggested that Gene signaling underlies insulin resistance induced by elevated serum levels of Gene in Disease animals. To investigate these activities in vivo, we generated and analyzed Gene-null Species. We show that the contribution of Gene to Chemical uptake by tissues in vivo is small and that, with the exception of the eye, ablation of Gene has only a modest effect on Chemical homeostasis and does not impair physiological functions that critically depend on Chemical in the embryo or in the adult. However, ablation of Gene effectively protects Species from Gene-induced suppression of insulin signaling. Thus one biological function of Gene in tissues other than the eye appears to be the coupling of circulating holo-Gene levels to cell signaling, in turn regulating key processes such as insulin response.

23029233.pub_title: Application of a novel strategy of engineering conditional alleles to a single exon gene, Gene.
23029233.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The Conditional by Inversion (Gene) method for engineering conditional alleles relies on an invertible optimized gene trap-like element, the Gene module, for imparting conditionality. The Gene module contains an optimized 3' splice site-polyadenylation signal pair, but is inserted antisense to the target gene and therefore does not alter transcription, until it is inverted by Cre recombinase. In order to make Gene applicable to all protein-coding genes, the Gene module has been engineered within an artificial intron, enabling insertion into an exon. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: Therefore, theoretically, the Gene method should be applicable to single exon genes, and to test this idea we engineered a Gene allele of Gene. This single exon gene presents additional design challenges, in that its proximal promoter and coding region are entirely contained within a CpG island, and are also spanned by an overlapping transcript, Gene, which contains mmu-Gene. Here, we show that despite disruption of the CpG island by the Gene module intron, the Gene allele of Gene (Gene) is phenotypically wild type, and also does not interfere with expression of Gene and Gene. Furthermore, the inverted Gene allele of Gene, Gene(Gene) is functionally null, as homozygotes recapitulate the phenotype of Gene(betageo/betageo) Species, a well-characterized Gene null. Lastly, the benefit of the eGFP marker embedded in the Gene allele is demonstrated as it mirrors the expression pattern of Gene. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Our results demonstrate the applicability of the Gene technology as a method of choice for targeting single exon genes.

23221805.pub_title: Deficiency of Gene (Gene) causes Disease in Species and Species.
23221805.pub_abstract: Disease (CDH) is a common life-threatening Disease. Recessive mutations in the Gene (Gene) gene have been shown to cause bifid nose with or without Disease (Gene) syndrome and Disease, but have not been previously implicated in the development of CDH. We have identified a female Species with an isolated left-sided posterolateral CDH covered by a membranous sac who had no features suggestive of Gene or MOTA syndromes. This Species carries a maternally-inherited ~86 kb Gene deletion that affects the expression of Gene's full-length transcripts and a paternally-inherited splice site mutation that causes activation of a cryptic splice site, leading to a shift in the reading frame and premature termination of all forms of the Gene protein. This suggests that recessive Gene mutations can cause isolated CDH in Species. Further evidence for the role of Gene in the development of CDH comes from an Chemical -derived Species strain, Gene, which has a homozygous truncating mutation in Gene. Gene(Gene) Species have Disease, Disease and develop Disease which are covered by a membranous sac. We confirmed that Gene is expressed in the anterior portion of the developing diaphragm and found that Gene(Gene) embryos had decreased levels of cell proliferation in their developing diaphragms when compared to wild-type embryos. We conclude that Gene plays a critical role in the development of the diaphragm and that Gene deficiency can cause CDH in both Species and Species.

22529382.pub_title: Altered subcellular localization of transcription factor Gene regulates first Species cell lineage commitment.
22529382.pub_abstract: In the preimplantation Species embryo, Gene is critical to establishing the trophectoderm (TE)-specific transcriptional program and segregating TE from the inner cell mass (ICM). However, Gene is expressed in the TE and the ICM. Thus, differential function of Gene rather than expression itself regulates specification of the first two cell lineages. We used ChIP sequencing to define genomewide Gene target genes and asked how transcription of Gene target genes is specifically maintained in the TE. Our analyses revealed an evolutionarily conserved mechanism, in which lack of nuclear localization of Gene impairs the TE-specific transcriptional program in inner blastomeres, thereby allowing their maturation toward the ICM lineage. Restoration of Gene nuclear localization maintains the TE-specific transcriptional program in the inner blastomeres and prevents segregation of the TE and ICM lineages and blastocyst formation. We propose that altered subcellular localization of Gene in blastomeres dictates first Species cell fate specification.

25596276.pub_title: Gene functions downstream of planar cell polarity to regulate myosin II distribution and cellular organization during neural tube closure.
25596276.pub_abstract: Neural tube closure is a critical developmental event that relies on actomyosin contractility to facilitate specific processes such as apical constriction, tissue bending, and directional cell rearrangements. These complicated processes require the coordinated activities of Gene (Gene), to regulate cytoskeletal dynamics and actomyosin contractility, and the Planar Cell Polarity (Chemical) pathway, to direct the polarized cellular behaviors that drive convergent extension (CE) movements. Here we investigate the role of Gene as a direct linker between Chemical and actomyosin contractility during Species neural tube morphogenesis. In embryos, simultaneous depletion of Gene and the Chemical components Gene or Gene results in an increased liability to NTDs and Disease. We further show that these pathways intersect at Dishevelled, as Gene and Gene co-distribute and form a physical complex in cells. We observed that multiple components of the Gene pathway are planar polarized along mediolateral cell junctions in the neural plate of E8.5 embryos in a Gene and Chemical-dependent manner. Finally, we demonstrate that Gene mutant embryos exhibit defects in planar cell arrangement during neural tube closure, suggesting a role for Gene activity in CE. These findings support a model in which the Gene and Chemical pathways interact to control CE and polarized bending of the neural plate and provide a clear illustration of the complex genetic basis of NTDs.

25314967.pub_title: Temporal and spatial regulation of Gene abundance and Gene signaling are required for lymphatic valve formation and function.
25314967.pub_abstract: Lymphatic valves prevent the backflow of the lymph fluid and ensure proper lymphatic drainage throughout the body. Local accumulation of lymphatic fluid in tissues, a condition called Disease, is common in individuals with malformed lymphatic valves. The Gene (Gene) is required for the development of lymphatic vascular system. The abundance of Gene in collecting lymphatic trunks is high before valve formation and, except at valve regions, decreases after valve formation. We found that in mesenteric lymphatics, the abundance of Gene, which are ubiquitin-binding adaptor proteins involved in endocytosis, was low at early stages of development. After lymphatic valve formation, the initiation of steady shear flow was associated with an increase in the abundance of Gene in collecting lymphatic trunks, but not in valve regions. Gene bound to Gene and mediated the internalization and degradation of Gene, resulting in termination of Gene signaling. Species with lymphatic endothelial cell-specific deficiency of Gene had dilated lymphatic capillaries, abnormally high Gene abundance in collecting lymphatics, immature lymphatic valves, and defective lymph drainage. Deletion of a single Gene allele or pharmacological suppression of Gene signaling restored normal lymphatic valve development and lymph drainage in Gene-deficient Species. Our findings establish a critical role for Gene in the temporal and spatial regulation of Gene abundance and signaling in collecting lymphatic trunks during lymphatic valve formation.

24727670.pub_title: Gene is essential for normal development of vasculature network and glomerular mesangium in the Species kidney.
24727670.pub_abstract: Gene has been shown to be essential for ureteral development. However, it remains unclear whether it plays a direct role in kidney development. Here we addressed this by focusing on examining the pattern and contribution of Gene+ cells in the kidney and its role in kidney vascular development. Expression studies and genetic lineage tracing revealed that Gene is expressed in renal capsule, vascular smooth muscle cells and pericytes and glomerular mesangial cells in the kidney and that Gene-expressing progenitors contribute to these cell types. Examination of Gene(-/-) kidneys revealed large reduction in vasculature density and dilation of glomerular capillary loops. While SMA+ cells were reduced in the mutant, Gene+ cells were seen in early capillary loop renal corpuscles in the mutant, but fewer than in the controls, and further development of the mesangium failed. Analysis of kidney explants cultured from E12.5 excluded the possibility that the defects observed in the mutant were caused by Disease. Reduced proliferation in glomerular tuft and increased apoptosis in perivascular mesenchyme were observed in Gene(-/-) kidneys. Thus, our analyses have identified a novel role of Gene in kidney vasculature development.

27151576.pub_title: Specification of embryonic stem cell-derived tissues into eye fields by Wnt signaling using rostral diencephalic tissue-inducing culture.
27151576.pub_abstract: The eyes are subdivided from the Disease in early development. How the neuroectoderm regulates this subdivision, however, is largely unknown. Taking advantage of embryonic stem cell (ESC) culture using a Gene reporter line to monitor Disease formation, we found that ESC-derived tissues at day 7 grown in Glasgow Minimum Expression Media (GMEM) containing knockout serum replacement (KSR) exhibited higher levels of expression of Gene, a Wnt target gene, than those grown in chemically defined medium (Chemical). Surprisingly, Wnt agonist facilitated eye field-like tissue specification in Chemical. In contrast, the addition of Wnt antagonist diminished eye field tissue formation in GMEM+KSR. Furthermore, the morphological formation of the eye tissue anlage, including the optic vesicle, was accompanied by Wnt signaling activation. Additionally, using Chemical culture, we developed an efficient method for generating Gene+/Gene+ Chemical progenitors, which could become fully stratified retina. Here we provide a new avenue for exploring the mechanisms of eye field specification in vitro.

23217170.pub_title: The transcription factor Gene acts in a short window of midbrain dopaminergic neuron differentiation.
23217170.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The homeobox containing transcription factor Gene is, amongst others, expressed in the Species midbrain. The early expression of this transcription factor in the Species, as well as in the Species midbrain, points to a conserved function of Gene, but so far a functional analysis in this brain territory is missing. The goal of the current study was to analyze in which midbrain neuronal subgroups Gene is expressed and to examine whether this factor plays a role in the early development of these neuronal subgroups. RESULTS: We have shown that Gene is expressed in GABAergic, glutamatergic and dopaminergic neurons in the Species midbrain. In midbrain dopaminergic (mDA) neurons Gene expression is particularly high around E11.5 and strongly diminished already at E17.5. The analysis of knockout Species revealed that the loss of Gene is accompanied with a 25% decrease in the population of mDA neurons, as marked by Gene (TH), Gene (Gene), Gene and Gene. In contrast, the number of glutamatergic Gene-positive cells was augmented, while the GABAergic neuron population appears not affected in Gene-deficient embryos. CONCLUSION: We conclude that Gene is implicated in the development of mDA neurons where it displays a unique temporal expression profile in the early postmitotic stage. Our data indicate that the mechanism underlying the role of Gene in mDA development is likely related to differentiation processes in postmitotic stages, and where Gene is engaged. Moreover, Gene might play an important role during glutamatergic neuronal differentiation in the Species midbrain.

22810622.pub_title: Disease is controlled during development by Gene-dependent inhibition of Gene and activation of Gene.
22810622.pub_abstract: Neocortical neurons have highly branched dendritic trees that are essential for their function. Indeed, defects in Disease are associated with Species Disease. The molecular mechanisms regulating Disease, however, are still poorly understood. Here, we uncover the molecular basis for the regulation of Disease during cortical development. We show that during development, Disease requires post-mitotic suppression of the RhoGTPase Gene. By generating genetically modified Species, we demonstrate that this is catalyzed in vivo by the novel Gene-GAP Gene. Loss of Gene leads to decreased neocortical volume, associated specifically with profound oversimplification of Disease and hyperactivation of Gene. Remarkably, Disease and cortical thickness can be partially restored by genetic reduction of post-mitotic Gene levels. Furthermore, we identify the actin regulator Gene as a key regulator of Disease in vivo. Gene activation during late cortical development depends on Gene expression and subsequent inhibition of Gene. Strikingly, in utero expression of active Gene is sufficient to restore postnatal Disease in Gene-deficient animals. Our findings define a novel cell-intrinsic mechanism to regulate Disease and thus neuronal complexity in the cerebral cortex.

25820347.pub_title: The gene encoding the Species Gene axonal glycoprotein is regulated by the collier/Gene/Gene family early B-Cell factor 2 transcription factor.
25820347.pub_abstract: The Gene axonal glycoprotein (formerly F3/Contactin) plays a relevant role in cerebellar ontogenesis, as shown in Gene KO-Species and in Species misexpressing the corresponding cDNA from a heterologous promoter. Likewise, null mutant Species for the Collier/Gene/Early B-cell family transcription factor Gene, in which Purkinje neuron development is primarily affected, Disease in cerebellar corticogenesis. Here, to evaluate the contribution to the Gene null phenotype of changes in the profile of Gene, we study its expression in Gene null Species. In addition, we explore the activation profile of the Gene gene promoter upon transferring the Gene mutation to Species expressing an enhanced green fluorescent protein reporter under control of Gene gene regulatory sequences. In Gene null Species, Gene protein expression and Gene gene promoter activity are both downregulated during Disease and early postnatal cerebellar development, both in the rostral and caudal folia, while in the latter an upregulation is observed at postnatal day 8. In vitro, vectors driving Gene transcription factors from a cytomegalovirus (CMV) promoter transactivate a Gene-Choline acetyltransferse (CAT) promoter-reporter construct in cotransfection assays and, accordingly, by chromatin immunoprecipitation, we show that the Gene gene 5' flanking region is bound by the Gene transcription factor, consistent with the evidence that this region bears the cognate Chemical (DNA) consensus sequences. These data indicate that Gene expression is dependent upon Gene factors, suggesting that the Gene gene belongs to the expanding regulatory cascade driven by these transcriptional regulators so that changes in its activation may contribute to the phenotype of Gene null mutant Species.

23903192.pub_title: Gene establishes the energy homeostasis essential for blastocoel formation.
23903192.pub_abstract: It has been suggested that during Species preimplantation development, the zygotically expressed transcription factor Gene is essential for specification of the trophectoderm lineage required for producing a blastocyst. Here we show that blastocysts can form without Gene but that Gene is required to prevent oxidative stress when blastocoel formation is accompanied by increased oxidative phosphorylation that leads to the production of reactive Chemical species (ROS). Both two-cell and eight-cell Gene(-/-) embryos developed into blastocysts when cultured under conditions that alleviate oxidative stress, and Gene(-/-) blastocysts that formed under these conditions expressed trophectoderm-associated genes. Therefore, Gene is not required for specification of the trophectoderm lineage. Once the trophectoderm was specified, Gene was not essential for either proliferation or differentiation of trophoblast cells in culture. However, ablation of Gene in trophoblast cells resulted in reduced mitochondrial membrane potential. Moreover, Gene suppressed ROS in embryos and embryonic fibroblasts. Finally, ectopically expressed Gene protein could localize to the mitochondria as well as to the nucleus, a property not shared by other members of the Gene family. These results reveal that Gene plays a crucial role in maintaining energy homeostasis during preimplantation development.

22222602.pub_title: The gamma3 chain of laminin is widely but differentially expressed in Species basement membranes: expression and functional studies.
22222602.pub_abstract: Laminins are heterotrimeric extracellular glycoproteins found in, but not confined to, basement membranes (BMs). They are important components in formation of the molecular networks of BMs as well as in cell polarity, cell differentiation and tissue morphogenesis. Each laminin is composed by an alpha, a beta and a gamma chain. Previous studies have shown that the gamma3 chain is partnered with either the Gene chain (in placenta) or Gene chain (in the CNS) (Libby et al., 2000). Several studies, including our own, suggested that the gamma3 chain is expressed in both apical and basal compartments (Koch et al., 1999; Gersdorff et al., 2005; Yan and Cheng, 2006). This study investigates the expression pattern of the gamma3 chain in Species. We developed three new gamma3-reactive antibodies, and we show that the gamma3 chain is present in BMs. The distribution pattern is considerably more restricted than that of the gamma1 chain and within any tissue there is differential deposition into BM compartments. This is particularly true in the retina and brain, where gamma3 is uniquely expressed in a subset of the vascular basement membranes and the pial surface. We used conventional genetic ablation techniques to remove the gamma3 chain in Species; unlike other laminin null Species (alpha5, Gene, gamma1 nulls), these Species live a normal lifespan and have only Disease, the most striking of which are ectopic granule cells in the cerebellum and an apparent increase in capillary branching in the outer retina. These data support the suggestion that the gamma3 chain is deposited in BMs and contributes some unique properties to their function, particularly in the nervous system.

22173944.pub_title: Role for Gene-activated kinase Gene in development of the Species heart.
22173944.pub_abstract: The Chemical kinase Gene plays a pivotal role in cell proliferation, survival, and control of the cytoskeleton. Species that lack Gene die in midgestation prior to embryonic day E11 from unidentified causes. Analysis of Gene protein levels demonstrated that it was highly expressed in the whole embryo and in the developing heart but became low in the hearts of adult Species. In this study we analyzed development of the heart in conventional and conditional Gene knockout Species and embryos. We found that in conventional Gene knockout Species cardiogenesis is strongly affected from early developmental stages and by E9.5, hearts of Gene-/- embryos developed multiple profound deficits. Conditional deletion of Gene in the progenitors of the secondary heart field led to abnormal development of the outflow tract, in which the pulmonary artery had a smaller diameter, and the aortal wall was thinner than in wildtype Species. The conditional knockout Species also displayed the characteristic enlargement of the right ventricles and Disease. Gene-/- embryos and cardiomyocytes in which Gene was depleted exhibited low levels of Gene, a protein that plays key roles in cytoskeletal organization. Knock down of Gene in cultured cardiomyocytes led to severely compromised sarcomeric structure and deficits in contraction. These results indicate that Gene functions, including control of actin dynamics, are necessary for normal development of the heart.

22610508.pub_title: A conditional allele of Gene reveals redundant function of R-spondins during Species limb development.
22610508.pub_abstract: R-spondins are secreted ligands that bind cell surface receptors and activate Wnt/Gene signaling. Species mutations and gene inactivation studies in Species have revealed a role for these four proteins (Gene) in diverse developmental processes ranging from sex determination to limb development. Among the genes coding for R-spondins, only inactivation of Gene shows early Disease (E10.5 in Species). Therefore, a conditional allele of this gene is necessary to understand the function of R-spondins throughout Species development. To address this need, we have produced an allele in which loxP sites flank exons 2-4 of Gene, allowing tissue-specific deletion of these exons in the presence of Cre recombinase. We used these Species to investigate the role of Gene during limb development and found that limbs ultimately developed normally in the absence of Gene function. However, severe hindlimb truncations resulted when Gene and Gene mutations were combined, demonstrating redundant function of these genes.

22154697.pub_title: Gene, an important mediator of quiescence during Disease formation, is dispensable for normal pituitary development during embryogenesis.
22154697.pub_abstract: A delicate balance between proliferation and differentiation must be maintained in the developing pituitary to ensure the formation of the appropriate number of hormone producing cells. In the adult, proliferation is actively restrained to prevent Disease formation. The cyclin dependent kinase inhibitors (CDKIs) of the Disease/KIP family, Gene, Gene and Gene, mediate cell cycle inhibition. Although Gene is induced in the pituitary upon loss of Notch signaling or initiation of Disease formation to halt cell cycle progression, its role in normal pituitary organogenesis has not been explored. In wildtype pituitaries, expression of Gene is limited to a subset of cells embryonically as well as during the postnatal proliferative phase. Species lacking Gene do not have altered cell proliferation during early embryogenesis, but do show a slight delay in separation of proliferating progenitors from the oral ectoderm. By embryonic day 16.5, Gene mutants have an alteration in the spatial distribution of proliferating pituitary progenitors, however there is no overall change in proliferation. At postnatal day 21, there appears to be no change in proliferation, as assessed by cells expressing Gene protein. However, Gene mutant pituitaries have significantly less mRNA of Gene and the cyclins Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene than wildtype pituitaries. Interestingly, unlike the redundant role in cell cycle inhibition uncovered in Gene/Gene double mutants, the pituitary of Gene/Gene double mutants has a similar proliferation profile to Gene single mutants at the time points examined. Taken together, these studies demonstrate that unlike Gene or Gene, Gene does not play a major role in control of progenitor proliferation in the developing pituitary. However, Gene may be required to maintain normal levels of cell cycle components.

24835466.pub_title: Gene levels modulate primitive endoderm cell fate choice and timing in the Species blastocyst.
24835466.pub_abstract: Cells of the inner cell mass (ICM) of the Species blastocyst differentiate into the pluripotent epiblast or the primitive endoderm (PrE), marked by the transcription factors Gene and Gene, respectively. To investigate the mechanistic regulation of this process, we applied an unbiased, quantitative, single-cell-resolution image analysis pipeline to analyze embryos lacking or exhibiting reduced levels of Gene. We find that Gene mutants exhibit a complete absence of PrE and demonstrate that Gene levels regulate the timing and speed of lineage commitment within the ICM. Furthermore, we show that Gene is necessary for PrE specification by FGF signaling and propose a model where interactions between Gene, Gene, and the FGF/Gene pathway determine ICM cell fate. This study provides a framework for quantitative analyses of Species embryos and establishes Gene as a nodal point in the gene regulatory network driving ICM lineage specification.

23946445.pub_title: Hedgehog signaling regulates prosensory cell properties during the basal-to-apical wave of hair cell differentiation in the Species cochlea.
23946445.pub_abstract: Mechanosensory hair cells and supporting cells develop from common precursors located in the prosensory domain of the developing cochlear epithelium. Prosensory cell differentiation into hair cells or supporting cells proceeds from the basal to the apical region of the cochleae, but the mechanism and significance of this basal-to-apical wave of differentiation remain to be elucidated. Here, we investigated the role of Hedgehog (Hh) signaling in cochlear development by examining the effects of up- and downregulation of Hh signaling in vivo. The Hh effector Gene (Gene) was genetically activated or inactivated specifically in the developing cochlear epithelium after prosensory domain formation. Cochleae expressing a constitutively active allele of Gene showed only one row of inner hair cells with no outer hair cells (Chemical); abnormal undifferentiated prosensory-like cells were present in the lateral compartment instead of Chemical and their adjacent supporting cells. This suggests that Hh signaling inhibits prosensory cell differentiation into hair cells or supporting cells and maintains their properties as prosensory cells. Conversely, in cochlea with the Gene conditional knockout (Gene CKO), hair cell differentiation was preferentially accelerated in the apical region. Gene CKO Species survived after birth, and exhibited hair cell disarrangement in the apical region, a decrease in hair cell number, and Disease. These results indicate that Hh signaling delays hair cell and supporting cell differentiation in the apical region, which forms the basal-to-apical wave of development, and is required for the proper differentiation, arrangement and survival of hair cells and for hearing ability.

24659232.pub_title: Species Gene is required for lymphatic vascular morphogenesis during development.
24659232.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The transmembrane receptor Gene is a critical regulator of arterial differentiation and blood vessel sprouting. Recent evidence shows that functional blockade of Gene and its ligand, Gene, leads to Disease in Species. However, the precise role of the Gene signaling pathway in lymphatic vessel development has yet to be defined. Here we show the developmental role of Gene in lymphatic vascular morphogenesis by analyzing lymphatic endothelial cell (LEC)-specific conditional Gene knockout Species crossed with an inducible GeneCreER(T2) driver. RESULTS: LEC-specific Gene mutant embryos exhibited enlarged lymphatic vessels. The phenotype of lymphatic overgrowth accords with increased LEC sprouting from the lymph sacs and increased filopodia formation. Furthermore, cell death was significantly reduced in Gene-mutant LECs, whereas proliferation was increased. RNA-seq analysis revealed that expression of cytokine/chemokine signaling molecules was upregulated in Gene-mutant LECs isolated from E15.5 dorsal skin, whereas Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene (Gene) were downregulated. CONCLUSIONS: The lymphatic phenotype of LEC-specific conditional Gene Species mutants indicates that Gene activity in LECs controls lymphatic sprouting and growth during development. These results provide evidence that similar to postnatal and pathological lymphatic vessel formation, the Gene signaling pathway plays a role in inhibiting developmental lymphangiogenesis.

24352556.pub_title: Gene autoregulates its own expression in Species gonadal cells via its distal 1b promoter.
24352556.pub_abstract: Transcription factor Gene is required for the development and function of the Species gonads. We first reported that the Gene gene in both Species and rodents is expressed as two major alternative transcripts that differ solely in their first untranslated exon (exon 1a vs. exon 1b). We had also showed by quantitative PCR that in Species tissues, both Gene exon 1a- and 1b-containing transcripts are present in all sites that are normally positive for Gene protein. In adult tissues, exon 1a-containing transcripts generally predominate. A notable exception, however, is the testis where the Gene exon 1a and 1b transcripts exhibit a similar level of expression. We now confirm by in situ hybridization analysis that each transcript is also strongly expressed during gonad differentiation in both sexes in the Species. To gain further insights into how Gene gene expression is controlled, we characterized the Species Gene promoter sequence located upstream of exon 1b. In vitro studies revealed that the Gene 1b promoter is less active than the 1a promoter in several gonadal cell lines tested. Whereas we have previously shown that endogenous Gene transcription driven by the 1a promoter is dependent on a proximally located Ebox motif, we now show using complementary in vitro and in vivo approaches that Gene promoter 1b-directed expression is regulated by Gene itself. Thus, Gene transcription in the gonads and other tissues is ensured by distinct promoters that are regulated differentially and independently.

27811335.pub_title: Variants of Rab GTPase-Effector Binding Protein-2 Cause Variation in the Collateral Circulation and Severity of Disease.
27811335.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: The extent (number and diameter) of collateral vessels varies widely and is a major determinant, along with arteriogenesis (collateral remodeling), of variation in severity of Disease after large Disease. Differences in genetic background underlie the majority of the variation in collateral extent in Species, through alterations in collaterogenesis (embryonic collateral formation). In brain and other tissues,  80% of the variation in collateral extent among different Species strains has been linked to a region on chromosome 7. We recently used congenic (CNG) fine mapping of C57BL/6 (B6, high extent) and BALB/cByJ (BC, low extent) Species to narrow the region to a 737 Kb locus, Dce1. Herein, we report the causal gene. METHODS: We used additional CNG mapping and knockout Species to narrow the number of candidate genes. Subsequent inspection identified a nonsynonymous single nucleotide polymorphism between B6 and BC within Gene (S N P). We then created B6 Species with the BC single nucleotide polymorphism at this locus plus 3 other lines for predicted alteration or knockout of Gene using gene editing. RESULTS: The single amino acid change caused by S N P accounted for the difference in collateral extent and Disease volume between B6 and BC Species attributable to Dce1. Mechanistically, variants of Gene altered collaterogenesis during embryogenesis but had no effect on angiogenesis examined in vivo and in vitro. Gene deficiency altered endosome trafficking known to be involved in Gene Gene signaling required for collaterogenesis. CONCLUSIONS: Naturally occurring variants of Gene are major determinants of variation in collateral extent and Disease severity in Species.

27196066.pub_title: Expression of Gene RNA-Binding Protein in the Adult and Developing Species Retina.
27196066.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene), which belongs to the STAR family of KH domain-containing RNA-binding proteins, functions in pre-mRNA splicing, microRNA regulation, and formation of circular RNA. Gene plays critical roles in myelinogenesis in the central and peripheral nervous systems and has been implicated neuron-glia fate decision in the brain; however, neither the expression nor function of Gene in the neural retina is known. Here we report the expression of Gene RNA-binding protein in the developing and mature Species retina. Gene was strongly expressed by Muller glial cells in both the developing and adult retina. Intriguingly, during development, Gene was expressed in early differentiating neurons, such as the horizontal and amacrine cells, and subsequently in later differentiating bipolar cells, but not in photoreceptors. Neuronal expression was uniformly weak in the adult. Among Gene isoforms (5, 6, and 7), Gene-5 was the predominantly expressed isoform in the adult retina. To study the function of Gene in the Species retina, we examined quakingviable(qkv) Species, which have a Disease phenotype that results from deficiency of Gene expression and reduced numbers of mature oligodendrocytes. In homozygous qkv mutant Species (qkv/qkv), the optic nerve expression levels of Gene-6 and 7, but not Gene-5 were reduced. In the retina of the mutant homozygote, Gene-5 levels were unchanged, and Gene-6 and 7 levels, already low, were also unaffected. We conclude that Gene is expressed in developing and adult Disease. Gene is additionally expressed in progenitors and in differentiating neurons during retinal development, but expression weakened or diminished during maturation. Among Gene isoforms, we found that Gene-5 predominated in the adult Species retina. Since Muller glial cells are thought to share properties with retinal progenitor cells, our data suggest that Gene may contribute to maintaining retinal progenitors prior to differentiation into neurons. On the other hand, the expression of Gene in different retinal neurons may suggest a role in neuronal cell type specific fate determination and maturation. The data raises the possibility that Gene may function in retinal cell fate determination and maturation in both glia and neurons.

22609550.pub_title: BMP receptor-activated Smads confer diverse functions during the development of the dorsal spinal cord.
22609550.pub_abstract: Bone Morphogenetic Proteins (BMPs) have multiple activities in the developing spinal cord: they specify the identity of the dorsal-most neuronal populations and then direct the trajectories of dorsal interneuron (dI) 1 commissural axons. How are these activities decoded by dorsal neurons to result in different cellular outcomes? Our previous studies have shown that the diverse functions of the BMPs are mediated by the canonical family of BMP receptors and then regulated by specific inhibitory (I) Smads, which block the activity of a complex of Gene second messengers. However, the extent to which this complex translates the different activities of the BMPs in the spinal cord has remained unresolved. Here, we demonstrate that the receptor-activated (R) Smads, Gene and Gene play distinct roles mediating the abilities of the BMPs to direct cell fate specification and axon outgrowth. Gene and Gene occupy spatially distinct compartments within the spinal cord, with Gene primarily associated with neural progenitors and Gene with differentiated neurons. Consistent with this expression profile, loss of function experiments in Species embryos reveal that Gene is required for the acquisition of dorsal spinal neuron identities whereas Gene is critical for the regulation of Gene axon outgrowth. Thus the R-Smads, like the I-Smads, have discrete roles mediating BMP-dependent cellular processes during spinal interneuron development.

25503409.pub_title: The Chemical-terminus of Gene links cell cycle control and the proliferative potential of epidermal progenitor cells.
25503409.pub_abstract: The transcription factor Gene (Gene) plays a key role in homeostasis and regeneration of the skin. The Gene gene is transcribed from dual promoters, generating TAp63 isoforms with growth suppressive functions and dominant-negative DeltaNp63 isoforms with opposing properties. Gene also encodes multiple Chemical (C)-terminal variants. Although mutations of C-terminal variants have been linked to the pathogenesis of Gene-associated Disease, the physiological role of the Gene C-terminus is poorly understood. We report here that deletion of the Gene C-terminus in Species leads to Disease, accompanied by a reduced proliferative capacity of epidermal progenitor cells. Notably, unlike the Gene-null condition, we find that Gene C-terminus deficiency promotes expression of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor Gene (Gene), a factor associated with reduced proliferative capacity of both hematopoietic and neuronal stem cells. These data suggest that the Gene C-terminus plays a key role in the cell cycle progression required to maintain the proliferative potential of stem cells of many different lineages. Mechanistically, we show that loss of Calpha, the predominant C-terminal Gene variant in epithelia, promotes the transcriptional activity of TAp63 and also impairs the dominant-negative activity of DeltaNp63, thereby controlling Gene(Gene/Gene) expression. We propose that the Gene C-terminus links cell cycle control and the proliferative potential of epidermal progenitor cells via mechanisms that equilibrate TAp63 and DeltaNp63 isoform function.

23020941.pub_title: Temporal expression analysis of angiogenesis-related genes in brain development.
23020941.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED:  BACKGROUND: The current knowledge on molecular pathogenesis of Disease (CVM), which are believed to arise during development, is very limited. To unravel the molecular mechanisms involved in CVMs, a detailed understanding of the brain vascular development at molecular level is crucial. In this study, we aimed to explore the temporal and comparative expression profile of angiogenesis-related genes in the establishment of brain vasculature. METHODS: Expression of a total of 113 angiogenesis-related genes during Species brain development has been analyzed using low-density array systems designed for angiogenesis-related genes. Gene (Gene), a recently identified novel anti-angiogenic gene, has been selected for further characterization. RESULTS: We found that 62 out of 113 analyzed genes have expression in brain development at varying levels. Nineteen of these were differentially expressed between embryonic and postnatal stages (>1.5 fold). Gene is strongly expressed on growing blood vessels of cerebral cortex and hippocampus, partially expressed in the lateral regions of striatum, but mostly absent on the thalamus. CONCLUSION: By showing the comparative expression analysis of angiogenesis-related genes throughout brain development, the data presented here will be a crucial addition to further functional studies on cerebrovascular research.

24983472.pub_title: RNA-seq analysis to identify novel roles of Gene during embryonic Species heart valve remodeling.
24983472.pub_abstract: Disease affects up to 30% of the population and has been shown to have origins during embryonic development. Valvulogenesis begins with formation of endocardial cushions in the Disease and outflow tract regions. Subsequently, endocardial cushions remodel, elongate and progressively form mature valve structures composed of a highly organized connective tissue that provides the necessary biomechanical function throughout life. While endocardial cushion formation has been well studied, the processes required for valve remodeling are less well understood.
