The transcription factor Gene (Gene) is detected in Species valves from E15.5 during initial stages of remodeling, and expression remains high until birth when formation of the highly organized mature structure is complete. Heart valves from Gene-/- Species are abnormally thick and develop fibrotic phenotypes similar to Species disease by juvenile stages. These phenotypes begin around E15.5 and are associated with defects in connective tissue organization and valve interstitial cell differentiation. In order to understand the etiology of this phenotype, we analyzed the transcriptome of remodeling valves isolated from E15.5 Gene-/- embryos using RNA-seq. From this, we have identified a profile of protein and non-protein mRNAs that are dependent on Gene function and using bioinformatics we can predict the molecular functions and biological processes affected by these genes. These include processes and functions associated with gene regulation (methyltransferase activity, DNA binding, Notch signaling), Chemical metabolism (Chemical biosynthesis) and cellular development (cell morphology, cell assembly and organization). In addition, several mRNAs are affected by alternative splicing events in the absence of Gene, suggesting additional roles in post-transcriptional modification. In summary, our findings have identified transcriptome profiles from abnormal heart valves isolated from E15.5 Gene-/- embryos that could be used in the future to understand mechanisms of Disease in the Species population.

23451271.pub_title: Comparative analysis of the expression profile of Gene and Gene/Gene splice variants in developing and adult Species tissues.
23451271.pub_abstract: The With No Chemical (K) family of Chemical/Chemical kinase (WNK) defines a small family of kinases with significant roles in ion homeostasis. Gene has been shown to have different isoforms due to what seems to be largely tissue specific splicing. Here, we used two distinct in situ hybridization riboprobes on developing and adult Species tissues to make a comparative analysis of Gene and its sensory associated splice isoform, Gene/Gene. The hybridization signals in developing Species tissues, which were prepared at embryonic day e10.5 and e12.5, revealed a homogenous expression profile with both probes. At e15.5 and in the newborn Species, the two probes revealed different expression profiles with prominent signals in nervous system tissues and also other tissues such as kidney, thymus and testis. In adult Species tissues, the two expression profiles appeared even more restricted to the nervous tissues, kidney, thymus and testis, with no detectable signal in the other tissues. Throughout the nervous system, sensory tissues, as well as in Cornu Ammonis 1 (CA1), Gene and Gene areas of the hippocampus, were strongly labeled with both probes. Hybridization signals were also strongly detected in Schwann and supporting satellite cells. Our results show that the expression profiles of Gene isoforms change during the development, and that the expression of the Gene splice variant containing the Gene exon is prominent during developing and in adult Species tissues, suggesting its important role in the development and maintenance of the nervous system.

27026076.pub_title: Essential role of the TFIID subunit Gene in Species embryogenesis and embryonic stem cell differentiation.
27026076.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) and its paralogue Gene are components of the TFIID core module. We inactivated the Species Gene gene to address Gene function during embryogenesis. Here we show that Gene(-/-) embryos survive until E9.5 where primary germ layers and many Disease are identified showing Gene is dispensable for their specification. In contrast, Gene is required for correct patterning of the trunk and anterior structures, ventral morphogenesis and proper heart positioning. Overlapping expression of Gene and Gene during embryogenesis suggests their redundancy at early stages. In agreement with this, Gene(-/-) embryonic stem cells (ESCs) are viable and comprise Gene-containing TFIID. Nevertheless, Gene(-/-) ESCs do not complete differentiation into glutamatergic neurons and cardiomyocytes in vitro due to impaired preinitiation complex formation at the promoters of critical differentiation genes. We define an essential role of a core TFIID Gene in differentiation events during Species embryogenesis.

24948010.pub_title: Gene regulates bone mass by targeting genes supporting osteoblast differentiation and mineral homeostasis in vivo.
24948010.pub_abstract: Species mutations and in vitro studies indicate that Gene has a crucial function in bone development, however, the in vivo role of Gene in endochondral ossification has not been established. Here, we identify Gene as a central attenuator of adult bone mass in the appendicular skeleton. Dynamic bone formation, histologic and micro-computed tomography analyses demonstrate that in vivo Gene conditional loss of function in mesenchymal cells (Gene-Cre) and osteoblasts (Gene-Cre) results in increased bone mass accrual observed as early as 2 weeks that remains elevated throughout the lifespan owing to increased osteoblast activity and increased expression of bone matrix genes. Dlx3OCN-conditional knockout Species have more trabeculae that extend deeper in the medullary cavity and thicker cortical bone with an increased mineral apposition rate, decreased bone mineral density and increased cortical porosity. Trabecular TRAP staining and site-specific Q-PCR demonstrated that osteoclastic resorption remained normal on trabecular bone, whereas cortical bone exhibited altered osteoclast patterning on the periosteal surface associated with high Gene/Gene ratios. Using RNA sequencing and chromatin immunoprecipitation-Seq analyses, we demonstrate that Gene regulates transcription factors crucial for bone formation such as Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene as well as genes important to mineral deposition (Gene, Gene, Gene) and Disease (Gene). Furthermore, with the removal of Gene, we observe increased occupancy of Gene, as well as increased and earlier occupancy of Gene on the bone-specific Gene promoter. Together, these findings provide novel insight into mechanisms by which Gene attenuates bone mass accrual to support bone homeostasis by Disease gene pathway regulation.

22442485.pub_title: Gene is required for epigenetic stability during Species oocyte to embryo transition.
22442485.pub_abstract: Phenotypic variability in Disease is usually attributed to genetic background variation or environmental influence. Here, we show that deletion of a single gene, Gene (Gene or Gene), from the maternal germ line alone, on an otherwise identical genetic background, results in severe phenotypic and epigenetic variability that leads to Disease. We identify early and minute epigenetic variations in blastomeres of the preimplantation embryo of these animals, suggesting that the Disease may result from the misregulation of genomic imprinting in Species lacking maternal Gene. Our results reveal the long-range effects of a maternal gene deletion on epigenetic memory and illustrate the delicate equilibrium of maternal and zygotic factors during nuclear reprogramming.

26632338.pub_title: Gene is required for Species preimplantation development.
26632338.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is evolutionarily conserved from Species to Species, and has been found to play an important role in accelerating cell proliferation, cell-cycle progression, and Disease. The expression pattern and function of Gene during early Species embryo development, however, has not been investigated. We identified Gene as an essential gene for development to the blastocyst stage while performing an RNA interference (RNAi)-based screen in Species preimplantation embryos. Gene is expressed throughout preimplantation development, with highest mRNA and protein accumulation at the 8-cell and morula stages, respectively. RNAi-mediated knockdown of Gene results in embryos that arrest as morula. Gene-deficient embryos exhibit reduced blastomere numbers, greatly increased apoptosis, and impaired cell-lineage specification. Furthermore, knockdown of Gene results in global reduction of all RNA species, including rRNA, small nuclear RNA, small nucleolar RNA, and mRNA. Taken together, our results demonstrate that Gene is an essential gene for blastocyst formation, and is required for RNA processing and/or stability in vivo during preimplantation embryo development in the Species.

22685326.pub_title: Gene protein phosphatase regulates tight junction formation in lung distal epithelium.
22685326.pub_abstract: Little is known about the regulatory mechanisms underlying lung epithelial tight junction (TJ) assembly, which is inextricably linked to the preservation of epithelial polarity, and is highly coordinated by proteins that regulate epithelial cell polarity, such as aPKCzeta. We recently reported that Gene phosphatase functions through aPKCzeta-Gene signaling to control cell polarity in the lung epithelium. Here, we have extended these observations to TJ formation to demonstrate that Gene is crucial for the maintenance of TJ protein assembly in the lung epithelium, probably by controlling aPKCzeta phosphorylation levels, aPKCzeta-mediated TJ protein phosphorylation and Gene-Gene activity. Thus, TJs are disassembled after interfering with Gene function in vivo or during Chemical-induced TJ assembly in vitro. These effects are reversed by reintroduction of wild-type Gene or partially inhibiting aPKCzeta in GenesiRNA cells. Moreover, genetic activation of Gene rescues Gene(-/-) lung epithelial TJ defects. These findings uncover novel functions for the Gene-aPKCzeta-Gene-Gene pathway as a crucial regulatory mechanism of TJ assembly and polarity of the lung epithelium, providing a conceptual framework for future mechanistic and translational studies in this area.

22360971.pub_title: The expression and activity of Gene in the thalamus and its projections to the cerebral cortex in the Species embryo.
22360971.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The Species thalamus relays sensory information from the periphery to the cerebral cortex for Disease processing via the thalamocortical tract. The thalamocortical tract forms during embryonic development controlled by mechanisms that are not fully understood. Gene is a nuclear and cytosolic protein that transduces signals from secreted signaling molecules to regulate both cell motility via the cytoskeleton and gene expression in the nucleus. In this study we tested whether Gene is likely to play a role in thalamocortical connectivity by examining its expression and activity in developing thalamic neurons and their axons. RESULTS: At embryonic day (E)15.5, the time when thalamocortical axonal projections are forming, we found that the thalamus is a site of particularly high Gene mRNA and protein expression. As well as being expressed at high levels in thalamic cell bodies, Gene protein is enriched in the axons and growth cones of thalamic axons and its growth cone concentration is sensitive to Gene. Using Species carrying the Gene reporter BAT-gal we find high levels of reporter activity in the thalamus. Further, Gene induces BAT-gal reporter expression and upregulates levels of endogenous transcripts encoding beta-actin and L1 proteins in cultured thalamic cells. We found that Gene mRNA is enriched in thalamic axons and its 3'UTR is phylogenetically conserved and is able to direct heterologous mRNAs along the thalamic axon, where they can be translated. CONCLUSION: We provide evidence that Gene protein is likely to be an important player in thalamocortcial development. It is abundant both in the nucleus and in the growth cones of post-mitotic thalamic cells during the development of thalamocortical connectivity and Gene mRNA is targeted to thalamic axons and growth cones where it could potentially be translated. Gene is involved in transducing the Gene signal to thalamic cells suggesting a mechanism by which Gene guides thalamocortical development.

23226340.pub_title: A spontaneous Gene/Scl27a4 splice site mutation in a new Species model for Disease.
23226340.pub_abstract: Congenital ichthyoses are life-threatening conditions in Species. We describe here the identification and molecular characterization of a novel recessive mutation in Species that results in newborn lethality with severe Disease. Mutant newborns have a taut, shiny, non-expandable epidermis that resembles cornified manifestations of Disease in Species. The skin is stretched so tightly that the newborn Species are immobilized. The Disease was mapped to a region near the proximal end of chromosome 2 by SNP analysis, suggesting Gene/Gene as a candidate gene. Gene mutations in Species cause Disease (Disease), and mutations of Gene in Species have previously been found to cause a phenotype that resembles Species congenital ichthyoses. Characterization of the Gene cDNA revealed a fusion of exon 8 to exon 10, with deletion of exon 9. Genomic sequencing identified an A to T mutation in the splice Species sequence at the 3'-end of exon 9. Loss of exon 9 results in a frame shift mutation upstream from the conserved very long-chain Chemical synthase (VLACS) domain. Histological studies revealed that the mutant Species have defects in keratinocyte differentiation, along with hyperproliferation of the stratum basale of the epidermis, a hyperkeratotic stratum corneum, and reduced numbers of secondary hair follicles. Since Gene protein is present primarily at the stratum granulosum and the stratum spinosum, the hyperproliferation and the alterations in hair follicle induction suggest that very long chain Chemical, in addition to being required for normal cornification, may influence signals from the stratum corneum to the basal cells that help to orchestrate normal skin differentiation.

22292060.pub_title: Expression of Gene instead of Gene can partially rescue organ of Corti cell survival.
22292060.pub_abstract: In the Species inner ear neurosensory cell fate depends on three closely related transcription factors, Gene for hair cells and Gene and Gene for neurons. We have previously shown that neuronal cell fate can be altered towards hair cell fate by eliminating Gene mediated repression of Gene expression in neurons. To test whether a similar plasticity is present in hair cell fate commitment, we have generated a knockin (KI) Species line (Gene(KINeurog1)) in which Gene is replaced by Gene. Expression of Gene under Gene promoter control alters the cellular gene expression pattern, differentiation and survival of hair cell precursors in both heterozygous (Gene(+/KINeurog1)) and homozygous (Gene(KINeurog1/KINeurog1)) KI Species. Homozygous KI Species develop patches of organ of Corti precursor cells that express Gene, Gene, several prosensory genes and neurotrophins. In addition, these patches of cells receive afferent and efferent processes. Some cells among these patches form multiple microvilli but no stereocilia. Importantly, Gene expressing mutants differ from Gene null mutants, as they have intermittent formation of organ of Corti-like patches, opposed to a complete 'flat epithelium' in the absence of Gene. In heterozygous KI Species co-expression of Gene and Gene results in change in fate and patterning of some hair cells and supporting cells in addition to the abnormal hair cell polarity in the later stages of development. This differs from Disease of Gene (Pax2cre; Gene(f/+)), indicating the effect of Gene expression in developing hair cells. Our data suggest that Gene(KINeurog1) can provide some degree of functional support for survival of organ of Corti cells. In contrast to the previously demonstrated fate plasticity of neurons to differentiate as hair cells, hair cell precursors can be maintained for a limited time by Gene but do not transdifferentiate as neurons.

25917546.pub_title: Loss of Gene Causes Hematopoietic Stem and Progenitor Cell Depletion in Species Under Genotoxic Stress.
25917546.pub_abstract: 20-kDa Gene-associated protein (Gene) is a recently identified protein that associates with the Disease (FA) core complex component, Gene. Gene contains a conserved ubiquitin-binding zinc-finger domain and plays critical roles in the FA-BRCA pathway of DNA repair and genome maintenance. The function of Gene in animals has not been explored. Here, we report that deletion of Gene in Species led to a mild FA-like phenotype with defects in the reproductive and hematopoietic systems. Specifically, hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs) from Gene(-) (/) (-) Species showed defects in long-term multilineage reconstitution in lethally irradiated recipient Species, with milder phenotype as compared to HSPCs from Gene(-) (/) (-) or Gene(-) (/) (-) Species. Gene(-) (/) (-) Species are susceptible to Chemical (Chemical)-induced Disease. That is, acute Chemical stress induced a significant progenitor loss especially the erythroid progenitors and megakaryocyte-erythrocyte progenitors in Gene(-) (/) (-) Species. Furthermore, Gene(-) (/) (-) HSPCs displayed aberrant cell cycle pattern during chronic Chemical treatment. Finally, using Gene(-) (/) (-) Gene(-) (/) (-) double-knockout Species, we demonstrated a possible dominant effect of Gene in the interaction between Gene and Gene. This novel Gene Species model may be valuable in studying the regulation of the FA pathway during Disease progress in FA Species.

22173107.pub_title: Gene expression temporally allocates Disease progenitors and defines their terminal cell fate in the cerebellum.
22173107.pub_abstract: The cerebellum (Cb) controls movement related physiology using a diverse array of morphologically and biochemically distinct neurons. During development, the Cb is derived from rhombomere 1 (r1), an embryonic compartment patterned by a signaling center referred to as the isthmus organizer. The secreted glycoprotein Gene is expressed in the Disease (mesencephalon, mes) and at the posterior limit of the mes. Gene plays a pivotal role in maintaining the isthmus organizer and mutations in Gene produce severe Cb defects that are generally attributed to aberrant organizer activity. Interestingly, Gene is also expressed at the most posterior limit of dorsal r1, in a region known as the Disease (URL). However, the distribution and molecular identity of Gene expressing progenitors have not been carefully described in r1. We used Gene-Venus Species to generate a molecular map of Gene expressing progenitors in relation to other well characterized Cb biomarkers such as Gene (Gene), Gene and Gene. Our analysis validated Gene expression in the URL and revealed molecularly-defined developmental zones in r1. We then used genetic inducible fate mapping (GIFM) to link transient Gene expression in r1 to terminal cell fates in the mature Cb. Gene expressing progenitors primarily contributed to neurons in deep cerebellar nuclei, granule cells, and unipolar brush cells in distinct but overlapping temporal windows and sparsely contributed to inhibitory neurons and Bergmann glia. We further demonstrate that the Gene lineage does not follow a competency model of progressive lineage restriction to generate the Cb or the functionally related precerebellar system. Instead, progenitors initiate Gene expression de novo to give rise to each Cb cell type and precerebellar nuclei. We also used GIFM to determine how the temporal control of Gene expression is related to molecular identity and cell migration in Cb development. Our findings provide new insight into how lineage and timing establish cell diversity within the Cb system.

23307742.pub_title: Gene orchestrates topographic migration and connectivity of Species precerebellar neurons.
23307742.pub_abstract: We investigated the role of histone methyltransferase Gene in tangential migration of Species precerebellar pontine nuclei, the main relay between neocortex and cerebellum. By counteracting the sonic hedgehog pathway, Gene represses Gene in dorsal hindbrain, which allows normal pontine neuron migration. In Gene mutants, ectopic Gene derepression results in abnormal migration and supernumerary nuclei integrating in brain circuitry. Moreover, intrinsic topographic organization of pontine nuclei according to rostrocaudal progenitor origin is maintained throughout migration and correlates with patterned cortical input. Gene maintains spatially restricted Hox expression, which, in turn, regulates differential expression of the repulsive receptor Gene in migrating neurons; together, they generate subsets with distinct responsiveness to environmental Gene. Thus, Gene-dependent epigenetic regulation of intrinsic and extrinsic transcriptional programs controls topographic neuronal guidance and connectivity in the cortico-ponto-cerebellar pathway.

27013679.pub_title: Deletion of Gene from Gene (Gene) Neurons Abolishes Gene Expression and Leads to Disease.
27013679.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: Hypothalamic Gene (Gene) neurons are at the apex of the Disease that regulates Species fertility. Herein we demonstrate a critical role for the homeodomain transcription factor Gene (Gene) in Gene neuron maturation and show that Gene deletion from Gene neurons leads to complete Disease in males and females. Specifically, global Gene knock-out embryos had normal numbers of Gene neurons at 13 d of gestation, but no Gene staining was detected by embryonic day 17. To identify the role of Gene specifically in Gene neuron development,Gene(flox)Species were generated and lineage tracing performed in Gene(flox/flox):Gene(cre):RosaLacZ Species. This identified Gene as essential for maintaining expression of Gene The absence of Gene staining in adult Gene(flox/flox):Gene(cre)Species led to delayed Disease, Disease, and Disease. To address the mechanism by which Gene maintains Gene transcription, the capacity of Gene to regulate Gene transcription was evaluated in the Gene cell lines GN11 and GT1-7. As determined by luciferase and electrophoretic mobility shift assays, we found Gene to be a direct activator of the Gene promoter through binding to four ATTA sites in the Gene enhancer (E1) and proximal promoter (P), and able to compete with the homeoprotein Gene for occupation of the identified ATTA sites in the Gene promoter. We conclude that Gene is expressed in Gene neurons where it is required for Gene neuron expression of Gene and maintenance of fertility in Species. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: Infertility classified as Disease (IHH) is characterized by delayed or absent sexual maturation and low sex Chemical levels due to alterations in neuroendocrine control of the Disease. The incidence of IHH is 1-10 cases per 100,000 births. Although extensive efforts have been invested in identifying genes giving rise to IHH, >50% of cases have unknown genetic origins. We recently showed that Disease of Gene (Gene) leads to subfertility, making it a candidate in polygenic IHH. In this study, we investigate the mechanism by which Gene controls fertility finding that Gene is required for maintenance of Gene gene expression and deletion of Gene from Gene neurons leads to complete Disease.

22865640.pub_title: Inhibition of Gene by Gene/Gene controls myocardial compaction in the heart.
22865640.pub_abstract: AIMS: The ventricular wall of the heart is composed of trabeculated and compact layers, which are separated by yet unknown processes during embryonic development. Here, we wanted to explore the role of Gene and Gene/Gene for myocardial trabeculation and compaction. METHODS AND RESULTS: We found that Gene activity is specifically down-regulated in the compact layer during cardiac development in the Species. The biological role of Gene down-regulation was investigated by the expression of constitutively active Gene in the myocardium of Species, resulting in hypertrabeculation, reduced compaction, and Disease. To disclose the mechanism that inhibited Gene activity during the formation of myocardial layers, we analysed potential suppressors of Gene signalling. We unveiled that concomitant but not separate ablation of Gene and Gene in the developing heart leads to increased Gene activity along with hypertrabeculation, reduced compaction, and Disease, phenocopying effects gained by overexpression of constitutively active Gene. Expression profiling revealed a strong up-regulation of Gene in Gene/Gene mutant hearts, which might also interfere with trabeculation and compaction. CONCLUSION: This study identified potential novel roles of Gene/Gene in regulating trabeculation and compaction by inhibiting Gene and Gene signalling.

22982455.pub_title: Early Disease of Species with disrupted transcription cofactor Gene/Gene/Gene gene.
22982455.pub_abstract: Gene (also known as Gene/Gene/Gene), first isolated as a transcription coactivator PRIP (Gene)-interacting 96-kDa protein with RNA-binding property, possesses RNA methyltransferase activity. As a transcription coactivator binding protein, Gene enhances the nuclear receptor transcriptional activity and its methyltransferase property is involved in the formation of the Chemical cap of non-coding small RNAs, but the in vivo functions of this gene have not been fully explored. To elucidate the biological functions, we used gene targeting to generate Species with a disrupted Gene/Gene gene. Disruption of Gene gene results in early Disease due to impairment of development around the blastocyst and uterine implantation stages. We show that Gene is expressed in all cells of the E3.5day blastocyst in the Species. Gene null mutation abolished Gene expression in all cells of the blastocyst and caused a reduction in the expression of Gene and Gene transcription factor proteins in the E3.5 blastocyst resulting in the near failure to form inner cell mass (ICM). With conditional deletion of Gene gene, Species embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) exhibit defective wound healing in the scratch assay and a reduction in cell proliferation due to decreased G0/G1 transition and G2/M phase cell cycle arrest. We conclude that Gene/Gene, which is expressed in all cells of the 3.5 day stage blastocyst, is indispensable for early embryonic development.

26303528.pub_title: The Gene Oncoprotein Is a Critical Component of the Gene/Gene Enhancer in Erythroid Cells.
26303528.pub_abstract: Understanding how transcriptional regulators are themselves controlled is important in attaining a complete picture of the intracellular effects that follow signaling cascades during early development and cell-restricted differentiation. We have addressed this issue by focusing on the regulation of Gene/Gene, a zinc finger transcription factor that plays a necessary role in the global regulation of erythroid gene expression. Using biochemical affinity purification, we have identified the Gene oncoprotein as a critical factor that interacts with an essential upstream enhancer element of the Gene promoter and exerts a positive effect on Gene levels. This element also binds a core set of erythroid transcription factors, suggesting that Gene is part of a tissue-restricted enhanceosome that contains Gene-dependent and -independent components. Together with local enrichment of properly coded histones and an open chromatin domain, optimal transcriptional activation of the Gene locus can be established.

23418536.pub_title: Characterization of the Gene-/- Species mutant: a requirement for Gene in normal locomotion and sensorimotor circuit development.
23418536.pub_abstract: The Gbx class of homeobox genes encodes DNA binding transcription factors involved in regulation of Disease (CNS) development. Gene is dynamically expressed within spinal neuron progenitor pools and becomes restricted to the dorsal mantle zone by embryonic day (E) 12.5. Here, we provide the first functional analysis of Gene. We generated Species containing a conditional Gene allele in which exon 2 that contains the functional homeodomain is flanked with loxP sites (Gene(flox)); Cre-mediated recombination of this allele results in a Gene null allele. In contrast to Species homozygous for a loss-of-function allele of Gene, Species homozygous for the Gene null allele, Gene(-/-), are viable and reproductively competent. However, Gene(-/-) Species display a gross Disease that specifically affects hindlimb gait. Analysis of embryos homozygous for the Gene null allele reveals disrupted assembly of the proprioceptive sensorimotor circuit within the spinal cord, and a reduction in Gene(+) ventral motor neurons. These data suggest a functional requirement for Gene in normal development of the neural networks that contribute to locomotion. The generation of this null allele has enabled us to functionally characterize a novel role for Gene in development of the spinal cord.

23608456.pub_title: Gene and Gene interaction in enteric neural crest cell migration.
23608456.pub_abstract: Gene involvement in Disease form of Disease (Disease, HSCR) in Species as well as Disease in animal models highlight the importance of this transcription factor in control of the pool of enteric progenitors and their differentiation. Here, we characterized the role of Gene in cell migration and its interactions with Gene-integrins. To this end, we crossed the Gene(lacZ/+) Species with the conditional Ht-PA::Cre; Gene(neo/+) and Gene(fl/fl) Species and compared the phenotype of embryos of different genotypes during enteric nervous system (ENS) development. The Gene(lacZ/+); Ht-PA::Cre; Gene(neo/fl) double mutant embryos presented with increased Disease and more severe neuronal network disorganization compared to single mutants. These defects, detected by E11.5, are not compensated after birth, showing that a coordinated and balanced interaction between these two genes is required for normal ENS development. Use of video-microscopy revealed that defects observed result from reduced migration speed and altered directionality of enteric neural crest cells. Expression of Gene-integrins upon Gene overexpression or in Gene(lacZ/+) Species was also analyzed. The modulation of Gene expression altered Gene-integrins, suggesting that Gene levels are critical for proper expression and function of this adhesion molecule. Together with previous studies, our results strongly indicate that Gene mediates ENCC adhesion and migration, and contribute to the understanding of the molecular and cellular basis of ENS defects observed both in mutant Species models and in Species carrying Gene mutations.

27358050.pub_title: LATS-Gene/Gene controls lineage specification by regulating TGFbeta signaling and Gene expression during liver development.
27358050.pub_abstract: The Hippo pathway regulates the self-renewal and differentiation of various adult stem cells, but its role in cell fate determination and differentiation during liver development remains unclear. Here we report that the Hippo pathway controls liver cell lineage specification and proliferation separately from Notch signalling, using Species and primary hepatoblasts with liver-specific knockout of Gene and Gene kinase, the direct upstream regulators of Gene and Gene. During and after liver development, the activation of Gene/Gene induced by loss of Gene/2 forces hepatoblasts or hepatocytes to commit to the biliary epithelial cell (BEC) lineage. It increases BEC and fibroblast proliferation by up-regulating TGFbeta signalling, but suppresses hepatoblast to hepatocyte differentiation by repressing Gene expression. Notably, oncogenic Gene/Gene activation in hepatocytes induces massive Gene-dependent cell senescence/Disease. Together, our results reveal that Gene/Gene activity levels govern liver cell differentiation and proliferation in a context-dependent manner.

22945933.pub_title: Gene regulates stem cell repair potential and self-renewal during skeletal muscle regeneration.
22945933.pub_abstract: Satellite cells (SCs) are stem cells that mediate skeletal muscle growth and regeneration. Here, we observe that adult quiescent SCs and their activated descendants expressed the homeodomain transcription factor Gene. Genetic disruption of Gene specifically in adult SCs impaired myogenic cell differentiation, impaired myofiber repair during regeneration, and perturbed homeostasis of the stem cell niche, as indicated by an increase in SC self-renewal. Gene regulated the expression of the myogenic regulatory factors Gene and Gene, but not Gene, which suggests that Gene acts on divergent genetic networks in the embryo and in the adult. Moreover, we demonstrate that Gene regulates the Gene (Gene) pathway during regeneration via direct control of Gene transcription. Muscles lacking Gene were able to regenerate properly but showed a marked increase in SC number after regeneration. We conclude that Gene homeoproteins act as a rheostat system to ensure proper regeneration of the tissue and replenishment of the stem cell pool during the events that follow skeletal Disease.

27452274.pub_title: Regulation of Gene by Gene is required for the restricted expression of Chrnalpha3 in Cerebellar Granule Neuron progenitors during development.
27452274.pub_abstract: Homeobox gene Gene is known to promote glutamatergic differentiation and is expressed in post-mitotic neurons of CNS. Contrary to this here, we discovered that Gene is expressed in the proliferating progenitors of the external granule layer in the cerebellum, and examined factors that regulate this expression. Using Gene(-/-)Sey Species model and molecular interaction studies we demonstrate Gene is a key activator of Gene specifically in cerebellum, and induces its expression starting at embryonic day (E)15. By Postnatal day (PN)7, Gene is expressed in a highly restricted manner in the cerebellar granule neurons of the posterior cerebellar lobes, where it is required for the restricted expression of nicotinic cholinergic receptor-alpha3 subunit (Chrnalpha3) and other genes involved in formation of synaptic connections and neuronal migration. These results demonstrate a novel role for Gene and indicate that Gene-Gene expression and interaction is part of a region specific regulatory network in cerebellum and its deregulation during development could possibly lead to Disease (Disease).

23578932.pub_title: Gene maintains apical adhesion of neural progenitors.
23578932.pub_abstract: Apical neural progenitors are polarized cells for which the apical membrane is the site of cell-cell and cell-extracellular matrix adhesion events that are essential for maintaining the integrity of the developing neuroepithelium. Apical adhesion is important for several aspects of the nervous system development, including morphogenesis and neurogenesis, yet the mechanisms underlying its regulation remain poorly understood. Here, we show that Gene, a cell surface protein that engages in cell signaling upon binding cognate Eph receptors, controls normal morphogenesis of the developing cortex. Gene-deficient embryos exhibit morphological alterations of the neuroepithelium that correlate with Disease. Using loss-of-function experiments by ex vivo electroporation, we demonstrate that Gene is required in apical progenitors (APs) to maintain their apical adhesion. Mechanistically, we show that Gene controls cell-ECM adhesion by promoting apical localization of Gene and we identify Gene (Gene) as an important effector of Gene reverse signaling in apical adhesion of APs. Our results provide evidence for an important role for Gene in maintaining the structural integrity of the developing cortex and highlight the importance of tightly controlling apical cell-ECM adhesion for Disease development.

23860123.pub_title: Gene is a novel islet factor necessary for proliferation and survival in the Gene beta-cell line.
23860123.pub_abstract: Recently, a novel type 1 Disease locus was identified at Species chromosome 6p31.3, and transcription factor 19 (Gene) is a likely causal gene. Little is known about Gene, and we now show that it plays a role in both proliferation and apoptosis in Disease cells. Gene is expressed in Species and Species islets, with increasing mRNA expression in Disease. The expression of Gene is correlated with beta-cell mass expansion, suggesting that it may be a transcriptional regulator of beta-cell mass. Increasing proliferation and decreasing apoptotic cell death are two strategies to increase pancreatic beta-cell mass and prevent or delay Disease. siRNA-mediated knockdown of Gene in the Gene Disease cell line, a beta-cell model, results in a decrease in proliferation and an increase in apoptosis. There was a significant reduction in the expression of numerous cell cycle genes from the late G1 phase through the M phase, and cells were arrested at the G1/S checkpoint. We also observed increased apoptosis and susceptibility to endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress after Gene knockdown. There was a reduction in expression of genes important for the maintenance of ER homeostasis (Gene, Gene(IPK), Gene, and Gene) and an increase in proapoptotic genes (Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene). Therefore, Gene is necessary for both proliferation and survival and is a novel regulator of these pathways.

26116174.pub_title: Constitutively active mutation of Gene in oral epithelium causes Disease in Species.
26116174.pub_abstract: Disease is among the most common Species Disease. Disease (SMCP) is a subgroup of Disease, which may be as common as overt Disease. Despite the high frequency of SMCP in Species, only recently have several animal models of SMCP begun to provide insight into the mechanisms by which SMCP develops. In this study, we show that enhanced BMP signaling through constitutively active Gene in Disease causes Disease in Species. In these mutant Species, the fusion of both palatal mesenchyme in Disease, and muscles in Disease were hampered by epithelial tissue. During palatal fusion, enhanced SMAD-dependent BMP signaling Disease and altered cell proliferation rate in medial edge epithelium (MEE), and resulted in MEE persistence. At the molecular level, downregulation of DeltaNp63, which is crucial for normal palatal fusion, in MEE cells was impaired, leading to a reduction in Gene activation. Our study provides a new insight into the etiology of SMCP caused by augmented BMP signaling.

24123507.pub_title: Gene identifies a chamber-specific cell population that contributes to Disease development.
24123507.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The Disease is the most prominent layer of the heart, and the most important for mediating cardiac physiology. Although the Disease is critical for heart function, the cellular hierarchy responsible for ventricle-specific myocardium development remains unresolved. RESULTS: To determine the pattern and time course of Disease development, we investigated Gene protein expression, which has not been previously reported. We identified Gene+ cells in the cardiac crescent, and these cells were positive for markers of the first or second heart fields. From the onset of chamber formation, Gene+ cells were restricted to the Disease. This expression pattern persisted into adulthood. Of interest, we observed that Gene exhibits developmentally regulated dynamic intracellular localization. Throughout prenatal cardiogenesis, and up to postnatal day 4, Gene was detected in the cytoplasm of ventricular myocytes. However, between postnatal days 5-6, Gene translocated to the nucleus of ventricular myocytes. CONCLUSIONS: Given the ventricle-specific expression of Gene in later stages of heart development, we hypothesize that Gene+ cells in the cardiac crescent represent the earliest cell population in the cellular hierarchy underlying Disease development.

23824574.pub_title: Wnt/Gene signalling regulates Gene expression and is essential for organizer and endoderm formation in the Species.
23824574.pub_abstract: Several signalling cascades are implicated in the formation and patterning of the three principal germ layers, but their precise temporal-spatial mode of action in progenitor populations remains undefined. We have used conditional gene deletion of Species Gene in Gene-positive embryonic and extra-embryonic endoderm as well as vascular endothelial progenitors to address the function of canonical Wnt signalling in cell lineage formation and patterning. Conditional mutants fail to form anterior brain structures and exhibit posterior body axis truncations, whereas initial blood vessel formation appears normal. Tetraploid rescue experiments reveal that lack of Gene in the anterior visceral endoderm results in defects in head organizer formation. Gene lineage tracing in the definitive endoderm (DE) shows a cell-autonomous requirement for Gene in midgut and hindgut formation. Surprisingly, wild-type posterior visceral endoderm (PVE) in midgut- and hindgut-deficient tetraploid chimera rescues the posterior body axis truncation, indicating that the PVE is important for tail organizer formation. Upon loss of Gene in the visceral endoderm and DE lineages, but not in the vascular endothelial lineage, Gene expression is not maintained, suggesting downstream regulation by canonical Wnt signalling. Strikingly, Gene/Gene transactivation complexes accumulated on Gene cis-regulatory elements specifically upon endoderm induction in an embryonic stem cell differentiation system. Together, these results indicate that the Wnt/Gene signalling pathway regulates Gene expression for visceral endoderm pattering and DE formation and provide the first functional evidence that the PVE is necessary for gastrula organizer gene induction and posterior axis development.

24210906.pub_title: Regulation of Disease and in development by the endogenous calpain inhibitor Chemical.
24210906.pub_abstract: Disease is widespread both in Disease and in normal neural development, but the molecular pathways regulating these degenerative processes and the extent to which they are distinct or overlapping remain incompletely understood. We report that Chemical, an inhibitor of Chemical-activated proteases of the calpain family, functions as a key endogenous regulator of Disease. Chemical depletion was observed in degenerating axons after Disease, and maintaining Chemical inhibited degeneration of transected axons in vitro and in the optic nerve in vivo. Chemical depletion also occurred in a caspase-dependent manner in trophic factor-deprived sensory axons and was required for this in vitro model of Disease. In vivo, Chemical regulated the normal pruning of retinal ganglion cell axons in their target field. These findings identify Chemical as a key checkpoint for axonal survival after Disease and during development, and demonstrate downstream convergence of these distinct pathways of Disease.

23372768.pub_title: Gene function is essential for early post-implantation development in the Species.
23372768.pub_abstract: The mitochondrial AAA+-ATPase Gene is implicated in the regulation of mitochondrial and ER dynamics and was shown to be necessary for larval development in Species. In order to elucidate the relevance of Gene for Species development, the phenotype of an Gene deficient Species line was analyzed. Gene deficient embryos die around embryonic day E7.5 due to Disease and a defective development of the trophoblast lineage immediately after implantation into the uterus. This indicates an essential function of Gene for the progression of the first steps of post-implantation development at a time point when mitochondrial biogenesis and Chemical production by oxidative phosphorylation are required. Therefore, Species Gene plays an important role in the biogenesis of mitochondria in trophoblast stem cells and in differentiating trophoblasts. At the biochemical level, we report here that Gene is present in five native mitochondrial protein complexes of different sizes, indicating complex roles of the protein in mitochondrial architecture and function.

27506979.pub_title: Disease or inhibition blocks Gene accumulation and improves bone growth in a model of Disease.
27506979.pub_abstract: Mutations that cause increased and/or inappropriate activation of Gene are responsible for a collection of short-limbed Disease. These mutations can alter receptor trafficking and enhance receptor stability, leading to increased receptor accumulation and activity. Here, we show that wildtype and mutant activated forms of Gene increase expression of the cytoplasmic deacetylase Gene (Gene) and that Gene accumulation is compromised in cells lacking Gene or following treatment of fibroblasts or chondrocytes with small molecule inhibitors of Gene. The reduced accumulation of Gene was linked to increased Gene degradation that occurred through a lysosome-dependent mechanism. Using a Species model of Thanatophoric Disease (TDII) we show that both Gene deletion and treatment with the small molecule Gene inhibitor tubacin reduced Gene accumulation in the growth plate and improved endochondral bone growth. Defective endochondral growth in TDII is associated with reduced proliferation and poor Disease differentiation and the improved bone growth was associated with increased chondrocyte proliferation and expansion of the differentiation compartment within the growth plate. These findings further define the mechanisms that control Gene accumulation and contribute to skeletal pathology caused by mutations in Gene.

23460641.pub_title: Species with Gene Disease lineage exhibit Disease associated with abnormal tongue development.
23460641.pub_abstract: Disease represents one of the most common Disease in Species. TGFbeta signaling, which is mediated by Smad-dependent and Smad-independent pathways, plays a crucial role in regulating craniofacial development and patterning, particularly in Disease development. However, it remains largely unknown whether the Smad-independent pathway contributes to TGFbeta signaling function during palatogenesis. In this study, we investigated the function of Gene (Gene), a key regulator of Smad-independent TGFbeta signaling in Disease development. We show that Gene protein is expressed in both the epithelium and mesenchyme of the developing palatal shelves. Whereas deletion of Gene in the Disease or mesenchyme did not give rise to a Disease, inactivation of Gene in the neural crest lineage using the Gene-Cre transgenic allele resulted in failed Disease elevation and subsequently the Disease formation. The failure in Disease elevation in Gene-Cre;Gene(F/F) Species results from a malformed tongue and micrognathia, resembling Species Pierre Species sequence cleft of the secondary Disease. We found that the abnormal tongue development is associated with Gene overexpression in the neural crest-derived tongue tissue. The failed Disease elevation and Disease were recapitulated in an Gene-overexpressing Species model. The repressive effect of the Gene-mediated noncanonical TGFbeta signaling on Gene expression was further confirmed by inhibition of Gene, a downstream kinase of Gene, in the primary cell culture of developing tongue. Gene thus functions to regulate tongue development by controlling Gene expression and could represent a candidate gene for mutation in Species PRS clefting.

27072135.pub_title: Gene Promotes Mesendoderm Differentiation of Species Embryonic Stem Cells by Targeting Gene.
27072135.pub_abstract: Specification of the three germ layers is a fundamental process and is essential for the establishment of organ rudiments. Multiple genetic and epigenetic factors regulate this dynamic process; however, the function of specific microRNAs in germ layer differentiation remains unknown. In this study, we established that Gene (Gene) is related to germ layer specification via microRNA array analysis of isolated three germ layers of E7.5 Species embryos and was verified through differentiation of Species embryonic stem cells. Gene is highly expressed in endoderm and primitive streak. Overexpression of Gene increases and inhibition of Gene decreases the expression of mesendoderm markers. We further show that Gene promotes mesendoderm differentiation through the nodal pathway, a determinative signaling pathway in early embryogenesis. Using luciferase reporter assay, Gene (Gene), an antagonist of nodal, is identified to be a novel target of Gene. Furthermore, the role of Gene in mesendoderm differentiation is attenuated by Gene overexpression. Altogether, our results indicate that Gene accelerates mesendoderm differentiation of Species embryonic stem cells through nodal signaling by targeting Gene.

25432534.pub_title: Mutant activated Gene impairs endochondral bone growth by preventing Gene downregulation in differentiating chondrocytes.
25432534.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) plays a critical role in the control of endochondral ossification, and bone growth and mutations that cause hyperactivation of Gene are responsible for a collection of Disease that feature poor endochondral bone growth. Gene is expressed in proliferating chondrocytes of the cartilaginous growth plate but also in chondrocytes that have exited the cell cycle and entered the prehypertrophic phase of chondrocyte differentiation. Disease in chondrocyte proliferation and differentiation, and the defects in differentiation have generally been considered to be a secondary manifestation of altered proliferation. By initiating a mutant activated knockin allele of Gene (Gene) that causes Thanatophoric Disease (TDII) specifically in prehypertrophic chondrocytes, we show that mutant Gene induces a differentiation block at this stage independent of any changes in proliferation. The differentiation block coincided with persistent expression of Gene, the master regulator of chondrogenesis, and reducing Gene dosage allowed chondrocyte differentiation to proceed and significantly improved endochondral bone growth in TDII. These findings suggest that a proliferation-independent and Gene-dependent differentiation block is a key driving mechanism responsible for poor endochondral bone growth in Disease caused by mutations in Gene.

26647347.pub_title: Expression of Gene (Gene) in multiple levels of sensory systems.
26647347.pub_abstract: Genome-wide association studies and copy number variation analyses have linked Gene (Gene, gene name Gene) with Disease (Disease). In line with these findings, Species lacking Gene (Gene(-/-)) were shown to have core Disease including Disease and communication, and Disease. However the role of Gene in Disease pathogenicity remains unclear. Here we have generated a new Gene:tau-LacZ knock-in reporter line (Gene(tlacz/tlacz)), which enabled us to monitor the neuronal circuits in the brain expressing Gene. We show that Gene is expressed in many brain regions and produced a comprehensive report of Gene expression. Moreover, we found that Gene marks all sensory modalities: it is expressed in distinct brain regions involved in different sensory processings and is present in all primary sensory organs. Olfaction-based behavioral tests revealed that Species lacking Gene exhibit abnormal response to sensory stimuli and lack preference for novel odors. These results suggest that loss of Gene throughout the sensory system may contribute to the sensory manifestations frequently observed in Disease.

27881714.pub_title: A GPI processing Gene, PGAP6, modulates Nodal signaling in embryos by shedding Gene.
27881714.pub_abstract: Chemical-anchored proteins (GPI-APs) can be shed from the cell membrane by GPI cleavage. In this study, we report a novel GPI-processing enzyme, termed post-Chemical attachment to proteins 6 (PGAP6), which is a GPI-specific Gene mainly localized at the cell surface. Gene, a GPI-AP, which plays critical roles in early embryonic development by acting as a Nodal coreceptor, is a highly sensitive substrate of PGAP6, whereas Gene, a close homologue of Gene, is not sensitive. Gene processed by PGAP6 was released as a Chemical-bearing form, which is further cleaved by phospholipase D. Gene shed by PGAP6 was active as a coreceptor in Nodal signaling, whereas cell-associated Gene activity was reduced when PGAP6 was expressed. Homozygous Pgap6 knockout Species showed defects in early embryonic development, particularly in the formation of the anterior-posterior axis, which are common features with Gene knockout embryos. These results suggest PGAP6 plays a critical role in Nodal signaling modulation through Gene shedding.

23554936.pub_title: Visceral endoderm expression of Gene (Gene) is required for Gene maintenance and yolk sac development.
23554936.pub_abstract: Species embryos lacking the polycomb group gene member Gene (Gene) die during the peri-implantation stage. To assess the post-gastrulation role of Gene, a conditional knock-out (cKO) strategy was used to delete Gene from the visceral endoderm of the yolk sac and the definitive endoderm of the embryo. cKO embryos display profound yolk sac defects at 9.5 days post coitum (dpc), including disrupted angiogenesis in mesoderm derivatives and altered epithelial characteristics in the visceral endoderm. Significant changes in both cell Disease and proliferation were confined to the Gene-expressing yolk sac mesoderm indicating that loss of Gene in the visceral endoderm causes defects in the adjacent yolk sac mesoderm. Production of Gene (Gene) by the visceral endoderm is essential for normal growth and development of the yolk sac vasculature. Reduced levels of Gene are observed in the cKO yolk sac, suggesting a cause for the angiogenesis defects. Ex vivo culture with exogenous Gene not only rescued angiogenesis and apoptosis in the cKO yolk sac mesoderm, but also restored the epithelial defects observed in the cKO visceral endoderm. Intriguingly, blocking the activity of the mesoderm-localized Gene receptor, Gene, recapitulates both the mesoderm and visceral endoderm defects observed in the cKO yolk sac. Taken together, these results demonstrate that Gene is responsible for maintaining Gene in the developing visceral endoderm and that a Gene-responsive paracrine signal, originating in the yolk sac mesoderm, is required to promote normal visceral endoderm development.

23076118.pub_title: Developmental expression patterns of Chemical receptors in the Species spinal cord.
23076118.pub_abstract: Chemical receptors, a subtype of ionotropic Chemical receptors, perform important functions in the spinal cord. This study aimed to examine the expression pattern of various Chemical receptor subunits in the spinal cord over different stages of development. The regional distribution and levels of Gene mRNAs, which encode Chemical receptor subunits, were examined in the spinal cord of embryonic, perinatal, and adult Species using in-situ hybridization and real-time PCR. At different developmental stages, the expression of Gene-5 genes showed different regional distributions in the spinal cord. At E16.5, Gene and Gene were mainly expressed in the dorsal horns whereas Gene was expressed in the entire spinal cord. At P0 and P7, Gene expression accumulated at laminae II-IV, whereas Gene accumulated at the superficial laminae of the dorsal horns. At Gene and Gene, the expression of Gene was concentrated in the superficial laminae of the dorsal horns. Development-related changes were observed in the expression pattern of Gene-5. Gene was expressed in the entire spinal cord up to the perinatal period, whereas from P7 to adult stages, Gene expression was almost exclusively restricted to the dorsal horns. Similar observations were present with Gene, Gene, and Gene. Consistently, quantitative determination of the expression levels of Gene was in accordance with the in-situ hybridization results. This age-related dynamic expression of Chemical receptors may act as one driving force for the development of the anatomofunctional pattern and the maturation of the somatosensory circuitry in the spinal cord.

26932671.pub_title: Gene regulates specific programs in heart development via histone H3 Chemical 4 di-methylation.
26932671.pub_abstract: Gene, which encodes a histone Chemical methyltransferase, has been implicated in Species Disease in the context of Disease. However, its role in heart development is not understood. Here, we demonstrate a requirement for Gene in cardiac precursors and cardiomyocytes during cardiogenesis in Species. Gene expression analysis revealed downregulation of ion transport and cell cycle genes, leading to altered Chemical handling and cell cycle defects. We further determined that myocardial Gene deletion led to decreased Chemical and Chemical at enhancers and promoters. Finally, we identified Gene-bound regions in cardiomyocytes, of which a subset was associated with decreased gene expression and decreased Chemical in mutant hearts. This subset included genes related to ion transport, Disease and cell cycle regulation, suggesting that Gene is important for these processes. Our findings indicate that Gene is essential for regulating cardiac gene expression during heart development primarily via Chemical di-methylation.

22840396.pub_title: Inhibitory effects of Gene on Gene: a crosstalk between positive and negative signals regulating podocyte structure.
22840396.pub_abstract: Gene is the cell surface receptor for the repulsive guidance cue Slit and is involved in axon guidance and neuronal migration. Gene is a podocyte slit-diaphragm protein that functions in the kidney glomerular filtration barrier. Here, we report that Gene is expressed at the basal surface of Species podocytes and colocalizes with Gene. Biochemical studies indicate that Gene forms a complex with Gene in the kidney through adaptor protein Gene. In contrast to the role of Gene that promotes actin polymerization, Gene-Gene signaling inhibits Gene-induced actin polymerization. In addition, the amount of F-actin associated with Gene is increased in Gene knockout Species that develop an altered podocyte foot process structure. Genetic interaction study further reveals that loss of Gene alleviates the abnormal podocyte structural phenotype in Gene null Species. These results suggest that Gene signaling acts as a negative regulator on Gene to influence podocyte foot process architecture.

23193000.pub_title: Correct timing of proliferation and differentiation is necessary for normal inner ear development and auditory hair cell viability.
23193000.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Hearing restoration through hair cell regeneration will require revealing the dynamic interactions between proliferation and differentiation during development to avoid the limited viability of regenerated hair cells. Gene-Cre N-Gene conditional knockout (CKO) Species highlighted the need of Gene for proper neurosensory development and possible redundancy with Gene. The late-onset hair cell death in the absence of early Gene expression could be due to mis-regulation of genes necessary for neurosensory formation and maintenance, such as Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene. RESULTS: Gene-Cre N-Gene Gene double CKO Species show that proliferation and differentiation are linked together through Gene and in the absence of both Mycs, altered proliferation and differentiation result in morphologically abnormal ears. In particular, the organ of Corti apex is re-patterned into a vestibular-like organization and the base is truncated and fused with the saccule. CONCLUSIONS: These data indicate that therapeutic approaches to restore hair cells must take into account a dynamic interaction of proliferation and differentiation regulation of basic Helix-Loop-Helix transcription factors in attempts to stably replace lost cochlear hair cells. In addition, our data indicate that Gene is an integral component of the evolutionary transformation process that resulted in the organ of Corti development.

22158708.pub_title: Polycomb repressive complex 2 regulates normal development of the Species heart.
22158708.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: Epigenetic marks are crucial for organogenesis, but their role in heart development is poorly understood. Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) trimethylates histone H3 at Chemical 27, which establishes H3K27me3 repressive epigenetic marks that promote tissue-specific differentiation by silencing ectopic gene programs. OBJECTIVE: We studied the function of PRC2 in Species heart development using a tissue-restricted conditional inactivation strategy. METHODS AND RESULTS: Inactivation of the PRC2 subunit Gene by Gene (Gene(NK)) caused lethal Disease, namely, compact Disease, hypertrabeculation, and Disease. Candidate and genome-wide RNA expression profiling and chromatin immunoprecipitation analyses of Gene(NK) heart identified genes directly repressed by Gene. Among these were the potent cell cycle inhibitors Gene/b (inhibitors of cyclin-dependent kinase 4 A and B), the upregulation of which was associated with decreased cardiomyocyte proliferation in Gene(NK). Gene-repressed genes were enriched for transcriptional regulators of noncardiomyocyte expression programs such as Gene, Gene, and Gene. Gene was also required for proper spatiotemporal regulation of cardiac gene expression, because Gene, Gene, and Gene were inappropriately upregulated in ventricular RNA. PRC2 was also required later in heart development, as indicated by cardiomyocyte-restricted Gene-Cre inactivation of the PRC2 subunit Gene. However, Gene inactivation by Gene-Cre did not cause an overt phenotype, likely because of functional redundancy with Gene. Thus, early Gene inactivation by Chemical caused later disruption of cardiomyocyte gene expression and heart development. CONCLUSIONS: Our study reveals a previously undescribed role of Gene in regulating heart formation and shows that perturbation of the epigenetic landscape early in cardiogenesis has sustained disruptive effects at later developmental stages.

25742799.pub_title: Morphogenesis of the Species neural plate depends on distinct roles of Gene in apical and basal epithelial domains.
25742799.pub_abstract: The genetic control of Species epithelial polarity and dynamics can be studied in vivo at cellular resolution during morphogenesis of the Species neural tube. The Species neural plate is a simple epithelium that is transformed into a columnar pseudostratified tube over the course of ~ 24 h. Apical F-actin is known to be important for neural tube closure, but the precise roles of actin dynamics in the neural epithelium are not known. To determine how the organization of the neural epithelium and neural tube closure are affected when actin dynamics are blocked, we examined the cellular basis of the Disease in Species mutants that lack the actin-severing protein Gene (Gene). Although apical localization of the adherens junctions, the Par complex, the Crumbs complex and Gene is normal in the mutants, Gene has at least two distinct functions in the apical and basal domains of the neural plate. Apically, in the absence of Gene myosin light chain does not become phosphorylated, indicating that Gene is required for the activation of apical actomyosin required for neural tube closure. On the basal side of the neural plate, loss of Gene has the opposite effect on myosin: excess F-actin and myosin accumulate and the ectopic myosin light chain is phosphorylated. The basal accumulation of F-actin is associated with the assembly of ectopic basal tight junctions and focal disruptions of the basement membrane, which eventually lead to a breakdown of epithelial organization.

25038043.pub_title: Vangl-dependent planar cell polarity signalling is not required for neural crest migration in mammals.
25038043.pub_abstract: The role of planar cell polarity (PCP) signalling in neural crest (NC) development is unclear. The PCP dependence of NC cell migration has been reported in Species and Species, but NC migration has not been studied in Species PCP mutants. Gene(Lp/Lp) Species embryos lack PCP signalling and undergo almost complete failure of neural tube closure. Here we show, however, that NC specification, migration and derivative formation occur normally in Gene(Lp/Lp) embryos. The gene family member Gene was not expressed in NC nor ectopically expressed in Gene(Lp/Lp) embryos, and doubly homozygous Gene/Gene mutants exhibited normal NC migration. Acute downregulation of Gene in the NC lineage did not prevent NC migration. In vitro, Gene(Lp/Lp) neural tube explants generated emigrating NC cells, as in wild type. Hence, PCP signalling is not essential for NC migration in mammals, in contrast to its essential role in neural tube closure. PCP mutations are thus unlikely to mediate NC-related Disease in Species.

24796693.pub_title: The complex morphology of reactive astrocytes controlled by fibroblast growth factor signaling.
24796693.pub_abstract: Astrocytes are the most abundant cell-type of the Species brain and play a variety of roles in brain homeostasis and synaptic maturation, under normal conditions. However, astrocytes undergo dramatic pathological changes in response to Disease, such as reactive Disease and glial scar formation. Although Disease and massive proliferation of astrocytes are obvious, the molecular identity and cues that dictate the structural changes in reactive astrocytes remain unclear. This study proposes that fibroblast growth factor (FGF) signaling is responsible for making astrocyte morphology more complex and Disease in response to an inflammatory stimulus such as lipopolysaccharide. Primary astrocytes isolated from perinatal brains developed more branches in the presence of Gene or lesser branches in the presence of Gene. Introduction of the constitutively active form of the FGF receptor 3 (caFGFR3) into the brain increases the structural complexity, with greater glial fibrillary acidic protein level in astrocytes, while overexpression of a dominant-negative form of Gene (dnFGFR3) reduces it. Treatment of Gene facilitated the wound-healing process of primary astrocytes in vitro by changing their morphology, indicating that the FGF signal may control the responsiveness of astrocytes in Disease. Finally, the blockade of FGF signaling by introducing dnFGFR3 at the site of reactive Disease reduces astrocyte branch formation and minimizes Disease responses during reactive Disease. Taken together, these results indicate that Gene-Gene signaling controls structural changes in astrocytes during reactive Disease, under pathogenic conditions.

25007825.pub_title: The intracellular redox protein Gene regulates the development of hippocampal mossy fibre connections.
25007825.pub_abstract: Gene is a reduction-oxidation (redox) enzyme that functions as an unusual F-actin disassembly factor during Disease. Although three Molecule interacting with Gene (Gene) proteins exist in vertebrate species, their mechanism of action remains poorly defined and their role in vivo unknown. Here, we report that vertebrate Gene regulates the targeting of secretory vesicles containing immunoglobulin superfamily cell adhesion molecules (IgCAMs) to the neuronal growth cone membrane through its ability to control the actin cytoskeleton using redox chemistry, thereby maintaining appropriate IgCAM cell surface levels. This precise regulation of IgCAMs by Gene is essential for the lamina-specific targeting of mossy fibre axons onto CA3 pyramidal neurons in the developing Species hippocampus in vivo. These findings reveal the first in vivo role for a vertebrate Gene protein, expand the repertoire of cellular functions controlled through Gene-mediated effects on the cytoskeleton, and provide insights into the poorly characterized mechanisms underlying neuronal protein cell surface expression and lamina-specific axonal targeting.

26283362.pub_title: Independent regulation of vertebral number and vertebral identity by microRNA-196 paralogs.
26283362.pub_abstract: The Hox genes play a central role in patterning the embryonic anterior-to-posterior axis. An important function of Hox activity in vertebrates is the specification of different vertebral morphologies, with an additional role in axis elongation emerging. The Gene family of microRNAs (miRNAs) are predicted to extensively target Gene' UTRs, although the full extent to which Gene regulates Hox expression dynamics and influences Species development remains to be elucidated. Here we used an extensive allelic series of Species knockouts to show that the Gene family of miRNAs is essential both for properly patterning vertebral identity at different axial levels and for modulating the total number of vertebrae. All three Gene paralogs, 196a1, 196a2, and 196b, act redundantly to pattern the midthoracic region, whereas 196a2 and 196b have an additive role in controlling the number of rib-bearing vertebra and positioning of the sacrum. Independent of this, 196a1, 196a2, and 196b act redundantly to constrain total vertebral number. Loss of Gene leads to a collective up-regulation of numerous trunk Hox target genes with a concomitant delay in activation of caudal Hox genes, which are proposed to signal the end of axis extension. Additionally, we identified altered molecular signatures associated with the Wnt, Fgf, and Notch/segmentation pathways and demonstrate that Gene has the potential to regulate Wnt activity by multiple mechanisms. By feeding into, and thereby integrating, multiple genetic networks controlling vertebral number and identity, Gene is a critical player defining axial formulae.

24159046.pub_title: Fine tuning of craniofacial morphology by distant-acting enhancers.
24159046.pub_abstract: The shape of the Species face and skull is largely genetically determined. However, the genomic basis of craniofacial morphology is incompletely understood and hypothesized to involve protein-coding genes, as well as gene regulatory sequences. We used a combination of epigenomic profiling, in vivo characterization of candidate enhancer sequences in Species, and targeted deletion experiments to examine the role of distant-acting enhancers in craniofacial development. We identified complex regulatory landscapes consisting of enhancers that drive spatially complex developmental expression patterns. Analysis of Species lines in which individual craniofacial enhancers had been deleted revealed significant alterations of craniofacial shape, demonstrating the functional importance of enhancers in defining face and skull morphology. These results demonstrate that enhancers are involved in craniofacial development and suggest that enhancer sequence variation contributes to the diversity of Species facial morphology.

26235619.pub_title: Functional Redundancy of Gene and Gene MAP Disease during Development.
26235619.pub_abstract: Gene and Gene are the effector kinases of the Gene MAP-kinase signaling pathway, which plays a central role in transducing signals controlling cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival. Deregulated activity of the Gene pathway is linked to a group of developmental syndromes and contributes to the pathogenesis of various Species diseases. One fundamental question that remains unaddressed is whether Gene and Gene have evolved unique physiological functions or whether they are used redundantly to reach a threshold of global Gene activity. Here, we show that the extent of development of the Species placenta and embryo bearing different combinations of Gene and Gene alleles is strictly correlated with total Gene activity. We further demonstrate that transgenic expression of Gene fully rescues the embryonic and placental Disease associated with the loss of Gene. We conclude that Gene and Gene exert redundant functions in Species development.

22186729.pub_title: Gene and Gene cross-regulatory interactions consolidate progenitor and melanocyte lineages in the cranial neural crest.
22186729.pub_abstract: The cellular origin and molecular mechanisms regulating pigmentation of head and neck are largely unknown. Melanocyte specification is controlled by the transcriptional activity of Gene, but no general logic has emerged to explain how Gene and progenitor transcriptional activities consolidate melanocyte and progenitor cell fates. We show that cranial melanocytes arise from at least two different cellular sources: initially from nerve-associated Schwann cell precursors (SCPs) and later from a cellular source that is independent of nerves. Unlike the midbrain-hindbrain cluster from which melanoblasts arise independently of nerves, a large center of melanocytes in and around cranial nerves IX-X is derived from SCPs, as shown by genetic cell-lineage tracing and analysis of Gene-null mutant Species. Conditional gain- and loss-of-function experiments show genetically that cell fates in the neural crest involve both the SRY transcription factor Gene and Gene, which consolidate an SCP progenitor or melanocyte fate by cross-regulatory interactions. A gradual downregulation of Gene in progenitors during development permits the differentiation of both neural crest- and SCP-derived progenitors into melanocytes, and an initial small pool of nerve-associated melanoblasts expands in number and disperses under the control of Gene (Gene) and Gene signaling.

25044744.pub_title: Gene regulates neural stem cell maintenance in the postnatal Species subventricular zone.
25044744.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Postnatal neurogenesis persists throughout life in the subventricular zone (SVZ)-olfactory bulb pathway in mammals. Extrinsic or intrinsic factors have been revealed to regulate neural stem cell (NSC) properties and neurogenesis. Gene (Gene) belongs to zyxin family of Gene proteins, which have been shown to interact with various proteins to mediate cellular functions. However, the role of Gene in NSCs is still unknown. RESULTS: By performing double immunofluorescence staining, we found that Gene was expressed by Gene-positive NSCs in Disease and postnatal Species forebrains. To study the function of Gene in NSCs, we performed overexpression and knockdown experiments with neurospheres derived from postnatal day 7 SVZ. We found that Gene was necessary and sufficient for self-renewal and proliferation of NSCs, but inhibited their differentiation. To further investigate the mechanism of Gene in NSCs, we performed Luciferase reporter assay and found that Gene activated Notch signaling, a pathway required for NSC self-renewal. CONCLUSIONS: Our data suggest that Gene regulates NSC maintenance and it may be a new marker for NSCs.

22639370.pub_title: Identification of novel transcription-regulating genes expressed during Species molar development.
22639370.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The mechanism of tooth development is a complex process regulated by numerous genes including transcription factors, growth factors, and other intra- and extracellular molecules. Especially, transcription factors play a central role in gene expression, regulating a wide spectrum of biological processes including organogenesis. Substantial evidence has been demonstrated by a number of studies using genetically engineered animal models. However, detailed molecular mechanisms of tooth development have not been completely elucidated, partially because numerous genes that play essential roles in tooth development remain unidentified. RESULTS: In this study, we conducted an expression-based screening using gene expression database and in situ hybridization assays. Based on the gene expression database "EMBRYS," 207 out of 1,520 genes were expressed in the maxillary and/or mandibular processes and thus were selected for further analysis by section in situ hybridization. Among these candidates, 28 genes were newly identified as potential factors associated with tooth development by in situ hybridization assays with frontal sections of embryonic day 13.5 and 14.5 Species embryos. The expression patterns were also examined at embryonic day 16.5 and 18.5. CONCLUSIONS: These results will contribute to elucidating the mechanisms of tooth development and to improving the technology for regeneration of tooth.

26764381.pub_title: Gene is involved in Disease development in Species and Species.
26764381.pub_abstract: Aberrant embryonic development of the Disease and/or pituitary gland in Species results in Disease (Chemical). Gene (Gene), an important regulator of the WNT/Gene signaling pathway, is expressed in the developing forebrain and pituitary gland, but its role during Disease (HP) axis formation or involvement in Species Chemical remains elusive. Using a conditional genetic approach in the Species, we first demonstrate that Gene is required in the prospective Disease to maintain normal expression of the Disease signals involved in the induction and subsequent expansion of Rathke's pouch progenitors. Next, we reveal that the function of Gene during HP axis development depends exclusively on the repressing activity of Gene and does not require its interaction with Gene. Finally, we report the identification of two independent missense variants in Species Gene, Protein Mutation and Protein Mutation, in a cohort of Species with forebrain and/or Disease. We demonstrate that these variants exhibit reduced repressing activity in vitro and in vivo relative to wild-type Gene. Together, our data provide support for a conserved molecular function of Gene as a transcriptional repressor during HP axis development in mammals and identify variants in this transcription factor that are likely to contribute to the etiology of Chemical.

23661717.pub_title: Reduced Chemical channel function unmasks residual embryonic slow conduction in the adult right ventricular outflow tract.
23661717.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: In Species with Disease, Disease typically originate in the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT). The RVOT develops from the slowly conducting embryonic outflow tract. OBJECTIVE: We hypothesize that this embryonic phenotype is maintained in the fetal and adult RVOT and leads to conduction slowing, especially after Chemical current reduction. METHODS AND RESULTS: We determined expression patterns in the Disease and performed activation mapping in fetal and adult hearts, including hearts from adult Species heterozygous for a mutation associated with Disease (Scn5a1798insD/+). The embryonic RVOT was characterized by expression of Gene, a repressor of differentiation, and absence of expression of both Gene, a ventricular transcription factor, and Gene, encoding the principal gap-junction subunit for ventricular fast conduction. Also, conduction velocity was lower in the RVOT than in the right ventricular free wall. Later in the development, Gene and Gene expression remained lower in the subepicardial myocardium of the RVOT than in RV myocardium. Nevertheless, conduction velocity in the adult RVOT was similar to that of the right ventricular free wall. However, in hearts of Scn5a1798insD/+ Species and in normal hearts treated with Chemical, conduction was slower in the RVOT than in the right ventricular wall. CONCLUSIONS: The slowly conducting embryonic phenotype is maintained in the fetal and adult RVOT and is unmasked when cardiac Chemical channel function is reduced.

27810937.pub_title: Deficiency of Gene-Confined Gene Expression in the Dorsal Motor Nucleus of Vagus Causes Disease.
27810937.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is an RNA-binding protein and translational regulator. To understand the physiological function of Gene, we generated Gene knock-out (KO) Species and found that most died within 3 d after birth. Gene is highly expressed in the brainstem, which controls vital functions, such as breathing. Whole-body plethysmography revealed that KO neonates had aberrant respiration with frequent Disease. Nevertheless, the morphology and function of the respiratory rhythm generator and diaphragm neuromuscular junctions appeared normal.
