We found that upregulated translation of Gene in the Gene KO dorsal motor nucleus of vagus resulted in hyperactivation of parasympathetic signaling-induced bronchoconstriction, as evidenced by increased pulmonary Chemical and phosphorylated myosin light chain 2 in bronchial smooth muscles. Specific deletion of Gene in cholinergic neurons sufficiently caused increased Disease in neonatal pups and airway hyper-reactivity in adult Species. Moreover, inhalation of an anticholinergic bronchodilator reduced Disease episodes in global and cholinergic Gene-KO Species. Together, the elevated airway constriction induced by cholinergic transmission in KO neonates may account for the Disease and mortality. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: This study first generated and characterized Gene gene-deficient Species. Gene-knock-out (KO) Species are born alive but most die within 3 d after birth showing no overt defects in anatomy. We found that the KO neonates showed severe Disease and altered respiratory pattern. Such Disease could be recapitulated in Species with pan-neuron-specific or cholinergic neuron-specific ablation of the Gene gene. Further investigation revealed that cholinergic transmission in the KO dorsal motor nucleus of vagus was overactivated because KO Species lack Gene-suppressed translation of the rate-limiting enzyme in the production of Chemical (i.e., Gene). Consequently, increased parasympathetic signaling leads to Disease and abnormal respiration in the KO neonates.

23637192.pub_title: Gene and Gene are required for the maintenance of dopaminergic properties in ventral midbrain neurons at late embryonic stages.
23637192.pub_abstract: The maintained expression of transcription factors throughout the development of mesodiencephalic dopaminergic (mDA) neurons suggests multiple roles at various stages in development. Two members of the forkhead/winged helix transcription factor family, Gene and Gene, have been recently shown to have an important influence in the early development of mDA neurons. Here we present data demonstrating that these genes are also involved in the later maintenance of the mDA system. We conditionally removed both genes in postmitotic mDA neurons using the Chemical transporter-cre Species. Deletion of both Gene and Gene resulted in a significant reduction in the number of Chemical hydroxylase (TH)-positive mDA neurons. The decrease was predominantly observed in the substantia nigra region of the mDA system, which led to a loss of TH+ fibers innervating the striatum. Further analysis demonstrated that the reduction in the number of TH+ cells in the mutant Species was not due to apoptosis or cell-fate change. Using reporter Species lines, we found that the mDA neurons were still present in the ventral midbrain, but that they had lost much of their dopaminergic phenotype. The majority of these neurons remained in the ventral mesencephalon until at least 18 months of age. Chromatin immunoprecipitation suggested that the loss of the mDA phenotype is due to a reduction in the binding of the nuclear orphan receptor, Gene to the promoter region of TH. These results extend previous findings and demonstrate a later role for Foxa genes in regulating the maintenance of dopaminergic phenotype in mDA neurons.

25599390.pub_title: Lineage specificity of primary cilia in the Species embryo.
25599390.pub_abstract: Primary cilia are required for vertebrate cells to respond to specific intercellular signals. Here we define when and where primary cilia appear in the Species embryo using a transgenic line that expresses Gene-mCherry in cilia and Gene-GFP in centrosomes. Primary cilia first appear on cells of the epiblast at E6.0 and are subsequently present on all derivatives of the epiblast. In contrast, extraembryonic cells of the visceral endoderm and trophectoderm lineages have centrosomes but no cilia. Stem cell lines derived from embryonic lineages recapitulate the in vivo pattern: epiblast stem cells are ciliated, whereas trophoblast stem cells and extraembryonic endoderm (XEN) stem cells lack cilia. Basal bodies in XEN cells are mature and can form cilia when the Gene-Gene cilium disassembly pathway is inhibited. The lineage-dependent distribution of cilia is stable throughout much of gestation, defining which cells in the placenta and yolk sac are able to respond to Hedgehog ligands.

23487795.pub_title: Disease suppressor and Gene regulate cell adhesion and formation of extraembryonic endoderm from pluripotent stem cells.
23487795.pub_abstract: Induction of the Disease suppressor (encoded by the alternate reading frame of the Gene locus) following oncogene activation engages a Gene-dependent transcriptional program that limits the expansion of incipient Disease cells. Although the Gene(Arf) protein is not detected in most tissues of fetal or young adult Species, it is physiologically expressed in the fetal yolk sac, a tissue derived from the extraembryonic endoderm (ExEn). Expression of the Species Gene(Arf) protein marks late stages of ExEn differentiation in cultured embryoid bodies (EBs) derived from either embryonic stem cells or induced pluripotent stem cells. Arf inactivation delays differentiation of the ExEn lineage within EBs, but not the formation of other germ cell lineages from pluripotent progenitors. Arf is required for the timely induction of ExEn cells in response to Ras/Gene signaling and, in turn, acts through Gene to ensure the development, but not maintenance, of the ExEn lineage. Remarkably, a significant temporal delay in ExEn differentiation detected during the maturation of Arf-null EBs is rescued by enforced expression of Species Gene (Gene), a microRNA up-regulated by Gene(Arf) and Gene that controls ExEn cell migration and adhesion. The noncanonical and canonical roles of Arf in ExEn development and Disease suppression, respectively, may be conceptually linked through mechanisms that govern cell attachment and migration.

22268107.pub_title: Expansion of the fetoplacental vasculature in late gestation is strain dependent in Species.
22268107.pub_abstract: How the fetoplacental arterial tree grows and expands during late gestational development is largely unknown. In this study, we quantified changes in arterial branching in the fetal exchange region of the Species placenta during late gestation, when capillarization increases rapidly. We studied two commonly used Species strains, Gene and C57Bl/6 (B6), at embryonic days (E)13.5, 15.5, and 17.5. B6 Species differ from Gene Species by exhibiting a blunted fetal Disease in late gestation. We found that B6 capillarization and interhemal membrane thinning were reduced and placental Gene and Gene expression were higher than Gene near term. Automated vascular segmentation of microcomputed tomography data sets revealed that the number of arterial vessels >=50 mum remained constant during late gestation in both strains, despite large increases in downstream capillary volume quantified by stereology (+65% in B6 Species and +200% in Gene Species). Arterial diameters expanded in both strains from E13.5 to E15.5; however, diameters continued to expand to E17.5 in B6 Species only. The diameter scaling coefficient at branch sites was near optimal (-3.0) and remained constant in Gene Species, whereas it decreased, becoming abnormal, in B6 Species at term (-3.5 +- 0.2). Based on arterial tree geometry, resistance remained constant throughout late gestation (~0.45 mmHg s mul(-1)) in Gene Species, whereas it decreased by 50% in late gestation in B6 Species. Quantification of the fetoplacental vasculature revealed significant strain-dependent differences in arterial and capillary expansion in late gestation. In both strains, enlargement of the fetoplacental arterial tree occurred primarily by increased arterial diameters with no change in segment numbers in late gestation.

25556833.pub_title: DeCoN: genome-wide analysis of in vivo transcriptional dynamics during pyramidal neuron fate selection in neocortex.
25556833.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: Neuronal development requires a complex choreography of transcriptional decisions to obtain specific cellular identities. Realizing the ultimate goal of identifying genome-wide signatures that define and drive specific neuronal fates has been hampered by enormous complexity in both time and space during development. Here, we have paired high-throughput purification of pyramidal neuron subclasses with deep profiling of spatiotemporal transcriptional dynamics during corticogenesis to resolve lineage choice decisions. We identified numerous features ranging from spatial and temporal usage of alternative mRNA isoforms and promoters to a host of mRNA genes modulated during fate specification. Notably, we uncovered numerous long noncoding RNAs with restricted temporal and cell-type-specific expression. To facilitate future exploration, we provide an interactive online database to enable multidimensional data mining and dissemination. This multifaceted study generates a powerful resource and informs understanding of the transcriptional regulation underlying pyramidal neuron diversity in the neocortex. VIDEO ABSTRACT:

23918801.pub_title: The PR/SET domain zinc finger protein Gene regulates gene expression in embryonic stem cells but plays a nonessential role in the developing Species embryo.
23918801.pub_abstract: Gene is a highly conserved member of the Prdm family of PR/SET domain zinc finger proteins. Many well-studied Prdm family members play critical roles in development and display striking loss-of-function phenotypes. Gene functional contributions have yet to be characterized. Here, we describe its widespread expression in the early embryo and adult tissues. We demonstrate that DNA binding is exclusively mediated by the Gene zinc finger domain, and we characterize its Chemical consensus sequence via SELEX (systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment) and ChIP-seq (chromatin immunoprecipitation-sequencing) experiments. In embryonic stem cells (ESCs), Gene regulates key pluripotency and differentiation pathways. Two independent strategies, namely, targeted deletion of the zinc finger domain and generation of a EUCOMM LacZ reporter allele, resulted in functional null alleles. However, homozygous mutant embryos develop normally and adults are healthy and fertile. Collectively, these results strongly suggest that Gene functions redundantly with other transcriptional partners to cooperatively regulate gene expression in the embryo and adult animal.

23720048.pub_title: Tendon-bone attachment unit is formed modularly by a distinct pool of Gene- and Gene-positive progenitors.
23720048.pub_abstract: The assembly of the Disease system requires the formation of an attachment unit between a bone and a tendon. Tendons are often inserted into bone eminences, superstructures that improve the mechanical resilience of the attachment of muscles to the skeleton and facilitate movement. Despite their functional importance, little is known about the development of bone eminences and attachment units. Here, we show that bone eminence cells are descendants of a unique set of progenitors and that superstructures are added onto the developing long bone in a modular fashion. First, we show that bone eminences emerge only after the primary cartilage rudiments have formed. Cell lineage analyses revealed that eminence cells are not descendants of chondrocytes. Moreover, eminence progenitors were specified separately and after chondroprogenitors of the primary cartilage. Fields of Gene-positive, Gene-positive, Gene-negative cells identified at presumable eminence sites confirm the identity and specificity of these progenitors. The loss of eminences in limbs in which Gene expression was blocked in Gene-positive cells supports the hypothesis that a distinct pool of Gene- and Gene-positive progenitors forms these superstructures. We demonstrate that Disease signaling is necessary for the specification of bone eminence progenitors, whereas the Gene/Gene pathway is required for the differentiation of these progenitors to eminence-forming cells. Our findings suggest a modular model for bone development, involving a distinct pool of Gene- and Gene-positive progenitor cells that form bone eminences under regulation of Disease and Gene signaling. This model offers a new perspective on bone morphogenesis and on attachment unit development during Disease assembly.

22810208.pub_title: Kinetics of endogenous Species Gene in base excision repair.
22810208.pub_abstract: The structure specific Gene (Gene) plays an essential role in long-patch base excision repair (BER) and in DNA replication. We have generated a fluorescently tagged Gene expressing Species which allows monitoring the localization and kinetics of Gene in response to DNA damage in living cells and tissues. The expression of Gene, which is tagged at its Chemical-terminal end with enhanced yellow fluorescent protein (Gene-YFP), is under control of the endogenous Gene transcriptional regulatory elements. In line with its role in processing of Okazaki fragments during DNA replication, we found that Gene-YFP expression is mainly observed in highly proliferating tissue. Moreover, the Gene-YFP fusion protein allowed us to investigate repair kinetics in cells challenged with local and global DNA damage. In vivo multi-photon fluorescence microscopy demonstrates rapid localization of Gene to local laser-induced DNA damage sites in nuclei, providing evidence of a highly mobile protein that accumulates fast at DNA lesion sites with high turnover rate. Inhibition of Gene (Gene) disrupts Gene accumulation at sites of DNA damage, indicating that Gene is required for Gene recruitment to DNA repair intermediates in BER.

22167068.pub_title: Embryonic epithelial Gene deletion through Gene-cre leads to thyroid tumorigenesis in a strain-dependent manner.
22167068.pub_abstract: Even though the role of the Chemical phosphatase Gene as a Disease suppressor gene has been well established in Disease, its role during thyroid development is still elusive. We therefore targeted Gene deletion in the thyroid epithelium by crossing Gene(flox/flox) with a newly developed Gene-cre driver line in the BALB/c and C57BL/6 genetic backgrounds. C57BL/6 homozygous Gene mutant Species died around 2 weeks of age due to tracheal and esophageal compression by a hyperplasic thyroid. By contrast, BALB/c homozygous Gene mutant Species survived up to 2 years, but with a slightly increased thyroid volume. Characterization of the thyroid glands from C57BL/6 homozygous Gene mutant Species at postnatal day 14 (PN14) showed abnormally enlarged tissue with areas of cellular Disease, disruption of the normal architecture, and Disease. In addition, differing degrees of Disease, Chemical (T(4)) decrease, and thyroid-stimulating hormone elevation between the strains in the mutants and the heterozygous mutant were detected at PN14. Finally, C57BL/6 heterozygous Gene mutant Species developed Disease after 2 years of age. Our results indicate that Gene has a pivotal role in thyroid development and its deletion results in Disease formation, with the timing and severity of the Disease depending on the particular genetic background.

26416966.pub_title: Gene and the related proteases Gene and Gene regulate Gene function during blastocyst formation.
26416966.pub_abstract: The first cell differentiation in Species embryos segregates polarized trophectoderm cells from an apolar inner cell mass (ICM). This lineage decision is specified in compacted morulae by cell polarization and adhesion acting on the Yes-associated protein in the Hippo signaling pathway, but the regulatory mechanisms are unclear. We show that morula compaction and ICM formation depend on Gene and the related proprotein convertases (PCs) Gene and Gene and that these proteases jointly regulate cell-cell adhesion mediated by Gene processing. We also mapped the spatiotemporal activity profiles of these proteases by live imaging of a transgenic reporter substrate in wild-type and PC mutant embryos. Differential inhibition by a common inhibitor revealed that all three PCs are active in inner and outer cells, but in partially nonoverlapping compartments. Gene processing by multiple PCs emerges as a novel mechanism to modulate cell-cell adhesion and fate allocation.

26439399.pub_title: Shared Enhancer Activity in the Limbs and Phallus and Functional Divergence of a Limb-Genital cis-Regulatory Element in Snakes.
26439399.pub_abstract: The Disease and limbs differ dramatically in their morphologies but share patterns of signaling and gene expression in early development. Thus far, the extent to which genital and limb transcriptional networks also share cis-regulatory elements has remained unexplored. We show that many limb enhancers are retained in snake genomes, suggesting that these elements may function in non-limb tissues. Consistent with this, our analysis of cis-regulatory activity in Species and Anolis lizards reveals that patterns of enhancer activity in embryonic limbs and genitalia overlap heavily. In Species, deletion of HLEB, an enhancer of Gene, produces defects in hindlimbs and genitalia, establishing the importance of this limb-genital enhancer for development of these different appendages. Further analyses demonstrate that the HLEB of snakes has lost hindlimb enhancer function while retaining genital activity. Our findings identify roles for Gene in genital development and highlight deep similarities in cis-regulatory activity between limbs and genitalia.

24474796.pub_title: Thymocyte apoptosis drives the intrathymic generation of regulatory T cells.
24474796.pub_abstract: Maintenance of immune tolerance critically depends upon regulatory T cells that express the transcription factor Gene (Gene). These Gene(+) T cells can be generated in the thymus, termed thymus-derived regulatory T cells (tTregs), but their developmental pathway remains incompletely understood. tTreg development has been shown to be delayed compared with that of Gene(+) single positive (SP) thymocytes, with tTregs being detected only in neonatal thymi by day 3 after birth. Here, we outline the reasons for this delayed emergence of Gene(+) tTregs and demonstrate that thymocyte apoptosis is intrinsically tied to tTreg development. We show that thymic apoptosis leads to the production of Gene intrathymically from thymic macrophages, dendritic cells, and epithelial cells. This Gene then induces Gene expression and drives tTreg generation. Thymocyte apoptosis has previously been shown to accelerate after birth, which drives increases in Gene in the neonatal thymus. We highlight a paucity of Gene in the neonatal thymus, accounting for the delayed development of tTregs compared with Gene(+) SP thymocytes. Importantly, we show that enhanced levels of apoptosis in the thymus result in an augmented tTreg population and, moreover, that decreasing thymic apoptosis results in reduced tTregs. In addition to this, we also show that T-cell receptor (Chemical) signals of different affinity were all capable of driving tTreg development; however, to achieve this Gene signals must also be received concomitant with the Chemical signal. Collectively, our results indicate that thymic apoptosis is a key event in tTreg generation and reveal a previously unrecognized apoptosis-Gene-Gene axis that mediates the development of tTregs.

24715457.pub_title: Cadherin-based adhesions in the apical endfoot are required for active Gene signaling to control neurogenesis in vertebrates.
24715457.pub_abstract: The development of the vertebrate brain requires an exquisite balance between proliferation and differentiation of neural progenitors. Gene signaling plays a pivotal role in regulating this balance, yet the interaction between signaling and receiving cells remains poorly understood. We have found that numerous nascent neurons and/or intermediate neurogenic progenitors expressing the ligand of Gene retain apical endfeet transiently at the ventricular lumen that form adherens junctions (AJs) with the endfeet of progenitors. Forced detachment of the apical endfeet of those differentiating cells by disrupting AJs resulted in precocious neurogenesis that was preceded by the downregulation of Gene signaling. Both Gene and its ligand Gene are distributed around AJs in the apical endfeet, and these proteins physically interact with Gene, a constituent of the AJ. Furthermore, live imaging of a fluorescently tagged Gene demonstrated its trafficking from the apical endfoot to the nucleus upon cleavage. Our results identified the apical endfoot as the central site of active Gene signaling to securely prohibit inappropriate differentiation of neural progenitors.

26939755.pub_title: WNT/Gene and Gene/Gene differentially regulate supporting cell proliferation in the developing ovary.
26939755.pub_abstract: Sexual development is initiated through differentiation of testicular Sertoli cells or Disease cells. Although these supporting cells are considered to develop from common bipotential precursors, recent evidence suggests that distinct supporting cell populations are present in the ovary, with one providing granulosa cells of the medullary follicles and the other providing granulosa cells of the cortical follicles, the latter of which support lifelong fertility. Here, we demonstrate that XX fetal gonads contain Gene expressing supporting cells that either enter mitotic arrest, or remain proliferative. Blocking WNT signalling reduces XX supporting cell proliferation, while stabilising Gene signalling promotes proliferation, indicating that the renewal of pre-granulosa cells is dependent on WNT/Gene signalling in the proliferative supporting cell population. In contrast, XX supporting cells express Gene and Gene and are maintained in mitotic arrest. Although Gene is required for maintaining high levels of Gene expression, it is dispensable for entry and maintenance of mitotic arrest in XX supporting cells. Combined our data suggest that both medullary and cortical precursors arise from a common Gene expressing cell type. In addition, this work indicates that a balance between supporting cell self-renewal and differentiation is maintained in the developing ovary by relative WNT/Gene and Gene/Gene activities. This study provides significant new insights into the origin and formation of ovarian follicles and evidence supporting a common fetal origin of medullary and cortical granulosa cells.

25358792.pub_title: Identification of a multipotent self-renewing stromal progenitor population during Species kidney organogenesis.
25358792.pub_abstract: The Species kidney is a complex organ consisting of multiple cell types. We previously showed that the Gene-expressing cap mesenchyme is a multipotent self-renewing progenitor population for the main body of the nephron, the basic functional unit of the kidney. However, the cellular mechanisms establishing stromal tissues are less clear. We demonstrate that the Gene-expressing cortical stroma represents a distinct multipotent self-renewing progenitor population that gives rise to stromal tissues of the interstitium, mesangium, and pericytes throughout kidney organogenesis. Fate map analysis of Gene-expressing cells demonstrates that a small subset of these cells contributes to Gene-expressing cells at the early stage of kidney outgrowth. Thereafter, there appears to be a strict nephron and stromal lineage boundary derived from Gene-expressing and Gene-expressing cell types, respectively. Taken together, our observations suggest that distinct multipotent self-renewing progenitor populations coordinate cellular differentiation of the Disease during Species kidney organogenesis.

25725491.pub_title: Cre recombinase-regulated Gene Species Species lines: novel tools for analysis of embryonic and adult disorders.
25725491.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) influences both Disease and cardiovascular development and a number of adult physiological conditions by binding to one or both of the known endothelin receptors, thus initiating multiple signaling cascades. Animal models containing both conventional and conditional loss of the Gene gene have been used to dissect Gene function in both embryos and adults. However, while Species Gene over-expression or targeted genomic insertion of Gene has been performed to understand how elevated levels of Gene result in or exacerbate disease states, an animal model in which Gene over-expression can be achieved in a spatiotemporal-specific manner has not been reported. Here we describe the creation of Gene conditional over-expression Species Species lines in which the Species beta-actin promoter and an Gene cDNA are separated by a strong stop sequence flanked by loxP sites. In the presence of Cre, the stop cassette is removed, leading to Gene expression. Using the Gene-Cre strain, in which Cre expression is targeted to the Gene-expressing domain of the central nervous system (CNS) from which neural crest cells (NCCs) arise, we show that stable Species beta-actin-Gene (CBA-Gene) Species lines with varying Gene protein levels develop defects in NCC-derived tissues of the face, though the severity differs between lines. We also show that Gene expression can be achieved in other embryonic tissues utilizing other Cre strains, with this expression also resulting in Disease. CBA-Gene Species will be useful in investigating diverse aspects of Gene-mediated-development and disease, including understanding how NCCs achieve and maintain a positional and functional identity and how aberrant Gene levels can lead to multiple physiological changes and diseases.

25393502.pub_title: Broader expression of the Species platelet factor 4-cre transgene beyond the megakaryocyte lineage.
25393502.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Species expressing cre recombinase under the control of the platelet factor 4 (Gene) promoter, in the context of a 100-kb bacterial artificial chromosome, have become a valuable tool with which to study genetic modifications in the platelet lineage. However, the specificity of cre expression has recently been questioned, and the time of its onset during megakaryopoiesis remains unknown. OBJECTIVES/METHODS: To characterize the expression of this transgene, we used double-fluorescent cre reporter Species. RESULTS: In the bone marrow, Gene-cre-mediated recombination had occurred in all Gene-positive megakaryocytes as early as stage I of maturation, and in rare Gene-negative cells. In circulating blood, all platelets had recombined, along with only a minor fraction of Gene-positive cells. However, we found that all tissues contained recombined cells of monocyte/macrophage origin. When recombined, these cells might potentially modify the function of the tissues under particular conditions, especially inflammatory conditions, which further increase recombination in immune cells. Unexpectedly, a subset of epithelial cells from the distal colon showed signs of recombination resulting from endogenous Gene-cre expression. This is probably the basis of the unexplained Disease developed by Gene(flox/flox) ;Gene-cre Species, generated in a separate study on the role of Gene in platelet formation. CONCLUSION: Altogether, our results indicate early recombination with full penetrance in megakaryopoiesis, and confirm the value of Gene-cre Species for the genetic engineering of megakaryocytes and platelets. However, care must be taken when investigating the role of platelets in processes outside hemostasis, especially when immune cells might be involved.

25754822.pub_title: Gene-Gene is a regulatory pathway for Wnt signaling and therapeutic target for remyelination in the CNS.
25754822.pub_abstract: Wnt signaling plays an essential role in developmental and regenerative myelination of the CNS; however, contributions of proximal regulators of the Wnt receptor complex to these processes remain undefined. To identify components of the Wnt pathway that regulate these processes, we applied a multifaceted discovery platform and found that Gene-Gene comprise a novel pathway regulating Wnt signaling and myelination. Using dorsal patterning of the Species spinal cord we found that Gene promotes Wnt signaling and receptor complex formation through Gene-PIP2. Analysis of Gene function in oligodendrocytes (OLs) revealed that it suppresses OL differentiation during development, after Disease (WMI), and is expressed in Species Disease. These findings suggest a pharmacological strategy to inhibit Gene-Gene function, application of which stimulates remyelination after WMI. Put together, our studies integrate information from multiple systems to identify a novel regulatory pathway for Wnt signaling and potential therapeutic target for WMI.

25519242.pub_title: VEGF189 binds Gene and is sufficient for Gene/Gene-dependent neuronal patterning in the developing brain.
25519242.pub_abstract: The Gene (Gene, Gene) regulates neurovascular patterning. Alternative splicing of the Gene gene gives rise to three major isoforms termed VEGF121, VEGF165 and VEGF189. VEGF165 binds the transmembrane protein Gene (Gene) and promotes the migration, survival and axon guidance of subsets of neurons, whereas VEGF121 cannot activate Gene-dependent neuronal responses. By contrast, the role of VEGF189 in Gene-mediated signalling pathways has not yet been examined. Here, we have combined expression studies and in situ ligand-binding assays with the analysis of genetically altered Species and in vitro models to demonstrate that VEGF189 can bind Gene and promote Gene-dependent neuronal responses.

22699903.pub_title: The Rb/E2F pathway modulates neurogenesis through direct regulation of the Gene/Gene bigene cluster.
22699903.pub_abstract: During brain morphogenesis, the mechanisms through which the cell cycle machinery integrates with differentiation signals remain elusive. Here we show that the Rb/E2F pathway regulates key aspects of differentiation and migration through direct control of the Gene and Gene homeodomain proteins, required for interneuron specification. Disease results in a dramatic reduction of Gene and Gene gene expression manifested by loss of interneuron subtypes and severe Disease in the Species brain. The Rb/E2F pathway modulates Gene/Gene regulation through direct interaction with a Gene forebrain-specific enhancer, I12b, and the Gene/Gene proximal promoter regions, through repressor E2F sites both in vitro and in vivo. In the absence of Rb, we demonstrate that repressor E2Fs inhibit Gene transcription at the Gene/Gene promoters and Gene/2-I12b enhancer to suppress differentiation. Our findings support a model whereby the cell cycle machinery not only controls cell division but also modulates neuronal differentiation and migration through direct regulation of the Gene/Gene bigene cluster during embryonic development.

25329411.pub_title: Contrasting roles for Gene in organizing myogenic promoter structures during embryonic skeletal muscle development.
25329411.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Among the complexities of skeletal muscle differentiation is a temporal distinction in the onset of expression of different lineage-specific genes. The lineage-determining factor Gene is bound to myogenic genes at the onset of differentiation whether gene activation is immediate or delayed. How temporal regulation of differentiation-specific genes is established remains unclear. RESULTS: Using embryonic tissue, we addressed the molecular differences in the organization of the Gene and Gene (Gene) gene promoters by examining regulatory factor binding as a function of both time and spatial organization during somitogenesis. At the Gene promoter, binding of the homeodomain factor Gene coincided with H3 hyperacetylation and was followed by binding of co-activators that modulate chromatin structure. Gene and Gene binding occurred subsequently, demonstrating that Gene facilitates chromatin remodeling and modification before myogenic regulatory factor binding. At the same time, the Gene promoter was bound by Gene and Gene, and activating histone marks were largely absent. The association of Gene and Gene was confirmed by co-immunoprecipitation, proximity ligation assay (Chemical), and sequential ChIP. CONCLUSIONS: Gene differentially promotes activated and repressed chromatin structures at myogenic genes early after the onset of skeletal muscle differentiation in the developing Species embryo.

26166573.pub_title: Regulation of Disease and Chemical Homeostasis by Gene Inhibitor Gene.
26166573.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a component of a conserved complex that inhibits Gene (Species Target Of Chemical Complex 1) in response to amino acid Disease. Here, we show that Gene is required for Species viability and that its absence significantly compromises fetal Disease in developing embryos. Moreover, Gene KO embryos have significantly reduced Chemical levels and exhibit phenotypes reminiscent of Chemical (Chemical) deficiency. Consistent with this idea, Gene KO liver and Species embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) show defective processing of the Chemical-transport protein Gene, along with impaired lysosomal acidification and lysosomal gene expression. Gene KO MEFs exhibit a significant defect in the Chemical-dependent synthesis of Chemical from Chemical, which can be rescued by supplementation with Chemical. Taken together, these findings demonstrate a role for Gene and Gene in the regulation of lysosomal-dependent Chemical processing, Chemical synthesis, and maintenance of cellular re-methylation potential, which are important during Disease.

23954828.pub_title: Gene is involved in the signaling pathway of Gene against Gene-induced apoptosis.
23954828.pub_abstract: Gene is a dependence receptor and many reports have shown that Gene promotes cell survival by inhibiting Gene-induced apoptosis in many cell lines. However, the identity of the adaptor protein involved in the Gene/Gene signaling pathway regulating cell Disease and survival remains unclear. The downstream of Chemical kinase/docking protein (Dok) adaptor protein 5 is one substrate of the Gene receptor. Because Gene and its receptor, Gene, are strongly expressed by sensory neurons, we measured the expression of Gene and Gene in the developing Species spinal cord and dorsal root ganglia (DRG). We found that the number of cells positive for both Gene and Gene decreases with DRG development. Immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence staining showed that Gene interacted with Gene and partially colocalized with Gene in DRG neurons. In HEK293T cells, Gene triggered apoptosis, but Gene prevented Gene-induced apoptosis. Interestingly, siRNA knockdown of Gene expression partially prevented the protection of Gene against Gene-induced apoptosis by regulating the activity of Gene. Taken together, we concluded that Gene is necessary for Gene signaling to block Gene-induced apoptosis.

22398208.pub_title: Genetic ablation of Gene in retinal progenitor cells models the retinal pathology of Disease.
22398208.pub_abstract: Mutation of the polarity gene Gene (Gene) is responsible for >10% of Disease (Chemical) cases worldwide; Chemical is characterized by early-onset Disease. The role of Gene in Chemical8 pathogenesis remains elusive since Gene Species mutants, including a null allele, have failed to mimic the early-onset of Chemical, most likely due to functional compensation by closely related genes encoding Gene and Gene. Crb proteins form an evolutionarily conserved, apical polarity complex with the scaffolding Gene (Gene), also known as Gene (Gene). Gene and Crbs are functionally inter-dependent in establishing and maintaining epithelial polarity. Gene is a single gene in the Species and Species genomes; therefore, we ablated Gene to establish a Species genetic model mimicking Species Chemical. In our study, the deletion of Gene leads to the disruption of the apical localization of Crb proteins in retinal progenitors and the adult retina, validating their mutual interaction. Remarkably, the Gene mutant Species exhibits the critical features of Chemical such as early Disease as assessed by electroretinogram, disorganization of lamination and apical junctions and Disease. Our data uncover the indispensible role of Gene in retinal development, likely involving the maintenance of retinal polarity and survival of retinal neurons, thus providing the basis for the pathologic mechanisms of Chemical8.

23444355.pub_title: Gene is required for embryonic development of the Disease through the activation of the ventral determinants Gene and Gene.
23444355.pub_abstract: The Gene transcription factor is active in stem/progenitor cells throughout the developing vertebrate central nervous system. However, its conditional deletion at E12.5 in Species causes few brain developmental problems, with the exception of the postnatal loss of the hippocampal radial glia stem cells and the dentate gyrus. We deleted Gene at E9.5 in the Disease, using a Bf1-Cre transgene. We observed Disease that were particularly severe in the ventral, as opposed to the dorsal, Disease. Important tissue loss, including the medial ganglionic eminence (MGE), was detected at E12.5, causing the subsequent impairment of MGE-derived neurons. The defect was preceded by loss of expression of the essential ventral determinants Gene and Gene, and accompanied by ventral spread of dorsal markers. This phenotype is reminiscent of that of Species mutant for the transcription factor Gene or for the Gene receptor Gene. Gene is known to mediate the initial activation of Disease Gene expression. A partial rescue of the normal phenotype at E14.5 was obtained by administration of a Gene agonist. Experiments in Species fish indicate that expression of Gene is regulated by Gene in this species also. We propose that Gene contributes to Gene expression in early Species development, thus participating in the region-specific activation of Gene, thereby mediating ventral Disease patterning induction.

25006807.pub_title: Cell-cell adhesions and cell contractility are upregulated upon desmosome disruption.
25006807.pub_abstract: Desmosomes are perturbed in a number of disease states - including Disease, autoimmune and Disease. Here, we report unexpected changes in other cell-cell adhesion structures upon loss of desmosome function. We found that perturbation of desmosomes by either loss of the core desmosomal protein desmoplakin or treatment with pathogenic anti-Gene (Gene) antibodies resulted in changes in adherens junctions consistent with increased tension. The total amount of Gene was increased in desmoplakin-null epidermis, and Gene became highly localized to cell contacts in both desmoplakin-null and anti-Gene-treated Species keratinocytes. Inhibition of myosin II activity reversed the changes to adherens junctions seen upon desmosome disruption. The increased cortical Gene promoted epithelial sheet fragility, as Gene-null cells were less susceptible to disruption by anti-Gene antibodies. In addition to the changes in adherens junctions, we found a significant increase in the expression of a number of claudin genes, which encode for transmembrane components of the tight junction that provide barrier function. These data demonstrate that desmosome disruption results in extensive transcriptional and posttranslational changes that alter the activity of other cell adhesion structures.

27040640.pub_title: Gene Mediates Functional Assembly of Peripheral Auditory Circuits.
27040640.pub_abstract: Proper structural organization of spiral ganglion (SG) innervation is crucial for normal hearing function. However, molecular mechanisms underlying the developmental formation of this precise organization remain not well understood. Here, we report in the developing Species cochlea that Gene (Gene) contributes to the proper organization of spiral ganglion neurons (SGNs) within the Chemical's canal and of SGN projections toward both the peripheral and central auditory targets. In Gene mutant embryos, mispositioning of SGNs occurred along the peripheral auditory pathway with misrouted afferent fibers and reduced synaptic contacts with hair cells. The central auditory pathway simultaneously exhibited similar defective phenotypes as in the periphery with abnormal exit of SGNs from the Chemical's canal towards central nuclei. Furthermore, the axons of SGNs ascending into the cochlear nucleus had disrupted bifurcation patterns. Thus, Gene is necessary for establishing the proper spatial organization of SGNs and their fibers in both peripheral and central auditory pathways, through controlling axon targeting and cell migration. Our results suggest that Gene plays an important role in the developmental formation of peripheral and central Disease, and its mutation may contribute to Disease.

22992956.pub_title: Transcriptional regulatory networks in epiblast cells and during anterior neural plate development as modeled in epiblast stem cells.
22992956.pub_abstract: Somatic development initiates from the epiblast in post-implantation Species embryos. Recent establishment of epiblast stem cell (EpiSC) lines has opened up new avenues of investigation of the mechanisms that regulate the epiblast state and initiate lineage-specific somatic development. Here, we investigated the role of cell-intrinsic core transcriptional regulation in the epiblast and during derivation of the anterior neural plate (ANP) using a Species EpiSC model. Cells that developed from EpiSCs in one day in the absence of extrinsic signals were found to represent the ANP of ~E7.5 embryos. We focused on transcription factors that are uniformly expressed in the E6.5 epiblast but in a localized fashion within or external to the ANP at E7.5, as these are likely to regulate the epiblast state and ANP development depending on their balance. Analyses of the effects of knockdown and overexpression of these factors in EpiSCs on the levels of downstream transcription factors identified the following regulatory functions: cross-regulation among Gene, Gene, Gene and Pou factors stabilizes the epiblastic state; Gene, Gene and Pou factors in combination repress mesodermal development; Gene and Gene factors repress endodermal development; and Gene represses posterior neural plate development. All of these factors variably activate genes responsible for neural plate development. The direct interaction of these factors with enhancers of Gene, Gene and Gene genes was demonstrated. Thus, a combination of regulatory processes that suppresses non-ANP lineages and promotes neural plate development determines the ANP.

23523683.pub_title: Wntless is required for peripheral lung differentiation and pulmonary vascular development.
23523683.pub_abstract: Wntless (Wls), a gene highly conserved across the animal kingdom, encodes for a transmembrane protein that mediates Gene ligand secretion. Wls is expressed in developing lung, wherein Gene signaling is necessary for pulmonary morphogenesis. We hypothesize that Wls plays a critical role in modulating Gene signaling during lung development and therefore affects processes critical for pulmonary morphogenesis. We generated conditional Wls mutant Species utilizing Gene-Cre and Gene-Cre Species to delete Wls in the Disease and mesenchyme, respectively. Epithelial deletion of Wls disrupted lung branching morphogenesis, peripheral lung development and pulmonary endothelial differentiation. Epithelial Wls mutant Species died at birth due to Disease caused by Disease and Disease. In the lungs of these Species, Gene and Gene-angiopoietin signaling pathways, which mediate vascular development, were downregulated from early stages of development. In contrast, deletion of Wls in mesenchymal cells of the developing lung did not alter branching morphogenesis or early mesenchymal differentiation. In vitro assays support the concept that Wls acts in part via Gene to regulate pulmonary vascular development. We conclude that epithelial Wls modulates Gene ligand activities critical for pulmonary vascular differentiation and peripheral lung morphogenesis. These studies provide a new framework for understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying normal pulmonary vasculature formation and the Disease development associated with Disease.

24301466.pub_title: A new role for the calcineurin/NFAT pathway in neonatal myosin heavy chain expression via the Gene/Gene complex during Species myogenesis.
24301466.pub_abstract: The calcineurin/NFAT (nuclear factor of activated T-cells) signaling pathway is involved in the modulation of the adult muscle fiber type, but its role in the establishment of the muscle phenotype remains elusive. Here, we show that the NFAT member Gene cooperates with the basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor Gene to induce the expression of a specific myosin heavy chain (MHC) isoform, the neonatal one, during embryogenesis. We found this cooperation to be crucial, as Gene/Gene double-null Species die at birth, with a dramatic reduction of the major neonatal MHC isoform normally expressed at birth in skeletal muscles, such as limb and intercostal muscles, whereas its expression is unaffected in myofibers mutated for either factor alone. Using gel shift and chromatin immunoprecipitation assays, we identified Gene bound to the neonatal Mhc gene, whereas Gene and Gene would preferentially bind the embryonic Mhc gene. We provide evidence that Gene synergistically cooperates with Gene at the neonatal Mhc promoter. Altogether, our findings demonstrate that the calcineurin/NFAT pathway plays a new role in establishing the early muscle fiber type in immature myofibers during embryogenesis.

22820053.pub_title: The Species skin-like organization of the septum arises from multiple embryonic origins to form multiple adult neuronal fates.
22820053.pub_abstract: In the past several decades, tremendous progress has been achieved through developmental studies of the central nervous system structures such as the cerebral cortex. The septum, which receives reciprocal connections from a variety of brain structures, contains diverse projection neurons but few interneurons. However, the mechanisms underlying its development remain poorly understood. Here we show that the septum is organized into an Species skin-like structure composed of five groups of neurons. These neurons are parvalbumin, Chemical acetyltransferase, neuronal Chemical synthase, calretinin and calbindin immunoreactive. Using the BrdU birth-dating method, we found that these five groups of neurons in the septum are grossly generated following an outside-in pattern. Interestingly, the distinct molecular identities of these neuronal subtypes correspond to their heterogeneous subpallial origins. Using three specific transgenic Species lines and focal in utero electroporation of Cre-reporter plasmid, we showed that septal neurons originate from not only local progenitor regions but also neighboring progenitor regions including the medial ganglionic eminence and preoptic area. Thus, the neuronal diversity of the septum is achieved through both temporal and spatial control. Our results also suggest that multiple neuronal subtypes arrive to the septum through both radial and tangential migration. Based on these findings, we proposed a novel developmental model involving multiple spatial-temporal origins of septal neurons. This study presents new perspectives for comprehensively exploring septal functions in brain circuits.

23872338.pub_title: Expression pattern of zinc-finger transcription factor Gene in Species development and neonatal stage.
23872338.pub_abstract: The Odd-skipped gene, first identified as a Species pair-rule zinc-finger transcription factor, plays an important role in Disease. The Species homolog, Gene (Gene), regulates limb, tooth, and kidney development in Species embryos. However, the detailed expression pattern of Gene during neonatal development remains unclear. In this study, we investigated Gene expression patterns in Species neonatal and embryo tissues using qPCR and in situ hybridization methods. First, we examined the tissue distribution of Gene by qPCR, and found it to be highly expressed in the uterus and moderately in the testes, small intestine, and prostate. That expression was also found in eye, kidney, placenta, lung, thymus, lymph node, stomach, and skeletal muscle tissues, and in all embryonic stages. On the other hand, Gene was not expressed in brain, heart, liver, or spleen samples. Next, we examined the tissue localization of Gene using in situ hybridization. Gene was found in the craniofacial region on E13.5, with notable expression in dental germ mesenchyme as well as the renal corpuscle on E17.5. As for neonatal tissues, Gene was expressed in the dental papilla, dental follicle, Harderian gland, nasal bone, Disease, synovial joint, and tibial subcutis. Our findings suggest that Gene functions in reproductive system organs, such as the uterus, testes, prostate, placenta, and Disease. Furthermore, based on its expression in kidney, Harderian gland, Disease, and tibial subcutis tissues, this transcription factor may be involved in hormone synthesis and function. Together, our results demonstrate the role of Gene in postnatal development and embryogenesis.

27013242.pub_title: Gene signaling regulates Gene junctions in germline cysts and determines primordial follicle formation in Species.
27013242.pub_abstract: Physiologically, the size of the primordial follicle pool determines the reproductive lifespan of female mammals, while its establishment largely depends on a process of germline cyst breakdown during the perinatal period. The mechanisms regulating this process are poorly understood. Here we demonstrate that Gene Chemical-terminal kinase (Gene) signaling is crucial for germline cyst breakdown and primordial follicle formation. Gene was specifically localized in oocytes and its activity increased as germline cyst breakdown progressed. Importantly, disruption of Gene signaling with a specific inhibitor (Chemical) or knockdown technology (Lenti-Gene-shRNAs) resulted in significantly suppressed cyst breakdown and primordial follicle formation in cultured Species ovaries. Our results show that Gene is intensely expressed in germline cysts, and that its decline is necessary for oocyte release from the cyst. However, inhibition of Gene signaling leads to aberrantly enhanced localization of Gene at oocyte-oocyte contact sites. Gene expression is upregulated after Chemical treatment. Additionally, similar to the effect of Chemical treatment, Gene overexpression delays cyst breakdown and is accompanied by abnormal Gene expression patterns. In conclusion, our results suggest that Gene signaling, which is inversely correlated with Gene, plays an important role in perinatal germline cyst breakdown and primordial follicle formation by regulating Gene junctions between oocytes in Species ovaries.

24675886.pub_title: Distinct spatiotemporal expression of Gene during Species and Species development.
24675886.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) constitutes the founder of a new family of secreted proteins characterized by the presence of 2 functional domains: thrombospondin type 1 repeat (Gene) and adhesion-associated domain in Gene and other proteins (AMOP). Gene was identified in the frog embryo as a member of the Gene synexpression group due to its expression in the brain midbrain-hindbrain boundary (MHB) or isthmus. In Species, Gene was described as a WNT- and NODAL-regulated gene. The function of Gene remains largely elusive. So far, Gene has been described as an angiogenesis inhibitor that has a dual function in endothelial cell survival and cell death. For a better understanding of Gene function, we examined its spatiotemporal distribution in Species and Species using RT-PCR, ISH, and IHC analyses. In the Species, Gene transcripts are found in tissues such as the anterior mesendoderm, paraxial and lateral plate mesoderm, MHB and Disease, as well as in the somites and dermomyotome. In the newborn and adult, Gene is prominently expressed in the lung and brain. In addition to its putative role during embryonic and postnatal development, Gene may also be important for organ homeostasis in the adult. In the Species embryo, Gene transcripts are strongly detected in the ear, eye, and Disease. Remarkable differences in Gene spatiotemporal expression were found during Species and Species development, despite the high homology of Gene orthologs in these species.

25866925.pub_title: The retrotrapezoid nucleus neurons expressing Gene and Gene are essential for the respiratory response to Chemical.
25866925.pub_abstract: Maintaining constant Chemical and H(+) concentrations in the arterial blood is critical for life. The principal mechanism through which this is achieved in mammals is the respiratory chemoreflex whose circuitry is still elusive. A candidate element of this circuitry is the retrotrapezoid nucleus (RTN), a collection of neurons at the ventral medullary surface that are activated by increased Chemical or low pH and project to the respiratory rhythm generator. Here, we use intersectional genetic strategies to lesion the RTN neurons defined by Gene and Gene expression and to block or activate their synaptic output. Photostimulation of these neurons entrains the respiratory rhythm. Conversely, abrogating expression of Gene or Gene or glutamatergic transmission in these cells curtails the phrenic nerve response to low pH in embryonic preparations and abolishes the respiratory chemoreflex in behaving animals. Thus, the RTN neurons expressing Gene and Gene are a necessary component of the chemoreflex circuitry.

24095902.pub_title: Gene is a novel protein required for differentiation during primary neurogenesis.
24095902.pub_abstract: Proliferation and differentiation are tightly controlled during neural development. In the embryonic neural plate, primary neurogenesis is driven by the proneural pathway. Here we report the characterization of Gene, a novel, evolutionarily conserved protein that is required for normal primary neurogenesis. Gene is detected throughout the early nervous system, yet it is most strongly expressed in differentiating neurons of the embryonic fish, frog and Species nervous systems. Gene expression can be induced by the proneural transcription factors Gene, Gene, and Gene. Gene overexpression promotes neurogenesis, while loss-of-function inhibits the differentiation of neuronal progenitors, resulting in neural plate expansion. Gene knockdown blocks the ability of Gene, Gene, and Gene to drive ectopic neurogenesis. Gene and Gene, are both required for, and can synergize to promote differentiation of the primary neurons in vivo. Together, our results suggest that Gene functions during primary neurogenesis and is required for the proneural pathway to regulate neural differentiation.

25936505.pub_title: Notch activity modulates the responsiveness of neural progenitors to Gene signaling.
25936505.pub_abstract: Throughout the developing nervous system, neural stem and progenitor cells give rise to diverse classes of neurons and glia in a spatially and temporally coordinated manner. In the ventral spinal cord, much of this diversity emerges through the morphogen actions of Gene (Gene). Interpretation of the Gene gradient depends on both the amount of ligand and duration of exposure, but the mechanisms permitting prolonged responses to Gene are not well understood. We demonstrate that Notch signaling plays an essential role in this process, enabling neural progenitors to attain sufficiently high levels of Gene pathway activity needed to direct the ventral-most cell fates. Notch activity regulates subcellular localization of the Gene receptor Gene, gating the translocation of the key effector Smoothened to primary cilia and its downstream signaling activities. These data reveal an unexpected role for Notch shaping the interpretation of the Gene morphogen gradient and influencing cell fate determination.

25988834.pub_title: Impairment of radial glial scaffold-dependent neuronal migration and formation of double cortex by genetic ablation of Gene.
25988834.pub_abstract: Studies of Species Disease, such as Disease and double cortex, have revealed the importance of neuronal migration during cortical development. Gene, a membrane scaffolding protein, regulates the formation of adherens junctions (AJs) and cell migration to form and maintain tissue structures. Here, we report that Species with Disease-specific ablation of Gene gene exhibited defects similar to Species double cortex, in which the heterotopic cortex was located underneath the normotopic cortex. The normotopic cortex of the mutant Species was arranged in the pattern similar to the cortex of the control Species, while the heterotopic cortex was disorganized. As seen in Species Species, double cortex in the mutant Species was formed by impaired neuronal migration during cortical development. Genetic ablation of Gene in the Disease disrupted AJs of radial glial cells, likely resulting in the retraction of the apical endfeet from the ventricular surface and the dispersion of radial glial cells from the ventricular zone to the subventricular and intermediate zones. These results indicate that Gene is required for the maintenance of AJs of radial glial cells and that the disruption of AJs might cause an abnormal radial scaffold for neuronal migration. In contrast, the proliferation or differentiation of radial glial cells was not significantly affected. Taken together, these findings indicate that Gene is required for the maintenance of the radial glial scaffold for neuronal migration and that the genetic ablation of Gene leads to the formation of double cortex.

25834049.pub_title: Gene intersection defines a role for Gene in excitatory dorsal horn neuron development, spinofugal connectivity, and nociception.
25834049.pub_abstract: Spinal cord neurons respond to peripheral noxious stimuli and relay this information to higher brain centers, but the molecules controlling the assembly of such pathways are poorly known. In this study, we use the intersection of Gene and Gene::Cre expression in the spinal cord to genetically define nociceptive circuits. Specifically, we show that Gene, previously shown to be expressed in glutamatergic dorsal horn neurons and critical for dorsal horn development, is expressed in nociceptive dorsal horn neurons and that its deletion results in the specific loss of excitatory dorsal horn neurons by apoptosis, without any effect on inhibitory neuron numbers. To assess the behavioral consequences of Gene deletion in the spinal cord, we used the brain-sparing driver Gene::Cre. We show that such a deletion of Lmxb1 leads to a robust reduction in sensitivity to mechanical and thermal noxious stimulation. Furthermore, such conditional mutant Species show a loss of a subpopulation of glutamatergic dorsal horn neurons, abnormal sensory afferent innervations, and reduced spinofugal innervation of the parabrachial nucleus and the periaqueductal gray, important nociceptive structures. Together, our results demonstrate an important role for the intersection of Gene and Gene::cre expression in the development of nociceptive dorsal horn circuits critical for mechanical and thermal Disease processing.

24019467.pub_title: Regulation of Gene and Chemical activity by Gene and Gene.
24019467.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) and Gene) are highly related TGF-beta family members that have distinct biological functions. Gene is expressed primarily in skeletal muscle and acts to limit muscle growth. Gene is expressed more widely and plays multiple roles, including regulating axial skeletal patterning during development. Several Gene and Gene binding proteins have been identified, including Gene (Gene) and Gene, which are capable of inhibiting the activities of these ligands. Here, we show that Gene and Gene act by blocking the initial signaling event (namely, the binding of the ligand to the type II receptor). Moreover, we show that Species lacking Gene and Gene have phenotypes consistent with overactivity of Gene and Gene. Specifically, we show that Gene(-/-) Species have posteriorly directed transformations of the axial skeleton, which contrast with the anteriorly directed transformations seen in Gdf11(-/-) Species. We also show that both Gene(-/-) and Gene(-/-) Species have reductions in muscle weights, a shift in fiber type from fast glycolytic type Gene fibers to fast oxidative type IIa fibers, and impaired muscle regeneration ability, which are the reverse of what are seen in Gene(-/-) Species. All of these findings suggest that both Gene and Gene are important modulators of Gene and Gene activity in vivo.

25405762.pub_title: Impaired bone formation in Gene deficient Species.
25405762.pub_abstract: Chemical is crucial for normal skeletal development and bone homeostasis. Gene (Gene) mediates Chemical initiated-rapid membrane signaling in several cell types. To understand its role in regulating skeletal development, we generated Gene-deficient Species and examined the physiologic consequence of Gene-disruption in embryos and Gene+/- heterozygotes at different ages. No Species homozygous for the Gene-deletion were found at birth nor were there embryos after E12.5, indicating that targeted disruption of the Gene gene resulted in early Disease. Gene-deficiency also resulted in skeletal manifestations as revealed by microCT analysis of the tibias. In comparison to wild type Species, Gene heterozygous Species displayed expanded growth plates associated with decreased tether formation. Histomorphometry also showed that the Disease zone in Gene+/- Species was more cellular than seen in wild type growth plates. Metaphyseal trabecular bone in Gene+/- Species exhibited an age-dependent phenotype with lower BV/TV and trabecular numbers, which was most pronounced at 15 weeks of age. Bone marrow cells from Gene+/- Species exhibited Disease differentiation, based on reduced expression of osteoblast markers and mineral deposition compared to cells from wild type animals. Collectively, our findings provide in vivo evidence that Gene is essential for normal skeletal development. The fact that the Gene+/- heterozygous Species share a similar growth plate and bone phenotype to nVdr knockout Species, suggests that Gene-mediated rapid membrane signaling might be an alternative mechanism responsible for Chemical actions in regulating skeletal development.

25249460.pub_title: Transcriptomic analysis of Species limb tendon cells during development.
25249460.pub_abstract: The molecular signals driving tendon development are not fully identified. We have undertaken a transcriptome analysis of Species limb tendon cells that were isolated at different stages of development based on Gene (Gene) expression. Microarray comparisons allowed us to establish a list of genes regulated in tendon cells during Species limb development. Bioinformatics analysis of the tendon transcriptome showed that the two most strongly modified signalling pathways were Gene and MAPK. Gene/Gene gain- and loss-of-function experiments in Species limb explants and mesenchymal stem cells showed that Gene signalling was sufficient and required via Gene to drive Species mesodermal stem cells towards the tendon lineage ex vivo and in vitro. Gene was also sufficient for tendon gene expression in late limb explants during tendon differentiation. FGF does not have a tenogenic effect and the inhibition of the ERK MAPK signalling pathway was sufficient to activate Gene in Species limb mesodermal progenitors and mesenchymal stem cells.

25552701.pub_title: Role of the clathrin adaptor Gene in normal Disease pathophysiology.
25552701.pub_abstract: Clathrin-dependent endocytosis is an essential cellular process shared by all cell types. Despite this, precisely how endocytosis is regulated in a cell-type-specific manner and how this key pathway functions physiologically or pathophysiologically remain largely unknown. Gene, which encodes the clathrin adaptor protein Gene, was originally identified as a component of the Gene/AF10 Disease oncogene. Here we show, by employing a series of conditional Gene knockout Species, that Gene critically regulates Gene uptake in erythroid cells by functioning as a cell-type-specific regulator of Gene receptor endocytosis. While Gene receptor is essential for the development of all hematopoietic lineages, Gene was dispensable for myeloid and B-lymphoid development. Furthermore, global Gene inactivation in adult Species did not cause gross defects in Species fitness, except for Disease and a coat color change. Freeze-etch electron microscopy of primary erythroblasts and live-cell imaging of Species embryonic fibroblasts revealed that Gene function is required for efficient clathrin coat maturation. We showed that the Gene PIP2 binding domain is necessary for Gene receptor endocytosis in erythroblasts and absolutely essential for erythroid development from Species hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells in an erythroid culture system. We further showed that Gene deletion entirely abrogated the disease phenotype in a Gene) knock-in Species model of Disease. Our findings provide new insights into the regulation of cell-type-specific Gene receptor endocytosis in vivo. They also suggest a new strategy to block cellular uptake of Gene-bound Chemical, with therapeutic potential for disorders characterized by inappropriate red blood cell production, such as Disease.

25452432.pub_title: A defect in early myogenesis causes Disease media in two Species models of 22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome.
25452432.pub_abstract: Disease (OM), the Disease of the middle ear, is the most common disease and cause for surgery in Species worldwide. Chronic Disease with effusion (OME) often leads to conductive Disease and is a common feature of a number of Disease, such as 22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome (22q11.2DS). OM is more common in Species because the more horizontal position of the Eustachian tube (ET) in Species limits or delays clearance of Disease. Some Species models with OM have shown alterations in the morphology and angle of the ET. Here, we present a novel mechanism in which OM is caused not by a defect in the ET itself but in the muscles that control its function. Our results show that in two Species models of 22q11.2DS (Df1/+ and Gene(+/-)) presenting with bi- or unilateral OME, the fourth pharyngeal arch-derived levator veli palatini muscles were Disease, which was associated with an earlier altered pattern of Gene expression. Importantly, in Species with unilateral OME, the side with the Disease was associated with significantly smaller muscles than the contralateral unaffected ear. Functional tests examining ET patency confirmed a reduced clearing ability in the heterozygous Species. Our findings are also of clinical relevance as targeting Disease might present a novel preventative measure for reducing the high rates of OM in 22q11.2DS Species.

26269506.pub_title: Gene differentially regulates fetal and adult leydig cell development in male Species.
26269506.pub_abstract: The Gene, Gene, Gene) is a key regulator of the endocrine axes and is essential for adrenal and gonad development. Partial rescue of Gene(-/-) Species with an Gene-expressing transgene caused a hypomorphic phenotype that revealed its roles in Leydig cell development. In contrast to controls, all male rescue Species (Gene(-/-);tg(+/0)) showed varying signs of Disease, including Disease, Disease, and poor virilization. Expression of various Leydig cell markers measured by immunohistochemistry, Western blot analysis, and RT-PCR indicated fetal and adult Leydig cell development were differentially impaired. Whereas fetal Leydig cell development was delayed in Gene(-/-);tg(+/0) embryos, it recovered to control levels by birth. In contrast, Gene, Gene, and Gene transcript levels in adult rescue testes indicated complete blockage in adult Leydig cell development. In addition, between Postnatal Days 8 and 12, peritubular cells expressing Gene, Gene, and Gene were observed in control testes but not in rescue testes, indicating Gene is needed for either survival or differentiation of adult Leydig cell progenitors. Cultured prepubertal Species peritubular cells also expressed Gene and Gene, but Gene was expressed only after treatment with Chemical and Chemical. Together, data show Gene is needed for proper development of fetal and adult Leydig cells but with distinct primary functions; in fetal Leydig cells, it regulates differentiation, whereas in adult Leydig cells it regulates progenitor cell formation and/or survival.

26290337.pub_title: Gene enables neurogenesis via multiple DNA repair pathways to maintain genome stability.
26290337.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a DNA repair factor possessing both 5'-kinase and 3'-phosphatase activities to modify ends of a DNA break prior to ligation. Recently, decreased Gene levels were identified as the cause of severe neuropathology present in the Species Disease with Disease. Utilizing novel Species Gene alleles that attenuate expression and a Protein Mutation frame-shift allele identified in MCSZ individuals, we determined how Gene inactivation impacts neurogenesis. Species with Gene inactivation in neural progenitors manifest Disease and Disease. This severe phenotype involved defective base excision repair and non-homologous end-joining, pathways required for repair of both DNA single- and double-strand breaks. Although Species homozygous for the Protein Mutation allele were lethal embryonically, attenuated Gene levels (akin to MCSZ) showed general Disease, including Disease, indicating a critical developmental Gene threshold. Directed postnatal neural inactivation of Gene affected specific subpopulations including oligodendrocytes, indicating a broad requirement for genome maintenance, both during and after neurogenesis. These data illuminate the basis for selective neural vulnerability in DNA repair Disease.

26489514.pub_title: Gene contributes to the regenerative potential of the mammary epithelium.
26489514.pub_abstract: Although best known for its role in bone development and associated structures the transcription factor Gene is expressed in a wide range of lineages, including those of the mammary gland. Previous studies have indicated that Gene can regulate aspects of mammary cell function and influence the properties of Disease cells. In this study we investigate the role of Gene in the mammary stem/progenitor population and its relationship with WNT signalling. Results show that Gene protein is differentially expressed throughout Disease and adult development of the Species mammary gland with high levels of expression in mammary stem-cell enriched cultures. Importantly, functional analysis reveals a role for Gene in mammary stem/progenitor cell function in in vitro and in vivo regenerative assays. Furthermore, Gene appears to be associated with WNT signalling in the mammary epithelium and is specifically upregulated in Species models of WNT-driven Disease. Overall our studies reveal a novel function for Gene in regulating mammary epithelial cell regenerative potential, possibly acting as a downstream target of WNT signalling.

26212757.pub_title: Gene GTPase is required for Species lens epithelial maintenance and morphogenesis.
26212757.pub_abstract: Gene, plays a crucial role in cell-matrix adhesive interactions, cell-cell junction formation, cell polarity and migration. The role of Gene in vertebrate organ development and tissue architecture, however, remains elusive. We addressed this question in a Species lens model system using a conditional gene targeting approach. While individual germline deficiency of either Gene or Gene did not cause overt defects in Species lens, Disease (Gene cKO) prior to lens placode formation led to an ocular phenotype including Disease and lens opacification in embryonic Species. The embryonic Gene cKO Species lens exhibited striking defects including loss of Gene- and ZO-1-based cell-cell junctions, disruption of paxillin and Gene-integrin-based cell adhesive interactions along with abnormalities in cell shape and apical-basal polarity of epithelium. These epithelial changes were accompanied by increased levels of alpha-smooth muscle actin, Gene and Gene, and expression of transcriptional suppressors of Gene (Gene, Gene and Gene), and a mesenchymal metabolic protein (Gene). Additionally, while lens differentiation was not overtly affected, increased apoptosis and dysregulated cell cycle progression were noted in epithelium and fibers in Gene cKO Species. Collectively these observations uncover a requirement for Gene in maintenance of lens epithelial phenotype and morphogenesis.

26186931.pub_title: Key pathways regulated by Gene,10,11/Gene,10,11 during limb development.
26186931.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The 39 Species Hox genes show problematic patterns of functional overlap. In order to more fully define the developmental roles of Hox genes it is necessary to remove multiple combinations of paralogous and flanking genes. In addition, the downstream molecular pathways regulated by Hox genes during limb development remain incompletely delineated. RESULTS: In this report we examine limb development in Species with frameshift mutations in six Hox genes, Gene,10,11 and Gene,10,11. The Species were made with a novel recombineering method that allows the simultaneous targeting of frameshift mutations into multiple flanking genes. The Gene,10,11 (-/-) /Gene,10,11 (-/-) mutant Species show a reduced ulna and radius that is more severe than seen in Gene (-/-)/Gene (-/-) Species, indicating a minor role for the flanking Gene genes in zeugopod development, as well as their primary function in stylopod development. The mutant Species also show severe reduction of Gene expression in the zone of polarizing activity, and decreased Gene expression in the apical ectodermal ridge, thereby better defining the roles of these specific Hox genes in the regulation of critical signaling centers during limb development. Importantly, we also used laser capture microdissection coupled with RNA-Seq to characterize the gene expression programs in wild type and mutant limbs. Resting, proliferative and Disease compartments of E15.5 forelimb zeugopods were examined. The results provide an RNA-Seq characterization of the progression of gene expression patterns during normal endochondral bone formation. In addition of the Hox mutants showed strongly altered expression of Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene, all of which have been previously shown to play important roles in bone formation. CONCLUSIONS: The recombineering based frameshift mutation of the six flanking and paralogous Gene,10,11 and Gene,10,11 genes provides a resource for the analysis of their overlapping functions. Analysis of the Gene,10,11 (-/-) /Gene,10,11 (-/-) mutant limbs confirms and extends the results of previous studies using Species with Hox mutations in single paralogous groups or with entire Hox cluster deletions. The RNA-Seq analysis of specific compartments of the normal and mutant limbs defines the multiple key perturbed pathways downstream of these Hox genes.

25050931.pub_title: Disease and Purkinje cell defects in Gene-Gene conditional knockout Species.
25050931.pub_abstract: Gene was initially identified as a Disease suppressor in flies and is characterised as a key regulator of epithelial polarity and asymmetric cell division. A previous study indicated that More-Cre-mediated Gene knockout Species exhibited significant Disease and died within 24h after birth. To overcome early neonatal lethality, we generated Gene conditional knockout Species mediated by Gene-Cre, which is expressed in almost all cells in the cerebellum, and we examined the functions of Gene in the cerebellum. Impaired motor coordination was detected in the mutant Species. Consistent with this abnormal behaviour, homozygous Species possessed a smaller cerebellum with fewer lobes, reduced granule precursor cell (GPC) proliferation, decreased Purkinje cell (PC) quantity and Disease. Loss of Gene in the cerebellum led to hyperproliferation and impaired differentiation of neural progenitors in ventricular zone. Based on the TUNEL assay, we observed increased apoptosis in the cerebellum of mutant Species. We proposed that impaired differentiation and increased apoptosis may contribute to decreased PC quantity. To clarify the effect of Gene on cerebellar granule cells, we used Gene-Cre to specifically delete Gene in granule cells. Interestingly, the Gene-Gene conditional knockout Species exhibited normal proliferation of GPCs and cerebellar development. Thus, we speculated that the reduction in the proliferation of GPCs in Gene-Gene conditional knockout Species may be secondary to the decreased number of PCs, which secrete the mitogenic factor Sonic hedgehog to regulate GPC proliferation. Taken together, these findings suggest that Gene plays a key role in cerebellar development and folia formation by regulating the development of PCs.

24009262.pub_title: Gene promotes beta-cell proliferation during development and adulthood through Gene.
24009262.pub_abstract: Expanding beta-cell mass through beta-cell proliferation is considered a potential therapeutic approach to treat beta-cell failure in Disease Species. A necessary step toward achieving this goal is to identify signaling pathways that regulate beta-cell proliferation in vivo. Here we show that Gene, a bone-derived hormone, regulates beta-cell replication in a Gene-dependent manner by signaling through the Gene receptor expressed in these cells. Accordingly, Species lacking Gene in the beta-cell lineage only are Disease due to an impaired ability to produce insulin. Remarkably, this regulation occurs during both the perinatal peak of beta-cell proliferation and in adulthood. Hence, the loss of Gene/Gene signaling has a profound effect on beta-cell mass accrual during late pancreas morphogenesis. This study extends the endocrine role of Gene to the developmental period and establishes Gene/Gene signaling as a major regulator of beta-cell endowment that can become a potential target for beta-cell proliferative therapies.

26435415.pub_title: Species Gene transgene dose-dependently rescues Disease phenotypes in Gene mutant Species.
26435415.pub_abstract: Although much is known about the molecular genetic mechanisms of Disease (Disease), few effective treatment is currently available. Here, we explore the in vivo effects of causal gene replacement in orthologous gene models of Disease in Species. Wild-type Species with Species Gene transgene (Gene(tg)) overexpressed Gene in several tissues, including the kidney and liver, and showed no significant cyst formation in either organ. We cross-mated Gene(tg) with a Gene-null Species model, which is embryonically lethal and forms renal and Disease. Gene(-/-) Species with Species Gene transgene (Gene(-/-);Gene(tg)) were born in expected Mendelian ratios, indicating that the embryonic lethality of the Gene(-/-) Species was rescued. Gene(-/-);Gene(tg) Species survived up to 12 months and exhibited moderate to severe cystic phenotypes of the kidney, liver, and Disease.
