RESULTS: We show that Rathke's pouch is located at a boundary region delineated by endoderm, neural crest-derived oral mesenchyme and the anterior limit of the notochord, using Gene, Protein Mutation-Gene-Cre and Protein Mutation-Gene-Cre Species lines. As revealed by synchrotron X-ray microtomography after Chemical staining in Species embryos, the pouch has a lobulated three-dimensional structure that embraces the descending diencephalon during pituitary formation. Polaris(fl/fl); Gene-Cre, Gene(-/-) and Gene(-/-) primary cilia Species mutants have abnormal sonic hedgehog (Gene) signaling and all present with Disease and midline structures of the anterior cranial base. Changes in the expressions of Gene downstream genes are confirmed in Gene(-/-) Species. From an evolutionary perspective, persistence of the buccohypophyseal canal is a basal character for all vertebrates and its maintenance in several groups is related to a specific morphology of the midline that can be related to modulation in Gene signaling. CONCLUSION: These results provide insight into a poorly understood ancestral vertebrate structure. It appears that the opening of the buccohypophyseal canal depends upon Gene signaling and that modulation in this pathway most probably accounts for its persistence in phylogeny.

25888806.pub_title: Gene is a novel interacting partner to Gene which controls radial migration within the developing Species cerebral cortex.
25888806.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: During fetal brain development in mammals, newborn neurons undergo cell migration to reach their appropriate positions and form functional circuits. We previously reported that the atypical RhoA GTPase Gene promotes the radial migration of Species cerebral cortical neurons (Nature 455(7209):114-8, 2008; Neuron 69(6):1069-84, 2011), but its downstream signalling pathway is not well understood. RESULTS: We have identified BTB-domain containing adaptor for Cul3-mediated RhoA degradation 2 (Gene) as a novel interacting partner to Gene, which promotes radial migration within the developing cerebral cortex. We find that Gene binds Gene at its C-terminus, and this interaction is critical to its cell migration function. We show that forced expression or knockdown of Gene Disease and alters the morphology of immature neurons. Our in vivo cellular analysis reveals that Gene influences the multipolar-to-bipolar transition of radially migrating neurons in a cell autonomous fashion. When we addressed the potential signalling relationship between Gene and Gene using a Gene-Gene chimeric construct, our results suggest that Gene and Gene could interact to promote radial migration within the embryonic cortex. CONCLUSIONS: Our studies demonstrate that Gene is a novel player in neuronal development and influences radial migration within the Disease.

27816607.pub_title: Gene and Gene induces cardiac Disease in Species.
27816607.pub_abstract: Platelet-derived growth factors (PDGFs) and their receptors (PDGFRs) contribute to normal heart development. Deficient or abnormal expression of Pdgf and Gene genes have a negative impact on cardiac development and function. The cellular effects of PDGFs in the hearts of Pdgf/Gene mutants and the pathogenesis of the resulting abnormalities are poorly understood, but different PDGF isoforms induce varying effects. Here, we generated three new Species Species types which complete a set of studies, where all different PDGF ligands have been expressed under the same heart specific alpha-myosin heavy chain promoter. Species expression of the natural isoforms of Gene and Gene resulted in isoform specific fibrotic reactions and Disease. Gene overexpression resulted in a severe fibrotic reaction with up to 8-fold increase in cardiac size, leading to lethal Disease within a few weeks after birth. In contrast, Gene overexpression led to focal Disease and moderate Disease. As Gene and Gene have different affinity for the two PDGF receptors, we analyzed the expression of the receptors and the histology of the fibrotic hearts. Our data suggest that the stronger fibrotic effect generated by Gene overexpression was mediated by Pdgfralpha in cardiac interstitial mesenchymal cells, i.e. the likely source of extracellular matrix depostion and fibrotic reaction. The apparent sensitivity of the heart to ectopic PDGFRalpha agonists supports a role for endogenous PDGFRalpha agonists in the pathogenesis of Disease.

24563484.pub_title: A Species model for dominant collagen VI disorders: heterozygous deletion of Gene Exon 16.
24563484.pub_abstract: Dominant and recessive mutations in collagen VI genes, Gene, Gene, and Gene, cause a continuous spectrum of disorders characterized by Disease and connective tissue abnormalities ranging from the severe Disease to the mild Disease. Herein, we report the development of a Species model for dominant collagen VI disorders by deleting exon 16 in the Gene gene. The resulting heterozygous Species, Gene(+/d16), produced comparable amounts of normal Gene mRNA and a mutant transcript with an in-frame deletion of 54 bp of triple-helical coding sequences, thus mimicking the most common molecular defect found in dominant Disease Species. Biosynthetic studies of mutant fibroblasts indicated that the mutant alpha3(VI) collagen protein was produced and exerted a dominant-negative effect on collagen VI microfibrillar assembly. The distribution of the alpha3(VI)-like chains of collagen VI was not altered in mutant Species during development. The Gene(+/d16) Species developed histopathologic signs of Disease and showed ultrastructural alterations of mitochondria and sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle and abnormal collagen fibrils in tendons. The Gene(+/d16) Species displayed compromised muscle contractile functions and thereby provide an essential preclinical platform for developing treatment strategies for dominant collagen VI disorders.

22990596.pub_title: Dynamic expression of the Chemical co-transporters, Gene and Gene, during perinatal kidney development.
22990596.pub_abstract: Isoform 1 of the Chemical co-transporter (Gene) is expressed in the apical membrane of proximal tubule epithelial cells in adult Species and Species kidneys. This study is aimed at analyzing the expression and function of SVCTs during kidney development. RT-PCR and immunohistochemical analyses revealed that Gene expression is increased progressively during postnatal kidney development. However, Gene transcripts were barely detected, if not absent, in the Disease. Instead, the high-affinity transporter, isoform 2 (Gene), was strongly expressed in the developing kidney from E15; its expression decreased at postnatal stages. Immunohistochemical analyses showed a dynamic distribution of Gene in epithelial cells during kidney development. In renal cortex tubular epithelial cells, intracellular distribution of Gene was observed at E19 with distribution in the basolateral membrane at P1. In contrast, Gene was localized to the apical and basolateral membranes between E17 and E19 in medullary kidney tubular cells but was distributed intracellularly at P1. In agreement with these findings, functional expression of Gene, but not Gene was detected in Species Disease-derived (HEK293) cells. In addition, kinetic analysis suggested that an Chemical-dependent mechanism accounts for targeted Gene expression in the developing kidney during medullary epithelial cell differentiation. However, during cortical tubular differentiation, Gene was induced and localized to the apical membrane of tubular epithelial cells. Gene showed a basolateral polarization only for the first days of postnatal life. These studies suggest that the uptake of Chemical mediated by different SVCTs plays differential roles during the ontogeny of kidney tubular epithelial cells.

27489999.pub_title: Gene negatively regulates neurite outgrowth through activation of Gene signaling pathways.
27489999.pub_abstract: Neurite outgrowth is essential for the establishment of functional neuronal connections during brain development. This study identifies that Gene is predominantly expressed in early neuronal developmental stages and negatively regulates neurite outgrowth. Knockdown of Gene in either Neuro-2a cells or primary cortical neurons leads to excess growth of neurites, whereas overexpression of Gene prominently restricts neurite formation. Gene strongly activates Gene activity while concomitantly inhibits Gene and Gene activities. Pharmacological blockade of Gene activity restores normal neurite outgrowth in Gene-overexpressed neurons. Importantly, Gene promotes F-actin polymerization in neurons, probably through inhibiting the activity of the actin-depolymerizing factor cofilin. Collectively, these findings reveal that Gene functions as a negative regulator of neurite outgrowth through regulating Gene-cofilin pathway and actin dynamics.

24302887.pub_title: Gene, a PCP protein required for ciliogenesis, regulates directional cell migration and cell polarity by direct modulation of the actin cytoskeleton.
24302887.pub_abstract: Planar cell polarity (PCP) regulates cell alignment required for collective cell movement during embryonic development. This requires PCP/PCP effector proteins, some of which also play essential roles in ciliogenesis, highlighting the long-standing question of the role of the cilium in PCP. Gene, a PCP effector, was recently shown to regulate both ciliogenesis and collective cell movement, but the underlying mechanism is unknown. Here we show Gene can regulate PCP by direct modulation of the actin cytoskeleton. These studies were made possible by recovery of a Gene mutant Species model. Gene-deficient Species exhibit phenotypes reminiscent of Bardet-Biedl/Disease, including cardiac outflow tract and cochlea defects associated with Disease. We observed Gene is localized to the transition zone, and in Gene-deficient cells, Gene, Gene, and Gene were lost from the transition zone, indicating Gene is required for recruitment of proteins essential for ciliogenesis. Gene is also found in the cytoplasm, where it is localized in the actin cytoskeleton and in focal adhesions. Gene interacts with Gene and is colocalized with Gene in actin filaments, but in Gene-deficient cells, Gene was lost from the actin cytoskeleton, suggesting Gene is required for Gene recruitment to actin filaments. Significantly, organization of the actin filaments and focal contacts were markedly changed in Gene-deficient cells. This was associated with decreased membrane ruffling, failure to establish cell polarity, and loss of directional cell migration. These results suggest the Disease in Gene mutants are not caused by loss of cilia, but by direct disruption of the actin cytoskeleton. Consistent with this, Gene mutant cochlea has normal kinocilia and yet exhibits Disease. Together, these findings provide the first evidence, to our knowledge, that a PCP component required for ciliogenesis can directly modulate the actin cytoskeleton to regulate cell polarity and directional cell migration.

24080509.pub_title: The ubiquitin ligase Gene regulates craniofacial development by promoting cranial neural crest cell survival and stem-cell like properties.
24080509.pub_abstract: The integration of multiple morphogenic signalling pathways and transcription factor networks is essential to mediate neural crest (NC) cell induction, delamination, survival, stem-cell properties, fate choice and differentiation. Although the transcriptional control of NC development is well documented in mammals, the role of post-transcriptional modifications, and in particular ubiquitination, has not been explored. Here we report an essential role for the ubiquitin ligase Gene in cranial NC cell development. Our analysis of Gene(-/-) embryos identified profound Disease NC cells in the absence of structural defects in the neural tube. Gene is expressed in migrating cranial NC cells and was found to positively regulate expression of the NC transcription factors Gene, Gene and Gene. We found that in the absence of these factors, a subset of cranial NC cells undergo apoptosis. In accordance with a lack of cranial NC cells, Gene(-/-) embryos have Disease, NC derived bone and malformation of the craniofacial skeleton. Our analyses therefore uncover an essential role for Gene in a subset of cranial NC cells and highlight E3 ubiquitin ligases as a likely point of convergence for multiple NC signalling pathways and transcription factor networks.

27458135.pub_title: Species-QC illuminates mitophagy and mitochondrial architecture in vivo.
27458135.pub_abstract: Autophagic turnover of mitochondria, termed mitophagy, is proposed to be an essential quality-control (QC) mechanism of pathophysiological relevance in mammals. However, if and how mitophagy proceeds within specific cellular subtypes in vivo remains unclear, largely because of a lack of tractable tools and models. To address this, we have developed "Species-QC," a transgenic Species with a pH-sensitive fluorescent mitochondrial signal. This allows the assessment of mitophagy and mitochondrial architecture in vivo. Using confocal microscopy, we demonstrate that Species-QC is compatible with classical and contemporary techniques in histochemistry and allows unambiguous in vivo detection of mitophagy and mitochondrial morphology at single-cell resolution within multiple organ systems. Strikingly, our model uncovers highly enriched and differential zones of mitophagy in the developing heart and within specific cells of the adult kidney. Species-QC is an experimentally advantageous tool of broad relevance to cell biology researchers within both discovery-based and translational research communities.

26235626.pub_title: Hox5 Genes Regulate the Gene-Gene-Signaling Axis during Lung Development.
26235626.pub_abstract: Hox genes are required for proper anteroposterior axial patterning and the development of several organ systems. Here, we show that all three Hox5 paralogous genes play redundant roles in the developing lung. Gene;Gene;Hoxc5 triple-mutant embryos develop severely Disease with reduced branching and proximal-distal patterning defects. Hox5 genes are exclusively expressed in the lung mesoderm; however, defects are observed in both lung mesenchyme and endodermally derived epithelium, demonstrating that Hox5 genes act to regulate mesodermal-epithelial crosstalk during development. We show that Hox5 loss of function leads to loss of Gene expression in the distal lung mesenchyme and the downregulation of previously identified downstream targets of Gene/2b signaling, including Gene, Gene, and Gene. Gene/2b-enriched media rescue proper Gene/Gene patterning and restore Gene expression in Hox5 triple-mutant lung explants. Taken together, these data show that Hox5 genes are key upstream mesenchymal regulators of the Gene-Gene-signaling axis critical for proper lung patterning.

24095903.pub_title: Gene is required for epithelial cell identity and prevents epithelial to mesenchymal transition in the Species.
24095903.pub_abstract: The integrity and function of epithelial tissues depend on the establishment and maintenance of defining characteristics of epithelial cells, cell-cell adhesion and cell polarity. Disruption of these characteristics can lead to the loss of epithelial identity through a process called epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT), which can contribute to pathological conditions such as tissue Disease and Disease. In invertebrates, the epithelial polarity gene Gene plays a critical role in establishing and maintaining cell adhesion and polarity. In this study we asked if the Species homolog, Gene, is required for establishment and/or maintenance of epithelial identity in vivo. To do so, we conditionally deleted Gene in the head ectoderm tissue that gives rise to both the ocular lens and the corneal epithelium. Deletion of Gene in the lens resulted in a change in epithelial cell shape from cuboidal to flattened and elongated. Early in the process, the cell adhesion protein, Gene, and apical polarity protein, Gene, were downregulated and the myofibroblast protein, Gene, was upregulated, suggesting EMT was occurring in the Gene deficient lenses. Correlating temporally with the upregulation of Gene, Gene and Gene, Gene signaling intermediates, accumulated in the nucleus and Gene, a Gene target and transcriptional repressor of the gene encoding Gene, was upregulated. Gene, a lens epithelial transcription factor required to maintain lens epithelial cell identity also was downregulated. Loss of Gene in the corneal epithelium also led to molecular changes consistent with EMT, suggesting that the effect of Disease was not unique to the lens. Together, these data indicate that Species Gene is required to maintain epithelial identity and that loss of Gene can culminate in EMT, mediated, at least in part, through Gene signaling.

23624942.pub_title: Differential expression of micro-heterogeneous LewisX-type glycans in the stem cell compartment of the developing Species spinal cord.
23624942.pub_abstract: Complex glycan structures and their respective carrier molecules are often expressed in a cell type specific manner. Thus, glycans can be used for the enrichment of specific cell types such as neural precursor cells (NPCs). We have recently shown that the monoclonal antibodies 487(LeX) and 5750(LeX) differentially detect the LewisX (LeX) glycan on NPCs in the developing Species forebrain. Here, we analysed the staining pattern of both antibodies during late embryonic Species spinal cord development. At E13.5 both antibodies strongly label the central canal region. Along these lines they detect the LeX glycan primarily on Nestin-positive NPCs at that age. Moreover, we show that spinal cord NPCs cultured as free floating neurospheres display a high immunoreactivity to both antibodies. In that context, we also demonstrate that the 487(LeX) antibody can be used to deplete a subpopulation of neurosphere forming NPCs from a mixed E13.5 spinal cord cell suspension. Towards the end of embryogenesis the overall immunoreactivity to both antibodies increases and the staining appears very diffuse. However, the 5750(LeX) antibody still labels the central canal region. The increase in immunoreactivity correlates with an expression increase of the extracellular matrix molecules Gene and Receptor Protein Chemical Phosphatase beta/zeta, two potential LeX carrier proteins. In line with this, immunoprecipitation analyses confirmed Gene as a LeX carrier protein in the embryonic Species spinal cord. However, the immunoreactivity to both antibodies appears only to be marginally affected in the absence of Gene, arguing against Gene being the major LeX carrier. In conclusion our study gives some novel insights into the complex expression of LeX glycans and potential carrier proteins during the development of the Species spinal cord.

22240590.pub_title: Gene and Gene differentially modulate neurogenesis in neural stem cells.
22240590.pub_abstract: Neuroepithelial cells undergoing differentiation efficiently remodel their cytoskeleton and shape in an energy-consuming process. The capacity of autophagy to recycle cellular components and provide energy could fulfill these requirements, thus supporting differentiation. However, little is known regarding the role of basal autophagy in neural differentiation. Here we report an increase in the expression of the autophagy genes Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene in vivo in the Species embryonic olfactory bulb (Disease) during the initial period of neuronal differentiation at E15.5, along with a parallel increase in neuronal markers. In addition, we observed an increase in Gene lipidation and autophagic flux during neuronal differentiation in cultured Disease-derived stem/progenitor cells. Pharmacological inhibition of autophagy with Chemical or Chemical markedly decreased neurogenesis. These observations were supported by similar findings in two Disease. In Gene loss-of-function homozygous Species (gt/gt) the expression of several neural markers was decreased in the Disease at E13.5 in vivo. In vitro, Gene Disease cells developed as small neurospheres with an impaired capacity for neuronal generation. The addition of Chemical during stem/progenitor cell differentiation in culture largely reversed the inhibition of neurogenesis induced by either Chemical or Gene Disease, suggesting that neural stem/progenitor cells activate autophagy to fulfill their high energy demands. Further supporting the role of autophagy for neuronal differentiation Gene-null Disease cells differentiating in culture displayed decreased TuJ1 levels and lower number of cells with neurites. These results reveal new roles for autophagy-related molecules Gene and Gene during early neuronal differentiation of stem/progenitor cells.

25111779.pub_title: Pleiotropic functions for transcription factor Gene.
25111779.pub_abstract: The transcription factor Gene had been attributed a role as a pluripotency factor in embryonic stem cells based on its interaction with Gene and Gene in in vitro assays. Here we suggest a potential role of Gene in controlling progenitor cell populations in vivo. Species homozygous for a Gene mutation exhibit reduced weight, mild Disease in the spleen, heart and long bones and phenocopy an eye malformation previously described for Gene hypomorphs. Disease are supported by the nature of Gene expression in midgestation embryos and adults suggesting a role for Gene in either maintaining progenitor cell subpopulation or impacting on fate choice decisions thereof.

26253404.pub_title: Gene coordinates a network of genes implicated in eye development and Disease.
26253404.pub_abstract: Disease is a rare Disease characterized by reduced eye size and Disease of variable degree. Sporadic and hereditary Disease have been associated with heterozygous mutations in genes fundamental for eye development. Yet, many cases are idiopathic or await the identification of molecular causes. Here we show that Disease of Gene, which encodes a transcription factor with evolutionarily conserved expression in the Disease, brain and sensory organs, including the eye, causes microphthalmic traits and Disease in adult Species. By combining analysis of Gene loss-of-function and conditional Gene functional rescue with ChIP-seq and RNA-seq approaches we show that, in contrast to its preferential association with Hox-Pbx BSs in the trunk, Gene binds to Hox/Pbx-independent sites during optic cup development. In the eye primordium, Gene coordinates, in a dose-dependent manner, retinal proliferation and differentiation by regulating genes responsible for Species Disease and components of the Notch signaling pathway. In addition, Gene is required for eye patterning by controlling a set of eye territory-specific transcription factors, so that in Gene(-/-) embryos boundaries among the different eye territories are shifted or blurred. We propose that Gene is at the core of a genetic network implicated in eye patterning/Disease, and represents an additional candidate for Disease cases of these Disease.

24763282.pub_title: FRA2A is a CGG repeat expansion associated with silencing of Gene.
24763282.pub_abstract: Chemical-sensitive fragile sites (FSFS) are a rare cytogenetically visible subset of dynamic mutations. Of the eight molecularly characterized FSFS, four are associated with Disease (ID). Cytogenetic expression results from Chemical-repeat expansion mutation associated with local CpG hypermethylation and transcriptional silencing. The best studied is the FRAXA site in the Gene gene, where large expansions cause Disease, the most common Disease. Here we studied three families with FRA2A expression at 2q11 associated with a wide spectrum of neurodevelopmental phenotypes. We identified a polymorphic CGG repeat in a conserved, brain-active alternative promoter of the Gene gene, an autosomal homolog of the X-linked Gene/Gene gene: Expansion of the Gene CGG repeat causes FRAXE ID. We found that FRA2A-expressing individuals have mosaic expansions of the Gene CGG repeat in the range of several hundred repeat units. Moreover, Chemical sequencing and pyrosequencing both suggest Gene promoter hypermethylation. cSNP-analysis demonstrates monoallelic expression of the Gene gene in FRA2A carriers thus predicting that FRA2A expression results in Disease for Gene at least in a subset of tissues. By whole-mount in situ hybridization the Species Gene ortholog shows strong regional expression in the developing brain, somites and limb buds in 9.5-12.5dpc Species embryos. Our data suggest that there may be an association between FRA2A and a delay in the acquisition of motor and language skills in the families studied here. However, additional cases are required to firmly establish a causal relationship.

26985063.pub_title: Gene determines susceptibility to endoplasmic reticulum stress and Gene resistance in the Disease.
26985063.pub_abstract: Sustained endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress disrupts normal cellular homeostasis and leads to the development of many types of Species diseases, including Disease. Gene (also known as Gene) is a member of the mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (Gene) family and is activated by a diverse set of inflammatory stimuli. Here, we demonstrate that Gene regulates ER stress and metabolic signaling through modulation of lipid biogenesis. We found that deletion of Gene increased ER volume and facilitated ER-stress tolerance in cultured cells, which was mediated by upregulation of Gene (Gene)-dependent lipogenesis. In the in vivo setting, central nervous system (CNS)-specific Gene deletion upregulated Gene-target lipogenic genes and blocked ER stress in the Disease. Furthermore, CNS-specific Gene deletion prevented ER-stress-induced Disease resistance and Disease under a high-fat diet (HFD). Thus, Gene is a crucial regulator of ER stress in vivo, which could be a target for alleviation of ER stress and its associated disease conditions.

23840065.pub_title: Gene kinases are required for vascular function, Gene expression, and Gene-mediated survival.
23840065.pub_abstract: Endothelial dysfunction is associated with diverse cardiovascular pathologies. Here, we show a previously unappreciated role for the Gene (Gene) family kinases (Gene and Chemical) in endothelial function and the regulation of angiogenic factor pathways important for vascular homeostasis. Endothelial Gene deletion in Chemical-null Species led to late-stage embryonic and perinatal lethality, with mutant Species displaying focal loss of vasculature and tissue Disease. Loss of Gene kinases led to increased endothelial cell apoptosis both in vitro and in vivo, contributing to Disease, Disease, and tissue damage. Mechanistically, we identify a unique dual role for Gene kinases in the regulation of angiopoietin/Gene protein kinase signaling. Endothelial Gene kinases modulate Gene expression and Gene-mediated endothelial cell survival. These findings reveal a critical requirement for the Gene kinases in vascular development and function, which may have important implications for the clinical use of Gene kinase inhibitors.

23077214.pub_title: 22q11 Gene dosage establishes an adaptive range for sonic hedgehog and Chemical signaling during early development.
23077214.pub_abstract: We asked whether key morphogenetic signaling pathways interact with 22q11 gene dosage to modulate the severity of cranial or Disease in Disease/22q1 deletion syndrome (22q11DS). Sonic hedgehog (Gene) and Chemical (Disease) signaling is altered in the brain and heart-clinically significant 22q11DS phenotypic sites-in LgDel Species embryos, an established 22q11DS model. LgDel embryos treated with Chemical, an Gene inhibitor, or carrying mutations in Gene(Xtj), an Gene-signaling effector, have morphogenetic Disease that are either not seen, or seen at significantly lower frequencies in control or single-mutant embryos. Similarly, Disease exposure or genetic loss of Disease function via heterozygous mutation of the Disease synthetic enzyme Gene induces novel Disease and enhances cardiovascular phenotypes in LgDel but not other genotypes. These changes are not seen in heterozygous Gene mutant embryos-a 22q11 gene thought to explain much of 22q11DS pathogenesis-in which Gene or Disease signaling has been similarly modified. Our results suggest that full dosage of 22q11 genes beyond Gene establish an adaptive range for morphogenetic signaling via Gene and Disease. When this adaptive range is constricted by diminished dosage of 22q11 genes, embryos are sensitized to otherwise benign changes in Gene and Disease signaling. Such sensitization, in the face of environmental or genetic factors that modify Gene or Disease signaling, may explain variability in 22q11DS morphogenetic phenotypes.

22378764.pub_title: Gene in the uterus is necessary for proper placental development and maintenance of pregnancy.
22378764.pub_abstract: Preterm birth is the single leading cause of perinatal mortality in developed countries, affecting approximately 12% of pregnancies and accounting for 75% of neonatal loss in the United States. Despite the prevalence and severity of premature delivery, the causes and mechanisms that underlie spontaneous and idiopathic preterm birth remain unknown. Our inability to elucidate these fundamental causes has been attributed to a poor understanding of the signaling pathways associated with the premature induction of parturition and a lack of suitable animal models available for preterm birth research. In this study, we describe the generation and analysis of a novel conditional knockout of the transforming growth factor beta (Gene) superfamily member, Gene, from the maternal reproductive tract of Species. Strikingly, uterine Gene knockout females exhibited a severe malformation of the maternal decidua basalis during placentation, leading to significant intrauterine growth restriction, and ultimately preterm birth and fetal loss on Day 17.5 of gestation. Using several approaches, we characterized aberrant placental development and demonstrated that reduced proliferation combined with increased apoptosis resulted in a diminished decidua basalis and compromised maternal-fetal interface. Last, we evaluated various components of the established parturition cascade and determined that preterm birth derived from the maternal Gene knockout occurs prior to Gene (Gene) upregulation at the placental interface. Taken together, the results presented in this study highlight an in vivo role for maternal Gene during placentation, present an interesting link between disrupted decidua basalis formation and premature parturition, and describe a potentially valuable model toward elucidating the complex processes that underlie preterm birth.

25729345.pub_title: The inner CSF-brain barrier: developmentally controlled access to the brain via intercellular junctions.
25729345.pub_abstract: In the adult the interface between the cerebrospinal fluid and the brain is lined by the ependymal cells, which are joined by gap junctions. These intercellular connections do not provide a diffusional restrain between the two compartments. However, during development this interface, initially consisting of neuroepithelial cells and later radial glial cells, is characterized by "strap" junctions, which limit the exchange of different sized molecules between cerebrospinal fluid and the brain parenchyma. Here we provide a systematic study of permeability properties of this inner cerebrospinal fluid-brain barrier during Species development from embryonic day, E17 until adult. Results show that at fetal stages exchange across this barrier is restricted to the smallest molecules (286Da) and the diffusional restraint is progressively removed as the brain develops. By postnatal day P20, molecules the size of plasma proteins (70 kDa) diffuse freely. Transcriptomic analysis of junctional proteins present in the cerebrospinal fluid-brain interface showed expression of adherens junctional proteins, actins, cadherins and catenins changing in a development manner consistent with the observed changes in the permeability studies. Gap junction proteins were only identified in the adult as was Gene. Immunohistochemistry was used to localize at the cellular level some of the adherens junctional proteins of genes identified from transcriptomic analysis. Gene, Gene immunoreactivity was detected outlining the inner CSF-brain interface from E16; most of these markers were not present in the adult ependyma. Gene was present in the apical-most part of radial glial cells and in endothelial cells in embryos, but only in endothelial cells including plexus endothelial cells in adults. Gene was only immunopositive in the adult, consistent with results obtained from transcriptomic analysis. These results provide information about physiological, molecular and morphological-related permeability changes occurring at the inner cerebrospinal fluid-brain barrier during brain development.

22949634.pub_title: Gene regulates mesoderm differentiation of embryonic stem cells independent of H3K27 demethylase activity.
22949634.pub_abstract: To investigate the role of histone H3K27 demethylase Gene in embryonic stem (ES) cell differentiation, we have generated Gene knockout (KO) and enzyme-dead knock-in male ES cells. Deletion of the X-chromosome-encoded Gene gene in male ES cells markedly decreases expression of the paralogous Gene gene encoded by Y chromosome, but has no effect on global H3K27me3 level, Hox gene expression, or ES cell self-renewal. However, Gene KO cells show severe defects in mesoderm differentiation and induction of Gene, a transcription factor essential for mesoderm development. Surprisingly, Gene regulates mesoderm differentiation and Gene expression independent of its enzymatic activity. Gene, which lacks detectable demethylase activity, compensates for the loss of Gene in regulating Gene expression. Gene and Gene bind directly to Disease and are required for Wnt/Gene signaling-induced Gene expression in ES cells. Interestingly, male Gene KO embryos express normal levels of Gene and survive until birth. In contrast, female Gene KO Species, which lack the Gene gene, show Disease before embryonic day 11.5. Female Gene KO embryos show severe defects in both Gene expression and embryonic development of mesoderm-derived posterior notochord, cardiac, and hematopoietic tissues. These results indicate that Gene controls mesoderm differentiation and Gene expression independent of H3K27 demethylase activity, and suggest that Gene and Gene are functionally redundant in ES cell differentiation and early embryonic development.

27106802.pub_title: Embryonic cardiomyocytes can orchestrate various cell protective mechanisms to survive mitochondrial stress.
27106802.pub_abstract: Whereas adult cardiomyocytes are highly susceptible to stress, cardiomyocytes in the prenatal heart appear to be rather resistant. To investigate how Disease respond to metabolic stress in vivo, we utilized tissue mosaicism for Disease in 13.5dpc Species hearts. The latter is based on inactivation of the X-linked gene encoding Gene (Gene), which is essential for mitochondrial respiration. In heterozygous heart conditional Gene knockout females (cHccs(+/-)) random X chromosomal inactivation results in a mosaic of healthy and Gene deficient cells in the myocardium. Microarray RNA expression analyses identified genes involved in unfolded protein response (UPR) and programmed cell death as differentially expressed in cHccs(+/-) versus control embryonic hearts. Activation of the UPR is localized to Disease but does not involve ER stress pathways, suggesting that it is caused by defective mitochondria. Consistently, mitochondrial chaperones, such as Gene and Gene, but not ER chaperones are induced in defective cells. Disease can result in oxidative stress, but no evidence for excessive ROS (reactive Chemical species) production was observed in cHccs(+/-) hearts. Instead, the antioxidative proteins Gene and Gene are induced, suggesting that ROS detoxification prevents oxidative damage in Disease. Disease and unrestricted UPR can induce cell death, and we detected the initiation of upstream events of both intrinsic as well as extrinsic apoptosis in cHccs(+/-) hearts. Cell death is not executed, however, suggesting the activation of antiapoptotic mechanisms. Whereas most apoptosis inhibitors are either unchanged or downregulated in Disease, Gene and ARC (apoptosis repressor with caspase recruitment domain) are induced. Given that ARC can inhibit both apoptotic pathways as well as Disease and attenuates UPR, we generated cHccs(+/-) embryos on an Arc knockout background (cHccs(+/-),Arc(-/-)). Surprisingly, the absence of ARC does not induce cell death in Disease and adult cHccs(+/-),Arc(-/-) Species exhibit normal cardiac morphology and function. Taken together, our data demonstrate an impressive plasticity of Disease to respond to metabolic stress, the loss of which might be involved in the high susceptibility of postnatal cardiomyocytes to cell death.

22972683.pub_title: Nonmuscle myosin II regulation of lung epithelial morphology.
22972683.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The regulation of epithelial cell shape and orientation during lung branching morphogenesis is not clearly understood. Nonmuscle myosins regulate cell size, morphology, and planar cell polarity. Here, we test the hypothesis that nonmuscle myosin II (NM II) regulates lung epithelial morphology in a spatially restricted manner. RESULTS: Epithelial cell orientation at airway tips in fetal Species lungs underwent a significant transformation at embryonic day (E) E17. Treatment of E15 lung explants with the NM II inhibitor Chemical increased airway branching, epithelial cell size, and the degree of anisotropy in epithelial cells lining the airway stalks. In cultured MLE-12 lung epithelial cells, Chemical increased cell velocity, but left the migratory response to Gene unchanged. CONCLUSIONS: In the developing lung, NM II acts to constrain cell morphology and orientation, but may be suppressed at sites of branching and cell migration. The regulation of epithelial orientation may therefore undergo dynamic variations from E15 to E17.

23689133.pub_title: Impaired epidermal permeability barrier in Species lacking Gene, the gene responsible for very-long-chain Chemical production.
23689133.pub_abstract: The Chemical backbone Chemical (Cer) is a major component of lipid lamellae in the stratum corneum of epidermis and has a pivotal role in epidermal barrier formation. Unlike Cers in other tissues, Cers in epidermis contain extremely long Chemical (FAs). Decreases in epidermal Cer levels, as well as changes in their FA chain lengths, cause several Disease. However, the molecular mechanisms that produce such extremely long Cers and determine their chain lengths are poorly understood. We generated Species deficient in the Gene gene, which encodes the FA elongase responsible for producing C20 to C28 FAs. Gene knockout Species died shortly after birth due to epidermal barrier defects. The lipid lamellae in the stratum corneum were largely diminished in these Species. In the epidermis of the Gene-null Species, the levels of Cers with >=C26 FAs were decreased, while those of Cers with <=C24 FAs were increased. In contrast, the levels of C24 Chemical were reduced, accompanied by an increase in C20 Chemical levels. Two Chemical synthases, Gene and Gene, expressed in an epidermal layer-specific manner, regulate Gene to produce Chemical As with different chain lengths. Gene is a key determinant of epidermal Cer chain length and is essential for permeability barrier formation.

24616052.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Tooth development is highly regulated in mammals and it is regulated by networks of signaling pathways (e. g. Gene, Wnt, Gene, Fgf and Bmp) whose activities are controlled by the balance between ligands, activators, inhibitors and receptors. The members of the Gene family are known as activators of Wnt signaling, and Gene, Gene, and Gene have been identified as receptors for R-spondins. The role of Gene/Gene signaling in tooth development, however, remains unclear. RESULTS: We first carried out comparative in situ hybridization analysis of R-spondins and Lgrs, and identified their dynamic spatio-temporal expression in Species odontogenesis. Gene expression was found both in Disease and the tooth-less region, the Disease. We further examined tooth development in Gene mutant Species, and although molars and incisors exhibited no significant abnormalities, supernumerary teeth were observed in the Disease. CONCLUSIONS: Gene/Gene signaling is thus involved in tooth development.

25587042.pub_title: Gene promotes chondrocyte proliferation and Disease during endochondral bone formation in Species.
25587042.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is an H3K27me3 demethylase and counteracts polycomb-mediated transcription repression. However, the function of Gene in vivo is not well understood. Here we show that Gene is highly expressed in cells of the chondrocyte lineage, especially in prehypertrophic and Disease chondrocytes, during endochondral ossification. Homozygous deletion of Gene results in severely decreased proliferation and delayed Disease of chondrocytes, and thereby marked Disease in Species. Genetically, Gene associates with Gene to promote proliferation and Disease of chondrocytes. Biochemically, Gene associates with and enhances Gene activity by derepression of Gene and Gene transcription through its H3K27me3 demethylase activity. These results demonstrate that Gene is a key epigenetic regulator in the process of cartilage maturation during endochondral bone formation.

22423107.pub_title: Loss of neuronal Chemical/Chemical cotransporter 3 (Gene) is responsible for the degenerative phenotype in a conditional Species model of Disease associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum.
22423107.pub_abstract: Disruption of the Chemical/Chemical cotransporter 3 (Gene), encoded by the Gene gene, causes Disease associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum (Disease/ACC), a neurodevelopmental and Disease affecting both the peripheral nervous system and CNS. However, the precise role of Gene in the maintenance of ion homeostasis in the nervous system and the pathogenic mechanisms leading to Disease/ACC remain unclear. We established two Gene Cre/LoxP transgenic Species lines expressing Chemical-terminal truncated Gene in either a neuron-specific or ubiquitous fashion. Our results suggest that neuronal Gene expression is crucial for axon volume control. We also demonstrate that the Disease features of Disease/ACC are predominantly due to a neuronal Gene deficit, while the Disease is due to loss of non-neuronal Gene expression. Furthermore, we demonstrate that Gene plays an essential role in inflammatory Disease pathways. Finally, we observed Disease of the corpus callosum in both Species mutants and a marked decrease in axonal tracts serving the auditory cortex in only the general deletion mutant. Together, these results establish Gene as an important player in both central and peripheral nervous system maintenance.

22906231.pub_title: Gene and Gene coordinately regulate development of the olfactory system.
22906231.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Proneural genes encode basic helix-loop-helix transcription factors that specify distinct neuronal identities in different regions of the nervous system. In the Disease, the proneural genes Gene and Gene specify a dorsal regional identity and glutamatergic projection neuron phenotype in the presumptive neocortex, but their roles in cell fate specification in the olfactory bulb, which is also partly derived from dorsal Disease progenitors, have yet to be assessed. Given that olfactory bulb development is guided by interactions with the olfactory epithelium in the periphery, where proneural genes are also expressed, we investigated the roles of Gene and Gene in the coordinated development of these two olfactory structures. RESULTS: Gene are co-expressed in olfactory bulb progenitors, while only Gene is widely expressed in progenitors for olfactory sensory neurons in the olfactory epithelium. Strikingly, only a remnant of an olfactory bulb forms in Gene-/-;Gene-/- double mutants, while this structure is smaller but distinguishable in Gene-/- single mutants and morphologically normal in Gene-/- single mutants. At the cellular level, fewer glutamatergic mitral and juxtaglomerular cells differentiate in Gene-/-;Gene-/- double-mutant olfactory bulbs. Instead, ectopic olfactory bulb interneurons are derived from dorsal Disease lineages in Gene-/-;Gene-/- double mutants and to a lesser extent in Gene-/- single mutants. Conversely, cell fate specification is normal in Gene-/- olfactory bulbs, but aberrant patterns of cell proliferation and neuronal migration are observed in Gene-/- single and Gene-/-;Gene-/- double mutants, probably contributing to their altered morphologies. Finally, in Gene-/- and Gene-/-;Gene-/- embryos, olfactory sensory neurons in the epithelium, which normally project to the olfactory bulb to guide its morphogenesis, fail to innervate the olfactory bulb. CONCLUSIONS: We have identified a cell autonomous role for Gene in specifying the glutamatergic identity of olfactory bulb neurons. Furthermore, Gene (and not Gene) is required to guide olfactory sensory neuron innervation of the olfactory bulb, the loss of which results in defects in olfactory bulb proliferation and tissue morphogenesis. We thus conclude that Gene/2 together coordinate development of the olfactory system, which depends on tissue interactions between the olfactory bulb and epithelium.

22629237.pub_title: Apoptosis of limb innervating motor neurons and erosion of motor pool identity upon lineage specific Gene inactivation.
22629237.pub_abstract: Diversification of Species spinal motor neurons into hundreds of subtypes is critical for the maintenance of body posture and coordination of complex movements. Motor neuron differentiation is controlled by extrinsic signals that regulate intrinsic genetic programs specifying and consolidating motor neuron subtype identity. While transcription factors have been recognized as principal regulators of the intrinsic program, the role of posttranscriptional regulations has not been systematically tested. MicroRNAs produced by Gene mediated cleavage of RNA hairpins contribute to gene regulation by posttranscriptional silencing. Here we used Gene-cre conditional deletion of Gene gene in motor neuron progenitors to examine effects of miRNA biogenesis disruption on postmitotic spinal motor neurons. We report that despite the initial increase in the number of motor neuron progenitors, disruption of Gene function results in a loss of many limb- and sympathetic ganglia-innervating spinal motor neurons. Furthermore, it leads to defects in motor pool identity specification. Thus, our results indicate that miRNAs are an integral part of the genetic program controlling motor neuron survival and acquisition of subtype specific properties.

24835278.pub_title: Critical roles of miRNA-mediated regulation of TGFbeta signalling during Species cardiogenesis.
24835278.pub_abstract: AIMS: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play critical roles during the development of the cardiovascular system. Blocking miRNA biosynthesis in embryonic hearts through a conditional gene inactivation approach led to differential Disease depending on the Cre drivers used in different studies. The goal of this study is to reveal the cardiogenic pathway that is regulated by the miRNA mechanism at midgestation, a stage that has not been evaluated in previous publications. METHODS AND RESULTS: We specifically inactivated Gene, which is essential for generation of functional mature miRNAs, in the myocardium by crossing Gene-Cre Species with Gene Species. Gene-Cre efficiently inactivates target genes in cardiomyocytes at midgestation. All mutants died between E14.5 and E16.5 with severe Disease, including reduced cell proliferation, increased cell death, and spongy myocardial wall. Expression of TGFbeta type I receptor (Gene), which encodes the Type I receptor of TGFbeta ligands, was up-regulated in mutant hearts. As expected, TGFbeta activity was increased in Gene-inactivated hearts. Our further molecular analysis suggested that Gene is a direct target of three miRNAs. Reducing TGFbeta activities using a pharmacological inhibitor on in vitro cultured hearts, or through an in vivo genetic approach, partially rescued the Disease caused by Gene inactivation. CONCLUSIONS: We show for the first time that TGFbeta signalling is directly regulated by the miRNA mechanism during myocardial wall morphogenesis. Increased TGFbeta activity plays a major role in the Disease caused by myocardial deletion of Gene. Thus, miRNA-mediated regulation of TGFbeta signalling is indispensable for normal cardiogenesis.

24357327.pub_title: Disease and disrupted cranial nerve development in a Species model of Disease (22q11) deletion syndrome.
24357327.pub_abstract: We assessed feeding-related Disease in the LgDel Species model of chromosome 22q11 deletion syndrome (22q11DS), a common Disease that frequently includes perinatal Disease--debilitating feeding, swallowing and nutrition difficulties from birth onward--within its phenotypic spectrum. LgDel pups gain significantly less weight during the first postnatal weeks, and have several signs of Disease due to food aspiration. Most 22q11 genes are expressed in anlagen of craniofacial and brainstem regions critical for feeding and swallowing, and diminished expression in LgDel embryos apparently compromises development of these regions. Palate and Disease indicate divergent oro-facial morphogenesis. Altered expression and patterning of hindbrain transcriptional regulators, especially those related to Chemical (RA) signaling, prefigures these disruptions. Subsequently, gene expression, axon growth and sensory ganglion formation in the trigeminal (V), glossopharyngeal (IX) or vagus (X) cranial nerves (CNs) that innervate targets essential for feeding, swallowing and digestion are disrupted. Posterior CN IX and Disease primarily reflect diminished dosage of the 22q11DS candidate gene Gene. Genetic modification of RA signaling in LgDel embryos rescues the anterior CN V phenotype and returns expression levels or pattern of RA-sensitive genes to those in wild-type embryos. Thus, diminished 22q11 gene dosage, including but not limited to Gene, disrupts oro-facial and CN development by modifying RA-modulated anterior-posterior hindbrain differentiation. These disruptions likely contribute to Disease in Species and young Species with 22q11DS.

22505032.pub_title: Genetic inactivation of Gene leads to cell cycle arrest and induces premature aging due to adult stem cell exhaustion.
22505032.pub_abstract: Cyclin-dependent kinase (Gene, the catalytic subunit of the Cdk-activating kinase (CAK) complex has been implicated in the control of cell cycle progression and of RNA polymerase II (RNA pol II)-mediated transcription. Genetic inactivation of the Gene locus revealed that whereas Gene is completely dispensable for global transcription, is essential for the cell cycle via phosphorylation of Gene and Gene. In vivo, Gene is also indispensable for cell proliferation except during the initial stages of embryonic development. Interestingly, widespread elimination of Gene in adult tissues with low proliferative indexes had no phenotypic consequences. However, ablation of conditional Gene alleles in tissues with elevated cellular turnover led to the efficient repopulation of these tissues with Gene-expressing cells most likely derived from adult stem cells that may have escaped the inactivation of their targeted Gene alleles. This process, a physiological attempt to maintain tissue homeostasis, led to the attrition of adult stem cell pools and to the appearance of age-related phenotypes, including telomere shortening and early Disease.

26764350.pub_title: Gene Is Essential for Pregnancy Success via Regulation of Species Trophoblast Stem Cell Proliferation and Differentiation.
26764350.pub_abstract: The Gene null mutant embryos died in utero between Embryonic Days 13.5 to 15.5 with dysmorphic placentae, characterized by excessive nonvascular cell nests consisting of proliferative trophoblastic tissue and abundant trophoblast stem cells (TSCs) in the labyrinth. Lethality of Gene null embryos was caused by insufficient placental perfusion as a result of remarkable decreases in both fetal and maternal blood vessels in the labyrinth. These defects were accompanied by a significant elevation of Gene expression and phosphorylation and its downstream effector Gene activation. Knockdown of Gene in wild-type TSCs in vitro provoked the proliferation but delayed the differentiation with an upregulation of Gene expression and an enhanced phosphorylation of Gene and Gene. In contrast, overexpression of Gene in wild-type TSCs exhibited completely opposite effects compared to knockdown TSCs. These results suggest that loss of Gene in the placenta aberrantly overactivates Gene-Gene signaling, alters TSC proliferation and differentiation, and ultimately compromises the structure of placental vascular labyrinth. Our studies for the first time demonstrate that Gene is an essential factor for pregnancy success acting through the maintenance of a balance of TSC proliferation and differentiation during placental development.

23185619.pub_title: Novel reporter alleles of Gene and Gene.
23185619.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a key player in development, physiology and disease. Because of this, Gene inhibitors are increasingly being explored for a variety of applications. In addition most analyses focus on Gene and overlook the closely related protein Gene. Here, we describe novel Gene and Gene Species alleles that allow us to visualise expression of their respective mRNAs by tracking beta-galactosidase activity. We used these new lacZ alleles to compare expression in the Disease and cranial sutures and found that there was indeed differential expression. Furthermore, both are loss of function alleles and can be used to generate homozygous mutant Species; in addition, excision of the lacZ cassette from Gene creates a Cre-dependent tissue-specific knockout. As expected, Gene mutants were viable, while Gene mutants died after birth with a complete Disease. We also assessed the Gene mutants for cranial and sternal phenotypes and found that they were essentially normal. Finally, we observed gestational lethality in compound Gene(-/-); Gene(+/-) mutants, suggesting that Gene dosage is critical during embryonic development.

23575831.pub_title: Gene establishes rostral motor cortex projection neuron subtype diversity.
23575831.pub_abstract: The Species neocortex is parcellated into anatomically and functionally distinct areas. The establishment of area-specific neuronal diversity and circuit connectivity enables distinct neocortical regions to control diverse and specialized functional outputs, yet underlying molecular controls remain largely unknown. Here, we identify a central role for the transcriptional regulator Gene (Gene) in establishing the diversity of neuronal subtypes within rostral Species motor cortex, where projection neurons have particularly diverse and multi-projection connectivity compared with caudal motor cortex. In rostral motor cortex, we report that both subcerebral projection neurons (SCPN), which send projections away from the cerebrum, and callosal projection neurons (CPN), which send projections to contralateral cortex, express Gene, whereas more caudal SCPN and CPN do not. Gene-expressing SCPN and CPN populations are comprised of multiple hodologically distinct subtypes. SCPN in rostral layer Va project largely to brainstem, whereas SCPN in layer Vb project largely to spinal cord, and a subset of both rostral SCPN and CPN sends second ipsilateral caudal (backward) projections in addition to primary projections. Without Gene function, the molecular identity of neurons in rostral motor cortex is disrupted and more homogenous, rostral layer Va SCPN aberrantly project to the spinal cord, and many dual-projection SCPN and CPN fail to send a second backward projection. These molecular and hodological disruptions result in greater overall homogeneity of motor cortex output. Together, these results identify Gene as a central developmental control over the diversity of motor cortex projection neuron subpopulations, establishing their area-specific identity and specialized connectivity.

22522965.pub_title: Generation of conditional alleles for Gene and Gene in Species.
22522965.pub_abstract: The Forkhead box transcription factors, Gene and Gene, are crucial for development of the eye, cardiovascular network, and other physiological systems, but their cell-type specific and postdevelopmental functions are unknown, in part because conventional (i.e., whole-organism) homozygous-null mutations of either factor result in perinatal death. Here, we describe the generation of Species with conditional-null Gene(flox) and Gene(flox) mutations that are induced via Cre-mediated recombination. Species homozygous for the unrecombined alleles are viable and fertile, indicating that the conditional alleles retain their wild-type function. The embryos of Gene(flox) or Gene(flox) Species crossed with Cre-deleter Species that are homozygous for the recombined allele (i.e., Gene(Delta/Delta) or Gene(Delta/Delta) embryos) lack expression of the corresponding gene and show the same developmental defects observed in conventional homozygous mutant embryos. We expect these conditional mutations to enable characterization of the cell-type specific functions of Gene and Gene in development, disease, and adult animals.

23064108.pub_title: Epileptiform activity and Disease in Gene(+/-) Species are normalized by antiepileptic drugs.
23064108.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a protein that participates in the regulation of synaptic vesicle exocytosis through the formation of the soluble NSF attachment protein receptor complex and modulates voltage-gated Chemical channels activity. The Gene gene has been associated with Disease, Disease, and Disease, and lower levels of Gene have been described in Species with Disease. We used Gene heterozygous (Gene(+/-)) Species to investigate at which extent the reduction of the protein levels affects neuronal network function and Species behavior. As interactions of genotype with the specific laboratory conditions may impact behavioral results, the study was performed through a multilaboratory study in which behavioral tests were replicated in at least 2 of 3 distinct European laboratories. Reductions of Gene levels were associated with a moderate Disease, which disappeared in the adult animals, and with Disease. Electroencephalographic recordings revealed the occurrence of frequent spikes, suggesting a diffuse network hyperexcitability. Consistently, Gene(+/-) Species displayed higher susceptibility to Chemical-induced Disease, paralleled by degeneration of hilar neurons. Notably, both EEG profile and Disease were improved by antiepileptic drugs. These results indicate that reduction of Gene expression is associated to generation of Disease and Disease, which can be effectively treated by antiepileptic drugs.

25343275.pub_title: Conditional deletion of Gene in the pancreatic beta-cell leads to glucagon-expressing Disease development.
25343275.pub_abstract: The Disease suppressor Gene is recognized as a key regulator of beta-cell proliferation. To induce tumorigenesis within the pancreatic beta-cells, floxed alleles of Gene were selectively ablated using Cre-recombinase driven by the insulin promoter. Despite the beta-cell specificity of the RipCre, glucagon-expressing Disease as well as Disease developed in old mutant Species. These glucagon-expressing Disease cells were Gene deficient and expressed the mature alpha-cell-specific transcription factors Gene (Gene) and v-maf Disease oncogene family, protein B (Gene). Moreover, the inactivation of beta-cell-specific transcription factors was observed in mutant beta-cells. Our work shows that Gene ablation in the pancreatic beta-cells leads to the inactivation of specific transcription factors, resulting in glucagon-expressing Disease development, which sheds light on the mechanisms of islet tumorigenesis.

24614228.pub_title: Gene-410 cluster miRNAs regulate neurogenesis and neuronal migration by fine-tuning Gene.
24614228.pub_abstract: Gene-mediated adhesion is essential for maintaining the tissue architecture and stem cell niche in the developing neocortex. Gene expression level is precisely and dynamically controlled throughout development; however, the underlying regulatory mechanisms remain largely unknown. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play an important role in the regulation of protein expression and subcellular localisation. In this study, we show that three miRNAs belonging to the Gene-410 cluster regulate Gene expression levels in neural stem cells and migrating neurons. The overexpression of these three miRNAs in radial glial cells repressed Gene expression and increased neural stem cell differentiation and neuronal migration. This phenotype was rescued when Gene was expressed from a miRNA-insensitive construct. Transient abrogation of the miRNAs reduced stem cell differentiation and increased cell proliferation. The overexpression of these miRNAs specifically in newborn neurons delayed migration into the cortical plate, whereas the knockdown increased migration. Collectively, our results indicate a novel role for miRNAs of the Gene-410 cluster in the fine-tuning of Gene expression level and in the regulation of neurogenesis and neuronal migration in the developing neocortex.

23613893.pub_title: Regulation of the epithelial adhesion molecule Gene is important for Disease formation.
23613893.pub_abstract: Disease results from a mixture of genetic and environmental factors and occurs when the bilateral palatal shelves fail to fuse. The objective of this study was to search for new genes involved in Species Disease formation. Gene expression of Species Disease tissue was analyzed at various developmental stages before, during, and after Disease fusion using GeneChip  microarrays. Gene was one of the highly up-regulated genes during Disease formation, and this was confirmed by quantitative real-time PCR. Immunohistochemical staining showed that Gene was present in prefusion palatal epithelium and was degraded during fusion. To investigate the developmental role of Gene, function-blocking antibody was added to Disease in organ culture. Palatal fusion was inhibited by this function-blocking antibody. To investigate the subsequent developmental role of Gene, we characterized Gene-deficient (Gene(-/-)) Species. Epithelial cells persisted abnormally at the midline of the Disease even on day E16.0, and Disease was delayed in Gene(-/-) Species. Gene expression, apoptosis, and cell proliferation in palatal epithelium were not affected in the Disease of Gene(-/-)Species. However, Gene expression was retained in the remaining MEE of Disease Species. These results suggest that Gene has roles in the Disease fusion via epithelial cell adhesion.

23233153.pub_title: A systematic survey of carbonic anhydrase mRNA expression during Species inner ear development.
23233153.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Carbonic anhydrases (CAs), which catalyze Chemical hydration to Chemical and protons, have been suggested to regulate Chemical homeostasis and endocochlear potential in the Species cochlea. Sixteen Species CA isozymes are currently known. To understand the specific roles of CA isozymes in the inner ear, a systematic survey was conducted to reveal Disease and spatial expression patterns of all 16 CA isozymes during inner ear development. RESULTS: Our quantitative reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction results showed that different tissues express unique combinations of CA isozymes. During inner ear development, transcripts of four cytosolic isozymes (Gene, Gene, Gene, and Car13), two membrane-bound isozymes (Car12 and Car14), and two CA-related proteins (Car8 and Car11) were expressed at higher levels than other isozymes. Spatial expression patterns of these isozymes within developing inner ears were determined by in situ hybridization. Each isozyme showed a unique expression pattern during development. For example, Car12 and Car13 expression closely overlapped with Gene, an anion exchanger, while Gene overlapped with Na-K-ATPase in type II and IV otic fibrocytes, suggesting functional relationships in the inner ear. CONCLUSIONS: The Disease and spatial expression patterns of each CA isozyme suggest unique and differential roles in inner ear development and function.

28005008.pub_title: Angiopoietin receptor Gene is required for vein specification and maintenance via regulating Gene.
28005008.pub_abstract: Mechanisms underlying the vein development remain largely unknown. Gene signaling mediates endothelial cell (EC) survival and vascular maturation and its activating mutations are linked to Disease. Here we show that vein formation are disrupted in Species skin and mesentery when Gene signals are diminished by targeted deletion of Gene either ubiquitously or specifically in embryonic ECs. Postnatal Gene attenuation resulted in the degeneration of newly formed veins followed by the formation of Disease and venous tortuosity. Mechanistically, Gene Disease compromised venous EC identity, as indicated by a significant decrease of Gene protein level, a key regulator in venogenesis. Consistently, Gene stimulation increased Gene in cultured ECs, while Gene knockdown or blockade of Gene downstream PI3K/Gene pathway reduced Gene which could be reverted by the proteasome inhibition. Together, our results imply that Gene is essential for venous specification and maintenance via Gene mediated stabilization of Gene.

22371395.pub_title: Endogenous Gene is highly expressed in Species epithelial barrier tissues, lymphoid organs, brain, embryos, and inflamed tissues: in situ analysis using a novel Gene-LacZ gene trap reporter strain.
22371395.pub_abstract: Gene (previously known as NF from high endothelial venules) is an IL-1 family cytokine that signals through the Gene receptor and drives cytokine production in mast cells, basophils, eosinophils, invariant NKT and NK cells, Gene lymphocytes, and type 2 innate immune cells (natural helper cells, nuocytes, and innate helper 2 cells). Little is known about endogenous Gene; for instance, the cellular sources of Gene in Species tissues have not yet been defined. In this study, we generated an Gene-LacZ gene trap reporter strain (Gene(Gt/Gt)) and used this novel tool to analyze expression of endogenous Gene in vivo. We found that the Gene promoter exhibits constitutive activity in Species lymphoid organs, epithelial barrier tissues, brain, and embryos. Immunostaining with anti-Gene Abs, using Gene(Gt/Gt) (Gene-deficient) Species as control, revealed that endogenous Gene protein is highly expressed in Species epithelial barrier tissues, including stratified Disease from vagina and skin, as well as cuboidal epithelium from lung, stomach, and salivary gland. Constitutive expression of Gene was not detected in blood vessels, revealing the existence of species-specific differences between Species and Species. Importantly, Gene protein was always localized in the nucleus of producing cells with no evidence for cytoplasmic localization. Finally, strong expression of the Gene-LacZ reporter was also observed in inflamed tissues, in the liver during LPS-induced Disease, and in the lung alveoli during papain-induced Disease. Together, our findings support the possibility that Gene may function as a nuclear alarmin to alert the innate immune system after Disease in epithelial barrier tissues.

25739401.pub_title: Identification of novel long noncoding RNAs underlying vertebrate cardiovascular development.
25739401.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) have emerged as critical epigenetic regulators with important functions in development and disease. Here, we sought to identify and functionally characterize novel lncRNAs critical for vertebrate development. METHODS AND RESULTS: By relying on Species pluripotent stem cell differentiation models, we investigated lncRNAs differentially regulated at key steps during Species cardiovascular development with a special focus on vascular endothelial cells. RNA sequencing led to the generation of large data sets that serve as a gene expression roadmap highlighting gene expression changes during Species pluripotent cell differentiation. Stage-specific analyses led to the identification of 3 previously uncharacterized lncRNAs, TERMINATOR, Gene, and Gene, specifically expressed in undifferentiated pluripotent stem cells, cardiovascular progenitors, and differentiated endothelial cells, respectively. Functional characterization, including localization studies, dynamic expression analyses, epigenetic modification monitoring, and knockdown experiments in lower vertebrates, as well as Species embryos and Species cells, confirmed a critical role for each lncRNA specific for each analyzed developmental stage. CONCLUSIONS: We have identified and functionally characterized 3 novel lncRNAs involved in vertebrate and Species cardiovascular development, and we provide a comprehensive transcriptomic roadmap that sheds new light on the molecular mechanisms underlying Species embryonic development, mesodermal commitment, and cardiovascular specification.

26407640.pub_title: Analysis of the Fam181 gene family during Species development reveals distinct strain-specific expression patterns, suggesting a role in nervous system development and function.
26407640.pub_abstract: During somitogenesis differential gene expression can be observed for so-called cyclic genes, which display expression changes with a periodicity of 120min in the Species. In screens to identify novel cyclic genes in Species embryos, Gene was predicted to be an oscillating gene in the presomitic mesoderm (psm). This gene, and its closely related paralog Gene, belong to the thus far uncharacterized Fam181 gene family. Here we describe the expression of Gene and Gene during Species embryonic development. In addition, we confirm oscillation of Gene in the psm in-phase with targets of, and regulated by, Notch signaling. Gene expression in the psm, as well as in the lateral plate mesoderm, was found to be affected by genetic background. We show that Gene and b exhibit partially overlapping mRNA expression patterns, and encode for proteins containing highly-conserved motifs, which predominantly localize to the nucleus. A Gene loss-of-function model was generated and found to result in no obvious phenotype.

22223678.pub_title: Gene(Gene) regulates Disease and intermediate precursor cell cycle dynamics and lower layer neurogenesis in developing cerebral cortex.
22223678.pub_abstract: During cerebral cortex development, precise control of precursor cell cycle length and cell cycle exit is required for balanced precursor pool expansion and layer-specific neurogenesis. Here, we defined the roles of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor (CKI) Gene(Gene), an important regulator of G1 phase, using deletion mutant Species. Mutant Species displayed Disease associated with cortical Disease during late embryogenesis and postnatal development. Embryonically, proliferation of radial glial cells (RGC) and intermediate precursors (IPC) was increased, expanding both populations, with greater effect on IPCs. Furthermore, cell cycle re-entry was increased during early corticogenesis, whereas cell cycle exit was augmented at middle stage. Consequently, neurogenesis was reduced early, whereas it was enhanced during later development. In agreement, the timetable of early neurogenesis, indicated by birthdating analysis, was delayed. Cell cycle dynamics analyses in mutants indicated that Gene(Gene) regulates cell cycle length in both RGCs and IPCs. By contrast, related CKI Gene(Gene) controlled IPC proliferation exclusively. Furthermore, Gene(Gene) deficiency markedly increased RGC and IPC divisions at E14.5, whereas Gene(Gene) increased IPC proliferation at E16.5. Consequently, loss of Gene(Gene) increased primarily layer 5-6 neuron production, whereas loss of Gene(Gene) increased neurons specifically in layers 2-5. In conclusion, our observations suggest that Gene(Gene) and Gene(Gene) control neuronal output for distinct cortical layers by regulating different stages of precursor proliferation, and support a model in which IPCs contribute to both lower and upper layer neuron generation.

23884928.pub_title: Gene balances progenitor maintenance with neurogenic output and promotes competence state progression in the developing retina.
23884928.pub_abstract: The LIM-Homeodomain transcription factor Gene is an essential organizer of early eye development and is subsequently expressed in retinal progenitor cells (RPCs). To determine its requirement in RPCs, we performed a temporal series of conditional inactivations in Species with the early RPC driver Pax6 alpha-Cre and the Chemical-inducible Gene(CreERT2) driver. Deletion of Gene caused a significant reduction of the progenitor population and a corresponding increase in neurogenesis. Precursor fate choice correlated with the time of inactivation; early and late inactivation led to the overproduction of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and rod photoreceptors, respectively. In each case, however, the overproduction was selective, occurring at the expense of other cell types and indicating a role for Gene in generating cell type diversity. RPCs that persisted in the absence of Gene continued to generate RGC precursors beyond their normal production window, suggesting that Gene facilitates a transition in competence state. These results identify Gene as a key regulator of RPC properties that contribute to the ordered production of multiple cell types during retinal tissue formation.

24726283.pub_title: A switch from low to high Gene activity regulates establishment of limb progenitors and signaling centers.
24726283.pub_abstract: The patterning and growth of the Disease is dependent on Gene (Gene), a morphogen that regulates the activity of Gene transcription factors. However, Gene expression is not observed during the first 12 hr of limb development. During this phase, the limb bud is prepatterned into anterior and posterior regions through the antagonistic actions of transcription factors Gene and Gene. We demonstrate that precocious activation of Gene signaling during this early phase interferes with the Gene-dependent specification of anterior progenitors, disturbing establishment of signaling centers and normal outgrowth of the limb. Our findings illustrate that limb development requires a sweet spot in the level and timing of pathway activation that allows for the Gene-dependent expansion of posterior progenitors without interfering with early prepatterning functions of Gene/Gli3R or specification of anterior progenitors.

23864681.pub_title: Gene acts in concert with Gene to promote polarization of migrating neurons.
23864681.pub_abstract: Gene has been ascribed a role in regulating polarization of primary hippocampal neurons. To better understand the possible role of Gene in the developing brain, we identified a member of the kinesin superfamily, Gene, as a novel Gene interacting protein and a potential mediator of Gene interaction with microtubules. Gene/Gene binding was mapped to a 57 aa Gene sequence, which was used as a dominant-negative fragment. Direct interaction between that peptide (MBD) and Gene was confirmed by surface plasmon resonance-based technology and the affinity was determined in the 10-7 m range. The proteins are expressed in the developing brain and formed a complex in vivo based on coimmunoprecipitation experiments and coimmunostaining in primary neurons. In primary hippocampal neurons Gene knockdown reduced Gene mobilization to the developing axon, as evidenced by immunostaining and fluorescence recovery after photobleaching analysis, suggesting that Gene is a novel Gene cargo. shRNA targeting of Gene reduced PIP3 accumulation in the growth cone, as did Gene shRNA. In the developing Species brain, Gene knockdown or expression of the Gene minimal binding domain inhibited neuronal migration, and in vivo migration assays suggested that Gene/Gene acts in the same genetic pathway. Time-lapse imaging of multipolar cells in the subventricular zone revealed that downregulating levels of either Gene or Gene hindered the transition from multipolar to bipolar cells. Collectively, our data demonstrate the importance of the Gene/Gene interaction to the dynamic process of Chemical neuronal polarization and migration.

24899573.pub_title: Simultaneous gene deletion of Gene and Gene leads to early disruption of follicular development and germ cell loss in the Species ovary.
24899573.pub_abstract: Granulosa cell formation and subsequent follicular assembly are important for ovarian development and function. Two members of the Gene family of transcription factors, Gene and Gene, are expressed in ovarian somatic cells early in development, and their importance in adult ovarian function has been recently highlighted. In this study, we demonstrated that the Disease of Gene and Gene expression within the ovary results in a strong down-regulation of genes involved in the Disease pathway (Fst and Gene) as well as diminished expression of the pregranulosa and granulosa cell markers SPRR2 and Gene, respectively. Disease in both Gene genes show impaired somatic cell proliferation and arrested follicular development at the primordial stage, where oocytes are either enclosed by one layer of squamous granulosa cells or remain in germ cell nests/clusters. Furthermore, germ cell nests and primordial follicles are predominantly localized to the central region of the Sf1Cre; Gene(flox/flox) Gene(flox/flox) ovaries, where the boundary between the medulla and cortex is almost nonexistent. Lastly, most of the oocytes are lost early in development in conditional double mutant ovaries, which confirms the importance of normally differentiated granulosa cells as supporting cells for oocyte survival. Thus, both Gene and Gene proteins are fundamental regulators of granulosa cell differentiation and proliferation, and consequently of proper follicular assembly during normal ovarian development and function.

23055936.pub_title: Mutations in Gene (Gene) perturb Hedgehog signaling, resulting in severe Disease.
23055936.pub_abstract: Disease (HPE) is a failure of the forebrain to bifurcate and is the most common structural malformation of the embryonic brain. Mutations in Gene underlie most familial (17%) cases of HPE; and, consistent with this, Gene is expressed in midline embryonic cells and tissues and their derivatives that are affected in HPE. It has long been recognized that a graded series of Disease occurs within the clinical spectrum of HPE, as HPE is often found in Species together with other malformations such as Disease, Disease, and agnathia. However, it is not known if these phenotypes arise through a common etiology and pathogenesis.
