Here we demonstrate for the first time using Species models that Gene (Gene) loss-of-function leads to Disease together with Disease and agnathia, which mimics the severe condition observed in Species. Gene is required for post-translational palmitoylation of Hedgehog (Hh) proteins; and, in the absence of Gene, Hh secretion from producing cells is diminished. We show through downregulation of the Hh receptor Gene that loss of Gene perturbs long-range Hh signaling, which in turn disrupts Fgf, Gene and Gene signaling. Collectively, this leads to abnormal patterning and extensive apoptosis within the craniofacial primordial, together with defects in Disease and bone differentiation. Therefore our work shows that Gene loss-of-function underscrores HPE; but more importantly it provides a mechanism for the co-occurrence of Disease, Disease, and agnathia. Future genetic studies should include Gene as a potential candidate in the etiology and pathogenesis of HPE and its associated disorders.

26333992.pub_title: Gene controls specialization of female gonads in Species.
26333992.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a type of membrane receptor with a seven-transmembrane structure. Gene is homologous to gonadotropin receptors, such as Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene). Recently, it has been reported that Gene is a membrane receptor for Gene ligands, which mediate Wnt/Gene signaling. Defects of Gene homolog (Gene) and Gene (Wnt4) cause masculinization of female gonads. We observed that Gene(-/-) female Species show abnormal development of the Wolffian ducts and somatic cells similar to that in the male gonads. Gene(-/-) female Species exhibited masculinization similar to that observed in Gene-deficient Species. In Gene(-/-) Disease cells, the expression levels of Gene (Lefl) and Gene (Gene), which are target genes of Wnt/Gene signaling, were lower than they were in wild-type Species. This study suggests that Gene is critical for Disease cell specialization via the cooperative signaling of Gene and Wnt/Gene.

26139165.pub_title: Ah Receptor Signaling Controls the Expression of Cardiac Development and Homeostasis Genes.
26139165.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) is the most common Disease and one of the leading causes of Disease throughout the world. Despite much emerging scientific information, the precise etiology of this disease remains elusive. Here, we show that the Gene (Gene) regulates the expression of crucial cardiogenesis genes and that interference with endogenous Gene functions, either by gene ablation or by agonist exposure during early development, causes overlapping structural and functional Disease that lead to altered fetal heart physiology, including higher heart rates, right and left ventricle dilation, higher Disease volume, and reduced ejection fraction. With striking similarity between Gene knockout (Gene(-/-)) and agonist-exposed wild type (Gene(+/+)) embryos, in utero disruption of endogenous Gene functions converge into dysregulation of molecular mechanisms needed for attainment and maintenance of cardiac differentiation, including the pivotal signals regulated by the cardiogenic transcription factor NKH2.5, energy balance via oxidative phosphorylation and Chemical cycle and global mitochondrial function and homeostasis. Our findings suggest that Gene signaling in the developing Species heart is central to the regulation of pathways crucial for cellular metabolism, cardiogenesis, and cardiac function, which are potential targets of environmental factors associated with Disease.

26367446.pub_title: Expression of Gene in microglia during development and following Disease.
26367446.pub_abstract: As the receptor of myelin associated inhibitory factors Gene (Gene) plays an important role in Disease and regeneration. It is found that Gene complex acts in neurons to transduce the signals intracelluarly including induction of growth cone collapse, inhibition of axonal regeneration and regulation of Disease. In recent studies, Gene has also been found to be expressed in the microglia. However, Gene expressed in microglia in the developing nervous systems and following Disease have not been widely investigated. In this study, we detected the expression and cellular localization of Gene in microglia during development and following Disease (TBI) in Species. The results showed that Gene was mainly expressed in microglia during embryonic and postnatal periods. The expression levels peaked at P4 and decreased thereafter into adulthood, while increased significantly with aging representatively at 17 mo. On the other hand, there was no significant difference in the number of double positive Gene(+)Iba1(+) cells between normal and TBI group. In summary, we first detected the expression of Gene in microglia during development and found that Gene protein expression increased significantly in microglia with aging. These findings will contribute to make a foundation for subsequent study about the role of Gene expressed in microglia on the CNS disorders.

27820600.pub_title: Direct reprogramming of fibroblasts into renal tubular epithelial cells by defined transcription factors.
27820600.pub_abstract: Direct reprogramming by forced expression of transcription factors can convert one cell type into another. Thus, desired cell types can be generated bypassing pluripotency. However, direct reprogramming towards renal cells remains an unmet challenge. Here, we identify renal cell fate-inducing factors on the basis of their tissue specificity and evolutionarily conserved expression, and demonstrate that combined expression of Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene converts Species and Species fibroblasts into induced renal tubular epithelial cells (iRECs). iRECs exhibit epithelial features, a global gene expression profile resembling their native counterparts, functional properties of differentiated renal tubule cells and sensitivity to Disease. Furthermore, iRECs integrate into kidney organoids and form tubules in decellularized kidneys. Our approach demonstrates that reprogramming factors can be identified by targeted in silico analysis. Renal tubular epithelial cells generated ex vivo by forced expression of transcription factors may facilitate disease modelling, drug and Disease testing, and regenerative approaches.

23161087.pub_title: The expression pattern of classical MHC class I molecules in the development of Species central nervous system.
23161087.pub_abstract: Classical major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I, first identified in the immune system, is also expressed in the developing and adult central nervous system (CNS). Although the MHC class I molecules have been found to be expressed in the CNS of different species, a necessary step to elucidate the temporal and spatial expression patterns of MHC class I molecules in the brain development has never been taken. Frozen sections were made from the brains of Disease and postnatal C57BL/6 J Species, and the expression of H-2D(b) mRNA was examined by in situ hybridization. Immunofluorescence was also performed to define the cell types that express Chemical-D(b) in P15 Species. At E10.5, the earliest stage we examined, Chemical-D(b) was expressed in neuroepithelium of the brain vesicles. From E12.5 to P0, Chemical-D(b) expression was mainly located at cerebral cortex, neuroepithelium of the lateral ventricle, neuroepithelium of aquaeductus and developing cerebellum. From P4 to adult, Chemical-D(b) mRNA was detected at olfactory bulb, hippocampus, cerebellum and some nerve nuclei. The major cell types expressing H-2D(b) in P15 hippocampus, cerebral cortex and olfactory bulb were neuron. Gene) signal paralleled that of Chemical-D(b) and the expression levels of the two molecules were comparable throughout the brain. The investigation of the expression pattern of H-2D(b) at both Disease and postnatal stages is important for further understanding the physiological and pathological roles of Chemical-D(b) in the developing CNS.

26439735.pub_title: Gene Controls the Proliferation of Cells of the Respiratory Airway through Distinct Microtubule Dependent Mechanisms.
26439735.pub_abstract: The cell cycle must be tightly coordinated for proper control of embryonic development and for the long-term maintenance of organs such as the lung. There is emerging evidence that Kinesin family member 7 (Gene) promotes Hedgehog (Hh) signaling during embryonic development, and its misregulation contributes to diseases such as Disease. Gene encodes a microtubule interacting protein that controls Hh signaling through regulation of microtubule dynamics within the primary cilium. However, whether Gene has a function in nonciliated cells remains largely unknown. The role Gene plays in basic cell biological processes like cell proliferation or cell cycle progression also remains to be elucidated. Here, we show that Gene is required for coordination of the cell cycle, and inactivation of this gene leads to increased cell proliferation in vivo and in vitro. Immunostaining and transmission electron microscopy experiments show that Kif7dda/dda mutant lungs are hyperproliferative and exhibit reduced alveolar epithelial cell differentiation. Gene depleted Chemical10T1/2 fibroblasts and Kif7dda/dda mutant Species embryonic fibroblasts have increased growth rates at high cellular densities, suggesting that Gene may function as a general regulator of cellular proliferation. We ascertained that in G1, Gene and microtubule dynamics regulate the expression and activity of several components of the cell cycle machinery known to control entry into S phase. Our data suggest that Gene may function to regulate the maintenance of the respiratory airway architecture by controlling cellular density, cell proliferation, and cycle exit through its role as a Gene.

23675524.pub_title: Generation and characterization of an Gene knockout Species to study Disease in a Species with Disease.
23675524.pub_abstract: Members of the Gene (Gene) family are involved in the export of mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm, or hypothesized to play a role in transport of cytoplasmic mRNA. We previously reported on the loss of Gene in a male Species with a syndromic form of Disease. To study the functional role of Gene we identified the Species counterpart. Based on synteny, Species Gene is the ortholog of Species Gene. However, we provide several lines of evidence that Species Gene is the actual functional equivalent of Gene. Both Gene and Gene are predominantly expressed in the brain, show cytoplasmic localization, and present as granules in neuronal dendrites suggesting a role in cytoplasmic mRNA metabolism in neurons. Gene was primarily detected in the pyramidal cells of the hippocampus and in layer V of the cortex. Similar to Species Gene, Species Gene is highly expressed in testis and shows a nuclear localization. Interestingly, these findings point to a different evolutionary path for both Gene genes in Species and Species. We thus generated and validated Gene knockout Species, which were fertile and did not present any gross anatomical or Disease. Expression profiling in the hippocampus and the cortex did not reveal significant changes between wild-type and Gene knockout Species. However, Disease was observed in these KO Species when evaluated in the Morris water maze test. In conclusion, our findings provide strong evidence that Species Gene is the functional counterpart of Species Gene, which might play a critical role in mRNA metabolism in the brain.

25848986.pub_title: Convergence and extrusion are required for normal fusion of the Species secondary Disease.
25848986.pub_abstract: The fusion of two distinct prominences into one continuous structure is common during development and typically requires integration of two epithelia and subsequent removal of that intervening epithelium. Using confocal live imaging, we directly observed the cellular processes underlying tissue fusion, using the secondary palatal shelves as a model. We find that convergence of a multi-layered epithelium into a single-layer epithelium is an essential early step, driven by cell intercalation, and is concurrent to orthogonal cell displacement and epithelial cell extrusion. Functional studies in Species indicate that this process requires an actomyosin contractility pathway involving Rho kinase (ROCK) and Gene (Gene), culminating in the activation of non-muscle myosin IIA (NMIIA). Together, these data indicate that actomyosin contractility drives cell intercalation and cell extrusion during Disease and suggest a general mechanism for tissue fusion in development.

23362312.pub_title: The polarity protein Gene is essential for directed endothelial cell migration.
23362312.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: Polarity proteins are involved in the apico-basal orientation of epithelial cells, but relatively little is known regarding their function in mesenchymal cells. OBJECTIVE: We hypothesized that polarity proteins also contribute to endothelial processes like angiogenesis. METHODS AND RESULTS: Screening of endothelial cells revealed high expression of the polarity protein Gene (Gene). On Gene-coated carriers Gene siRNA (siScrib) blocked directed but not random migration of Species umbilical vein endothelial cells and led to an increased number and disturbed orientation of cellular lamellipodia. Coimmunoprecipitation/mass spectrometry and Gene (Gene) pulldown assays identified Gene as a novel Gene interacting protein. By total internal reflection fluorescence (TIRF) microscopy, Gene and Gene colocalize at the basal plasma membrane of endothelial cells. Western blot and fluorescence activated cell sorting (FACS) analysis revealed that silencing of Gene reduced the protein amount and surface expression of Gene whereas surface expression of integrin alphaV was unaffected. Moreover, in contrast to Gene, the ligand of Gene, directional migration on collagen mediated by collagen-binding integrins was unaffected by siScrib. Mechanistically, Gene supported Gene recycling and protein stability by blocking its interaction with Gene, its translocation into lysosomes, and its subsequent degradation by Chemical-sensitive proteases. In siScrib-treated cells, reinduction of the wild-type protein but not of Gene, Dlg, Gene (Chemical), or Chemical rich repeat domain mutants restored Gene abundance and directional cell migration. The downregulation of Gene function in Tg(kdrl:EGFP)(s843) transgenic Species embryos delayed the angiogenesis of intersegmental vessels. CONCLUSIONS: Gene is a novel regulator of Gene turnover and sorting, which is required for oriented cell migration and sprouting angiogenesis.

24478334.pub_title: Deletion of Gene (Gene) specifically in cardiac and vascular smooth muscle cells reveals a crucial role for Gene in Species cardiovascular development.
24478334.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: Our previous study has shown that Gene (Gene) plays a crucial role in the phenotypic modulation of vascular smooth muscle cells (SMCs) in response to Disease. However, the role of Gene in vascular SMC development is unknown. OBJECTIVE: The goal of this study was to investigate the functional role of Gene in cardiovascular development in Species and determine the mechanisms underlying Gene's actions. METHODS AND RESULTS: Gene was deleted in cardiomyocytes and vascular SMCs by crossing Gene flox Species with Gene-Cre Species. Cardiac/SMC-specific deletion of Gene directed by Gene-Cre resulted in perinatal lethality in Species because of profound Disease including Disease, membranous Disease, and double outlet right ventricle. The cardiac/SMC-specific Gene knockout Species also displayed severe Disease including Disease wall, short/Disease, and retroesophageal right subclavian artery. Deletion of Gene in Species vascular SMCs induced expression of a subset of cell cycle arrest genes including G-protein-coupled receptor 132 (Gene). Silencing Gene promoted SMC proliferation, whereas overexpression of Gene attenuated SMC growth by arresting cell cycle in G0/G1 phase, suggesting that ablation of Gene-induced Disease was mediated, at least in part, by induction of Gene expression. Mechanistically, Gene recruited the epigenetic repressor histone deacetylase-4 to suppress Gene gene expression via a muscle CAT element in the Gene gene. CONCLUSIONS: Gene plays a critical role in cardiac/SMC proliferation during cardiovascular development by epigenetically regulating expression of a set of cell cycle suppressors.

23884891.pub_title: Gene and islet vascularization are necessary in developing, but not adult, Disease.
23884891.pub_abstract: Disease are highly vascularized mini-organs, and Gene (Gene)-A is a critical factor in the development of islet vascularization. To investigate the role of Gene and endothelial cells (ECs) in adult islets, we used complementary genetic approaches to temporally inactivate Gene in developing Species pancreatic and islet progenitor cells or in adult beta-cells. Inactivation of Gene early in development dramatically reduced pancreatic and islet vascularization, leading to reduced beta-cell proliferation in both developing and adult islets and, ultimately, reduced beta-cell mass and Disease clearance. When Gene was inactivated in adult beta-cells, islet vascularization was reduced twofold. Surprisingly, even after 3 months of reduced islet vascularization, islet architecture and beta-cell gene expression, mass, and function were preserved with only a minimal abnormality in Chemical clearance. These data show that normal pancreatic Gene expression is critical for the recruitment of ECs and the subsequent stimulation of endocrine cell proliferation during islet development. In contrast, although Gene is required for maintaining the specialized vasculature observed in normal adult islets, adult beta-cells can adapt and survive long-term reductions in islet vascularity. These results indicate that Gene and islet vascularization have a lesser role in adult islet function and beta-cell mass.

26582204.pub_title: The A-kinase Anchoring Protein Gene Regulates Gene Activity and Controls Palatal Shelf Fusion in Species.
26582204.pub_abstract: A-kinase anchoring proteins (AKAPs) represent a family of structurally diverse proteins, all of which bind PKA. A member of this family is Gene (Gene (Gene). Gene interacts with PKA and also directly interacts with Gene. The physiological function of the Gene protein in vivo is unknown. We developed and characterized a conditional knock-out Species model and found that Gene deficiency caused lethality at birth. Embryos obtained through Caesarean section at embryonic day 18.5 were cyanotic, suffered from respiratory distress, and failed to initiate breathing properly. Additionally, all Gene-deficient embryos showed an incomplete closure of the palatal shelves accompanied by a delay in ossification along the fusion area of secondary palatal bones. On the molecular level, Gene deficiency resulted in decreased phosphorylation of Gene at Chemical-9 starting early in development (embryonic day 10.5), leading to enhanced Gene activity. At embryonic day 18.5, Gene activity decreased to levels close to that of wild type. Our findings reveal a novel, crucial role for Gene in the coordination of Gene signaling in palatal shelf fusion.

22234993.pub_title: Preaxial polydactyly caused by Gene Disease is rescued by Gene loss of function in Species.
22234993.pub_abstract: Disease are important birth defects that are incompletely understood genetically and mechanistically. Gene, a mediator of hedgehog signaling, is a genetic cause of Disease including pre- and postaxial polydactyly, Disease and Disease. A closely related Gli (Disease-associated oncogene homolog)-superfamily member, Gene, causes Disease in Species but has not been investigated in limb development. During limb development, post-translational processing of Gene from activator to repressor antagonizes and posteriorly restricts Gene (Gene). We demonstrate that Gene and Gene expression overlap in developing limbs and that Gene converts Gene from repressor to activator in vitro. In Gene mutant Species, Gene loss of function abrogates ectopic Gene expression in anterior limb buds, limits overexpression in the zone of polarizing activity and normalizes aberrant Gene repressor/Gene activator ratios observed in Gene+/- embryos. Gene null;Gene+/- neonates show rescue of the Disease phenotype seen in Gene+/- animals. These studies identify a previously unrecognized role for Gene in regulating limb digit number via its modifying effect on Gene and Gene expression levels. Together, these results indicate that two Gli superfamily members that cause disparate Species Disease interact genetically and demonstrate the importance of Gene in regulating Gene pathway in developing limbs.

22841643.pub_title: Limb anterior-posterior polarity integrates activator and repressor functions of Gene as well as Gene.
22841643.pub_abstract: Anterior-posterior (AP) limb patterning is directed by Gene (Gene) signaling from the posteriorly located zone of polarizing activity (ZPA). Gene and Gene are the transcriptional mediators generally utilized in Gene signaling, and each can function as an activator (A) and repressor (R). Although GLI3R has been suggested to be the primary effector of Gene signaling during limb AP patterning, a role for GLI3A or Gene has not been fully ruled out, nor has it been determined whether Gene plays distinct roles in limb development at different stages. By conditionally removing Gene in the limb at multiple different time points, we uncovered four Gene-mediated functions in limb development that occur at distinct but partially over-lapping time windows: AP patterning of the proximal limb, AP patterning of the distal limb, regulation of digit number and bone differentiation. Furthermore, by removing Gene in Gene temporal conditional knock-outs, we uncovered an essential role for Gene in providing the remaining posterior limb patterning seen in Gene single mutants. To test whether GLIAs or GLIRs regulate different aspects of AP limb patterning and/or digit number, we utilized a knock-in allele in which Gene, which functions solely as an activator, is expressed in place of the bifunctional Gene protein. Interestingly, we found that GLIAs contribute to AP patterning specifically in the posterior limb, whereas GLIRs predominantly regulate anterior patterning and digit number. Since Gene is a more effective repressor, our results explain why Gene is required only for anterior limb patterning and why Gene can compensate for GLI3A in posterior limb patterning. Taken together, our data suggest that establishment of a complete range of AP positional identities in the limb requires integration of the spatial distribution, timing, and dosage of Gene and Gene activators and repressors.

26395878.pub_title: Gene plays an essential role in axon growth and guidance and in neuronal survival in the central and peripheral nervous systems.
26395878.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Gene is a critical regulator of cytoskeletal dynamics in multiple cell types. In the nervous system, it has been implicated in the control of cell proliferation, neuronal migration, and axon development. RESULTS: To systematically investigate the role of Gene in axon growth and guidance in the developing nervous system, we have examined the phenotypes associated with deleting Gene in the embryonic Species forebrain, in cranial and spinal motor neurons, in cranial sensory and dorsal root ganglion neurons, and in the retina. We observe a widespread requirement for Gene in axon growth and guidance and a cell-autonomous defect in axon growth in Gene (-/-) motor neurons in culture. Disease, presumably a secondary consequence of the axon growth and/or guidance defects, was observed in multiple locations. Following deletion of Gene in the forebrain, thalamocortical axons were misrouted inferiorly, with the majority projecting to the contralateral thalamus and a minority projecting ipsilaterally to the ventral cortex, a pattern of misrouting that is indistinguishable from the pattern previously observed in Gene (-/-) and Gene (-/-) forebrains. In the limbs, motor-neuron-specific deletion of Gene produced a distinctive stalling of axons within the dorsal nerve of the hindlimb but a much milder loss of axons in the ventral hindlimb and forelimb nerves, a pattern that is virtually identical to the one previously observed in Gene (-/-) limbs. CONCLUSIONS: The similarities in axon growth and guidance phenotypes caused by Gene, Gene, and Gene loss-of-function mutations suggest a mechanistic connection between tissue polarity/planar cell polarity signaling and Gene-dependent cytoskeletal regulation.

24650709.pub_title: Foxi transcription factors promote pharyngeal arch development by regulating formation of FGF signaling centers.
24650709.pub_abstract: The bones of the vertebrate face develop from transient Disease that are populated by cranial neural crest cells. We have characterized a Species mutant for the Forkhead family transcription factor Gene, which is expressed in branchial ectoderm and endoderm. Gene mutant Species are not viable and display severe branchial arch-derived facial skeleton defects, including absence of all but the most distal tip of the mandible and complete absence of the inner, middle and external ear structures. Although cranial neural crest cells of Gene mutants are able to migrate, populate the branchial arches, and display some elements of correct proximo-distal patterning, they succumb to apoptosis from embryonic day 9.75 onwards. We show this cell death correlates with a delay in expression of Gene in branchial arch ectoderm and a failure of neural crest cells in the arches to express FGF-responsive genes. Species Gene is also expressed in branchial arch ectoderm and endoderm, and morpholino knock-down of Gene also causes apoptosis of neural crest in the branchial arches. We show that heat shock induction of Gene in Species arch tissue can rescue cell death in Gene morphants. Our results suggest that Gene may play a role in the establishment of signaling centers in the branchial arches that are required for neural crest survival, patterning and the subsequent development of branchial arch derivatives.

22976838.pub_title: EphA/ephrin-A signaling is critically involved in region-specific apoptosis during early brain development.
22976838.pub_abstract: EphAs and ephrin-As have been implicated in the morphogenesis of the developing brain. We found that Gene and Gene are coexpressed in the dorsal midline (DM) of the Disease. Interestingly, programmed cell death (Disease) of the neural epithelial cells normally found in this region was reduced in Gene/Gene dual-deficient embryos. In contrast, in vivo expression of Gene-Fc or full-length Gene strongly induced apoptosis in neural epithelial cells and was accompanied by severe brain malformation during embryonic development. Expression of Gene-Fc correlated with apoptosis of Gene-expressing cells, whereas null mutation of Gene resulted in the converse phenotype. Importantly, null mutation of Gene or endogenous Gene attenuated the Disease induced by ectopically overexpressed Gene. Together, our results suggest that brain region-specific Disease may occur in a region where EphAs cluster with neighboring ephrin-As through cell-cell contact.

23399934.pub_title: Gene is stage-specifically expressed during Species embryonic development and regulates Gene.
23399934.pub_abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small non-coding RNAs that participate in a large variety of biological processes. In this paper, the spatiotemporal expression pattern of Gene was characterized during Species embryonic development, and was found to be stage- and tissue-specifically expressed. In addition, through luciferase reporter assays and western blot analyses, Gene (Gene) was identified as a directly regulated target of Gene. Altogether, our results indicate that Gene may play important roles in the morphogenesis of diverse organs, especially brain and adrenal glands, by mediating Gene expression during Species development.

22958821.pub_title: Gene governs the migration of postmitotic neurons that shape respiratory effectiveness at birth and chemoresponsiveness in adulthood.
22958821.pub_abstract: Hindbrain neuronal networks serving respiratory, proprioceptive, and arousal functions share a developmental requirement for the bHLH transcription factor Gene. Loss of Gene in Species results in Disease and neonatal lethality; however, the neuronal identity and mechanism by which Gene-dependent cells sustain newborn breathing remains unknown. We uncovered that selective loss of Gene from the postmitotic retrotrapezoid nucleus (RTN) neurons results in severely impaired inspiratory rhythm and pronounced Disease. Species that escape Disease develop Disease as adults. Interestingly, the expression of Gene in the RTN neurons is not required for their specification or maintenance, but is important for their proper localization and to establish essential connections with the preBotzinger Complex (preBotC). These results provide insights into the genetic regulation of Disease and shed light on the labile sites that might contribute to Disease in newborn Species and altered chemoresponsiveness in adults.

25807483.pub_title: Global genetic analysis in Species unveils central role for cilia in Disease.
25807483.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) is the most prevalent Disease, affecting nearly 1% of live births; the incidence of Disease is up to tenfold higher in Species fetuses. A genetic contribution is strongly suggested by the association of Disease with Disease and high recurrence risk. Here we report findings from a recessive forward genetic screen in fetal Species, showing that cilia and cilia-transduced cell signalling have important roles in the pathogenesis of Disease. The cilium is an evolutionarily conserved organelle projecting from the cell surface with essential roles in diverse cellular processes. Using echocardiography, we ultrasound scanned 87,355 chemically mutagenized C57BL/6J fetal Species and recovered 218 Disease Species models. Whole-exome sequencing identified 91 recessive Disease mutations in 61 genes. This included 34 cilia-related genes, 16 genes involved in cilia-transduced cell signalling, and 10 genes regulating vesicular trafficking, a pathway important for ciliogenesis and cell signalling. Surprisingly, many Disease genes encoded interacting proteins, suggesting that an interactome protein network may provide a larger genomic context for Disease pathogenesis. These findings provide novel insights into the potential Mendelian genetic contribution to Disease in the fetal population, a segment of the Species population not well studied. We note that the pathways identified show overlap with Disease candidate genes recovered in Disease Species, suggesting that they may have relevance to the more complex genetics of Disease overall. These Disease Species models and >8,000 incidental mutations have been sperm archived, creating a rich public resource for Species disease modelling.

26272686.pub_title: Expression of multiple formins in adult tissues and during developmental stages of Species brain.
26272686.pub_abstract: Formins are highly conserved heterogeneous family of proteins with several isoforms having significant contribution in multiple cellular functions. Formins play crucial role in remodelling of actin cytoskeleton and thus play important role in cell motility. Formins are also involved in many cellular activities like determining cell polarity, cytokinesis and morphogenesis. Formins are multi domain protein with characteristic homodimeric formin homology 2 (FH2) domain. It nucleates the actin filaments and its activity is regulated by the presence of characteristic formin homology 1 (FH1) domain. In higher mammals like Species and Species fifteen different formin isoforms are present. However the function and expression pattern of each and every formin in different adult tissues are not well characterized. Here we have found that multiple formins are expressing in each adult tissue of Species, irrespective of their origin from the germ layer. Formins are also expressing from early stage of development to the adulthood in brain. The expression of many formins in a single tissue of adult Species indicates that regulation of actin cytoskeleton dynamics by formins may be crucial for physiological processes like wound healing, tissue repairing, exocytosis, endocytosis, synapse formation and maintenance. Expression of Gene and Gene are high in adult Species brain as compare to embryonic stages. Higher expression of Gene and Gene indicates that Gene and Gene might be very important for the adult brain functions.

23934215.pub_title: Primary cilium migration depends on G-protein signalling control of subapical cytoskeleton.
23934215.pub_abstract: In ciliated Species cells, the precise migration of the primary cilium at the apical surface of the cells, also referred to as translational polarity, defines planar cell polarity (PCP) in very early stages. Recent research has revealed a co-dependence between planar polarization of some cell types and cilium positioning at the surface of cells. This important role of the primary cilium in Species cells is in contrast with its absence from Disease. Here, we show that deletion of GTP-binding protein alpha-i subunit 3 (Galphai3) and Species Partner of inscuteable (mPins) disrupts the migration of the kinocilium at the surface of cochlear hair cells and affects hair bundle orientation and shape. Inhibition of G-protein function in vitro leads to kinocilium Disease, PCP phenotype and abnormal hair bundle morphology. We show that Galphai3/mPins are expressed in an apical and distal asymmetrical domain, which is opposite and complementary to an aPKC/Gene/Gene expression domain, and non-overlapping with the core PCP protein Gene. Thus G-protein-dependent signalling controls the migration of the cilium cell autonomously, whereas core PCP signalling controls long-range tissue PCP.

24934157.pub_title: The Cavbeta1a subunit regulates gene expression and suppresses Gene in muscle progenitor cells.
24934157.pub_abstract: Voltage-gated Chemical channel (Gene) beta subunits are auxiliary subunits to Cavs. Recent reports show Cavbeta subunits may enter the nucleus and suggest a role in transcriptional regulation, but the physiological relevance of this localization remains unclear. We sought to define the nuclear function of Cavbeta in muscle progenitor cells (MPCs). We found that Cavbeta1a is expressed in proliferating MPCs, before expression of the Chemical conducting subunit Gene, and enters the nucleus. Loss of Cavbeta1a expression impaired MPC expansion in vitro and in vivo and caused widespread changes in global gene expression, including up-regulation of Gene. Additionally, we found that Cavbeta1a localizes to the promoter region of a number of genes, preferentially at noncanonical (NC) E-box sites. Cavbeta1a binds to a region of the Gene promoter containing an NC E-box, suggesting a mechanism for inhibition of Gene gene expression. This work indicates that Cavbeta1a acts as a Gene-independent regulator of gene expression in MPCs, and is required for their normal expansion during myogenic development.

26965372.pub_title: Single-stranded DNA binding proteins are required for Gene complexes to induce transcriptionally active chromatin and specify spinal neuronal identities.
26965372.pub_abstract: Gene homeodomain factors regulate the development of many cell types. However, transcriptional coactivators that mediate their developmental function remain poorly defined. To address these, we examined how two related Gene-dependent Gene complexes, which govern the development of spinal motor neurons and V2a interneurons, activate the transcription in the Disease. We found that single-stranded DNA-binding proteins are recruited to these Gene complexes via Gene, and enhance their transcriptional activation potential. Gene and Gene (Gene) are highly expressed in the neural tube and promote motor neuron differentiation in the Disease and P19 stem cells. Inhibition of Gene activity in Species and Species embryos suppresses the generation of motor neurons and V2a interneurons. Furthermore, Gene recruit histone-modifying enzymes to the motor neuron-specifying Gene complex and trigger acetylation and Chemical 4 trimethylation of histone H3, which are well-established chromatin marks for active transcription. Our results suggest that Gene function as crucial transcriptional coactivators for Gene complexes to specify spinal neuronal identities during development.

24167707.pub_title: Dynamic relationship of the epithelium and mesenchyme during salivary gland initiation: the role of Gene.
24167707.pub_abstract: Salivary glands provide an excellent model for the study of epithelial-mesenchymal interactions. We have looked at the interactions involved in the early initiation and development of Species salivary glands using classic recombination experiments and knockout Species. We show that salivary gland epithelium, at thickening and initial bud stages, is able to direct salivary gland development in non-gland pharyngeal arch mesenchyme at early stages. The early salivary gland epithelium is therefore able to induce gland development in non-gland tissue. This ability later shifts to the mesenchyme, with non-gland epithelium, such as from the limb bud, able to form a branching gland when combined with pseudoglandular stage gland mesenchyme. This shift appears to involve Fgf signalling, with signals from the epithelium inducing Gene in the mesenchyme. Gene then signals back to the epithelium to direct gland down-growth and bud development. These experiments highlight the importance of epithelial-mesenchymal signalling in gland initiation, controlling where, when and how many salivary glands form.

23622242.pub_title: Gene forms a complex with Dicer to promote microRNA processing and RNA-induced gene silencing.
23622242.pub_abstract: Chemical deaminases acting on RNA (ADARs) are involved in RNA editing that converts Chemical residues to Chemical specifically in double-stranded RNAs. In this study, we investigated the interaction of the RNA editing mechanism with the RNA interference (RNAi) machinery and found that Gene forms a complex with Dicer through direct protein-protein interaction. Most importantly, Gene increases the maximum rate (Vmax) of pre-microRNA (miRNA) cleavage by Dicer and facilitates loading of miRNA onto RNA-induced silencing complexes, identifying a new role of Gene in miRNA processing and RNAi mechanisms. Gene differentiates its functions in RNA editing and RNAi by the formation of either Gene/Gene homodimer or Dicer/Gene heterodimer complexes, respectively. As expected, the expression of miRNAs is globally inhibited in Gene(-/-) Species embryos, which, in turn, alters the expression of their target genes and might contribute to their embryonic lethal phenotype.

25354456.pub_title: Expression and evolution of the Gene and Gene genes in vertebrates.
25354456.pub_abstract: Gene is a Wnt protease and antagonist specifically expressed in the Spemann-Mangold Organizer and is required for head formation in Species embryos. Here we report neighbor-joining phylogenetic analysis of vertebrate Tiki genes and their mRNA expression patterns in Species, Species, and Species embryos. Gene and Gene orthologues are highly conserved, and exhibit similar but also different developmental expression patterns among the vertebrate/Species species analyzed. The Gene gene is noticeably absent in the rodent lineage, but is present in lagomorphs and all other vertebrate/Species species examined. Expression in Hensen's node, the equivalent of the Species Organizer, was observed for Species Gene and Species Gene and Gene. Species Gene was detected at low levels at gastrulation and head fold stages, but not in the node. Species Gene and Species Gene display similar expression in the dorsal spinal cord. Species Gene expression was also detected in the surface ectoderm and maxillary bud, while Species Gene was found in the anterior intestinal portal, head mesenchyme and primitive atrium. Our expression analyses provide evidence that Gene and Gene are evolutionarily conserved among vertebrate species and their expression in the Organizer and other regions suggests contributions of these Wnt inhibitors to embryonic patterning, as well as organogenesis. Our analyses further reveal mis-regulation of Gene and Gene in Species Disease and diseases.

27100196.pub_title: Gene Controls Acquisition of Sensory Area Identity and Establishment of Sensory Input Fields in the Developing Neocortex.
27100196.pub_abstract: While transcriptional controls over the size and relative position of cortical areas have been identified, less is known about regulators that direct acquisition of area-specific characteristics. Here, we report that the transcription factor Gene functions in primary sensory areas to repress motor and activate sensory programs of gene expression, enabling establishment of sharp molecular boundaries defining functional areas. In Gene mutants, abnormal gene expression leads to aberrantly motorized corticocortical and corticofugal output connectivity. Gene critically regulates differentiation of layer IV neurons, and selective loss of Gene in cortex deprives thalamocortical axons of their receptive "sensory field" in layer IV, which normally provides a tangentially and radially defined compartment of dedicated synaptic territory. Therefore, although thalamocortical axons invade appropriate cortical regions, they are unable to organize into properly configured sensory maps. Together, these data identify Gene as a critical control over sensory area development.

25105228.pub_title: Exome sequencing identifies a recurrent de novo Gene mutation associated with Disease.
25105228.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) is a Disease characterized by distinct craniofacial, brain, and Disease, including Disease, interhemispheric Disease, agenesis of the corpus callosum, Disease, preaxial polydactyly of the feet, and Disease. Exome sequencing of one trio and two unrelated probands revealed the same heterozygous variant (c.3487C>T [Protein Mutation]) in a highly conserved protein domain of Gene; this variant has not been seen in the 1000 Genomes data, dbSNP, or the Exome Sequencing Project. Sanger validation of the three trios confirmed that the variant was de novo and was also present in a fourth isolated proband. In situ hybridization of early Species embryos at 24 hr postfertilization (hpf) demonstrated Disease expression of Gene and onset of midbrain, hindbrain, and retinal expression at 48 hpf. Immunohistochemistry of later-stage Species embryos demonstrated tissue-specific expression in the derivatives of all three germ layers. qRT-PCR expression analysis of osteoblast and fibroblast cell lines available from two probands was suggestive of Hedgehog pathway activation, indicating that the Gene mutation associated with Disease may lead to the craniofacial, brain and Disease through the disruption of Hedgehog signaling.

22903314.pub_title: Gene controls subplate formation and growth of cortical axons.
22903314.pub_abstract: The formation of a functional cortical circuitry requires the coordinated growth of cortical axons to their target areas. While the mechanisms guiding cortical axons to their targets have extensively been studied, very little is known about the processes which promote their growth in vivo. Gene encodes a zinc finger transcription factor which is expressed in cortical progenitor cells and has crucial roles in cortical development. Here, we characterize the Gene compound mutant Gene(Xt/Pdn), which largely lacks Neurofilament(+) fibers in the rostral and intermediate neocortex. Chemical labeling and Golli-tauGFP immunofluorescence indicate that Gene(Xt/Pdn) cortical neurons form short and stunted axons. Using transplantation experiments we demonstrate that this axon growth defect is primarily caused by a nonpermissive cortical environment. Furthermore, in Emx1Cre;Gene(Pdn/fl) conditional mutants, which mimic the reduction of Gene expression in the dorsal telencephalon of Gene(Xt/Pdn) embryos, the growth of cortical axons is not impaired, suggesting that Gene controls this process early in Disease development. In contrast to cortical plate neurons, Gene(Xt/Pdn) embryos largely lack subplate (SP) neurons which normally pioneer cortical projections. Collectively, these findings show that Gene specifies a cortical environment permissive to the growth of cortical axons at the progenitor level by controlling the formation of SP neurons.

23789102.pub_title: Gene (Gene) plays a role in the maintenance of hematopoietic stem cell activity in the Species embryonic aorta.
23789102.pub_abstract: Integrins are transmembrane receptors that play important roles as modulators of cell behaviour through their adhesion properties and the initiation of signaling cascades. The Gene integrin subunit (Gene) is one of the first cell surface markers indicative of hematopoietic commitment. Gene pairs exclusively with beta3 to form the alphaIIbbeta3 integrin. beta3 (Gene) also pairs with Chemical (Gene) to form the alphavbeta3 integrin. The expression and putative role of these integrins during Species hematopoietic development is as yet unknown. We show here that hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) differentially express alphaIIbbeta3 and alphavbeta3 integrins throughout development. Whereas the first HSCs generated in the aorta at mid-gestation express both integrins, HSCs from the placenta only express alphavbeta3, and most fetal liver HSCs do not express either integrin. By using Gene deficient embryos, we show that Gene is not only a reliable HSC marker but it also plays an important and specific function in maintaining the HSC activity in the Species embryonic aorta.

25354453.pub_title: Palatal adhesion is dependent on Gene family kinases and p38MAPK.
25354453.pub_abstract: During secondary palate development, palatal shelves adhere to each other in the midline to form a midline epithelial seam leading to palatal closure. Cell-cell and cell-extracellular matrix adhesions, which are mediated by cell adhesion receptors, Gene and integrins, are implicated in the process of adhesion of the palatal shelves. Gene family kinases (SFK) function downstream of both receptors. In this study, we focused on the role of SFK in the process of palatal adhesion. During palatal adhesion, the expression of SFK mRNA, as well as localization and quantitation of the protein in the activated form, were examined by real-time qPCR and immunofluorescence. Palatal organ cultures were performed to identify the effect of pharmacological inhibition of SFK on palatal adhesion. Activated SFKs were found to be co-localized with adhesion receptors, Gene and integrins in the palatal medial edge epithelium. Gene, Gene and Yes subfamily members were expressed in the palatal tissue. The expression of SFK mRNA and the quantity of the activated form of the protein were upregulated during palatal adhesion. An SFK inhibitor, Gene, blocked palatal adhesion, but another SFK inhibitor, Chemical was not inhibitory. However, the combination of Chemical and either of the p38MAPK inhibitors, Chemical or Chemical, showed similar inhibitory effects on palatal adhesion compared to Gene alone. The p38MAPK inhibitors alone did not alter palatal adhesion. Real-time qPCR revealed that p38MAPK alpha and delta were elevated during palatal adhesion. This study indicates that palatal cell adhesion is dependent on signaling from integrin receptors and Gene through SFK and p38MAPK.

24131628.pub_title: Fetal adrenal capsular cells serve as progenitor cells for steroidogenic and stromal adrenocortical cell lineages in Species.
24131628.pub_abstract: The lineage relationships of fetal adrenal cells and adrenal capsular cells to the differentiated adrenal cortex are not fully understood. Existing data support a role for each cell type as a progenitor for cells of the adult cortex. This report reveals that subsets of capsular cells are descendants of fetal adrenocortical cells that once expressed Gene. These fetal adrenocortical cell descendants within the adrenal capsule express Gene, a known marker of progenitors of steroidogenic adrenal cells. The capsule is also populated by cells that express Gene, a known inhibitor of Gene gene expression. We demonstrate that Gene-expressing cells give rise to Gene-expressing cells but only before capsular formation. After the capsule has formed, capsular Gene-expressing cells give rise only to non-steroidogenic stromal adrenocortical cells, which also express collagen 1a1, Gene and Gene) but not Gene. These observations integrate prior observations that define two separate origins of adult adrenocortical steroidogenic cells (fetal adrenal cortex and/or the adrenal capsule). Thus, these observations predict a unique temporal and/or spatial role of adult cortical cells that arise directly from either fetal cortical cells or from fetal cortex-derived capsular cells. Last, the data uncover the mechanism by which two populations of fetal cells (fetal cortex derived Gene-expressing cells and mesenchymal Gene-expressing mesenchymal cells) participate in the establishment of the homeostatic capsular progenitor cell niche of the adult cortex.

23788624.pub_title: A genetic and developmental pathway from Gene to the Gene-Gene circuit is essential for maintenance of ICM lineages in vivo.
23788624.pub_abstract: Although it is known that Gene-Gene are required for maintenance of pluripotent cells in vitro, the upstream signals that regulate this circuit during early development in vivo have not been identified. Here we demonstrate, for the first time, Gene (Gene)-dependent regulation of the Gene-Gene circuitry necessary to maintain the pluripotent inner cell mass (ICM), the source of in vitro-derived Disease stem cells (ESCs). We show that Gene is highly expressed in Species oocytes and becomes phosphorylated and translocates to the nucleus in the four-cell and later stage embryos. Using Gene (Gene)-null embryos, we found that Gene phosphorylation is dependent on Gene in four-cell stage embryos. In Disease, Gene (Gene) acts in an autocrine fashion to ensure Gene phosphorylation, mediated by Gene (Gene), a Gene- and Gene-dependent kinase. Using genetically engineered Species strains to eliminate Gene in oocytes and embryos, we firmly establish that Gene is essential for maintenance of ICM lineages but not for ICM and trophectoderm formation. Indeed, Gene directly binds to the Gene and Gene distal enhancers, modulating their expression to maintain pluripotency of Species Disease and induced pluripotent stem cells. These results provide a novel genetic model of cell fate determination operating through Gene in the preimplantation embryo and pluripotent stem cells in vivo.

22421355.pub_title: Gene (Gene) regulate early migration of Cajal-Retzius cells from the cortical hem.
22421355.pub_abstract: Cajal-Retzius (CR) cells play a crucial role in the formation of the cerebral cortex, yet the molecules that control their development are largely unknown. Here, we show that Gene transcription factors are expressed in forebrain signalling centres-the septum, cortical hem and the pallial-subpallial boundary-known to generate CR cells. We identified Gene, through fate mapping studies, as a novel marker for cortical hem- and septum-derived CR cells. Loss of Gene in vivo causes a transient decrease in CR cell numbers on the cortical surface due to a migratory defect in the cortical hem, and is accompanied by upregulation of Gene in this and other forebrain territories that produce CR cells, without affecting proper cortical lamination. Accordingly, using in vitro preparations, we demonstrated that both Gene and Gene, singly or together, control the migration of CR cells arising in the cortical hem. These findings provide evidence that Ebfs directly regulate CR cell development.

22354863.pub_title: Avian intervertebral disc arises from rostral sclerotome and lacks a nucleus pulposus: implications for evolution of the vertebrate disc.
22354863.pub_abstract: Deterioration of the intervertebral discs is an unfortunate consequence of aging. The intervertebral disc in mammals is composed of three parts: a jelly-like center called the nucleus pulposus, the Disease, and anterior and posterior endplates that attach the discs to vertebrae. To understand the origin of the disc, we have investigated the intervertebral region of Species. Surprisingly, our comparison of Species and Species discs revealed that Species discs lack nuclei pulposi. In addition, the notochord, which in Species forms nuclei pulposi, was found to persist as a rod-like structure and express Gene throughout Species embryogenesis. Our fate mapping data indicate that cells originating from the rostral half of each somite are responsible for forming the avian disc while cells in the caudal region of each somite form vertebrae. A histological analysis of Species and nonmammalian organisms suggests that nuclei pulposi are only present in mammals.

24173031.pub_title: Disease model reveals Gene deletion causes apoptosis of Gene+ progenitors and peripheral neurons.
24173031.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) is a devastating developmental and progressive Disease caused by a mutation in the gene inhibitor of kappa B kinase complex-associated protein (Gene). To identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms that cause Disease, we generated Species in which Gene expression is ablated in the peripheral nervous system and identify the steps in peripheral nervous system development that are Gene-dependent. We show that Gene is not required for trunk neural crest migration or pathfinding, nor for the formation of dorsal root or sympathetic ganglia, or the adrenal medulla. Instead, Gene is essential for the second wave of neurogenesis during which the majority of tropomyosin-related kinase A (Gene(+)) nociceptors and thermoreceptors arise. In its absence, approximately half the normal complement of Gene(+) neurons are lost, which we show is partly due to Gene-mediated premature differentiation and death of mitotically-active progenitors that express the paired-box gene Gene and give rise to the majority of Gene(+) neurons. By the end of sensory development, the number of Gene neurons is significantly increased, which may result from an increase in Gene(+) cells. Furthermore, our data demonstrate that Gene(+) (but not Gene(+)) sensory and sympathetic neurons undergo exacerbated Gene-mediated programmed cell death in the absence of Gene and that this death is not due to a reduction in nerve growth factor synthesis. In summary, these data suggest that Disease does not result from a failure in trunk neural crest migration, but rather from a critical function for Gene in Gene progenitors and Gene(+) neurons.

25678108.pub_title: Region-specific regulation of cell proliferation by FGF receptor signaling during the Wolffian duct development.
25678108.pub_abstract: The Wolffian duct (Disease) is a primordium of the male reproductive tract and kidney collecting duct system. Fibroblast growth factor receptors (FGFRs), members of the Gene (Gene) family, are essential for kidney development. Although the functions of FGFR signaling in kidney morphogenesis have been analyzed, their function in Disease development has not been comprehensively investigated. Here, we demonstrate that Gene is the major Fgfr gene expressed throughout the Disease and that it is essential for the maintenance of the Disease, specifically in the caudal part of the Disease. Gene-Cre mediated inactivation of Gene in the Species Disease resulted in the regression of the caudal part of the Disease and abnormal male reproductive tract development. Cell proliferation and expression of the downstream target genes of Gene signaling (Gene and Gene) were decreased in the caudal part of the Disease in the mutant embryos. Cranial (rostral) Disease formation and ureteric budding were not affected. Gene, Gene, and Gene expression were sustained in the ureteric bud of the mutant embryos. Taken together, these data suggest region-specific requirements for Gene signaling in the developing caudal Disease.

26203155.pub_title: Orchestration of Neuronal Differentiation and Progenitor Pool Expansion in the Developing Cortex by SoxC Genes.
26203155.pub_abstract: As the cerebral cortex forms, specialized molecular cascades direct the expansion of progenitor pools, the differentiation of neurons, or the maturation of discrete neuronal subtypes, together ensuring that the correct amounts and classes of neurons are generated. In several neural systems, the SoxC transcriptional regulators, particularly Gene and Gene, have been characterized as functioning exclusively and redundantly in promoting neuronal differentiation. Using the Species cerebral cortex as a model, Gene and Gene were examined in the formation of the most complex part of the Species brain. Anticipated prodifferentiation roles were observed. Distinct expression patterns and mutant phenotypes, however, reveal that Gene and Gene are not redundant in the cortex, but rather act in overlapping and discrete populations of neurons. In particular, Gene acts in early-born neurons; binding to its partner protein, Gene, leads to selective targeting and transactivation of a downstream gene, Gene. In addition to neuronal expression, Gene was unexpectedly expressed in intermediate progenitor cells, the transit amplifying cell of the cerebral cortex. Gene mutant analyses reveal a requirement for Gene in IPC specification and maintenance. In intermediate progenitors, Gene partners with the proneural gene Gene to activate Gene and then with Gene to maintain this cell fate. This work reveals an intricately structured molecular architecture for SoxC molecules, with Gene acting in a select set of cortical neurons and Gene playing an unanticipated role in designating secondary progenitors.

24036135.pub_title: Parcellation of the thalamus into distinct nuclei reflects EphA expression and function.
24036135.pub_abstract: Intercellular signaling via the Eph receptor Chemical kinases and their ligands, the ephrins, acts to shape many regions of the developing brain. One intriguing consequence of Eph signaling is the control of mixing between discrete cell populations in the developing hindbrain, contributing to the formation of segregated rhombomeres. Since the thalamus is also a parcellated structure comprised of discrete nuclei, might Eph signaling play a parallel role in cell segregation in this brain structure? Analyses of expression reveal that several Eph family members are expressed in the forming thalamus and that cells expressing particular receptors form cellular groupings as development proceeds. Specifically, expression of receptors Gene or Gene and ligand Gene is localized to distinct thalamic domains. Gene and Gene are often coexpressed in regions of the forming thalamus, with each receptor marking discrete thalamic domains. In contrast, Gene is expressed by a limited group of thalamic cells. Within the ventral thalamus, Gene is present broadly, occasionally overlapping with Gene expression. Gene is more restricted in its expression and is largely nonoverlapping with Gene. In mutant Species lacking one or both receptors or Gene, the appearance of the venteroposterolateral (VPL) and venteroposteromedial (Chemical) nuclear complex is altered compared to wild type Species. These in vivo results support a role for Eph family members in the definition of the thalamic nuclei. In parallel, in vitro analysis reveals a hierarchy of mixing among cells expressing Gene with cells expressing Gene alone, Gene and Gene together, or Gene alone. Together, these data support a model in which EphA molecules promote the parcellation of discrete thalamic nuclei by limiting the extent of cell mixing.

24972638.pub_title: Postnatal maintenance of the Gene-Gene autoregulatory loop by Chemical in the raphe nuclei of the brainstem.
24972638.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the importance of Gene as a major target for the action of several anxiolytics/antidepressant drugs, little is known about its regulation in central Chemical (Chemical, 5-HT) neurons. RESULTS: We report that expression of Gene and the transcription factor Gene was impaired in the rostral raphe nuclei of Species lacking Gene (Gene) after birth. The downregulation of Gene was recapitulated in Gene-/- Species. Using an explant culture system, we show that reduction of Gene and Gene was rescued in Gene-/- brainstem by exogenous 5-HT. In contrast, 5-HT failed to rescue reduced expression of Gene in Gene-/- brainstem explant culture. CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest a causal relationship between Gene and Gene, and reveal a potential mechanism by which Gene-Gene autoregulatory loop is maintained by 5-HT in a spatiotemporal-specific manner during postnatal development. Our results are relevant to understanding the pathophysiology of certain Disease and Disease.

22144232.pub_title: Isolation of fetal gonads from embryos of timed-pregnant Species for morphological and molecular studies.
22144232.pub_abstract: Gonadal sex differentiation is an important developmental process, in which a bipotential primordial gonad undergoes two distinct pathways, i.e., testicular and Disease differentiation, dependent on its genetic sex. Techniques of isolating fetal gonads at various developmental stages are valuable for studies on the molecular events involved in cell-fate determination, sex-specific somatic and germ-cell differentiation and structural organization. Here we describe various procedures for isolation of embryonic gonads at different developmental stages from embryos of timed-pregnant Species. The isolated fetal gonads can be used for a variety of studies, such as organ culture, gene and protein expression. As examples of applications, we describe the immunofluorescence detection of Gene expression in gonadal tissue sections and microRNAs profiling/expression in fetal gonads at a critical stage for sex determination.

23034632.pub_title: Gene regulates Gene through Gene-dependent and -independent functions during skin development and tumorigenesis.
23034632.pub_abstract: Abnormal activation of Hedgehog (Hh) signaling leads to Disease (BCC) of the skin, the most common Species Disease. Gene, the major transcriptional activator of Hh signaling, is essential for hair follicle development and its overexpression in epidermis induces BCC formation and maintains Disease growth. Despite its importance in skin development and tumorigenesis, little is known about the molecular regulation of Gene. Gene and Gene are two evolutionarily conserved regulators of Gli transcription factors. Here, we show that Gene and Gene regulate Gene through distinct mechanisms in keratinocytes. Gene restricts the activity of Gene through cytoplasmic sequestration. Gene possesses Gene-dependent and -independent regulatory functions in Hh signaling: while it promotes Hh pathway activity through the dissociation of Gene-Gene complex, it also contributes to the repression of Hh target genes in the absence of Gene. Deletion of both Gene and Gene in embryonic skin leads to complete loss of follicular fate. Importantly, although inactivation of Gene or Gene alone in adult epidermis cannot promote BCC formation, their simultaneous deletion induces BCC. These studies establish Gene and Gene as crucial components in the regulation of Gene localization and activity, and illustrate their overlapping functions in skin development and Disease suppression.

24183668.pub_title: Single-cell profiling of epigenetic modifiers identifies Gene as an inducer of cell fate in the Species embryo.
24183668.pub_abstract: Cell plasticity or potency is necessary for the formation of multiple cell types. The mechanisms underlying this plasticity are largely unknown. Preimplantation Species embryos undergo drastic changes in cellular potency, starting with the totipotent zygote through to the formation of the pluripotent inner cell mass (ICM) and differentiated trophectoderm in the blastocyst. Here, we set out to identify and functionally characterize chromatin modifiers that define the transitions of potency and cell fate in the Species embryo. Using a quantitative microfluidics approach in single cells, we show that developmental transitions are marked by distinctive combinatorial profiles of epigenetic modifiers. Pluripotent cells of the ICM are distinct from their differentiated trophectoderm counterparts. We show that Gene is heterogeneously expressed in 4-cell-stage embryos. Forced expression of Gene at the 2-cell stage leads to increased Chemical and can induce a pluripotent ICM fate. Our results shed light on the epigenetic networks that govern cellular potency and identity in vivo.

24146773.pub_title: The AERO system: a 3D-like approach for recording gene expression patterns in the whole Species embryo.
24146773.pub_abstract: We have recently constructed a web-based database of gene expression in the Species whole embryo, EMBRYS (http://embrys.jp/embrys/html/MainMenu.html). To allow examination of gene expression patterns to the fullest extent possible, this database provides both photo images and annotation data. However, since embryos develop via an intricate process of morphogenesis, it would be of great value to track embryonic gene expression from a three dimensional perspective. In fact, several methods have been developed to achieve this goal, but highly laborious procedures and specific operational skills are generally required. We utilized a novel microscopic technique that enables the easy capture of rotational, 3D-like images of the whole embryo. In this method, a rotary head equipped with two mirrors that are designed to obtain an image tilted at 45 degrees to the microscope stage captures serial images at 2-degree intervals. By a simple operation, 180 images are automatically collected. These 2D images obtained at multiple angles are then used to reconstruct 3D-like images, termed AERO images. By means of this system, over 800 AERO images of 191 gene expression patterns were captured. These images can be easily rotated on the computer screen using the EMBRYS database so that researchers can view an entire embryo by a virtual viewing on a computer screen in an unbiased or non-predetermined manner. The advantages afforded by this approach make it especially useful for generating data viewed in public databases.

27606421.pub_title: Sexual Fate Change of XX Germ Cells Caused by the Deletion of Gene and Gene Independent of Somatic Sex Reprogramming.
27606421.pub_abstract: The differential programming of sperm and eggs in gonads is a fundamental topic in reproductive biology. Although the sexual fate of germ cells is believed to be determined by signaling factors from sexually differentiated somatic cells in fetal gonads, the molecular mechanism that determines germ cell fate is poorly understood. Herein, we show that Gene (Gene) in germ cells is required for female-type differentiation. Germ cells in Disease respond to Chemical signaling but fail to undergo meiotic prophase I, which coincides with the weaker expression of genes required for follicular formation, indicating that Gene signaling is essential for oocyte differentiation and meiotic progression. Intriguingly, germline-specific deletion of Gene in Gene-null female germ cells resulted in the up-regulation of genes required for male gonocyte differentiation, including Gene and Gene, suggesting the initiation of male-type differentiation in Disease. Moreover, our transcriptome analyses of mutant Disease revealed that the sex change phenotype is achieved without global gene expression changes in somatic cells. Our results demonstrate that Gene and Gene are essential factors that regulate the female fate of germ cells.

24857857.pub_title: RELAXIN enhances differentiation and matrix mineralization through Gene (Gene) in MC3T3-E1 cells in vitro.
24857857.pub_abstract: RELAXIN (RLN) is a polypeptide hormone of the Gene-like hormone family; it facilitates birth by softening and widening the pubic symphysis and cervix in many mammals, including Species. The role of RLN in bone metabolism was recently suggested by its ability to induce osteoclastogenesis and activate osteoclast function. RLN binds to RELAXIN/Gene-LIKE FAMILY PEPTIDE 1 (Gene) and 2 (Gene), with varying species-specific affinities. Young Species with mutated Gene are at high risk for Disease, as Gene influences osteoblast metabolism by binding to Gene (Gene). However, there have been no reports on RLN function in osteoblast differentiation and mineralization or on the functionally dominant receptors for RLN in osteoblasts. We previously described Gene expression patterns in developing Species oral components, including the maxillary and mandibular bones, Meckel's cartilage, tongue, and Disease. We hypothesized that Rln/Rxfp signaling is a key mediator of skeletal development and metabolism. Here, we present the gene expression patterns of Gene in developing Species calvarial frontal bones as determined by in situ hybridization. In addition, RLN enhanced Disease and caused abnormal mineralization and extracellular matrix metabolism through Gene, which was predominant over Gene in MC3T3-E1 Species calvarial osteoblasts. Our data suggest a novel role for Rln in craniofacial skeletal development and metabolism through Gene.

22693558.pub_title: The BMP ligand Gene prevents differentiation of coronal suture mesenchyme in early cranial development.
22693558.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a member of the Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP) family of secreted signaling molecules. Previous studies have shown that Gene plays a role in formation of a diverse subset of skeletal joints. In Species, loss of Gene results in fusion of the coronal suture, the intramembranous joint that separates the frontal and parietal bones. Although the role of GDFs in the development of Disease has been studied, limb joints are developmentally quite distinct from cranial sutures and how Gene controls suture formation has remained unclear. In this study we show that coronal suture fusion in the Gene-/- Species is due to accelerated differentiation of suture mesenchyme, prior to the onset of calvarial ossification. Gene is expressed in the Species frontal bone primordia from embryonic day (E) 10.5 through 12.5. In the Gene-/- embryo, the coronal suture fuses prematurely and concurrently with the Disease in the cranial bones. Alkaline phosphatase (Disease) activity and Gene expression assays both showed that the suture width is reduced in Gene+/- embryos and is completely absent in Gene-/- embryos by E12.5. Disease activity is also increased in the suture mesenchyme of Gene+/- embryos compared to wild-type. This suggests Gene delays differentiation of the mesenchyme occupying the suture, prior to the onset of ossification. Therefore, although BMPs are known to promote bone formation, Gene plays an inhibitory role to prevent the osteogenic differentiation of the coronal suture mesenchyme.

22277947.pub_title: Identification of Gene target genes reveals the involvement of chemokines in hair development.
22277947.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene), a member of the Gene (Gene) family, regulates skin appendage morphogenesis via its receptor Gene and transcription factor Gene. In Species, inactivating mutations in the Gene pathway components lead to Disease (Disease), a syndrome characterized by sparse hair, Disease, and Disease in several cutaneous glands. A corresponding phenotype is observed in Gene-null Species, where failure in the initiation of the first wave of hair follicle development is a hallmark of Disease pathogenesis. In an attempt to discover immediate target genes of the Gene/Gene pathway, we performed microarray profiling of genes differentially expressed in Disease explants after a short exposure to recombinant Fc-Gene protein. Upregulated genes included components of the Wnt, fibroblast growth factor, transforming growth factor-beta, Gene, and epidermal growth factor families, indicating that Gene modulates multiple signaling pathways implicated in skin appendage development. Surprisingly, we identified two ligands of the chemokine receptor Gene, Gene and Gene, as new hair-specific transcriptional targets of Gene. Deficiency in Gene resulted in decreased primary hair follicle density but otherwise normal hair development, indicating that chemokine signaling influences the patterning of primary hair placodes only.

23145320.pub_title: Loss of maternal annexin A5 increases the likelihood of placental platelet Disease and Disease.
23145320.pub_abstract: Disease is associated with an increased risk of Disease and pregnancy loss. Annexin A5 (Anxa5) is a candidate autoantigen. It is not known, however, whether endogenous Anxa5 prevents Disease during normal pregnancy. We found significant reductions in litter size and foetal weight in Anxa5-null Species (Anxa5-KO). These changes occurred even when only the mother was Anxa5-KO. A small amount of placental fibrin deposition was observed in the decidual tissues, but did not noticeably differ between wild-type and Anxa5-KO Species. However, immunoreactivity for integrin beta 3/CD61, a platelet marker, was demonstrated within thrombi in the arterial canals only in Anxa5-KO mothers. Subcutaneous administration of the anticoagulant heparin to pregnant Anxa5-KO Species significantly reduced pregnancy loss, suggesting that maternal Anxa5 is crucial for maintaining intact placental circulation. Hence, the presence of maternal Anxa5 minimises the risk of Disease in the placental circulation and reduces the risk of Disease.

26319580.pub_title: Class 3 semaphorins negatively regulate dermal lymphatic network formation.
26319580.pub_abstract: The development of a patterned lymphatic vascular network is essential for proper lymphatic functions during organ development and homeostasis. Here we report that class 3 semaphorins (SEMA3s), Gene and Gene negatively regulate lymphatic endothelial cell (LEC) growth and sprouting to control dermal lymphatic network formation. Gene (Gene) functions as a receptor for Gene and Gene, as well as Gene (Gene). In culture, Both Gene and Gene inhibit Gene-mediated sprouting and proliferation of Species dermal LECs. In the developing Species skin, Gene is expressed in the epidermis and Gene expression is restricted to arteries, whereas their receptor Gene is preferentially expressed by lymphatic vessels. Both Gene;Gene double mutants and Gene mutants exhibit increased LEC growth in the skin. In contrast, Gene;Gene double mutants display increased lymphatic branching, while Gene mutants exhibit reduced lymphatic branching. A targeted mutation in Gene or Gene, signal transducers forming a receptor complex with Gene for SEMA3s, exhibits an increase in LEC growth and lymphatic branching as observed in Gene;Gene double mutants. Our results provide the first evidence that Gene and Gene function as a negative regulator for dermal lymphangiogenesis in vivo. The reciprocal phenotype in lymphatic branching between Gene;Gene double mutants and Gene mutants suggest a complex Gene function that regulates LEC behavior both positively and negatively, through a binding with Gene or SEMA3s.

24026051.pub_title: Evidence that the novel receptor Gene signals indirectly via Gene.
24026051.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a recently discovered member of the FGF receptor (Gene) family. Similar to the classical FGFRs, it contains three extracellular immunoglobulin-like domains and interacts with FGF ligands. However, in contrast to the classical receptors, it does not contain any intracellular Chemical kinase domain and consequently cannot signal by transphosphorylation. In Species kidneys, Gene is expressed primarily at embryonic stages E14-E15 in regions where nascent nephrons develop. In this study, we used whole-mount in situ hybridization to show the spatial pattern of five different Fgfrs in the developing Species kidney. We compared the expression pattern of Gene with that of other Fgfrs. The expression pattern of Gene closely resembled that of Gene, but clearly differed from that of Gene-Gene. It is therefore conceivable that Gene signals indirectly via Gene. The mechanisms by which Gene affects the activity of Gene remain to be elucidated.

26253403.pub_title: Gene is required for cytoskeletal support of endothelial cell adhesion during blood vessel formation in Species.
26253403.pub_abstract: The Rho family of small GTPases has been shown to be required in endothelial cells (ECs) during blood vessel formation. However, the underlying cellular events controlled by different GTPases remain unclear. Here, we assess the cellular mechanisms by which Gene regulates Species vascular morphogenesis and maintenance. In vivo deletion of Gene in embryonic ECs (Gene(Tie2KO)) results in blocked lumen formation and endothelial tearing, leading to lethality of mutant embryos by E9-10 due to failed blood circulation. Similarly, inducible deletion of Gene (Gene(Cad5KO)) at mid-gestation blocks angiogenic tubulogenesis. By contrast, deletion of Gene in postnatal retinal vessels leads to aberrant vascular remodeling and sprouting, as well as markedly reduced filopodia formation. We find that Gene is essential for organization of EC adhesion, as its loss results in disorganized cell-cell junctions and reduced focal adhesions. Endothelial polarity is also rapidly lost upon Gene deletion, as seen by failed localization of apical Gene (Gene) and basal actin. We link observed failures to a defect in F-actin organization, both in vitro and in vivo, which secondarily Disease and polarity. We also identify Gene effectors Gene and Gene, as well as the actomyosin machinery, to be crucial for EC actin organization. This work supports the notion of Gene as a central regulator of the cellular machinery in ECs that drives blood vessel formation.

24040265.pub_title: Developmental expression of Gene/peripheral Chemical receptor in reproductive tissues.
24040265.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) present in the outer mitochondrial membrane has been suggested to be critical for Disease, a rate-limiting step for Chemical hormone biosynthesis. Despite the importance of steroidogenesis in regulating reproductive functions, the developmental profile of Gene expression in the gonads and accessory sex organs has not been completely characterized. As a first step towards understanding the function of Gene, we studied its expression in male and female Species reproductive organs. We examined testes and Disease at embryonic days 14.5 and 18.5, and postnatal days 0, 7, 14, 21 and 56 of development. In the adult testis, Gene was expressed in both Leydig cells and Sertoli cells. In the developing testes Gene expression was seen in immature Sertoli cells, fetal Leydig cells and gonocytes. In the ovary, Gene was expressed in the ovarian surface epithelium, interstitial cells granulosa cells and luteal cells. Corpora lutea of Disease from pregnant Species showed strong expression of Gene. In the developing ovary, Gene expression was seen in the squamous pregranulosa cells associated with germ line cysts, together with progressively increasing expression in interstitial cells and the ovarian surface epithelium.
