Furthermore, Gene(+) and Gene(+) proepicardial cells contribute to the early sinus venosus and cardiac endocardium, respectively, two tissues linked to vascular endothelial formation at later stages. Taken together, our studies demonstrate that the proepicardial organ is a molecularly compartmentalized structure, reconciling prior Species and Species data and providing a more complete understanding of the progenitor populations that establish the coronary vascular endothelium.

25446526.pub_title: Gene DNA methylation regulates the timing and Chemical sensitivity of Species prostate ductal development.
25446526.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) signaling initiates Species prostate development by stimulating prostate ductal bud formation and specifying bud patterns. Curiously, however, prostatic bud initiation lags behind the onset of gonadal Chemical synthesis by about three days. This study's objective was to test the hypothesis that DNA methylation controls the timing and scope of prostate ductal development by regulating Ar expression in the urogenital sinus (UGS) from which the prostate derives. We determined that Ar DNA methylation decreases in UGS mesenchyme during prostate bud formation in vivo and that this change correlates with decreased DNA methyltransferase expression in the same cell population during the same time period. To examine the role of DNA methylation in prostate development, fetal UGSs were grown in serum-free medium and 5 Chemical (Chemical) and the DNA methylation inhibitor Chemical (5AzadC) were introduced into the medium at specific times. As a measure of prostate development, in situ hybridization was used to visualize and count Gene mRNA positive prostatic buds. We determined that inhibiting DNA methylation when prostatic buds are being specified, accelerates the onset of prostatic bud development, increases bud number, and sensitizes the budding response to Chemical. Inhibition of DNA methylation also reduces Ar DNA methylation in UGS explants and increases Ar mRNA and protein in UGS mesenchyme and epithelium. Together, these results support a novel mechanism whereby Ar DNA methylation regulates UGS Chemical sensitivity to control the rate and number of prostatic buds formed, thereby establishing a developmental checkpoint.

24164893.pub_title: Crumbs3 is essential for proper epithelial development and viability.
24164893.pub_abstract: First identified in Disease, the Crumbs (Crb) proteins are important in epithelial polarity, apical membrane formation, and tight junction (TJ) assembly. The conserved Crb intracellular region includes a FERM (Gene/ezrin/radixin/moesin) binding domain (FBD) whose Species binding partners are not well understood and a PDZ binding motif that interacts with Species Gene (protein associated with lin seven) (also known as Gene). Gene binds Patj (Gene), a multi-PDZ-domain protein that associates with many tight junction proteins. The Crb complex also binds the conserved Gene/Gene (aPKC) polarity cassette that restricts migration of basolateral proteins through phosphorylation. Here, we describe a Gene knockout Species that demonstrates extensive defects in epithelial morphogenesis. The Species die shortly after birth, with Disease and proteinaceous debris throughout the lungs. The intestines display villus fusion, apical membrane blebs, and disrupted microvilli. These intestinal defects phenocopy those of Ezrin knockout Species, and we demonstrate an interaction between Crumbs3 and ezrin. Taken together, our data indicate that Crumbs3 is crucial for epithelial morphogenesis and plays a role in linking the apical membrane to the underlying ezrin-containing cytoskeleton.

23822972.pub_title: Gene Dosage Effects at the Imprinted Gene Cluster.
23822972.pub_abstract: Genomic imprinting results in parent-of-origin-dependent monoallelic gene expression. Early work showed that distal Species chromosome 2 is imprinted, as maternal and paternal duplications of the region (with corresponding paternal and Disease) give rise to different anomalous phenotypes with early Disease. Newborns with maternal duplication (MatDp(dist2)) are long, thin and hypoactive whereas those with paternal duplication (PatDp(dist2)) are chunky, Disease, and Disease. Here we focus on PatDp(dist2). Loss of expression of the maternally expressed Gene transcript at the Gene cluster has been thought to account for the PatDp(dist2) phenotype. But PatDp(dist2) also have two expressed doses of the paternally expressed Gene transcript. Through the use of targeted mutations, we have generated PatDp(dist2) Species predicted to have 1 or 2 expressed doses of Gene, and 0, 1 or 2 expressed doses of Gene. We confirm that Disease is due to lack of expression of imprinted Gene alone. We show that it is the combination of a double dose of Gene, with no dose of imprinted Gene, that gives rise to the characteristic Disease, chunky, Disease, lethal PatDp(dist2) phenotype, which is also hypoglycaemic. However PatDp(dist2) Species in which the dosage of the Gene and Gene is balanced (either 2:2 or 1:1) are neither dysmorphic nor Disease, have normal Chemical levels, and are fully viable. But PatDp(dist2) with biallelic expression of both Gene and Gene show a marked Disease. Our results show that most of the PatDp(dist2) phenotype is due to overexpression of Gene combined with loss of expression of Gene, and suggest that Gene and Gene may act antagonistically in a number of tissues and to cause a wide range of phenotypic effects. It can be concluded that monoallelic expression of both Gene and Gene is a requirement for normal postnatal growth and development.

25545407.pub_title: Gene-deficient Species have Disease due to defective Chemical neuronal migration.
25545407.pub_abstract: Disease (HH) can be acquired through energy restriction or may be inherited as Disease and its anosmia-associated form, Disease. Disease is associated with mutations in a group of genes that impact Gene (Gene) function. The Gene gene encodes a Chemical-dependent histone deacetylase that links intracellular metabolic stress to gene expression. Herein Gene(-/-) Species are shown to have HH due to failed Chemical neuronal migration. Gene (Gene) catalytic function induces Chemical neuronal migration via binding and deacetylating Gene. Gene colocalized with Gene in Chemical neurons in vitro. Gene colocalization with Gene was regulated in an Gene/Gene dependent manner. The profound effect of Gene on the hormonal status of Gene(-/-) Species, mediated via defective Chemical neuronal migration, links energy metabolism directly to the hypogonadal state. Gene-Gene may serve as the distal transducer of neuronal migration mediated by the Gene synexpression group of genes that govern HH.

27687499.pub_title: Impaired Gene secretion: A potential mechanism for Disease in Disease.
27687499.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease), a Disease, results from recessive mutations affecting the glucosyltransferase Gene, leading to Disease and diverse extra-ocular manifestations. Together with the fucosyltransferase Gene, Gene adds Chemical to a consensus sequence in thrombospondin type 1 repeats (TSRs) of several proteins. Which of these target proteins is functionally compromised in Disease is unknown. We report here that Disease of Species Gene, encoding a secreted metalloproteinase with 15 TSRs, leads to Disease and Disease (persistent lens-cornea adhesion), which is a Disease. Mass spectrometry of recombinant Gene showed that 9 of 12 TSRs with the O-fucosylation consensus sequence carried the Chemical and Gene knockdown reduced Gene secretion in HEK293F cells. Together, the genetic and biochemical findings imply a dosage-dependent role for Gene in ocular morphogenesis. Reduced secretion of Gene in the absence of Gene is proposed as a mechanism of Disease in Disease. The functional link between Gene and Gene established here also provides credence to their recently reported association with age-related macular degeneration.

22354913.pub_title: Expression pattern changes and function of Gene during Species lymph node microarchitecture development.
22354913.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) expression was examined during the development of Species fetal peripheral lymphoid organs. A shift in the expression pattern was detected during the transition from lymphoid tissue inducer (LTi) cells to lymphoid tissue organizer (LTo) cells in the lymph node (LN) anlagen but not in the Peyer's patch anlagen. In order to understand the functional impact of these changes in the fetal expression of Gene, the Gene function was blocked by a blocking antibody. Excess anti-Gene antibody was administered to pregnant Species between 13.5 and 16.5 dpc and was found to completely block LN anlagen development, suggesting that Gene function during this period is critical for LN development. In addition, small amounts of anti-Gene antibodies were injected directly into the amniotic space at 13.5 dpc, resulting in perturbed B-cell follicle formation and high endothelial venule differentiation after birth. These results suggest that Gene expression on LTi cells during the early phase of LN development is critical for the development LN microarchitecture.

27546376.pub_title: Transcriptional targets of Gene in the cranial mesoderm regulate cell-matrix interactions and mesenchyme maintenance.
27546376.pub_abstract: Gene, a basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor is essential for the development of cranial mesoderm and cranial neural crest-derived craniofacial structures. We have previously shown that, in the absence of Gene, cells within the cranial mesoderm adopt an abnormal epithelial configuration via a process reminiscent of a mesenchymal to epithelial transition (MET). Here, we show by gene expression analysis that loss of Gene in the cranial mesoderm is accompanied by a reduction in the expression of genes that are associated with cell-extracellular matrix interactions and the acquisition of mesenchymal characteristics. By comparing the transcriptional profiles of cranial mesoderm-specific Gene loss-of-function mutant and control Species embryos, we identified a set of genes that are both Gene-dependent and predominantly expressed in the mesoderm. ChIP-seq was used to identify Gene-binding sites in an in vitro model of a Gene-dependent mesenchymal cell state, and the data were combined with the transcriptome data to identify potential target genes. Three direct transcriptional targets of Gene (Gene, Gene and Gene) were validated by ChIP-PCR using Species embryonic tissues and by luciferase assays. Our findings reveal that the mesenchymal properties of the cranial mesoderm are likely to be regulated by a network of Gene targets that influences the extracellular matrix and cell-matrix interactions, and collectively they are required for the morphogenesis of the craniofacial structures.

24992711.pub_title: The mineral dissolution function of osteoclasts is dispensable for Disease degradation during long bone development and growth.
24992711.pub_abstract: During long bone development and post-natal growth, the cartilaginous model of the skeleton is progressively replaced by bone, a process known as endochondral ossification. In the primary spongiosa, osteoclasts degrade the mineralized cartilage produced by Disease chondrocytes to generate cartilage trabeculae that osteoblasts embed in bone matrix. This leads to the formation of the trabecular bone network of the secondary spongiosa that will undergo continuous remodeling. Osteoclasts are specialized in mineralized tissue degradation, with the combined ability to solubilize Chemical and to degrade extracellular matrix proteins. We reported previously that osteoclasts lacking Gene could not degrade bone due to abnormal podosome organization and absence of sealing zone formation. Consequently, adult Gene(-/-) Species have increased trabecular bone mass. We used Gene(-/-) Species to further investigate the different functions of osteoclast during endochondral bone formation. We show that long bones are overall morphologically normal in developing and growing Gene(-/-) Species. We demonstrate that Gene(-/-) Species also have normal Disease and cartilage trabecular network. Conversely, trabecular bone volume increased progressively in the secondary spongiosa of Gene(-/-) growing Species as compared to Gene(+/+) animals, even though their osteoclast numbers were the same. In vitro, we show that Gene(-/-) osteoclasts do present acidic compartments at the ventral plasma membrane and produce normal amounts of active Gene, Gene and Gene for matrix protein degradation but they are unable to solubilize minerals. These observations reveal that contrarily to bone resorption, the ability of osteoclasts to dissolve minerals is dispensable for the degradation of mineralized Disease during endochondral bone formation.

22922260.pub_title: Autonomic Disease-associated mutations in Gene dysregulate Gene expression.
22922260.pub_abstract: The most common forms of Disease in the autonomic nervous system are Disease (HSCR), resulting in Disease, and Disease (NB), Disease originating from the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. The risk for these diseases dramatically increases in Species with Disease (Disease) harboring a Chemical repeat expansion mutation of the Gene (Gene) gene, but the molecular mechanism of pathogenesis remains unknown. We found that introducing Chemical repeat expansion mutation of the Gene into the Species Gene locus recapitulates the clinical features of the Disease associated with HSCR and NB. In mutant embryos, enteric and sympathetic ganglion progenitors showed sustained sex-determining region Y (Gene (Gene) expression, with Disease and biased differentiation toward the glial lineage. Chemical repeat expansion mutation of Gene reduced transactivation of wild-type Gene on its known target, Gene (Gene), in a dominant-negative fashion. Moreover, the introduced mutation converted the transcriptional effect of Gene on a Gene enhancer from repression to transactivation. Collectively, these data reveal that Chemical repeat expansion mutation of Gene is both a dominant-negative and gain-of-function mutation. Our results also demonstrate that Gene regulation by Gene is pivotal for the development and pathogenesis of the autonomic ganglia.

27321946.pub_title: Mutations in Gene Are Identified in Individuals with Disease.
27321946.pub_abstract: Disease is one of the most common Disease in Species. Disease, a severe form of Disease, is genetically and phenotypically a heterogeneous condition. Although significant efforts have been made, the genetic etiology of dental agenesis remains largely unknown. In the present study, we performed whole-exome sequencing to identify the causative mutations in Chinese families in whom Disease segregates with dominant inheritance. We detected a heterozygous missense mutation (c.632G>A [Protein Mutation]) in Gene in all affected family members. By Sanger sequencing a cohort of 145 unrelated individuals with Disease, we identified three additional mutations (c.569C>G [Protein Mutation], c.786G>A [Protein Mutation*)], and c.851T>G [Protein Mutation]). Interestingly, analysis of genotype-phenotype correlations revealed that mutations in Gene affect the development of permanent dentition, particularly the lateral incisors. Furthermore, a functional assay demonstrated that each of these mutants could not normally enhance the canonical Gene signaling in HEPG2 epithelial cells, in which activity of the TOPFlash luciferase reporter was measured. Notably, these mutant Gene ligands could not efficiently induce endothelial differentiation of dental pulp stem cells. Our findings provide the identification of autosomal-dominant Gene mutations in individuals with Disease, which increases the spectrum of Disease and suggests attenuated Gene signaling in endothelial differentiation of dental pulp stem cells.

25910836.pub_title: AVE protein expression and visceral endoderm cell behavior during anterior-posterior axis formation in Species embryos: Asymmetry in Gene and Gene expression.
25910836.pub_abstract: The initial landmark of anterior-posterior (A-P) axis formation in Species embryos is the distal visceral endoderm, DVE, which expresses a series of anterior genes at embryonic day 5.5 (E5.5). Subsequently, DVE cells move to the future anterior region, generating anterior visceral endoderm (AVE). Questions remain regarding how the DVE is formed and how the direction of the movement is determined. This study compares the detailed expression patterns of Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene and Gene by immunohistology and live imaging at E4.5-E6.5. At E6.5, the AVE is subdivided into four domains: most anterior (Gene, Gene, Gene-low/Gene-high), anterior (Gene, Gene, Gene-high/Gene-low), main (Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene-high) and antero-lateral and posterior (Gene, Gene-low). The study demonstrates how this pattern is established. AVE protein expression in the DVE occurs de novo at E5.25-E5.5. Neither Gene, Gene nor Gene expression is asymmetric. In contrast, Gene expression is tilted on the future posterior side with the Gene expression at its proximal domain; the DVE cells move in the opposite direction of the tilt.

26718006.pub_title: Gene and Gene play a crucial role in neural crest-derived craniofacial development.
26718006.pub_abstract: The role of the Hippo signaling pathway in Disease (CNC) development is poorly understood. We used the Gene and Gene(Cre2SOR) drivers to conditionally ablate both Gene and Gene in the CNC of Species. When using either Cre driver, Gene and Disease in the CNC resulted in enlarged, Disease arch blood vessels and Disease. However, Gene(Cre2SOR) mutants had an Disease phenotype that was not evident in Gene(Cre) mutants. In Chemical-1 CNC cells, the loss of Gene impaired smooth muscle cell differentiation. RNA-sequencing data indicated that Gene and Gene regulate genes encoding Fox transcription factors, specifically Gene. Proliferation was reduced in the branchial arch mesenchyme of Gene and Gene CNC conditional knockout (CKO) embryos. Moreover, Gene and Gene CKO embryos had Disease similar to Dandy-Walker spectrum malformations observed in Species Species and Species embryos with mutations in Gene. In embryos and Chemical-1 cells deficient for Gene and Gene, Gene expression was significantly reduced. Analysis of Gene regulatory regions revealed a conserved recognition element for the Gene and Gene DNA binding co-factor Tead. ChIP-PCR experiments supported the conclusion that Gene is directly regulated by the Gene-Tead complex. Our findings uncover important roles for Gene and Gene in CNC diversification and development.

26965927.pub_title: Establishment of a cone photoreceptor transplantation platform based on a novel cone-GFP reporter Species line.
26965927.pub_abstract: We report successful retinal cone enrichment and transplantation using a novel cone-GFP reporter Species line. Using the putative cone photoreceptor-enriched transcript Gene (Gene) GFP-trapped allele, we monitored developmental reporter expression, facilitated the enrichment of cones, and evaluated transplanted GFP-labeled cones in wildtype and Disease mutant retinas. GFP reporter and endogenous Gene transcripts exhibit overlapping temporal and spatial expression patterns, both initiated in cone precursors of the Disease and persisting to the adult stage in S and S/M opsin(+) cones as well as rod bipolar cells. The trapped allele does not affect cone function or survival in the adult mutant retina. When comparing the integration of GFP(+) embryonic cones and postnatal Gene(-/-) 'cods' into retinas of adult wildtype and blind Species, both cell types integrated and exhibited a degree of morphological maturation that was dependent on Species age. These results demonstrate the amenability of the adult retina to cone transplantation using a novel transgenic resource that can advance therapeutic cone transplantation in models of age-related macular degeneration.

25864637.pub_title: Specification of select Disease and innate behaviors by the embryonic patterning gene Gene.
25864637.pub_abstract: The Disease integrates information required for the production of a variety of innate behaviors such as feeding, mating, Disease, and predator avoidance. Despite an extensive knowledge of Disease, how embryonic genetic programs specify circuits that regulate these behaviors remains unknown. Here, we find that in the Disease the developmentally regulated homeodomain-containing transcription factor Gene is required for the generation of specific subclasses of neurons within the lateral Disease area/zona incerta (LH) and the arcuate (Arc) nucleus. Consistent with this specific developmental role, Gene Disease-specific conditional-knockout Species display attenuated responses to predator odor and feeding stressors but do not display deficits in other innate behaviors such as mating or conspecific Disease. Thus, activity of a single developmentally regulated gene, Gene, is a shared requirement for the specification of Disease nuclei governing a subset of innate behaviors. VIDEO ABSTRACT.

25093893.pub_title: Nicotinic receptor Gene expression during Species adrenal gland development.
25093893.pub_abstract: The nicotinic Chemical receptor alpha 7 (Gene) is a ligand-activated ion channel that contributes to a diversity of cellular processes involved in development, neurotransmission and Disease. In this report the expression of Gene was examined in the Species developing and adult adrenal gland that expresses a green fluorescent protein (GFP) reporter as a bi-cistronic extension of the endogenous Gene transcript (Gene(G)). At embryonic day 12.5 (E12.5) Gene(G) expression was associated with the suprarenal ganglion and precursor cells of the adrenal gland. The Gene(G) cells are catecholaminergic chromaffin cells as reflected by their progressive increase in the co-expression of Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene) that is complete by E18.5. In the adult, Gene(G) expression is limited to a subset of chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla that cluster near the border with the adrenal cortex. These chromaffin cells co-express Gene(G), Gene and Gene, but they lack Gene (Gene) consistent with only Chemical (NE) synthesis. These cell groups appear to be preferentially innervated by pre-ganglionic afferents identified by the neurotrophin receptor Gene. No afferents identified by Chemical-III tubulin, neurofilament proteins or Gene co-expressed Gene(G). Occasional Gene(G) cells in the pre-E14.5 embryos express neuronal markers consistent with intrinsic ganglion cells and in the adult some Gene(G) cells co-express Chemical decarboxylase. The transient expression of Gene during adrenal gland development and its prominent co-expression by a subset of NE chromaffin cells in the adult suggests that the Gene receptor contributes to multiple aspects of adrenal gland development and function that persist into adulthood.

24344131.pub_title: Gene regulates the repression of type II collagen expression during the differentiation from proliferative to Disease chondrocytes.
24344131.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a transcription factor that promotes Disease differentiation by stimulating type X collagen and matrix metalloproteinase 13 during chondrocyte differentiation. However, the effect of Gene on proliferative chondrocytes is unclear. Here, we investigated whether Gene represses type II collagen (Gene) expression and is involved in the regulation of sex-determining region Y-type high mobility group box 9 (Gene), a crucial factor for transactivation of Gene. Endogenous expression of Gene in the embryonic growth plate and differentiated ATDC5 cells were opposite to those of Gene and Gene. Overexpression of Gene by adenovirus vector in ATDC5 cells caused marked repression of Gene. The expression of Gene mRNA and nuclear protein was also repressed, resulting in decreased binding of Gene to the Gene enhancer as shown by a ChIP assay. Knockdown of Gene by lentivirus expressing shRNA caused significant stimulation of these genes in ATDC5 cells. Reporter assays demonstrated that Gene repressed transcriptional activity of Gene. Deletion and mutation analysis showed that the Gene core responsive element was located between +2144 and +2152 bp within the Gene enhancer. EMSA and ChIP assays also revealed that Gene directly bound to this region. Ex vivo organ cultures of Species limbs transfected with Gene showed that the expression of Gene and Gene was reduced upon ectopic Gene expression. Together, these results indicated that Gene represses the transcriptional activity of Gene both directly and indirectly through modulation of Gene expression. This consequently promotes the phenotypic conversion from proliferative to Disease chondrocytes during chondrocyte differentiation.

22516201.pub_title: Atypical E2F repressors and activators coordinate placental development.
22516201.pub_abstract: The evolutionarily ancient arm of the E2f family of transcription factors consisting of the two atypical members Gene and Gene is essential for Species embryonic development. However, the critical tissues, cellular processes, and molecular pathways regulated by these two factors remain unknown. Using a series of fetal and placental lineage-specific cre Species, we show that Gene functions in extraembryonic trophoblast lineages are both necessary and sufficient to carry fetuses to term. Expression profiling and biochemical approaches exposed the canonical Gene activator as a key family member that antagonizes Gene/Gene functions. Remarkably, the concomitant loss of Gene normalized placental gene expression programs, corrected placental defects, and fostered the survival of Gene/Gene-deficient embryos to birth. In summary, we identified a placental transcriptional network tightly coordinated by activation and repression through two distinct arms of the E2F family that is essential for extraembryonic cell proliferation, placental development, and fetal viability.

22902560.pub_title: A role for Gene and the chaperone machinery in piRNA amplification and transposon silencing.
22902560.pub_abstract: Epigenetic silencing of transposons by Piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) constitutes an RNA-based genome defense mechanism. Piwi endonuclease action amplifies the piRNA pool by generating new piRNAs from target transcripts by a poorly understood mechanism. Here, we identified Species Gene as a factor in this biogenesis pathway delivering piRNAs to the Piwi protein Gene. Species lacking Gene derepress LINE1 (L1) retrotransposon and display reduced DNA methylation due to deficient nuclear accumulation of Gene. Like other cochaperones, Gene associates with the molecular chaperone Gene via its tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) domain. Inhibition of the Chemical-dependent Gene activity in an insect cell culture model results in the accumulation of short antisense RNAs in Piwi complexes. We identify these to be byproducts of piRNA amplification that accumulate only in nuage-localized Piwi proteins. We propose that the chaperone machinery normally ejects these inhibitory RNAs, allowing turnover of Piwi complexes for their continued participation in piRNA amplification.

25426952.pub_title: carboxypeptidase E-DeltaN, a neuroprotein transiently expressed during development protects embryonic neurons against Chemical Disease.
25426952.pub_abstract: Neuroprotective proteins expressed in the fetus play a critical role during early Disease, especially during maternal exposure to Chemical and drugs that cause stress, Disease, and damage to the fetal brain, if prolonged. We have identified a novel protein, carboxypeptidase E-DeltaN (CPE-DeltaN), which is a splice variant of CPE that has neuroprotective effects on embryonic neurons. CPE-DeltaN is transiently expressed in Species embryos from embryonic day 5.5 to postnatal day 1. It is expressed in embryonic neurons, but not in 3 week or older Species brains, suggesting a function primarily in utero. CPE-DeltaN expression was up-regulated in embryonic hippocampal neurons in response to Chemical treatment. CPE-DeltaN transduced into Species embryonic cortical and hippocampal neurons protected them from Chemical- and Chemical-induced cell death. When transduced into embryonic cortical neurons, CPE-DeltaN was found in the nucleus and enhanced the transcription of Gene mRNA. Embryonic cortical neurons challenged with Chemical resulted in attenuated Gene levels and cell death, but CPE-DeltaN transduced neurons treated in the same manner showed increased Gene expression and normal viability. This neuroprotective effect of CPE-DeltaN was mediated by secreted Gene. Through receptor signaling, Gene activated the Gene and ERK signaling pathways, which in turn increased Gene expression. This led to inhibition of Gene activity and cell survival.

25641781.pub_title: Deletion of Gene in neural precursor cells leads to altered neurogenesis and neonatal lethality of Species.
25641781.pub_abstract: Gene is a noncanonical Chemical exchange factor for a subset of Galpha subunits. Gene has been reported in different model organisms to participate in the control of mitotic cell division, cell signalling, development and cell migration. Still, the function of Gene in the Species nervous system has not been sufficiently analysed yet. Adult Species express Gene in the brain regions involved in the regulation of memory and emotional behaviour. To elucidate the role of Gene in Species neurogenesis we have inactivated Gene in neural precursor cells using Cre/Gene system. As a result, the conditional knockout Species were born at expected Mendelian ratio, but died or were cannibalized by their mother within 12 h after birth. The cerebral cortex of the newborn Nes;Gene(CKO) Species was thinner compared to littermates and the basement membrane was discontinuous, enabling migrating neurons to invade to the marginal zone. In addition, the balance between the planar and oblique cell divisions was altered, influencing the neuron production. Taken together, Gene has an essential role in the development of Species nervous system by maintaining the integrity of pial basement membrane and modulating cell division.

26681395.pub_title: Cell autonomous roles of Gene in craniofacial bone formation.
26681395.pub_abstract: Gene is an E3 ubiquitin ligase that has an essential role in craniofacial development. However, how and when Gene controls skull formation is ill defined. Here we have used a collection of complementary genetic Species models to dissect the cell-autonomous roles of Gene in the formation of neural crest cell derived cranial bone. Removal of Gene specifically from neural crest cells leads to profound Disease with marked Disease that was preceded by Disease. Removal of Gene after differentiation of neural crest cells into progenitors of chondrocytes and osteoblasts also led to profound Disease in the absence of Disease. Notably, these skull Disease were conserved when Gene was specifically removed from the osteoblast lineage after specification of osteoblast precursors from mesenchymal skeletal progenitors. We further show that absence of Gene in pre-osteoblasts results in decreased cell proliferation and altered osteogenic differentiation. Taken together our data demonstrate a novel cell-autonomous role for Gene in promoting expansion of the osteoblast progenitor pool to control craniofacial development. Gene mutant Species therefore represent a unique Species model of Disease that provide an ideal resource to explore the cell-intrinsic mechanisms of neural crest cells in craniofacial morphogenesis.

22586092.pub_title: Nuclear factor of activated T cells (Gene) is required for Gene-dependent survival of adult-born neurons and spatial memory formation in the hippocampus.
22586092.pub_abstract: New neurons generated in the adult dentate gyrus are constantly integrated into the hippocampal circuitry and activated during encoding and recall of new memories. Despite identification of extracellular signals that regulate survival and integration of adult-born neurons such as neurotrophins and neurotransmitters, the nature of the intracellular modulators required to transduce those signals remains elusive. Here, we provide evidence of the expression and transcriptional activity of Gene (Gene) in hippocampal progenitor cells. We show that Gene calcineurin-dependent activity is required selectively for survival of adult-born neurons in response to Gene signaling. Indeed, Chemical injection and stereotaxic delivery of the Gene scavenger Gene-Fc in the Species dentate gyrus reduce the survival of hippocampal adult-born neurons in wild-type but not in Gene(-/-) Species and do not affect the net rate of neural precursor proliferation and their fate commitment. Furthermore, associated with the reduced survival of adult-born neurons, the absence of Gene leads to selective defects in LTP and in the encoding of hippocampal-dependent spatial memories. Thus, our data demonstrate that Gene is essential in the regulation of adult hippocampal neurogenesis and identify Gene as a central player of Gene-driven prosurvival signaling in hippocampal adult-born neurons.

27564454.pub_title: Identification of a novel progenitor cell marker, Gene in the developing pituitary.
27564454.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Pituitary stem/progenitor cells give rise to all of the endocrine cell types within the pituitary gland and are necessary for both development and gland homeostasis. Recent studies have identified several key factors that characterize the progenitor cell population. However, little is known about the factors that regulate progenitor cell differentiation and maintenance. Therefore, it is crucial to identify novel factors that help elucidate mechanisms of progenitor cell function in the developing pituitary. Our studies are the first to characterize the expression of Gene (Gene), a transcription factor known to regulate progenitor cell plasticity, in the developing pituitary. RESULTS: Our studies show Gene expression is highest in the embryonic and early Disease and is localized in pituitary progenitor cells. We demonstrate Gene expression is changed in Gene cKO and Genedf/df Species, Species models that display progenitor cell number defects. In addition, our studies indicate a potential relationship between Gene signaling and Gene expression in the developing pituitary. CONCLUSIONS: Taken together, our results indicate Gene as a novel progenitor cell maker in the developing pituitary that may contribute to progenitor cell function and maintenance. Developmental Dynamics 245:1097-1106, 2016.   2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.

27307076.pub_title: Gene, a New Maternally Expressed Gene, Regulates Placental Development in the Species.
27307076.pub_abstract: Imprinted genes play an important role in placental and embryonic development. Abnormalities in their regulation can result in placental and Disease, leading to Disease. The imprinting state, expression, and function of Gene (Gene) were explored in knockout Species by imprinting analysis, real-time PCR, and immunohistochemistry. In the present study, Gene was identified as a new, imprinted, and placenta-specific maternally expressed gene in the Species. Compared with wild-type Gene(+/+) Species, there was significant placental and Disease in Gene(-/+) (loss of maternal allele) and Gene(-/-) Species, but not in Gene(+/-) (loss of paternal allele) Species at Embryonic Day (E) 12.5-E18.5. In addition, the masses of Postnatal Day 0 (P0) embryos (Gene(-/-) and Gene(-/+)) were highest among the four types. In Gene(-/+) and Gene(-/-) Species, phenotypic analysis indicated that the number and branching of blood vessels, as well as the labyrinth area, increased significantly in placentae of E12.5-E18.5 Species. Moreover, there were abnormalities in the placental junctional zone and the Chemical zone at E15.5. Quantitative analysis showed that Gene expression decreased significantly in the placentae of Gene(-/+) and Gene(-/-) Species at E15.5, and that the Gene protein expression signals were detected weakly in the decidual and spongioblast layers. Our results demonstrate that Gene is maternally expressed in the placenta, and that its deficiency resulted in Disease in the Species. Gene may have a specific inhibitory role in Species placental development. These results provide new insights for the treatment of diseases relating to placental and embryonic development.

24753163.pub_title: Role of heparan Chemical proteoglycans in optic disc and stalk morphogenesis.
24753163.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Heparan Chemical proteoglycans (Gene) are important for embryonic development by means of the regulation of gradient formation and signaling of multiple growth factors and morphogens. Previous studies have shown that Bmp/Gene/Fgf signaling are required for the regionalization of the optic vesicle (OV) and for the closure of the optic fissure (OF), the disturbance of which underlie Disease such as Disease, coloboma, and Disease. RESULTS: To study Gene-dependent coordination of these signaling pathways during Species visual system development, we have generated a series of OV-specific mutations in the heparan Chemical (HS) N-sulfotransferase genes (Gene and Gene) and HS O-sulfotransferase genes (Hs2st, Gene, and Gene) in Species. Of interest, the resulting HS undersulfation still allowed for normal retinal neurogenesis and optic fissure closure, but led to Disease and stalk development. The adult mutant animals further developed Disease and displayed Disease. We observed that MAPK/ERK signaling was down-regulated in Ndst mutants, and consistent with this, HS-related optic nerve morphogenesis defects in mutant Species could partially be rescued by constitutive Kras activation. CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest that HSPGs, depending on their HS sulfation pattern, regulate multiple signaling pathways in optic disc and stalk morphogenesis.

22119667.pub_title: Gene (Gene) is expressed in Species retinal vessels.
22119667.pub_abstract: The Gene (Gene) Gene (Gene) regulates numerous members of the Rho family that are involved in neuronal morphogenesis of the central and peripheral nervous system. In the present study we investigated the spatial and temporal expression of Gene in the Species eye. The expression of Gene was analysed on both mRNA and protein level. To identify the Gene transcripts, adult retina and cerebrum (positive control) of postnatal day (P) 158 was subjected to reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and sequencing of the amplified cDNA. The Gene protein was analyzed in adult retina by Western blotting and in developing eyes at embryonic day (E) 12, Gene and P158 by immunohistochemistry. Gene transcripts were detected in adult retina by RT-PCR and confirmed by sequencing. Western blot analysis revealed the expression of Gene protein in the adult retina. Immunohistochemical examination of developing eyes localized the protein to retinal vasculature with an onset of Gene expression from Gene onwards. The specific expression pattern suggests that Gene could have a physiological role in the retinal vasculatures. At Gene, the vessel development in the retina is widely completed, implying that Gene has either a function during adulthood or for the generation of the intermediate plexus during the late vessel development of the retina.

22876201.pub_title: Multiple roles and interactions of Gene and Gene in development of the respiratory system.
22876201.pub_abstract: Normal development of the respiratory system is essential for survival and is regulated by multiple genes and signaling pathways. Both Gene and Gene are expressed throughout the mesenchyme of the developing lung and trachea; and, although multiple genes are known to be required in the epithelium, only Fgfs have been well studied in the mesenchyme. In this study, we investigated the roles of Gene and Gene in lung and trachea development using conditional mutant alleles and two different Cre recombinase transgenic lines. Loss of Gene leads to a Disease bud specification and absence of tracheal specification in organ culture. Mutants deficient in Gene and Gene show severely reduced lung branching at mid-gestation. Concordant with this defect, the expression of mesenchymal markers Gene and Gene, as well as Gene target genes Gene and Gene, in the epithelium is downregulated. Lung branching undergoes arrest ex vivo when Gene and Gene are both completely lacking. Lung-specific Gene heterozygous;Gene conditional null Species die soon after birth due to Disease. These pups have small lungs and show severe disruptions in tracheal/bronchial cartilage rings. Gene, a master regulator of cartilage formation, is expressed in the trachea; but mesenchymal cells fail to condense and consequently do not develop cartilage normally at birth. Gene;Gene double heterozygous mutants show Disease and fewer tracheal cartilage rings, suggesting a genetic interaction. Finally, we show that Gene and Gene interact with Gene during the process of lung growth and branching but not during tracheal/bronchial cartilage development.

25406395.pub_title: Gene in Species Sertoli cells is required for proper regulation of the testis stem cell niche.
25406395.pub_abstract: Stem cells are influenced by their surrounding microenvironment, or niche. In the testis, Sertoli cells are the key niche cells directing the population size and differentiation fate of spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs). Failure to properly regulate SSCs leads to Disease or germ cell Disease. Several Sertoli cell-expressed genes, such as Gdnf and Gene, have been identified as being indispensable for the proper maintenance of SSCs in their niche, but the pathways that modulate their expression have not been identified. Although we have recently found that constitutively activating NOTCH signaling in Sertoli cells leads to premature differentiation of all prospermatogonia and sterility, suggesting that there is a crucial role for this pathway in the testis stem cell niche, a true physiological function of NOTCH signaling in Sertoli cells has not been demonstrated. To this end, we conditionally ablated recombination signal binding protein for immunoglobulin kappa J region (Gene), a crucial mediator of NOTCH signaling, in Sertoli cells using Amh-cre. Gene knockout Species had: significantly increased testis sizes; increased expression of niche factors, such as Gdnf and Gene; significant increases in the number of pre- and post-meiotic germ cells, including SSCs; and, in a significant proportion of Species, Disease and Disease with tubule Disease, possibly due to these unsustainable increases in the number of germ cells. We also identified germ cells as the NOTCH ligand-expressing cells. We conclude that NOTCH signaling in Sertoli cells is required for proper regulation of the testis stem cell niche and is a potential feedback mechanism, based on germ cell input, that governs the expression of factors that control SSC proliferation and differentiation.

22354871.pub_title: Gene (X99384) is expressed in the vasculature and shifts from endothelial to vascular smooth muscle cells during Species development.
22354871.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Angiogenesis is implicated in many pathological conditions. The role of the proteins involved remains largely unknown, and few vascular-specific drug targets have been discovered. Previously, in a screen for angiogenesis regulators, we identified Gene (Species: X99384, Species: Gene), a protein containing predicted S/T/Y phosphatase domains. RESULTS: We present a Species knockout allele for Gene with a beta-galactosidase reporter, which in combination with Gene antibodies demonstrate that Gene is expressed in the vasculature. During Species embryogenesis, Gene is primarily expressed in capillary and venous endothelial cells. In adult Species Gene is predominantly expressed in arterial pericytes and vascular smooth muscle cells. Gene also displays vascular-restricted expression in Species brain, Disease, and Disease. CONCLUSIONS: Gene, a novel putative phosphatase, displays a dynamic expression pattern in the vasculature. During embryonic stages it is broadly expressed in endothelial cells, while in the adult it is selectively expressed in arterial smooth muscle cells.

22832491.pub_title: Gene deficiency during skin development impairs cell division and stratification.
22832491.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) promotes timely entry into mitosis, centrosome maturation, and formation of bipolar spindles. To address the role of Gene in skin development and homeostasis, we interbred a floxed Gene (Gene) Species with the Cre-deleter strain, K14.Cre. Gene(Gene/Gene);Krt14.Cre (Gene(-/-)) Species died shortly after birth. These Species had translucent skin, and histological evaluation showed that the dorsal skin was very thin and fragile with frank erosions. Although the expression of the basal layer marker keratin 14 and the differentiation marker keratin 1 was evident in Gene(-/-) epidermis, there was a marked reduction in the number of suprabasal layers and basal keratinocytes. Dye exclusion assays also showed defects in barrier function. Unlike wild-type cells, Gene(-/-) basal progenitors were delayed in forming two layers at embryonic day (E)13.5 when embryonic skin begins to stratify. Increased numbers of mitotic cells, apoptotic bodies, and polyploid keratinocytes were evident in Gene(-/-) epidermis, indicating that a deficiency in Gene promotes aberrant mitosis, mitotic slippage, and cell death. Finally, Gene(-/-) keratinocytes displayed centrosomal abnormalities that included centrosomes located at nonapical sites in basal cells. Thus, the deletion of Gene in the developing epidermis alters centrosome function of basal keratinocytes and markedly impairs their ability to divide and stratify.

24906020.pub_title: Monoallelic and biallelic mutations in Gene cause a spectrum of major Disease.
24906020.pub_abstract: We identified four different missense mutations in the single-exon gene Gene in eight individuals with Disease from five unrelated families via three independent exome sequencing projects. Three mutational events altered the same amino acid (Chemical), and two were identical de novo mutations (c.151C>T [Protein Mutation]) in unrelated Species with Disease, Disease, and Disease. c.152G>A (Protein Mutation) segregated with Disease in a large multiplex family. The fourth heterozygous mutation (c.145G>A [Protein Mutation]) affected an amino acid within two residues of Chemical51 in an adult male with bilateral colobomata. In a fifth family, a homozygous mutation (c.740G>A [Protein Mutation]) altering a different region of the protein was identified in two male siblings with bilateral retinal colobomata. In Species embryos, Gene showed strong expression in the developing eye, pharyngeal arches, and limb bud. As predicted by structural homology, wild-type Gene bound single-stranded RNA, whereas this activity was lost in all altered forms of the protein. Gene had no detectable nucleotidyltransferase activity in vitro, and its function remains unknown. Induced expression of wild-type Gene in Species Disease 293 cells increased phospho-ERK (pERK1/2) signaling. Compared to the wild-type and Protein Mutation proteins, the proteins with the Glu49 and Chemical51 variants had increased stability. Abnormal persistence of pERK1/2 signaling in Gene-expressing cells during development is a plausible pathogenic mechanism for the heterozygous mutations. The phenotype associated with the homozygous mutation might be a consequence of complete loss of Gene RNA binding, although the cellular function of this interaction remains unknown.

25391964.pub_title: Radial glia require Gene-Gene signalling in Species but not Species neocortex.
25391964.pub_abstract: Evolutionary expansion of the Species neocortex underlies many of our unique mental abilities. This expansion has been attributed to the increased proliferative potential of Disease (RG; neural stem cells) and their subventricular dispersion from the periventricular niche during neocortical development. Such adaptations may have evolved through gene expression changes in RG. However, whether or how RG gene expression varies between Species and other species is unknown. Here we show that the transcriptional profiles of Species and Species neocortical RG are broadly conserved during neurogenesis, yet diverge for specific signalling pathways. By analysing differential gene co-expression relationships between the species, we demonstrate that the growth factor Gene is specifically expressed by RG in Species, but not Species, corticogenesis. We also show that the expression domain of Gene, the cognate receptor for Gene, is evolutionarily divergent, with high expression in the germinal region of dorsal Species neocortex but not in the Species. Pharmacological inhibition of Gene-Gene signalling in slice culture prevents normal cell cycle progression of neocortical RG in Species, but not Species. Conversely, injection of recombinant Gene or ectopic expression of constitutively active Gene in developing Species neocortex increases the proportion of RG and their subventricular dispersion. These findings highlight the requirement of Gene-Gene signalling for Species neocortical development and suggest that local production of growth factors by RG supports the expanded germinal region and progenitor heterogeneity of species with large brains.

26363621.pub_title: The histone variant Gene is dynamically expressed in the developing Species placenta and in differentiating trophoblast stem cells.
26363621.pub_abstract: The histone variant Gene is important in establishing new chromatin environments necessary for permitting changes in gene expression and thus differentiation in Species embryonic stem (mES) cells. In this study we show that Gene is highly expressed in the early Species placenta, and is specifically limited to progenitor-like trophoblast cells. Using in vitro models, we revealed distinct differences in Gene abundance between undifferentiated, differentiating and differentiated Species trophoblast stem (mTS) cells. Our work supports the hypothesis that in addition to roles in differentiating mES cells, Gene is also involved in the differentiation of extra-embryonic tissues.

24415953.pub_title: Gene is a crucial regulator of Gene in the limb bud.
24415953.pub_abstract: In the limb bud, patterning along the anterior-posterior (A-P) axis is controlled by Gene (Gene), a signaling molecule secreted by the "Zone of Polarizing Activity", an organizer tissue located in the posterior margin of the limb bud. We have found that the transcription factors Gene and Gene, which are key regulators of cell identity, are expressed in an anterior to posterior gradient in the early limb bud, raising the possibility that Gene transcription factors may play an additional role in patterning this tissue. While both Gene and Gene are expressed in an A-P gradient in the forelimb buds, the hindlimb buds principally express Gene in an A-P gradient. Thus, to specifically examine the role of Gene in limb patterning we generated Gene-Cre; Gene(fl/fl) Species, which conditionally delete Gene from their developing limb buds. We found that these animals display ectopic expression of both Gene and its transcriptional targets specifically in the anterior mesenchyme of the hindlimb buds. Loss of Gene in the developing limbs results in the formation of preaxial polydactyly in the hindlimbs. Conversely, forced expression of Gene throughout the limb bud represses expression of Gene and results in hypomorphic limbs. We have found that Gene can bind to chromatin (isolated from limb buds) encoding either Gene or Gene regulatory elements that drive expression of these genes in this tissue, and demonstrated that Gene works synergistically with Gene co-factors to repress expression of luciferase reporters driven by these sequences. Most significantly, we have found that conditional loss of Gene in limb buds lacking Gene prevents development of hindlimb polydactyly in these compound mutant embryos, indicating that Gene expression in the anterior region of the limb bud blocks hindlimb polydactyly by repressing ectopic expression of Gene.

23457539.pub_title: Gene (Gene) affects bone size and shape and contributes to natural variation in postnatal growth in Species.
23457539.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a protease of Gene and is receiving increasing attention for its roles in pregnancy and postnatal growth. The goals of the present study were to characterize the effects of Gene deletion on bone size and shape in Species at 10 weeks of age, and to determine whether Gene is the gene responsible for a previously-identified quantitative trait locus (QTL) contributing to natural variation in postnatal growth in Species. Species homozygous for constitutive Gene deletion were lighter than wild-type littermates, and had smaller mandible dimensions and shorter skull, humerus, femur, tibia, pelvic girdle, and tail bone. Furthermore, Gene deletion reduced mandible dimensions and the lengths of the skull, femur, pelvic girdle, and tail bone more than would be expected due to the effect on body mass. In addition to its effects on bone size, Disease also altered the shape of the mandible and pelvic girdle, as assessed by geometric morphometrics. Species homozygous for the Gene deletion had less deep mandibles, and pelvic girdles with a more feminine shape. Using a quantitative complementation test, we confirmed that Gene is responsible for the effects of the previously-identified QTL, demonstrating that natural variation in the Gene gene contributes to variation in postnatal growth in Species. If similar functional variation in the Gene gene exists in other species, effects of this variation on the shape of the pelvic girdle might explain the previously-reported associations between Gene SNPs and Disease in Species, and birthing in Species.

23522784.pub_title: Mutations in Gene confirm the genetic heterogeneity of Disease.
23522784.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) is a rare, autosomal-dominant or -recessive disorder characterized primarily by Disease. Recently, we demonstrated that homozygous mutations in Gene cause an autosomal-recessive form of Disease. In this study, we sought to determine the contribution of Gene mutations to the etiology of Disease in several consanguineous families. In two of the five families studied, we identified two homozygous truncating mutations (a splice-site mutation and a frameshift duplication). Gene sequencing revealed no mutation in the remaining three families, consistent with their autozygosity mapping and linkage-analysis results, which revealed a single candidate locus in 3p14.1 on three different haplotype backgrounds in the three families. Indeed, exome sequencing in one family revealed one missense mutation in Gene (Gene), and subsequent targeted sequencing of this gene revealed a homozygous missense mutation and a homozygous frameshift deletion mutation in the other two families. Gene encodes EGF-domain-specific O-linked Chemical (Gene) transferase, which is involved in the O-GlcNAcylation (attachment of Gene to Chemical and Chemical residues) of a subset of extracellular EGF-domain-containing proteins. It has a documented role in epithelial-cell-matrix interactions in Drosophila, in which deficiency of its ortholog causes wing blistering. Our findings highlight a developmental role of O-GlcNAcylation in Species and expand the genetic heterogeneity of Disease.

24309208.pub_title: Wnt/Gene signaling in dermal condensates is required for hair follicle formation.
24309208.pub_abstract: Broad dermal Wnt signaling is required for patterned induction of hair follicle placodes and subsequent Wnt signaling in placode stem cells is essential for induction of dermal condensates, cell clusters of precursors for the hair follicle dermal papilla (DP). Progression of hair follicle formation then requires coordinated signal exchange between dermal condensates and placode stem cells. However, it remains unknown whether continued Wnt signaling in DP precursor cells plays a role in this process, largely due to the long-standing inability to specifically target dermal condensates for gene ablation. Here we use the Gene(Cre) knockin Species line to ablate the Wnt-responsive transcription factor Gene specifically in these cells at E14.5 during the first wave of guard hair follicle formation. In the absence of Gene, canonical Wnt signaling is effectively abolished in these cells. Gene(+) dermal condensates initiate normally; however by E16.5 guard hair follicle numbers are strongly reduced and by E18.5 most whiskers and guard hair follicles are absent, suggesting that active Wnt signaling in dermal condensates is important for hair follicle formation to proceed after induction. To explore the molecular mechanisms by which Wnt signaling in dermal condensates regulates hair follicle formation, we analyze genome-wide the gene expression changes in embryonic Gene null DP precursor cells. We find altered expression of several signaling pathway genes, including Fgfs and Activin, both previously implicated in hair follicle formation. In summary, these data reveal a functional role of Wnt signaling in DP precursors for embryonic hair follicle formation and identify Fgf and Activin signaling as potential effectors of Wnt signaling-regulated events.

27015307.pub_title: Heterogeneity in Gene and Gene Targets Biases Cell Fate in 4-Cell Species Embryos.
27015307.pub_abstract: The major and essential objective of pre-implantation development is to establish embryonic and extra-embryonic cell fates. To address when and how this fundamental process is initiated in mammals, we characterize transcriptomes of all individual cells throughout Species pre-implantation development. This identifies targets of master pluripotency regulators Gene and Gene as being highly heterogeneously expressed between blastomeres of the 4-cell embryo, with Gene showing one of the most heterogeneous expression profiles. Live-cell tracking demonstrates that cells with decreased Gene yield more extra-embryonic than pluripotent progeny. Consistently, decreasing Gene results in premature upregulation of the differentiation regulator Gene, suggesting that Gene helps safeguard pluripotency. Furthermore, Gene is elevated following increased expression of the histone H3R26-methylase Gene and is lowered following Gene inhibition, indicating the importance of epigenetic regulation. Therefore, our results indicate that heterogeneous gene expression, as early as the 4-cell stage, initiates cell-fate decisions by modulating the balance of pluripotency and differentiation.

25715397.pub_title: Wnt ligands from the embryonic surface ectoderm regulate 'bimetallic strip' optic cup morphogenesis in Species.
25715397.pub_abstract: The Wnt/Gene response pathway is central to many developmental processes. Here, we assessed the role of Wnt signaling in early eye development using the Species as a model system. We showed that the surface ectoderm region that includes the lens placode expressed 12 out of 19 possible Wnt ligands. When these activities were suppressed by conditional deletion of wntless (Le-cre; Wls(fl/fl)) there were dramatic consequences that included a saucer-shaped optic cup, ventral coloboma, and a Disease mesenchyme. This phenotype shared features with that produced when the Wnt/Gene pathway co-receptor Gene is mutated or when Chemical (Disease) signaling in the eye is compromised. Consistent with this, microarray and cell fate marker analysis identified a series of expression changes in genes known to be regulated by Disease or by the Wnt/Gene pathway. Using pathway reporters, we showed that Wnt ligands from the surface ectoderm directly or indirectly elicit a Wnt/Gene response in retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) progenitors near the optic cup rim. In Le-cre; Wls(fl/fl) Species, the numbers of RPE cells are reduced and this can explain, using the principle of the bimetallic strip, the curvature of the optic cup. These data thus establish a novel hypothesis to explain how differential cell numbers in a bilayered epithelium can lead to shape change.

23829703.pub_title: Chemical regulates olfactory progenitor cell fate and differentiation.
23829703.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: In order to fulfill their chemosensory function, olfactory neurons are in direct contact with the external environment and are therefore exposed to environmental aggressive factors. Olfaction is maintained through life because, unlike for other Disease, olfactory neurons have a unique capacity to regenerate after Disease. The mechanisms that control the ontogenesis and regenerative ability of these neurons are not fully understood. Here, we used various experimental approaches in two model systems (Species and Species) to assess the contribution of Chemical signaling in the induction of the olfactory epithelium, the generation and maintenance of progenitor populations, and the ontogenesis and differentiation of olfactory neurons. RESULTS: We show that Chemical signaling, although dispensable for initial induction of the olfactory placode, plays a key role in neurogenesis within this neuroepithelium. Chemical depletion in the olfactory epithelium, both in Species and Species models, results in a failure of progenitor cell maintenance and, consequently, differentiation of olfactory neurons is not sustained. Using an explant system, we further show that renewal of olfactory neurons is hindered if the olfactory epithelium is unable to synthesize Chemical. CONCLUSIONS: Our data show that Chemical is not a simple placodal inductive signal, but rather controls olfactory neuronal production by regulating the fate of olfactory progenitor cells. Gene (Gene) is the key enzyme required to generate Chemical within the olfactory epithelium.

26235979.pub_title: Age-regulated function of autophagy in the Species inner ear.
26235979.pub_abstract: Autophagy is a highly conserved catabolic process essential for embryonic development and adult homeostasis. The autophagic machinery supplies energy by recycling intracellular components and facilitates the removal of apoptotic cells. In the inner ear, autophagy has been reported to play roles during early development in the Species embryo and in the response to Disease in the adult Species. However, there are no studies on the expression of the autophagy machinery in the postnatal and adult inner ear. Gene (Gene) is one of the factors that regulate both otic development and cochlear postnatal maturation and function. Here, we hypothesised that autophagy could be one of the processes involved in the cochlear development and functional maturation. We report that autophagy-related genes (ATG) Gene, Atg4g and Gene are expressed in the Species cochlea, vestibular system and brainstem cochlear nuclei from late developmental stages to adulthood. Gene was studied in the Species cochlea and showed a similar pattern. The presence of autophagic flux was confirmed by decreased Gene (Gene/Gene) and increased relative levels of microtubule-associated protein light chain 3-II (LC3-II). Inner ear autophagy flux is developmentally regulated and is lower at perinatal stages than in the adult Species, where an expression plateau is reached at the age of two-months, coinciding with the age at which full functional activity is reached. Expression is maintained in adult Species and Disease after the age of twelve months. Gene labelling showed that autophagy was primarily associated with spiral ganglion neurons. Over time, Gene wild type Species showed lower expression of genes coding for Gene high affinity receptor and the family factor Gene than null Species. Parallel analysis of autophagy machinery gene expression showed no significant differences between the genotypes over the lifespan of the null Species. Taken together, these results show that the autophagy machinery expression in the inner ear is regulated with age but is not compromised by the chronic absence of Gene. Our data also strongly support that the up-regulation of autophagy machinery genes is concomitant with the functional maturation of the inner ear.

23224557.pub_title: Sexually dimorphic Gene signaling directs sensory innervation of the mammary gland.
23224557.pub_abstract: How neural circuits associated with sexually dimorphic organs are differentially assembled during development is unclear. Here, we report a sexually dimorphic pattern of Species mammary gland sensory innervation and the mechanism of its formation. Gene (Gene), emanating from mammary mesenchyme and signaling through its receptor Gene on sensory axons, is required for establishing mammary gland sensory innervation of both sexes at early developmental stages. Subsequently, in males, Chemical promote mammary mesenchymal expression of a truncated form of Gene, which prevents Gene-Gene signaling in sensory axons and leads to a rapid loss of mammary gland innervation independent of neuronal apoptosis. Thus, sex hormone regulation of a neurotrophic factor signal directs sexually dimorphic axonal growth and maintenance, resulting in generation of a sex-specific neural circuit.

20619502.pub_title: MicroRNA-16 targets amyloid precursor protein to potentially modulate Disease's-associated pathogenesis in SAMP8 Species.
20619502.pub_abstract: Disease (Disease) is a progressive Disease mainly characterized by amyloid-beta (Abeta) deposition and neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs). The abnormal enrichment of amyloid protein precursor (APP) leads to a high risk of Disease. One of the plausible age-associated Disease animal models, senescence-accelerated Species prone 8 (SAMP8), have age-related Disease. We found APP protein significantly increased in the hippocampus of aged SAMP8 Species. The 20 to 25 nucleotide (nt) tiny regulators, known as micro ribonucleic acids (miRNAs), have been found to play crucial roles in Disease. Here, we examined the post-transcriptional regulation mechanism of APP mediated by micro ribonucleic acids and found that Gene was one of the post-transcriptional regulators of APP in SAMP8 Species. Overexpression of Gene, both in vitro and in vivo, led to reduced APP protein expression. Furthermore, Gene and APP displayed complementary expression patterns in SAMP8 Species and BALb/c Species embryos. Taken together, these findings demonstrate that APP is a target of Gene and the abnormally low expression of Gene could potentially lead to APP protein accumulation in Disease Species.

27923395.pub_title: Regulation of downstream neuronal genes by proneural transcription factors during initial neurogenesis in the vertebrate brain.
27923395.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: Neurons arise in very specific regions of the neural tube, controlled by components of the Notch signalling pathway, proneural genes, and other bHLH transcription factors. How these specific neuronal areas in the brain are generated during development is just beginning to be elucidated. Notably, the critical role of proneural genes during differentiation of the neuronal populations that give rise to the early axon scaffold in the developing brain is not understood. The regulation of their downstream effectors remains poorly defined. RESULTS: This study provides the first overview of the spatiotemporal expression of proneural genes in the neuronal populations of the early axon scaffold in both Species and Species. Overexpression studies and mutant Species have identified a number of specific neuronal genes that are targets of proneural transcription factors in these neuronal populations. CONCLUSION: Together, these results improve our understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in differentiation of the first neuronal populations in the brain.

23086929.pub_title: Identification of amino acid residues required for the substrate specificity of Species and Species Gene (conventional Gene).
23086929.pub_abstract: Species Gene (Gene), a member of the hyaluronidase family, has no hyaluronidase activity, but is a Chemical (CS)-specific endo-beta-N-acetylgalactosaminidase. The expression of Gene is not ubiquitous but restricted to placenta, skeletal muscle, and Disease, suggesting that Gene is not involved in the systemic catabolism of CS, but rather has specific functions in particular organs or tissues. To elucidate the function of Gene in vivo, Species Gene (Gene) was characterized. Gene was also demonstrated to be a CS-specific endo-beta-N-acetylgalactosaminidase. However, Gene and Gene differed in the Chemical groups they recognized. Although Gene strongly preferred Chemical-containing sequences typical in Gene, where GlcUA represents Chemical, Gene depolymerized various CS isoforms to a similar extent, suggesting broad substrate specificity. To identify the amino acid residues responsible for this difference, a series of Species/Species Gene chimeric proteins and Gene point mutants were generated, and their preference for substrates was investigated. A combination of the amino acid residues at 261-265 and Chemical at 305 was demonstrated to be essential for the enzymatic activity as well as substrate specificity of Gene.

23482493.pub_title: Gene: a protein essential for neuromuscular junction stability during Species late embryonic development.
23482493.pub_abstract: Gene is a new member of the cytoplasmic linker proteins (CLIP) family mainly localized to the trans-Golgi network. We show here that Gene expression in Species is restricted to specific pools of neurons, in particular motoneurons (MNs), and progressively increases from embryonic day 12.5 (E12.5) until the first postnatal days. We generated a Gene knockout Species model that presents perinatal lethality due to Disease. Physiological experiments revealed that this altered innervation prevents the normal nerve-elicited contraction of the mutant diaphragm that is reduced both in amplitude and fatigue-resistance at E18.5, despite unaffected functional muscular contractility. Innervation of the mutant diaphragm is not altered until E15.5, but is then partially lost in the most distal parts of the muscle. Ultrastructural observations of neuromuscular junctions (NMJs) in the distal region of the diaphragm reveal a normal organization, but a lower density of nerve terminals capped by terminal Schwann cells in E18.5 mutant when compared with control embryos. Similar defects in NMJ stability, with a hierarchy of severity along the caudo-rostral axis, are also observed in other muscles innervated by facial and spinal MNs in Gene mutant Species. Gene deficiency therefore affects axon maintenance but not axon guidance toward muscle targets. Thus, Gene is involved in the stabilization of specific motor axons at the NMJ during Species late embryogenesis and its role is crucial for Species perinatal development.

26658478.pub_title: Critical roles for Species Gene in the regulation of vascular patterning and stabilization.
26658478.pub_abstract: Extracellular matrix (ECM) is known to play several important roles in vascular development, although the molecular mechanisms behind these remain largely unknown. Gene, a Disease suppressor downregulated in a wide variety of Disease, encodes a membrane-anchored matrix-metalloproteinase-regulator. Species lacking functional Gene die in utero, demonstrating its importance for Species embryogenesis; however, the underlying causes of mid-gestation lethality remain unclear. Using Gene conditional knockout Species, we have now demonstrated that the lack of Gene in vascular mural cells is largely responsible for mid-gestation lethality. Experiments using cultured aortic explants further revealed that Gene is essential for at least two events in sprouting angiogenesis; (1) correct association of mural and endothelial tip cells to the microvessels and (2) maintenance of Gene matrix surrounding the vessels. These findings demonstrate the importance of appropriate cell-cell interactions and ECM maintenance for angiogenesis and the involvement of Gene as a critical regulator of these events.

23315162.pub_title: Gene acts cell autonomously in endothelium to promote tip cell function during sprouting angiogenesis.
23315162.pub_abstract: Gene is a receptor for the Gene (Gene)-A and is essential for normal angiogenesis. Previous in vitro experiments identified Gene interactions with Gene's main signaling receptor Gene within endothelial cells, but also between nonendothelial Gene and endothelial Gene. Consistent with an endothelial role for Gene in angiogenesis, we found that Gene and Gene were coexpressed in endothelial tip and stalk cells in the developing brain. In addition, Gene was expressed on two cell types that interact with growing brain vessels-the neural progenitors that secrete Gene to stimulate tip cell activity and the pro-angiogenic macrophages that promote Disease. Selective targeting of Gene in each of these cell types demonstrated that neural progenitor- and macrophage-derived Gene were dispensable, whereas endothelial Gene was essential for normal brain vessel growth. Gene therefore promotes brain angiogenesis cell autonomously in endothelium, independently of heterotypic interactions with nonendothelial cells. Genetic mosaic analyses demonstrated a key role for Gene in endothelial tip rather than stalk cells during vessel sprouting. Thus, Gene-expressing endothelial cells attained the tip cell position when competing with Gene-negative endothelial cells in chimeric vessel sprouts. Taken together, these findings demonstrate that Gene promotes endothelial tip cell function during angiogenesis.

22539416.pub_title: Guidepost neurons for the lateral olfactory tract: expression of Gene and innervation by glutamatergic olfactory bulb axons.
22539416.pub_abstract: The guidepost neurons for the lateral olfactory tract, which are called lot cells, are the earliest-generated neurons in the neocortex. They migrate tangentially and ventrally further down this tract, and provide scaffolding for the olfactory bulb axons projecting into this pathway. The molecular profiles of the lot cells are largely uncharacterized. We found that lot cells specifically express metabotropic Chemical receptor subtype-1 at a very early stage of development. This receptor is functionally competent and responds to a metabotropic Chemical receptor agonist with a transient increase in the intracellular Chemical ion concentration. When the glutamatergic olfactory bulb axons were electrically stimulated, lot cells responded to the stimulation with a Chemical increase mainly via ionotropic Chemical receptors, suggesting potential neurotransmission between the axons and lot cells during early development. Together with the finding that lot cells themselves are glutamatergic excitatory neurons, our results provide another notable example of precocious interactions between the projecting axons and their intermediate targets.

24531968.pub_title: Evolutionarily dynamic alternative splicing of Gene regulates regional cerebral cortical patterning.
24531968.pub_abstract: The Species neocortex has numerous specialized functional areas whose formation is poorly understood. Here, we describe a 15-base pair deletion mutation in a regulatory element of Gene that selectively disrupts Species cortex surrounding the Sylvian fissure bilaterally including "Broca's area," the primary language area, by disrupting regional Gene expression and blocking Gene transcription factor binding. Gene encodes a heterotrimeric Chemical-binding protein (G protein)-coupled receptor required for normal cortical development and is expressed in cortical progenitor cells. Gene expression levels regulate progenitor proliferation. Gene splice forms are highly variable between Species and Species, and the regulatory element of Disease mammals directs restricted lateral cortical expression. Our data reveal a mechanism by which control of Gene expression pattern by multiple alternative promoters can influence stem cell proliferation, gyral patterning, and, potentially, neocortex evolution.

24051375.pub_title: A Disease Species model reveals Gene-dependent ER shaping.
24051375.pub_abstract: Axonopathies are a group of clinically diverse disorders characterized by the progressive degeneration of the axons of specific neurons. In Disease (HSP), the axons of cortical motor neurons degenerate and cause a Disease. HSP is linked to mutations in several loci known collectively as the Disease genes (SPGs). We identified a heterozygous Gene (Gene) exon 2 deletion in a Species suffering from the autosomal dominantly inherited HSP variant Gene. We generated the corresponding Species model to study the underlying cellular pathology. Species with heterozygous deletion of exon 2 in Gene displayed a Disease closely resembling Gene in Species. Homozygous exon 2 deletion resulted in the complete loss of Gene and a more severe phenotype with earlier onset. At the molecular level, we demonstrated that Gene is a neuron-specific, membrane-binding, and membrane curvature-inducing protein that resides in the ER. We further show that Gene expression was prominent in cortical motor neurons. In Gene-deficient Species, these neurons showed reduced complexity of the peripheral ER upon ultrastructural analysis. Our study connects proper neuronal ER architecture to long-term axon survival.

22110129.pub_title: Gene (Gene, AT rich interactive domain 2) regulates Gene expression via histone modification in the developing heart.
22110129.pub_abstract: Gene/Gene, the founding member of the Gene factor family, critically regulates various developmental processes, including cardiovascular development. The Gene family was identified as histone demethylases, indicating epigenetic regulation by Gene proteins. Deletion of Gene in Species resulted in Disease and increased endocardial Gene expression during development. Although Gene has been shown to occupy the Gene locus in the developing heart, the precise molecular role of Gene remains unknown. Here we show that deletion of Gene results in reduced methylation of Chemical 9 on histone H3 (H3K9) at the Gene genomic locus in embryonic hearts. Interestingly, Gene, a histone H3K9 methyltransferase, was identified as a putative cofactor of Gene by yeast two-hybrid screening, and the physical interaction between Gene and Gene was confirmed by coimmunoprecipitation experiments. Concurrently, accumulation of Gene at the site of Gene occupancy was significantly reduced in Gene knock out (KO) hearts. Employing genome-wide approaches, putative Gene target genes regulated by Gene via H3K9 methylation were identified in the developing heart by ChIP-chip. These targets are involved in biological processes that, when dysregulated, could manifest in the phenotypic defects observed in Gene KO Species. Our data demonstrate that Gene functions as a transcriptional repressor of target genes, including Gene, through a novel process involving the modification of H3K9 methylation via specific interaction with Gene during heart development. Therefore, our study provides new mechanistic insights into epigenetic regulation by Gene, which will enhance our understanding of the molecular basis of other organ development and biological processes.

25244320.pub_title: Gene functions as a Gene co-receptor to guide developmental angiogenesis independent of ligand binding.
