25244320.pub_abstract: During development, tissue repair, and Disease growth, most blood vessel networks are generated through angiogenesis. Gene (Gene) is a key regulator of this process and currently both Gene and its receptors, Gene, Gene, and Gene (Gene), are targeted in therapeutic strategies for Disease and Disease. Gene is essential for vascular morphogenesis, but how Gene functions to guide vascular development has not been completely elucidated. In this study, we generated a Species line harboring a point mutation in the endogenous Gene locus that selectively abolishes Gene binding (Gene(Gene-)). Gene(Gene-) mutants survive to adulthood with normal vasculature revealing that Gene functions independent of Gene binding during developmental angiogenesis. Moreover, we found that Gene-deficient vessels have reduced Gene surface expression in vivo demonstrating that Gene regulates its co-receptor, Gene. Given the resources invested in Gene-targeted anti-angiogenesis therapies, our results will be integral for developing strategies to re-build vasculature in disease.

24574009.pub_title: Hox proteins drive cell segregation and non-autonomous apical Disease during hindbrain segmentation.
24574009.pub_abstract: Hox genes encode a conserved family of homeodomain transcription factors regulating development along the major body axis. During embryogenesis, Hox proteins are expressed in segment-specific patterns and control numerous different segment-specific cell fates. It has been unclear, however, whether Hox proteins drive the epithelial cell segregation mechanism that is thought to initiate the segmentation process. Here, we investigate the role of vertebrate Hox proteins during the partitioning of the developing hindbrain into lineage-restricted units called rhombomeres. Loss-of-function mutants and ectopic expression assays reveal that Gene and its paralogue Gene are necessary and sufficient for cell segregation, and for the most caudal rhombomere boundary (r6/r7). Gene proteins regulate Eph/ephrins and other cell-surface proteins, and can function in a non-cell-autonomous manner to induce apical cell enlargement on both sides of their expression border. Similarly, other Hox proteins expressed at more rostral rhombomere interfaces can also regulate Eph/ephrins, induce apical Disease and drive cell segregation in ectopic expression assays. However, Gene, a key segmentation factor expressed in odd rhombomeres (r3 and r5), can largely override Hox proteins at the level of regulation of a cell surface target, Gene. This study suggests that most, if not all, Hox proteins share a common potential to induce cell segregation but in some contexts this is masked or modulated by other transcription factors.

22945632.pub_title: Gene regulates the Disease at multiple levels.
22945632.pub_abstract: Sex-determining region Y (Gene (Gene) Disease causes a form of Disease in Species that is characterized by gonadotrophin deficiency known as Disease. Here, we conditionally deleted Gene in Species to investigate the pathogenesis of Disease. First, we found that absence of Gene in the developing Rathke pouch of conditional embryos led to severe Disease with drastically reduced expression of the pituitary-specific transcription factor Gene (Gene) as well as severe disruption of somatotroph and thyrotroph differentiation. In contrast, corticotrophs, rostral-tip Gene-independent thyrotrophs, and, interestingly, lactotrophs and gonadotrophs were less affected. Second, we identified a requirement for Gene in normal proliferation of periluminal progenitors; in its absence, insufficient precursors were available to produce all cell lineages of the anterior pituitary. Differentiated cells derived from precursors exiting cell cycle at early stages, including corticotrophs, rostral-tip thyrotrophs, and gonadotrophs, were generated, while hormone-producing cells originating from late-born precursors, such as somatotrophs and Gene-dependent thyrotrophs, were severely reduced. Finally, we found that 2 previously characterized Species with Gene Disease and associated Disease had a measurable response to Gene (Chemical) stimulation, suggesting that it is not the absence of gonadotroph differentiation, but rather the Disease stimulation of gonadotrophs, that underlies typical Disease.

21732189.pub_title: Endogenous tagging of the Species transcription factor Gene with hemaglutinin for functional studies.
21732189.pub_abstract: Gene expression is usually studied at the transcript level rather than at the protein level due to the lack of a specific and sensitive antibody. A way to overcome this is to fuse to the protein of interest an immunoreactive tag that has well-characterized antibodies. This epitope tagging approach is often used for in vitro experiments but for in vivo studies, the success rate of protein tagging has not been extensively analyzed and our study seeks to cover the void. A small epitope, hemaglutinin derived from the Species was used to tag a transcription factor, Gene at the Chemical-terminal via homologous recombination in the Species. Gene is part of the Sry-related high-mobility-group box gene family and plays multiple roles in essential biological processes. Understanding of its molecular function in relation to its biological roles remains incomplete. In our study, we show that the longer isoform of Gene can be tagged endogenously with hemaglutinin without affecting its biological function in vivo. The tagged protein is easily and specifically detected with an anti-hemaglutinin antibody using immunohistochemistry with its expression matching the endogenous expression of Gene. Immunoprecipitation of Gene was also carried out successfully using an anti-hemaglutinin antibody. The transgenic line generated from this study is predicted to be useful for future experiments such as co-immunoprecipitation and chromatin immunoprecipitation, allowing the further understanding of Gene. Lastly, this approach can be easily employed for the investigation of other transcription factors and proteins in vivo to overcome technical limitations such as antibody cross-reactivity and to perform isoform-specific studies.

25978062.pub_title: Gene Regulates the Balance between Self-Renewal and Differentiation of Radial Glial Cells and Intermediate Neuronal Precursors in Cooperation with FGF Signaling.
25978062.pub_abstract: In Species cerebral corticogenesis, neurons are generated from radial glial cells (RGCs) or from their immediate progeny, intermediate neuronal precursors (INPs). The balance between self-renewal of these neuronal precursors and specification of cell fate is critical for proper cortical development, but the signaling mechanisms that regulate this progression are poorly understood. Gene, a member of the receptor Chemical kinase superfamily, is expressed in RGCs during embryogenesis. To illuminate the function of Gene in RGC cell fate determination during early corticogenesis, we deleted Gene in cortical cells at E11.5 or E13.5. Loss of Gene at both stages led to precocious in vivo RGC differentiation toward neurogenesis. Cortical cells isolated at E14.5 and E15.5 from both deletion mutants showed reduced capacity for neurosphere formation with greater differentiation toward neurons. They also exhibited lower phosphorylation of Gene and Gene in the presence of FGF. The size of the cerebral cortex at P0 was smaller than that of controls when Gene was deleted at E11.5 but not when it was deleted at E13.5, although the cortical layers were formed normally in both mutants. The number of Gene-positive RGCs decreased at later developmental stages only in the E11.5 Gene deletion mutant. These results suggest that Gene, in cooperation with an FGF signal, contributes to the maintenance of RGC self-renewal and repression of RGC differentiation through the neuronal lineage. This function of Gene is especially critical and uncompensated in early stages of corticogenesis, and thus deletion at E11.5 reduces the size of the neonatal cortex.

25993027.pub_title: Role of Gene in the Transforming Ascending Thin Limb of Henle's Loop during Species Kidney Development.
25993027.pub_abstract: The homeobox transcription factor Gene is critical to the development of many embryonic organs and tissues, although current understanding of its expression in the developing renal medulla is limited. We examined the functional role of Gene during Species kidney development with particular emphasis on the developing loop of Henle. Our data show that Gene is expressed in the transdifferentiating region from the Gene-positive thick ascending limb, into the Gene-positive ascending thin limb of Henle's loop beginning at embryonic day 18. From 1 to 14 days of age, Gene-positive cells gradually disappeared from the papillary tip, and remained in the initial part of inner medulla after 21 days. In this transforming area, no Gene was observed in cells undergoing apoptosis but was expressed strongly in the remaining cells, which differentiated into ascending thin limb epithelial cells. In vitro and in vivo approaches showed that Gene expression increases where the osmolality is near optimal range, but decreases at below- or above-optimal ranges. Disease induced by Chemical (Gene inhibitor) inhibited Gene expression and delayed maturation of the ascending limb of Henle's loop. Together, these studies suggest that Gene appears to be a critical stage specific regulator of specifying ascending thin limb cell fate and that its expression is regulated by osmolality.

24209762.pub_title: Transient activation of autophagy via Gene-mediated suppression of Gene is an important early step in reprogramming to pluripotency.
24209762.pub_abstract: Autophagy is an essential cellular mechanism that degrades cytoplasmic proteins and organelles to recycle their components. Here we show that autophagy is required for reprogramming of somatic cells to form induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). Our data indicate that Gene (Gene) is downregulated by Gene at an early stage of iPSC generation and that this transient downregulation of Gene is required for reprogramming to take place. In the absence of Gene, Gene remains at a high level and inhibits autophagy. Mechanistically, Gene binds to a repressive region on the Gene promoter and recruits the NuRD complex to mediate transcriptional repression. We also detected enhanced autophagy at the four- to eight-cell stage of embryonic development, and a similar Gene and Gene-mediated regulatory pathway seems to operate in this context as well. Thus, our findings reveal Gene-dependent temporal regulation of autophagy as a key step in cellular reprogramming processes.

25856312.pub_title: O-fucosylation of Gene is required for its function during somitogenesis.
25856312.pub_abstract: Delta-like 3 (Gene) is a member of the DSL family of Gene ligands in Species. In contrast to Gene and Gene, the other Delta-like proteins in the Species, Gene does not bind in trans to Gene and does not activate the receptor, but shows cis-interaction and cis-inhibitory properties on Gene signaling in vitro. Loss of the DSL protein Gene in the Species results in severe somite patterning defects, which are virtually indistinguishable from the defects in Species that lack Gene (Gene), a Gene involved in modifying Gene signaling. Like Gene, Gene is located within the trans-Golgi, however, its biochemical function is still unclear. Here, we show that i) both proteins interact, ii) epidermal growth factor like repeats 2 and 5 of Gene are Chemical at consensus sites for Gene, and iii) further modified by FNG proteins in vitro. Embryos double homozygous for null mutations in Gene and Gene are phenotypically indistinguishable from the single mutants supporting a potential common function. Mutation of the O-fucosylation sites in Gene does not disrupt the interaction of Gene with Gene or full length Geneor Gene, and O-fucosylation-deficient Gene can still inhibit Gene in cis in vitro. However, in contrast to wild type Gene, O-fucosylation-deficient Gene cannot compensate for the loss of endogenous Gene during somitogenesis in the embryo. Together our results suggest that the cis-inhibitory activity of Gene observed in cultured cells might not fully reflect its assumed essential physiological property, suggest that Gene and Gene act together, and strongly supports that modification of Gene by O-linked Chemical is essential for its function during somitogenesis.

23982205.pub_title: Disease activates an Gene-Gene-Gene pathway that leads to Disease.
23982205.pub_abstract: Disease result from failure to completely close neural tubes during development. Disease is a substantial risk factor for Disease, and available evidence suggests that the mechanism that links Disease involves oxidative stress and apoptosis. We demonstrated that maternal Disease correlated with activation of the Gene (Gene) in the developing neural tube, and Gene gene deletion was associated with reduced Disease and development of Disease. Gene activation stimulated the activity of the transcription factor Gene, which increased the abundance of the apoptosis-promoting adaptor protein Gene, leading to activation of Gene. Disease-induced apoptosis and the development of Disease were reduced with genetic ablation of either Gene or Gene or inhibition of Gene by Gene. Examination of Species neural tissues affected by Disease revealed increased activation or abundance of Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene. Thus, activation of an Gene-Gene-Gene-Gene pathway participates in the development of Disease, which could be prevented by inhibiting intermediates in this cascade.

22248926.pub_title: Disruption of the developmentally-regulated Gene pre-mRNA alternative splicing switch in a transgenic knock-in Species model.
22248926.pub_abstract: The present study describes the generation of a knock-in Species model to address the role of type II procollagen (Gene) alternative splicing in skeletal development and maintenance. Alternative splicing of Gene precursor mRNA is a developmentally-regulated event that only occurs in chondrogenic tissue. Normally, chondroprogenitor cells synthesize predominantly exon 2-containing mRNA isoforms (Gene) while Gene mRNA devoid of exon 2 (type Gene) is the major isoform produced by differentiated chondrocytes. Another isoform, Chemical, has also been identified that contains a truncated exon 2 and is not translated into protein. The biological significance of this Gene/Gene to Gene splicing switch is not known. Utilizing a splice site targeting knock-in approach, a 4 nucleotide mutation was created to convert the 5' splice site of Gene exon 2 from a weak, non-consensus sequence to a strong, consensus splice site. This resulted in apparent expression of only the Gene mRNA isoform, as confirmed in vitro by splicing of a type II procollagen mini-gene containing the 5' splice site mutation. To test the splice site targeting approach in vivo, homozygote Species engineered to retain Gene exon 2 (Gene(+ex2)) were generated. Chondrocytes from hindlimb epiphyseal cartilage of homozygote Species were shown to express only Gene mRNA and protein at all pre- and post-natal developmental stages analyzed (E12.5, E16.5, P0, P3, P7, Gene, Gene and Gene). As expected, type Gene procollagen was the major isoform produced in wild type cartilage at all post-natal time points. Gene(+ex2) homozygote Species are viable, appear healthy and display no overt phenotype to date. However, research is currently underway to investigate the biological consequence of persistent expression of the exon 2-encoded conserved Chemical-rich domain in post-natal skeletal tissues.

23590306.pub_title: Orphan G protein-coupled receptor Gene regulates pulmonary surfactant pool size.
23590306.pub_abstract: Pulmonary surfactant levels within the alveoli are tightly regulated to maintain lung volumes and promote efficient gas exchange across the air/blood barrier. Quantitative and Disease in surfactant are associated with severe Disease in Species and adults. Although the cellular and molecular mechanisms that control surfactant metabolism have been studied intensively, the critical molecular pathways that sense and regulate endogenous surfactant levels within the alveolus have not been identified and constitute a fundamental knowledge gap in the field. In this study, we demonstrate that expression of an orphan G protein-coupled receptor, Gene, in the Species lung is developmentally regulated, reaching maximal levels 1 day after birth, and is highly expressed on the apical surface of alveolar type I and type II epithelial cells. To define the physiological role of Gene in vivo, Species with a targeted mutation of the Gene locus, Gene(Deltaexon17), were generated. Gene(Deltaexon17) Species developed a profound accumulation of alveolar surfactant phospholipids at 4 weeks of age (12-fold) that was further increased at 20 weeks of age (30-fold). Surfactant accumulation in Gene(Deltaexon17) Species was associated with increased saturated Chemical synthesis at 4 weeks and the presence of enlarged, lipid-laden macrophages, Disease, and Disease at 20 weeks. mRNA microarray analyses indicated that Gene, a purinergic receptor known to mediate surfactant secretion, was induced in Gene(Deltaexon17) type II cells. Collectively, these data support the concept that Gene functions as a molecular sensor of alveolar surfactant lipid pool sizes by regulating surfactant secretion.

24211589.pub_title: Gene encodes a novel transcriptional co-activator of Gene in Species embryonic hearts.
24211589.pub_abstract: Despite considerable advances in surgical repairing procedures, Disease (Disease) remain the leading noninfectious cause of Species morbidity and mortality. Understanding the molecular/genetic mechanisms underlying normal cardiogenesis will provide essential information for the development of novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies against Disease. BMP signaling plays complex roles in multiple cardiogenic processes in mammals. Gene is a canonical nuclear mediator of BMP signaling, the activity of which is critically regulated through its interaction partners. We screened a Species embryonic heart yeast two-hybrid library using Gene as bait and identified Gene as a novel interaction partner of Gene. Gene contains multiple potential functional domains, including two partially overlapping transactivation domains at the C terminus. The Gene-Gene interaction in vitro and in Species cells was further confirmed through biochemical assays. The expression of Gene in developing hearts was demonstrated using RT-PCR, western blotting and in situ hybridization analyses. We also showed that Gene was localized in both the cytoplasm and nucleus of immortalized cardiomyocytes and primary Disease cultures. The overexpression of Gene in cardiomyocytes not only enhanced the activity of two BMP reporters in a dose-dependent manner but also increased the expression of several known BMP/Gene regulatory targets. Therefore, these data suggest that Gene acts as a Gene transcriptional co-activator to promote the expression of BMP target genes during Species cardiogenesis.

25859010.pub_title: Disease due to mutations in the Disease gene, Gene (Gene).
25859010.pub_abstract: Disease (RP), the most common form of inherited Disease, is clinically and genetically heterogeneous and can appear as syndromic or non-syndromic. Disease (Disease) is a lethal disorder, caused by mutations in the Gene (Gene) gene and characterized by progressive Disease, with Disease as a prominent feature. We identified Gene mutations in six Species with non-syndromic RP. Whole exome sequencing (WES) in an Ashkenazi Jewish Israeli RP Species revealed a novel homozygous Gene variant, c.370A>T, which leads to partial skipping of exon 3. Screening of 66 Ashkenazi RP index cases revealed an additional family with two siblings homozygous for c.370A>T. WES in three Dutch siblings with RP revealed a complex Gene variant, c.[398G>C; 1843G>A] on one allele, and c.1843G>A on the other allele. Gene activity levels in blood leukocytes of Species were reduced compared with healthy controls, but usually higher than those in Disease Species. All Species were diagnosed with non-syndromic RP and did not exhibit Disease, or any phenotypic features consistent with Disease IIIC. Furthermore, four of the Species were over 60 years old, exceeding by far the life expectancy of Disease Species. Gene is highly expressed in the Species retina, and we hypothesize that the retina requires higher Gene activity to maintain proper function, compared with other tissues associated with Disease IIIC, such as the brain. This report broadens the spectrum of phenotypes associated with Gene mutations and highlights the critical function of Gene in the Species retina.

24616499.pub_title: Mechanism governing a stem cell-generating cis-regulatory element.
24616499.pub_abstract: The unremitting demand to replenish differentiated cells in tissues requires efficient mechanisms to generate and regulate stem and progenitor cells. Although master regulatory transcription factors, including Gene (Gene), have crucial roles in these mechanisms, how such factors are controlled in developmentally dynamic systems is poorly understood. Previously, we described five dispersed Gene locus sequences, termed the -77, -3.9, -2.8, -1.8, and +9.5 Gene switch sites, which contain evolutionarily conserved Gene motifs occupied by Gene and Gene in hematopoietic precursors and erythroid cells, respectively. Despite common attributes of transcriptional enhancers, targeted deletions of the -2.8, -1.8, and +9.5 sites revealed distinct and unpredictable contributions to Gene expression and hematopoiesis. Herein, we describe the targeted deletion of the -3.9 site and mechanistically compare the -3.9 site with other Gene switch sites. The -3.9(-/-) Species were viable and exhibited normal Gene expression and steady-state hematopoiesis in the embryo and adult. We established a Gene repression/reactivation assay, which revealed unique +9.5 site activity to mediate Gene factor-dependent chromatin structural transitions. Loss-of-function analyses provided evidence for a mechanism in which a mediator of long-range transcriptional control [Gene (Gene)] and a chromatin remodeler [Gene (Gene)] synergize through the +9.5 site, conferring expression of Gene, which is known to promote the genesis and survival of hematopoietic stem cells.

27480238.pub_title: Gene suppresses excitatory synapse development by cis-inhibiting trans-synaptic Gene-Gene adhesion.
27480238.pub_abstract: Synaptic adhesion molecules regulate various aspects of synapse development, function and plasticity. These functions mainly involve trans-synaptic interactions and positive regulations, whereas cis-interactions and negative regulation are less understood. Here we report that Gene, a member of the SALM/Lrfn family of synaptic adhesion molecules, suppresses excitatory synapse development through cis inhibition of Gene, another SALM family protein with synaptogenic activity. Gene-mutant (Gene(-/-)) Species show increased excitatory synapse numbers in the hippocampus. Gene cis-interacts with Gene, inhibits trans-synaptic Gene interaction with presynaptic Gene family receptor Chemical phosphatases and suppresses Gene-dependent presynaptic differentiation. Importantly, deletion of Gene in Gene(-/-) Species (Gene(-/-); Gene(-/-)) normalizes the increased excitatory synapse number. These results suggest that Gene negatively regulates excitatory synapses via cis inhibition of the trans-synaptic Gene-Gene adhesion.

26188246.pub_title: Gene coordinates cellular migration and extracellular matrix remodeling during aortic valve maturation.
26188246.pub_abstract: Proper remodeling of the endocardial cushions into thin fibrous valves is essential for gestational progression and long-term function. This process involves dynamic interactions between resident cells and their local environment, much of which is not understood. In this study, we show that deficiency of the cell-cell adhesion protein Gene (Gene) results in significant Disease and perinatal lethality primarily due to valve related Disease. While endocardial to mesenchymal transformation is not abrogated, mesenchymal cells do not homogeneously cellularize the cushions. These cushions remain thickened with disorganized ECM, resulting in pronounced Disease. Species that survive to adulthood maintain thickened and stenotic semilunar valves, but interestingly do not develop Disease. Gene (-/-) aortic valve leaflets contained reduced Gene activity, beta1 integrin expression, and Gene-GTP activity, suggesting that remodeling defects are due to improper migration and/or cellular contraction. Gene deletion or siRNA knockdown reduced migration, eliminated collective migration, and impaired 3D matrix compaction by aortic valve interstitial cells (Chemical). Gene depleted cells in culture contained few filopodia, stress fibers, or contact inhibited locomotion. Transfection of Gene depleted cells with constitutively active Gene restored cell phenotypes. Together, these results identify Gene mediated adhesive signaling for proper remodeling of the Disease valves.

22405651.pub_title: The glomuvenous malformation protein Gene binds Gene and regulates cullin RING ligase-mediated turnover of Gene.
22405651.pub_abstract: Gene, a substrate receptor for Gene-RING-ligase (Gene), facilitates the ubiquitination and degradation of several proteins, including Cyclin E and Gene. In spite of much effort, the mechanisms underlying Gene regulation are mostly unknown. Here, we show that Gene (Gene), a protein found mutated in the Disease (GVM), binds directly to the RING domain of Gene and inhibits its E3 ubiquitin ligase activity. Loss of Gene in a variety of cells, tissues, and GVM lesions results in decreased levels of Gene and increased levels of Cyclin E and Gene. The increased turnover of Gene is dependent on Gene and proteasome activity, indicating that Gene modulates the E3 activity of Gene(Gene). These data reveal an unexpected functional connection between Gene and Gene and demonstrate that defective regulation of Gene levels contributes to GVM.

24421385.pub_title: Gene role in heme biosynthesis in vivo: Gene knockout in Species causes Disease with Chemical and Chemical accumulation.
24421385.pub_abstract: Gene, member 10 of the ABC transporter family, is reportedly a part of a complex in the mitochondrial inner membrane with Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene) and is responsible for heme biosynthesis in utero. However, it is unclear whether loss of Gene causes pathological changes in adult Species. Here, we show that Gene(-/-) Species lack heme biosynthesis and Disease and die in midgestation. Moreover, we generated Gene(F/-); Gene-Cre Species, with Gene in hematopoietic cells deleted, which showed accumulation of Chemical and maturation arrest in reticulocytes. Electron microscopy images of Gene(-/-) hematopoietic cells showed a marked increase of Chemical deposits at the mitochondria. These results suggest a critical role for Gene in heme biosynthesis and provide new insights into the pathogenesis of Disease and Disease.

26771085.pub_title: Gene deficiency discloses a repressive role of Gene on endocrine differentiation in the Disease.
26771085.pub_abstract: Transcriptional and signaling networks establish complex cross-regulatory interactions that drive cellular differentiation during development. Using microarrays we identified the gene encoding the ligand Gene as a candidate target of Gene, a basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor that functions as a master regulator of Disease differentiation. Here we show that Gene is expressed in the Disease and that its deficiency enhances activation of the endocrine transcriptional program and increases the number of endocrine cells at birth. We identify the gene encoding the endocrine transcription factor Gene as one of the most upregulated genes in Gene-ablated pancreases and associate its activation to reduced expression of the Gene effector Gene. Accordingly, in vitro studies confirm that Gene represses activation of Gene by Gene and inhibits Gene expression in differentiated beta-cells. Further, we report that Gene protein levels decline upon initiation of endocrine differentiation in vivo, disclosing the downregulation of this factor in the developing endocrine compartment. These findings highlight the notion that modulation of signalling cues by lineage-promoting factors is pivotal for controlling differentiation programs.

22427063.pub_title: Gene is necessary for normal temporomandibular joint development.
22427063.pub_abstract: Mutation of the Species Gene gene leads to Disease (Disease), which is characterized by an abnormal development of various organs including the craniofacial skeleton. Gene has recently been shown to be expressed in the Disease of Species; however, whether Gene is expressed in the Species temporomandibular joint (TMJ), or whether it is necessary for TMJ development is unknown. We have analyzed (1) the expression pattern of Gene during TMJ development in Species and (2) TMJ development in Gene knockout animals. Gene is expressed in the maxillo-mandibular junction at embryonic day (E) 11.5. At E15.5, expression is restricted to the developing condylar cartilage and to the surrounding joint disc progenitor cells. In Gene knockout Species, the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone forms relatively normally but the condylar process is extremely small and the joint disc and cavities do not develop. The initiation of condyle formation is slightly delayed in the mutants at E14.5; however, at E18.5, the flattened chondrocyte layer is narrowed and most of the condylar chondrocytes exhibit precocious chondrocyte maturation. Expression of Gene and its target genes is expanded toward the condylar apex in the mutants. These observations underscore the indispensable role played by Gene in normal TMJ development in supporting the differentiation of disc and synoviocyte progenitor cells and in coordinating condylar chondrocyte differentiation.

23048031.pub_title: Transcription factor Gene (Gene) recruits Gene (Gene) to mediate histone Chemical methylation and control neural stem cell proliferation and differentiation.
23048031.pub_abstract: During development of the cerebral cortex, neural stem cells (NSCs) undergo a temporal switch from proliferative (symmetric) to neuron-generating (asymmetric) divisions. We investigated the role of Schwann cell factor 1 (Gene/Gene), a member of the PRDM family of transcription factors, in this critical transition. We discovered that Gene recruits the chromatin modifier Gene, an Chemical methyltransferase that catalyzes symmetric dimethylation of histone H4 Chemical 3 (Chemical) and that this modification is preferentially associated with undifferentiated cortical NSCs. Overexpressing Gene in Disease led to an increase in the number of Nestin-expressing precursors; mutational analysis of Gene showed that this was dependent on recruitment of Gene. We found that Gene protein levels are down-regulated at the onset of neurogenesis and that experimental knockdown of Gene in primary NSCs triggers precocious neuronal differentiation. We propose that Gene and Gene are components of an epigenetic regulatory complex that maintains the "stem-like" cellular state of the NSC by preserving their proliferative capacity and modulating their cell cycle progression. Our findings provide evidence that histone Chemical methylation regulates NSC differentiation.

26518685.pub_title: Chemical dehydrogenase activity is necessary for beta cell development and functionality in Species.
26518685.pub_abstract: AIMS/HYPOTHESIS: Pancreatic beta cells maintain Chemical homeostasis and Disease is a major risk factor in developing Disease. Therefore, understanding the developmental regulatory networks that define a fully functional beta cell is important for elucidating the genetic origins of the disease. Chemical dehydrogenase activity has been associated with stem/progenitor cells and we have previously shown that Gene is specifically expressed in pancreas progenitor pools. Here we address the hypothesis that Gene may regulate the timing of the appearance and eventual functionality of beta cells. METHODS: We generated an Gene-knockout Species line (Gene (tm1lacZ)) and used this to study Disease development, beta cell functionality and Chemical homeostasis in the absence of Gene function. RESULTS: Differentiation in the developing pancreas of Gene (tm1lacZ) null Species was accelerated. Transcriptome analyses of newborn and adult islets showed misregulation of key beta cell transcription factors and genes crucial for beta cell function. Functional analyses showed that Chemical-stimulated insulin secretion was severely compromised in islets isolated from null Species. Several key features of beta cell functionality were affected, including control of oxidative stress, Chemical sensing, stimulus-coupling secretion and secretory granule biogenesis. As a result of Disease, homozygous Species developed Disease and age-dependent Disease. CONCLUSIONS/INTERPRETATION: These findings show that Gene influences the timing of the transition from the pancreas endocrine progenitor to the committed beta cell and demonstrate that changes in the timing of this transition lead to Disease and thus constitute a Disease risk factor later in life. Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) accession: GSE58025.

24817584.pub_title: Constitutive Gene signaling in adult Species inhibits Gene-induced angiogenesis and Disease follicle development.
24817584.pub_abstract: Gene signaling is important in angiogenesis during embryonic development. However, the embryonic lethal phenotypes of knock-out and Species have precluded studies of the role of Gene post-natally. To develop a Species model that would bypass the embryonic lethal phenotype and investigate the possible role of Gene signaling in adult vessel growth, we developed Species with Cre-conditional expression of the constitutively active intracellular domain of Gene (Gene). Double Species Gene/Gene-Cre embryos with endothelial specific Gene expression died at embryonic day 9.5. They displayed collapsed and leaky blood vessels and defects in angiogenesis development. A Chemical-inducible system was used to express Cre recombinase postnatally in endothelial cells. In adult Species, Gene expression inhibited Gene-induced neovascularization and female Species lacked mature ovarian follicles, which may reflect the block in Gene-induced angiogenesis required for follicle growth. Our results demonstrate that Gene signaling is important for both embryonic and adult angiogenesis and indicate that the Gene signaling pathway may be a useful target for angiogenic therapies.

24893171.pub_title: Patterns of gene expression associated with Disease in the developing inner ear.
24893171.pub_abstract: In inner ear development, phosphatase and tensin homolog (Gene) is necessary for neuronal maintenance, such as neuronal survival and accurate nerve innervations of hair cells. We previously reported that Gene conditional knockout (cKO) Species exhibited Disease with neuronal apoptosis in spiral ganglion neurons (SGNs). To better understand the genes and signaling networks related to auditory neuron maintenance, we compared the profiles of differentially expressed genes (Chemical) using microarray analysis of the inner ear in E14.5 Gene cKO and wild-type Species. We identified 46 statistically significant transcripts using significance analysis of microarrays, with the false-discovery rate set at 0%. Among the Chemical, expression levels of candidate genes and expression domains were validated by quantitative real-time RT-PCR and in situ hybridization, respectively. Ingenuity pathway analysis using Chemical identified significant signaling networks associated with apoptosis, cellular movement, and axon guidance (i.e., Gene (Gene)-mediated cellular movement and Gene (Gene)-mediated axon guidance). This result was consistent with the phenotypic defects of SGNs in Gene cKO Species (e.g., neuronal apoptosis, abnormal migration, and irregular nerve fiber patterns of SGNs). From this study, we suggest two key regulatory signaling networks mediated by Gene and Gene, which may play potential roles in neuronal differentiation of developing auditory neurons.

24448552.pub_title: Gene regulates differentiation onset and migration of trophoblast stem cells.
24448552.pub_abstract: Propagation and differentiation of stem cell populations are tightly regulated to provide sufficient cell numbers for tissue formation while maintaining the stem cell pool. Embryonic parts of the Species placenta are generated from differentiating trophoblast stem cells (TSCs) invading the maternal decidua. Here we demonstrate that Gene (Gene) regulates differentiation onset of TSCs. Deletion of Gene in Species results in the Disease, diminished formation of trophectoderm tissues and early Disease. Gene-deficient TSCs display features of differentiation initiation, including alterations of cell morphology, and increased migration and invasion. We show that increased TSC motility is mediated by the premature expression of the transcription factor Gene that is directly repressed by Gene in undifferentiated cells. In summary, our data demonstrate that the epigenetic modifier Gene functions as a Species for the differentiation onset of TSCs, whereby differentiation-associated cell migration is controlled by the transcription factor Gene.

26438843.pub_title: cKit+ cardiac progenitors of neural crest origin.
26438843.pub_abstract: The degree to which cKit-expressing progenitors generate cardiomyocytes in the heart is controversial. Genetic fate-mapping studies suggest minimal contribution; however, whether or not minimal contribution reflects minimal cardiomyogenic capacity is unclear because the embryonic origin and role in cardiogenesis of these progenitors remain elusive. Using high-resolution genetic fate-mapping approaches with cKit(CreERT2/+) and Gene::Flpe Species lines, we show that cKit delineates cardiac neural crest progenitors (CNC(kit)). CNC(kit) possess full cardiomyogenic capacity and contribute to all CNC derivatives, including cardiac conduction system cells. Furthermore, by modeling cardiogenesis in cKit(CreERT2)-induced pluripotent stem cells, we show that, paradoxically, the cardiogenic fate of CNC(kit) is regulated by bone morphogenetic protein antagonism, a signaling pathway activated transiently during establishment of the cardiac crescent, and extinguished from the heart before CNC invasion. Together, these findings elucidate the origin of cKit(+) cardiac progenitors and suggest that a nonpermissive cardiac milieu, rather than minimal cardiomyogenic capacity, controls the degree of CNC(kit) contribution to myocardium.

27009605.pub_title: Primitive Embryonic Macrophages are Required for Coronary Development and Maturation.
27009605.pub_abstract: RATIONALE: It is now recognized that macrophages residing within developing and adult tissues are derived from diverse progenitors including those of embryonic origin. Although the functions of macrophages in adult organisms are well studied, the functions of macrophages during organ development remain largely undefined. Moreover, it is unclear whether distinct macrophage lineages have differing functions. OBJECTIVE: To address these issues, we investigated the functions of macrophage subsets resident within the developing heart, an organ replete with embryonic-derived macrophages. METHODS AND RESULTS: Using a combination of flow cytometry, immunostaining, and genetic lineage tracing, we demonstrate that the developing heart contains a complex array of embryonic macrophage subsets that can be divided into Gene(+) macrophages derived from primitive yolk sac, Gene(+) lymphomyeloid, and Gene(+) fetal monocyte lineages. Functionally, yolk sac-derived Gene(-) macrophages are instrumental in coronary development where they are required for remodeling of the primitive coronary plexus. Mechanistically, Gene(-) macrophages are recruited to coronary blood vessels at the onset of coronary perfusion where they mediate coronary plexus remodeling through selective expansion of perfused vasculature. We further demonstrate that insulin like growth factor signaling may mediate the proangiogenic properties of embryonic-derived macrophages. CONCLUSIONS: Together, these findings demonstrate that the embryonic heart contains distinct lineages of embryonic macrophages with unique functions and reveal a novel mechanism that governs coronary development.

25446274.pub_title: Abnormal development of placenta in Gene-deficient Species.
25446274.pub_abstract: Abnormal levels of Gene (Gene) protein have been repeatedly observed in sera and placentas of preeclampsia Species. To understand the functions of Gene in placentation and in the etiology of preeclampsia, we established Gene(-/-) Species. Gene(-/-) Species show Disease, and their placentas are small due to a reduced size of the junctional zone and aberrant vascularization in the labyrinth at the mid-gestation stage. Gene is expressed by Gene-positive trophoblast precursors in the outer ectoplacental cone and junctional zone from embryonic day 7.5 to 10.5. In the Gene(-/-) placenta, Gene-positive cell precursors are decreased in the early stage. Spongiotrophoblasts and glycogen trophoblast cells, both of which differentiate from Gene-positive precursors, are consequently decreased in the junctional zone. Fewer spiral artery-associated trophoblast giant cells, another cell type derived from Gene-positive precursors, invade the decidua and associate with maternal arteries in the Gene(-/-) placenta than in the wild type placenta. Maternal arteries in the Gene(-/-) decidua have narrower lumens, thicker arterial walls, and more vascular smooth muscle cells remaining in the walls than those in the wild type decidua, indicating impaired remodeling of maternal arteries. These results indicate that Gene plays important roles in the differentiation of trophoblasts from Gene-positive precursors in the ectoplacental cone. Insufficient levels of Gene cause poor placental development and Disease, due to aberrant trophoblast differentiation and consequent defects in maternal artery remodeling, and may contribute to the onset of preeclampsia.

22072714.pub_title: Loss of the Chemical effector protein Gene impacts the expression of genes regulated by the Chemical acetyltransferase MOF.
22072714.pub_abstract: In epigenetic signaling pathways, histone tails are heavily modified, resulting in the recruitment of effector molecules that can influence transcription. One such molecule, Gene (Gene), uses a Tudor domain to read Chemical residues and is a known component of the MOF (male absent on the first) histone acetyltransferase protein complex, suggesting it plays a role in the cross-talk between Chemical methylation and histone acetylation. We sought to investigate the biological role of Gene by generating a knockout Species. Without Gene, Species die shortly after birth and display a wide variety of phenotypes within the skeletal and hematopoietic systems. Mechanistically, Gene is not required for maintaining the global H4K16 acetylation levels or locus specific histone acetylation but instead works downstream in transcriptional regulation of MOF target genes.

22363783.pub_title: Comparison of phenotypes between different Gene mutants demonstrates dominant effects of the Looptail mutation during hair cell development.
22363783.pub_abstract: Experiments utilizing the Looptail mutant Species, which harbors a missense mutation in the Gene gene, have been essential for studies of planar polarity and linking the function of the core planar cell polarity proteins to other developmental signals. Originally described as having dominant phenotypic traits, the molecular interactions underlying the Looptail mutant phenotype are unclear because Gene protein levels are significantly reduced or absent from mutant tissues. Here we introduce a Gene knockout Species and directly compare the severity of the knockout and Looptail mutant phenotypes by intercrossing the two lines and assaying the planar polarity of inner ear hair cells. Overall the Gene knockout phenotype is milder than the phenotype of compound mutants carrying both the Looptail and Gene knockout alleles. In compound mutants a greater number of hair cells are affected and changes in the orientation of individual hair cells are greater when quantified. We further demonstrate in a heterologous cell system that the protein encoded by the Looptail mutation (Gene(Protein Mutation)) disrupts delivery of Gene and Gene proteins to the cell surface as a result of oligomer formation between Gene and Gene(Protein Mutation), or Gene and Gene(Protein Mutation), coupled to the intracellular retention of Gene(Protein Mutation). As a result, Gene protein is missing from the apical cell surface of vestibular hair cells in Looptail mutants, but is retained at the apical cell surface of hair cells in Gene knockouts. Similarly the distribution of Prickle-like2, a putative Gene interacting protein, is differentially affected in the two mutant lines. In summary, we provide evidence for a direct physical interaction between Gene and Gene through a combination of in vitro and in vivo approaches and propose that this interaction underlies the dominant phenotypic traits associated with the Looptail mutation.

26525805.pub_title: Gene functionally complements the related Gene and Gene as important developmental modulators in Species spinal cord oligodendrocytes.
26525805.pub_abstract: The role of transcription factor Gene, which together with Gene and Gene belongs to the SoxD family, is only poorly characterized in central nervous system development. Therefore, we analysed whether Gene expression and function overlaps with or differs from that of its close relatives Gene and Gene. In the developing Species spinal cord, we found Gene predominantly expressed in neuroepithelial precursors, oligodendroglial and astroglial cells. The substantially overlapping expression with Gene and Gene in oligodendroglial cells prompted us to study potential roles during specification, lineage progression and differentiation of oligodendrocytes. In contrast to Gene and Gene, Gene expression continues after differentiation and even increases in myelinating oligodendrocytes. Gene deletion did not interfere with oligodendroglial development, which was normal in Gene-deficient Species. However, the premature differentiation of oligodendrocyte precursors triggered by loss of Gene was slightly more prominent in Gene/Gene double-deficient Species. Gene can bind to the same sites in myelin gene promoters as Gene and Gene in vitro. Reporter gene assays furthermore reveal a similar antagonizing effect on Gene-dependent transactivation of myelin gene promoters as previously shown for Gene and Gene. This argues that Gene is functionally redundant with the other SoxD proteins and complements Gene and Gene in their role as important modulators of oligodendrocyte development. The transcription factor Gene is co-expressed with the related Gene and Gene in cells of the oligodendroglial lineage. By itself, it has little impact on oligodendrocyte development but supports Gene and Gene during the process as a functionally redundant transcription factor.

27246713.pub_title: Chromatin remodeling enzyme Gene regulates Disease differentiation and denucleation.
27246713.pub_abstract: Ocular lens morphogenesis is a model for investigating mechanisms of cellular differentiation, spatial and temporal gene expression control, and chromatin regulation. Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene) are catalytic subunits of distinct Chemical-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes implicated in transcriptional regulation. Previous studies have shown that Gene regulates both lens fiber cell differentiation and organized degradation of their nuclei (denucleation). Here, we employed a conditional Gene(flox) Species model to probe the cellular and molecular mechanisms of lens formation. Depletion of Gene induces premature and expanded differentiation of lens precursor cells forming the lens vesicle, implicating Gene as a key regulator of lens vesicle polarity through spatial control of Gene, Gene, Gene(Gene) (Gene) and Gene(Gene) (Gene) gene expression. The abnormal Gene(-/-) fiber cells also retain their nuclei. RNA profiling of Gene(-/) (-) and Gene(-/-) eyes revealed differences in multiple transcripts, including prominent downregulation of those encoding Gene and Gene, which are implicated in the denucleation process. In summary, our data suggest that Gene is essential for the establishment of lens vesicle polarity, partitioning of prospective lens epithelial and fiber cell compartments, lens fiber cell differentiation, and lens fiber cell nuclear degradation.

22737085.pub_title: Genome-wide location analysis reveals distinct transcriptional circuitry by paralogous regulators Gene and Gene.
22737085.pub_abstract: Gene duplication is a powerful driver of evolution. Newly duplicated genes acquire new roles that are relevant to fitness, or they will be lost over time. A potential path to functional relevance is mutation of the coding sequence leading to the acquisition of novel biochemical properties, as analyzed here for the highly homologous paralogs Gene and Gene transcriptional regulators. We determine by genome-wide location analysis (ChIP-Seq) that, although Gene and Gene share a large fraction of binding sites in the liver, each protein also occupies distinct regulatory elements in vivo. Gene-only sites are enriched for Gene binding sites and are frequently found near genes important to cell cycle regulation, while Gene-restricted sites show only a limited match to the forkhead consensus and are found in genes involved in Chemical and lipid metabolism. Thus, Gene and Gene, while redundant during development, have evolved divergent roles in the adult liver, ensuring the maintenance of both genes during evolution.

25615698.pub_title: Gene (Gene) is required for corneal epithelial cell proliferation and differentiation during embryonic development.
25615698.pub_abstract: Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs) play important roles in many aspects of embryonic development. During eye development, the lens and corneal epithelium are derived from the same surface ectodermal tissue. FGF receptor (FGFR)-signaling is essential for lens cell differentiation and survival, but its role in corneal development has not been fully investigated. In this study, we examined the Disease in Gene conditional knockout Species in which Cre expression is activated at lens induction stage by Gene P0 promoter. The cornea in LeCre, Gene(loxP/loxP) Species (referred as Gene(CKO)) was analyzed to assess changes in cell proliferation, differentiation and survival. We found that Gene(CKO) cornea was much thinner in epithelial and stromal layer when compared to Disease. At embryonic day 12.5-13.5 (E12.5-13.5) shortly after the lens vesicle detaches from the overlying surface ectoderm, cell proliferation (judged by labeling indices of Gene, Chemical and Chemical-histone H3) was significantly reduced in corneal epithelium in Gene(CKO) Species. At later stage, cell differentiation markers for corneal epithelium and underlying stromal mesenchyme, keratin-12 and keratocan respectively, were not expressed in Gene(CKO) cornea. Furthermore, Gene, a transcription factor essential for eye development, was not present in the Gene(CKO) mutant corneal epithelial at E16.5 but was expressed normally at E12.5, suggesting that Gene-signaling is required for maintaining Gene expression in this tissue. Interestingly, the role of Gene in corneal epithelial development is independent of Gene-signaling. In contrast to the lens, Gene is not required for cell survival in cornea. This study demonstrates for the first time that Gene plays an essential role in controlling cell proliferation and differentiation, and maintaining Gene levels in corneal epithelium via Gene-independent pathways during embryonic development.

23028704.pub_title: Disease phenotype in Gene;Gene compound mutants: a novel experimental model for studies of caudal body Disease.
23028704.pub_abstract: Disease is a severe congenital malformation of the lower body characterized by the fusion of the legs into a single lower limb. This striking external phenotype consistently associates severe Disease, most commonly of the kidneys, intestine, and genitalia that generally make the condition lethal. Although the causes of Disease remain unknown, clinical studies have yielded two major hypotheses: i) a primary defect in the generation of caudal mesoderm, ii) a primary Disease that leaves the caudal part of the embryo hypoperfused. Interestingly, Disease has been shown to have a genetic basis in Species, and although it has been considered a sporadic condition in Species, recently some possible familial cases have been reported. Here, we report that the removal of one or both functional alleles of Gene from the Gene-null background leads to a Disease phenotype that faithfully replicates the constellation of external and internal Disease, typical of the Species condition. These mutants represent an invaluable model in which we have analyzed the pathogenesis of Disease. We show that the signaling defect predominantly impacts the morphogenesis of the hindgut and the development of the caudal end of the dorsal aortas. The deficient formation of ventral midline structures, including the interlimb mesoderm caudal to the umbilicus, leads to the approximation and merging of the hindlimb fields. Our study provides new insights for the understanding of the mechanisms resulting in caudal body Disease, including Disease.

25615642.pub_title: Gene is required for normal heart valve development and cardiac function.
25615642.pub_abstract: Disease in Species occur in approximately 2% of live births and are a major source of compromised cardiac function. In this study we demonstrate that normal heart valve development and cardiac function are dependent upon Gene, the gene that encodes a member of the family of glycosyltransferases (Chemical-Ts) responsible for the initiation of mucin-type O-glycosylation. In the adult Species, compromised cardiac function that mimics Species congenital Disease, including aortic and Disease and regurgitation; altered ejection fraction; and Disease, was observed in Gene null animals. The underlying phenotype is aberrant valve formation caused by increased cell proliferation within the outflow tract cushion of developing hearts, which is first detected at developmental stage E11.5. Developing valves from Gene deficient animals displayed reduced levels of the proteases Gene and Gene, decreased cleavage of the proteoglycan versican and increased levels of other extracellular matrix proteins. We also observed increased BMP and MAPK signaling. Taken together, the ablation of Gene appears to disrupt the formation/remodeling of the extracellular matrix and alters conserved signaling pathways that regulate cell proliferation. Our study provides insight into the role of this conserved protein modification in cardiac valve development and may represent a new model for Disease.

24292013.pub_title: Cell-to-cell expression variability followed by signal reinforcement progressively segregates early Species lineages.
24292013.pub_abstract: It is now recognized that extensive expression heterogeneities among cells precede the emergence of lineages in the early Species embryo. To establish a map of pluripotent epiblast (Chemical) versus primitive endoderm (PrE) lineage segregation within the inner cell mass (ICM) of the Species blastocyst, we characterized the gene expression profiles of individual ICM cells. Clustering analysis of the transcriptomes of 66 cells demonstrated that initially they are non-distinguishable. Early in the segregation, lineage-specific marker expression exhibited no apparent correlation, and a hierarchical relationship was established only in the late blastocyst. Gene exhibited a bimodal expression at the earliest stage analysed, and in its absence, the differentiation of PrE and Chemical was halted, indicating that Gene drives, and is required for, ICM lineage segregation. These data lead us to propose a model where stochastic cell-to-cell expression heterogeneity followed by signal reinforcement underlies ICM lineage segregation by antagonistically separating equivalent cells.

22951644.pub_title: Gene inhibits sprouting angiogenesis during vascular development.
22951644.pub_abstract: Coordination between the vascular system and forming organs is essential for proper embryonic development. The vasculature expands by sprouting angiogenesis, during which tip cells form filopodia that incorporate into capillary loops. Although several molecules, such as Gene (Gene), are known to induce sprouting, the mechanism that terminates this process to ensure neovessel stability is still unknown. Gene (Gene(1)) has been shown to mediate interaction between endothelial and mural cells during vascular maturation. In vitro studies have identified Gene(1) as a pro-angiogenic factor. Here, we show that Gene acts as an endothelial cell (EC)-autonomous negative regulator of sprouting angiogenesis during vascular development. Severe aberrations in vessel size and excessive sprouting found in limbs of Gene(1)-null Species embryos before vessel maturation imply a previously unknown, mural cell-independent role for Gene as an anti-angiogenic factor. A similar phenotype observed when Gene(1) expression was blocked specifically in ECs indicates that the effect of Gene on sprouting is EC-autonomous. Comparable Disease in Gene(1) knockdown Species embryos suggest cross-species evolutionary conservation of this mechanism. Finally, genetic interaction between Gene(1) and Gene suggests that these factors interplay to regulate vascular development, as Gene promotes sprouting whereas Gene(1) inhibits it to prevent excessive sprouting and fusion of neovessels. More broadly, because Gene, the ligand of Gene, is blood-borne, our findings suggest a new mode of regulation of angiogenesis, whereby blood flow closes a negative feedback loop that inhibits sprouting angiogenesis once the vascular bed is established and functional.

24297939.pub_title: Protein O-mannosylation is crucial for Gene-mediated cell adhesion.
24297939.pub_abstract: In recent years protein O-mannosylation has become a focus of attention as a pathomechanism underlying severe Disease associated with Disease. A key feature of these disorders is the lack of Chemical glycans on alpha-dystroglycan, resulting in abnormal basement membrane formation. Additional functions of O-mannosylation are still largely unknown. Here, we identify the essential cell-cell adhesion glycoprotein epithelial (E)-cadherin as an Chemical protein and establish a functional link between Chemical glycans and Gene-mediated cell-cell adhesion. By genetically and pharmacologically blocking protein O-mannosyltransferases, we found that this posttranslational modification is essential for preimplantation development of the Species embryo. O-mannosylation-deficient embryos failed to proceed from the morula to the blastocyst stage because of defects in the molecular architecture of cell-cell contact sites, including the adherens and tight junctions. Using mass spectrometry, we demonstrate that Chemical glycans are present on Gene, the major cell-adhesion molecule of blastomeres, and present evidence that this modification is generally conserved in cadherins. Further, the use of newly raised antibodies specific for an Chemical-conjugated epitope revealed that these glycans are present on early Species embryos. Finally, our cell-aggregation assays demonstrated that Chemical glycans are crucial for cadherin-based cell adhesion. Our results redefine the significance of O-mannosylation in Species and other mammals, showing the immense impact of cadherins on normal as well as pathogenic cell behavior.

24723342.pub_title: The zinc finger gene Gene is required for the development of excitatory neurons in the basolateral complex of the amygdala.
24723342.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The basolateral complex, comprised of the lateral, basolateral, and basomedial nuclei, is the main structure of the amygdala and contains two neuronal cell types: excitatory neurons and inhibitory interneurons. Studies show that most of the excitatory neurons originate in the ventral pallium of the Disease. However, their subsequent development remains poorly understood. RESULTS: In this study, we examined the roles of the zinc finger gene Gene in the development of the amygdala. Gene is expressed in the lateral and basolateral nuclei during development. In Gene-deficient embryos, specific excitatory neuron markers in the lateral and basolateral nuclei were reduced, with concurrent induction of other markers in the endopiriform cortex. Furthermore, the morphology of the lateral and basolateral nuclei was abnormal. In the adult stages, excitatory neurons in the lateral and basolateral nuclei were greatly reduced because of apoptosis that occurred soon after birth. CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest that Gene is required for the development of excitatory neurons and nuclear morphology in the lateral and basolateral nuclei, and that abnormal formation of these regions leads to cell death soon after birth in Gene-deficient Species.

23606267.pub_title: The dynamics of supernumerary tooth development are differentially regulated by Sprouty genes.
23606267.pub_abstract: In Species, a Disease separates the single incisor from the three molars in each dental quadrant. In the prospective Disease of the embryo, small rudimentary buds are found that are presumed to be rudiments of suppressed teeth. A supernumerary tooth occurs in the Disease of adult Species carrying mutations in either Gene or Gene. In the case of Gene mutants, the origin of the supernumerary tooth involves the revitalization of a Disease bud (called R2), whereas its origin in the Gene mutants is not known. In addition to R2, another rudimentary primordium (called MS) arises more anteriorly in the prospective Disease. We investigated the participation of both rudiments (MS and R2) in supernumerary tooth development in Gene and Gene mutants by comparing morphogenesis, proliferation, apoptosis, size and Gene expression in the dental epithelium of MS and R2 rudiments. Increased proliferation and decreased apoptosis were found in MS and R2 at embryonic day (ED) 12.5 and 13.5 in Gene(-/-) embryos. Apoptosis was also decreased in both rudiments in Gene(-/-) embryos, but the proliferation was lower (similar to WT Species), and supernumerary tooth development was accelerated, exhibiting a cap stage by ED13.5. Compared to Gene(-/-) Species, a high number of Gene(-/-) supernumerary Disease after ED13.5, resulting in a low percentage of supernumerary teeth in adults. We propose that Sprouty genes were implicated during evolution in reduction of the cheek teeth in Muridae, and their deletion can reveal ancestral stages of Species dental evolution.

26601269.pub_title: Cis-regulatory mechanisms governing stem and progenitor cell transitions.
26601269.pub_abstract: Cis-element encyclopedias provide information on phenotypic diversity and disease mechanisms. Although cis-element polymorphisms and mutations are instructive, deciphering function remains challenging. Mutation of an intronic GATA motif (+9.5) in Gene, encoding a master regulator of Disease, underlies an Disease associated with Disease (Disease) and Disease (Disease). Whereas an inversion relocalizes another Gene cis-element (-77) to the proto-oncogene Gene, inducing Gene expression and Disease, whether this reflects ectopic or physiological activity is unknown. We describe a Species strain that decouples -77 function from proto-oncogene deregulation. The -77(-/-) Species exhibited a novel phenotypic constellation including late Disease. The -77 established a vital sector of the myeloid progenitor transcriptome, conferring multipotentiality. Unlike the +9.5(-/-) embryos, hematopoietic stem cell genesis was unaffected in -77(-/-) embryos. These results illustrate a paradigm in which cis-elements in a locus differentially control stem and progenitor cell transitions, and therefore the individual cis-element alterations cause unique and overlapping disease phenotypes.

27417127.pub_title: Genetic depletion of Gene leads to Disease due to Disease.
27417127.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a Chemical/Chemical kinase that plays multiple and essential roles during the cell division cycle. Its inhibition in cultured cells leads to severe mitotic Disease and cell death. Whereas previous reports suggested that Gene depletion in Species leads to a non-mitotic arrest in early embryos, we show here that the bi-allelic Gene depletion in Species certainly results in Disease due to extensive mitotic aberrations at the morula stage, including multi- and mono-polar spindles, impaired chromosome segregation and Disease. In addition, the conditional depletion of Gene during mid-gestation leads also to severe Disease. Our data also confirms that Gene is completely dispensable for mitotic entry in vivo. On the other hand, Gene Disease Species are viable, and Gene-heterozygous fibroblasts do not harbor any cell cycle alterations. Gene is overexpressed in many Species Disease, suggesting a therapeutic benefit of inhibiting Gene, and specific small-molecule inhibitors for this kinase are now being evaluated in clinical trials. Therefore, the different Gene Species models here presented are a valuable tool to reexamine the relevance of the mitotic kinase Gene during Species development and animal physiology.

23364048.pub_title: The genome-defence gene Gene suppresses LINE-1 retrotransposons in the placenta and prevents intra-uterine Disease in Species.
23364048.pub_abstract: DNA methylation plays an important role in suppressing retrotransposon activity in Species genomes, yet there are stages of Species development where global hypomethylation puts the genome at risk of retrotransposition-mediated genetic instability. Hypomethylated primordial germ cells appear to limit this risk by expressing a cohort of retrotransposon-suppressing genome-defence genes whose silencing depends on promoter DNA methylation. Here, we investigate whether similar mechanisms operate in hypomethylated trophectoderm-derived components of the Species placenta to couple expression of genome-defence genes to the potential for retrotransposon activity. We show that the hypomethylated state of the Species placenta results in activation of only one of the hypomethylation-sensitive germline genome-defence genes: Gene. Gene appears to play an important role in placenta function as Gene(-/-) Species embryos exhibit Disease and have small placentas due to a reduction in the number of spongiotrophoblast, glycogen trophoblast and sinusoidal trophoblast giant cells. Furthermore, we show that retrotransposon mRNAs are derepressed in Gene(-/-) placentas and that protein encoded by the LINE-1 retrotransposon is upregulated in hypomethylated trophectoderm-derived cells that normally express Gene. This study suggests that post-transcriptional genome-defence mechanisms are operating in the placenta to protect the hypomethylated cells in this tissue from retrotransposons and suggests that imbalances between retrotransposon activity and genome-defence mechanisms could contribute to Disease and disease.

26040895.pub_title: The exocyst gene Gene regulates renal epithelial monolayer homeostasis and apoptotic sensitivity.
26040895.pub_abstract: The highly conserved exocyst protein complex regulates polarized exocytosis of subsets of secretory vesicles. A previous study reported that shRNA knockdown of an exocyst central subunit, Gene (Gene-KD) in Madin-Darby Species kidney (MDCK) cells disrupted primary cilia assembly and 3D cyst formation. We used three-dimensional collagen cultures of MDCK cells to further investigate the mechanisms by which Gene and the exocyst regulate epithelial polarity, morphogenesis, and homeostasis. Gene-KD cysts initially demonstrated undisturbed lumen formation although later displayed significantly fewer and shorter primary cilia than controls. Later in cystogenesis, control cells maintained normal homeostasis, while Gene-KD cysts displayed numerous apoptotic cells extruded basally into the collagen matrix. Gene-KD MDCK cells were also more sensitive to apoptotic triggers than controls. These phenotypes were reversed by restoring Gene expression with shRNA-resistant Species Gene. Apico-basal polarity appeared normal in Gene-KD cysts, whereas mitotic spindle angles differed significantly from controls, suggesting a planar cell polarity defect. In addition, analysis of renal tubules in a newly generated kidney-specific Gene-knockout Species model revealed significant defects in primary cilia assembly and in the targeted renal tubules; abnormal epithelial cell extrusion was also observed, supporting our in vitro results. We hypothesize that, in Gene-KD cells, the disrupted exocyst activity results in increased apoptotic sensitivity through defective primary cilia signaling and that, in combination with an increased basal cell extrusion rate, it affects epithelial barrier integrity and homeostasis.

25720380.pub_title: Disease induced by Genes knockdown alters the Gene-Gene signaling balance downstream of Gene.
25720380.pub_abstract: Recently, we demonstrated in cultured endothelial cells and in vivo that deficiency of an isoform of Gene, Genes, impairs caveolae and clathrin-mediated endocytosis and functionally upregulates compensatory pathways and their morphological carriers (i.e. enlarged endocytic structures, membranous rings or tubules) that are normally underrepresented. We now show that these endocytic structures internalize the broadly expressed Gene (Disease or Gene), also known as Gene, leading to its ubiquitylation and degradation. Moreover, the apoptotic or activated vascular cells of the Genes-knockdown Species release Gene-bearing microparticles to the systemic circulation. These interact with and transfer Gene to Disease endothelial cells, resulting in lung endothelial cell survival and phenotypic alteration towards proliferation through activation of Gene and Gene (also known as Gene and Gene, respectively). We also show that non-productive assembly of the Gene-Smad-Gene (Smad anchor for receptor activation, also known as Gene) signaling complex and preferential formation of the Gene-mSos-Gene complex account for Gene activation downstream of Gene and proliferation of pulmonary endothelial cells. Taken together, our studies demonstrate a functional relationship between the intercellular transfer of Gene by microparticles and endothelial cell survival and proliferation, and define a novel molecular mechanism for Gene and Gene-dependent Gene(MAPK) signaling that is significant for proliferative signaling and abnormal growth.

23500896.pub_title: Episodic-like memory is sensitive to both Disease-like pathological accumulation and normal ageing processes in Species.
23500896.pub_abstract: Episodic memory depends on the hippocampus and is sensitive to both Disease (Disease) pathology and normal ageing. We showed previously that 3xTgAD Species express a specific, Disease at 6 months of age in the What-Where-Which occasion (WWWhich) task (Davis, Easton, Eacott and Gigg, 2013). This task requires the integration of object-location and contextual cues to form an episodic-like memory. Here, we explore the cumulative effect of Disease on WWWhich memory by testing very young and middle-aged Species (3 and 12 months old, respectively). For comparison, we included an alternative episodic-like task (What-Where-When; WWWhen) and an object temporal order (Recency) task to explore claims that WWWhen types of memory are open to non-episodic solutions. We found that in contrast to their performance at 6 months, 3-month-old 3xTgAD Species formed WWWhich episodic-like memories; however, their performance at this age was poorer than in matched controls. In contrast, 3xTgAD and control animals aged 12 months were both impaired on the WWWhich task. Finally, 3xTgAD Species with a WWWhich deficit were unimpaired in both Recency and WWWhen tasks. These results support conclusions that: (1) young 3xTgAD Species express episodic-like memory, albeit depressed relative to controls; (2) age-related changes result in a deficit on the hippocampal-dependent WWWhich episodic memory task; and (3) control and 3xTgAD Species can use recency (trace strength) rather than episodic-like memory for tasks that contain a temporal 'When' component. These results, in combination with our previous findings, support an age-related decline in WWWhich episodic-like memory in Species. Furthermore, this decline is accelerated in the 3xTgAD model.

26060190.pub_title: Reversibility of Disease in an inducible Species model for FXTAS.
26060190.pub_abstract: Fragile X-associated Disease/Disease (FXTAS) is a late-onset Disease affecting carriers of the fragile X-premutation, who have an expanded CGG repeat in the 5'-UTR of the Gene gene. FXTAS is characterized by progressive development of intention Disease, Disease, Disease and neuropsychological problems. The disease is thought to be caused by a toxic RNA gain-of-function mechanism, and the major hallmark of the disease is ubiquitin-positive intranuclear inclusions in neurons and astrocytes. We have developed a new transgenic Species model in which we can induce expression of an expanded repeat in the brain upon Chemical (dox) exposure (i.e. Tet-On Species). This Tet-On model makes use of the PrP-rtTA driver and allows us to study disease progression and possibilities of reversibility. In these Species, 8 weeks of dox exposure was sufficient to induce the formation of ubiquitin-positive intranuclear inclusions, which also stain positive for the Gene translation product FMRpolyG. Formation of these inclusions is reversible after stopping expression of the expanded CGG RNA at an early developmental stage. Furthermore, we observed a deficit in the compensatory eye movements of Species with inclusions, a functional phenotype that could be reduced by stopping expression of the expanded CGG RNA early in the disease development. Taken together, this study shows, for the first time, the potential of disease reversibility and suggests that early intervention might be beneficial for FXTAS Species.

22753924.pub_title: The chemoattractant Gene suppresses Disease by recruiting natural killer cell antitumor defenses.
22753924.pub_abstract: Infiltration of specialized immune cells regulates the growth and survival of Disease. Here, in a survey of public whole genome expression datasets we found that the gene for Gene, a widely expressed endogenous chemoattractant protein, is down-regulated in Disease as well as other Species Disease. Moreover, high Gene messenger RNA expression in Disease correlated with improved outcome in Species Disease. In experiments using the B16 transplantable Species Disease, Disease-expressed Gene inhibited in vivo Disease growth without altering in vitro proliferation. Growth inhibition was associated with an altered profile of Disease-infiltrating cells with an increase in natural killer (NK) cells and a relative reduction in myeloid-derived suppressor cells and putative immune inhibitory plasmacytoid dendritic cells. Tumor inhibition required host expression of Gene (Gene), the chemoattractant receptor for Gene, and was abrogated by NK cell depletion. Intratumoral injection of Gene also inhibited Disease growth, suggesting the potential for therapeutic application. These results show that Gene, whether expressed by Disease cells or within the Disease environment, can recruit host immune defenses that inhibit tumorigenesis and suggest that down-regulation of Gene may be an important mechanism of Disease immune evasion.

24424049.pub_title: Gene is neither sufficient nor necessary for the physiological actions of Gene on Chemical homeostasis in male ob/ob Species.
24424049.pub_abstract: The ability of Gene to improve Disease, Disease, and even type 1 Disease is of significant interest. However, the mechanism by which Gene mediates these effects remains ill-defined. Gene was recently reported to regulate Gene (Gene), and adenoviral overexpression of pharmacological levels of Gene ameliorates Disease in many models of Disease. We sought to determine the role of physiological levels of Gene in the glucoregulatory action of Gene. To investigate whether physiological levels of Gene are sufficient to mimic the action of Gene, we treated male ob/ob Species with low-dose Gene adenovirus (Ad-Gene) or low-dose Gene. Despite similar levels of circulating Gene, Gene but not Ad-Gene lowered body weight and plasma insulin and improved Chemical and insulin tolerance. To elucidate the role of Gene in normal Chemical homeostasis, we knocked down Gene in male C57BL/6 Species using small interfering RNA to determine whether this would recapitulate any aspect of the ob/ob phenotype. Despite successful Gene knockdown, body weight, blood Chemical, and plasma insulin were unchanged. Finally, to determine whether Gene is required for the glucoregulatory actions of Gene, we prevented Gene-mediated increases in Gene in male ob/ob Species using RNA interference. Even though increases in Gene were blocked, the ability of Gene to decrease body weight, blood Chemical, and plasma insulin levels were unaltered. In conclusion, physiological levels of Gene are neither sufficient to mimic nor required for the physiological action of Gene.

22077064.pub_title: Transfusion in the absence of Disease induces antigen-specific tolerance to Species RBCs.
22077064.pub_abstract: Most Species transfusion recipients fail to make detectable alloantibodies to foreign RBC antigens ("nonresponders"). Herein, we use a Species model to test the hypothesis that nonresponders may be immunologically tolerant. FVB Species transfused with RBCs expressing transgenic Species Gene (Gene) antigen in the absence of Disease produced undetectable levels of anti-Gene immunoglobulins, unlike those transfused in the presence of Chemical-induced Disease. Species in the nonresponder group failed to produce anti-Gene after subsequent transfusions in the presence of Chemical:Chemical, whereas anti-Gene levels increased in the responder group. This tolerance was antigen specific, because nonresponders to Gene produced alloantibodies to RBCs that expressed a different transgenic antigen. This tolerance was not an idiosyncrasy of the Gene antigen nor of the recipient strain, because Gene.BR Species transfused with membrane-bound hen egg lysozyme antigen-transgenic RBCs also demonstrated induced nonresponsiveness. These data demonstrate that RBCs transfused in the absence of Disease can induce tolerance.

24324406.pub_title: Distinct roles of synaptic and extrasynaptic GABAAreceptors in striatal inhibition dynamics.
24324406.pub_abstract: Striatonigral and striatopallidal projecting medium spiny neurons (MSNs) express Chemical D1 (D1+) and D2 receptors (D2+), respectively.
