Collectively, these data reveal the multifaceted role of PRC2 in Disease, with divergent dose-dependent effects in Gene and distinct roles in maturing blood cells. Because PRC2 is a potential target for Disease therapy, the significant consequences of modest changes in PRC2 activity, as well as the cell and developmental stage-specific effects, will need to be carefully considered in any therapeutic context.

23728777.pub_title: Transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulation of Gene upon engagement of the BCR, TLRs and FcgammaR.
23728777.pub_abstract: Gene is a nuclear IkappaB protein robustly induced in macrophages and fibroblasts upon TLR or IL-1R stimulation. Gene associates with NF-kappaB in the cell nucleus and is essential for the induction of a subset of secondary response genes represented by Gene. Here, we analyzed induction of Gene in Species B cells and found that Gene is induced by BCR or TLR stimulation. Similar to TLR stimulation, BCR stimulation elicited NF-kappaB-mediated transcriptional activation and mRNA stabilization of Gene via a cis-element in Gene mRNA. Proteasome inhibitors inhibited transcriptional activation but not post-transcriptional activation, indicating independency of the two signals. Chemical-stimulation of the BCR and Gene or Gene, but not Gene, synergistically induced Gene. Chemical-engagement of inhibitory Fcgamma receptor suppressed BCR-mediated Gene expression but not that induced by TLR stimulation alone or co-stimulation of TLR and the BCR. The PI3K inhibitor Chemical inhibited BCR-mediated, but not TLR-mediated, induction of Gene, consistent with the role of PI3K in BCR signaling and its suppression by FcgammaR. Analysis of Gene-deficient B cells demonstrated that Gene was essential upon stimulation of BCR or TLR for the expression of several genes including Gene and Gene. Gene-deficient B cells exhibited impaired proliferation and enhanced up-regulation of CD86 following stimulation of Gene, but not the BCR, indicating critical roles for Gene in TLR signaling in B cells. Strict regulatory mechanisms for the induction of Gene via multiple pathways and its essential function upon stimulation indicate that Gene plays an important role in B cells.

23554486.pub_title: Gene protein and beta-amyloid oligomers promote neuronal differentiation of adult hippocampal neural progenitors via Gene/nuclear factor-kappaB axis: relevance for Disease.
23554486.pub_abstract: Dysregulated hippocampal neurogenesis has been associated with Disease, including Disease (Disease), in which it may potentially represent an auto-reparatory mechanism that could counteract Disease and Disease. We evaluated hippocampal neurogenesis in TgCRND8 Species and reported that, at 32 weeks of age, corresponding to an advanced Disease-like neuropathology stage, increased numbers of proliferating cells, doublecortin-expressing progenitors/neuroblasts, and early postmitotic calretinin-expressing neurons were present compared with wild-type (WT) littermates. When hippocampal neural progenitor cells (NPCs) were isolated from TgCRND8 Species, we demonstrated that (1) their neurogenic potential was higher compared with WT NPCs; (2) medium conditioned by TgCRND8 NPC promoted neuronal differentiation of WT NPCs; and (3) the proneurogenic effect of TgCRND8-conditioned medium was counteracted by blockade of the Gene (Gene)/nuclear factor-kappaB (NF-kappaB) axis. Furthermore, we showed that beta-amyloid 1-42 (Abeta(1-42)) oligomers, but not monomers and fibrils, and the alarmin Gene protein (Gene) could promote neuronal differentiation of NPCs via activation of the Gene/NF-kappaB axis. Altogether, these data suggest that, in Disease brain, an endogenous proneurogenic response could be potentially triggered and involve signals (Abeta(1-42) oligomers and Gene) and pathways (Gene/NF-kappaB activation) that also contribute to Disease. A more detailed analysis confirmed no significant increase of new mature neurons in hippocampi of TgCRND8 compared with WT Species, suggesting reduced survival and/or integration of newborn neurons. Therapeutic strategies in Disease should ideally combine the ability of sustaining hippocampal neurogenesis as well as of counteracting an hostile brain microenvironment so to promote survival of vulnerable cell populations, including adult generated neurons.

24301657.pub_title: Gene modulates DSS-induced Disease through a macrophage-ROS-NO axis.
24301657.pub_abstract: Breakdown of the epithelial barrier because of toxins or other insults leads to severe Disease. Gene (Gene) is a critical regulator of this, yet its cellular targets and mechanisms of action are not resolved. We address this here. Species with a macrophage-selective deletion of Gene (Gene(Mdel)) developed markedly enhanced dextran Chemical (DSS)-induced Disease that did not significantly differ from disease in Gene(-/-) or Gene(-/-) Species; no impact of Disease in other lineages was observed. Gene(Mdel) Disease was associated with increased mucosal barrier disruption in the setting of intact epithelial regeneration. Lamina propria macrophages (LPMphis) did not show numerical or phenotypic differences from controls, or a competitive advantage over wild-type cells. Proinflammatory cytokine production, and particularly Gene (Gene), was increased, although Gene neutralization failed to reveal a defining role for this cytokine in the aggravated disease. Rather, Gene(Mdel) LPMphis produced substantially greater levels of Chemical (NO) and reactive Chemical species (ROS) than controls. Inhibition of these had modest effects in wild-type Species, although they dramatically reduced Disease severity in Gene(Mdel) Species, and largely eliminated the differential effect of DSS in them. Therefore, the palliative actions of Gene in DSS-induced Disease predominantly results from its macrophage-specific effects. Downregulation of NO and ROS production are central to the protective actions of Gene.

23443342.pub_title: Initially disadvantaged, Gene-Gene cells expand and initiate Disease in response to irradiation and cooperating mutations.

24066808.pub_title: Gene-mediated Gene activation confers protection against Disease.
24066808.pub_abstract: Supplemental Chemical is frequently used in an attempt to improve Chemical delivery; however, prolonged exposure results in damage to the pulmonary endothelium and epithelium. Although Gene has been identified as a redox-responsive transcription factor, whether Gene activation exacerbates or attenuates Disease is unclear. We determined that sustained Gene activity mediated by Disease and prevents mortality in adult Species exposed to greater than 95% Chemical. Adult wild-type Species demonstrated evidence of Disease and 100% mortality by 6 days of hyperoxic exposure, and showed Gene nuclear translocation that terminated after 48 hours. Furthermore, these Species showed increased expression of Gene-regulated proinflammatory and proapoptotic cytokines. In contrast, Species overexpressing the Gene inhibitory protein, Gene (AKBI), demonstrated significant resistance to Disease, with 50% surviving through 8 days of exposure. This was associated with Gene nuclear translocation that persisted through 96 hours of exposure. Although induction of Gene-regulated proinflammatory cytokines was not different between wild-type and AKBI Species, significant up-regulation of antiapoptotic proteins (Gene, Gene) was found exclusively in AKBI Species. We conclude that sustained Gene activity mediated by Gene protects against Disease through increased expression of antiapoptotic genes.

24824219.pub_title: Disease with subcortical cysts protein 1 regulates glial surface localization of Gene from fish to Species.
24824219.pub_abstract: Disease with subcortical cysts (Gene) is a Disease characterized by myelin vacuolization and caused by mutations in Gene or Gene. Species with recessive mutations in either Gene or Gene show the same clinical phenotype. It has been shown that Gene is necessary for the correct targeting of Gene to the membrane at cell junctions, but its own localization was independent of Gene in vitro. However, recent studies in Gene(-/-) Species have shown that Gene is mislocalized in glial cells. In order to investigate whether the relationship between Gene and Gene is species-specific, we first identified Gene-related genes in Species and generated an Gene(-/-) Species. We have characterized Gene(-/-) Species both functionally and histologically and compared the phenotype with that of the Gene(-/-) Species. In Gene(-/-) Species, as in Gene(-/-) Species, Gene is mislocalized. Chemical-examination of a brain biopsy from an Gene Species indicates that Gene is also mislocalized in Disease in the cerebellum. In vitro, impaired localization of Gene was observed in astrocyte cultures from Gene(-/-) Species only in the presence of elevated Chemical levels, which mimics neuronal activity. In summary, here we demonstrate an evolutionary conserved role for Gene in regulating glial surface levels of Gene, and this interrelationship explains why Species with mutations in either gene (Gene or Gene) share the same clinical phenotype.

26486174.pub_title: Abnormal mechanosensing and cofilin activation promote the progression of ascending Disease in Species.
26486174.pub_abstract: Smooth muscle cells (SMCs) and the extracellular matrix (ECM) are intimately associated in the aortic wall. Gene(SMKO) Species with an SMC-specific deletion of the Gene gene, which encodes the vascular ECM component Gene, develop ascending Disease that have increased abundance of Gene (Gene); inhibiting angiotensin II signaling within the first month of life prevents Disease development. We used comparative proteomics analysis of Gene(SMKO) aortas from postnatal day (P) 1 to Gene Species to identify key molecules involved in Disease and expansion. At Gene, the actin depolymerizing factor cofilin was dephosphorylated and thus activated, and at P7, the abundance of Gene (Gene) phosphatase, an activator of cofilin, was increased, leading to actin cytoskeletal remodeling. Also, by P7, biomechanical changes and underdeveloped elastic lamina-SMC connections were evident, and the abundance of early growth response 1 (Gene), a mechanosensitive transcription factor that stimulates Gene expression, was increased, which was before the increases in Gene abundance and cofilin activation. Postnatal deletion of Gene in SMCs at P7 prevented cofilin activation and Disease formation, suggesting that these processes required disruption of elastic lamina-SMC connections. Phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) is involved in the angiotensin II-mediated activation of Gene, and administration of PI3K inhibitors from P7 to Gene decreased Gene abundance and prevented Disease. These results suggest that Disease formation arises from abnormal mechanosensing of SMCs resulting from the loss of elastic lamina-SMC connections and from increased Gene and cofilin activity, which may be potential therapeutic targets for treating ascending Disease.

23772027.pub_title: Critical role of dendritic cells in T cell retention in the interfollicular region of Peyer's patches.
23772027.pub_abstract: Peyer's patches (PPs) simultaneously initiate active and quiescent immune responses in the gut. The immunological function is achieved by the rigid regulation of cell distribution and trafficking, but how the cell distribution is maintained remains to be elucidated. In this study, we show that binding of stromal cell-derived lymphoid chemokines to conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) is essential for the retention of naive CD4(+) T cells in the interfollicular region (IFR) of PPs. Transitory depletion of Gene(high) cDCs in Species rapidly impaired the IFR structure in the PPs without affecting B cell follicles or germinal centers, lymphoid chemokine production from stromal cells, or the immigration of naive T cells into the IFRs of PPs. The cDC-orchestrated retention of naive T cells was mediated by heparinase-sensitive molecules that were expressed on cDCs and bound the lymphoid chemokine CCL21 produced from stromal cells. These data collectively reveal that interactions among cDCs, stromal cells, and naive T cells are necessary for the formation of IFRs in the PPs.

24150244.pub_title: Gene plays protective roles in ConA-induced Disease by both suppressing Gene expression and inducing Gene.
24150244.pub_abstract: The Gene (Gene), a ligand-activated nuclear transcription factor, is known to mediate the toxic and Disease effects of various environmental pollutants, while Gene has been shown to protect animals from various types of Disease. ConA-induced Disease is known as a Species model of Disease. Here, we found a protective role of Gene in ConA-induced Disease. Gene is induced in the liver during ConA-induced Disease, and Gene (-/-) Species were highly sensitive to this model. Bone marrow chimera experiments indicate that Gene (-/-) hematopoietic cells are responsible for Disease to ConA-induced Disease. We found that Gene from invariant NKT cells was up-regulated and Gene from innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) was abolished in Gene (-/-) Species. In addition, Gene production was still observed in Gene (-/-) Species but it was severely reduced in Gene (-/-) Gene (-/-) Species. ConA-induced Gene production was also dependent on Chemical-related orphan receptor gammat. These results show that Gene has crucial protective roles in ConA-induced Disease via promoting Gene production from ILCs and suppressing Gene expression from NKT cells.

24567369.pub_title: The Gene 3' wnt-responsive element suppresses colonic tumorigenesis.
24567369.pub_abstract: Mutations in components of the Wnt/Gene signaling pathway are commonly found in Disease, and these mutations cause aberrant expression of genes controlled by Wnt-responsive DNA elements (WREs). While the Gene (Gene) is required for intestinal phenotypes associated with pathogenic Wnt/Gene signaling in vivo, the WREs that control Gene expression in this setting have yet to be fully described. Previously, we demonstrated that the Gene 3' WRE was required for intestinal homeostasis and intestinal repair in response to damage. Here, we tested the role of the Gene 3' WRE in intestinal tumorigenesis using two independent Species models. In comparison to Apc(Min/+) Species, Apc(Min/+) Gene 3' WRE(-/-) Species contained 25% fewer Disease in the small intestine. Deletion of the Gene 3' WRE(-/-) in the Apc(Min/+) background resulted in 4-fold more Disease. In a model of Disease, the Gene 3' WRE suppressed colonic tumorigenesis, most notably within the cecum. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and transcript analysis of purified colonic crypts, we found that the Gene 3' WRE is required for the transcriptional regulation of Gene expression in vivo. These results emphasize the critical role of the Gene 3' WRE in maintaining homeostatic Gene expression.

26290230.pub_title: Ubiquitin-Synaptobrevin Fusion Protein Causes Degeneration of Presynaptic Motor Terminals in Species.
26290230.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: Protein aggregates containing ubiquitin (Ub) are commonly observed in Disease, implicating the involvement of the ubiquitin proteasome system (Disease) in their pathogenesis. Here, we aimed to generate a Species model for monitoring Disease function using a green fluorescent protein (GFP)-based substrate that carries a "noncleavable" Chemical-terminal ubiquitin moiety (Ub(Protein Mutation)). We engineered Species expressing a fusion protein, consisting of the following: (1) Ub(Protein Mutation), GFP, and a synaptic vesicle protein Gene (Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene); (2) GFP-Gene; or (3) Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Syntaxin1, all under the control of a neuron-specific Gene promoter. As expected, Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene, GFP-Gene, and Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Sytaxin1 were highly expressed in neurons, such as motoneurons and motor nerve terminals of the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). Surprisingly, Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene Species developed progressive adult-onset Disease terminals, whereas GFP-Gene and Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Syntaxin1 Species were normal. The degeneration of nerve terminals in Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene Species was preceded by a progressive impairment of synaptic transmission at the NMJs. Biochemical analyses demonstrated that Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene interacted with Gene and Syntaxin1, the SNARE partners of synaptobrevin. Ultrastructural analyses revealed a marked reduction in synaptic vesicle density, accompanying an accumulation of tubulovesicular structures at presynaptic nerve terminals. These morphological defects were largely restricted to motor nerve terminals, as the ultrastructure of motoneuron somata appeared to be normal at the stages when synaptic nerve terminals degenerated. Furthermore, synaptic vesicle endocytosis and membrane trafficking were impaired in Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene Species. These findings indicate that Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene may compete with endogenous synaptobrevin, acting as a gain-of-function mutation that impedes SNARE function, resulting in the depletion of synaptic vesicles and Disease terminals. SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT: Degeneration of motor nerve terminals occurs in Disease (Disease) Species as well as in Species models of Disease, leading to progressive Disease. What causes a motor nerve terminal to degenerate remains unknown. Here we report on Species expressing a ubiquitinated synaptic vesicle protein (Ub(Protein Mutation)-GFP-Gene) that develop progressive Disease terminals. These Species may serve as a model for further elucidating the underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms of presynaptic Disease.

25253849.pub_title: Optogenetic activation of cajal-retzius cells reveals their glutamatergic output and a novel feedforward circuit in the developing Species hippocampus.
25253849.pub_abstract: Cajal-Retzius cells orchestrate the development of cortical circuits by secreting the glycoprotein reelin. However, their computational functions are still unknown. In fact, the nature of their postsynaptic targets, major neurotransmitter released, as well as the class of postsynaptic receptors activated by their firing remain unclear. Here, we have addressed these questions by activating Cajal-Retzius cells optogenetically in Species hippocampal slices. Light delivered to stratum lacunosum-moleculare triggered EPSCs both on local interneurons and on pyramidal cells. Responses recorded under voltage-clamp conditions had identical short latencies and similar amplitudes, but were kinetically different (i.e., faster in interneurons vs pyramidal cells). In both cases, responses were blocked by Chemical, indicating that they were generated by action potential-dependent release. Responses in interneurons were rescued by the addition of 4-AP to Chemical, and decreased when presynaptic firing in Cajal-Retzius cells was reduced by the chemokine Gene, indicating the existence of a direct Cajal-Retzius cell-interneuron monosynaptic connection. Although the combined application of 4-AP and Chemical did not rescue responses in pyramidal cells, neither were they affected by the GABAA receptor blocker Chemical, which would be expected if they were polysynaptic. Both connections showed physiological and pharmacological properties indicating the involvement of Chemical- and Chemical-type Chemical receptors. The connectivity from presynaptic Cajal-Retzius cells to interneurons was strong enough to generate long-latency feedforward GABAergic input onto pyramidal cells. We propose that this newly defined Cajal-Retzius cell-dependent microcircuit may regulate synaptic plasticity and dendritic development in stratum lacunosum-moleculare, thus impacting the integrative properties of the developing hippocampus.

26980188.pub_title: Disease and DNA damage-induced Disease in Gene nuclease-defective knock-in Species.
26980188.pub_abstract: The Gene endonuclease is required for repair of DNA interstrand cross-links (ICLs). Mutations in Species Gene cause karyomegalic Disease (KIN), but it is unclear whether defective ICL repair is responsible or whether Gene nuclease activity is relevant. We show that Gene nuclease-defective (Gene(nd/nd)) Species develop a mild form of KIN. The karyomegalic nuclei from Gene(nd/nd) kidneys are polyploid, and fibroblasts from Gene(nd/nd) Species become polyploid upon ICL induction, suggesting that defective ICL repair causes karyomegaly. Thus, Gene nuclease activity promotes ICL repair in a manner that controls ploidy, a role that we show is not shared by the Disease pathway or the Gene-Slx1 nuclease also involved in ICL repair.

23475183.pub_title: Secondary T cell-T cell synaptic interactions drive the differentiation of protective Gene+ T cells.
23475183.pub_abstract: Immunization results in the differentiation of Gene+ T cells, such that they acquire effector abilities and convert into a memory pool. Priming of T cells takes place via an immunological synapse formed with an antigen-presenting cell (Disease). By disrupting synaptic stability at different times, we found that the differentiation of Gene+ T cells required cell interactions beyond those made with Gene. We identified a critical differentiation period that required interactions between primed T cells. We found that T cell-T cell synapses had a major role in the generation of protective Gene+ T cell memory. T cell-T cell synapses allowed T cells to polarize critical secretion of Gene (Gene) toward each other. Collective activation and homotypic clustering drove cytokine sharing and acted as regulatory stimuli for T cell differentiation.

27090359.pub_title: Brief Report: Alternative Splicing of Extra Domain A (EIIIA) of Gene Plays a Tissue-Specific Role in Hematopoietic Homeostasis.
27090359.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a major extracellular matrix protein implicated in cell adhesion and differentiation in the bone marrow (BM) environment. Alternative splicing of Gene gene results in the generation of protein variants containing an additional EIIIA domain that sustains cell proliferation or differentiation during physiological or pathological tissue remodeling. To date its expression and role in adult hematopoiesis has not been explored. In our research, we demonstrate that during physiological hematopoiesis a small fraction of BM derived Gene contains the EIIIA domain and that Species constitutively including (EIIIA(+/+) ) or excluding (EIIIA(-/-) ) the EIIIA exon present comparable levels of hematopoietic stem cells, myeloid and lymphoid progenitors within BM. Moreover, only minor alterations were detected in blood parameters and in hematopoietic frequencies of BM granulocytes/monocytes and B cells. As opposed to other tissues, unique compensatory mechanisms, such as increased Gene accumulation and variable expression of the EIIIA receptors, Toll like receptor-4 and alpha9 integrin subunit, characterized the BM of these Species. Our data demonstrate that Gene is a fundamental component of the hematopoietic tissue and that the EIIIA exon may play a key role in modulating hematopiesis in conditions of BM stress or diseases. Stem Cells 2016;34:2263-2268.

26834238.pub_title: Gene controls autophagy by integrating AMPK signaling to enhance Gene-associated PI3K activity.
26834238.pub_abstract: The Gene-Gene complex is recognized as a central node in regulating autophagy via interacting with diverse molecules such as Gene for autophagy initiation and UVRAG for autophagosome maturation. However, the underlying molecular mechanism that coordinates the timely activation of Gene complex is poorly understood. Here, we identify that Gene governs the preferential formation and activation of Gene-linked Gene complex for autophagy initiation via two levels of regulation. Firstly, Gene functions as a scaffold protein that facilitates the formation of Gene- but not UVRAG-linked Gene complex, leading to elevated capacity of PI(3)P generation ahead of starvation signals. Secondly, AMPK phosphorylates Gene at Chemical 32 and switches on PI(3)P production to initiate autophagosome formation swiftly after Chemical starvation. Deletion of Gene leads to reduction of exercise-induced autophagy in Species, accompanied by a certain degree of disaggregation of Gene-associated Gene complex. Together, this study uncovers that Gene can not only enhance the capacity of pro-autophagy class III PI3K due to its scaffold function, but also integrate AMPK signal to activation of Gene-linked Gene complex upon Chemical starvation.

23313488.pub_title: Gene is required for cranial neural crest-derived craniofacial bone formation.
23313488.pub_abstract: Gene plays essential roles in regulating osteoblast and chondrocyte differentiation, and bone formation during Species skeletal development. However, many questions remain regarding the requirement for Gene in different cell lineages. In this study, we asked whether Gene is required for craniofacial bone formation derived from cranial neural crest (CNC) cells. The Gene gene was conditionally inactivated in CNC-derived cells using a Gene-Cre recombination system. Neural crest-specific inactivation of Gene resulted in the complete absence of intramembranous skeletal elements derived from the CNC, and CNC-derived endochondral skeletal elements were also affected by Gene inactivation. Interestingly, Gene inactivated CNC-derived cells, which were recapitulated by lacZ expression, occupied the same regions of craniofacial skeletal elements as observed for controls. However, cells lost their osteogenic ability to differentiate into functional osteoblasts by Gene inactivation. These results suggest that Gene is important for craniofacial bone formation by CNC-derived cells. This finding provides novel insights of the regulation of craniofacial development by the gene network and transcription factors, and the understanding of Species diseases caused by Disease.

24270572.pub_title: Gene inhibits genotoxic Gene activation by Gene-facilitated deubiquitination of Gene.
24270572.pub_abstract: DNA damage-induced activation of the transcription factor Gene plays an important role in the cellular response to genotoxic stress. However, uncontrolled Gene activation upon DNA damage may lead to deleterious consequences. Although the mechanisms mediating genotoxic Gene activation have been elucidated, how this signalling is terminated remains poorly understood. Here, we show that the CCCH-type zinc finger-containing protein Gene (Gene; also known as Gene) is induced upon genotoxic treatment in an Gene-dependent manner. Gene upregulation reduces Gene linear ubiquitylation, resulting in decreased activation of IKK and Gene. Gene ubiquitylation is decreased through the deubiquitinase Gene, which interacts with Gene via Gene upon genotoxic stress. Gene association with Gene leads to removal of Gene-attached linear polyubiquitin chains and subsequent inhibition of the genotoxic Gene signalling cascade. Consistently, Gene is required for Gene-mediated inhibition of genotoxic Gene activation and promotion of apoptosis. Thus, by mediating Gene-dependent deubiquitination of Gene, Gene induction serves as a negative feedback mechanism for attenuating genotoxic Gene activation.

24743339.pub_title: Species triggers type I IFN production in Species conventional dendritic cells via a Gene/STING-mediated cytosolic DNA-sensing pathway.
24743339.pub_abstract: Species (Species) is an attenuated poxvirus that has been engineered as a vaccine against infectious agents and Disease. Our goal is to understand how Species modulates innate immunity in dendritic cells (DCs), which can provide insights to vaccine design. In this study, using Species bone marrow-derived dendritic cells, we assessed type I interferon (IFN) gene induction and protein secretion in response to Disease. We report that Disease the production of type I IFN in Species conventional dendritic cells (cDCs), but not in plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs). Transcription factors Gene (IFN regulatory factor 3) and IRF7, and the positive feedback loop mediated by IFNAR1 (IFN alpha/beta receptor 1), are required for the induction. Species induction of type I IFN is fully dependent on STING (stimulator of IFN genes) and the newly discovered cytosolic DNA sensor Gene (Chemical synthase). Disease triggers phosphorylation of TBK1 (Tank-binding kinase 1) and Gene, which is abolished in the absence of Gene and STING. Furthermore, intravenous delivery of Species induces type I IFN in wild-type Species, but not in Species lacking STING or Gene. Treatment of cDCs with inhibitors of endosomal and lysosomal acidification or the lysosomal enzyme Cathepsin B attenuated Species-induced type I IFN production, indicating that lysosomal enzymatic processing of virions is important for Species sensing. Taken together, our results demonstrate a critical role of the Gene/STING-mediated cytosolic DNA-sensing pathway for type I IFN induction in cDCs by Species. We present evidence that vaccinia virulence factors E3 and N1 inhibit the activation of Gene and the induction of IFNB gene in Disease.

24167582.pub_title: Heat Disease attenuates overloading-associated Disease of Species soleus muscle.
24167582.pub_abstract: Disease stimuli, such as mechanical stress and overloading, induce stress response, which is mediated by Gene (Gene), and up-regulate heat shock proteins (HSPs) in Species skeletal muscles. Therefore, Gene-associated stress response may play a key role in loading-associated skeletal Disease. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effects of Disease caused by overloading. Functional overloading on the left soleus was performed by cutting the distal tendons of gastrocnemius and plantaris muscles for 4 weeks. The right muscle served as the control. Soleus muscles from both hindlimbs were dissected 2 and 4 weeks after the operation. Disease of soleus muscle in Gene-null Species was partially inhibited, compared with that in wild-type (C57BL/6J) Species. Absence of Gene partially attenuated the increase of muscle wet weight and fiber cross-sectional area of overloaded soleus muscle. Population of Gene-positive muscle satellite cells in Gene-null Species was significantly less than that in wild-type Species following 2 weeks of overloading (p<0.05). Significant up-regulations of Gene and Disease Disease factor mRNAs were observed in Gene-null, but not in wild-type, Species following 2 weeks of overloading. Overloading-related increases of Gene and AFT3 mRNA expressions seen after 2 weeks of overloading tended to decrease after 4 weeks in both types of Species. In Gene-null Species, however, the significant overloading-related increase in the expression of Gene, not Gene, mRNA was noted even at 4th week. Inhibition of Disease might be attributed to the greater and prolonged enhancement of Gene expression. Gene and/or Gene-mediated stress response may, in part, play a key role in loading-induced Disease.

25994353.pub_title: A quantitative microscopic approach to predict local recurrence based on in vivo intraoperative imaging of Disease margins.
25994353.pub_abstract: The goal of resection of soft tissue Disease located in the extremity is to preserve limb function while completely excising the Disease with a margin of normal tissue. With surgery alone, one-third of Species with soft tissue Disease of the extremity will have local recurrence due to microscopic residual disease in the Disease bed. Currently, a limited number of intraoperative pathology-based techniques are used to assess margin status; however, few have been widely adopted due to sampling error and time constraints. To aid in intraoperative diagnosis, we developed a quantitative optical microscopy toolbox, which includes Chemical staining, fluorescence microscopy, and analytic techniques called sparse component analysis and circle transform to yield quantitative diagnosis of Disease margins. A series of variables were quantified from images of resected primary Disease and used to optimize a multivariate model. The sensitivity and specificity for differentiating positive from negative ex vivo resected Disease margins was 82 and 75%. The utility of this approach was tested by imaging the in vivo Disease cavities from 34 Species after resection of a Disease with local recurrence as a bench mark. When applied prospectively to images from the Disease cavity, the sensitivity and specificity for differentiating local recurrence was 78 and 82%. For comparison, if pathology was used to predict local recurrence in this data set, it would achieve a sensitivity of 29% and a specificity of 71%. These results indicate a robust approach for detecting microscopic residual disease, which is an effective predictor of local recurrence.

22920255.pub_title: Gene reprograms Schwann cells of injured nerves to generate a repair cell essential for regeneration.
22920255.pub_abstract: The radical response of peripheral nerves to injury (Disease) is the Chemical of nerve repair. We show that activation of the transcription factor Gene in Schwann cells is a global regulator of Disease. Gene governs major aspects of the injury response, determines the expression of trophic factors, adhesion molecules, the formation of regeneration tracks and myelin clearance and controls the distinctive regenerative potential of peripheral nerves. A key function of Gene is the activation of a repair program in Schwann cells and the creation of a cell specialized to support regeneration. We show that absence of Gene results in the formation of a dysfunctional repair cell, striking failure of functional recovery, and Disease. We conclude that a single glial transcription factor is essential for restoration of damaged nerves, acting to control the transdifferentiation of myelin and Remak Schwann cells to dedicated repair cells in damaged tissue.

23169653.pub_title: Conditionally reprogrammed cells represent a stem-like state of adult epithelial cells.
23169653.pub_abstract: The combination of irradiated fibroblast feeder cells and Rho kinase inhibitor, Chemical, conditionally induces an indefinite proliferative state in primary Species epithelial cells. These conditionally reprogrammed cells (CRCs) are karyotype-stable and nontumorigenic. Because self-renewal is a recognized property of stem cells, we investigated whether Chemical and feeder cells induced a stem-like phenotype. We found that CRCs share characteristics of adult stem cells and exhibit up-regulated expression of Gene, Gene, and telomerase reverse transcriptase, as well as decreased Notch signaling and an increased level of nuclear Gene. The induction of CRCs is rapid (occurs within 2 d) and results from reprogramming of the entire cell population rather than the selection of a minor subpopulation. CRCs do not overexpress the transcription factor sets characteristic of Disease or induced pluripotent stem cells (e.g., Gene, Gene, Gene, or Gene). The induction of CRCs is also reversible, and removal of Chemical and feeders allows the cells to differentiate normally. Thus, when CRCs from ectocervical epithelium or tracheal epithelium are placed in an air-liquid interface culture system, the cervical cells form a well differentiated stratified squamous epithelium, whereas the tracheal cells form a ciliated airway epithelium. We discuss the diagnostic and therapeutic opportunities afforded by a method that can generate adult stem-like cells in vitro without genetic manipulation.

27455110.pub_title: The coding of cutaneous temperature in the spinal cord.
27455110.pub_abstract: The spinal cord is the initial stage that integrates temperature information from peripheral inputs. Here we used molecular genetics and in vivo Chemical imaging to investigate the coding of cutaneous temperature in the spinal cord in Species. We found that heating or cooling the skin evoked robust Chemical responses in spinal neurons, and their activation threshold temperatures distributed smoothly over the entire range of stimulation temperatures. Once activated, heat-responding neurons encoded the absolute skin temperature without adaptation and received major inputs from transient receptor potential (TRP) channel V1 (Gene)-positive dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons. By contrast, cold-responding neurons rapidly adapted to ambient temperature and selectively encoded temperature changes. These neurons received Gene (Gene)-positive DRG inputs as well as novel Gene(+) DRG inputs that were selectively activated by intense cooling. Our results provide a comprehensive examination of the temperature representation in the spinal cord and reveal fundamental differences in the coding of heat and cold.

23931754.pub_title: Gene regulates Gene-dependent Chemical efflux from macrophages and the development of Disease.
23931754.pub_abstract: Gene is involved in the transport of Chemical in skin, but it may play a wider role in lipid metabolism. We show that, in Gene-deficient macrophages, Chemical efflux failed to respond to activation with Gene agonists. Gene deficiency caused a reduction in the abundance of Gene, Gene, and Gene. Overexpression of Gene reversed the effects. Mechanistically, Gene deficiency did not affect expression of genes involved in Chemical metabolism. Instead, a physical association between Gene, Gene, and Gene proteins was established. Gene deficiency enhanced interaction between Gene and Gene and the degradation of Gene. Overexpression of Gene in HeLa-Gene cells increased the abundance and stability of Gene. Gene deficiency caused an accumulation of Chemical in macrophages and the formation of foam cells, impaired reverse Chemical transport in vivo, and increased the development of Disease in irradiated Gene(-/-) Species reconstituted with Gene(-/-)Gene(-/-) bone marrow. Thus, Gene regulates the cellular Chemical metabolism via an Gene-dependent posttranscriptional mechanism.

24158093.pub_title: An intact immune system is required for the anticancer activities of histone deacetylase inhibitors.
24158093.pub_abstract: Cell-intrinsic effects such as induction of apoptosis and/or inhibition of cell proliferation have been proposed as the major antitumor responses to histone deacetylase inhibitors (HDACi). These compounds can also mediate immune-modulatory effects that may contribute to their anticancer effects. However, HDACi can also induce anti-inflammatory, and potentially immunosuppressive, outcomes. We therefore sought to clarify the role of the immune system in mediating the efficacy of HDACi in a physiologic setting, using preclinical, syngeneic Species models of Disease and Disease. We showed an intact immune system was required for the robust anticancer effects of the HDACi Chemical and panobinostat against a Disease and two aggressive models of Disease. Importantly, although HDACi-treated immunocompromised Species bearing established Disease succumbed to disease significantly earlier than Disease bearing, HDACi-treated wild-type (WT) Species, treatment with the conventional chemotherapeutic Chemical equivalently enhanced the survival of both strains. Gene and Disease cell signaling through Gene were particularly important for the anticancer effects of HDACi, and Chemical and Gene acted in concert to enhance the immunogenicity of Disease cells. Furthermore, we show that a combination of Chemical with Chemical (alpha-GalCer), an Gene-inducing agent, was significantly more potent against established Disease than Chemical treatment alone. Intriguingly, B cells, but not natural killer cells or CD8(+) T cells, were implicated as effectors of the Chemical antitumor immune response. Together, our data suggest HDACi are immunostimulatory during Disease treatment and that combinatorial therapeutic regimes with immunotherapies should be considered in the clinic.

26342068.pub_title: Induction of Gene limits survival following infarct-induced Disease in Species.
26342068.pub_abstract: Numerous fibrotic and inflammatory changes occur in the failing heart. Recent evidence indicates that certain transcription factors, such as Gene (Gene), are activated during Disease. Because Gene may be upregulated in the failing heart and affect Disease, we focused on the potential role of Gene on Disease. We subjected anesthetized, wild-type Species to nonreperfused Disease and observed a significant induction in Gene expression and nuclear translocation. To test whether the induction of Gene affected the severity of Disease, we subjected wild-type and Gene-null Species to nonreperfused Disease. There were no differences in cardiac function between the two genotypes, except at the 2-wk time point; however, Gene-null Species survived the Disease protocol at a significantly higher rate than the wild-type Species. Similar to the slight favorable improvements in chamber dimensions at 2 wk, we also observed greater Disease and more Disease in the noninfarcted regions of the Gene-null hearts compared with the wild-type. Nevertheless, there were no significant group differences at 4 wk. Furthermore, we found no significant differences in markers of Disease between the wild-type and Gene-null hearts. Our data suggest that Gene suppresses Disease early but not late during Disease. Although Gene Disease was associated with more Disease, this did not occur at the expense of survival, which was higher in the Gene-null Species. Overall, Gene may serve a largely maladaptive role during Disease.

23747247.pub_abstract: Diet, host gene composition, and alterations in the intestinal microbiota can contribute to Disease. In microbe-induced Disease, metabolic changes stem from primary perturbation of the microbiota, consequent to modern changes in Species biology. Microbiota disruption during early development can result in syndromes of Disease. We focus on the pathways involved in these interactions, particularly related to energy extraction and the role of Disease in the metabolic phenotypes. Model physiologic systems and perturbations including gastric bypass surgery, pregnancy, and hibernation provide insight into the respective roles of the critical Species.

26067272.pub_title: Systemic RNA Interference Disease Selectively Binds Long Double-stranded RNA and Is Required for RNA Transport by Gene.
26067272.pub_abstract: During systemic RNA interference (RNAi) in Species, RNA spreads across different cells and tissues in a process that requires the Gene (Gene) gene, which encodes an integral membrane protein. Gene acts cell-autonomously and is required for cellular import of interfering RNAs. Heterologous expression of Gene in Disease 2 cells enables passive uptake of dsRNA and subsequent soaking RNAi. Previous studies have suggested that Gene may serve as an RNA channel, but its precise molecular role remains unclear. To test the hypothesis that Gene mediates a direct biochemical recognition of RNA molecule and subsequent permeation, we expressed the extracellular domain (ECD) of Gene and purified it to near homogeneity. Recombinant purified Gene ECD selectively binds dsRNA but not dsDNA in a length-dependent and sequence-independent manner. Genetic missense mutations in Gene ECD causal for deficient systemic RNAi resulted in significant reduction in its affinity for dsRNA. Furthermore, full-length proteins with these mutations decrease Gene-mediated RNA transport efficiency, providing evidence that dsRNA binding to Gene ECD is related to RNA transport. To examine the functional similarity of Species homologs of Gene (Gene and Gene), we expressed and purified Species Gene and Gene ECDs. We show that they bind long dsRNA in vitro, supportive of dsRNA recognition. In summary, our study illustrates the functional importance of Gene ECD as a dsRNA binding domain that contributes to RNA transport.

25391241.pub_title: Chemical is effective therapy for metastatic Gene Disease.
25391241.pub_abstract: Disease is the most common Disease, with Disease present at diagnosis conferring a poor prognosis. Mechanisms of dissemination are poorly understood and metastatic lesions are genetically divergent from the matched primary Disease. Effective and less toxic therapies that target both compartments have yet to be identified. Here, we report that the analysis of several large nonoverlapping cohorts of Species with Disease reveals MET kinase as a marker of Gene (Gene)-driven Disease. Immunohistochemical analysis of phosphorylated, active MET kinase in an independent Species cohort confirmed its correlation with increased Disease relapse and poor survival, suggesting that Species with Disease may benefit from MET-targeted therapy. In support of this hypothesis, we found that the approved MET inhibitor Chemical could suppress MET activation, decrease Disease cell proliferation, and induce apoptosis in Disease in vitro and in vivo. Chemical penetrated the blood-brain barrier and was effective in both the primary and metastatic Disease compartments. In established Species xenograft or transgenic models of metastatic Disease, Chemical administration reduced the growth of the primary Disease, decreased the incidence of Disease, and increased host survival. Taken together, our results provide a strong rationale to clinically evaluate Chemical as an effective therapy for Species with Gene-driven Disease.

23572516.pub_title: Gene is required for BBSome formation and its absence in Species results in Disease phenotypes and selective abnormalities in membrane protein trafficking.
23572516.pub_abstract: Bardet-Biedl Syndrome (BBS) is a pleiotropic and genetically heterozygous disorder caused independently by numerous genes (Gene-BBS17). Seven highly conserved BBS proteins (Gene) form a complex known as the BBSome, which functions in ciliary membrane biogenesis. Gene is both a unique subunit of the BBSome and displays direct physical interaction with a second BBS complex, the BBS chaperonin complex. To examine the in vivo function of Gene, we generated Gene knockout Species. Gene(-/-) Species show similar phenotypes to other BBS gene mutant Species including Disease, Disease, Disease and Disease characterized by Disease. Using tissues from Gene(-/-) Species, we show that Gene is required for BBSome formation, and that Gene and Gene depend on each other for protein stability. Although the BBSome serves as a coat complex for ciliary membrane proteins, Gene is not required for the localization of ciliary membrane proteins Gene, Gene, or bitter taste receptors, but absence of Gene leads to abnormal accumulation of the Gene to the ciliary membrane, indicating that Gene is involved in specific membrane protein localization to cilia.

24730055.pub_title: Chronic Chemical treatment rescues Disease-related, social and Disease in Gene knockout Species.
24730055.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is a homeobox transcription factor that regulates neurodevelopmental processes including neuronal connectivity and elaboration of monoaminergic neurons in the ventral hindbrain. We previously reported abnormalities in brain noradrenergic concentrations in Gene null mutant Species that were accompanied by increased immobility in the forced swim test, relevant to Disease. An Gene genetic polymorphism has been associated with Disease, and Species with a deletion in Gene display Disease that may be relevant to multiple neuropsychiatric conditions. This study evaluated the ability of chronic treatment with Chemical (Chemical), a selective Chemical (NE) reuptake inhibitor and classical antidepressant, to reverse Disease in Gene-/- Species. Chemical treatment significantly reduced immobility in the tail suspension and forced swim tests, restored sociability in the three-chambered social approach task and reversed impairments in contextual fear conditioning in Gene-/- Species. Our findings indicate that modulation of brain noradrenergic systems rescues the Disease-related phenotype in Gene-/- Species and suggest new roles for NE in the pathophysiology of the social and Disease seen in Disease such as Disease or Disease.

26976635.pub_title: Differential Involvement of the Gene Zinc Finger Domains of Gene and Gene in Linear Ubiquitin Chain Assembly Complex-Mediated Cell Death Protection.
26976635.pub_abstract: The linear ubiquitin chain assembly complex (LUBAC) participates in NF-kappaB activation and cell death protection. Loss of any of the three LUBAC subunits (catalytic Gene, accessory Gene, or accessory Gene subunit) leads to distinct phenotypes in Species and Species. cpdm Species (chronic proliferative Disease in Species [cpdm]) that lack Gene exhibit chronic inflammatory phenotypes, whereas Gene knockout Species exhibit no overt phenotypes, despite sharing highly homologous ubiquitin-like (UBL) and Gene zinc finger (NZF) domains. Here, we intercrossed Species lacking Gene and Gene and found that reduction of Gene in cpdm Species exacerbated inflammatory phenotypes without affecting characteristic features of cpdm disease, whereas reduction of Gene in Gene knockout Species provoked no overt phenotypes. Hence, loss of Gene and reduction of LUBAC triggers cpdm phenotypes. We found that the NZF domain of Gene, but not that of Gene, is critical for effective protection from programmed cell death by enhancing the recruitment of LUBAC to the activated TNFR complex. The binding activity to K63-linked ubiquitin chains that the NZF domain of Gene, but not that of Gene, possesses appears to be involved in the recruitment. Thus, selective recognition of ubiquitin chains by NZFs in LUBAC underlies the regulation of LUBAC function.

24206218.pub_title: Gene affects the efficiency of mitochondrial Chemical oxidation.
24206218.pub_abstract: Transcription factor Gene (Gene) regulates the cellular redox homoeostasis and cytoprotective responses, allowing adaptation and survival under conditions of stress. The significance of Gene in intermediary metabolism is also beginning to be recognized. Thus this transcription factor negatively affects Chemical synthesis. However, the effect of Gene on Chemical oxidation is currently unknown. In the present paper, we report that the mitochondrial oxidation of long-chain (Chemical) and short-chain (Chemical) Chemical is depressed in the absence of Gene and accelerated when Gene is constitutively active. Addition of Chemical stimulates respiration in heart and liver mitochondria isolated from wild-type Species. This effect is significantly weaker when Gene is deleted, whereas it is stronger when Gene activity is constitutively high. In the absence of Chemical, addition of Chemical differentially affects the production of Chemical in Species embryonic fibroblasts from wild-type, Gene-knockout and Gene (Gene)-knockout Species. In acute tissue slices, the rate of regeneration of Chemical is reduced when Gene is absent. This metabolic role of Gene on Chemical oxidation has implications for Disease conditions including Disease, Disease and Disease.

22241991.pub_title: Replication in cells of hematopoietic origin is necessary for Species dissemination.
22241991.pub_abstract: Species (Species) is a mosquito-borne pathogen for which no vaccine or specific therapeutic is available. Although it is well established that dendritic cells and macrophages are primary sites of Species replication, it remains unclear whether non-hematopoietic cellular compartments serve as virus reservoirs. Here, we exploited hematopoietic-specific microRNA-142 (miR-142) to control virus tropism by inserting tandem target sites into the virus to restrict replication exclusively in this cell population. In vivo use of this virus restricted infection of Gene+, Gene+, and CD45+ cells, resulting in a loss of virus spread, regardless of the route of administration. Furthermore, sequencing of the targeted virus population that persisted at low levels, demonstrated total excision of the inserted miR-142 target sites. The complete conversion of the virus population under these selective conditions suggests that these immune cells are the predominant sources of virus amplification. Taken together, this work highlights the importance of hematopoietic cells for Species replication and showcases an invaluable tool for the study of virus pathogenesis.

22236012.pub_title: Gene (Gene) signal strength controls Disease severity in proteoglycan-specific Gene Species.
22236012.pub_abstract: Gene Species (Gene-Tg) Species specific for the arthritogenic 5/4E8 epitope in the G1 domain of cartilage proteoglycan were generated and back-crossed into Disease-prone BALB/c background. Although more than 90% of Gene(+)  T cells of all Gene-Tg lines were 5/4E8-specific, one (Gene-TgA) was highly sensitive to G1-induced or spontaneous Disease, while another (Gene-Gene) was less susceptible. Here we studied whether fine differences in Gene signalling controlled the onset and severity of Disease. Species from the two Gene-Tg lines were immunized side by side with purified recombinant Species G1 (rhG1) domain for G1 domain of cartilage proteoglycan (Chemical)-induced Disease (GIA). Gene-TgA Species developed severe and early-onset Disease, whereas Gene-Gene Species developed Disease with delayed onset, although Gene-Gene Gene(+)  T cells expressed approximately twice more Gene-Vbeta4 chain protein. The more severe Disease in Gene-TgA Species was associated with higher amounts of anti-G1 domain-specific antibodies, larger numbers of B cells and activated T helper cells. Importantly, Gene-Gene Gene(+)  T cells were more sensitive to in vitro activation-induced apoptosis, correlating with their higher Gene and Gene expression and with the increased Gene signal strength. These findings indicate that Gene signal strength determines the clinical outcome of Disease induction: 'optimal' Gene signal strength leads to strong T cell activation and severe Disease in Gene-TgA Species, whereas 'supra-optimal' Gene signal leads to enhanced elimination of self-reactive T cells, resulting in Disease.

24593825.pub_title: Gene heterozygous Species reveal essential role for Chemical in amygdalar behavioral and synaptic function.
24593825.pub_abstract: Chemical (Chemical) is an essential element with many biological roles, but its roles in the Species nervous system are poorly understood. Species deficient in the cuproenzyme peptidylglycine alpha-amidating monooxygenase (Gene(+/-) Species) were initially generated to study neuropeptide amidation. Gene(+/-) Species exhibit profound Disease in a few behavioral tasks, including enhancements in innate fear along with Disease in acquired fear. Interestingly, several Gene(+/-) phenotypes were recapitulated in Chemical-restricted wild-type Species and rescued in Chemical-supplemented Gene(+/-) Species. These behaviors correspond to enhanced excitability and deficient synaptic plasticity in the amygdala of Gene(+/-) Species, which are also rescued by Chemical supplementation. Chemical and Gene are present at synapses, in key positions to respond to and influence synaptic activity. Further study demonstrated that extracellular Chemical is necessary for wild-type synaptic plasticity and sufficient to induce long-term potentiation. These experiments support roles for Gene in Chemical homeostasis and for synaptic Chemical in amygdalar function.

22649244.pub_title: Glutamatergic synapse formation is promoted by alpha7-containing nicotinic Chemical receptors.
22649244.pub_abstract: Chemical is the primary excitatory transmitter in adult brain, acting through synapses on dendritic spines and shafts. Early in development, however, when glutamatergic synapses are only beginning to form, nicotinic cholinergic excitation is already widespread; it is mediated by Chemical activating nicotinic Chemical receptors (nAChRs) that generate waves of activity across brain regions. A major class of nAChRs contributing at this time is a species containing alpha7 subunits (alpha7-nAChRs). These receptors are highly permeable to Chemical, influence a variety of Chemical-dependent events, and are diversely distributed throughout the developing CNS. Here we show that alpha7-nAChRs unexpectedly promote formation of glutamatergic synapses during development. The dependence on alpha7-nAChRs becomes clear when comparing wild-type (WT) Species with Species constitutively lacking the Gene gene. Ultrastructural analysis, immunostaining, and patch-clamp recording all reveal synaptic deficits when Gene input is absent. Similarly, nicotinic activation of alpha7-nAChRs in WT organotypic culture, as well as cell culture, increases the number of glutamatergic synapses. RNA interference demonstrates that the alpha7-nAChRs must be expressed in the neuron being innervated for normal innervation to occur. Moreover, the deficits persist throughout the developmental period of major de novo synapse formation and are still fully apparent in the adult. GABAergic synapses, in contrast, are undiminished in number under such conditions. As a result, Species lacking alpha7-nAChRs have an altered balance in the excitatory/inhibitory input they receive. This ratio represents a fundamental feature of neural networks and shows for the first time that endogenous nicotinic cholinergic signaling plays a key role in network construction.

23471340.pub_title: Constitutive expression of Gene in intestinal epithelium worsens Species acute Disease and is associated with increased levels of proinflammatory cytokine Kc.
23471340.pub_abstract: Disease (IBD), which includes Disease and Disease, is a chronic Disease associated with an increased risk for Disease. Matrix metalloproteinases (Gene) are the predominant proteinases expressed in the gut mucosa during active IBD. Our laboratory has previously demonstrated that epithelial-derived Gene is absent in normal colonic tissue but is upregulated during IBD. In this study Gene Species (Tg-villin-Gene) are generated specifically to overexpress Gene in intestinal epithelium to examine the role and underlying mechanism by which it modulates the pathogenesis of Disease. Dextran Chemical (3% DSS)- and Species (Species.)-induced Disease models were used to study gut Disease in Tg-villin-Gene and wild-type littermates (WT). Colonic tissue was analyzed via Western blot, histology, Gene (Gene) assay, and quantitative PCR. Tg-villin-Gene Species expressed significantly increased Gene mRNA and protein expression at basal level. There was a significant decrease in the goblet cells, but a significant increase in proliferation and apoptosis were observed among Tg-villin-Gene Species compared with WT Species. There was also a significant increase in the proinflammatory chemokine Kc among Tg-villin-Gene compared with WT Species. Tg-villin-Gene exhibited a severe inflammatory response than WT Species in both DSS- and Species.-induced Disease models as evident by greater Disease and higher clinical score, histological score, and Gene activity, which correlated with relative levels of Kc mRNA. Gene expressed by intestinal epithelial cells mediates Disease in Disease with simultaneous increase in proinflammatory cytokine Kc.

24211578.pub_title: Retina-specific gene excision by targeted expression of Cre recombinase.
24211578.pub_abstract: The use of Cre recombinase for conditional targeting permits the controlled removal or activation of genes in specific tissues and at specific times of development. The Rho-Cre Species provide an improved tool for studying gene ablation in rod photoreceptor cells. To establish a robust expression of Rho-Cre Species that would be useful for the study of various protein functions in photoreceptor cells, a total 11,987 kb fragment (pNCHS4 Rho-NLS-cre) containing Species Gene promoter was cloned. The Rho-Cre plasmid was digested with EcoR1 and I Ceu-1, and the 9.316 kb fragment containing the hRho promoter and Cre recombinase gel was purified. To generate Species, the purified DNA fragment was injected into fertilized oocytes according to standard protocols. ROSA26R reported the steady expression of Rho-Cre especially in photoreceptor cells, allowing further excising proteins in rod photoreceptors across the retina. This Rho-Cre Species line should thus prove useful as a general deletor line for genetic analysis of diverse aspects of Disease.

23979159.pub_title: Chronic epithelial Gene expression causes Species Disease.
23979159.pub_abstract: Disease predisposes Species to the development of both Disease and Disease, but the molecular details underlying this important clinical association remain obscure. We report that Gene (Gene), an epithelial phosphatidylserine receptor expressed transiently after Disease and chronically in Disease, promotes Disease. Conditional expression of Gene in renal epithelial cells (Gene) in the absence of an Disease stimulus resulted in focal epithelial vacuolization at birth, but otherwise normal tubule histology and kidney function. By 4 weeks of age, Gene(RECtg) Species developed spontaneous and progressive Disease with Disease, leading to Disease with Disease, Disease, Disease, Disease, Disease, and Disease, analogous to progressive Disease in Species. Gene(RECtg) kidneys had elevated expression of proinflammatory Gene (Gene) at early time points. Heterologous expression of Gene in an immortalized proximal tubule cell line triggered Gene secretion and increased Gene-dependent macrophage chemotaxis. In Species expressing a mutant, truncated Gene polypeptide, experimental Disease was ameliorated with reduced levels of Gene, consistent with a profibrotic role for native Gene. Thus, sustained Gene expression promotes kidney Disease and provides a link between acute and recurrent Disease with progressive Disease.

23824539.pub_title: Gene acts stage specifically to regulate multiple aspects of Species meiotic silencing.
23824539.pub_abstract: In mammals, homologs that fail to synapse during meiosis are transcriptionally inactivated. This process, meiotic silencing, drives inactivation of the heterologous XY bivalent in male germ cells (meiotic sex chromosome inactivation [MSCI]) and is thought to act as a meiotic surveillance mechanism. The checkpoint protein Gene and Gene localizes to unsynapsed chromosomes, but its role in the initiation and maintenance of meiotic silencing is unknown. Here we show that Gene has multiple roles in silencing. Gene first regulates HORMA (Hop1, Gene, and Gene) domain protein Gene/2 phosphorylation and localization of Disease I (Gene) and Gene cofactors Gene (Gene)/topoisomerase 2-binding protein 1 (Gene) at unsynapsed axes. Later, it acts as an adaptor, transducing signaling at unsynapsed axes into surrounding chromatin in a manner that requires interdependence with Gene (Gene) and Gene. Finally, Gene catalyzes histone Gene phosphorylation, the epigenetic event leading to gene inactivation. Using a novel genetic strategy in which MSCI is used to silence a chosen gene in pachytene, we show that Gene depletion does not disrupt the maintenance of silencing and that silencing comprises two phases: The first is dynamic and reversible, and the second is stable and irreversible. Our work identifies a role for Gene in the epigenetic regulation of gene expression and presents a new technique for ablating gene function in the germline.

22379027.pub_title: Follicular helper NKT cells induce limited B cell responses and germinal center formation in the absence of Gene(+) T cell help.
22379027.pub_abstract: B cells require Gene (Gene)-restricted cognate help and CD40 engagement by Gene(+) T follicular helper (T(FH)) cells to form germinal centers and long-lasting Ab responses. Invariant NKT (iNKT) cells are innate-like lymphocytes that jumpstart the adaptive immune response when activated by the Gene-restricted lipid Chemical (Disease). We previously observed that immunization of Species lacking Gene(+) T cells (Gene(-/-)) elicits specific IgG responses only when protein Ags are mixed with Disease. In this study, we investigated the mechanisms underpinning this observation. We find that induction of Ag-specific Ab responses in Gene(-/-) Species upon immunization with protein Ags mixed with Disease requires Gene expression and CD40 engagement on B cells, suggesting that iNKT cells provide Gene-restricted cognate help for B cells. Remarkably, splenic iNKT cells from immunized Gene(-/-) Species display a typical Gene(hi)programmed Disease and induce germinal centers. The specific IgG response induced in Gene(-/-) Species has shorter duration than that developing in Gene-competent animals, suggesting that iNKT(FH) cells preferentially induce transient rather than long-lived Ab responses. Together, these results suggest that iNKT cells can be co-opted into the follicular helper function, yet iNKT(FH) and Gene(+) T(FH) cells display distinct helper features, consistent with the notion that these two cell subsets play nonredundant functions throughout immune responses.

22301546.pub_title: The MC159 protein from the Species contagiosum poxvirus inhibits NF-kappaB activation by interacting with the IkappaB kinase complex.
22301546.pub_abstract: Species (Species) causes persistent Disease in healthy and immunocompromised Species. Its ability to persist likely is due to its arsenal of viral immunoevasion proteins. For example, the Species MC159 protein inhibits Gene-R1-induced NF-kappaB activation and apoptosis. The MC159 protein is a viral FLIP and, as such, possesses two tandem death effector domains (DEDs). We show in this article that, in Species Disease 293 T cells, the expression of wild-type MC159 or a mutant MC159 protein containing the first DED (Chemical) inhibited Gene-induced NF-kappaB, or NF-kappaB activated by Chemical or Gene overexpression, whereas a mutant protein lacking the first DED (Chemical) did not. We hypothesized that the MC159 protein targeted the IkappaB kinase (IKK) complex to inhibit these diverse signaling events. Indeed, the MC159 protein, but not Chemical, coimmunoprecipitated with Gene. MC159 coimmunoprecipitated with Gene when using Species embryonic fibroblasts that lack either Gene or Gene, suggesting that the MC159 protein interacted directly with Gene. MC159-Gene coimmunoprecipitations were detected during infection of cells with either Species isolated from Species lesions or with a recombinant MC159-expressing Species. MC159 also interacts with Gene, a signaling molecule involved in NF-kappaB activation. However, mutational analysis of MC159 failed to reveal a correlation between MC159-Gene interactions and MC159's inhibitory function. We propose that MC159-IKK interactions, but not MC159-Gene interactions, are responsible for inhibiting NF-kappaB activation.

25143585.pub_title: Gene-unrestricted NKT cells are endowed with a hybrid function far superior than that of iNKT cells.
25143585.pub_abstract: Invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells to date represent the best example of cells known to have a hybrid function, representing both innate and adaptive immunity. Shared phenotypic similarities with NK cells together with a rapid response to a cytokine stimulus and a productive Gene engagement are the features that underline the hybrid nature of iNKT cells. Using these criteria, we provide molecular and functional evidence demonstrating that Gene-independent (Gene(ind)) NKT cells, a population of Gene-unrestricted NKT cells, are endowed with a hybrid function far superior to that of iNKT cells: (i) an extensive shared program with NK cells, (ii) a closer Euclidian distance with NK cells, and (iii) the ability to respond to innate stimuli (Chemical:IC) with cytotoxic potential in the same manner as NK cells identify a hybrid feature in Gene(ind)NKT cells that truly fulfills the dual function of an NK and a T cell. Our finding that Gene(ind)NKT cells are programmed to act like NK cells in response to innate signals while being capable of adaptive responses is unprecedented, and thus might reemphasize Gene-unrestricted NKT cells as a subset of lymphocytes that could affect biological processes of antimicrobial and Disease immunity in a unique way.

23121668.pub_title: Activated natural killer T cells producing Gene elicit promoting activity to Species dendritic cell-based Disease.
23121668.pub_abstract: As natural killer (NK) T cells play an important role in the development of Disease, they should have significant roles for the pathogenesis of Disease. Implication of the NK T cells in the generation of autoimmune-related Disease was investigated using a novel Species model. Immunization of Species with dendritic cells (DCs) loaded with hepatocyte-mimicking Disease cells (DC/Hepa1-6) induces cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL) capable of killing hepatocytes. Subsequent administration of interleukin (IL)-12, a potent Gene (Gene) inducer, to the immunized Species generates Disease (AHI), as reported previously. Upon onset of the AHI response, the number of intrahepatic CD3(+) NK1   1(+) NK T cells increased markedly, along with a decrease in the number of splenic NK T cells, augmented expression of Gene on intrahepatic NK T cells and Gene in hepatic tissue, suggesting that NK T cells were recruited into the inflamed liver. The NK T cells were strongly positive for Gene and produced Gene, but not Gene. AHI activity was attenuated markedly in Gene(-/-) NK T cell-deficient Species, indicating that NK T cells play a pivotal role in the development of AHI. Species treated with DC/Hepa1-6 and Chemical, a potent NK T cell activator, also exhibited similar Disease, in which activated NK T cells producing Gene and CD8(+) T cells cytotoxic to hepatocytes were induced in liver-infiltrating mononuclear cells. Activated NK T cells producing Gene potentiate DC-based AHI in the Species model.

23038263.pub_title: Gene protects Species against Chemical-induced type 1 Disease through Gene: the role of Gene/Gene ratio in beta-cell death.
23038263.pub_abstract: Disease is characterized by a loss of islet beta-cells. Gene (Gene) protects pancreatic islets against cytokine-induced apoptosis. For this reason, we assessed whether Gene protects Species against Chemical-induced Disease (a model of type 1 Disease) and the mechanism for this protection. WT and Gene knockdown C57BL6 Species were treated for 5 days with Chemical buffer or 0.1 mg/kg Gene before receiving 80 mg/kg Chemical. Glycemia in non-fasted Species was measured weekly from days 0-28 after Chemical administration. Disease was defined as a blood Chemical > 11.2 mmol/liter. Wild-type (WT) and Gene knockdown MIN6 cells were cultured with Gene, Gene, or both. Gene reduced Disease incidence and islet apoptosis in WT but not in Genekd Species. Likewise, Gene inhibited apoptosis in WT but not in Genekd MIN6 cells. Gene increased Gene phosphorylation in WT and Genekd Species and MIN6 cells but reduced Gene phosphorylation only in WT Species, in contrast to Chemical and Gene. Moreover, Gene reduced Gene activation and required down-regulation of Gene expression to exert its protective effects. In conclusion, Gene protects Species against Chemical-induced Disease by increasing pancreatic islet survival, and this protection depends on Gene. In addition, Gene expression and beta-cell fate are dependent on Gene/Gene ratio.

25690660.pub_title: A Gene-dependent signal promotes pro-inflammatory polarization in microglia following Disease and exacerbates Disease.
25690660.pub_abstract: Under pathological conditions, activated microglia play paradoxical roles and could have Disease or neuroprotective effects. However, the signal determining how activated microglia affects the fate of neuronal cells remains largely unknown. Here we demonstrate that Gene (Gene), a transmembrane adaptor protein that contains an immunoreceptor Chemical-based activation motif, is a critical regulator of microglial function after Disease. In a model of Species Disease, the duration of microglial increase after Disease became shorter in Species lacking Gene, although microglial morphology and total cell numbers were not significantly affected during early phase after Disease. Intriguingly, expressions of M1-phenotype markers including pro-inflammatory cytokines were suppressed in Gene-deficient microglia. Furthermore, axotomy-induced motor neuron Disease was markedly prevented in Gene-deficient Species. Collectively, Gene-mediated microglial activation following axotomy promotes pro-inflammatory responses, and thereby accelerates Disease, suggesting that Gene is a potential therapeutic target for the protection of Disease caused by microglial activation.

22342532.pub_title: Segmental variations in trabecular bone density and microstructure of the spine in senescence-accelerated Species (SAMP6): a Species model for Disease.
22342532.pub_abstract: The senescence-accelerated Species strain P6 (SAMP6) is a model of Disease, which possesses many features of Disease in Species. So far, little is known about the systemic bone microstructural changes that occur at the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar vertebrae. In this study, we therefore investigated segmental variations of vertebral trabecular bone mineral density (BMD) and three-dimensional microstructure in SAMP6 and the normal control Species (SAMR1) at 12 months of age using quantitative micro computed tomography (micro-CT) and image analysis software. The vertebral height and vertebral cross-sectional area (CSA) increased, while vertebral trabecular BMD and trabecular bone volume fraction (BV/TV) decreased from the cervical to lumbar spine both in SAMR1 and SAMP6. As compared with SAMR1, the thoracic vertebral CSA had a tendency to be low and the lumbar vertebral CSA was significantly declined in SAMP6. The vertebral trabecular BMD, BV/TV, trabecular thickness (Tb.Th), and trabecular number (Tb.N) significantly decreased in cervical, thoracic and lumbar spine of SAMP6. Trabecular bone pattern factor (TBPf) was higher at the lumbar spine and the structure model index (SMI) of the lower thoracic and lumbar spine was higher in SAMP6. These results indicate that vertebral trabecular bone microstructures are remarkably heterogeneous throughout the spine in both SAMR1 and SAMP6. The decrease of vertebral trabecular bone density in SAMP6 advanced faster caudally than cranially within the spine, similar phenomena were observed in Species. These findings highlight the relevance of SAMP6 for studies of vertebral fragility associated with Disease.

23958305.pub_title: P2X7 receptors regulate engulfing activity of non-stimulated resting astrocytes.
23958305.pub_abstract: We previously demonstrated that P2X7 receptors (P2X7Rs) expressed by cultured Species astrocytes were activated without any exogenous stimuli, but its roles in non-stimulated resting astrocytes remained unknown. It has been reported that astrocytes exhibit engulfing activity, and that the basal activity of P2X7Rs regulates the phagocytic activity of macrophages. In this study, therefore, we investigated whether P2X7Rs regulate the engulfing activity of Species astrocytes. Uptake of non-opsonized beads by resting astrocytes derived from ddY-Species cortex time-dependently increased, and the uptaken beads were detected in the intracellular space. The bead uptake was inhibited by cytochalasin D (CytD), an F-actin polymerization inhibitor, and agonists and antagonists of P2X7Rs apparently decreased the uptake. Spontaneous YO-Gene uptake by ddY-Species astrocytes was reduced by the agonists and antagonists of P2X7Rs, but not by CytD. Down-regulation of P2X7Rs using siRNA decreased the bead uptake by ddY-Species astrocytes. In addition, compared to in the case of ddY-Species astrocytes, SJL-Species astrocytes exhibited higher YO-Gene uptake activity, and their bead uptake was significantly greater. These findings suggest that resting astrocytes exhibit engulfing activity and that the activity is regulated, at least in part, by their P2X7Rs.

26941104.pub_title: The Chemical terminal mutational hotspot of the Disease (Disease GTPase regulator) is glutamylated in vivo.
26941104.pub_abstract: Mutations inRPGR(ORF15)(Disease GTPase regulator) are a major cause of inherited Disease. Gene)(1152 residues) is a ciliary protein involved in regulating the composition and function of photoreceptor cilia. The mutational hotspot in Gene)is an unusual C-terminal domain encoded by exon ORF15, which is rich in polyglutamates and Chemical residues (Chemical-Gly domain) followed by a short stretch of basic amino acid residues (Disease; residues 1072-1152). However, the properties of the ORF15-encoded domain and its involvement in the pathogenesis of the disease are unclear. Here we show that Gene)is glutamylated at the C-terminus, as determined by binding to GT335, which recognizes glutamylated substrates. This reactivity is lost in two Species mutants ofRpgr, which do not express Gene)due to disease-causing mutations in exon ORF15. Our results indicate that Gene)is posttranslationally glutamylated in the Chemical-Gly domain and that the GT335 antibody predominantly recognizes Gene)in photoreceptor cilia.

26766588.pub_title: Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 Is a Barrier to Gene-Driven Inflammation and Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition in Disease.
26766588.pub_abstract: Polycomb repressive complexes (PRC) are frequently implicated in Species Disease, acting either as oncogenes or Disease suppressors. Here, we show that PRC2 is a critical regulator of Gene-driven Disease progression. Modulation of PRC2 by either Gene overexpression or Eed deletion enhances Gene-driven Disease, respectively. Eed-loss-driven inflammation leads to massive macrophage recruitment and marked decline in tissue function. Additional Gene inactivation activates a cell-autonomous epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition program leading to an Disease. A switch between methylated/acetylated chromatin underlies the Disease phenotypic evolution, prominently involving genes controlled by Hippo/Wnt signaling. Our observations in the Species models were conserved in Species cells. Importantly, PRC2 inactivation results in context-dependent phenotypic alterations, with implications for its therapeutic application.

25246631.pub_title: Binding of WIP to actin is essential for T cell actin cytoskeleton integrity and tissue homing.
25246631.pub_abstract: The Disease protein (Gene) is important for actin polymerization in T cells and for their migration. Gene (WIP) binds to and stabilizes Gene and also interacts with actin. Cytoskeletal and Disease are more severe in WIP(-/-) T cells, which lack Gene, than in Gene(-/-) T cells, suggesting that WIP interaction with actin may be important for T cell cytoskeletal integrity and function. We constructed Species that lack the actin-binding domain of WIP (WIPDeltaABD Species). WIPDeltaABD associated normally with Gene but not F-actin. T cells from WIPDeltaABD Species had normal Gene levels but decreased cellular F-actin content, a disorganized actin cytoskeleton, impaired chemotaxis, and defective homing to lymph nodes. WIPDeltaABD Species exhibited a Disease and impaired responses to cutaneous challenge with protein antigen. Adoptively transferred antigen-specific CD4(+) T cells from WIPDeltaABD Species had decreased homing to antigen-challenged skin of wild-type recipients. These findings show that WIP binding to actin, independently of its binding to Gene, is critical for the integrity of the actin cytoskeleton in T cells and for their migration into tissues. Disruption of WIP binding to actin could be of therapeutic value in T cell-driven inflammatory diseases.

23864664.pub_title: Persistent synaptic scaling independent of Chemical receptor subunit composition.
