23864664.pub_abstract: Despite long-standing evidence that the specific intracellular domains of Chemical-type Chemical receptor (AMPAR) subunits are critical for trafficking, it has recently been demonstrated that there is no absolute requirement for any AMPAR subunit for the receptor insertion underlying LTP. It is unclear whether this holds true to other forms of plasticity. Homeostatic synaptic plasticity (HSP) is an important form of negative feedback that provides stability to neuronal networks, and results at least in part from the insertion of Gene into glutamatergic synapses following chronic reductions in neuronal activity. Similar to LTP, the Gene subunit has been suggested to be the requisite subunit for HSP-induced AMPAR insertion and acute treatment with signaling molecules that underlie some forms of HSP results in the preferential incorporation of Gene-lacking receptors. However, knockdown experiments have instead implicated a requirement for the Gene subunit. Here we re-examined the requirement for specific AMPAR subunit during chronic Chemical-induced HSP using hippocampal cultures derived from AMPAR subunit knock-out Species. We observed HSP in cultures from Gene-/-, Gene-/-, and Gene-/- Gene-/- Species, and conclude that, as with LTP, there is no subunit requirement for HSP.

23335078.pub_title: Dynamic migration and cell-cell interactions of early reprogramming revealed by high-resolution time-lapse imaging.
23335078.pub_abstract: Discovery of the cellular and molecular mechanisms of induced pluripotency has been hampered by its low efficiency and slow kinetics. Here, we report an experimental system with multicolor time-lapse microscopy that permits direct observation of pluripotency induction at single cell resolution, with temporal intervals as short as 5 minutes. Using granulocyte-monocyte progenitors as source cells, we visualized nascent pluripotent cells that emerge from a hematopoietic state. We engineered a suite of image processing and analysis software to annotate the behaviors of the reprogramming cells, which revealed the highly dynamic cell-cell interactions associated with early reprogramming. We observed frequent cell migration, which can lead to sister colonies, satellite colonies, and colonies of mixed genetic makeup. In addition, we discovered a previously unknown morphologically distinct two-cell intermediate of reprogramming, which occurs prior to other reprogramming landmarks. By directly visualizing the reprogramming process with Gene inhibition, we demonstrate that Gene is required for proper cellular interactions from an early stage of reprogramming, including the two-cell intermediate. The detailed cell-cell interactions revealed by this imaging platform shed light on previously unappreciated early reprogramming dynamics. This experimental system could serve as a powerful tool to dissect the complex mechanisms of early reprogramming by focusing on the relevant but rare cells with superb temporal and spatial resolution.

22518062.pub_title: The anorectic effect of Gene does not require action in Gene-responsive neurons.
22518062.pub_abstract: Gene resistance is a feature of Disease that poses a significant therapeutic challenge. Any treatment that is effective to reduce body weight in Disease Species must overcome or circumvent Gene resistance, which promotes the maintenance of excess body fat in Disease individuals. Gene (Gene) is unique in its ability to reduce food intake and body weight in Disease, Gene-resistant Species and rodents. Although attempts to use Gene as an Disease therapy failed due to the development of neutralizing antibodies to the drug, efforts to understand mechanisms for Gene's anorectic effects provide an opportunity to develop new drugs for Gene-resistant individuals. Gene and Gene share several structural, anatomic, and signaling properties, but it is not understood whether or how the two cytokines might interact to affect energy balance. Here, we conditionally deleted the Gene (Gene) subunit, Gene, in cells expressing Gene receptors. We found that Gene signaling in Gene-responsive neurons is not required for endogenous maintenance of energy balance and is not required for the anorectic response to exogenous administration of a Gene agonist. These results indicate that despite anatomical overlap for Gene and Gene action, Gene appears to act within a distinct neuronal population to elicit its potent anorectic effect.

23049792.pub_title: Phosphorylation of Species Gene by protein kinase A.
23049792.pub_abstract: The visual pigment Gene is expressed in intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells (ipRGCs) in the Species retina, where it is involved in non-image forming light responses including circadian photoentrainment, Disease, suppression of pineal Chemical synthesis, and direct photic regulation of sleep. It has recently been shown that the Gene-based light response in ipRGCs is attenuated by the neurotransmitter Chemical. Here, we use a heterologous expression system to demonstrate that Species Gene can be phosphorylated by protein kinase A, and that phosphorylation can inhibit Gene signaling in HEK cells. Site-directed mutagenesis experiments revealed that this inhibitory effect is primarily mediated by phosphorylation of sites T186 and S287 located in the second and third intracellular loops of Gene, respectively. Furthermore, we show that this phosphorylation can occur in vivo using an in situ proximity-dependent ligation assay (Chemical). Based on these data, we suggest that the attenuation of the Gene-based light response by Chemical is mediated by direct PKA phosphorylation of Gene, rather than phosphorylation of a downstream component of the signaling cascade.

24098333.pub_title: Antioxidant Chemical Disease by inhibiting ROS/ER stress in Gene deficient Species.
24098333.pub_abstract: Disease (HCC) remains one of the most deadly solid Disease worldwide. We recently find that the loss of Gene (Gene) activities promotes the Chemical (Chemical) induced Disease and Disease progression, which associates with an abundant accumulation of reactive Chemical species (ROS) and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. This finding suggests that the ROS/ER stress plays a role in Gene modulated carcinogenesis of HCC. To investigate the mechanism of Gene activity defending against Disease, the Gene-deficient Species were treated with or without antioxidant Chemical (Chemical) before Chemical administration. We found that pretreatment of these animals with Chemical Disease and progression of HCC in the Gene-deficient Species, declined ROS/ER stress, and alleviated the unfold protein response and inflammatory response in Disease. Moreover, the Chemical treatment significantly reduced the enhanced aggregation of Gene and Mallory-Denk bodies in the Chemical-induced HCC liver tissue, suggesting that Chemical treatment improves the suppressive autophagic flux in the Disease. These findings indicate that Gene activity defends against Disease through diminishing the accumulation of ROS and alleviating ER stress and unfold protein response mediated inflammatory response in the liver.

26081170.pub_title: Accumulation and activation of epidermal gammadelta T cells in a Species model of chronic Disease is not required for the inflammatory phenotype.
26081170.pub_abstract: Disease resulting from a defective epidermal barrier is a Disease (Disease). We previously demonstrated that Species lacking FGF receptors 1 and 2 in keratinocytes (K5-R1/R2 Species) develop an Disease-like chronic Disease as a result of an impaired epidermal barrier. Here, we show that gammadelta T cells, which rapidly respond to various insults, accumulate in the epidermis of K5-R1/R2 Species before the development of histological abnormalities. Their number and activation further increase as the phenotype progresses, most likely as a consequence of increased expression of Gene and the stress-induced proteins Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, and Gene. To determine the role of gammadelta T cells in the skin phenotype, we generated quadruple mutant K5-R1/-R2 Species lacking gammadelta T cells. Surprisingly, loss of gammadelta T cells did not or only marginally affect keratinocyte proliferation, epidermal thickness, epidermal barrier function, and accumulation and activation of different immune cells in the skin of K5-R1/R2 Species, possibly due to partial compensation by Disease cells. These results demonstrate that gammadelta T cells do not contribute to the development or maintenance of chronic Disease in response to a defect in the epidermal barrier.

25706117.pub_title: Expression of the SNARE protein Gene is essential for cell survival.
25706117.pub_abstract: Members of the SNARE-family of proteins are known to be key regulators of the membrane-membrane fusion events required for intracellular membrane traffic. The ubiquitously expressed SNARE protein Gene regulates a wide variety of exocytosis events and is essential for Species development. Germline deletion of Gene results in early Disease in Species, and for this reason we now describe Species and cell lines in which Gene can be conditionally-deleted using Cre-Gene technology. Deletion of Gene in Gene-Cre expressing Species prevents B lymphocyte development and deletion of Gene using a variety of T lymphocyte-specific Cre Species prevents T lymphocyte development. Acute depletion of Gene in Species fibroblasts leads to rapid apoptotic cell death. These data highlight the importance of Gene for cell survival and describe a Species in which specific cell types can be eliminated by expression of tissue-specific Cre-recombinase.

23166161.pub_title: Gene mediates Toll-like receptor 2-dependent inflammatory responses to Species.
23166161.pub_abstract: Gene is an adaptor molecule important in transducing signals from intracellularly signaling Toll-like receptor 3 (TLR3) and TLR4. Recently, Gene was found to signal from intracellular compartments. Using a synthetic ligand for Gene/1 heterodimers, as well as Species, which is a strong activator of Gene/1, we found that Gene signaling can utilize Gene. Unlike Gene signaling by other TLRs, Gene-mediated Gene signaling is dependent on the presence of another adaptor molecule, MyD88. However, unlike MyD88 Disease, Disease does not result in diminished control of Disease with Species in a Species model of disease. This appears to be due to the effects of MyD88 on phagocytosis via scavenger receptors, such as MARCO, which are not affected by the loss of Gene. In Species, Disease did have an effect on the production of inflammatory cytokines, suggesting that regulation of inflammatory cytokines and control of bacterial growth may be uncoupled, in part through transduction of Gene signaling through Gene.

22556254.pub_title: Removal of shelterin reveals the telomere end-protection problem.
22556254.pub_abstract: The telomere end-protection problem is defined by the aggregate of DNA damage signaling and repair pathways that require repression at telomeres. To define the end-protection problem, we removed the whole shelterin complex from Species telomeres through conditional deletion of Gene and Gene in nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ) deficient cells. The data reveal two DNA damage response pathways not previously observed upon deletion of individual shelterin proteins. The shelterin-free telomeres are processed by microhomology-mediated alternative-NHEJ when Ku70/80 is absent and are attacked by nucleolytic degradation in the absence of 53BP1. The data establish that the end-protection problem is specified by six pathways [Gene) and Gene (Gene) signaling, classical-NHEJ, alt-NHEJ, homologous recombination, and resection] and show how shelterin acts with general DNA damage response factors to solve this problem.

23469143.pub_title: Consequences of Gene heteromerization with the chemokine receptors Gene and Gene.
23469143.pub_abstract: Recent studies have shown that heteromerization of the chemokine receptors Gene, Gene and Gene is associated to negative binding cooperativity. In the present study, we build on these previous results, and investigate the consequences of chemokine receptor heteromerization with Gene, the receptor of Gene, a leukocyte chemoattractant protein structurally unrelated to chemokines. We show, using BRET and HTRF assays, that Gene forms homomers, and provide data suggesting that Gene also forms heteromers with the chemokine receptors Gene and Gene. As previously described for other chemokine receptor heteromers, negative binding cooperativity was detected between Gene and chemokine receptors, i.e. the ligands of one receptor competed for the binding of a specific tracer of the other. We also showed, using Species bone marrow-derived dendritic cells prepared from wild-type and Gene knockout Species, that Gene-specific ligands cross-inhibited Gene binding on Gene in a Gene-dependent manner, supporting the relevance of the Gene/Gene interaction in native leukocytes. Finally, and in contrast to the situation encountered for other previously characterized Gene heteromers, we showed that the Gene-specific antagonist Chemical did not cross-inhibit Gene binding in cells co-expressing Gene and Gene, demonstrating that cross-regulation by Chemical depends on the nature of receptor partners with which Gene is co-expressed.

22773187.pub_title: Dual functions of Gene promote biphasic Wnt-on and Wnt-off states during anteroposterior neural patterning.
22773187.pub_abstract: Gene, a dimerization partner protein of the transcription factor E2F, is known to inhibit Wnt/Gene signalling along with E2F, although the function of Gene itself was not well characterized. Here, we present a novel dual regulatory mechanism of Wnt/Gene signalling by Gene independent from E2F. Gene negatively regulates Wnt/Gene signalling by inhibiting Gene-Gene interaction and by enhancing poly-ubiquitination of Gene. In contrast, Gene positively modulates the signalling upon Wnt stimulation, via increasing cytosolic Gene and antagonizing the kinase activity of Gene. In Species embryos, Gene exerts both positive and negative roles in Wnt/Gene signalling during anteroposterior neural patterning. From subcellular localization analyses, we suggest that the dual roles of Gene in Wnt/Gene signalling are endowed by differential nucleocytoplasmic localizations. We propose that these dual functions of Gene can promote and stabilize biphasic Wnt-on and Wnt-off states in response to a gradual gradient of Wnt/Gene signalling to determine differential cell fates.

23893895.pub_title: Gene regulates levels of Gene and adhesion between photoreceptors and Muller cells.
23893895.pub_abstract: Gene and Gene both interact directly with Gene/Gene and through this scaffold protein may form a large protein complex. To investigate the role of Gene in the retina we have analyzed conditional mutant Gene knockout Species. Ultrastructural localization studies revealed that Gene is predominantly localized in apical villi of Disease cells. Retinas lacking Gene developed late onset Disease, with sporadic foci of rosette formation in the central part of the retina. Disease in Gene cKO Species was accelerated by exposure to moderate levels of white light. Electroretinography recordings in aging Species under both scotopic and photopic conditions ranged from normal to mildly subnormal, while the magnitude correlated with the strength and extent of morphological alterations. Loss of Gene resulted in significant loss of Gene at the subapical region adjacent to adherens junctions, and loss of Gene in Gene conditional knockdown retinas significantly accelerated the onset of Disease. These data suggest that Gene is required for maintaining proper levels of Gene at the subapical region, and indicate that the Gene gene is a candidate modulator of the Crumbs complex.

22992651.pub_title: Cell-type specific deletion of Gene in Gene-containing neurons enhances Disease and disrupts fear extinction.
22992651.pub_abstract: Gene (CRF) is critical for the endocrine, autonomic, and behavioral responses to stressors, and it has been shown to modulate fear and Disease. The CRF receptor is widely expressed across a variety of cell types, impeding progress toward understanding the contribution of specific CRF-containing neurons to fear dysregulation. We used a unique CRF-Cre driver transgenic Species line to remove floxed Gene subunits specifically from Disease [CRF-Gene KO]. This process resulted in Species with decreased Gene expression only in Disease and increased CRF mRNA within the amygdala, bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) and paraventricular nucleus of the Disease. These Species show normal locomotor and Disease responses and no difference in Disease-like behavior or Pavlovian fear conditioning. However, CRF-Gene KO increased Disease-like behavior and impaired extinction of conditioned fear, coincident with an increase in plasma Chemical concentration. These Disease were rescued with systemic or BNST infusion of the CRF antagonist Chemical. Infusion of Chemical, a Gene-preferring Chemical-site agonist, into the BNST of the CRF-Gene KO was ineffective at decreasing Disease. Electrophysiological findings suggest a disruption in inhibitory current may play a role in these changes. These data indicate that disturbance of CRF containing Gene neurons causes increased Disease and impaired fear extinction, both of which are symptoms diagnostic for Disease, such as Disease.

23393389.pub_title: A 28-kDa splice variant of Gene is nuclear-localized and involved in redox signaling in vascular cells.
23393389.pub_abstract: OBJECTIVE: Reactive Chemical species-generating Chemical (Chemical)-oxidase proteins (Noxs) are involved in cell differentiation, migration, and apoptosis. Gene is unique among Noxs in being constitutively active, and its subcellular localization may therefore be particularly important. In this study, we identified and characterized a novel nuclear-localized 28-kDa splice variant of Gene in vascular cells. APPROACH AND RESULTS: Gene immunoreactivity was noted in the nucleus and nucleolus of vascular smooth muscle cells and multiple other cell types by confocal microscopy. Cell fractionation, sequence analyses, and siRNA studies indicated that the nuclear-localized Gene is a 28-kDa splice variant, Nox4D, which lacks putative transmembrane domains. Nox4D overexpression resulted in significant Chemical-dependent reactive Chemical species production as detected by several different methods and caused increased phosphorylation of Gene and the nuclear transcription factor Gene. Overexpression of Nox4D could also induce DNA damage as assessed by gamma-H2AX phosphorylation. These effects were inhibited by a single amino acid substitution in the Nox4D Chemical-binding region. CONCLUSIONS: Nox4D is a nuclear-localized and functionally active splice variant of Gene that may have important pathophysiologic effects through modulation of nuclear signaling and DNA damage.

25164009.pub_title: Activated d16Gene homodimers and SRC kinase mediate optimal efficacy for trastuzumab.
25164009.pub_abstract: A splice isoform of the Gene receptor that lacks exon 16 (d16HER2) is expressed in many Gene-positive Disease, where it has been linked with resistance to the Gene-targeting antibody trastuzumab, but the impact of d16HER2 on Disease pathobiology and therapeutic response remains uncertain. Here, we provide genetic evidence in Species that expression of d16HER2 is sufficient to accelerate mammary tumorigenesis and improve the response to trastuzumab. A comparative analysis of effector signaling pathways activated by d16HER2 and wild-type Gene revealed that d16HER2 was optimally functional through a link to SRC activation (pSRC). Clinically, Gene-positive Disease from Species who received trastuzumab exhibited a positive correlation in d16HER2 and pSRC abundance, consistent with the Species genetic results. Moreover, Species expressing high pSRC or an activated "d16Gene metagene" were found to derive the greatest benefit from trastuzumab treatment. Overall, our results establish the d16HER2 signaling axis as a signature for decreased risk of relapse after trastuzumab treatment.

25955222.pub_title: Role of the Species retinal photoreceptor ribbon synapse in visual motion processing for optokinetic responses.
25955222.pub_abstract: The ribbon synapse is a specialized synaptic structure in the retinal outer plexiform layer where visual signals are transmitted from photoreceptors to the bipolar and horizontal cells. This structure is considered important in high-efficiency signal transmission; however, its role in visual signal processing is unclear. In order to understand its role in visual processing, the present study utilized Gene-null mutant Species that show improper formation of the photoreceptor ribbon synapse. We examined the initial and late phases of the optokinetic responses (OKRs). The initial phase was examined by measuring the open-loop eye velocity of the OKRs to sinusoidal grating patterns of various spatial frequencies moving at various temporal frequencies for 0.5 s. The mutant Species showed significant initial OKRs with a spatiotemporal frequency tuning (spatial frequency, 0.09 +- 0.01 cycles/ ; temporal frequency, 1.87 +- 0.12 Hz) that was slightly different from the wild-type Species (spatial frequency, 0.11 +- 0.01 cycles/ ; temporal frequency, 1.66 +- 0.12 Hz). The late phase of the OKRs was examined by measuring the slow phase eye velocity of the optokinetic Disease induced by the sinusoidal gratings of various spatiotemporal frequencies moving for 30 s. We found that the optimal spatial and temporal frequencies of the mutant Species (spatial frequency, 0.11 +- 0.02 cycles/ ; temporal frequency, 0.81 +- 0.24 Hz) were both lower than those in the wild-type Species (spatial frequency, 0.15 +- 0.02 cycles/ ; temporal frequency, 1.93 +- 0.62 Hz). These results suggest that the ribbon synapse modulates the spatiotemporal frequency tuning of visual processing along the ON pathway by which the late phase of OKRs is mediated.

25855749.pub_title: CD8+ T Cells Can Mediate Short-Term Protection against Heterotypic Species Reinfection in Species.
25855749.pub_abstract: UNLABELLED: Species (Species) is a major public health threat worldwide. Infection with one of the four serotypes of Species results in a transient period of protection against reinfection with all serotypes (cross-protection), followed by lifelong immunity to the infecting serotype. While a protective role for neutralizing antibody responses is well established, the contribution of T cells to reinfection is less clear, especially during heterotypic reinfection. This study investigates the role of T cells during homotypic and heterotypic Species reinfection. Species were sequentially infected with homotypic or heterotypic Species serotypes, and T cell subsets were depleted before the second Disease to assess the role of Species-primed T cells during reinfection. Species primed nonlethally with Species were protected against reinfection with either a homotypic or heterotypic serotype 2 weeks later. Homotypic priming induced a robust neutralizing antibody response, whereas heterotypic priming elicited binding, but nonneutralizing antibodies. CD8(+) T cells were required for protection against heterotypic, but not homotypic, reinfection. These results suggest that T cells can contribute crucially to protection against heterotypic reinfection in situations where humoral responses alone may not be protective. Our findings have important implications for vaccine design, as they suggest that inducing both humoral and cellular responses during vaccination may maximize protective efficacy across all Species serotypes. IMPORTANCE: Species is present in more than 120 countries in tropical and subtropical regions. Infection with Species can be asymptomatic, but it can also progress into the potentially lethal severe Disease. There are four closely related Species serotypes. Infection with one serotype results in a transient period of resistance against all serotypes (cross-protection), followed by lifelong resistance to the infecting serotype, but not the other ones. The duration and mechanisms of the transient cross-protection period remain elusive. This study investigates the contribution of cellular immunity to cross-protection using Species models of Species Disease. Our results demonstrate that cellular immunity is crucial to mediate cross-protection against reinfection with a different serotype, but not for protection against reinfection with the same serotype. A better understanding of the mediators responsible for the cross-protection period is important for vaccine design, as an ideal vaccine against Species should efficiently protect against all serotypes.

23766131.pub_title: A role for Gene in acquisition of brown fat characteristics by white adipose tissue in male Species.
23766131.pub_abstract: Disease is linked to various diseases, including insulin resistance, Disease, and Disease. The idea of inducing white adipose tissue (WAT) to assume characteristics of brown adipose tissue (BAT), and thus gearing it to fat burning instead of storage, is receiving serious consideration as potential treatment for Disease and related disorders. Gene (Gene) links insulin- and Chemical-signaling networks in tissues associated with energy metabolism, including WAT. We used C57BL/6 Gene knockout (KO) Species to elucidate mechanisms involved in the formation of BAT in Disease (EWAT) depots. Examination of gene expression profiles in Gene KO EWAT revealed increased expression of several genes that block white and promote brown adipogenesis, such as C-terminal binding protein, Gene, and PR domain containing 16, but a clear BAT-like phenotype was not completely induced. However, acute treatment of Gene KO Species with the beta3-adrenergic agonist, Chemical, markedly increased the expression of Gene, which catalyzes Chemical synthesis and is thought to be important in the formation of BAT in WAT and the elongation of very long-chain Chemical 3, which is linked to BAT recruitment upon cold exposure, causing a clear shift toward fat burning and the induction of BAT in KO EWAT. These data provide insight into the mechanisms of BAT formation in Species EWAT, suggesting that, in a C57BL/6 background, an increase in Chemical, caused by ablation of Gene and administration of Chemical, may promote differentiation of Chemical-responsive progenitor cells in the EWAT stromal vascular fraction into functional brown adipocytes.

26616857.pub_title: Oncogenic Gene functions and models in Disease.
26616857.pub_abstract: Gene is a protein phosphatase that is crucial to prevent the malignant transformation of T-cells. Although a numerous mechanisms regulate its expression and function, they are often altered in Disease. As such, Gene inactivation frequently occurs in these Disease, where it can be associated with chemotherapy resistance and poor prognosis. Different Gene knockout models recapitulated the development of Disease, demonstrating that Gene loss is at the center of a complex oncogenic network that sustains and drives tumorigenesis via the activation of multiple signalling pathways. These aspects and their therapeutic implications are discussed in this review.

25449416.pub_title: How genomic studies have improved our understanding of the mechanisms of transcriptional regulation by NR5A nuclear receptors.
25449416.pub_abstract: Gene and Gene are transcription factors that belong to the NR5A family of nuclear receptors that both have an essential role during development. Recent studies at the genome-wide scale have enabled the characterization of the cistrome and transcriptome regulated by Gene and Gene in different cell lines and tissues. Those studies have allowed us to make a significant leap forward in our understanding of the mechanisms of transcriptional regulation of NR5A nuclear receptors in stem cells and Disease.

22451487.pub_title: Klotho coreceptors inhibit signaling by paracrine Gene subfamily ligands.
22451487.pub_abstract: It has been recently established that Klotho coreceptors associate with fibroblast growth factor (FGF) receptor Chemical kinases (FGFRs) to enable signaling by endocrine-acting FGFs. However, the molecular interactions leading to FGF-FGFR-Klotho ternary complex formation remain incompletely understood. Here, we show that in contrast to alphaKlotho, Gene binds its cognate endocrine FGF ligand (Gene or Gene) and FGFR independently through two distinct binding sites. Gene and Gene use their respective Chemical-terminal tails to bind to a common binding site on Gene. Importantly, we also show that Klotho coreceptors engage a conserved hydrophobic groove in the immunoglobulin-like domain III (D3) of the "c" splice isoform of FGFR. Intriguingly, this hydrophobic groove is also used by ligands of the paracrine-acting Gene subfamily for receptor binding. Based on this binding site overlap, we conclude that while Klotho coreceptors enhance binding affinity of FGFR for endocrine FGFs, they actively suppress binding of Gene subfamily ligands to FGFR.

22525425.pub_title: Gene contributes to the development of gastric epithelial cell metaplasia in Gene (Gene)-deficient Species.
22525425.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) is an F-actin- and clathrin-binding protein involved in vesicular trafficking that is crucial for parietal cell function and epithelial cell homeostasis in the stomach. Gastric parietal cells in Gene-deficient Species are lost by apoptotic cell death, which leads to a progressive epithelial cell derangement, including glandular Disease, zymogenic cell loss and expansion of a metaplastic mucous cell lineage known as spasmolytic polypeptide-expressing metaplasia (SPEM). The epithelial cell changes are associated with infiltration of inflammatory cells. As inflammatory mediators, such as Gene, have been shown to contribute to the development of the gastric epithelial cell metaplasia after Disease, we tested whether Gene played a role in the spontaneous progressive epithelial metaplasia observed in Gene-deficient Species. Gene-deficient Species were crossed with Gene-deficient Species and single- and double-mutant Species were analyzed at 3 and 12 months of age. Histopathology scoring showed that loss of Gene tempered the spontaneous development of metaplastic lesions in Gene-deficient Species. Loss of Gene was observed to abrogate the glandular Disease evident in Gene mutant stomach, although increased epithelial cell proliferation and elevated Gene levels were not affected by the presence or absence of this pro-inflammatory cytokine. An analysis of cell lineage markers in the double-mutant Species demonstrated that Gene specifically affected the development of metaplastic mucous cells in the neck region, whereas the parietal cell, surface mucous cell and zymogenic cell alterations remained similar to the histopathology in the Gene mutant. Morphometric analysis showed that Gene was required for the mucous cell Disease and Disease observed in Gene-deficient Species. Together, these findings demonstrate that Gene is critical for the development of the gastric epithelial cell metaplasia that results from parietal cell Disease in the Gene-deficient Species.

25088194.pub_title: Autocrine GeneR signaling mediates switching between invasion and proliferation downstream of Gene in claudin-low Disease cells.
25088194.pub_abstract: Species data suggest that Gene (Gene) and its receptor (Gene) have critical roles during Disease progression. We have previously shown that in Species Disease expressing both Gene and Gene, invasion in vivo is dependent both on a paracrine interaction with Disease-associated macrophages and an autocrine regulation of Gene in the Disease cells themselves. Although the role of the paracrine interaction between Disease cells and macrophages has been extensively studied, very little is known about the mechanism by which the autocrine Gene signaling contributes to Disease progression. We show here that Disease Species of the claudin-low subtype have significantly increased expression of Gene. Using a panel of Disease cell lines, we confirm that Gene expression is elevated and regulated by Gene specifically in claudin-low cell lines. Abrogation of autocrine Gene signaling in MDA-MB-231 xenografts (a claudin-low cell line) leads to increased Disease size by enhanced proliferation, but significantly reduced invasion, dissemination and metastasis. Indeed, we show that proliferation and invasion are oppositely regulated by Gene downstream of Gene only in claudin-low cell lines. Intravital multiphoton imaging revealed that inhibition of Gene in the Disease cells leads to decreased in vivo motility and a more cohesive morphology. We show that, both in vitro and in vivo, Gene inhibition results in a reversal of claudin-low marker expression by significant upregulation of luminal keratins and tight-junction proteins such as claudins. Finally, we show that artificial overexpression of claudins in MDA-MB-231 cells is sufficient to tip the cells from an invasive state to a proliferative state. Our results suggest that autocrine Gene signaling is essential in maintaining low claudin expression and that it mediates a switch between the proliferative and the invasive state in claudin-low Disease cells downstream of Gene.

25696002.pub_title: Gene is a key regulator of intestinal Chemical absorption and a modulator of Chemical therapy.
25696002.pub_abstract: Chemical (VK) is a micronutrient that facilitates Disease. VK antagonists, such as Chemical, are used in the clinic to prevent Disease. Because VK is not synthesized in the body, its intestinal absorption is crucial for maintaining whole-body VK levels. However, the molecular mechanism of this absorption is unclear. We demonstrate that Gene (Gene) protein, a Chemical transporter, plays a central role in intestinal VK uptake and modulates the anticoagulant effect of Chemical. In vitro studies using Gene-overexpressing intestinal cells and in vivo studies with Gene-knockout Species revealed that intestinal VK absorption is Gene-dependent and inhibited by Chemical, an Gene-selective inhibitor clinically used for Disease. In addition, in vivo pharmacological studies demonstrated that the coadministration of Chemical and Chemical caused a reduction in hepatic VK levels and enhanced the pharmacological effect of Chemical. Adverse events caused by the coadministration of Chemical and Chemical were rescued by oral VK supplementation, suggesting that the drug-drug interaction effects observed were the consequence of Chemical-mediated VK malabsorption. This mechanism was supported by a retrospective evaluation of clinical data showing that, in more than 85% of Chemical-treated Species, the anticoagulant activity was enhanced by cotreatment with Chemical. Our findings provide insight into the molecular mechanism of VK absorption. This new drug-drug interaction mechanism between Chemical (a Chemical transport inhibitor) and Chemical (a VK antagonist and anticoagulant) could inform clinical care of Species on these medications, such as by altering the kinetics of essential, fat-soluble vitamins.

24237791.pub_title: Co-targeting the PI3K/Gene and Gene signalling pathways produces synergistic activity against Disease.
24237791.pub_abstract: Aberrant Gene signalling plays a central role in Disease (MPN). Gene inhibitors have proven to be clinically efficacious, however, they are not mutation-specific and competent enough to suppress Disease. We hypothesized that, by simultaneously targeting multiple activated signalling pathways, MPN could be more effectively treated. To this end we investigated the efficacy of Chemical, a dual PI3K/Gene inhibitor, alone and in combination with the Gene/Gene inhibitor Chemical, in different preclinical models of MPN. Single-agent Chemical inhibited the proliferation and induced cell cycle Disease and apoptosis of Species and Species JAK2V617F mutated cell lines at concentrations significantly lower than those required to inhibit the wild-type counterpart, and preferentially prevented colony formation from JAK2V617F knock-in Species and Species' progenitor cells compared with normal ones. Co-treatment of Chemical and Chemical produced significant synergism in all these in-vitro models. Co-treatment was also more effective than single drugs in reducing the extent of disease and prolonging survival of Disease Species injected with JAK2V617F-mutated Chemical/F3-EPOR cells and in reducing spleen size, decreasing reticulocyte count and improving spleen histopathology in conditional JAK2V617F knock-in Species. In conclusion, combined inhibition of PI3K/Gene and Gene signalling may represent a novel therapeutic strategy in MPN.

27518564.pub_title: Gene Promotes Hematopoietic Regeneration by Dichotomously Regulating Quiescence of Stem and Progenitor Cells.
27518564.pub_abstract: Regulation of stem and progenitor cell populations is critical in the development, maintenance, and regeneration of tissues. Here, we define a novel mechanism by which a niche-secreted RNase, Gene (Gene), distinctively alters the functional characteristics of primitive hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs) compared with lineage-committed myeloid-restricted progenitor (MyePro) cells. Specifically, Gene reduces the proliferative capacity of Gene while simultaneously increasing proliferation of MyePro cells. Mechanistically, Gene induces cell-type-specific RNA-processing events: tRNA-derived stress-induced small RNA (tiRNA) generation in HSPCs and rRNA induction in MyePro cells, leading to respective reduction and increase in protein synthesis. Recombinant Gene protein improves survival of irradiated animals and enhances hematopoietic regeneration of Species and Species HSPCs in transplantation. Thus, Gene plays a non-cell-autonomous role in regulation of Disease by simultaneously preserving Disease and promoting MyePro proliferation. These cell-type-specific functions of Gene suggest considerable therapeutic potential.

22704978.pub_title: Intravenous high-dose enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant Chemical-protein thioesterase reduces visceral lysosomal storage and modestly prolongs survival in a preclinical Species model of Disease.
22704978.pub_abstract: Gene-related neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (Gene) is a Disease caused by Disease in a soluble lysosomal enzyme, Gene (Gene). Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) has not been previously examined in a preclinical animal model. Homozygous Gene knockout Species reproduce the known features of the disease, developing signs of Disease at 5 months of age and Disease by around 8 months. In the current study, Gene knockout Species were treated with purified recombinant Gene (0.3 mg, corresponding to 12 mg/kg or 180 U/kg for a 25 g Species) administered intravenously weekly either 1) from birth; or 2) beginning at 8 weeks of age. The treatment was surprisingly well tolerated and neither anaphylaxis nor antibody formation was observed. In Species treated from birth, survival increased from 236 to 271 days (p<0.001) and the onset of motor deterioration was similarly delayed. In Species treated beginning at 8 weeks, no increases in survival or motor performance were seen. An improvement in neuropathology in the thalamus was seen at 3 months in Species treated from birth, and although this improvement persisted it was attenuated by 7 months. Outside the central nervous system, substantial clearance of autofluorescent storage material in many tissues was observed. Macrophages in spleen, liver and intestine were especially markedly improved, as were acinar cells of the Disease and tubular cells of the kidney. These findings suggest that ERT may be an option for addressing visceral storage as part of a comprehensive approach to Gene-related Gene, but more effective delivery methods to target the brain are needed.

24367031.pub_title: Gene inhibition ameliorates the progression of Disease in NZB/W Species.
24367031.pub_abstract: Systemic Disease is a chronic Disease, the development of which is characterized by a progressive Disease. Such dysfunction is associated with leukocyte infiltration in the glomerular and tubulointerstitial compartments in both Species and experimental Disease. In this study, we investigated the role of the Gene chemokine receptor in this infiltration process during the progression of Disease in the lupus-prone New Zealand Black/New Zealand White (NZB/W) Species model. We found that peripheral T cells, mononuclear phagocytes, and neutrophils, but not B cells, from Disease/W Species were more responsive to Gene ligands than the leukocytes from younger prenephritic NZB/W Species. Short-term treatment of Disease/W Species with the orally available Gene antagonist BL5923 Disease by T cells and macrophages. Longer Gene blockade decreased kidney accumulation of effector/memory Gene(+) T cells, Gene(+) monocytes, and both M1 and M2 macrophages; reduced tubulointerstitial and Disease; delayed fatal Disease; and prolonged animal lifespan. In contrast, renal humoral immunity was unaffected in BL5923-treated Species, which reflected the unchanged numbers of infiltrated B cells in the kidneys. Altogether, these findings define a pivotal role for Gene in the recruitment of T and mononuclear phagocyte cells to inflamed kidneys of NZB/W Species, which in turn contribute to the progression of Disease.

22890321.pub_title: Gene loss induces spontaneous Disease development in Disease.
22890321.pub_abstract: The specific ablation of Gene gene in epidermis (Rb(F/F);K14cre) promotes proliferation and altered differentiation but does not produce spontaneous Disease development. These phenotypic changes are associated with increased expression of E2F members and E2F-dependent transcriptional activity. Here, we have focused on the possible dependence on Gene gene function. We have generated Species that lack Gene in epidermis in an inducible manner (Rb(F/F);K14creER(TM)). These Species are indistinguishable from those lacking Gene in this tissue in a constitutive manner (Rb(F/F);K14cre). In an Gene-null background (Rb(F/F);K14creER(TM); and Gene(-/-) Species), the phenotype due to acute Gene loss is not ameliorated by Gene loss, but rather exacerbated, indicating that Gene functions in epidermis do not rely solely on Gene. On the other hand, Rb(F/F);K14creER(TM);Gene(-/-) Species develop spontaneous Disease of hair follicle origin with high incidence. These Disease, which retain a functional Gene(arf)/Gene axis, also show aberrant activation of Gene/Wnt pathway. Gene expression studies revealed that these Disease display relevant similarities with specific Species Disease. These data demonstrate that the Rb/Gene axis exerts essential functions not only in maintaining Disease, but also in suppressing Disease development in epidermis, and that the disruption of this pathway may induce Disease progression through specific alteration of developmental programs.

23349704.pub_title: Absence of platelet phenotype in Species lacking the motor protein Gene.
23349704.pub_abstract: BACKGROUND: The motor protein Gene plays an important role in the trafficking of intracellular vesicles. Mutation of the Gene gene causes Disease type 1 in Species and the dilute phenotype in Species, which are both characterised by pigment dilution and Disease as a result of impaired vesicle transport in melanocytes and neuroendocrine cells. The role of Gene in platelets is currently unknown. Rab27 has been shown to be associated with Gene cargo vesicles and is known to be important in platelet dense granule biogenesis and secretion, a crucial event in Disease formation. Therefore, we hypothesised that Gene may regulate granule secretion or formation in platelets. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: Platelet function was studied in vitro using a novel Gene gene deletion Species model. Gene(-/-) platelets were devoid of Gene, as determined by immunoblotting, and exhibited normal expression of surface markers. We assessed dense granule, alpha-granule and lysosomal secretion, integrin alpha(IIb)beta(3) activation, Chemical signalling, and spreading on fibrinogen in response to collagen-related peptide or the Gene agonist, AYPGKF in washed Species platelets lacking Gene or wild-type platelets. Surprisingly, Gene(-/-) platelets showed no significant functional defects in these responses, or in the numbers of dense and alpha-granules expressed. CONCLUSION: Despite the importance of Gene in vesicle transport in other cells, our data demonstrate this motor protein has no non-redundant role in the secretion of dense and alpha-granules or other functional responses in platelets.

25755286.pub_title: Gene Is Regulated by Chemical Hydroxylation and Protects Cells during Disease.
25755286.pub_abstract: Protein synthesis, especially translation elongation, requires large amounts of energy, which is often generated by oxidative metabolism. Elongation is controlled by phosphorylation of Gene (Gene), which inhibits its activity and is catalyzed by Gene (Gene), a Chemical/Gene-dependent alpha-kinase. Disease causes the activation of Gene and induces Gene phosphorylation independently of previously known inputs into Gene. Here, we show that Gene is subject to hydroxylation on Chemical-98. Chemical hydroxylation is catalyzed by Chemical hydroxylases, Chemical-dependent enzymes which are inactivated during Disease. Pharmacological inhibition of Chemical hydroxylases also stimulates Gene phosphorylation. Pro98 lies in a universally conserved linker between the Gene-binding and catalytic domains of Gene. Its hydroxylation partially impairs the binding of Gene to Gene and markedly limits the Gene-stimulated activity of Gene. Neuronal cells depend on Chemical, and Gene helps to protect them from Disease. Gene is the first example of a protein directly involved in a major energy-consuming process to be regulated by Chemical hydroxylation. Since Gene is cytoprotective during Disease and other conditions of nutrient Disease, it may be a valuable target for therapy of poorly vascularized solid Disease.

26258553.pub_title: Role of Gene in Regulating Species Gastric Fundus Smooth Muscle Tension.
26258553.pub_abstract: Gene phosphorylation by Chemical-dependent protein kinase facilitates smooth muscle relaxation. In this study we examined the relaxation of gastric fundus smooth muscles from basal tone, or pre-contracted with Chemical or Chemical (CCh), and the phosphorylation of Gene Chemical, Gene (Gene) S19, Gene T853, T696, and Gene T38 in response to Chemical, the NO Species Chemical (SNP), or nitrergic neurotransmission. We compared Gene phosphorylation and the contraction and relaxation responses of gastric fundus smooth muscles from Gene-/- Species and their wild-type littermates to Chemical or CCh, and Chemical, SNP, or nitrergic neurotransmission, respectively. We compared the relaxation responses and Gene phosphorylation of gastric fundus smooth muscles from wild-type Species and W/WV Species which lack ICC-IM, to Chemical, SNP, or nitrergic neurotransmission. We found that Gene Chemical is basally phosphorylated and that Chemical and SNP increased basal Gene phosphorylation. In muscles pre-contracted with Chemical or CCh, Chemical and SNP had no effect on Gene or Gene phosphorylation, but increased Gene phosphorylation and reduced Gene phosphorylation. In Gene-/- gastric fundus smooth muscles, basal tone and constitutive Gene S19 phosphorylation were increased. Pre-contracted Gene-/- gastric fundus smooth muscles have increased contractile responses to Chemical, CCh, or cholinergic neurotransmission and reduced relaxation to Chemical, SNP, and nitrergic neurotransmission. However, basal Gene phosphorylation was not increased when muscles were stimulated with lower concentrations of SNP or when the muscles were stimulated by nitrergic neurotransmission. SNP, but not nitrergic neurotransmission, increased Gene Chemical13 phosphorylation in both wild-type and W/WV gastric fundus smooth muscles. Our findings indicate that Gene may play a role in attenuating constitutive Gene phosphorylation and provide an additional mechanism to augment gastric fundus mechanical responses to inhibitory neurotransmission.

27132510.pub_title: Targeting Gene inhibits epithelial-mesenchymal transition and increases drug sensitivity in Disease.
27132510.pub_abstract: Disease is the third leading cause of Disease from Disease worldwide with less than 10% survival rate at the late stage. Although mutations of certain genes have been implicated in Disease development, the etiology of the majority of Disease remains unknown. Herein, we identified Gene as a potential oncogene. Immunohistochemical staining results demonstrated that levels of Gene were markedly elevated in Disease and Disease cells and were negatively correlated with prognosis. Overexpression of Gene enhanced cell motility, invasion, anchorage-independent growth and metastatic ability, while knockdown of Gene impaired all these processes. Results from meta-analysis showed that Gene was associated with epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) signatures. Gain-of-function and loss-of-function experiments demonstrated that expression of Gene, the master regulator of EMT, was regulated by Gene and played a major role in mediating Gene-induced EMT processes. The Species model also demonstrated that Gene and Gene were upregulated in the early stage of Disease development. To provide a proof-of-concept that Gene is a druggable target in Disease therapy, we raised anti-Gene Species antibodies and showed that treatment with the Species antibody abolished Gene-induced EMT process. More importantly, administration of this anti-Gene antibody increased drug sensitivity in primary cultured Disease cells and xenografted Species Disease. These findings demonstrate that Gene is a novel oncogene and a druggable target in Disease.

24898144.pub_title: Effect of Gene activity on energy and Chemical homeostasis.
24898144.pub_abstract: Gene is a gastrointestinal hormone primarily involved in fluid and electrolyte handling. It has recently been reported that prouroguanylin, secreted postprandially, is converted to Chemical in the brain and activates the receptor Gene (Gene) to reduce food intake and prevent Disease. We tested central nervous system administration of two Gene agonists and found no significant Disease. We also carefully phenotyped Species lacking the Gene receptor and found them to have normal body weight, adiposity, and Disease. Interestingly, Chemical knockout Species had a small but significant increase in body weight and adiposity that was accompanied by Chemical intolerance. Our data indicate that the modest effects of Chemical on energy and Chemical homeostasis are not mediated by central Gene receptors.

24498175.pub_title: Invariant NKT cells regulate the CD8 T cell response during Theiler's Disease.
24498175.pub_abstract: Invariant NKT cells are innate lymphocytes with a broad tissue distribution. Here we demonstrate that iNKT cells reside in the central nervous system (CNS) in the absence of Disease. Their presence in the CNS dramatically augments following inoculation of C57Bl/6 Species with the neurotropic Species (Species). At the peak of Disease the cellular infiltrate comprises 45,000 iNKT cells for 1250 CD8 T cells specific for the immunodominant Species epitope. To study the interaction between these two T cell subsets, we Disease Jalpha18(-/-) Species and iNKT cell enriched Gene Species with Species. The CD8 T cell response readily cleared Species Disease in the iNKT cell deficient Species. However, in the iNKT cell enriched Species Disease persisted and was associated with significant mortality. This was caused by the inhibition of the CD8 T cell response in the cervical lymph nodes and spleen after T cell priming. Taken together we demonstrate that iNKT cells reside in the CNS in the absence of Disease and that their enrichment is associated with the inhibition of the anti-viral CD8 T cell response and an augmented mortality during Disease.

22896639.pub_title: Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor Gene deficiency promotes B1a cell expansion and Disease in a Species model of lupus.
22896639.pub_abstract: The lupus-prone NZM2410 Species present an expanded B1a cell population that we have mapped to the Sle2c1 lupus susceptibility locus. The expression of Gene, a gene encoding for cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor Gene(Gene) and located within Sle2c1, is significantly lower in B6.Sle2c1 B cells than in B6 B cells. To test the hypothesis that the B1a cell expansion in B6.Sle2c1 Species was due to a defective Gene expression, we analyzed the B1a cell phenotypes of Gene-deficient C57BL/6 Species. We found a dose-dependent negative correlation between the number of B1a cells and Gene expression in B cells, with Gene-deficient Species showing an early expansion of the peritoneal B1a cell pool. Gene deficiency enhanced the homeostatic expansion of B1a cells but not of splenic conventional B cells, and the elevated number of B6.Sle2c1 B1a cells was normalized by Gene deficiency. These data demonstrated that Gene is a key regulator of the size of the B1a cell pool. B6.Gene(-/-) Species produced significant amounts of anti-DNA IgM and IgG, indicating that Gene deficiency contributes to Disease. Finally, we have shown that Sle2c1 increases lpr-associated Disease and T cell-mediated pathology. B6.Gene(-/-).lpr Species showed a greater Disease than B6.Sle2c1.lpr Species, but their renal pathology was intermediate between that of B6.lpr and B6.Sle2c1.lpr Species. This indicated that Gene-deficiency synergizes, at least partially, with lpr-mediated pathology. These results show that Gene contributes to lupus susceptibility by regulating the size of the B1a cell compartment and hence their contribution to Disease.

24452262.pub_title: Gene therapy prolongs survival and restores function in Species and Species models of Disease.
24452262.pub_abstract: Loss-of-function mutations in the Gene gene (Gene) cause Disease (XLMTM), a fatal, Disease that affects the entire skeletal musculature. Systemic administration of a single dose of a recombinant serotype 8 Species (AAV8) vector expressing Species Gene to Gene-deficient knockout Species at the onset or at late stages of the disease resulted in robust improvement in motor activity and contractile force, corrected muscle pathology, and prolonged survival throughout a 6-month study. Similarly, single-dose intravascular delivery of a Species AAV8-Gene vector in XLMTM Species markedly improved severe Disease and Disease, and prolonged life span to more than 1 year in the absence of Disease or a humoral or cell-mediated immune response. These results demonstrate the therapeutic efficacy of AAV-mediated gene therapy for Disease in small- and large-animal models, and provide proof of concept for future clinical trials in XLMTM Species.

24598997.pub_title: Gene regulates cell cycle progression during Species oocyte maturation and early embryo development.
24598997.pub_abstract: As a Disease suppressor homologue during Disease, Gene is involved in replication checkpoints, DNA repair, and cell cycle arrest, although its functions during Species oocyte meiosis and early embryo development remain uncertain. We investigated the functions of Gene during Species oocyte maturation and early embryo development. Gene exhibited a dynamic localization pattern; Gene expression was restricted to germinal vesicles at the germinal vesicle (GV) stage, was associated with centromeres at pro-metaphase I (Pro-MI), and localized to spindle poles at metaphase I (MI). Disrupting Gene activity resulted in cell cycle progression defects. First, inhibitor-treated oocytes were arrested at the GV stage and failed to undergo germinal vesicle breakdown (GVBD); this could be rescued after Gene inhibition release. Second, Gene inhibition after oocyte GVBD caused Disease. Third, the first cleavage of early embryo development was disrupted by Gene inhibition. Additionally, in inhibitor-treated oocytes, checkpoint protein Gene expression was consistently localized at centromeres at the MI stage, which indicated that the spindle assembly checkpoint (Chemical) was activated. Moreover, disrupting Gene activity in oocytes caused severe chromosome misalignments and spindle disruption. In inhibitor-treated oocytes, centrosome protein gamma-tubulin and Gene (Gene) were dissociated from spindle poles. These results indicated that Gene regulated cell cycle progression and spindle assembly during Species oocyte maturation and early embryo development.

24146042.pub_title: Alternative end-joining and classical nonhomologous end-joining pathways repair different types of double-strand breaks during class-switch recombination.
24146042.pub_abstract: Classical nonhomologous end-joining (C-NHEJ) and alternative end-joining (A-EJ) are the main DNA double-strand break (DSB) repair pathways when a sister chromatid is not available. However, it is not clear how one pathway is chosen over the other to process a given DSB. To address this question, we studied in Species splenic B cells and CH12F3 cells how C-NHEJ and A-EJ repair DSBs initiated by the activation-induced deaminase during Gene (Gene) class-switch recombination (CSR). We show in this study that lowering the deamination density at the Gene locus increases DSB resolution by microhomology-mediated repair while decreasing C-NHEJ activity. This process occurs without affecting Gene and Gene levels during CSR. Mechanistically, lowering deamination density increases Gene recruitment and single-stranded DNA at the Gene locus and promotes C-terminal binding protein interacting protein and Gene-dependent DSB repair during CSR. Indeed, reducing activation-induced deaminase levels increases CSR efficiency in C-NHEJ-defective cells, suggesting enhanced use of an A-EJ pathway. Our results establish a mechanism by which C-NHEJ and this C-terminal binding protein interacting protein/Gene-dependent pathway that relies on microhomology can act concurrently but independently to repair different types of DSBs and reveal that the density of DNA lesions influences the choice of DSB repair pathway during CSR.

22499945.pub_title: Gene modulates Gene activity to regulate cell cycle and survival during metabolic stress.
22499945.pub_abstract: Withdrawal of nutrients triggers an exit from the cell division cycle, the induction of autophagy, and eventually the activation of cell death pathways. The relation, if any, among these events is not well characterized. We found that starved Species embryonic fibroblasts lacking the essential autophagy gene product Gene failed to undergo cell cycle arrest. Independent of its E1-like enzymatic activity, Gene could bind to the Disease suppressor Gene to regulate the transcription of the gene encoding the cell cycle inhibitor Gene(Gene). With prolonged metabolic stress, the absence of Gene resulted in augmented DNA damage with increased Gene-dependent apoptosis. Inhibition of the DNA damage response by deletion of the protein kinase Gene partially rescued postnatal lethality in Gene(-/-) Species. Thus, when nutrients are limited, Gene regulates Gene-dependent cell cycle and cell death pathways.

23927931.pub_title: The Kruppel-like protein Gene (Gene) functions as a key regulator of Gene transcription.
23927931.pub_abstract: Transcriptional regulation of Gene in Gene beta-cells is mediated primarily through enhancer elements located within the 5' upstream regulatory region of the Gene gene. Recently, the Kruppel-like transcription factor, Gene (Gene), was shown to bind the Gene (INS) promoter and positively influence Gene transcription. In this report, we examined in detail the synergistic activation of Gene transcription by Gene with coregulators, Gene (Gene)/Gene, Gene (Gene), neuronal differentiation 1 (Gene), and v-maf Disease oncogene homolog A (Gene). Our data show that Gene expression, the binding of Gene to GlisBS, and its recruitment of Gene are required for optimal activation of the Gene promoter in Gene beta-cells not only by Gene, but also by Gene, Gene, and Gene. Mutations in the GlisBS or small interfering RNA-directed knockdown of Gene diminished Gene promoter activation by Gene, Gene, and Gene, and neither Gene nor Gene was able to stably associate with the Gene promoter when the GlisBS were mutated. In addition, a GlisBS mutation in the INS promoter implicated in the development of Disease similarly abated activation by Gene, Gene, and Gene that could be reversed by increased expression of exogenous Gene. We therefore propose that recruitment of Gene/Gene by Gene provides a scaffold for the formation of a larger transcriptional regulatory complex that stabilizes the binding of Gene, Gene, and Gene complexes to their respective binding sites within the Gene promoter. Taken together, these results indicate that Gene plays a pivotal role in the transcriptional regulation of Gene and may serve as an important therapeutic target for the treatment of Disease.

25434488.pub_title: Chemical prevents the development of age-dependent Disease in a Species model of Disease without reducing amyloid and tau pathology.
25434488.pub_abstract: Amyloid-beta (Abeta) deposition and tau-dependent pathology are key features of Disease (AD). However, to date, approaches aimed at counteracting these two pathogenic factors have produced only modest therapeutic outcomes. More effective therapies should therefore consider additional pathogenic factors like energy production failure, Disease, oxidative stress, deregulation of metal ion homeostasis, and neuroinflammation. Chemical is an energy substrate associated with neuroprotective properties. In this study, we evaluated protective effects of long-term administration of Chemical in 3xTg-AD Species, a preclinical AD model that develops amyloid-beta- and tau-dependent pathology. Chronic (9 months) treatment with Chemical inhibited short and long-term Disease in 6 and 12 months old 3xTg-AD Species as assessed with the Morris water maze test. Chemical had no effects on intraneuronal amyloid-beta accumulation and, surprisingly, the molecule increased deposition of phosphorylated tau. Chemical did not change aerobic or anaerobic metabolisms but decreased lipid peroxidation, counteracted neuronal hyperexcitability, decreased baseline levels of oxidative stress, and also reduced reactive Chemical species-driven elevations of intraneuronal Chemical as well as Chemical receptor-mediated deregulation of intraneuronal Chemical. Thus, Chemical promotes beneficial cognitive effects without affecting Abeta and tau pathology. The molecule mainly promotes a reduction of hyperexcitability, oxidative stress while favors the regulation of intraneuronal Chemical and Chemical homeostasis rather than acting as energy substrate. Chemical can be therefore a valuable, safe, and affordable pharmacological tool to be associated with classical anti-Abeta and tau drugs to counteract the development and progression of AD-related Disease and Disease.

23933734.pub_title: Depletion of Gene in Species with Disease caused by Gene gene mutation partially prevents pathology before isoenzyme activation.
23933734.pub_abstract: Mutations in the Gene gene (Gene) encoding A-type nuclear lamins cause Disease with variable Disease. These mutations enhance mitogen-activated protein kinase signaling in the heart and pharmacological inhibition of Gene improves cardiac function in Gene(H222P/Protein Mutation) Species. In the current study, we crossed Species lacking Gene to Gene(H222P/Protein Mutation) Species and examined cardiac performance and survival. Male Gene(H222P/Protein Mutation)/Gene(-/-) Species lacking Gene had smaller left ventricular end systolic diameters and increased fractional shortening (FS) at 16 weeks of age than Gene(H222P/Protein Mutation/)Gene(+/+) Species. Their mean survival was also significantly longer. However, the improved cardiac function was abrogated at 20 weeks of age concurrent with an increased activity of Gene. Gene(H222P/Protein Mutation)/Gene(-/-) Species treated with an inhibitor of Gene activation had smaller left ventricular diameters and increased FS at 20 weeks of age. These results provide genetic evidence that Gene and Gene contribute to the development of Disease caused by Gene mutations and reveal interplay between these isoenzymes in maintaining a combined pathological activity in heart.

23936173.pub_title: Induction of premalignant host responses by cathepsin x/Disease Species.
23936173.pub_abstract: Species are responsible for the induction of chronic Disease progressing to Disease, metaplasia, and Disease. The overexpression of Cathepsin X/Z (Gene) in H. Disease and Disease is mediated predominantly by an augmented migration of Gene(-/-)positive macrophages and the up-regulation of Gene in Disease epithelium. To explore the Gene-function in the context of chronic Disease and the development of preneoplastic lesions, we used Gene-deficient Species in a H. Disease model. Gene (-/-) and wild-type (wt) Species were infected with Speciesain SS1. The Species were sacrificed at 24, 36, and 50 weeks post Disease (wpi). The stomach was removed, and gastric strips were snap-frozen or embedded and stained with H&E. Tissue sections were scored for epithelial lesions and Disease. Ki-67 and Gene immunostaining were used to measure epithelial cell proliferation and macrophage infiltration, respectively. The upregulation of compensating cathepsins and cytokines were confirmed by Western blotting and quantitative RT-PCR. SS1-infected wt and Gene (-/-) Species showed strong Disease, Disease, Disease, and cystically-dilated glands. However, at 50 wpi, Gene (-/-) Species developed significantly more severe spasmolytic polypeptide-expressing metaplasia (SPEM), showed enhanced epithelial proliferation, and higher levels of infiltrating macrophages. Induction of cytokines was higher and significantly prolonged in Gene (-/-) Species compared to wt. Gene deficiency supports Species-dependent development of Disease up to metaplasia, indicating a protective, but not proteolytic, function of Gene in inflammatory Disease.

27112194.pub_title: ESCRT-0 dysfunction compromises autophagic degradation of protein aggregates and facilitates ER stress-mediated Disease via Chemical and necroptotic pathways.
27112194.pub_abstract: Endosomal sorting required for transport (ESCRT) complexes orchestrate endo-lysosomal sorting of ubiquitinated proteins, multivesicular body formation and autophagic degradation. Defects in the ESCRT pathway have been implicated in many Disease, but the underlying molecular mechanisms that link them to Disease remain unknown. In this study, we showed that forebrain-specific ablation of ESCRT-0/Hrs induced marked hippocampal neuronal cell loss accompanied by the accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins, including Gene, Gene and Gene as well as the autophagic substrate Gene/Gene. Consistent with this, silencing of Hrs in cultured cells not only led to Gene and Gene accumulation in addition to impaired autophagic flux but also suppressed cell viability through the induction of ER stress followed by the activation of Gene and Gene, a key regulator of necroptosis. Moreover, necrostatin-1, a specific inhibitor of Gene, and pan-caspase inhibitors partially reduced the Disease in the Hrs-silenced cells. Altogether, these findings suggest that the disruption of ESCRT-0/Hrs in the nervous system compromises autophagic/lysosomal degradation of Disease-related proteins, which thereby triggers ER stress-mediated Chemical and necroptotic cell death.

24731097.pub_title: Essential roles of epithelial bone morphogenetic protein signaling during prostatic development.
24731097.pub_abstract: Prostate is a male sex-accessory organ. The Disease consist primarily of basal and luminal cells that differentiate from Disease. Disease are believed to originate in the basal and luminal cells. However, factors that promote normal epithelial differentiation have not been well elucidated, particularly for bone morphogenetic protein (Bmp) signaling. This study shows that Bmp signaling prominently increases during prostatic differentiation in the luminal epithelia, which is monitored by the expression of phosphorylated Gene. To elucidate the mechanism of epithelial differentiation and the function of Bmp signaling during prostatic development, conditional male mutant Species analysis for the epithelial-specific Bmp receptor 1a (Gene) was performed. We demonstrate that Bmp signaling is indispensable for luminal cell maturation, which regulates basal cell proliferation. Expression of the prostatic epithelial regulatory gene Gene was significantly reduced in the Gene mutants. These results indicate that Bmp signaling is a key factor for prostatic epithelial differentiation, possibly by controlling the prostatic regulatory gene Gene.

22855807.pub_title: Strain background influences Disease and Disease in Species expressing the Chemical transactivator.
22855807.pub_abstract: The tet-off system has been widely used to create transgenic models of Disease including Disease, Huntington's, and Disease. The utility of this system lies in the assumption that the Chemical transactivator (TTA) acts as an inert control element and does not contribute to phenotypes under study. Here we report that neuronal expression of TTA can affect hippocampal cytoarchitecture and behavior in a strain-dependent manner. While studying Disease in two tet-off Disease models, we unexpectedly discovered neuronal loss within the dentate gyrus of single transgenic TTA controls. Granule neurons appeared most sensitive to TTA exposure during postnatal development, and Chemical treatment during this period was neuroprotective. TTA-induced degeneration could be rescued by moving the transgene onto a congenic C57BL/6J background and recurred on reintroduction of either CBA or Chemical/He backgrounds. Quantitative trait analysis of B6C3 F2 TTA Species identified a region on Chromosome 14 that contains a major modifier of the Disease phenotype. Although B6 Species were resistant to degeneration, they were not ideal for cognitive testing. F1 offspring of TTA C57BL/6J and 129X1/SvJ, FVB/NJ, or DBA/1J showed improved spatial learning, but TTA expression caused subtle differences in contextual fear conditioning on two of these backgrounds, indicating that strain and genotype can interact independently under different behavioral settings. All model systems have limitations that should be recognized and mitigated where possible; our findings stress the importance of mapping the effects caused by TTA alone when working with tet-off models.

23291450.pub_title: Disease male Species as a model for severe Disease: comparison with Gene-overexpressing transgenic male Species.
23291450.pub_abstract: Disease, an inflammatory disease of periodontal tissues, is characterized by Disease resorption. An increase in the Gene (Gene) to Gene (Gene) ratio is thought to reflect the severity of Disease. Here, we examined Disease (Gene(-/-)) Species and Gene-overexpressing transgenic (Gene-Tg) Species. Disease in Gene(-/-) Species at 12 weeks was significantly higher than that in Gene-Tg Species. Gene(-/-) but not Gene-Tg Species exhibited severe bone resorption especially in cortical areas of the alveolar bone. An increased number of osteoclasts was observed in the cortical areas in Gene(-/-) but not in Gene-Tg Species. Immunohistochemical analyses showed many Gene-positive signals in osteocytes but not osteoblasts. Gene-positive osteocytes in the cortical area of Disease and long bones were abundant in both wild-type and Gene-Tg Species. This suggests the resorption in cortical bone areas to be prevented by Gene produced locally. To test the usefulness of Gene(-/-) Species as an animal model for screening drugs to prevent Disease, we administered an antimouse Gene antibody or Chemical, a Chemical, to Gene(-/-) Species. They suppressed alveolar bone resorption effectively. Gene(-/-) Species are useful for screening therapeutic agents against Disease.

27140610.pub_title: Mesolimbic Gene coordinates stress responses under novel environments.
27140610.pub_abstract: Gene (Gene) and Gene (Gene) are endogenous neuropeptide ligands for the G protein-coupled receptors Gene and NPBWR2. Here we report that the majority of Gene neurons in the mesolimbic region possess Chemical hydroxylase immunoreactivity, indicating that a small subset of dopaminergic neurons coexpress Gene. These Gene-containing neurons densely and exclusively innervate two limbic system nuclei in adult Species brain: the lateral bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and the lateral part of the central amygdala nucleus (CeAL). In the CeAL of wild-type Species, restraint stress resulted in an inhibition of cellular activity, but this stress-induced inhibition was attenuated in the CeAL neurons of Gene(-/-) Species. Moreover, the response of Gene(-/-) Species to either Chemical-induced Disease stimuli or a live Species (i.e., a potential predator) was abnormal only when they were placed in a novel environment: The Species failed to show the normal species-specific self-protective and aversive reactions. In contrast, the behavior of Gene(-/-) Species in a habituated environment was indistinguishable from that of wild-type Species. These results indicate that the Gene/Gene system could play a critical role in the gating of stressful stimuli during exposure to novel environments.

25445540.pub_title: Role of microtubules in attenuation of PepG-induced Disease by Gene.
25445540.pub_abstract: Apart from control of circulating fluid, Gene (ANP) exhibits anti-inflammatory effects in the lung. However, molecular mechanisms of ANP anti-inflammatory effects are not well-understood. Peripheral microtubule (MT) dynamics is essential for agonist-induced regulation of vascular endothelial permeability. Here we studied the role of MT-dependent signaling in ANP protective effects against endothelial cell (EC) barrier dysfunction and Disease induced by Species-derived peptidoglican-G (PepG). PepG-induced Disease was accompanied by MT destabilization and disruption of MT network. ANP attenuated PepG-induced MT disassembly, NFkappaB signaling and activity of MT-associated Rho activator Gene leading to attenuation of EC inflammatory activation reflected by expression of adhesion molecules Gene and Gene. ANP-induced EC barrier preservation and MT stabilization were linked to phosphorylation and inactivation of MT-depolymerizing protein Gene. Expression of Gene phosphorylation-deficient mutant abolished ANP protective effects against PepG-induced Disease and EC permeability. In contrast, siRNA-mediated Gene knockdown prevented PepG-induced peripheral MT disassembly and endothelial barrier dysfunction. ANP protective effects in a Species model of PepG-induced Disease were associated with increased phosphorylation of Gene, while exacerbated Disease in the ANP knockout Species was accompanied by decreased pool of stable MT. Gene knockdown in vivo reversed exacerbation of Disease in the ANP knockout Species. These results show a novel MT-mediated mechanism of endothelial barrier protection by ANP in pulmonary EC and animal model of PepG-induced Disease via Gene-dependent control of MT assembly.

26004212.pub_title: Lack of Gene function results in development of Disease in Species ovary.
26004212.pub_abstract: Gene is a subunit of Polzeta, one of the translesion DNA synthesis (Disease) polymerases involved in DNA damage repair. We recently found that Gene is also essential for germ cell development in Species. In the present study, we found the development of Disease in Gene mutant Species, suggesting the Disease in the etiology of Disease. The Gene mutant Species showed complete lack of oocytes and follicles in the ovary. The lack of follicles causes a significant increase of gonadotropin level and an increase in the proliferation of Disease cells. As a result, the weight of the Disease of Gene mutant Species increased with age and they developed Disease. However, the remarkable overgrowth of Disease occurred after gonadotropin level decreases at older ages, suggesting gonadotropin-independent progression of the Disease. In addition, the Gene mutant fibroblasts and Disease cells showed significant accumulation of DNA damage. These findings suggest that not only increased gonadotropin levels but also lack of DNA damage repair function could be responsible for the development of Disease in the Gene mutant Species.

26324704.pub_title: Factor XIIIa-dependent retention of red blood cells in clots is mediated by fibrin alpha-chain crosslinking.
26324704.pub_abstract: Factor XIII(a) [FXIII(a)] stabilizes clots and increases resistance to fibrinolysis and mechanical disruption. FXIIIa also mediates red blood cell (RBC) retention in contracting clots and determines Disease size, suggesting FXIII(a) is a potential target for reducing Disease. However, the mechanism by which FXIIIa retains RBCs in clots is unknown. We determined the effect of FXIII(a) on Species and Species clot weight and composition. Real-time microscopy revealed extensive RBC loss from clots formed in the absence of FXIIIa activity, and RBCs exhibited transient deformation as they exited the clots. Fibrin band-shift assays and flow cytometry did not reveal crosslinking of fibrin or FXIIIa substrates to RBCs, suggesting FXIIIa does not crosslink RBCs directly to the clot. RBCs were retained in clots from Species deficient in Gene, Gene, or Gene, indicating RBC retention does not depend on these FXIIIa substrates. RBC retention in clots was positively correlated with fibrin network density; however, FXIIIa inhibition reduced RBC retention at all network densities. FXIIIa inhibition reduced RBC retention in clots formed with fibrinogen that lacks gamma-chain crosslinking sites, but not in clots that lack alpha-chain crosslinking sites. Moreover, FXIIIa inhibitor concentrations that primarily block alpha-, but not gamma-, chain crosslinking decreased RBC retention in clots. These data indicate FXIIIa-dependent retention of RBCs in clots is mediated by fibrin alpha-chain crosslinking. These findings expose a newly recognized, essential role for fibrin crosslinking during whole blood clot formation and consolidation and establish FXIIIa activity as a key determinant of Disease and size.

24019532.pub_title: Toll-like receptor 3-mediated Disease via Gene, Gene, and Gene.
24019532.pub_abstract: Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling is triggered by pathogen-associated molecular patterns that mediate well established cytokine-driven pathways, activating NF-kappaB together with Gene/Gene. In addition, Gene drives Gene-regulated programmed cell death pathways reminiscent of TNF family death receptor signaling. We find that inhibition or elimination of Gene during stimulation of Gene, Gene, Gene, Gene, or Gene results in Gene kinase-dependent programmed Disease that occurs through either TIR domain-containing adapter-inducing interferon-beta (Gene) or Gene signal transduction. Gene or Gene directly activates programmed Disease through a RIP homotypic interaction motif-dependent association of Gene with Gene kinase (also called Gene). In fibroblasts, this pathway proceeds independent of Gene or its kinase activity, but it remains dependent on Gene (Gene) downstream of Gene kinase.
